translated: The establishment of the property of the reason in the subject.

analyzed: yathā śabdaḥ nityaḥ cākṣuṣa tvāt iti
translated: For example, Sound is eternal because it is visible.

analyzed: vyadhikaraṇa asiddhiḥ
translated: The reason is not established with respect to the subject.

analyzed: yathā śabdaḥ nityaḥ ghaṭasya kṛtaka tvāt iti
translated: For example, Sound is non-eternal because a pot is produced.

analyzed: vyāpti asiddhiḥ
translated: The pervasion is not established.

analyzed: yathā yat sat tat kṣaṇikam yathā pradīpaḥ
translated: For example, Whatever exists is momentary, like a lamp.

analyzed: san ca prapañcaḥ iti
translated: And the world is existent.

analyzed: evam viśeṣaṇa asiddhi ādayaḥ api draṣṭavyāḥ
translated: In the same way, the non-establishment of the qualifier and others should be seen.

analyzed: tatra sarvāsām api asiddhīnām dūṣaṇa tve prāpte pa vādam āha āśraya iti
translated: There, when it is obtained that all non-establishments are faults, he states an exception with the non-establishment of the substratum, etc.

analyzed: āśraya vyāśraya asiddhī sādhya siddhiḥ ca dūṣaṇam
translated: The non-establishment of the substratum and the superstratum, and the establishment of what is to be established, are faults.

analyzed: keṣāñcid
translated: For some...

original: āśrayāsiddhirvyadhikaraṇāsiddhiḥ sādhyāsiddhiśca yadyapi keṣāñcinnaiyyāyikādīnāṃ mate dūṣaṇam /
analyzed: āśraya asiddhiḥ vyadhikaraṇa asiddhiḥ sādhya asiddhiḥ ca yadi api keṣāñcid naiyyāyika ādīnām mate dūṣaṇam
translated: Although the non-establishment of the substratum, the non-establishment with a different subject, and the non-establishment of what is to be established are faults according to the opinion of some Naiyāyikas and others,

original: tathāpi tattvato na ca te doṣāḥ /
analyzed: tathā api tattvataḥ na ca te doṣāḥ
translated: nevertheless, in reality, they are not faults.

analyzed: āśraya asiddhiḥ aneka prakārā
translated: The non-establishment of the substratum is of many kinds.

analyzed: asat āśraya tvam abhāva āśraya tvam apratīta āśraya tvam pakṣīkṛta ākāreṇa asattvam siddha sādhaka tvam
translated: It is being based on what is non-existent, being based on what is absent, being based on what is not accepted, not existing in the form that is the subject, proving what is already established,

analyzed: na tvam ca iti
translated: and not being.

analyzed: tatra ādyayoḥ dvayoḥ adoṣa tvam pratijānīte na ca iti
translated: There, he declares that the first two are not faults with not being.

original: na ca te doṣā vyāptau satyāṃ kathañcana // / / //
analyzed: na ca te doṣāḥ vyāptau satyām kathañcana
translated: And those faults are not at all in the case of pervasion.

analyzed: apratīta āśraya tva ādeḥ deṣatvasya siddha tvāt
translated: Because the faults of being based on what is not accepted, etc. are well-established.

analyzed: atas eva uktam anyatra asat āśrayasya ityādi
translated: For this very reason it is said elsewhere: Of what has no basis in reality, etc.

analyzed: na ca atyanta abhāvaḥ iti
translated: And Nor is absolute non-existence.

analyzed: evam uttaratra api jñātavyam
translated: It should be understood in the same way in the following [cases] as well.

analyzed: āśraya asiddhi śabdena dṛṣṭāntasya āśraya hīna tā api saṅgrāhyā
translated: By the word unestablished basis the lack of basis in the example is also included.

analyzed: kutas te na doṣāḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked Why are they not faults?,

original: kiṃ vyāptyādibhaṅgahetutvena doṣatvamuta satyeva vyāptyādau prakārāntareṇa /
analyzed: kim vyāpti ādi bhaṅga hetu tvena doṣa tvam uta sati eva vyāpti ādau prakāra antareṇa
translated: is it because of being the cause of the destruction of pervasion, etc., or is it in some other way, even when pervasion, etc. are true?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so,

analyzed: āśraya asiddhi ādau api vyāpti ādeḥ sattvāt
translated: because pervasion, etc. exist even in the case of unestablished basis, etc.

analyzed: dvitīye tu idam upatiṣṭhate
translated: In the second case, this is presented:

original: vyāptau satyāṃ kathañcana kenāpi prakāreṇa na doṣā iti /
analyzed: vyāptau satyām kathañcana kena api prakāreṇa na doṣāḥ iti
translated: In the case of pervasion, they are not faults at all by any means.

analyzed: vyāpti grahaṇam abādhita viṣaya tva ādi upalakṣaṇam  vastutas vyāptau eva tasya upayogāt na pṛthak uktam
translated: The mention of pervasion is a metaphor for unobstructed object, etc.🔽It is not stated separately because it is useful only in the case of real pervasion.

analyzed: asya eva arthasya prapañca artham uttaraḥ prabandhaḥ
translated: The subsequent text is for the purpose of elaborating on this very meaning.

original: tatra bhagavadabhāvasyāpi prāmāṇikatvaṃ sadharmakatvaṃ ca prāgeva sādhitam /
analyzed: tatra bhagavat abhāvasya api prāmāṇika tvam sadharmaka tvam ca prāk eva sādhitam
translated: There, the authoritativeness and having properties of even the non-existence of the Lord have been established earlier.

original: asadāśrayasya tu kuto duṣṭatvamiti vācyam /🔽kinnaraviṣāṇamasti viṣāṇatvādityāderapi sādhanatvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: asat āśrayasya tu kutas duṣṭa tvam iti vācyam  kinnara viṣāṇam asti viṣāṇa tvāt ityādeḥ api sādhanatva prasaṅgāt
translated: But it should be said how there can be falsity in what has no basis.🔽Because it would follow that even the argument The horn of a man exists, because it is a horn would be a proof.

analyzed: uta asataḥ nirdharmaka tvena sādhya dharma āśraya tva anupapattyā bādhita viṣaya tvena
translated: Or, because the nonexistent, being devoid of properties, cannot be the substratum of the property to be proved, it is contradicted by having an invalid subject.

analyzed: atha sādhana dharma āśraya tva anupapattyā svarūpa asiddha tvena
translated: Or, because it cannot be the substratum of the property to be proved, it is unestablished in itself.

analyzed: yat vāsatas sakala vyavahāra abhājana tvena
translated: Or, because the nonexistent is not a receptacle for any transaction.

analyzed: yadi vā aprāmāṇikasya pramāṇa aṅga tā sambhavena
translated: Or, because what is not established by a means of knowledge cannot be a part of a means of knowledge.

analyzed: athavā asat āśrayasya vyāpti anupapattyā iti
translated: Or, because the nonexistent cannot be pervaded.

analyzed: ādyam nirākaroti doṣaḥ iti
translated: He rejects the first by saying The fault

analyzed: doṣaḥ vyāhatiḥ evā asti nṛśṛṅga astitva sādhane
translated: There is only the fault of contradiction in proving the existence of a man's horn.

analyzed: vyāhatiḥ pramāṇa virodhaḥ
translated: Contradiction means being contradicted by a means of knowledge.

original: śṛṅgaśabdo hi mahataḥ śissaṃyuktasya rūpavato 'vayavaviśeṣasya vācako 'bhipretaḥ syāt /
analyzed: śṛṅga śabdaḥ hi mahataḥ śis saṃyuktasya rūpavataḥ vayava viśeṣasya vācakaḥ bhipretaḥ syāt
translated: The word horn is intended to denote either a large, hairy, fleshy part of the body,

original: atīndriyasya vā kasyacit /🔽ādye pratyakṣeṇa tasya nāstitāvadhāraṇāt /
analyzed: atīndriyasya vā kasyacid  ādye pratyakṣeṇa tasya nāstitā avadhāraṇāt
translated: or some imperceptible thing.🔽In the first case, because its non-existence is ascertained by perception,

analyzed: pramāṇa bādhita tvena eva viṣāṇa tvasya asādhana tvāt na atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: because the horn-ness is contradicted by a means of knowledge, it is not a proof, so there is no over-extension.

analyzed: dvitīye tviṣi āpādanam iti
translated: In the second, there is the consequence of the desired conclusion.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be the case.

analyzed: śṛṅga tvam tāvat asādhanam iti avivādam
translated: The horn-ness is indeed not a means of proof, there is no dispute about that.

original: asti ca tatra bādhitaviṣayatvamasadāśrayatvaṃ ca /🔽tatra bādhitaviṣayatvameva tadīyāsādhanatve prayojakaṃ nāsadāśrayatvamiti kuto niyamyata ityata āha yatreti //
analyzed: asti ca tatra bādhita viṣaya tvam asat āśraya tvam ca  tatra bādhita viṣaya tvam eva tadīya asādhanatve prayojakam na asat āśraya tvam iti kutas niyamyate iti atas āha yatra iti
translated: And there is the invalidity of the subject and the invalidity of the proposition.

original: yatra vyāhatatā nāsti ko 'tisaṅgo 'sya sādhane // / / //🔽yasminsādhye vyāhatatā pramāṇabādho nāsti /
analyzed: yatra vyāhata tā na asti sādhane  yasmin sādhye vyāhata tā pramāṇa bādhaḥ na asti
translated: There, the invalidity of the subject alone is the reason for its being a non-means of proof, not the invalidity of the proposition. How is this restricted? Therefore he says: Where there is no contradiction, what is the great fault in proving it?

analyzed: asya sādhane sat āśrayeṇa api hetunā kriyamāṇe kaḥ tiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: Where there is no contradiction, i.e. no contradiction with valid means of knowledge, in proving it, i.e. in establishing it even by a reason with an invalid subject, what is the great fault?

analyzed: na kaḥ pi doṣaḥ
translated: There is no fault at all.

analyzed: vyāhata tā iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: The word contradiction is a synecdoche.

analyzed: vyabhicāra ādikam ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: And deviation etc. should also be seen.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

original: asti tāvadbādhitaviṣayatvasya dūṣaṇatve kṛśānuśaityādisādhanaṃ kṛtakatvādikaṃ doṣāntarāsaṅkīrṇamudāharaṇam /
analyzed: asti tāvat bādhita viṣaya tvasya dūṣaṇa tve kṛśānu śaitya ādi sādhanam kṛtaka tva ādikam doṣa antara asaṅkīrṇam udāharaṇam
translated: There is indeed an example of the reason of being produced etc. unmixed with other faults, which proves the coolness of fire etc., in the invalidity of the subject being a fault.

analyzed: tena
translated: By that.

analyzed: tasya dūṣaṇa tvam niśninumaḥ
translated: We ascertain its being a fault.

analyzed: na ca āsāt āśraya tvasya doṣa tve bādhita viṣaya tva ādi asaṅkīrṇam udāharaṇam asti
translated: And when the fact of having a non-existent substratum is not a fallacy, there is no example of a reason which is not contradicted and is free from confusion with other fallacies,

analyzed: yena tasya doṣa tvam pratīmaḥ
translated: by which we could know that it is a fallacy.
Because in the absence of other fallacies such as having a contradicted subject, there is no contradiction in the reason having a non-existent substratum.

analyzed: dṛśyate ca tathāvidhasya hetu tvam
translated: And such a reason is seen to be valid.

analyzed: yathā vandhyā sutaḥ na vaktā acetana tvāt pāṣāṇa vat iti
translated: For example, The son of a barren woman is not a speaker, because of being insentient, like a stone.

analyzed: atas bādhita viṣaya tvena eva śṛṅga tvam asādhanam na asat āśraya tvena iti niścīyate
translated: Therefore, it is ascertained that the horn is not a means of valid knowledge only because of having a contradicted subject, not because of having a non-existent substratum.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is argued:

analyzed: vandhyā sutaḥ vaktā suta tvāt sammata vat iti sat pratipakṣam etat kim na syāt
translated: The son of a barren woman is a speaker, because of being a son, like an accepted one, why can this not be a counter-argument?

analyzed: asat āśraya tā bhayasya bhavatā eva tyājita tvāt iti
translated: Because you yourself have abandoned the fear of having a non-existent substratum.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: tadīya vaktṛ tā kāryasya kadāpi kena api anupalabdha tvena bādhita viṣaya tayā durbalasya apratipakṣa tvāt
translated: Because that which has a contradicted subject, being weak, is not a counter-argument, since the effect of being a speaker, which belongs to it, is never perceived by anyone.

analyzed: nahi bhavati tarakṣoḥ pratipakṣaḥ hariṇa śāvaḥ
translated: For a young deer is not a counter-argument for a hyena.

analyzed: avaktṛ tvam api vacana itara kriyā kartṛ tvam iti atas cetana tvam api bādhita viṣayam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the absence of being a speaker also means being the agent of an action other than speaking, and therefore the property of being insentient is also contradicted, it is not so.

analyzed: vaktṛ tva abhāva mātrasya sādhya tvāt  nanu abhāvaḥ pi asati katham
translated: Because the mere absence of being a speaker is what is to be proved.

analyzed: tasya dharma abhāvāt iti ced na
translated: If it is asked how an absence can be so if it does not exist, it is not so.

analyzed: dharmāṇām anekavidha tvāt
translated: Because properties are of many kinds.

analyzed: kecid hi dharmi samavetāḥ bhavanti
translated: For some properties inhere in the substratum,

analyzed: yathā rūpa ādayaḥ
translated: like color etc.

analyzed: kecid anya samavetāḥ api anyam uparañjanīyam
translated: Some, though inhering in something else, color that other thing,

analyzed: yathā jñāna ādayaḥ ghaṭa ādīnām
translated: like knowledge etc. in pots etc.

analyzed: kecid āśraya samavāyam api na apekṣante kevalam kenacid nirūpyante
translated: Some do not even depend on inherence in a substratum, but are simply determined by something.

analyzed: yathā bhāvaḥ
translated: Like absence.

analyzed: na ca vācyam abhāvaḥ nirūpaṇīyaḥ iti
translated: And it cannot be said that absence also is to be determined by something existent.

analyzed: prāgabhāva ādi anirūpaṇa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the absurdity of the non-determination of prior absence etc.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādeḥ kadācid sattvāt na evam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is not so in the case of a pot etc. because they sometimes exist, it is not so.

analyzed: tasya nirūpaṇa samaye n upayogāt
translated: Because it is of no use at the time of determining it.

analyzed: pratītyāḥ nirūpaka tvam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that determination is by cognition,

analyzed: samam prakṛte pi
translated: it is the same in the present case also.

analyzed: śabda ābhāsa ādinā vandhyā sutasya api pratīti sambhavāt
translated: Because the cognition of the son of a barren woman is possible by the appearance of a word etc.

analyzed: asiddham ca suta tvam vandhyā sutasya
translated: And the property of being a son is not established for the son of a barren woman.

analyzed: na ca evam sva vacana vyāghātaḥ
translated: And it is not thus that there is a contradiction with your own words.

analyzed: kālpanika anuvādena vāstava nirākaraṇāt
translated: Because the real is denied by the statement of the imaginary.

analyzed: kālpanikasya katham pakṣa tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is asked how the imaginary can be the subject, it is not so.

analyzed: niṣedham prati pakṣa tve bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction in being the subject with regard to the negation.

analyzed: anyathā parapakṣa pratikṣepa ayogāt
translated: Otherwise, it would be impossible to refute the opponent's position.

analyzed: atha acetana tvam api asiddham  tasya cetanā atirikta svabhāva tvāt iti ced na
translated: Now, if insentience is also unestablished,🔽and that is because it has a nature different from sentience, it is not so.

analyzed: caitanya vyāvṛtti mātrasya hetu tvāt  abhāvasya ca asataḥ tā
translated: Because the mere exclusion of sentience is the reason.

analyzed: nirūpaṇam upapadyate iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that the determination of a non-existent absence is also possible.

analyzed: mūke na aikāntikaḥ ca satatva hetuḥ
translated: And the reason of existence is inconclusive with regard to the mute.

original: amūkatvena viśeṣaṇe tasya vaktṛtvānatiriktatvena sādhyaviśiṣyatā syāt /
analyzed: amūka tvena viśeṣaṇe tasya vaktṛ tva anatirikta tvena sādhya viśiṣya tā syāt
translated: If it is qualified by non-muteness, then it would be the same as the probandum, because it is not different from speech.

original: etena vikalpitāḥ pakṣāḥ samastā api nirastā bhavantītyāstāṃ vistaraḥ / /
analyzed: etena vikalpitāḥ pakṣāḥ samastāḥ api nirastāḥ bhavanti iti āstām vistaraḥ
translated: By this, all the alternative subjects are refuted collectively. Let this discussion end here.

analyzed: pramāṇa bādhe
translated: In the case of contradiction with valid cognition,

analyzed: virodhena śṛṅga tva hetuḥ ābhāsaḥ iti uktam
translated: it has been said that the reason of having horns is fallacious due to contradiction.

analyzed: atha pramāṇa virodhasya api kutas dūṣaṇa tvam
translated: Now, why is the contradiction with valid cognition also a fault?

analyzed: vyāpti ādi aṅga sākalye sādhya siddheḥ āvaśyaka tvāt
translated: Because the establishment of the probandum is necessary when the components such as pervasion are complete.

analyzed: tad abhāve tatas eva ābhāsa tvam
translated: If they are absent, it is fallacious for that very reason.

analyzed: kim pramāṇa bādhena iti atas āha pratyakṣa iti
translated: To this he says: Pratyakṣāgamāśrayāḥ.

analyzed: pratyakṣa āgama mūlāḥ tu nyāyāḥ sarve bhavanti hi
translated: All reasonings are indeed based on perception and scripture.

analyzed: nyāya ābhāsāḥ amūlāḥ syuḥ
translated: Reasonings that are not based on perception and scripture are fallacious.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe hi śabdaḥ prasiddhau
translated: The word tu (but) is for emphasis, the word hi (indeed) is for well-known fact.

analyzed: yasmāt iti arthe ca
translated: And the word yasmāt (since) is for the meaning because.

analyzed: yadi api niṣedhaka hetoḥ niṣedha ātmanaḥ prāmāṇikam api āśrayaḥ dṛṣṭānta dharmī ca kvacid bhavati iti uktam
translated: Although it has been said that for a negating reason, which has the nature of negation, a non-authoritative basis and an example-subject may sometimes occur,

original: tathāpi vidhāyakānāṃ vidhirūpāṇāṃ cāśrayeṇāvaśyaṃ pratyakṣāgamagṛhītena bhāvyam /
analyzed: tathā api vidhāyakānām vidhi rūpāṇām ca āśrayeṇa avaśyam pratyakṣa āgama gṛhītena bhāvyam
translated: nevertheless, for affirming reasons, which have the nature of affirmation, the basis must necessarily be one that is grasped by perception and scripture.

analyzed: kvacid niṣedhakasya niṣedha ātmanaḥ ca niṣedhe  sādhye
translated: In some cases, for a negating reason, which has the nature of negation, in the negation that is to be proved,

original: kvacitpratiyoginā pratyakṣādigṛhītena bhavitavyam /🔽liṅgaṃ ca na svarūpeṇa sādhyapramitimupajanayitumalam /
analyzed: kvacid pratiyoginā pratyakṣa ādi gṛhītena bhavitavyam  liṅgam ca na sva rūpeṇa sādhya pramitim upajanayitum alam
translated: the counter-correlate must be one that is grasped by perception etc.🔽And a logical mark cannot generate the cognition of what is to be proved by its own form.

analyzed: kintu pratyakṣa āgamābhyām niścita svarūpa vyāptikam
translated: But rather, one whose form and pervasion are ascertained by perception and scripture.

original: ityevamanekadhā sarve 'pi nyāyāḥ pratyakṣāgamamūlā eva bhavantīti tāvatprasiddham /
analyzed: iti evam anekadhā sarve pi nyāyāḥ pratyakṣa āgama mūlāḥ eva bhavanti iti tāvat prasiddham
translated: Thus, it is well-known that all reasonings are indeed based on perception and scripture in many ways.

original: yata evaṃ / tasmādamūlāḥ svamūlabhūtapratyakṣāgamaviruddhā nyāyābhāsā eva syuḥ /
analyzed: yatas evam tasmāt amūlāḥ sva mūla bhūta pratyakṣa āgama viruddhāḥ nyāya ābhāsāḥ eva syuḥ
translated: Since this is so, therefore, these [fallacious reasonings] would be mere fallacies of reasoning, unrooted, contradicted by perception and scripture which are their own roots.

original: yathā khalu🔽naiśatyādisampanno 'pi paraśuraviṣaye gaganādau na chidāṃ janayati evamanumānānyapyupajīvyatvādinā
analyzed: yathā khalu  naiśatya ādi sampannaḥ pi paraśuḥ aviṣaye gagana ādau na chidām janayati evam anumānāni api upajīvya tva ādinā
translated: Just as,🔽even though an axe is endowed with sharpness etc., it does not produce cutting in an improper object such as the sky, in the same way, inferences also, being weak due to being dependent on perception etc.,

analyzed: prabalābhyām pratyakṣa āgamābhyām bādhita tvena aviṣaye na pramām upajanayitum alam iti ābhāsa bhūtāni eva iti
translated: are not able to produce valid knowledge in an improper object, being contradicted by the strong perception and scripture, and thus are mere fallacies.

analyzed: nanu anumāna mūlaḥ api nyāyaḥ sti
translated: But there is also reasoning which has inference as its root.

analyzed: yathā cakṣuḥ ādi pakṣīkāreṇa pravṛttaḥ
translated: For example, that which operates by positing the eye etc.

analyzed: tat katham pratyakṣa āgama mūlāḥ syuḥ iti uktam iti atas āha nyāyasya iti
translated: How then can it be said that they have perception and scripture as their roots? To this he says reasoning etc.

analyzed: nyāyasya anyasya tau punar
translated: The two [perception and scripture] are again the root of another reasoning.

analyzed: pratyakṣa āgama mūlāt nyāyāt anyasya api nyāyasya tau pratyakṣa āgamau eve mūlam
translated: The two, perception and scripture, are the root of another reasoning, which has reasoning as its root, and not of the reasoning which has perception and scripture as its root.

analyzed: katham
translated: How is this?

original: yato mūlabhūtasyāpyanyasya nyāyasya tau punarmūlamityantataḥ sarvathā pratyakṣāgamānatikramāttathoktamiti /
analyzed: yatas mūla bhūtasya api anyasya nyāyasya tau punar mūlam iti antataḥ sarvathā pratyakṣa āgama anatikramāt tathā uktam iti
translated: Because the two are again the root of another reasoning, which is the root, ultimately, since they are never beyond perception and scripture, it is said thus.

original: yadyapyāgamo 'pi pratyakṣamūlastathāpi kvacitpratyakṣasyāpi mūlaṃ bhavatītyato dvayorgrahaṇam /
analyzed: yadi api āgamaḥ pratyakṣa mūlaḥ tathā api kvacid pratyakṣasya api mūlam bhavati iti atas dvayoḥ grahaṇam
translated: Although the scriptures also have perception as their basis, in some cases perception also has scriptures as its basis. Therefore, both are mentioned.

analyzed: anumānasya api kvacid tad mūla tve pi na svatantrasya iti atas tad parityāgaḥ
translated: Although inference also has scriptures as its basis in some cases, it is not independent. Therefore, it is excluded.

analyzed: evam vyāpti bhaṅga ādi anapekṣam eva aviṣaya vṛtti tvena bādhitasya duṣṭa tvam upapāditam
translated: Thus, the fault of a reason that is contradicted by a cognition that does not have a real object is explained without the need for a contradiction of the pervasion, etc.

analyzed: prakāra antaram api āha adṛṣṭe iti
translated: He states another method, saying when there is no seen contradiction...

original: adṛṣṭe vyabhicāre tu sādhakaṃ taditi sphuṭam /
analyzed: adṛṣṭe vyabhicāre tu sādhakam tat iti sphuṭam
translated: When there is no seen contradiction, it is clear that the reason proves the conclusion.

analyzed: jñāyate sākṣiṇā eva a t vā
translated: It is known only by the witness.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word tu (but) is for emphasis.

original: talliṅgaṃ dhūmādikaṃ dahanādisādhyavyabhicāre 'ddhā sarvathāpyadṛṣṭa eva sati tasya sādhakaṃ na tu vyabhicāradarśana iti tāvatsākṣiṇaiva sphuṭaṃ 🔽jñāyate / /
analyzed: tad liṅgam dhūma ādikam dahana ādi sādhya vyabhicāre sarvathā api adṛṣṭe eva sati tasya sādhakam na tu vyabhicāra darśane iti tāvat sākṣiṇā eva sphuṭam  jñāyate
translated: When the reason, such as smoke, is seen to be contradicted in relation to the probandum, such as fire, it is clear that it proves the conclusion only when there is no contradiction at all, and not when there is seen contradiction. This is known only by the witness.

original: kimate yadyadṛṣṭavyabhicārasyaiva liṅgasya sādhyasādhakatvaṃ sākṣisiddhamityata āha māneti //
analyzed: kimate yadi adṛṣṭa vyabhicārasya eva liṅgasya sādhya sādhaka tvam sākṣi siddham iti atas āha māna iti
translated: What if it is established by the witness that only a reason that has no seen contradiction proves the conclusion? To this he says when there is contradiction by valid cognition...

analyzed: māna bādhe na tat bhavet
translated: It would not be so.

analyzed: yat sākṣiṇā eva māna tvam mānānām avasīyate
translated: That the validity of the means of knowledge is ascertained by the witness itself.

analyzed: pramāṇa bādhe sati tad dṛṣṭānta vyabhicāri tvam na bhavet
translated: If there is contradiction by valid knowledge, then the example would not be fallacious.

original: pramāṇabādhenāgnyādeḥ śaityādyapahāre sati tatraiva liṅgasya kṛtakatvādeḥ sādhyavyabhicāradarśanāt /
analyzed: pramāṇa bādhena agni ādeḥ śaitya ādi apahāre sati tatra eva liṅgasya kṛtaka tva ādeḥ sādhya vyabhicāra darśanāt
translated: If the coldness etc. of fire etc. is removed by the contradiction of valid knowledge, then the logical mark such as being produced is seen to be fallacious with respect to the probandum in that case.

analyzed: tat anena vyāpti bhaṅga hetutayā bādhasya dūṣaṇa tvam iti uktam bhavati
translated: By this it is said that contradiction is a fault as the cause of the destruction of pervasion.

analyzed: tatra ayam vivekaḥ
translated: Here is the distinction.

analyzed: para artha prayoga uttarakālam aviṣaya vṛtti tvam eva udbhāvyam
translated: Only the non-apprehension of the object should be stated after the argument for the sake of others.

analyzed: na vyāpti bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Not the destruction of pervasion.

analyzed: vyāpti bhaṅga upapādanāya upajīvyena aviṣaya vṛtti tvena eva anumānasya duṣṭa tve jaghanya pratipattikasya vyāpti bhaṅgasya anusaraṇasya anyāyya tvāt
translated: Because it is not proper to follow the destruction of pervasion, which is of secondary cognition, by the fault of inference itself due to the non-apprehension of the object, which is to be relied upon, for the establishment of the destruction of pervasion.

analyzed: vyāpti grahaṇa samaye tu tad bhaṅga hetu tvena eva
translated: But at the time of grasping the pervasion, it is only as the cause of its destruction.

analyzed: tadānīm viṣayasya buddhau anārūḍha tvāt  vyāpti bhaṅgasya eva pura sphūtiḥ ka tvāt ca iti sākṣiṇā eva iti uktam
translated: Because at that time the object is not present in the mind.🔽And because the destruction of pervasion is clearly present, it is said by the witness itself.

analyzed: tad prasaṅgāt upapādayati yat iti
translated: He explains it incidentally by saying that.

analyzed: yasmāt sarveṣām mānānām jñānānām māna tvam sākṣiṇā eva avasīyate
translated: Because the validity of all cognitions is ascertained only by the witness.

analyzed: anyatā anavasthā ādi prasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the contingence of infinite regress, otherness, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt anumānasya api prāmāṇyam tena eva jñāyate iti uktam eva
translated: Therefore, it has been said that even the validity of inference is known by that [witness] itself.

original: yadi tarhi prāmāṇyaṃ sākṣivedyaṃ sākṣiṇaḥ prāgupapādito yāthārthyaniyamo bhajyeta /
analyzed: yadi tarhi prāmāṇyam sākṣi vedyam sākṣiṇaḥ prāk upapāditaḥ yāthārthya niyamaḥ bhajyeta
translated: If then validity is known by the witness, the restriction of truthfulness to the witness, which has been established earlier, would be violated.

analyzed: kadācid amānasya api hi māna tvam gṛhyate
translated: For sometimes even an invalid cognition is apprehended as valid.

analyzed: anyathā viparyaya ādi śaṅkā pravṛttiḥ na syāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be no doubt about error, etc., and no engagement [in action].

original: tasya cāyathārthatvaṃ bādhenāvedyate ityata āha amānasyeti //🔽amānasya tu mānatvaṃ mānasatvāccalaṃ bhavet // / / //
analyzed: tasya ca ayathārtha tvam bādhena āvedyate iti atas āha amānasya iti  amānasya tu māna tvam mānasa tvāt calam bhavet
translated: And its untruthfulness is not known by contradiction, hence he says:🔽But the validity of an invalid cognition would be unsteady due to being mental.
The validity, i.e., the apprehension of validity, would be unsteady, i.e., contradicted.

analyzed: amānasya tu yat māna tvam gṛhyate tat manasā eva
translated: But the validity that is apprehended of an invalid cognition is only by the mind.

analyzed: na sākṣiṇā
translated: Not by the witness.

analyzed: atas tasya bādhya tvam na doṣam āvahati iti
translated: Therefore, its being contradicted does not cause a fault.

analyzed: atra eṣā prakriyā
translated: Here is the process:

analyzed: sarvam api jñānam sākṣī gṛhṇāti
translated: The witness apprehends all cognitions.

original: yadyasya bādho bhaviṣyati tadāpramāṇaṃ na cetpramāṇameveti tatprāmāṇyamapi gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: yadi asya bādhaḥ bhaviṣyati tadā apramāṇam na ced pramāṇam eva iti tat prāmāṇyam api gṛhṇāti
translated: If there is contradiction of any, then it is invalid, if not, it is valid. Thus it also apprehends its validity.

original: sati prayojane prāmāṇyādijijñāsāyāṃ parīkṣāmanusṛtya prāmāṇyamaprāmāṇyaṃ vā vyavasthāpayati /
analyzed: sati prayojane prāmāṇya ādi jijñāsāyām parīkṣām anusṛtya prāmāṇyam aprāmāṇyam vā vyavasthāpayati
translated: When there is a purpose, when there is a desire to know about validity etc., one determines validity or invalidity by following the examination.

analyzed: alābhe tu parīkṣāyāḥ viśeṣa avadhāraṇāt udāste
translated: But when there is no examination, one remains indifferent due to the lack of a specific determination.

analyzed: asyām avasthāyām rāga ādi kaluṣitam manaḥ parīkṣā ābhāsa sahāyam prāmāṇya ādikam avadhārayati
translated: In this state, the mind polluted by passion etc., with the help of a semblance of examination, determines validity etc.

analyzed: tat ca kadācid bādhyate kadācid na iti
translated: And that is sometimes contradicted and sometimes not.

analyzed: kutas eṣā kalpanā iti ced sākṣiṇaḥ yāthārthya niyamasya eva upāpadita tvāt
translated: If it is asked how this is imagined, it is because the truthfulness of the witness is itself established.

analyzed: vakṣyate ca etat iti  adṛṣṭe vyabhicāraḥ iti sādhya vyabhicāri liṅgam apramāṇam iti uktam
translated: And this will be explained.🔽It is said that an inferential mark that deviates from the probandum is not a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: tatra dṛṣṭa vyabhicāri liṅgam apramāṇam iti uktam bhavati  tatra viśeṣam āha utsargataḥ pi iti
translated: There it is said that an inferential mark that deviates from what is seen is not a valid means of knowledge.🔽There he states the distinction: Even when generally accepted, free from exception,

analyzed: utsargataḥ yat prāptam apavāda vivarjitam
translated: That which is generally accepted, free from exception,

analyzed: vyabhicāri apavādena mānam eva bhaviṣyati
translated: Will be a valid means of knowledge, even if it deviates from the exception.

original: yalliṅgamutsargataḥ svabhāvenāpavādavivarjitaṃ sādhyavyabhicāravarjitaṃ prāptaṃ niścitamapyapavādena kāraṇaviśeṣeṇaiva vyabhicāri tanmānameva
analyzed: yat liṅgam utsargataḥ svabhāvena apavāda vivarjitam sādhya vyabhicāra varjitam prāptam niścitam api apavādena kāraṇa viśeṣeṇa eva vyabhicāri tat mānam eva
translated: That probans which is naturally invariable, free from exception, free from the fallacy of being absent from the subject, even though ascertained, becomes a valid means of knowledge only when it is invariably concomitant with the probandum by a special reason, by an exception.

analyzed: bhaviṣyati
translated: It will be just this.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: yathā sādhanasya sādhya sāhitya mātram na
translated: Just as the mere presence of the probans with the probandum is not useful for validity,

analyzed: kintu nirupādhikam eva
translated: but only when free from restriction.

analyzed: anyathā sa upādhika sādhya sambandhasya  maitrītanaya tva ādeḥ api śyamatā sādhanatva prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, if the relation with the probandum were restricted,🔽then even the son of Maitreya, etc. would be a probans for blackness,

analyzed: tathā vyabhicāraḥ pi nirupādhikaḥ sā
translated: because the fallacy is also accepted only when free from restriction.

analyzed: dhana tve hetuḥ
translated: A probans is a reason for invalidity

original: yathā prameyatvasya nityatvena /🔽nahi prameyatvaṃ svabhāvena nityatvāvyabhicāri /
analyzed: yathā prameya tvasya nitya tvena  nahi prameya tvam svabhāvena nitya tva avyabhicāri
translated: like the knowability of an entity with eternality.🔽For knowability is not invariably concomitant with eternality by nature.

original: vyabhicāri tu nimittāntareṇetyatra niyāmakaṃ paśyāmaḥ yastu svabhāvena nityatvāvyabhicāri /
analyzed: vyabhicāri tu nimitta antareṇa iti atra niyāmakam paśyāmaḥ yaḥ tu svabhāvena nitya tva avyabhicāri
translated: But we see no restriction that it is invariably concomitant with eternality by some other cause. But that which is invariably concomitant with eternality by nature,

original: vyabhicāri tu nimittāntareṇetyatra paśyāmaḥ yastu svabhāvena sādhyavyabhicāriṇo 'pi sādhanasyaupādhiko vyabhicāro nāsāvaprāmāṇyakāraṇamiti
analyzed: vyabhicāri tu nimitta antareṇa iti atra paśyāmaḥ yaḥ tu svabhāvena sādhya vyabhicāriṇaḥ sādhanasya aupādhikaḥ vyabhicāraḥ na asau aprāmāṇya kāraṇam iti
translated: But in the case of deviation due to another cause, we shall see that even when the reason is deviating from the probandum by its very nature, the deviation of the reason due to an extraneous cause is not a ground for invalidity.

analyzed: kutas etat iti atas āha atas hi iti
translated: How is this known? To this he says 'because of this' etc.

analyzed: atas hi bhojana ādīnām iṣṭa sādhana tā anumā
translated: Because of this, the inference of the instrumentality of future food etc.

analyzed: mānam vyavahṛtau nityam
translated: in the desired object is always the basis for usage.

analyzed: eva śabdaḥ tra adhyāhāryaḥ  sa upādhikasya  vyabhicārasya aprāmāṇya kāraṇa tva abhāvāt eva hi āgāmi bhojana ādīnām iṣya sādhanatā anumānam yadi sa upādhikaḥ pi vyabhicāraḥ prāmāṇya hetuḥ
translated: The word 'eva' (only) should be supplied here.🔽Because the deviation with a cause is not a ground for invalidity,🔽the inference of the instrumentality of future food etc. in the desired object would not be possible. If the deviation with a cause were a ground for invalidity,

original: syāttadā vimataṃ bhojanamiṣyasādhanaṃ bhojanatvāt hyastanabhojanavadityanumānamamānaṃ prasajyeteti /
analyzed: syāt tadā vimatam bhojanam iṣya sādhanam bhojana tvāt hyastana bhojana vat iti anumānam amānam prasajyeta iti
translated: then the inference 'the disputed food is an instrument in the desired object because of being food, like yesterday's food' would be invalid.

analyzed: aprāmāṇyam eva tat astu iti atas āha vyavahṛtau iti
translated: To this he says 'in the usage' etc.

analyzed: kāraṇam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is 'the ground'.

original: yadi vyabhicāreṇedamamānaṃ syāttadā prameyatvamiva vyavahartṛbhiramānatayā niścīyetāpi /
analyzed: yadi vyabhicāreṇa idam amānam syāt tadā prameya tvam iva vyavahartṛbhiḥ amāna tayā niścīyeta api
translated: If this were invalid due to deviation, then it would be ascertained as invalid by the users of pramāṇa, like the pameya (object of knowledge).

original: tathā ca tato bhojane prekṣāvatāṃ pravṛttirna syāt /🔽nanu vyabhicārisādhanaṃ sandehamāvahati /
analyzed: tathā ca tatas bhojane prekṣāvatām pravṛttiḥ na syāt  nanu vyabhicāri sādhanam sandeham āvahati
translated: And hence the wise would not engage in eating.🔽But an inconclusive reason produces doubt.

analyzed: sandehaḥ pi bhavati pravṛtti hetuḥ iti
translated: And doubt also is a cause of engagement.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: sandehaḥ sa āśaṅkām pravṛttim upajanayati na niraṅkuśām
translated: Doubt produces engagement with suspicion, not without restraint.

analyzed: iyam tu niraṅkuśā sarva anubhava siddhā iti
translated: But this [doubt] is without restraint, as established by all experience.

analyzed: tat idam uktam nityam iti
translated: This is what is meant by saying always.

analyzed: pūrveṇa eva sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with the previous [statement].

original: bhavatīdamanumānaṃ pramāṇaṃ kintu vyabhicārābhāvādevetyata āha vyabhicāro hīti //
analyzed: bhavati idam anumānam pramāṇam kintu vyabhicāra abhāvāt eva iti atas āha vyabhicāraḥ hi iti
translated: This inference is a means of valid knowledge, but only because there is no fallacy. To this he says For fallacy is there too.

analyzed: vyabhicāraḥ hi tatra ca
translated: For fallacy is there too in that [inference].

original: tatra bhojanatvādau sādhane sādhyeṣyasādhanatvavyabhicāraḥ sphuṭa eva /🔽kvacidaniṣyasādhanatvasyāpyupalambhāt /
analyzed: tatra bhojana tva ādau sādhane sādhya iṣyasādhanatva vyabhicāraḥ sphuṭaḥ eva  kvacid aniṣya sādhana tvasya api upalambhāt
translated: In that [inference] where eating, etc. are the reason, there is clearly fallacy in the relation of the probandum and probans.🔽Because in some cases the relation of non-desired means is also observed.

analyzed: kintu apathya tva ādi upādhi nibandhanaḥ eva
translated: But it is only based on the limiting conditions such as unhealthiness, etc.

original: naca pathyatvādiviśiṣyameva bhojanatvādikaṃ sādhanamiti vācyam /🔽tasya pravṛttyuttarakāle /
analyzed: na ca pathya tva ādi viśiṣyam eva bhojana tva ādikam sādhanam iti vācyam  tasya pravṛtti uttara kāle
translated: And it cannot be said that eating, etc. qualified by healthiness, etc. are the means.

analyzed: phala anumeyasya prāk asiddheḥ
translated: Because that [healthiness, etc.] is to be inferred from the result after engagement.🔽Because it is not established before.

analyzed: na khalu phala mūla ādīnām viṣapatrikā ādi anupahata tvam asmat ādibhiḥ avadhārayitum śakyate
translated: Indeed, it is not possible for us to ascertain that fruits, roots, etc. are not affected by poisonous leaves, etc.

original: tasmānnirupādhika eva vyabhicāro 'sādhanatvaheturiti /🔽tadevaṃ pramāṇabādhasya dūṣaṇatve prakārasambhavānnāsadāśrayatvasyādūṣaṇatve tatpratibandī yukteti /
analyzed: tasmāt nirupādhikaḥ eva vyabhicāraḥ sādhanatva hetuḥ iti  tat evam pramāṇa bādhasya dūṣaṇa tve prakāra sambhavāt na asat āśraya tvasya adūṣaṇa tve tad pratibandī yuktā iti
translated: Therefore, the absence of a counter-example alone is the reason for non-establishment.🔽Thus, since it is possible for contradiction by valid means of knowledge to be a fault in that way, it is not proper to use the counter-argument that the basis being non-existent is not a fault.

original: evamasadāśrayatvasya hetudūṣaṇatvaṃ nirākṛtya vyadhikaraṇatvasyāpi tannirākurvāṇo yadi vyadhikaraṇo 'pi hetuḥ syāttadā'tmā'ni
analyzed: evam asat āśraya tvasya hetu dūṣaṇa tvam nirākṛtya vyadhikaraṇa tvasya api tat nirākurvāṇaḥ yadi hetuḥ syāt tadā ātmāni
translated: Having thus refuted the faultiness of the reason in the form of the basis being non-existent, he refutes the faultiness of the reason in the form of being about a different subject. If the reason were about a different subject, then the self would be

original: nityaḥ kākasya kārṣyādityayamapi hetuḥ syādityatiprasaṅgādvā vyadhikaraṇatvasya hetudūṣaṇatvamaṅgīkatarvyam
analyzed: nityaḥ kākasya kārṣyāt iti ayam api hetuḥ syāt iti atiprasaṅgāt vā vyadhikaraṇa tvasya hetu dūṣaṇa tvam aṅgīkatarvyam
translated: non-eternal because of the blackness of the crow. This would also be a reason, leading to over-extension. Therefore, the faultiness of the reason in the form of being about a different subject must be accepted.

original: vyāptyabhāvādvā pakṣadharmatābhāvādveti vikalpaṃ manasi nidhāyādyaṃ nirācaṣṭe vyāptatva iti // /
analyzed: vyāpti abhāvāt vā pakṣa dharma tā abhāvāt vā iti vikalpam manasi nidhāya ādyam nirācaṣṭe vyāpta tve iti
translated: Or, it is because of the absence of pervasion or the absence of the property of the subject. Having mentally considered this option, he first refutes the pervasion in the statement if there is pervasion, how can the different basis be a fault?

original: vyāptatve vyāśrayatvaṃ tu kathameva hi dūṣaṇam // / / //
analyzed: vyāpta tve vyāśraya tvam tu katham eva hi dūṣaṇam
translated: If there is pervasion, how can the different basis be a fault at all?

original: sādhanasya sādhyena vyāptatve sati tena vibhinnāśrayatvaṃ kathameva hi dūṣaṇam /
analyzed: sādhanasya sādhyena vyāpta tve sati tena vibhinna āśraya tvam katham eva hi dūṣaṇam
translated: When the probans is pervaded by the probandum, how can its being based on a different substratum be a fault?

analyzed: na kathañcid
translated: Not in any way.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: kākasya kārṣṇyaṃ vyāptyabhāvādeva hi nityatvāsādhakaṃ na punarvyadhikaraṇatvam /
analyzed: kākasya kārṣṇyam vyāpti abhāvāt eva hi nitya tva asādhakam na punar vyadhikaraṇa tvam
translated: The blackness of the crow is not a prover of its permanence because of the absence of pervasion, not because of being based on a different substratum.

analyzed: atas na atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: Therefore there is no overextension.

analyzed: kutas etat
translated: Where is this from?

analyzed: vyāpti ādi aṅga sākalye vyadhikaraṇa tva mātreṇa asādhaka tvasya kvāpi anupalambhāt
translated: Because even when pervasion and other components are complete, being based on a different substratum alone is never seen to be a non-prover.

original: ghaṭasya kṛtakatvāt śabdo 'nityata ityādau dṛṣṭamiti cet /
analyzed: ghaṭasya kṛtaka tvāt śabdaḥ nityatas ityādau dṛṣṭam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is seen in Sound is impermanent because a pot is produced,

analyzed: ghaṭasya iti etat hetu viśeṣaṇam na vā
translated: is of a pot a qualification of the reason or not?

analyzed: ādye vaiyarthyam
translated: In the first case, it is useless.

analyzed: dvitīye katham asādhaka tvam
translated: In the second case, how can it be a non-prover?

original: atha anityatvavyāptamapi kṛtakatvaṃ ghaṭavṛtti na śabde 'nityatvaṃ sādhayatīti cenna /
analyzed: atha anitya tva vyāptam api kṛtaka tvam ghaṭa vṛtti na śabde nitya tvam sādhayati iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that even though production is pervaded by impermanence, it does not prove impermanence in sound because it occurs in a pot, that is not so.

analyzed: vyāpti abhāvāt
translated: Because of the absence of pervasion.

analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And we will explain that.

original: na kevalaṃ vyāptyādyaṅgasākalye vyadhikaraṇatvamātreṇa duṣṭatvaṃ na dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: na kevalam vyāpti ādi aṅga sākalye vyadhikaraṇa tva mātreṇa duṣṭa tvam na dṛṣṭam
translated: Not only is being based on a different substratum alone not seen to be faulty when pervasion and other components are complete,

original: kintu dṛṣṭaṃ ca vyadhikaraṇasyāpi vyāptyādisampattimataḥ sādhakatvamityāha rohiṇīti //
analyzed: kintu dṛṣṭam ca vyadhikaraṇasya api vyāpti ādi sampattimataḥ sādhaka tvam iti āha rohiṇī iti
translated: But it is seen that even when there is a difference of substratum, if there is the presence of pervasion etc., it is a valid reason. He says Rohini etc.

analyzed: rohiṇī udayaḥ āsannaḥ kṛttikā abhyuditā yatas
translated: The rising of Rohini is imminent, because Krittika has risen.

analyzed: iti ukte sādhanam no kim
translated: When this is stated, is it not a valid reason?

analyzed: nadī pūra darśanena uttara deśe vṛṣṭai anumānam
translated: The inference of rain in the northern region from the sight of the swelling of a river,

original: pratyagraśarāvacakrabhramadarśanena kulālāsattyanumānaṃ cāśaṅkaya kenaciduktaṃ nottaradeśo 'tra pakṣaḥ kinnāma nadī /
analyzed: pratyagra śarāva cakra bhrama darśanena kulāla āsatti anumānam ca āśaṅkaya kenacid uktam na uttara deśaḥ pakṣaḥ kinnāma nadī
translated: and the inference of the non-existence of a potter from the sight of the rotation of a newly made pot and saucer, being suspected by someone, it is said: The northern region is not the subject here, but rather the river.

analyzed: tad dharmeṇa eva pūreṇa
translated: By the swelling, which is its property alone.

analyzed: tad dharmasya vṛṣṭimat uttara deśa sambandhasya sādhya tvam
translated: The connection of that property, rain, with the northern region, is what is to be proved.

analyzed: evam śarāva cakra dharmābhyām pratyagra tva bhramābhyām tad dharmasya eva kulāla āsatteḥ anumānam iti
translated: In the same way, the inference of the non-existence of a potter, which is the property of the pot and saucer, by the properties of newness and rotation, is the inference of that property alone.

analyzed: atas idam udāharaṇa antaram uditam
translated: Therefore, this is stated as a different example.

analyzed: nahi tathā iha
translated: For it is not so here.

original: treveha rohiṇyāḥ kṛttikāyā vā dvau dharmau sampādayituṃ śakyau /
analyzed: trā iva iha rohiṇyāḥ kṛttikāyāḥ vā dvau dharmau sampādayitum śakyau
translated: Here, it is not possible to establish two properties of Rohini or Krittika.

analyzed: nanu iha api kālam pakṣīkṛtya prayoktavyam
translated: But here also, time should be taken as the subject and used.

analyzed: vimataḥ kālaḥ rohiṇī udaya āsattimān kṛttikā udayavat kāla tvāt atīta kāla vat iti
translated: The time in question is connected with the rising of Rohini, because it is time, like the past time.

original: maivam evaṃ sati deśaṃ kālaṃ vā'dāya sāmānādhikaraṇyasya sarvatra sattvādvayadhikaraṇāsiddha eva na syāditi vyarthaṃ tatparisaṅkhayānam /
analyzed: mā evam evam sati deśam kālam vā ādāya sāmānādhikaraṇyasya sarvatra sattvāt vayadhikaraṇa asiddhaḥ eva na syāt iti vyartham tat parisaṅkhayānam
translated: If it were so, then, since the co-reference of the two terms is present everywhere, taking the place or time, the reason would not be unestablished even in the case of different substrata. So the enumeration of that (i.e., the unestablished reason) is useless.

analyzed: evam aprayoge vyadhikaraṇa tvam sa avakāśam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that in this way, when not used thus, the different substratum is open to objection, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā satya siddheḥ ukti doṣa tva abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if it were so, then the statement would not be open to the fault of being unestablished.

analyzed: na ca ukti doṣa tvam api
translated: And it is not even open to the fault of being a statement.

analyzed: vyadhikaraṇa tayā ukteḥ api sādhya siddhayaṅgatva anubhavāt
translated: Because even when stated with different substrata, it is seen to be a means to the establishment of the probandum.

original: evameva hi laukikānāmuktayaḥ /🔽parīkṣakā api hitatprāmāṇyamapātaprāmāṇyāt' /🔽ityādi prayujyate /
analyzed: evam eva hi laukikānām uktayaḥ  parīkṣakāḥ api hi tat prāmāṇyam apāta prāmāṇyāt  ityādi prayujyate
translated: For such are the statements of worldly people.🔽Even the investigators use it, saying The validity of that (statement) is due to the a priori validity.

analyzed: tat idam uktam iti vyadhikaraṇa tayā ukte pi etat vākyam
translated: This is what is said: Even when stated with different substrata, this statement

analyzed: sādhanam sādhya sidhi aṅgam no kim bhavati eva iti
translated: is a means to the establishment of the probandum, is it not?

original: kiñca kālādikamādāya prayogavipariṇāmaḥ kārya ityatra kiṃ
analyzed: kiñca kāla ādikam ādāya prayoga vipariṇāmaḥ kāryaḥ iti atra kim
translated: Moreover, in this matter of the transformation of the statement taking time etc., what is the determining factor?

analyzed: naiyāyika ādi samayaḥ niyāmakaḥ kiṃvā atra
translated: Is it the convention of the Naiyāyikas etc.? Or is there

analyzed: pramāṇam asti
translated: any proof in this matter?

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati na hi iti
translated: He refutes the first [view] with For it is not...

analyzed: na hi ājñā eva atra sādhakā  atra upapatti siddhe rthe
translated: For mere command is not a means of valid knowledge in this case.🔽Here, in a matter established by reasoning,

analyzed: sādhye rthe
translated: in a matter to be proven,

analyzed: ājñā eva samaya mātram
translated: mere command is just an agreement.

analyzed: tathā sati sarvam vāc mātreṇa eva upadeṣyavyam
translated: If that were so, everything would have to be taught merely by words.

analyzed: na punar kvāpi pramāṇam vācyam
translated: And valid knowledge would not have to be stated anywhere.

original: viparītājñayā satpratipakṣatā ca syāditi hi śabdārthaḥ /
analyzed: viparīta ājñayā sat pratipakṣa tā ca syāt iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: And there would be opposition by contrary commands. This is the meaning of the word.

analyzed: ājñā khalu pramāṇāt para viṣaye dharma ādau bhavati
translated: For a command is about dharma and so on, which are beyond the scope of valid knowledge.

analyzed: sā ca avagata āpta bhāvānām
translated: And that [command] is for those who have ascertained the trustworthiness [of the one giving the command].

analyzed: na api dvitīyaḥ
translated: Nor is the second [view].

analyzed: tad anupalambhāt
translated: Because that [command] is not perceived.

analyzed: syāt etat  vyāptiḥ tāvat anumāna aṅgam
translated: This may be said:🔽Vyaapti (pervasion) is indeed a part of anumana (inference).

analyzed: sambandha viśeṣaḥ ca vyāptiḥ
translated: And vyaapti is a special kind of relation.

original: naca vyāśrayayoḥ sambandho yujyate /🔽ato vyāśrayatvasya doṣatvātsambhatavi
analyzed: na ca vyāśrayayoḥ sambandhaḥ yujyate  atas vyāśraya tvasya doṣa tvāt sambhatavi
translated: And a relation between two things that are not based on the same substratum is not possible.

analyzed: te viṣaye vipariṇāmaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, because being based on a different substratum is a fault, there is a change in the intended object.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: avinābhāva mātrasya vyāpti tvāt
translated: Because mere invariable concomitance is vyaapti (pervasion).

analyzed: avinābhāvaḥ ca kvacid eka āśraya tām antar bhāvya bhavati
translated: And invariable concomitance sometimes occurs by being included in the same substratum,

analyzed: yathā kṛtaka tvasya anitya tvena
translated: as in the case of being produced and being impermanent.

analyzed: atas eva anya gatena tena nā anyatra anitya tā siddhiḥ
translated: For this very reason, the establishment of impermanence is not in another [object] by that [invariable concomitance] which is in another [object].

analyzed: kvacid vibhinna āśrayayoḥ eva
translated: In some cases, [the relation of probans and probandum] is between two things that have different substrata.

analyzed: yathā dhūmasya agninā
translated: For example, smoke and fire.

analyzed: dhūma agnī khalu na samavāya vṛttyā samāna āśrayau
translated: For smoke and fire do not have the same substratum in the sense of inherence.

analyzed: na api saṃyoga vṛttyā
translated: Nor do they have the same substratum in the sense of inherence-cum-concomitance.

analyzed: ūrdhva adhas deśa saṃyogi tvāt
translated: Because they are related to upper and lower regions respectively.

analyzed: dhūmasya adhas deśa saṃyogasya siddha tvāt
translated: Because the relation of smoke with the lower region is already established.

analyzed: tathā api eka parvata saṃyogi tā dvayoḥ asti iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the two have the relation of being connected with the same mountain, that is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati agni arthinaḥ niyamena pradeśa viśeṣe pravṛtti anupapatteḥ
translated: Because in that case, one seeking fire would not necessarily engage in activity with respect to a particular region.

original: dhūma eva dhūmatvena mūle 'gnimānsādhyata iti cet /
analyzed: dhūmaḥ eva dhūma tvena mūle gnimān sādhyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that smoke itself, as smoke, is inferred to be associated with fire in the substratum,

analyzed: kim eṣā laukikī pratītiḥ
translated: is this the ordinary cognition?

analyzed: āhosvit samaya siddhaye vipariṇāmaḥ kriyate
translated: Or is a transformation made for the sake of establishing convention?

analyzed: na prathamaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: laukikāḥ hi ūrdhva deśam dhūmavantam avalokya adhas deśam vahnimantam avagacchanti
translated: For ordinary people, seeing the upper region as smoky, understand the lower region as fiery.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: nirmūla tvāt
translated: Because it has no basis.

original: api ca dehādīnāṃ tāvatpareṇa kṣaṇikatā svīkriya''sthīyate /
analyzed: api ca deha ādīnām tāvat pareṇa kṣaṇika tā
translated: Moreover, the opponent accepts and maintains the momentariness of the body and so on.

analyzed: tatra patana kama arṇā guru tva anumānam durghaṭam syāt
translated: In that case, the inference of heaviness as the cause of falling would be difficult to establish.

analyzed: nahi tayoḥ kālataḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyam
translated: For they [heaviness and falling] are not co-extensive in time.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāvāt
translated: Because of the relation of cause and effect.

analyzed: na api deśataḥ
translated: Nor is it in respect of place.

analyzed: vibhinna dravya āśraya tvāt
translated: Because it has a different substance as its substratum.

analyzed: atas kasyacid vibhinna āśrayeṇa eva avinābhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the invariable concomitance of something is with a different substratum.

original: nanu vyadhikaraṇasya pakṣadharmatā nāstīti cenmā bhūt /
analyzed: nanu vyadhikaraṇasya pakṣa dharma tā na asti iti ced mā bhūt
translated: If it is argued that what has a different substratum cannot be the property of the subject, let it not be so.

analyzed: tad niyamasya nirnibandhana tvāt  tathā sati sādhyasya
translated: Because the restriction is groundless.

analyzed: niyata deśa tā katham siddhayet iti ced vayāpti svabhāvāt iti brūmaḥ
translated: If that is so, how can the definite locality of the probandum be established? We say it is due to the nature of pervasion.

analyzed: yathā hi
translated: For example,

original: yatkṛtakaṃ tadanityamiti sāmānādhikaraṇyamantarbhāvya vyāpteḥ kṛtakatvaṃ svāśraya evānityatvaṃ gamayati /
analyzed: yat kṛtakam tat anityam iti sāmānādhikaraṇyam antarbhāvya vyāpteḥ kṛtaka tvam sva āśraye eva anitya tvam gamayati
translated: just as the pervasion of being produced and being impermanent is included in the co-substantiality, and the quality of being produced indicates impermanence only in its own substratum,

original: tathā kṛttikodayo vyadhikaraṇayaiva rohiṇyudayāsattyā vyāpta iti tau tathaiva gamayati /
analyzed: tathā kṛttikā udayaḥ vyadhikaraṇayā eva rohiṇī udaya āsattyā vyāptaḥ iti tau tathā eva gamayati
translated: in the same way, the rising of the Kṛttikā star is pervaded by the non-existence of the rising of the Rohiṇī star, even though they have different substrata. Therefore, they indicate each other in the same way.

original: yathā ca sāmānādhikaraṇye 'pyasti pradeśādiniyamastathā vaiyadhikaraṇye 'pīti ko doṣaḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca sāmānādhikaraṇye pi asti pradeśa ādi niyamaḥ tathā vaiyadhikaraṇye pi iti kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: And just as there is restriction by place, etc. even in co-substantiality, why should it not be so in the case of different substrata?

original: tasmādyatredaṃ tatredamitivadyadedaṃ tadedamitivat yadevaṃ tadevamitivacca yadīdaṃ tarhīdamiti vyāptisambhavāt /
analyzed: tasmāt yatra idam tatra idam itivat yadā idam tadā idam itivat yat evam tat evam itivat ca yadi idam tarhi idam iti vyāpti sambhavāt
translated: Therefore, just as the statement wherever this is, this is and whatever this is, this is and whatever is thus, that is thus and if this is, then this is, so too the pervasion is possible.

analyzed: vyāpti anurodhena eva hetu siddheḥ āvaśyaka tayā pakṣa dharma tā anāvaśyaka tva ādi uktam vyadhikaraṇasya api hetu tvam iti
translated: Because the establishment of the reason is necessary only in accordance with the pervasion, and the property of being a property of the subject is not necessary, it is proper for a reason to have a different substratum.

analyzed: tathā sādhya viśeṣaṇasya aprasiddhau api
translated: Similarly, even when the qualifier of the probandum is not well-known,

analyzed: tathā hi  sādhya viśeṣaṇa śa prasiddheḥ kutas dūṣaṇa tvāt
translated: It is like this.🔽How can it be a fault because the qualifier of the probandum is not well-known?

original: kiṃ viśvaṃ sadasadvilakṣaṇaṃ bādhyatvādityāderapi prāmāṇyaprasaṅgāt /🔽uta sādhyaviśeṣaṇāprasiddhau tatsandehānupapattau pakṣatvānupapatterhetoḥ pakṣadharmatvānupapattiprasakteḥ /🔽athavā sādhyaviśeṣaṇāprasiddhau tena sādhanasya vyāptipratītyanupapattiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: kim viśvam sat asat vilakṣaṇam bādhya tvāt ityādeḥ api prāmāṇya prasaṅgāt  uta sādhya viśeṣaṇa aprasiddhau tad sandeha anupapattau pakṣa tva anupapatteḥ hetoḥ pakṣa dharma tva anupapatti prasakteḥ  athavā sādhya viśeṣaṇa aprasiddhau tena sādhanasya vyāpti pratīti anupapatti prasaṅgāt
translated: Is it because it would follow that even the argument The universe is different from existent and non-existent because it is an object of knowledge would be valid?🔽Or, when the qualifier of the probandum is not well-known, because the doubt about it is not possible, the property of being a property of the subject of the reason would be suspected to be impossible because the subject is not possible.🔽Or, when the qualifier of the probandum is not well-known, because the understanding of the pervasion of the proof by it is not possible, it would follow that the argument is not a proof.

analyzed: yat vā pratijñā vākyasya apratīta padārthaka tvena abodhaka tva āpatteḥ
translated: Or, because the sentence of the thesis would be non-informative due to having a meaning of a word that is not well-known.

original: ādyaṃ dūṣayati anyaditi //🔽anyat sadasatorviśvamiti ca vyāhateramā // / / //
analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati anyat iti  anyat sat asatoḥ viśvam iti ca vyāhateḥ amā
translated: He refutes the first by saying other etc.🔽Because it is contradicted by saying the universe is other than existent and non-existent,

analyzed: sat na bhavati iti ukte sattvam uktam bhavet syāt sa
translated: When it is said it is not existent, non-existence would be stated, because existence would be.

analyzed: sattva pratikṣepa rūpa tvāt asattvasya
translated: Because non-existence has the form of the negation of existence.

analyzed: punar asat na bhavati iti ukte sva vacana vyāhatiḥ
translated: If it is said again that it is not non-existent, there is self-contradiction in one's own statement.

original: evamasanna bhavatītyuktyā dvau nañau prakṛtamarthaṃ sātiśayaṃ gamayata iti sattvaṃ labhyate /
analyzed: evam asat na bhavati iti uktyā dvau nañau prakṛtam artham sa atiśayam gamayataḥ iti sattvam labhyate
translated: Thus, by saying it is not non-existent, the two negative particles convey the primary meaning with excellence, so existence is obtained.

analyzed: punar sat na bhavati iti ukte sva vyāhatiḥ eva
translated: If it is said again that it is not existent, there is self-contradiction again.

original: tadevaṃ viśvaṃ sadasatoḥ sakāśādanyat sadasacca na bhavatītyeṣā pratijñā svavyāhatereva amā'pramā🔽sādhanāṅgaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: tat evam viśvam sat asatoḥ sakāśāt anyat sat asat ca na bhavati iti eṣā pratijñā sva vyāhateḥ eva amā apramā  sādhana aṅgam na bhavati
translated: Thus, this proposition that the universe is different from existence and non-existence and is neither existent nor non-existent is invalid due to self-contradiction alone, not due to being a means of proof.

analyzed: na tu viśeṣaṇasya sat asat vailakṣaṇya lakṣaṇasya aprasiddha tvena
translated: But not due to the unestablishedness of the qualification characterized by being different from existence and non-existence.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why is that?

original: svavyāhatirhi me mātā vandhyetyādau dūṣaṇatvena sampratipannā /
analyzed: sva vyāhatiḥ hi me mātā vandhyā ityādau dūṣaṇa tvena sampratipannā
translated: For self-contradiction is recognized as a fault in statements like my mother is barren.

analyzed: sva vacana sva nyāya sva kriyā sva siddhānta pramāṇa antara apratihatāyāḥ eva ukteḥ sādhana dūṣaṇa aṅga tvāt
translated: Because only what is not contradicted by one's own statement, one's own reasoning, one's own action, one's own established doctrine, or other means of knowledge is a part of the proof or refutation.

analyzed: nahi sva viṣa vimūrchitā bhujaṅgī param daśati
translated: For a snake that is stupefied by its own poison does not bite another.

original: naca doṣāntarāsaṅkīrṇaṃ sādhyaviśeṣaṇāsiddherudāharaṇaṃ paśyāmo yena doṣatvaṃ pratīmaḥ /
analyzed: na ca doṣa antara asaṅkīrṇam sādhya viśeṣaṇa asiddheḥ udāharaṇam paśyāmaḥ yena doṣa tvam pratīmaḥ
translated: And we do not see an example of the non-establishedness of the qualification of the probandum that is not mixed with other faults, by which we would recognize it as a fault.

original: kasyacidasādhāraṇadharmeṇa śaśaviṣāṇādimattvasādhanamapi pramāṇaṃ kinna syāditi cenna /
analyzed: kasyacid asādhāraṇa dharmeṇa śaśaviṣāṇa ādimattva sādhanam api pramāṇam kin na syāt iti ced na
translated: If it be said that for some (person) the proof of the existence of horns on the head of a hare by a property peculiar to it may also be a means of valid knowledge, (we say) no.

analyzed: tatra api dṛśya anupalambha bādhasya vidyamāna tvāt
translated: Because there also the contradiction by the non-apprehension of the perceptible is present.

original: atīndriyasaṃsagarsādhane na ko 'pi doṣa iti cenna /
analyzed: na kaḥ pi doṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that there is no fault at all in the proof of the connection with the supersensible (object), (we say) no.

analyzed: īśvara ādi saṃsargeṇa siddha sādhana tvāt
translated: Because the probandum is established by the connection with God, etc.

analyzed: evam anyatra api sampratipanna aprāmāṇye doṣa antaram anveṣaṇīyam
translated: In the same way, in other cases also, another fault should be sought in the well-known invalidity (of the reason).

analyzed: tat idam uktam caśabdena
translated: This is what is said by the word 'ca' (and).

analyzed: atas eva vyāhateḥ iti upalakṣaṇam  dvitīyam parācaṣṭe asiddha iti
translated: For this very reason, the word 'vyāhata' (contradicted) is a mere illustration.🔽He explains the second (objection) with the words 'What fault is there in proving the unestablished?'

original: asiddhasādhane doṣaḥ ko vyāptiryadi vidyate // / / //🔽sādhyāprasiddhayā yatra pakṣadharmatvāsiddhirucyatehetau
analyzed: asiddha sādhane doṣaḥ kaḥ vyāptiḥ yadi vidyate  sādhya aprasiddhayā yatra pakṣa dharma tva asiddhiḥ ucyate hetau
translated: If there is pervasion, what fault is there in proving the unestablished?🔽Where the non-establishment of the property of the subject in the reason is said due to the non-establishment of the probandum,

original: tatra vyāptyādītarāṅgasākalyamasti na vā /🔽na cettata evānumānaṃ duṣyaṃ kiṃ sādhyaviśeṣaṇāprasiddhayā /
analyzed: tatra vyāpti ādi itara aṅga sākalyam asti na vā  na ced tatas eva anumānam duṣyam kim sādhya viśeṣaṇa aprasiddhayā
translated: there is the completeness of the other parts such as pervasion or not?🔽If not, then the inference is faulty from that itself. What is the use of the non-establishment of the qualified probandum?

original: yadi vyāptyādikaṃ vidyate tadāsiddhasādhane ko doṣaḥ /
analyzed: yadi vyāpti ādikam vidyate tadā asiddha sādhane kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: If there is pervasion, etc., then what fault is there in proving the unestablished?

analyzed: na kaḥ pi
translated: None at all.

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intention.

analyzed: hetoḥ hi pakṣa dharma tva asiddhiḥ tadā syāt
translated: For the non-establishment of the property of the subject in the reason would be then,

original: yadi dharmī vā hetostaddharmatvaṃ vā na syāt /
analyzed: yadi dharmī vā hetoḥ tad dharma tvam vā na syāt
translated: if either the subject or the property of the reason were not to exist.

analyzed: sandeha abhāvena pakṣa dharma tva asiddhiḥ tadā syāt
translated: The non-establishment of the property of the subject by the absence of doubt would be then,

original: yadi dharmī vā hetostaddharmatvaṃ vā na syāt /
analyzed: yadi dharmī vā hetoḥ tad dharma tvam vā na syāt
translated: if either the subject or the property of the reason were not to exist.

analyzed: sandeha abhāvena pakṣa tva anupapattyā pakṣa dharma tva
translated: By the impossibility of the subject due to the absence of doubt, the non-establishment of the property of the subject

analyzed: tad abhāve tu sva artha anumāna viśeṣa vilopaḥ syāt
translated: But if that were not so, there would be the loss of the particularity of inference for one's own sake.

original: yadā hi yo dhūmavānasāvagnimāniti gṛhītavyāptiko giriśekhare dhūmaṃ paśyanvyāptiṃ smarati /
analyzed: yadā hi yaḥ dhūmavān asau agnimān iti gṛhīta vyāptikaḥ giriśekhare dhūmam paśyan vyāptim smarati
translated: When one who has grasped the pervasion thus, That which has smoke has fire, sees smoke on the peak of a mountain, he remembers the pervasion.

analyzed: tadā utpadyate eva asya anumitiḥ
translated: Then his inference arises.

analyzed: na ca tasya agni sandehaḥ sti
translated: And he does not have doubt about fire.

analyzed: yadā ca āpta vacanāt viniścita parvata agni sambandhaḥ parvatam pratyāsīdan dhūmam avalokayati
translated: And when one who has ascertained the relation of mountain and fire from the words of a reliable person sees smoke on the mountain as it approaches,

analyzed: tadā api tasya vinā sandehena agni anumitiḥ bhavati eva
translated: then for him the inference of fire occurs even without doubt.

analyzed: nahi sāmagrī buddhimatī
translated: For a collection of causes is not intelligent.

original: yena yanmayā kartavyaṃ tadanyena kṛtamiti paryālocyodāsīta /
analyzed: yena yat mayā kartavyam tat anyena kṛtam iti paryālocya udāsīta
translated: By which it would consider, That which is to be done by me has been done by another, and remain inactive.

original: nāpi chinne chidāyā iva paricchinne paricchedāntarotpādo 'yuktaḥvaktuṃ na śakyaḥ /
analyzed: na api chinne chidāyāḥ iva paricchinne pariccheda antara utpādaḥ yuktaḥ vaktum na śakyaḥ
translated: Nor is it proper to say that when something is delimited, another delimitation arises, like when something is cut, another cutting.

analyzed: na api para artha anumāne sandeha niyamaḥ
translated: And in inference for others, there is no restriction on doubt.

analyzed: viparyastasya api prativādi tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because even one who is mistaken can be a respondent.

original: ata eva siddhasādhako 'saṅgata eva nāśrayāsiddha ityuktam /
analyzed: atas eva siddha sādhakaḥ saṅgataḥ eva na āśraya asiddhaḥ iti uktam
translated: For this very reason, it is said that the inconclusive reason is not a fallacy of unestablished basis, but rather a fallacy of irrelevance.

analyzed: kiñca yadā para parīkṣā artham
translated: Moreover, even one who knows the truth, when for the sake of examining others,

analyzed: tatra pramāṇam pṛcchati
translated: asks about the means of knowledge in a matter,

analyzed: tadā prayuktam anumānam amānam syāt
translated: then the inference employed would be invalid.

analyzed: sandeha abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no doubt.

original: tasmātsandigdhasādhyaḥ pakṣa ityādyāḥ prācāṃ vācaḥ sambhāvanābhiprāyāḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt sandigdha sādhyaḥ pakṣaḥ ityādyāḥ prācām vācaḥ sambhāvanā abhiprāyāḥ
translated: Therefore, the statements of the ancients such as the subject is doubtful regarding the probandum are intended to express possibility.

analyzed: paramārthataḥ tu anumiti viṣayaḥ eva pakṣaḥ
translated: But in reality, the subject is only the object of inference.

original: ataḥ sandehābhāve pakṣatvānupapattyabhāvānnāprasiddhasādhane pakṣadharmatvāsiddhirūpo doṣa iti / /🔽tṛtīyaṃ nirākaroti vyāptiśceti //
analyzed: atas sandeha abhāve pakṣa tva anupapatti abhāvāt na aprasiddha sādhane pakṣa dharma tva asiddhi rūpaḥ doṣaḥ iti  tṛtīyam nirākaroti vyāptiḥ ca iti
translated: Therefore, in the absence of doubt, there is no impossibility of being a subject. Hence, in an unestablished proof, there is no fallacy in the form of unestablished property of the subject.🔽He refutes the third view with And the pervasion is understood by them through the negative example.

analyzed: vyāptiḥ ca vyatirekeṇa tatra taiḥ ca eva gamyate
translated: And the pervasion is understood by them through the negative example.

analyzed: tatra jīvāt śarīra jātam sātmakam prāṇa ādimat tvāt
translated: There, the living body is with a soul, because it has life etc.

analyzed: bhūri itarebhyaḥ bhidyate gandhavat tvāt
translated: Earth is distinguished from the others because it has smell.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ sarvajñaḥ kevala vyatirekiṇi sādhana samūhe
translated: In the case of the collection of reasons like God is omniscient because he is the creator of everything, which are purely negative,

analyzed: taiḥ aprasiddhaiḥ api sātmaka tva ādibhiḥ sādhyaiḥ
translated: even though the probandum, such as having a soul, is not well-known,

analyzed: vyāptiḥ ca asti
translated: there is still pervasion.

analyzed: na kevalam pakṣa dharma tā
translated: And it is not just the property of the subject.

original: vyatirekeṇa sādhyābhāvasya sādhanābhāvavyāptatvena liṅgenāvagamyate ca sā /
analyzed: vyatirekeṇa sādhya abhāvasya sādhana abhāva vyāpta tvena liṅgena avagamyate ca sā
translated: By the negative concomitance, the absence of the probandum is pervaded by the absence of the reason, and that is understood by the inferential mark.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

analyzed: sādhya viśeṣaṇa aprasiddhayā vyāpti pratīti abhāvam prasajjayataḥ vyāpti abhāvaḥ
translated: For one who maintains that the absence of the cognition of pervasion results from the non-establishment of the qualification of the probandum, there is an absence of pervasion.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: kevala vyatireki anumānam pramāṇam na vā
translated: Is inference based solely on negative concomitance a valid means of knowledge or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣe vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: If not, we will say.

analyzed: ādye tasya vyāpti sadbhāvaḥ vyāpti avagamaḥ ca avaśyam aṅgī
translated: If the former, then the existence of pervasion and the cognition of pervasion must necessarily be accepted.

analyzed: śca aṅgīkāryaḥ
translated: And that must be accepted.

analyzed: anyathā anumāna tva vyāghātāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be a contradiction with being an inference.

analyzed: na ca kevala vyatirekiṇi sādhyam prasiddham
translated: And the probandum is not well-known in the case of a purely negative inference.

analyzed: pakṣe prasiddhau siddha sādhana tvāt
translated: If it is well-known in the subject, then it is a case of proving what is already established.

analyzed: anyatra prasiddhau kevala vyatirekiṇi sādhyam prasiddham
translated: If it is well-known elsewhere, then the probandum is well-known in the case of a purely negative inference.

analyzed: pakṣe prasiddhau siddha sādhana tvāt
translated: If it is well-known in the subject, then it is a case of proving what is already established.

analyzed: anyatra prasiddhau kevala vyatirekiṇi sādhyam prasiddham
translated: If it is well-known elsewhere, then in a purely negative inference, the probandum is well-known.

analyzed: pakṣe prasiddhau siddha sādhana tvāt
translated: If it is well-known in the subject, then it is a case of proving what is already established.

analyzed: anyatra prasiddhau tatra hetoḥ vṛttau kevala vyatireki tva anupapatteḥ
translated: If it is well-known elsewhere, then if the reason occurs there, it cannot be a purely negative inference.

analyzed: avṛttau asādhāraṇya prasaṅgāt
translated: If it does not occur, then it is a fallacy of the reason being not common to the subject.

original: ataḥ praśithilamūlaḥ prasaṅgaḥ vyatirekiṇaḥ kva vyāptiḥ kena cāvagamyata iti cet /
analyzed: atas praśithila mūlaḥ prasaṅgaḥ vyatirekiṇaḥ kva vyāptiḥ kena ca avagamyate iti ced
translated: Therefore, this consequence has a loose foundation. If it is asked where is the pervasion of the purely negative inference and by whom is it known,

analyzed: pakṣaḥ eva vyatirekeṇa avagamyate iti brūmaḥ
translated: we say it is known by the negative method in the subject itself.

analyzed: pakṣa ādi pravibhāgāt prāk avagatā tatra eva vipratipattyā upadarśayitum aśakyā vyatirekeṇa upapādyate iti
translated: Before the distinction of subject etc. is known, it cannot be shown there due to disagreement. It is established by the negative method.

analyzed: taiḥ iti bahuvacanena ati prasiddha tām prasaṅga vyāpti bhaṅgasya sūcayati
translated: By using the plural they, he indicates the great fame of the breaking of the pervasion by consequence.

original: na kevalaṃ kevalavyatirekisādhanasya sādhyena vyāptirvyatirekeṇa tadavagamaścāsmābhirevāṅgīkriyate /
analyzed: na kevalam kevala vyatireki sādhanasya sādhyena vyāptiḥ vyatirekeṇa tad avagamaḥ ca asmābhiḥ evā aṅgīkriyate
translated: It is not only the pervasion of the probandum by the purely negative proof that is accepted by us,

analyzed: kintu aprasiddha viśeṣaṇatva dūṣaṇatva vādibhiḥ api kaiścid iti āha taiḥ ca iti
translated: but also by some who argue that the fault of the qualifier being not well-known is a fault of the reason. He says they and so on.

analyzed: avagamyate abhyupagamyate
translated: Is understood, is accepted.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ
translated: As they say:

original: yadi sādhyenāsya kvacidapyanvayo nāsti tadā viruddha evāyamityāśaṅkaya nopeyatvamanvayasya vyāsedhāmo 'pi tūpāyami
analyzed: yadi sādhyena asya kvacid api anvayaḥ na asti tadā viruddhaḥ eva ayam iti āśaṅkaya na upeyatvam anvayasya tu
translated: If there is no anvaya (positive concomitance) of this [reason] with anything to be established, then it is indeed contradictory. Fearing this, we do not deny anvaya, but we do deny upāyāmi.

analyzed: ya tvam ityādi
translated: Yatva (having that) and so on.

analyzed: tathā yathā ca vyatireka balāt anvaya siddhiḥ tathā vaiśeṣikaiḥ api upapādanīyam
translated: Similarly, the Vaiśeṣikas should also explain how the anvaya (positive concomitance) is established by the power of vyatireka (negative concomitance).

analyzed: anyathā sādhya sādhanayoḥ avyāptau vyatirekiṇaḥ gamaka tva bhaṅgāt ityādi
translated: Otherwise, if there is no pervasion of the thesis and the reason, there would be a breakdown of the inferential nature of the vyatireki (negative example), and so on.

original: tathā cāprasiddhaviśeṣaṇasyāpi kevalavyatirekiṇo vyāptyupapādanamaprasiddhaviśeṣaṇatve vyāptyapratītiprasañjanaṃ ca kathaṃ na vyāhatamiti bhāvaḥ🔽yaduktaṃ kevalavyatirekiṇo vyāptyavagamātparairabhyupagamācca nāprasiddhaviśeṣaṇatve 'pi vyāptyavagamātparairabhyupagamācca nāprasiddhaviśeṣaṇatve
analyzed: tathā ca aprasiddha viśeṣaṇasya api kevala vyatirekiṇaḥ vyāpti upapādanam aprasiddha viśeṣaṇa tve vyāpti apratīti prasañjanam ca katham na vyāhatam iti bhāvaḥ  yat uktam kevala vyatirekiṇaḥ vyāpti avagamāt paraiḥ abhyupagamāt ca na aprasiddha viśeṣaṇa tve vyāpti avagamāt paraiḥ abhyupagamāt ca na aprasiddha viśeṣaṇa tve
translated: And thus, how is it not contradictory to explain the pervasion of the mere vyatireki (negative example) even when the qualifier is not well-known, and to argue that if the qualifier is not well-known, the pervasion is not understood?

analyzed: pi vyāpti anavagatiḥ iti
translated: What was said, that the pervasion of the mere vyatireki (negative example) is not understood because it is accepted by others, and that even when the qualifier is not well-known, the pervasion is not understood because it is accepted by others,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: is not correct.

analyzed: yatas kevala vyatirekiṇī anyā eva gatiḥ
translated: Because the understanding of the mere vyatireki (negative example) is different.

analyzed: ye hi sampratipanna pramāṇa bhāvāḥ kevala vyatirekiṇaḥ teṣu sāmānyatas nvaya vyāptiḥ eva abhidhātavyā
translated: In those cases where only the negative concomitance is admitted, the positive concomitance should be stated in a general way.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For example,

analyzed: prāṇa ādimattvena jīvat śarīrasya sātmaka tve sādhye yat yat kāryavat tat tat kāraṇavat yathā ahaṅkuravatī bhūmiḥ bīja garbhā iti
translated: when the living body's possession of life, etc. is being proved to show that it has a soul, it is said: Whatever is efficacious has a cause, like a sprout, which is contained in the earth, which is pregnant with the seed.

original: yatathā gandhavattvena bhuvo 'nyabhedasādhane yadyadasādhāraṇadharmavattattato bhidyate yathā abādīti /
analyzed: gandhavat tvena bhuvaḥ ni abheda sādhane yat yat asādhāraṇa dharmavat tat tatas bhidyate yathā ap ādi iti
translated: Similarly, when the earth's difference from other things is being proved by its having smell, it is said: Whatever has an uncommon property is different from that, like water, etc.

original: evamīśvarasya sarvakartṛtvena sārvajñasādhane yo yasya kartā sa tasya kāraṇaṃ prayojanaṃ ca jānāti /🔽yathā kulāla iti /
analyzed: evam īśvarasya sarva kartṛ tvena sārvajña sādhane yaḥ yasya kartā sa tasya kāraṇam prayojanam ca jānāti  yathā kulālaḥ iti
translated: In the same way, when the omniscience of God is being proved by His being the creator of all, it is said: He who is the creator of something knows the cause and purpose of that, like a potter.

analyzed: evam śabdaḥ pṛthivī ādi aṣṭa dravya atirikta dravya āśritaḥ pṛthivī ādi vṛttau bādhaka upapanna tve
translated: In the same way, when sound is being proved to inhere in a substance other than the eight substances like earth, because it is a quality that is not contradicted in the occurrence of earth, etc.,

original: sati guṇatvādityādau yo yadvṛttau bādhakopapannatve sati guṇaḥ sa tato 'nyadravyavṛttiryathā
analyzed: sati guṇa tvāt ityādau yaḥ yad vṛttau bādhaka upapanna tve sati guṇaḥ sa tatas nyadravya vṛttiḥ yathā
translated: it is said: Whatever is a quality that is not contradicted in the occurrence of something is inherent in a different substance from that, like smell.

analyzed: gandhaḥ ityādi rūpeṇa sāmānyataḥ vyāptiḥ abhidhātavyā
translated: In this way, the general concomitance should be stated in the form of an example.

original: yadvā sāmānyato viśeṣaṇaprasiddhiṃ vidhāya kevalavyatirekī prayoktavyaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā sāmānyatas viśeṣaṇa prasiddhim vidhāya kevala vyatirekī prayoktavyaḥ
translated: Or, having established the general and particular well-known properties, the purely negative [reason] should be employed.

original: yathā jñānatāratamyaṃ kvacidviśrāntaṃ tāratamyatvādityanena sāmānyataḥ sārvajñasiddhau tasyeśvarasambandhaḥ kevalavyatirekiṇā sādhyate /
analyzed: yathā jñāna tāratamyam kvacid viśrāntam tāratamya tvāt iti anena sāmānyatas sārvajña siddhau tasya īśvara sambandhaḥ kevala vyatirekiṇā sādhyate
translated: For example, after establishing omniscience in general by [the reason] The gradation of knowledge must rest somewhere, because it is gradation, the connection of that [omniscience] with God is to be proved by a purely negative [reason].

analyzed: tathā icchā ādayaḥ kvacid āśritāḥ guṇa tvāt rūpa vat
translated: Similarly, Will and so on must rest on something, because they are qualities, like color.

original: yaścecchādīnāmāśrayaḥ sa evātmeti sāmānyenātmasiddhau tatsambandho jīvaccharīrasya kevalavyatirekiṇā sādhyate /
analyzed: yaḥ ca icchā ādīnām āśrayaḥ saḥ eva ātmā iti sāmānyena ātma siddhau tad sambandhaḥ jīvat śarīrasya kevala vyatirekiṇā sādhyate
translated: And the connection of that [support of will and so on] with the living body is to be proved by a purely negative [reason], after establishing the self in general by [the reason] That which is the support of will and so on is the self.

analyzed: evam anyatra api yathāsambhavam ūhyam
