analyzed: atha vastre kardamena iva ātmani deha upādhinā kṛtam kārṣṇyam asti iti pratīti sambhāvanā vivakṣitā tatra āha yadi iti
translated: If it is argued that just as blackness is produced in the cloth by the limiting adjunct of mud, so blackness is produced in the self by the limiting adjunct of the body, then the answer is If it is so, etc.

analyzed: yadi upādhi kṛtam tadā
translated: If it is due to an adventitious property, then...

original: yadi vastra ivātmani dehopādhikṛtaṃ kārṣṇyamastīti tatpratītiḥ sambhāvyate tadā pratyakṣapratītasyānumānādinā bādha ityatra nedamudāharaṇamiti
analyzed: yadi vastre iva ātmani deha upādhi kṛtam kārṣṇyam asti iti tad pratītiḥ sambhāvyate tadā pratyakṣa pratītasya anumāna ādinā bādhaḥ iti atra na idam udāharaṇam iti
translated: If it is possible to have the cognition that blackness in the self is due to the adventitious property of the body, like in a cloth, then this is not an example of the contradiction of what is perceived by perception by inference etc.

analyzed: śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is implied.

analyzed: katham iti atas āha svatas iti
translated: How is it so? Therefore it is said: naturally.

original: svataḥ śuklatvavat kārṣṇyaṃ na mameti pratīyate // / / //
analyzed: svatas śukla tva vat kārṣṇyam na mama iti pratīyate
translated: Blackness is perceived as not mine, like natural whiteness.

analyzed: atra dṛṣṭānte dārṣya antike ca eka deśa utkīrtanena anyat api upalakṣyate
translated: In this example and in the illustrated case, other things are also indicated by the mention of a part.

analyzed: tathā ca ayam arthaḥ
translated: And the meaning is this.

analyzed: vastre khalu kārṣṇyam kardama upādhi kṛtam aupādhikam
translated: In a cloth, blackness is adventitious, produced by the adventitious property of mud.

analyzed: pratīyamānam evam pratyetavyam
translated: When it is perceived, it should be cognized thus.

analyzed: svatiḥ śuklam eva idam vastram na kṛṣṇam
translated: This cloth is naturally white only, not black.

analyzed: kārṣṇyantu upādhi kṛtam iti
translated: But blackness is produced by an adventitious property.

analyzed: tathā atrā api svatas nīrūpaḥ eva aham
translated: Similarly here also, I am naturally formless only.

original: kārṣṇyaṃ tu na mama svabhāvataḥ /🔽kintu dehopādhikṛtamiti pratīyata ityaṅgīkartavyam /
analyzed: kārṣṇyam tu na mama svabhāvataḥ  kintu deha upādhi kṛtam iti pratīyate iti aṅgīkartavyam
translated: But blackness is not my nature.🔽But it is produced by the adventitious property of the body. This is how it is perceived. This should be accepted.

analyzed: tathā ca asyāḥ pratīteḥ yathārtha tvāt na anumāna ādinā atas bādhaḥ iti
translated: And thus, since this perception is true, it is not contradicted by inference etc.

analyzed: yat uktam deha ātma tā pratītiḥ nā asti dehaḥ ham iti pratīti ananubhavāt iti tat asat
translated: What was said, that the cognition of the identity of the body and the self does not exist because the cognition of 'I am the body' is not experienced, is not correct.

analyzed: aham iti pratīteḥ eva tad pratīti tvāt  idam an idam rūpa vastu garbhaḥ hi ahaṅkāraḥ
translated: Because the cognition of 'I' itself is the cognition of that [identity].

analyzed: yat ca uktam mama dehaḥ iti
translated: For the notion of 'I' contains the thing that is the object of the notion of 'this' and 'that'.🔽And what was said, that the appearance of the identity of the body and the self is not possible because of the cognition of difference in the expression 'my body' and

analyzed: ti anuvṛtteḥ deha ātma tva pratibhāsaḥ nu papannaḥ iti
translated: because of the non-recurrence [of the cognition of identity], is not correct.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: bheda pratīti asampratipatteḥ
translated: Because there is no agreement on the cognition of difference.

original: mama deha iti vyavahārasya mama svarūpamitivadaupacārikatvopapatteḥ /
analyzed: mama dehaḥ iti vyavahārasya mama sva rūpam iti vat aupacārika tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because the usage 'my body' is possible as figurative, like 'my own form'.

analyzed: na khalu kevale dehe ātma tva pratītiḥ
translated: Indeed, the cognition of the self is not only in the mere body.

analyzed: kintarhi deha indriya antaḥkaraṇa ādi saṅghāte
translated: But rather in the aggregate of body, senses, internal organ, and so on.

original: tatra saṅghātāpekṣayā dehamātre sambandhapratītirapi na bādhikā /
analyzed: tatra saṅghāta apekṣayā deha mātre sambandha pratītiḥ api na bādhikā
translated: There, the cognition of relation to the mere body in relation to the aggregate is also not contradictory.

analyzed: prasādasya stambho
translated: The pillar of the satisfaction.

analyzed: vṛkṣasya śākhā iti yathā
translated: Like the branch of the tree.

analyzed: na ca deha indriya ādeḥ ātmanaḥ ca bheda avabhāse sphuṭam pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no clear evidence for the appearance of difference between the body, senses, and so on, and the self.

analyzed: yena deha ādi ātma pratītiḥ virudhyeta
translated: By which the cognition of the self in the body and so on would be contradicted.

analyzed: yat api uktam kṛṣṇaḥ ham ityādi rūpa deha ādi dharmāṇām ātma niṣṭha pratītiḥ na asti pramāṇa abhāvāt iti
translated: As for what was said that there is no cognition of the attributes of the body etc. as belonging to the self in the form I am Krishna etc., because there is no means of valid knowledge,

analyzed: tat na
translated: that is not so.

analyzed: kṛṣṇaḥ ham iti vyavahāra darśanāt  jñāna mūla tā khalu vyavahārasya utsargataḥ siddhā
translated: Because the usage I am Krishna is seen.🔽Indeed, the root of usage is established by nature.

analyzed: tad anupapattau tu upacāra tva kalpanā
translated: But when that is not possible, the assumption of figurative usage is made.

analyzed: na ca na aham kṛṣṇaḥ ityādi rūpā pratītiḥ asti
translated: And there is no cognition in the form I am not Krishna etc.

analyzed: yad bhayāt upacāra tvam kalpayāmaḥ
translated: Out of fear of which we assume figurative usage.

analyzed: atas bheda ādi pratīti abhāvāt asti eva ubhayī pratītiḥ
translated: Therefore, due to the absence of cognition of difference etc., the twofold cognition certainly exists.

analyzed: yathā āha
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: anyonyasmin anyonya ātmaka tām anyonya dharmān ca adhyasya iti
translated: Superimposing on each other the nature of each other and the attributes of each other.

original: pratyakṣajā ceyaṃ pratītiriti kathaṃ pratyakṣasiddhasya nānumānādinā bādha ityata āha kathaṃ ceti /
analyzed: pratyakṣa jā ca iyam pratītiḥ iti katham pratyakṣa siddhasya na anumāna ādinā bādhaḥ iti atas āha katham ca iti
translated: And this cognition is produced by perception. How then is what is established by perception not contradicted by inference etc.? To this he says How then etc.

original: kathaṃ ca bhedo dehāderātmano na pramīyate // / / //🔽bhedaśabdenāsaṃsargo 'pi gṛhyate /
analyzed: katham ca bhedaḥ deha ādeḥ ātmanaḥ na pramīyate  bheda śabdena a saṃsargaḥ pi gṛhyate
translated: And how is the difference of the body etc. from the self not cognized?🔽By the word difference, non-association is also included.

original: dehādiśabdena saṅghātastaddharmāśca /🔽yadā dehāderiti pañcamī tadā'tmana iti ṣaṣṭhī /
analyzed: deha ādi śabdena saṅghātaḥ tad dharmāḥ ca 🔽yadā deha ādeḥ iti pañcamī tadā ātmanaḥ iti ṣaṣṭhī
translated: By the word body etc., the aggregate and its attributes are meant.🔽When the ablative case is used with from the body etc., then the genitive case is used with of the self.

original: yadā cātmana iti pañcamī tadā dehāderiti ṣaṣṭhī /
analyzed: yadā ca ātmanaḥ iti pañcamī tadā deha ādeḥ iti ṣaṣṭhī
translated: And when the fifth case 'of the self' is used, then the sixth case 'of the body etc.' is used.

analyzed: anyonya āropasya pareṇa ukta tvāt
translated: Because mutual superimposition has been stated by the opponent.

original: dehādisaṅghātasyātmanaścānyonyaṃ bhedastaddharmāṇāṃ ca parasparamasaṃsargaḥ pratīyata evetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: deha ādi saṅghātasya ātmanaḥ ca anyonyam bhedaḥ tad dharmāṇām ca parasparam a saṃsargaḥ pratīyate eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the difference between the aggregate of body etc. and the self, and the non-connection of their attributes with each other, is indeed understood.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha jāta mātrāḥ iti
translated: How is that? In response to this, he says 'as soon as born'.

original: jātamātrā mṛgā gāvo hastinaḥ pakṣiṇo khaṣāḥ /
analyzed: jāta mātrāḥ mṛgāḥ gāvaḥ hastinaḥ pakṣiṇaḥ khasāḥ
translated: As soon as born, deer, cows, elephants, birds, insects,

analyzed: bhaya abhaya sva bhoga ādau kāraṇāni vijānate
translated: know the causes in fear, non-fear, their own enjoyment, etc.

original: jātā eva na tu vyāpārāntaraṃ kṛtavantaḥ /
analyzed: jātāḥ eva na tu vyāpāra antaram kṛtavantaḥ
translated: They know even when born, not having done any other operation.

analyzed: bhujyate iti bhogaḥ sukham
translated: Enjoyment is happiness, that which is enjoyed.

analyzed: ādi padena duḥkham
translated: By the word 'etc.' suffering is included.

analyzed: siṃha vyāghra ādīni bhaya kāraṇāni
translated: Lions, tigers, etc. are the causes of fear.

analyzed: mātrā ādīni abhaya kāraṇāni
translated: Mothers, etc. are the causes of non-fear.

analyzed: stana pāna ādīni sukha kāraṇāni
translated: Suckling at the breast, etc. are the causes of happiness.

analyzed: śaṅku ādinā nayana antar kaṇḍūyana ādīni duḥkha kāraṇāni iti vijānate
translated: Scratching inside the eyes with a pin, etc. are the causes of suffering.

analyzed: atas eva siṃha ādi dhvani mātreṇa palāyante
translated: For this very reason, they run away merely at the sound of a lion, etc.

analyzed: mātrā ādīni ca upasarpanti  stana pāna ādi artham pravartante
translated: And they approach their mothers, etc.🔽They engage in sucking at the breast, etc. for the sake of happiness.

analyzed: varjayanti śaṅku kaṇḍūyana ādīni
translated: They avoid scratching inside the eyes with a pin, etc.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha asmṛtau iti
translated: What then? In response to this, he says 'in the absence of memory'.

original: asmṛtau pūrvadehasya vijñānaṃ tat kathaṃ bhavet // / / //
analyzed: asmṛtau pūrva dehasya vijñānam tat katham bhavet
translated: How can there be the cognition of that (fear, etc.) when the previous body is not remembered?

analyzed: tat vijñānam bhaya ādi kāraṇam etat iti vijñānam  pūrva deha asmaraṇe
translated: That cognition of fear, etc. is the cause of this, such is the cognition.

analyzed: katham na bhavet iti atas āha anvaya iti
translated: When there is no remembrance of the previous body, how can that cognition not be made? To this he says 'in the case of...'

analyzed: anvaya vyatireka ādeḥ anusandhāna vismṛtau
translated: In the case of the forgetting of the ascertainment of concomitance and non-concomitance, etc.,

analyzed: ādi padena dṛṣṭānta dharmiṇoḥ grahaṇam
translated: The word 'etc.' includes the example and the subject.

analyzed: yadvādi grahaṇena upadeśaḥ gṛhyate
translated: Or, by the word 'etc.', instruction is included.

analyzed: anvaya vyatireka ādeḥ vismṛtau iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The relation is: in the forgetting of the ascertainment of concomitance and non-concomitance, etc.

analyzed: na kevalam etāvat
translated: Not only this much,

original: kintu tathā cāyamityanusandhanasya ca vismṛtau satyāṃ vijñānaṃ tatkathaṃ bhavediti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: kintu tathā ca ayam iti anusandhanasya ca vismṛtau satyām vijñānam tat katham bhavet iti sambandhaḥ
translated: but also in the case of the forgetting of the ascertainment 'and thus this', how can there be that cognition? Such is the relation.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

original: asti tāvanmṛgādīnāṃ stanapānādau pravṛttiḥ śaṅkukaṇḍūyanādito nivṛttiśca /
analyzed: asti tāvat mṛga ādīnām stana pāna ādau pravṛttiḥ śaṅku kaṇḍūyana āditaḥ nivṛttiḥ ca
translated: There is indeed the engagement of deer, etc. in drinking milk, etc. and the desisting from scratching with horns, etc.

analyzed: tatas numīyate vidyete tatra teṣām rāga dveṣau iti
translated: From that, it is inferred that attachment and aversion exist there in them.

analyzed: rāga dveṣayoḥ eva pravṛtti kāraṇa tvena asmat ādau nirṇīta tvāt
translated: Because attachment and aversion are ascertained in us, etc. as the cause of engagement.

analyzed: rāga dveṣābhyām ca iṣya aniṣya sādhana tva jñānam
translated: And from attachment and aversion, the knowledge of the means of the desirable and the undesirable arises.

analyzed: tasya eva rāga ādi kāraṇatayā niścita tvāt
translated: Because it is certain that it is the cause of passion etc.

analyzed: na ca tat jñānam pratyakṣa sādhyam
translated: And that knowledge is not accomplished by perception.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāvasya atīndriya tvāt  kintu anumāna upadeśa sādhyam eva
translated: Because the relation of cause and effect is beyond the senses.🔽But it is accomplished only by inference and instruction.

analyzed: na ca mṛga ādīnām upadeśaḥ sambhavati
translated: And instruction is not possible for deer etc.

analyzed: anadhikārāt
translated: Because they are not entitled.

analyzed: tasmāt prāgbhavīya upadeśaḥ iti vācyam
translated: Therefore it must be said that it is the instruction of a previous birth.

analyzed: na ca asmṛtaḥ sau tat kāraṇam iti tad smṛti sadbhāvaḥ ṅgīkāryaḥ
translated: And it cannot be the cause of that which is not remembered. Therefore the existence of its memory must be accepted.

analyzed: yat vā anumānam
translated: Or it is inference.

analyzed: na ca tat yat yat stana pānam tat iṣya sādhanam
translated: And that is not so. Whatever is sucking at the breast is the means to the desired goal.

original: yadiṣyasādhanaṃ na bhavati tatstanapānaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: yat iṣya sādhanam na bhavati tat stana pānam na bhavati
translated: What is not the means to the desired goal does not suck at the breast.

analyzed: yathā amukam
translated: Like such and such.

analyzed: stana pānam ca idam iti anvaya ādi smaraṇena vinā bhavati
translated: And this sucking at the breast occurs without the memory of the relation etc.

analyzed: na ca ananubhūte smṛtiḥ utpadyate
translated: And memory does not arise from what has not been experienced.

analyzed: na ca asmin janmani anvaya ādi anubhavaḥ sti
translated: And there is no experience of the relation etc. in this birth.

analyzed: jāta mātrāṇām udāhṛta tvāt  atas janma antara anubhūta anvaya ādi smaraṇam eṣṭavyam
translated: Because it is stated that they suck at the breast as soon as they are born.🔽Therefore the memory of the relation etc. experienced in a previous birth must be accepted.

analyzed: prāk bhavīyasya upadeśasya anvaya ādeḥ ca smaraṇe pūvar deha smaraṇam api aṅgīkartavyam
translated: And when there is memory of the instruction of a previous birth and of the relation etc., the memory of the previous body must also be accepted.

analyzed: samāna yogakṣema tvāt
translated: Because they are of the same nature.

original: naceddehāntarasmaraṇaṃ mṛgādīnāṃ tadā tadaviśiṣyānvayayādismaraṇamapi na syāt /🔽tadabhāve cānumānādyabhāveneṣyāniṣyakāraṇatājñānaṃ notpadyeta /
analyzed: na ced deha antara smaraṇam mṛga ādīnām tadā tad aviśiṣya anvayayā ādi smaraṇam api na syāt  tad abhāve ca anumāna ādi abhāvena iṣya aniṣya kāraṇa tā jñānam na utpadyeta
translated: If there were no memory of a previous body in the case of deer etc., then the memory of their specific relations etc. would also not exist.🔽And in the absence of that, due to the absence of inference etc., the knowledge of the causes of the desirable and undesirable would not arise.

analyzed: tad anutpāde ca rāga ādi anutpādāt pravṛtti ādi anutpadya tadyate
translated: And in the absence of that, due to the absence of attachment etc., activity etc. would not arise.

analyzed: kāraṇa abhāve kārya abhāvasya sulabha tvāt
translated: Because the absence of an effect is easily explained by the absence of its cause.

analyzed: adṛṣṭa vaśāt pravṛtti ādi iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that activity etc. arise due to unseen [forces], that is not so.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa atikrama doṣāt
translated: Because it would violate what is seen.

analyzed: etāvān tu adṛṣṭasya upayogaḥ yat janmāntara anubhūtam sarvam asmaran etāvat smarati
translated: The only use of the unseen is that, not remembering everything experienced in a previous life, one remembers only this much.

analyzed: yādṛcchikam pravṛtti ādi bhavatu iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that activity etc. may occur by chance, that is not so.

analyzed: anantānām tad anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for infinite [beings].

analyzed: atas eva mṛgāḥ iti ādi bahuvacanam
translated: For this very reason, the plural deer etc. is used.

analyzed: astu jāti svabhāvaḥ yam na
translated: Let this be the nature of a particular species. No.

analyzed: bhinna jātīyānām api upalambhāt
translated: Because it is observed even in beings of different species.

analyzed: atas eva mṛgāḥ gāvaḥ ityādi uktam
translated: For this very reason, deer, cows etc. are mentioned.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa atikrama doṣaḥ ca aparihāryaḥ
translated: And the fault of violating what is seen cannot be avoided.

analyzed: tasmāt asti mṛga ādīnām pūrva deha smaraṇam
translated: Therefore, deer etc. do have the memory of their previous bodies.

analyzed: tathā eva mānuṣa ādīnām api iti siddham iti
translated: In the same way, humans etc. also have it. Thus it is established.

original: tathāpi kiṃ prakṛta ityata āha yadeti //
analyzed: tathā api kim prakṛte iti atas āha yadā iti
translated: Still, what is the point? To this he says:
When there is the remembrance of another body, how can there be the ascertainment of identity with the body?

original: yadaivametaddehavartino mama na kevalamayameva dehaḥ kintu tatprāganyo 'pyabhūditi dehāntarasmaraṇaṃ pramitamṇamāpatitam /🔽tadaitaddehena svasyaikyādhya
analyzed: yadā evam etad deha vartinaḥ mama na kevalam ayam eva dehaḥ kintu tad prāk anyaḥ pyabhūt iti deha antara smaraṇam  tadā etat dehena
translated: When this is so, that is, when the remembrance of another body is established, namely, 'not only this body of mine exists, but also another existed before it,'

analyzed: vasāyaḥ kutas syāt
translated: how can there be the ascertainment of identity of oneself with that body?

original: kintvanekamaṇiṣvanusyūtaṃ sūtramivānekadehānusyūtamātmānaṃ paśyataḥ svasya tato 'tyantabhedāvasitireva yuktā /
analyzed: kintu aneka maṇiṣu anusyūtam sūtram iva aneka deha anusyūtam ātmānam paśyataḥ svasya tyanta bheda avasitiḥ eva yuktā
translated: But for one who sees the self as connected to many bodies like a thread running through many beads, it is indeed proper to ascertain the absolute difference of oneself from it.

analyzed: tathā ca kārṣṇya ādīnām a saṃsarga jñānam api
translated: And thus the knowledge of the non-connection of blackness etc. is also well-established.

analyzed: pareṇa deha ādi āropa nibandhana tva abhyupagamāt tad āropasya
translated: Because the superimposition of that is accepted by the opponent as being based on the superimposition of the body etc.

analyzed: ahaṃpratyayaḥ tu na āropaḥ iti prāk eva uktam
translated: But the notion of 'I' is not a superimposition, as has been stated earlier.

original: ato mama deha iti pratyayo nānyathayitavyaḥ kṛṣṇo 'hamityādiścopacāro 'ṅgīkaraṇīya iti /
analyzed: atas mama dehaḥ iti pratyayaḥ na anyathayitavyaḥ kṛṣṇaḥ ham ityādiḥ ca upacāraḥ ṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the notion 'my body' should not be altered, and the figurative usage 'I am black' etc. should be accepted.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be argued:

analyzed: na mukhya artha anupapatti mātrāt upacāraḥ labhyate
translated: Figurative usage is not obtained merely from the non-applicability of the primary meaning.

original: kintu sādṛśye sambandhe vā prayojane ca sati /
analyzed: kintu sādṛśye sambandhe vā prayojane ca sati
translated: But when there is similarity, relation, or purpose,

analyzed: na ca atra sādṛśya ādikam asti
translated: and there is no similarity etc. here,

original: tatkathamayamupacāraḥ /🔽kiñca mṛgādīnāṃ pāmārāṇāṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ ca yadi dehātmabhedajñānaṃ syāttarhinaiṣāṃ mamāhamiti dhīḥ śvasṛgālabhakṣya' /
analyzed: tat katham ayam upacāraḥ  kiñca mṛga ādīnām pāmārāṇām manuṣyāṇām ca yadi deha ātma bheda jñānam syāt tarhi na eṣām mama aham iti dhīḥ śva sṛgāla bhakṣya
translated: how then is this figurative usage?

analyzed: ityādayaḥ purāṇa ādi vyavahārāḥ katham saṅgacchante
translated: Moreover, if there were knowledge of the difference between the body and the self of deer, barbarians, and humans, then how could these statements from the Puranas and other texts be reconciled, such as food for dogs and jackals?

analyzed: katham ca deha ātma viveka arthānām upadeśānām ānarthakyam na syāt
translated: And how could the teachings for the sake of discriminating the self from the body not be meaningless?

original: dehānukūlapratikūlārthayo rāgadveṣau ca dehātmabhedajñāne sati na syātām /
analyzed: deha anukūla pratikūla arthayoḥ rāga dveṣau ca deha ātma bheda jñāne sati na syātām
translated: And attachment and aversion to things favorable and unfavorable to the body would not occur if there were knowledge of the difference between the body and the self.

original: tataśca saṃsārānupapattirityata āha vyāptatvāditi // /🔽vyāptatvādātmano dehe vyavahāreṣvapāṭavāt // / / //
analyzed: tatas ca saṃsāra anupapattiḥ iti atas āha vyāpta tvāt iti  vyāpta tvāt ātmanaḥ dehe vyavahāreṣu apāṭavāt
translated: And then there would be no possibility of worldly existence. Therefore he says because of pervasion, etc.🔽Because the self is pervaded by the body, the figurative usages are not clear.

analyzed: bheda jñāne ca aṅgāra vahni vat sva avivikta vat
translated: And even in the knowledge of difference, like charcoal and fire, like the inseparable self,

analyzed: bhavanti vyavahārāḥ ca
translated: the usages exist.

analyzed: bheda ajñāne pi ca iti caśabdaḥ vyavahāreṣu apāṭavāt ca iti sambaddhayate  aṅgāra vahni vat iti
translated: And even in the absence of knowledge of difference, the word ca is connected with and because the figurative usages are not clear.🔽Like charcoal and fire.

analyzed: aṅgāra vyāpta vanhau iva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is like fire inseparable from charcoal.

original: svāviviktavat svābhinne svasaṃsṛṣṭe ca yathā tathetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: sva avivikta vat sva abhinne sva saṃsṛṣṭe ca yathā tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: as if they were not distinguished, as if they were not different from themselves, and as if they were mixed with themselves.

analyzed: vyavahārāḥ ca iti caśabdaḥ nukta samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: And the usages, and the word 'and' is for including what is not mentioned.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ dehe
translated: In the body of the self,

original: vyāptatvātsvāviviktavadvayavahārā bhavanti ityanenaikadeśatvalakṣaṇaṃ sādṛśyaṃ sambandho 'pyabhihitaḥ /🔽bhedajñāne 'pyabhinnavadvayavahāre kiṃ prayojanamityasyottaraṃ bhedajñāne 'pi lokānāṃ
analyzed: vyāpta tvāt sva avivikta vat vayavahārāḥ bhavanti iti anena eka deśa tva lakṣaṇam sādṛśyam sambandhaḥ api abhihitaḥ  bheda jñāne pi abhinna vat vayavahāre kim prayojanam iti asya uttaram bheda jñāne pi lokānām
translated: because it is all-pervading, the usages are as if they were not distinguished. By this, the similarity characterized by being a part, and the relation, is also stated.

analyzed: vyavahāreṣu apāṭavāt sva avivikta vat vayavahāre kim prayojanam iti asya uttaram bheda jñāne
translated: What is the purpose of the usage as if it were non-different, even in the knowledge of difference? The answer to this is:

analyzed: pi lokānām vyavahāreṣu apāṭava vātsva avivikta vat vayavahārāḥ bhavanti iti
translated: Even in the knowledge of difference, the usages of people are not clear, therefore the usages are as if they were not distinguished.

analyzed: na prayojanam uddiśya lokāḥ tathā vyavaharanti
translated: People do not engage in such usage with a purpose in mind.

original: kintu viviktavyavahāreṣu pāṭavābhāvādeveti /🔽apāṭave heturvyāptatvādātmano deha iti /
analyzed: kintu vivikta vyavahāreṣu pāṭava abhāvāt eva iti  apāṭave hetuḥ vyāpta tvāt ātmanaḥ dehe iti
translated: But it is only due to the lack of clarity in the usage of the distinguished.🔽The reason for the lack of clarity is because the self is all-pervading in the body.

original: rūḍhatvāccaiteṣāṃ vyavahārāṇāṃ na prayojanāpekṣetyāśayena uktam aṅgāravahnivaditi /
analyzed: rūḍha tvāt ca eteṣām vyavahārāṇām na prayojana apekṣā iti āśayena uktam aṅgāra vahni vat iti
translated: And because these usages are well-established, they do not depend on a purpose. With this idea in mind, it is said: like charcoal and fire.

analyzed: bheda jñāne pi ātmanaḥ deha vyāpta tvāt aṅgāra vahni vat lokānām vyavahāreṣu apāṭavāt atyanta vivikta vedaneṣu asāmarthyāt purāṇa ādi vyavahārāḥ ca sva avivikta vat bhavanti
translated: Even in the knowledge of difference, due to the pervasion of the self in the body, like the charcoal and fire, in the worldly transactions and in the extremely distinct cognitions, due to the incapacity, the transactions of the Puranas etc. also become as if not distinct.

analyzed: viśada viveka abhāva vivakṣayā eva te vyavahārāḥ iti āśayaḥ
translated: The idea is that those transactions are only with the intention of the absence of clear discrimination.

analyzed: atas eva viveka arthānām upadeśānām ca sārthakyam upapadyate
translated: For this very reason, the purposefulness of the teachings for discrimination is established.

original: viśado hi vivekaḥ puruṣārthāya kalpate na tvautpattikaḥ /
analyzed: viśadaḥ hi vivekaḥ puruṣa arthāya kalpate na tu autpattikaḥ
translated: For, clear discrimination is fit for the purpose of man, not natural.

original: ātmano dehe vyāptatvādatyantaṃ premāspadatvādrāgādayo yujyanta eveti / /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ dehe vyāpta tvāt atyantam prema āspada tvāt rāga ādayaḥ yujyante eva iti
translated: Due to the pervasion of the self in the body and being the object of extreme affection, attachment etc. are indeed proper.

original: nanu jñānameva vyavahārakāraṇaṃ taccedasti kathaṃ tarhi vyavahāreṣvapāṭavamityata āha nahīti //🔽na hi pratyakṣagānapi // / / // /🔽arthān yathānubhavataḥ pratipādayituṃ kṣamāḥ /🔽lokās / / / // / /c //
analyzed: nanu jñānam eva vyavahāra kāraṇam tat ced asti katham tarhi vyavahāreṣu apāṭavam iti atas āha nahi iti  na hi pratyakṣa gān api  arthān yathā anubhavataḥ pratipādayitum kṣamāḥ  lokāḥ
translated: But, is not knowledge itself the cause of transaction? And if that exists, then how is there incapacity in transactions? To this he says: For,🔽the people are not able to present the objects which are perceived by perception as they are experienced.

analyzed: yathā anubhavataḥ anubhava anusāreṇa pratipādayitum vyavahartum
translated: The people are not able to present, i.e., to transact, according to the experience, in accordance with the experience.

original: yamalayoratyantavivekaṃ paśyanto 'pi mātrādayaḥ kathametau viviktāvavagantavyāviti pṛṣṭā evamiti svapratyakṣānubhavānusāreṇa na parānpratipādayituṃ 🔽kṣamanta ityādyanubhavasiddham /
analyzed: yamalayoḥ atyanta vivekam paśyantaḥ pi mātṛ ādayaḥ katham etau viviktau avagantavyau iti pṛṣṭāḥ evam iti sva pratyakṣa anubhava anusāreṇa na parān pratipādayitum  kṣamantaḥ ityādi anubhava siddham
translated: Even though Yama and Maya see a very clear distinction, when asked how these two should be understood as distinct, they say this in accordance with their own direct experience, but are not able to convey it to others. This is well-known from direct experience.

analyzed: kā nāma atra kathantā
translated: What doubt can there be here?

original: atha tatrātyantasādṛśyaṃ pratibandhakaṃ tarhyatrāpyaṅgāravahnivadātmano dehe vyāptatvaṃ pratibandhakamuktameva /
analyzed: atha tatra atyanta sādṛśyam pratibandhakam tarhi atra api aṅgāra vahni vat ātmanaḥ dehe vyāpta tvam pratibandhakam uktam eva
translated: If extreme similarity is an obstruction there, then here too, the pervasion of the self in the body, like the coal and fire, is said to be an obstruction.

original: śuktirajatādipratyakṣāṇāmanumānādinā bādho nāstītyanyatropapāditamityāśayavānkva ca pratyakṣataḥ prāptam' /
analyzed: śukti rajata ādi pratyakṣāṇām anumāna ādinā bādhaḥ na asti iti anyatra upapāditam iti āśayavān kva ca pratyakṣataḥ prāptam
translated: It has been explained elsewhere that there is no contradiction of the direct perceptions of mother-of-pearl and silver etc. by inference etc. With this intention, he concludes what was stated beginning with Where is it attained through direct perception?

analyzed: ityādinā uktam upasaṃharati tatas hi iti
translated: He concludes with Therefore...

original: tato hi pratyakṣasiddhaṃ nānyena kenacit // / / //🔽śakyaṃ vārayituṃ kvāpi / / / // / / //
analyzed: tatas hi pratyakṣa siddham na anyena kenacid  śakyam vārayitum kvāpi
translated: For what is established by direct perception cannot be refuted by any other means of knowledge anywhere.

analyzed: kvacid pratīteḥ eva abhāvāt kvacid pratīti sadbhāve pi pratyakṣa janya tva abhāvāt kvacid pratyakṣa pratīti bhāve pi yathārtha tvāt kvacid ayathārtha tve pi
translated: Because there is no cognition in some cases, even when there is cognition in some cases, it is not produced by direct perception, even when there is a cognition produced by direct perception in some cases, it is true, even when it is false in some cases,

analyzed: prabala pratyakṣeṇa eva bādhāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is contradicted by a very strong perception.

analyzed: atas eva kvāpi iti uktam
translated: For this very reason, it is said in some cases.

analyzed: anyena iti
translated: By another.

analyzed: anupajīvyena āgama ādinā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is by scripture etc. which are not the basis of the other.

original: tadevaṃ svabhāvataḥ prabalena pratyakṣeṇa viruddhāvanumānāgamāvabhāsāveveti / /🔽bhavatvāgamāditaḥ pratyakṣaṃ prabalaṃ mā vā bhūt /
analyzed: tat evam svabhāvataḥ prabalena pratyakṣeṇa viruddhau anumāna āgama avabhāsau eva iti  bhavatu āgama āditas pratyakṣam prabalam mā vā bhūt
translated: Thus, inference and scripture, which are contradicted by perception which is strong by nature, are only apparent.🔽Let perception be stronger than scripture etc., or let it not be so.

analyzed: tad virodhaḥ tu āgama ādeḥ nā asti
translated: But there is no contradiction of scripture etc.

analyzed: bhinna viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because they have different objects.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: This is how it is.

original: āgamādikaṃ khalvāgāminaṃ viśvasya bādhaṃ pratipādayati na tu adhunātanam /
analyzed: āgama ādikam khalu āgāminam viśvasya bādham pratipādayati na tu adhunātanam
translated: For scripture etc. indeed teaches the future destruction of the universe, but not the present one.

original: sa eva ca mithyādipadena vedanīyaḥ /🔽tasya ca pratyakṣavirodhastadā syāt /
analyzed: saḥ eva ca mithyā ādi padena vedanīyaḥ  tasya ca pratyakṣa virodhaḥ tadā syāt
translated: And that very [future destruction] is to be understood by the word 'false' etc.

analyzed: yadi āgāminam api viśvasya bādham pratyakṣam pratikṣipet
translated: And that would be contradicted by perception if perception were to reject the future destruction of the universe.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

original: tasya vartamānamātragrāhitvena āgāminamapi viśvasya bādhaṃ pratyakṣaṃ pratikṣipet /
analyzed: tasya vartamāna mātra grāhi tvena āgāminam api viśvasya bādham pratyakṣam pratikṣipet
translated: Because it grasps only the present, perception cannot grasp the future non-existence of the destruction of the universe.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: And it is not so.

analyzed: tasya vartamāna mātra grāhi tvena āgāmi bādhā bhāva grahaṇe sāmarthya abhāvāt
translated: Because it lacks the ability to grasp the future non-existence of destruction, since it grasps only the present.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it has been said:

original: sambaddhaṃ vartamānaṃ ca gṛhyate cakṣurādinā' / iti /
analyzed: sambaddham vartamānam ca gṛhyate cakṣuḥ ādinā iti
translated: And it is connected and present that is apprehended by the eye, etc.

analyzed: idānīntana bādhā bhāva grahaṇe pi na virodhaḥ
translated: Even if the apprehension of the absence of present contradiction is accepted, there is no contradiction.

analyzed: na ca bhinna viṣayayoḥ virodhaḥ sti
translated: And there is no contradiction between two things with different objects.

original: tathā satīdānīntanaghaṭābhāvagrāhiṇā pratyakṣeṇa bhaviṣyati ghaṭa ityāgamādervirodhaḥ syāditi / /
analyzed: tathā sati idānīntana ghaṭa abhāva grāhiṇā pratyakṣeṇa bhaviṣyati ghaṭaḥ iti āgama ādeḥ virodhaḥ syāt iti
translated: If it were so, then there would be contradiction of the scriptures etc. by the perception apprehending the absence of the pot in the present, thinking 'it will be a pot'.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: asti tāvat pratyakṣaṃ vartamānakālīnaṃ bādhābhāvamāvedayatīti parasyāpi sampratipattiḥ /
analyzed: asti tāvat pratyakṣam vartamāna kālīnam bādhā bhāvam āvedayati iti parasya api sampratipattiḥ
translated: It is accepted by the opponent also that there is perception pertaining to the present time which reveals the absence of contradiction.

original: āgamaśca neha nānāstītyādirūpo vartamānameva viśvasya bādhaṃ pratipādayatīti kathaṃ na pratyakṣaviruddhaḥ /
analyzed: āgamaḥ ca na iha nānā asti ityādi rūpaḥ vartamānam eva viśvasya bādham pratipādayati iti katham na pratyakṣa viruddhaḥ
translated: And the scripture in the form of 'There is no diversity here' etc. teaches the contradiction of the universe in the present time itself. How is it not contradictory to perception?

analyzed: astu vā āgāmi bodhaka tvam āgama ādeḥ tathā api bādhaḥ nāma traikālika satta niṣedhaḥ
translated: Even if the scriptures etc. have the nature of teaching the future, even then contradiction is the negation of existence in the three times.

original: sa ca vartamānakālīnasattāgrāhiṇā pratyakṣeṇa viruddhayata eveti tatpratipādakasyāgamādeḥ kathaṃ na pratyakṣavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca vartamāna kālīna sattā grāhiṇā pratyakṣeṇa viruddhayataḥ eva iti tad pratipādakasya āgama ādeḥ katham na pratyakṣa virodhaḥ
translated: And that is contradicted by perception apprehending existence in the present time itself. How then is there no contradiction with perception for the scriptures etc. which teach that?

original: etenāsmatpratyakṣamasmanniṣṭhameva bādhaṃ pratikṣeptuṃ kṣamate na puruṣāntaragatamiti nirastam /
analyzed: etena asmad pratyakṣam asmad niṣṭham eva bādham pratikṣeptum kṣamate na puruṣa antara gatam iti nirastam
translated: By this (argument) it is refuted that our perception is able to reject only the contradiction that is in ourselves, but not that which is in another person.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādi sattā niṣedha rūpasya bādhasya tad sattā grāhiṇā pratyakṣeṇa virodha avaśyambhāvāt
translated: Because there must be contradiction between the perception that grasps the existence of that (object) and the contradiction that has the form of the negation of the existence of the pot, etc.

original: tadevaṃ pratyakṣasya vartamānamātragrāhitve 'pyāgamādestadvirodho duṣparihāra eva /🔽tathāpi prasaktau vastusthitirvaktavyetyāśayavānpratyakṣasya vartamānamātragrāhitāniyamamapākartumuttaraṃ
analyzed: tat evam pratyakṣasya vartamāna mātra grāhi tve pi āgama ādeḥ tad virodhaḥ duṣparihāraḥ eva  tathā api prasaktau vastu sthitiḥ vaktavyā iti āśayavān pratyakṣasya vartamāna mātra grāhi tā niyamam apākartum uttaram
translated: Thus, even though perception grasps only the present, the contradiction with the scriptures is indeed difficult to avoid.🔽Nevertheless, with the intention that the true state of things must be stated when there is a doubt, he begins the next section to remove the restriction that perception grasps only the present.

analyzed: prakaraṇam ārabhamāṇaḥ sākṣi pratyakṣasya tāvat tad niyamam apākaroti tat ced iti
translated: The revered author of the Bhāṣya, beginning with the word that, first removes the restriction regarding the perception of the witness.

analyzed: tat ced na uttara gocaram
translated: And if that (perception) does not have the future as its object,

analyzed: katham eva uttaraḥ kālaḥ tad gaḥ mokṣaḥ ca gamyate
translated: how is the future time and the attainment of liberation in that (future time) understood?

analyzed: gamyate iti vakṣyamāṇena sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with what is to be stated as understood.

analyzed: tat iti pratyakṣa viśeṣa sākṣiṇam eva adhikurute bhagavān bhāṣyakāraḥ ced śabda śravaṇāt tarhi iti adhyāhāryam
translated: The revered author of the Bhāṣya takes up the witness, a particular kind of perception, itself, with the word that. The word if is to be supplied after hearing the word that.

analyzed: na uttara gocaram iti
translated: Does not have the future as its object means

analyzed: vartamāna mātra gocaram iti arthaḥ  pramāṇa antarāṇām prāk eva dūṣita tvāt iti eva arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it has only the present as its object.🔽The meaning is that other means of knowledge have already been refuted.

analyzed: uttaraḥ iti atītasya api upalakṣaṇam
translated: The word later is a synecdoche for the past as well.

analyzed: yeṣām ca akhaṇḍaḥ eva kālaḥ taiḥ api upādhi bhedaḥ ṅgīkartavyaḥ eva
translated: Even for those for whom time is undivided, the difference of limiting adjuncts must be accepted.

analyzed: anyathā sarva ākhyāta pratyayānām aikāthya r prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, all verbs would have the same meaning.

analyzed: atas svābhāvikaḥ vā aupādhikaḥ vā asti uttaraḥ kālaḥ
translated: Therefore, whether time is natural or adventitious, there is a later time.

analyzed: mā avagāmi uttaraḥ kālaḥ idānīm
translated: We understand the later time as the present.

analyzed: kinnas chinnam iti atas āha tad gaḥ iti
translated: What is not cut off for us? To this he says: that which is related to it.

analyzed: katham eva iti anuvartate
translated: How indeed? continues.

analyzed: uttara kāla anavagatau iti ca arthaḥ
translated: And the meaning is: in the non-understanding of the later time.

analyzed: gamyate avagamyate
translated: It is understood, it is comprehended.

analyzed: atra atītasya kaṇṭhataḥ saṅkīrtanam kaiścid atīta mokṣasya an aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Here, the past is not mentioned explicitly by some because they do not accept liberation in the past.

analyzed: uttara kāla anavagatau tad sambandhi tayā mokṣaḥ nā avagamyate eva
translated: In the non-understanding of the later time, liberation related to that is not understood either.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa anavagame viśiṣya anavagamasya prasiddha tvāt
translated: Because it is well-known that when the qualifier is not understood, the qualified is not understood.

original: bhaviṣyati mokṣa ityavagamābhāve ca tadarthaḥ prayatno na syāt /
analyzed: bhaviṣyati mokṣaḥ iti avagama abhāve ca tad arthaḥ prayatnaḥ na syāt
translated: And if there is no understanding that liberation will exist, effort for that purpose would not occur.

original: mokṣe sarvasya bādho bhaviṣyatītyetadapi na syāditi / /
analyzed: mokṣe sarvasya bādhaḥ bhaviṣyati iti etat api na syāt iti
translated: And this also would not be the case that there would be obstruction for all in liberation.

original: śukavāmadevādayo jñānena muktā abhūvannahamapi mukto bhaviṣyāmītyādyavagatiḥ āgamādeva bhaviṣyatīti🔽ti kimatra sākṣiṇo 'tītānāgatārthagocaratvenetyata āha āgamo 'pīti //
analyzed: śuka vāmadeva ādayaḥ jñānena muktāḥ abhūvan aham api muktaḥ bhaviṣyāmi ityādi avagatiḥ āgamāt eva bhaviṣyati iti  kim atra sākṣiṇaḥ tīta anāgata artha gocara tvena iti atas āha āgamaḥ pi iti
translated: The understanding that Śuka, Vāmadeva, and others were liberated by knowledge, and that I too will be liberated, will arise only from scripture.

original: āgamo 'pi hi sāmānye siddhe pratyakṣataḥ punaḥ /
analyzed: āgamaḥ pi hi sāmānye siddhe pratyakṣataḥ punar
translated: What is the need for the witness to have the past and future objects as its domain in this matter? To this he says: Even scripture, when the general sense is established by perception,

analyzed: viśeṣam gamayet eva
translated: would indeed convey only the specific meaning.

analyzed: eṣā khalu āgamasya sthitiḥ  yad sāmānye nvaya sāmānyavati padārtha samūhe  pratyakṣataḥ pramāṇa antareṇa
translated: This is indeed the position of scripture.🔽That when a group of words has a general sense, a general connection,

analyzed: siddhe sati  punar paścāt viśeṣam anvaya viśeṣavantam tam eva padārtha samūham
translated: if it is established by another means of knowledge, by perception,🔽then later, again, it would convey only that same group of words with a specific connection, with a specific meaning.

analyzed: gamayet iti eva na punar padārthān api gamayet iti
translated: It does not convey the word meanings again.

original: nadyāstīre pañcaphalāni santītyādau tathā darśanāditi hiśabdārthaḥ /
analyzed: nadyāḥ tīre pañca phalāni santi ityādau tathā darśanāt iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: Because it is seen thus in statements like There are five fruits on the bank of the river, etc. This is the meaning of the word hi.

analyzed: kim prāk pada athar siddhayā iti atas āha katham iti
translated: How is it that the word meanings are established first? To this he says how (kathan).

analyzed: katham śakti grahaḥ nyathā
translated: How is the grasping of the power (of a word) otherwise?

original: yadi padārthāḥ prāṅ na siddhāstarhi padānāṃ teṣu vācakatvaśaktigrahaṇaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: yadi padārthāḥ prāk na siddhāḥ tarhi padānām teṣu vācaka tva śakti grahaṇam na syāt
translated: If the meanings of words are not already known, then the power of expression of those words in relation to those meanings cannot be grasped.

analyzed: a vidita viṣayāyāḥ śakteḥ gṛhītum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because the power whose object is unknown cannot be grasped.

analyzed: nahi kāṣṭham a jānan kuṭhārasya tad chedana śaktim jñātu śaknoti
translated: For one who does not know wood cannot know the power of an axe to cut it.

analyzed: astu padānām śakti grahāya padārtha jñānam āvaśyakam
translated: Let it be that the knowledge of the meanings of words is necessary for grasping the power of words.

original: atha śaktigraha eva kimartha ityata āha atīteti //🔽atītānāgatārtheṣu jāte śaktigrahe 'khilam /
analyzed: atha śakti grahaḥ eva kimarthaḥ iti atas āha atīta iti  atīta anāgata artheṣu jāte śakti grahe khilam
translated: Then why is the grasping of power itself necessary? In response to this, it is said:🔽When the power is grasped in relation to past and future objects, the sentence would indicate the entire specific meaning.

analyzed: viśeṣam jñāpayet vākyam na tat ajñātaśaktike
translated: Not when the power is unknown in that sentence.

original: atrātītānāgatagrahaṇaṃ prakṛtāpekṣam /🔽akhilamapi vākyaṃ padānāṃ padārtheṣu vācakatvaśaktigrahe jāta evānvayaviśeṣaṃ gamayet /
analyzed: atra atīta anāgata grahaṇam prakṛta apekṣam  akhilam api vākyam padānām padārtheṣu vācaka tva śakti grahe jāte eva anvaya viśeṣam gamayet
translated: Here, the mention of past and future is in relation to the present context.🔽Even the entire sentence would convey the specific relation only when the power of expression of the words in relation to the meanings of the words is already known.

original: natu tadvākyaṃ padārtheṣu padasamūhe 'jñātaśaktike sati viśeṣaṃ gamayedityanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ /
analyzed: na tu tat vākyam padārtheṣu pada samūhe jñāta śaktike sati viśeṣam gamayet iti anvaya vyatirekābhyām
translated: But that sentence would not convey the specific meaning when the power of the group of words in relation to the meanings of the words is unknown. This is understood through positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: vākyasya vākya artha avagatau kartavyāyām
translated: When the sentence is to be used for understanding the meaning of the sentence,

analyzed: śakti grahaḥ ṅgam iti jñāyate saḥ avarthanīyaḥ
translated: it is known that the grasping of power is a means. Therefore, it should be accepted.

analyzed: prakṛta vākyānām ca atīta anāgata artha saṃsarga bodhaka tvāt atīta anāgata artheṣu luṅ ḷḍ ādi anta padānām śaktiḥ jñātavyā iti arthaḥ  /
translated: And the meaning is that the power of the verbal roots ending in lūṅ and ḷa should be known to be in the past and future meanings, because the sentences in the present tense indicate the connection with the past and future meanings.

original: astu śaktigrahāvaśyambhāvaḥ kintu vartamāneṣvevārtheṣu nātītānāgateṣvanupayogādityata āha śaktiścediti //
analyzed: astu śakti graha avaśyambhāvaḥ kintu vartamāneṣu eva artheṣu na atīta anāgateṣu anupayogāt iti atas āha śaktiḥ ced iti
translated: Let there be the necessity of grasping the power, but only in the present meanings, not in the past and future, because of non-use. To this he says 'If there is power' etc.

analyzed: śaktiḥ ced vartamāne syāt na atīta anāgatam vadet
translated: If there is power, it would be in the present, it would not speak of the past and future.

original: yadi vartamāna evārthe padānāṃ śaktirgṛhītā syāttadā vākyam atītānāgatam atītānāgatārthasaṃsargaṃ na vadet na pratipādayet /
analyzed: yadi vartamāne eva arthe padānām śaktiḥ gṛhītā syāt tadā vākyam atīta anāgatam atīta anāgata artha saṃsargam na vadet na pratipādayet
translated: If the power of the words were grasped only in the present meaning, then the sentence would not speak, would not convey, the past and future, the connection with the past and future meanings.

analyzed: sahakāri virahāt
translated: Because of the absence of auxiliaries.

analyzed: sarvaḥ dvandvaḥ vibhāṣayā eka vat bhavati iti eka vat bhāvaḥ
translated: All compounds become singular by option. This is the singular form.

analyzed: atīta anāgata artheṣu iti uktasya abhiprāya kathanam etat
translated: This is the explanation of what was said about the past and future meanings.

analyzed: astu atīta anāgata artheṣu api padānām śakti grahaḥ
translated: Let there be the grasping of the power of the words even in the past and future meanings.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: What then? To this he says 'If' etc.

original: yadi śaktigraho 'nyatra kathaṃ sa syāt tadagrahe // / / //
analyzed: yadi śakti grahaḥ nyatra katham sa syāt tad agrahe
translated: If the grasping of power is elsewhere, how could it be, if that is not grasped?

original: vartamānādanyatrātītānāgatayorapi padaśaktigraho yadyaṅgīkṛtastadā saḥ atītānāgatārtheṣu padaśaktigrahastadagrahe 'tītānāgatārthāgrahe kathaṃ
analyzed: vartamānāt anyatra atīta anāgatayoḥ api pada śakti grahaḥ yadi aṅgīkṛtaḥ tadā saḥ atīta anāgata artheṣu pada śakti grahaḥ tad agrahe tīta anāgata artha agrahe katham
translated: If the comprehension of the power of words with regard to the past and future, which are different from the present, is accepted, then how could that comprehension of the power of words with regard to past and future meanings, when there is no comprehension of them,

analyzed: syāt
translated: be possible?

analyzed: na kathañcid
translated: In no way.

analyzed: nirviṣayāyāḥ śakteḥ jñātum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because the power, which is objectless, cannot be known.

analyzed: atas tīta anāgata artha jñānam api aṅgīkāryam
translated: Therefore, the knowledge of past and future meanings must also be accepted.

analyzed: ayam atra samudāya arthaḥ
translated: The overall meaning here is this.

original: vākyaṃ tāvatpadārthasaṃsargaviśeṣalakṣaṇaṃ vākyārthameva bodhayati na padārthamātram /
analyzed: vākyam tāvat padārtha saṃsarga viśeṣa lakṣaṇam vākya artham eva bodhayati na padārtha mātram
translated: A sentence, which is characterized by the particular combination of word meanings, only conveys the meaning of the sentence, not just the word meanings.

analyzed: tat ca apekṣate padānām padārtheṣu vācaka tva śakti graham  śakti grahaḥ ca padārtha graham
translated: And that depends on the comprehension of the power of words to denote the word meanings.🔽And the comprehension of power depends on the comprehension of word meanings.

analyzed: padārtha grahaḥ ca pramāṇa antara āyattaḥ na pada vākya janyaḥ
translated: And the comprehension of word meanings is dependent on other means of knowledge, not on words or sentences.

analyzed: itaretara āśraya ādi doṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because the fallacy of mutual dependence and so on would ensue.

analyzed: yatra ca atīta anāgata artha saṃsargaḥ vākya arthaḥ tatra atīta anāgata artha grahaṇam āvaśyakam
translated: And where the meaning of the sentence is the combination of past and future meanings, the comprehension of past and future meanings is necessary.

original: śukavāmadevedayo muktā abhūvannahaṃ ca mukto bhaviṣyāmītyādikaṃ ca tathā /
analyzed: muktāḥ abhūvan aham ca muktaḥ bhaviṣyāmi iti ādikam ca tathā
translated: And so on, such as Suka and Vamadeva were liberated, and I will be liberated.

analyzed: tasmāt luṅ ḷḍ ādi anta pada vācyānām atīta anagata kāla tad sambandhi padārthānām ca grahaṇam āgamena ukta artha pratipattim abhilaṣatā api pareṇa eṣyavyam
translated: Therefore, even one who desires to understand the meaning expressed by the words ending with the suffixes lṛṅ and ḷa, and the objects related to the past and future time, must accept that [knowledge] by means of the scriptures.

original: naca tatsākṣiṇā vinā bhavatīti kathamatītānāgatārthagrāhiṇastasya vartamānamātraviṣayatvamiti / /
analyzed: na ca tat sākṣiṇā vinā bhavati iti katham atīta anāgata artha grāhiṇaḥ tasya vartamāna mātra viṣaya tvam iti
translated: And that [knowledge] does not occur without the witness [consciousness]. So how can it be said that [the witness consciousness], which perceives past and future objects, has only the present as its object?

analyzed: mīmāṃsaka mata anusāreṇa śaṅkate sāmānyam iti
translated: Following the Mīmāṃsaka view, he raises a doubt with [the verse beginning with] sāmānyam [i.e., If that [consciousness] would make one understand elsewhere only what is seen in general...]

analyzed: sāmānyam dṛṣṭam eva asau anyatra gamayet yadi
translated: If that [consciousness] would make one understand elsewhere only what is seen in general,

analyzed: asau iti prakṛ vākya eka deśasya śabdasya parāmarśaḥ
translated: That refers to a part of the original sentence, the word.

analyzed: sakalam api vastu sāmānya viśeṣa ātmakam
translated: The entire entity is of the nature of general and particular.

original: tatra sāmānyākāra eva śabdavācyo viśeṣastu lakṣya eveti tāvanniṣyaṅkitam /
analyzed: tatra sāmānya ākāraḥ eva śabda vācyaḥ viśeṣaḥ tu lakṣyaḥ evā iti tāvat niṣyaṅkitam
translated: It is first assumed that the general form alone is denoted by the word, while the particular is only indicated.

analyzed: sāmānyam ca atīta anāgata viśeṣeṣu ekam eva
translated: And the general [form] is the same in past, future, and present particulars.

original: tacca vartamānaṃ cakṣurādinā dṛṣṭaṃ śabdaśaktiviṣayatayā avagatameva /
analyzed: tat ca vartamānam cakṣuḥ ādinā dṛṣṭam śabda śakti viṣaya tayā avagatam eva
translated: And that [general form] is seen by the present eye, etc., and is understood as the object of the power of the word.

analyzed: anyatra kāla antare pi
translated: Even elsewhere, at another time,

analyzed: śabdaḥ bodhayati
translated: the word conveys [the meaning].

analyzed: tatra kim atīta anāgata artha jñānena
translated: What is the use of knowing the past and future objects in that case?

original: viśeṣāṇāṃ hi śabdavācyatve teṣāmatītādirūpatvāt śaktigrahaṇāyātītādijñānamapekṣitaṃ syāt /
analyzed: viśeṣāṇām hi śabda vācya tve teṣām atīta ādi rūpa tvāt śakti grahaṇāya atīta ādi jñānam apekṣitam syāt
translated: For if the particulars are denoted by words, then in order to grasp their power, knowledge of the past etc. would be required, because they have the form of past etc.

analyzed: naca luṅ ḷḍ ādi śakti grahaṇāya atīta anāgata ādi kāla grahaṇam aparihāryam iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that in order to grasp the power of the verbal endings like lūṅ and ḷa, the grasping of past, future etc. times is unavoidable.

analyzed: tatra api kāla tva jāteḥ eva vācya tvāt
translated: Because even there, only the universal of time is denoted.

analyzed: nahi vaiśeṣika ādi vat mīmāṃsakānām nissāmānyam kim api asti
translated: For the Mīmāṃsakas, unlike the Vaiśeṣikas etc., there is nothing without a universal.

analyzed: atas na śakti grahāya atīta ādi graha apekṣā iti
translated: Therefore, there is no need to grasp the past etc. in order to grasp the power.

analyzed: uttaram āha sāmānya iti
translated: The answer is given by sāmānya etc.

analyzed: sāmānya varjitam vastu svarūpam gamayet katham  astu tāvat sarva viśeṣāṣayā
translated: How can it convey the nature of a thing devoid of universals?

original: nugataṃ nityaṃ gotvādisāmānyameva gavādiśabdavācvatvaṃ sāsnādimanto viśeṣāstu lakṣyā eva /
analyzed: anugatam nityam go tva ādi sāmānyam eva gavādi śabda vācvatvam sāsnādimantaḥ viśeṣāḥ tu lakṣyāḥ eva
translated: Let it be for now that the general, eternal universal like cowness, which is common to all particulars, is denoted by words like cow. But the particulars possessing dewlap etc. are only to be defined.

analyzed: tathā api idam vaktavyam
translated: Even so, this must be stated:

analyzed: svarūpa śabdaḥ vastu svarūpāṇi avagamayati na vā iti
translated: Does the word nature convey the natures of things or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣe nubhava virodhaḥ
translated: If not, it contradicts experience.

analyzed: ādye katham kayā vṛttyā iti vācyam
translated: If so, it must be said by what operation and how.

analyzed: na tāvat lakṣaṇayā  vācya artha dvāraivareṇa eva
translated: Not by indication first.🔽Only through the denoted meaning.

analyzed: sakṣaṇa asambhava alābhā
translated: Because indication is impossible without the denoted meaning.

analyzed: t sāmānyasya eva vācya tvāt
translated: Because only the universal is denoted.

analyzed: sva rūpāṇām ca sāmānya varjita tvāt
translated: And because the individual forms are devoid of the universal.

original: ataḥ svarūpaśabdo vastusvarūpāṇāṃ vācaka ityevāṅgīkāryamiti / /🔽nanu sarvasāmānyānāṃ vastusvarūpābahirbhāvātsāmānyavarjitaṃ vastu
analyzed: atas svarūpa śabdaḥ vastu svarūpāṇām vācakaḥ iti eva aṅgīkāryam iti  nanu sarva sāmānyānām vastu svarūpa abahirbhāvāt sāmānya varjitam vastu
translated: Therefore, it must be accepted that the word 'svarūpa' denotes only the individual forms of things.

analyzed: svarūpam iti katham iti atas āha na iti
translated: But since all universals are not external to the individual forms of things, how can the individual form of a thing be said to be devoid of the universal? To this he says 'no'.

analyzed: na svarūpa tva sāmānyam kena api aṅgīkṛtam kvacid
translated: The universal 'svarūpatva' (being an individual form) is not accepted by anyone anywhere.

analyzed: satyam santi svarūpe sāmānyāni
translated: It is true that there are universals in individual forms.

analyzed: na ca tāni svarūpa śabda vācyāni
translated: But those are not denoted by the word 'svarūpa'.

original: nahi sāsnādimati piṇḍe vatarmānaṃ paśutvaṃ gośabdavācyam /
analyzed: nahi sāsnādimati piṇḍe vatarmānam paśu tvam go śabda vācyam
translated: The universal 'paśutva' (cow-ness) inhering in the individual having dewlap is not denoted by the word 'go' (cow).

analyzed: kintu go tvam eva
translated: But only the universal 'gotva' (cow-ness) is.

analyzed: tat atra api svarūpa śabdasya vācyam sāmānyam abhyupagacchatā sva rūpa tvam eva aṅgīkāryam
translated: Similarly, here also, by one who accepts the universal as denoted by the word 'svarūpa', only 'svarūpatva' (being an individual form) must be accepted.

analyzed: tat ca na asti
translated: And that does not exist.

analyzed: kena api parīkṣakeṇa
translated: By any investigator.

analyzed: kvacid api an aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Anywhere, because it is not accepted by anyone.

analyzed: mā aṅgīkāri kena api svarūpa tva sāmānyam
translated: The universal 'svarūpatva' (being an individual form) is not accepted by anyone.

analyzed: mayā tu aṅgīkariṣyate
translated: But it will be accepted by me.

analyzed: nahi sarvaiḥ aṅgīkṛtam eva aṅgīkaraṇīyam iti asti niyamaḥ
translated: There is no rule that only what is accepted by all should be accepted.

original: tathātve darśanabhedāsambhavāditi vaiyātyādvadantaṃ pratyāha svarūpaṃ cediti //
analyzed: tathātve darśana bheda asambhavāt iti vaiyātyāt vadantam pratyāha svarūpam ced iti
translated: If it were so, then the difference of perception would be impossible. Speaking thus out of ignorance, he says If the form etc.

original: svarūpaṃ cedanugataṃ vyāvṛttaṃ tatra kiṃ bhavet // / / //
analyzed: sva rūpam ced anugatam vyāvṛttam tatra kim bhavet
translated: If the form were common, what would be the difference there?

analyzed: svarūpam iti bhāva pradhānaḥ nirdeśaḥ
translated: The word form is a direction in which the substance is predominant.

analyzed: tatra vastuni
translated: There, in the object.

analyzed: kiṃśabdaḥ praśne
translated: The word what is in a question.

original: evaṃ satyatva praśno niruttaraḥ syāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: evam satya tva praśnaḥ niruttaraḥ syāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that if it were so, the question of truth would be unanswered.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha sarva iti
translated: How is that? Therefore he says all etc.

analyzed: sarva anugata dharmāṇām ante hi sva tvam iṣyate
translated: The state of being one's own is accepted at the end of all common properties.

analyzed: kim vyāvṛttam iti praśne svarūpam iti kevalam
translated: In the question What is the difference?, the answer would be The form alone.

analyzed: syāt uttaram
translated: It would be so.

analyzed: yasmāt sarveṣām anugata dharmāṇām ante vasāne svattvam svarūpa tvam iṣyate mīmāṃsakena
translated: Because the Mimamsaka accepts that the state of being one's own, the state of being the form, is at the end, at the conclusion, of all common properties.

original: tasmātkiṃ tatra vyāvṛttamiti praśne kṛte svarūpatvamityevottaraṃ vaktavyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tasmāt kim tatra vyāvṛttam iti praśne kṛte sva rūpa tvam iti eva uttaram vaktavyam syāt
translated: Therefore, when the question What is the difference there? is asked, the answer The state of being the form should be given.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: dravyeṣvatyantaṃ vyāvṛttā dharmā antyā viśeṣā iti vaiśeṣikairaṅgīkṛtam /
analyzed: dravyeṣu atyantam vyāvṛttāḥ dharmāḥ antyāḥ viśeṣāḥ iti vaiśeṣikaiḥ aṅgīkṛtam
translated: The Vaisheshikas accept that the properties that are absolutely different in the substances are the ultimate specificities.

analyzed: viśeṣeṣu api viśeṣa antara aṅgīkāre
translated: If even in the specificities, another specificity is accepted, there would be an infinite regress.

original: tatra yathā svarūpatvameva vyāvṛttaṃ tathā dravyeṣvapi tadevāstu kiṃ viśeṣairiti
analyzed: tatra yathā svarūpa tvam eva vyāvṛttam tathā dravyeṣu api tat eva astu kim viśeṣaiḥ iti
translated: There, just as the nature itself is excluded, so let it be the same in substances also. What is the use of the distinctions?

original: viśeṣānavajñāya tatsthāne svarūpatvamabhiṣiñcatā mīmāṃsakena kiṃ vyāvṛttamiti praśne
analyzed: viśeṣān avajñāya tad sthāne svarūpa tvam abhiṣiñcatā mīmāṃsakena kim vyāvṛttam iti praśne
translated: Neglecting the distinctions, when the Mīmāṃsaka anoints the nature in their place, when asked what is excluded,

original: 'ntyā viśeṣā iti vaktuṃ na śakyata eva /
analyzed: ntyāḥ viśeṣāḥ iti vaktum na śakyate eva
translated: he cannot say that the ultimate distinctions are.

analyzed: apasiddhānta āpātāt
translated: Because of the fallacy of self-contradiction.

analyzed: guṇa ādayaḥ tu vyāvṛtta tve pi anugata ādhāra tayā aṅgīkṛtāḥ anugata kalpāḥ eva  atas sva rūpa tvam iti e
translated: But qualities and so on, although excluded, are accepted as having a common substratum, and are indeed common concepts.

analyzed: mā iva vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, it must be said that it is the nature itself.

original: tasya cedānīmanugatatvāṅgīkāre kathamayaṃ praśno niruttaro na bhavediti / /
analyzed: tasya ca idānīm anugata tva aṅgīkāre katham ayam praśnaḥ niruttaraḥ na bhavet iti
translated: And now, when its commonness is accepted, how could this question not be unanswerable?

analyzed: nanu bhedaḥ eva vyāvṛttaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: But difference itself will be excluded.

analyzed: tasya anugateḥ anugata ādhāra tāyāḥ ca abhāvāt iti atas āha tatas iti
translated: Because it has no commonness or common substratum. To this he says tataḥ (from that).

analyzed: tatas tat eva svayam eva naḥ
translated: If it is different from that, that itself is our own nature.

analyzed: ekasya eva śabdasya tarhi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word eva (only) is then.

analyzed: tatas svarūpa tvāt anyat bheda lakṣaṇam vyāvṛttam yadi aṅgīkriyate
translated: If a difference characterized by exclusion, which is different from the nature, is accepted,

analyzed: tarhi tat eva asmākam svayam svarūpam
translated: then that itself is our own nature, which is the object of the word.

analyzed: svarūpam udāhṛtam tatra bhedaḥ eva udāharaṇam bhaviṣyati iti arthaḥ
translated: The nature has been stated. The difference itself will be the example. This is the meaning.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: udāharaṇasya an ādaraṇīya tvāt bhedaḥ tāvat nissāmānyaḥ pi śabda bodhyaḥ vacana vṛttyā evā iti aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: Since the example is not to be accepted, the difference, though devoid of generality, should be accepted as expressible by words only through conventional usage.

original: naca vācakaḥ śabdaḥ śaktigrahaṇe vinār'thaṃ bodhayatīti tatra tasya śaktigraho 'pyeṣyavya iti /
analyzed: na ca vācakaḥ śabdaḥ śakti grahaṇe vinā artham bodhayati iti tatra tasya śakti grahaḥ pyeṣyavyaḥ iti
translated: And since a word that denotes does not convey the meaning without the apprehension of its power, the apprehension of its power in that case should also be accepted.

original: tataḥ kiṃ prakṛta ityata āha evamiti //
analyzed: tatas kim prakṛtaḥ iti atas āha evam iti
translated: What then is the point? To this he says 'thus'.

analyzed: evam vyāvṛtta rūpe yadā śakti grahaḥ bhavet
translated: Thus, even in a differentiated form, when there is apprehension of power,

analyzed: tasya
translated: of that...

original: evamuktaprakāreṇa vyāvṛttarūpe nissāmānye 'pi svarūpe vā bhede vā svarūpabhedādiśabdānāṃ🔽vācakatvaśaktigraho yadāṅgīkṛto bhavettadā sa ca śaktigrahastasya svarūpāderjñānaṃ vinā kuto bhavet /
analyzed: evam ukta prakāreṇa vyāvṛtta rūpe nissāmānye sva rūpe vā bhede vā sva rūpa bheda ādi śabdānām  vācaka tva śakti grahaḥ yadā aṅgīkṛtaḥ bhavet tadā sa ca śakti grahaḥ tasya svarūpa ādeḥ jñānam vinā kutas bhavet
translated: Thus, even in a differentiated form, in a particular, or in a universal, or in a difference, or in a nature, when the apprehension of the power of words like 'particular', etc.🔽as denoting is accepted, how can that apprehension of power occur without the knowledge of that particular, etc.?

analyzed: sambandha jñānasya sambandhi jñāna pūrvaka tva niyamāt na bhavet eva iti tat jñānam aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: Since the knowledge of the relation is invariably preceded by the knowledge of the relata, it cannot occur at all. Therefore, the knowledge of that should be accepted.

analyzed: sarveṣām svarūpāṇām bhedānām ca
translated: In the knowledge of all particulars and differences,

analyzed: sārvajñam āpatitam iti atas āha sāmānyatas iti
translated: To this he says 'from the general' etc.

original: sāmānyato jñānaṃ vinā sa ca bhavet kutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: sāmānyatas jñānam vinā sa ca bhavet kutas
translated: How can that be without knowledge of the general?
The acquisition of knowledge is possible only through knowledge of the general.

analyzed: viśeṣataḥ jñāna abhāvāt ca sārvajñāna āpattiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: And because there is no knowledge of particulars, the attainment of omniscience is not possible. This is the meaning.

original: nanu sāmānyavarjitasya svarūpādeḥ kathaṃ sāmānyato jñānamityata āha ata iti //
analyzed: nanu sāmānya varjitasya svarūpa ādeḥ katham sāmānyatas jñānam iti atas āha atas iti
translated: But how can there be knowledge of the general of the nature etc. which is devoid of the general? To this he says 'therefore' etc.

analyzed: atas viśeṣa sāmānya rūpam sarvam api iṣyate
translated: Therefore, everything is accepted to have the form of particulars and universals.

original: sarvamapi vastvasmābhirviśeṣasāmānyarūpaṃ vyāvṛttarūpaṃ sāmānyarūpaṃ ceṣyate 'to na kācidanupapattiḥ /
analyzed: sarvam api vastu asmābhiḥ viśeṣa sāmānya rūpam vyāvṛtta rūpam sāmānya rūpam ca iṣyate na kācid anupapattiḥ
translated: Everything is accepted by us to have the form of particulars and universals, the form of exclusions and the form of universals. Therefore, there is no inconsistency.

analyzed: kutas evam iṣyate
translated: From where is this accepted?

original: ataḥ pūrvanyāyāt /🔽yadi vyāvṛttameva syāttadoktaprakāreṇa sārvajñamāpadyeta śaktigrahābhāvo vā syāt /
analyzed: atas pūrva nyāyāt  yadi vyāvṛttam eva syāt tadā ukta prakāreṇa sārvajñam āpadyeta śakti graha abhāvaḥ vā syāt
translated: From the previous reasoning.🔽If it were only an exclusion, then omniscience would be attained in the manner stated, or there would be no apprehension of potency.

analyzed: yadi ca sāmānya rūpam eva bhavet tadā vyāvṛtta buddhaya nupapattiḥ eva iti
translated: And if it were only of the form of a universal, then the cognition of exclusion would be impossible.

analyzed: nanu idam pūrva ukta viruddham ucyate
translated: But this is said to be contradictory to what was said earlier.

original: yāvatā prāk svarūpādikaṃ nissāmānyameveti prasādhyedānīṃ sarvamapi viśeṣasāmānyarūpamiṣyata ityucyata ityata āha vyāvṛttamiti //
analyzed: yāvatā prāk svarūpa ādikam nissāmānyam eva iti prasādhya idānīm sarvam api viśeṣa sāmānya rūpam iṣyate iti ucyate iti atas āha vyāvṛttam iti
translated: Since it has been previously established that the form etc. are absolutely without any commonality, it is now said that everything is accepted to have the nature of both particular and universal. To this he says The excluded etc.

original: vyāvṛttaṃ yacca sāmānyaṃ tadeva syād viśeṣataḥ // / / //
analyzed: vyāvṛttam yat ca sāmānyam tat eva syāt viśeṣataḥ
translated: That which is excluded would be the universal, due to its particularity.

analyzed: na ca eka dharma tā tena padārthānām parasparam
translated: Therefore, the entities do not have a single property in relation to each other.

original: yadeva vyāvṛttaṃ svarūpaṃ tadeva viśeṣabalena sāmānyaṃ ca syādyatastena kāraṇena padārthānāṃ parasparamekadharmatā nāstīti /
analyzed: yat eva vyāvṛttam sva rūpam tat eva viśeṣa balena sāmānyam ca syāt yatas tena kāraṇena padārthānām parasparam eka dharma tā na asti iti
translated: That very excluded form would be the universal due to the power of the particular. For this reason, the entities do not have a single property in relation to each other.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

original: yatprāk svarūpabhedādau sāmānyaṃ nāstītyuktaṃ tatpadārthasvarūpāṇāṃ parasparamanugataikadharmatā nāstītyabhiprāyeṇa /🔽tadabhāve 'pi vyāvṛttasya
analyzed: yat prāk svarūpa bheda ādau sāmānyam na asti iti uktam tat padārtha svarūpāṇām parasparam anugata eka dharma tā na asti iti abhiprāyeṇa  tad abhāve vyāvṛttasya
translated: What was previously stated as the absence of a universal in the form etc., that is with the intention that the entities do not have a single property that is common to all in relation to each other.

original: svarūpābhinnasya pratiniyatasya sāmānyākārasyābhyupagame viśeṣasāmānyarūpaṃ sarvamapīṣyata ityuktamiti na pūrvottaravirodhaḥ /
analyzed: svarūpa abhinnasya pratiniyatasya sāmānya ākārasya abhyupagame viśeṣa sāmānya rūpam sarvam api iṣyate iti uktam iti na pūrva uttara virodhaḥ
translated: Even in the absence of that, when the form that is not different from the excluded, which is restricted, is accepted to have the nature of a universal, it is said that everything is accepted to have the nature of both particular and universal. Thus there is no contradiction between the previous and subsequent statements.

analyzed: na ca etat ayuktam
translated: And this is not unreasonable.

analyzed: ekasya eva vastunaḥ viśeṣa balena vyāvṛtta anuvṛtta buddhi janaka tvena viśeṣa sāmānya rūpa tā upapattiḥ ittiḥ iti
translated: Because it is possible for a single thing to have the nature of both particular and universal by producing cognitions that are both excluded and included due to the power of its particularity.

analyzed: evam go tva ādi sāmānyasya anugata tvam aṅgīkṛtya svarūpa tva ādi sāmānya abhāvāt tatra śabda śakti graha artham tad svarūpa jñānam apekṣitam iti uktam
translated: Thus, accepting the universal such as cowhood to be pervasive, it has been said that the knowledge of its nature is required for grasping the power of words in that [universal], because there is no universal such as substantiality.

analyzed: idānīm go tva ādikam api na anugatam iti āha dharmāṇām iti
translated: Now, he says that even cowhood etc. is not pervasive.

analyzed: dharmāṇām bheda dṛṣṭayā eva
translated: By the very perception of the difference of attributes...

analyzed: padārthānām paramparam eka dharma tā na iti etāvat anuvatarte
translated: The mutual oneness of attributes is not so - this much alone continues.

analyzed: samudāya vyatiriktānām śauklaya ādi dharmāṇām bheda dṛṣṭayā pratidharmi vyāvṛtta tva darśanāt tad dṛṣṭāntena
translated: By the perception of the difference of attributes such as whiteness, which are different from the whole, being seen to be excluded from each attribute, by that example,

analyzed: gavā ādi padārthānām api parasparam eka dharmatā anugata go tva ādi dharmavat tā na iti anumātavyam
translated: it should be inferred that even the mutual oneness of attributes such as cowhood, which is the possession of a pervasive attribute, is not so for the entities such as cows.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: go tva ādikam prati vyakti vyāvṛttam samudāya atirikta dharma tvāt śauklaya ādi vat iti
translated: Cowhood etc. is excluded from each individual, because it is an attribute different from the whole, like whiteness etc.

analyzed: evaśabdaḥ pratijñayā sambaddhayate
translated: The word eva (only) is connected with the proposition.

analyzed: tena anugata buddhi bādhaḥ iti nirākaroti
translated: Therefore, the cognition that follows is contradicted. Thus he refutes.

analyzed: anugata buddheḥ anyathā eva upapādita tvāt
translated: Because the cognition that follows is explained in another way.

analyzed: athavā yathā anyāsām eva astu sambandhaḥ
translated: Or let there be a relation of the same as it is placed.

analyzed: prābhākarāḥ manyante
translated: The Prabhākaras think.

original: rūpādayo 'pi dharmā anuvṛttā eva na tu prativyakti bhidyate /
analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ pi dharmāḥ anuvṛttāḥ eva na tu prativyakti bhidyate
translated: Even forms and other properties are only universal, not different for each individual.

analyzed: atas sādhya vikala tā iti
translated: Therefore, it is inconclusive.

analyzed: tad nirāsāya bheda dṛṣṭayā eva iti uktam
translated: To refute that, it is said only by the perception of difference.

analyzed: anyathā bhedāt iti eva avakṣyat
translated: Otherwise, he would have simply said because of difference.

analyzed: śauklaya ādeḥ vyāvṛtta tve nu vṛtta pratyayaḥ viruddhayeta iti atas āha tat iti
translated: If the whiteness, etc. are excluded, the cognition of the universal is contradicted. Therefore, it is said that.

analyzed: tad sādṛśyasya darśanāt
translated: Because the similarity of that is seen.

original: śauklayamidaṃ śauklayamidamiti pratītau himaśauklayasādṛśyameva himāṃśuśauklaye pratīyate natu tenaikyamityato na virodhaḥ /
analyzed: śauklayam idam śauklayam idam iti pratītau hima śauklaya sādṛśyam eva himāṃśu śauklaye pratīyate na tu tena aikyam iti atas na virodhaḥ
translated: When there is the cognition this is whiteness, this is whiteness, only the similarity to the whiteness of snow is cognized in the whiteness of the moon, not identity with it. Therefore, there is no contradiction.

original: mā bhūdanugataṃ sāmānyaṃ tataḥ kiṃ prakṛta ityata āha ata iti //
analyzed: mā bhūt anugatam sāmānyam tatas kim prakṛte iti atas āha atas iti
translated: If there is no universal, what is the point of the present discussion? To this, it is said therefore.

analyzed: atas sarva padārthāḥ ca sāmānyāt sākṣi gocarāḥ
translated: Therefore, all objects are the objects of perception through the universal.

original: anugatasāmānyābhāvenātītānāgatavartamānavyaktīnāmeva vācyatvādagṛhītaśaktīnāṃ ca🔽padānāmabodhakatvāt śaktigrahaṇasya ca padārthajñānena vināsambhavādviśeṣato jñāne
analyzed: anugata sāmānya abhāvena atīta anāgata vartamāna vyaktīnām eva vācya tvāt agṛhīta śaktīnām ca  padānām abodhaka tvāt śakti grahaṇasya ca padārtha jñānena vinā asambhavāt viśeṣataḥ jñāne
translated: Because only past, future and present individuals are denoted due to the absence of a universal that pervades them, and because words whose power is not grasped do not convey meaning, and because the grasping of power is not possible without the knowledge of the meaning of words, and because of the consequence of omniscience

analyzed: sārvajña āpatteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: if the knowledge of particulars is necessary, the meaning is that.

analyzed: sarve iti
translated: All means

analyzed: vartamāna atīta anāgatāḥ
translated: past, future and present.

analyzed: astu atīta ādi jñāna apekṣā śaktigrahasya
translated: Let there be dependence on the knowledge of past etc. for grasping power.

original: tacca sākṣiṇeti kuta ityata āha sarvamiti //
analyzed: tat ca sākṣiṇā iti kutas iti atas āha sarvam iti
translated: And that is by the witness. How so? To this he says 'all' etc.

analyzed: sarvam iti eva vijñānam sarveṣām katham anyathā
translated: How else can there be the knowledge of all as 'all'?
The word 'eva' (only) is for the purpose of excluding the form of particulars.

analyzed: pramāṇa antara abhāvāt iti bhāvaḥ  anumānena atīta ādi sarva sāmānya jñānam bhaviṣyati iti asya ca idam uttaram
translated: The meaning is that there is no other means of knowledge.🔽If it is argued that the knowledge of all universals of past etc. will be by inference, this is the answer to that.

original: atītānāgatavartamānaṃ sarvamapi liṅgamanena sādhyena vyāptamiti jñānāpekṣaṃ khalvanumānam /
analyzed: atīta anāgata vartamānam sarvam api liṅgam anena sādhyena vyāptam iti jñāna apekṣam khalu anumānam
translated: Inference indeed depends on the knowledge that all the inferential mark, whether past, future or present, is pervaded by this probandum.

analyzed: na ca etat jñānam sākṣiṇā vinā sambhavati iti
translated: And this knowledge is not possible without the witness.

analyzed: yat vā pramāṇa antaram eva anena ucyate
translated: Or, when the witness has as its object the universal form of all past etc., this is said to be the other means of knowledge.

original: atītādikaṃ sarvaṃ dhūmādi tathāvidhenāgnyādinā vyāptamiti jñānapūrvakaṃ khalvanumānam /
analyzed: atīta ādikam sarvam dhūma ādi tathāvidhena agni ādinā vyāptam iti jñāna pūrvakam khalu anumānam
translated: For inference is preceded by the knowledge that all past etc. things such as smoke are pervaded by such things as fire in that way.

analyzed: tathā ca tīta ādi gocara tva abhāve nyasya tathāvidhasya abhāvāt anumāna mātra ucchedaḥ syāt iti
translated: And so, if perception did not have past etc. as its object, and there were no other such thing, inference alone would be destroyed.

analyzed: kiñca asti tāvat sarveṣām sarva śabda śakti grahaḥ  anyathā asarvam khalu idam brahma
translated: Moreover, there is indeed the comprehension of the power of all words for all.

analyzed: iti vyavahāra vilopa prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of the usage All this is Brahman.

original: śaktigrahaścārthagrahāpekṣa iti sarveṣāṃ sāmānyataḥ sarvamiti jñānamaṅgīkāryam /
analyzed: śakti grahaḥ ca artha graha apekṣaḥ iti sarveṣām sāmānyatas sarvam iti jñānam aṅgīkāryam
translated: And the comprehension of power depends on the comprehension of meaning. Therefore, the knowledge of all in a general way that all must be accepted.

analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ ca atīta ādi sarva gocara tva abhāve tat na syāt iti
translated: And that would not be possible if perception did not have past etc. as its object.

original: nanvanugatasāmānyābhāve vyaktīnāmānantyādvayabhicārācca śabdaśaktigraha eva na saṅgacchate /
analyzed: nanu anugata sāmānya abhāve vyaktīnām ānantyāt vayabhicārāt ca śabda śakti grahaḥ eva na saṅgacchate
translated: But in the absence of a universal that pervades all, due to the infinite number of individual things and the possibility of error, the comprehension of the power of words itself is not possible.

analyzed: kutas tad anyathā anupapattyā sākṣiṇaḥ utīta ādi gocara tva siddhiḥ iti atas āha kiñcid iti  kiñcid sādṛśya vijñānāt akhilasya api vastunaḥ
translated: How then can the perception of past etc. be established by the non-applicability of that? To this he says Moreover, etc.🔽From the knowledge of a little similarity, there would be the comprehension of the power of words for all things.

analyzed: śabda śakti grahaḥ ca syāt
translated: And there would be the apprehension of the power of the word.🔽🔽

analyzed: tat etat vaiśeṣika parīkṣāyām vyākhyāta prāyam
translated: This has been explained for the most part in the examination of the Vaiśeṣika [school].

original: nanvevaṃ sati gośabdasya gavaye 'pi śaktiṃ gṛhṇīyāt /🔽sādṛśyasadbhāvādityata āha tattaditi //
analyzed: nanu evam sati go śabdasya gavaye śaktim gṛhṇīyāt  sādṛśya sadbhāvāt iti atas āha tat tat iti
translated: If that is so, then one would grasp the power of the word 'cow' even with regard to a gayal,🔽because of the existence of similarity. To this he says 'that and that' (in the verse).

analyzed: tad tad sādṛśya mānataḥ
translated: The meaning is that the knowledge of that and that similarity is the cause of grasping the power of the word.

analyzed: pūrveṇa anvayaḥ
translated: The connection is with the preceding [verse].

analyzed: na yat kiñcid sādṛśya jñānam śabda śakti grahaṇa kāraṇam
translated: Any knowledge of similarity is not the cause of grasping the power of the word.

analyzed: kintu ativyāpti vidhuram
translated: But [it is] that which is free from over-extension.

analyzed: yathā go śabde sāsnādimattvam evam anyatra anyat iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the case of the word 'cow', it is only the possession of a dewlap, and in other cases something else.

analyzed: etena pūrvaḥ kiñcid
translated: By this, the previous [verse] is explained a little.

analyzed: śabdaḥ vyākhyātaḥ bhavati
translated: The word is explained.

original: evaṃ sākṣipratyakṣasya vartamānamātragrāhitvamapākṛtya mānasapratyakṣasyāpi tadapākaroti pratyakṣamiti //🔽pratyakṣaṃ mānasaṃ caiva yadātītārthagocaram // / / //
analyzed: evam sākṣi pratyakṣasya vartamāna mātra grāhi tvam apākṛtya mānasa pratyakṣasya api tat apākaroti pratyakṣam iti  pratyakṣam mānasam ca eva yadā atīta artha gocaram
