translated: Having thus refuted the fact that perception by the witness (i.e. the inner sense) grasps only the present, he refutes the same with regard to mental perception also, with (the words), 'Perception' (in the verse).🔽Perception and mental perception, when they have as their object a past object,

analyzed: mānasam pratyakṣam ca atīta artha gocaram eva yat smṛti kāraṇam iti
translated: are the cause of memory. That mental perception and that perception which have as their object a past object are the cause of memory.

analyzed: yadā iti uttara vākye sambaddhayate
translated: The word 'which' is connected with the subsequent sentence.

original: pūrvānubhavānadhikaviṣayāyāḥ smṛteḥ prāmāṇyameva durlabhaṃ kuto mānasapratyakṣajatvamityata āha yadetitadeti / /
analyzed: pūrva anubhava anadhika viṣayāyāḥ smṛteḥ prāmāṇyam eva durlabham kutas mānasa pratyakṣa ja tvam iti atas āha yadā iti tadā iti
translated: The validity itself of memory, which has for its object something not experienced before, is difficult to establish; how much more so its being produced by mental perception? To this he says: When it is thus, then the validity of memory, qualified by pastness, is established.

analyzed: tadā smṛti pramāṇa tvam atīta tva viśeṣitam
translated: When it is thus, then the validity of memory, qualified by pastness, is established.

original: yadā yasmāt atītatvaviśeṣitam arthaṃ smṛtirviṣayīkarotīti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: yadā yasmāt atīta tva viśeṣitam artham smṛtiḥ viṣayīkaroti iti śeṣaḥ
translated: When memory makes the object qualified by pastness its object, this is the remainder.

analyzed: tadā tasmāt smṛti pramāṇa tvam siddham
translated: Then, from that, the validity of memory is established.

original: atītatvaviśeṣitārthaviṣayatve 'pi kathaṃ smṛteḥ pramāṇatvamityata āha ādhikyamiti //
analyzed: atīta tva viśeṣita artha viṣaya tve pi katham smṛteḥ pramāṇa tvam iti atas āha ādhikyam iti
translated: Even when the object qualified by pastness is the object of memory, how can memory be valid? To this he says: The superiority.

analyzed: ādhikyam anubhūtāt tu yadā atīta tvam iṣyate
translated: The superiority is accepted as pastness over what is experienced.

original: mānatā ca kathaṃ na syāt smṛter / / / // / /d //
analyzed: māna tā ca katham na syāt smṛteḥ
translated: And how can memory not have validity?

original: yasmātsmṛtiviṣayīkṛtamatītatvaṃ vartamānatayānubhūtārthādadhikyamiṣyate sarvaistasmātsmṛtermānatā kathaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: yasmāt smṛti viṣayīkṛtam atīta tvam vartamānatayā anubhūta arthāt ādhikyam iṣyate sarvaiḥ tasmāt smṛteḥ māna tā katham na syāt
translated: Since all accept that the pastness which is made the object of memory is superior to the object experienced as present, how can memory not have validity?

original: mānatve ca mānasapratyakṣajatvaṃ kathaṃ na syāditi cārthaḥ /
analyzed: māna tve ca mānasa pratyakṣa ja tvam katham na syāt iti ca arthaḥ
translated: And the meaning is: and how can it not be produced by mental perception if it has validity?

analyzed: api ca anadhigata artha gantṛ tvam pramāṇa lakṣaṇam aṅgīkṛtya idam smṛteḥ anubhava adhika viṣaya tvam vyutpāditam
translated: Moreover, this distinction between memory and experience in regard to their objects has been explained on the basis of accepting the definition of a means of valid knowledge as that which leads to the knowledge of a hitherto unknown object.

analyzed: vastutas tu na idam lakṣaṇam
translated: But this is not the definition (of a means of valid knowledge).

analyzed: kintu yathārtha tvam eva
translated: Rather, it is only the conformity with the real state of things.

analyzed: tat ca asti smṛteḥ anubhava siddham
translated: And that exists in memory, as established by experience.

analyzed: bādhaka pratyaye hi sati tat na bhavet
translated: It would not exist if there were a contradictory cognition.

analyzed: na ca asau atra asti iti āha bādhaḥ ca iti
translated: And that is not present here, he says: And there is no contradiction here.

analyzed: bādhaḥ ca na atrahi
translated: And there is no contradiction here.

original: cākṣuṣādipratyakṣe 'pi na vartamānamātragrāhitvaniyama iti bhāvenāha mānatvamiti //
analyzed: cākṣuṣa ādi pratyakṣe pi na vartamāna mātra grāhi tva niyamaḥ iti bhāvena āha māna tvam iti
translated: Even in visual and other direct perception, there is no restriction to grasping only the present. With this in mind, he says authoritativeness etc.

analyzed: māna tvam pratyabhijñāyāḥ api sarva anubhūti gam
translated: Authoritativeness is also recognized in recognition by all experiencers.

analyzed: sarve hi parīkṣakāḥ tad balena ātma ādeḥ sthāyi tvam sādhayanti
translated: For all investigators establish the permanence of the self etc. on the strength of that.

original: tataḥ kiṃ prakṛta ityata āha atīteti //
analyzed: tatas kim prakṛtaḥ iti atas āha atīta iti
translated: Then what is the point? To this he says past etc.

analyzed: atīta vartamāna tva dharmiṇī sā ca dṛśyate
translated: And that is seen as having the property of being past and present.

analyzed: atīta tva vartamāna tva dharma viśiṣya artha viṣaya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it has as its object a thing qualified by the properties of being past and present.

analyzed: dṛśyate sākṣiṇā
translated: It is seen by the witness.

analyzed: saḥ yam iti hi pratyabhijñā kāraḥ nubhūyate
translated: For the form of recognition is experienced as this is the same.

original: sā ca cakṣurādinaiva jāyata iti bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: sā ca cakṣuḥ ādinā eva jāyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And that is produced only by the eye, etc. This is the idea.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is thought:

analyzed: pratyabhijñāyām catvāraḥ pakṣāḥ sambhavanti
translated: In recognition, four positions are possible.

original: anubhava eveti vā smṛtireveti vā smṛtyanubhavarūpaṃ jñānadvayamiti caikameva jñānamaṃśe smṛtiraṃśe 'nubhava iti veti /
analyzed: anubhavaḥ eva iti vā smṛtiḥ eva iti vā smṛti anubhava rūpam jñāna dvayam iti ca ekam eva jñānam aṃśe smṛtiḥ aṃśe nubhavaḥ iti vā iti
translated: Either it is only experience, or it is only memory, or it is a pair of cognitions, one of memory and one of experience, or it is a single cognition, with the part of memory and the part of experience.

analyzed: tatra na tāvat ādyaḥ
translated: Among these, the first is not so.

original: tathātve hyahamityeva syānna tu sa iti /
analyzed: tathātve hi aham iti eva syāt na tu saḥ iti
translated: For if it were so, it would be only I, not he.

analyzed: na api dvitīyaḥ
translated: Nor is the second so.

original: tathā sati sa ityeva syānna tvayamiti /
analyzed: tathā sati saḥ iti eva syāt na tu ayam iti
translated: For if it were so, it would be only he, not this.

analyzed: vakṣyamāṇa
translated: The fault that will be stated

analyzed: ṇaḥ doṣaḥ ca syāt
translated: would also be there.

analyzed: atha uttaram pakṣa dvayam eva aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: If the last two positions are to be accepted,

original: tathāca sa ityaṃśasya smṛtitvānna cākṣuṣādipratyakṣasyātītaviṣayatvamityata āha naceti //
analyzed: tathā ca saḥ iti aṃśasya smṛti tvāt na cākṣuṣa ādi pratyakṣasya atīta viṣaya tvam iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: and so, because the part he is memory, the present perception of the eye, etc. does not have a past object, then he says no etc.

analyzed: na ca sā smṛti mātrā ardhā
translated: And that is not only half memory.

analyzed: smṛtiḥ eva mātrā
translated: Memory is the measure.

original: smṛtimātrā smṛtimātrārdhaṃ yasyāḥ sā tathoktā smṛtyanubhavarūpaikadeśasamudāyarūpā tathā smṛtyanubhavātmakaikajñānarūpā ca netyarthaḥ /
analyzed: smṛti mātrā smṛti mātra ardham yasyāḥ sā tathā uktā smṛti anubhava rūpa eka deśa samudāya rūpā tathā smṛti anubhava ātmaka eka jñāna rūpā ca na iti arthaḥ
translated: That which has only memory as its measure is said to be so. It is not of the form of a single cognition consisting of the collection of the two parts of memory and experience, nor is it of the form of a single cognition consisting of memory and experience. This is the meaning.

analyzed: kutas na iti atas prathama pratijñāyām hetum āha tad idaṃtva iti
translated: Why not? Therefore, in the first proposition, he states the reason: That and this are grasped as one...

analyzed: tad idantva graha ekataḥ
translated: That and this are grasped as one...

analyzed: tattva idantva grahayoḥ eka tva anubhavāt
translated: Because the grasping of that and this is experienced as one.

analyzed: graha grahaṇena anubhava tvam sūcayati
translated: By the word grasping, he indicates the nature of experience.

analyzed: dvitīya pratijñāyām hetum āha tad idantva iti
translated: In the second proposition, he states the reason: That and this are grasped...

analyzed: tattva idantva grahasya ekatvāt niraṃśa tvāt
translated: Because the grasping of that and this is one, because it is partless.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: pratyabhijñā na smṛtiḥ eva iti pareṇa api uktam
translated: It has been stated by the opponent also that recognition is not mere memory.

analyzed: na api jñāna dvaya rūpā
translated: Nor is it of the form of two cognitions.

analyzed: tat tāvataḥ evā idantāyām māna abhāva prasaṅgena kṣaṇa bhaṅga bhaṅga asiddheḥ
translated: Because, in that case, the refutation of momentariness would not be established, as it would lead to the absence of a valid means of knowledge in the case of thisness.

analyzed: na ca smṛti anubhava rūpam ekam eva jñānam
translated: And one cognition cannot be of the form of memory and experience.

analyzed: eka tve dvi rūpa tā avirodhāt
translated: Because if it were one, the contradiction of having two forms would arise.

original: tasmādanubhavarūpamekameva vijñānaṃ saṃskārasacivena cakṣurādinā jātatvātsoyamityākāraṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tasmāt anubhava rūpam ekam eva vijñānam saṃskāra sacivena cakṣuḥ ādinā jāta tvāt saḥ yam iti ākāram bhavati
translated: Therefore, consciousness is of the form of experience alone, because it arises from the eye etc. assisted by impressions, it has the form this is that.

analyzed: yathā khalu śukla harita pīta ādi rūpāṇām citra rūpa ārambhaka tvam
translated: Just as variegated forms are composed of white, green, yellow etc. forms,

analyzed: yathā vā doṣa sahakṛtānām indriyāṇām viparyaya hetu tvam
translated: or just as the senses, when aided by defects, are the cause of error,

original: tathā saṃskārasacivānāmindriyāṇāṃ pratyabhijñāhetutvaṃ bhaviṣyatīti ko doṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā saṃskāra sacivānām indriyāṇām pratyabhijñā hetu tvam bhaviṣyati iti kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: Similarly, why should there be any objection to the sense-organs, which are associated with impressions, being the cause of recognition?

analyzed: na ca saṃskārasya svatantrasya jñāna hetu tvam
translated: And the impression by itself is not the cause of knowledge.

analyzed: smṛteḥ mānasa pratyakṣa ja tva aṅgīkārāt iti
translated: Because memory is accepted as arising from mental perception.

analyzed: tat ced na uttara gocaram ityādinā uktam artham upasaṃharati atas iti
translated: And this he concludes with the word 'therefore' (in the text).

original: ato na vatarmānaikaniyamaḥ syād grahe 'kṣaje // / / //🔽vartamānaikaniyamaḥ vartamānamekameva viṣayīkarotītyevaṃrūpo niyamaḥ / /
analyzed: atas na syāt grahe kṣaje  vartamāna eka niyamaḥ vartamānam ekam eva viṣayīkaroti iti evaṃrūpaḥ niyamaḥ
translated: Therefore, there would not be the restriction of the non-eye sense-organs to the present object.🔽The restriction in the form 'it cognizes only the present' (is not applicable to the non-eye sense-organs).

original: pramāṇaprameyapramātṛbhedaṃ viśvamabādhyamiti yaduktaṃ tadupasaṃhariṣyannarthagatāyā jñātatāyāḥ prākaṭyāparaparyāyā
analyzed: pramāṇa prameya pramātṛ bhedam viśvam abādhyam iti yat uktam tat upasaṃhariṣyan artha gatāyāḥ jñāta tāyāḥ prākaṭya apara paryāyā
translated: It has been said that the entire universe consisting of the means of valid knowledge, the objects of valid knowledge and the knowers is unobstructed. He is about to conclude that. The manifestation of the knownness belonging to the object, which is synonymous with manifestation of thatness,

original: tattāprākaṭyasamākhyāyāḥ pramiteścaturthyā vidyamānatvātkathaṃ trividhaṃ viśvamityāśaṅkāṃ tāvatpariharati naceti //
analyzed: tattā prākaṭya samākhyāyāḥ pramiteḥ caturthyāḥ vidyamāna tvāt katham trividham viśvam iti āśaṅkām tāvat pariharati na ca iti
translated: and the fourth one, which is the ascertainment, since these two exist, how can the universe be threefold? He first answers this doubt with the words 'and nowhere else'.

analyzed: na ca pramāṇataḥ nyā syāt pramitiḥ nāma kutracid
translated: And nowhere else is there anything called ascertainment apart from the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: māna abhāvāt gauravāt ca kalpanāyāḥ kim etayā
translated: Because there is no proof (for its existence) and because of the difficulty (in postulating it), what is the use of this (postulation)?

analyzed: pramitiḥ nāma vastu na asti eva tatra māna abhāvāt
translated: The so-called cognition does not exist at all, because there is no means of valid knowledge regarding it.

original: nanu kathaṃ mānābhāvaḥ /🔽pramātā ca prameyaṃ ca pramāṇaṃ pramitistathā' /
analyzed: nanu katham māna abhāvaḥ  pramātā ca prameyam ca pramāṇam pramitiḥ tathā
translated: But how can there be no means of valid knowledge?🔽Because of scriptures such as The cognizer, the object to be cognized, the means of valid knowledge, and the cognition,

analyzed: ityādeḥ āgamasya vidyamāna tvāt iti atas uktam pramāṇataḥ nyeti
translated: it is said other than the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: dvividham pramāṇam karaṇam phalam ca
translated: The means of valid knowledge is of two kinds: instrument and result.

original: atra tatra pramāṇaśabdena karaṇamabhidhāya pramitiśabdena phalarūpapramāṇamevocyate /
analyzed: atra tatra pramāṇa śabdena karaṇam abhidhāya pramiti śabdena phala rūpa pramāṇam eva ucyate
translated: Here, in that scripture, the means of valid knowledge is denoted by the word means of valid knowledge, and the means of valid knowledge itself in the form of result is denoted by the word cognition.

analyzed: na tu tatas nyā pramitiḥ iti
translated: But cognition is not different from that.

analyzed: asti tāvat artha jñānayoḥ viṣaya viṣayi bhāva niyamaḥ
translated: There is indeed a restriction of the relation between object and subject between the object and the knowledge of the object.

analyzed: na ca asau sattayā kāraṇa tvena vā ativyāpteḥ
translated: And this is not due to existence or being a cause, because of over-extension.

analyzed: na api tādātmya sārūpyābhyām
translated: Nor is it due to identity or similarity.

analyzed: asambhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible.

analyzed: yatra jñāne yaḥ rthaḥ vabhāsate tatra asau
translated: Where an object appears in a cognition, it would be

analyzed: syā asau viṣayaḥ iti atra saptamī artha anupapattiḥ
translated: there. In this case, the genitive case would be illogical.

original: tasmādyena yasyātiśaya utpadyate tasyāsau viṣaya ityaṅgīkāryam /
analyzed: tasmāt yena yasya atiśayaḥ utpadyate tasya asau viṣayaḥ iti aṅgīkāryam
translated: Therefore, it must be accepted that that by which a particular quality is produced in something, that is its object.

original: tathā cārthasya viṣayatvasiddhaye jñānajanyo 'rthagato 'tiśayaḥ sarvathāṅgīkārya iti kathaṃ mānābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca arthasya viṣaya tva siddhaye jñāna janyaḥ ṛtha gataḥ tiśayaḥ sarvathā aṅgīkāryaḥ iti katham māna abhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, in order to establish the object as the content, an excess in the object produced by cognition must be accepted in every way. So how can there be no means of valid knowledge?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati atīta anāgatayoḥ jñāna viṣaya tā bhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if that were so, the past and future would not be the content of cognition.

original: na hyasati dharmiṇi tatra dharmotpattiḥ sambhavati /
analyzed: na hi asati dharmiṇi tatra dharma utpattiḥ sambhavati
translated: For when the substratum does not exist, the arising of a property in it is not possible.

original: atha karaṇasambhavāttatra viṣayatvamityucyate tarhi vartamāne 'pi tathā sambhavānna jñātatā kalpanīyeti /
analyzed: atha karaṇa sambhavāt tatra viṣaya tvam iti ucyate tarhi vartamāne tathā sambhavāt na jñāta tā kalpanīyā iti
translated: But if it is said that the content is there because the means of knowledge is possible, then even in the present, because it is possible in that way, the knownness should not be imagined.

analyzed: tat idam uktam kutracid iti
translated: This is what is meant by saying in some cases.

analyzed: atīta ādi vat vartamāne pi na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it does not exist in the present also, like the past etc.

original: kiñca jñānaṃ svaviṣaye jñātatāmupajanayati yatra kvacidvā /
analyzed: kiñca jñānam sva viṣaye jñāta tām upajanayati yatra kvacid vā
translated: Moreover, does cognition produce knownness in its own object, or somewhere else?

analyzed: dvitīye tiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the second case, there is the fallacy of over-extension.

analyzed: ādye jñāta upajananāt prāk eva arthasya viṣaya tva siddheḥ vyartham tad kalpanam iti āha kim etayā iti
translated: In the first case, since the object is established as the content even before the production of knownness, the imagination of that is useless. This is what is said by what is the use of this?

original: api ca jñātatāyāmapi jñātatotpādo 'ṅgīkriyate na vā /
analyzed: api ca jñāta tāyām api jñāta tā utpādaḥ ṅgīkriyate na vā
translated: Moreover, is the production of knownness accepted even in knownness or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣe jñāna viṣaya tvam na syāt
translated: If not, it would not be the content of cognition.

original: ādye 'nubhavānārūḍhaṃ jñātatāpravāhamaṅgīkurvāṇasya kalpanāgauravaṃ syādityāha kalpanāyā gauravācceti //
analyzed: ādye nubhava an ārūḍham jñāta tā pravāham aṅgīkurvāṇasya kalpanā gauravam syāt iti āha kalpanāyāḥ gauravāt ca iti
translated: If the first, then there would be the difficulty of the assumption of a series of cognitions not resting on experience, for him who admits the series of cognitions of the form of knownness. This is what is said by the words ‘and on account of the difficulty of the assumption’.

original: atha jñātatā jñātatāntaramantareṇaiva viṣaya iti kalpyate /
analyzed: atha jñāta tā jñāta tā antaram antareṇa eva viṣayaḥ iti kalpyate
translated: If, on the other hand, it is assumed that knownness is the object of itself, without the intervention of another knownness,

analyzed: tadā api kalpanā gauravam eva
translated: then also there is the same difficulty of the assumption.

original: etena jñānaṃ svaviṣaye kiñcitkaroti kriyātvādgamanavadityanumānamapi nirastam /
analyzed: etena jñānam sva viṣaye kiñcid karoti kriyā tvāt gamana vat iti anumānam api nirastam
translated: By this, the inference also is refuted, viz., that ‘cognition does something to its object, because it is an action, like the act of going’.

analyzed: jñāna mātra pakṣīkāre tīta anāgata jñāta tā jñāneṣu bādhāt
translated: For, if the view is that cognition is mere illumination, then there is annulment in the case of the cognition of the knownness of the past and the future.

analyzed: anyathā tatra eva vyabhicārāt iti
translated: Otherwise, there would be the fallacy of the reason being found even where there is no consequence.

original: nanu jñāto ghaṭaḥ prakaṭo ghaṭa ityarthaviśeṣaṇatayā jñātatā pratyakṣamīkṣyata ityata āha mayeti //
analyzed: nanu jñātaḥ ghaṭaḥ prakaṭaḥ ghaṭaḥ iti artha viśeṣaṇa tayā jñāta tā pratyakṣam īkṣyate iti atas āha mayā iti
translated: But it is seen that knownness is perceived as the qualification of the object, in the expressions ‘the jar is known’ and ‘the manifest jar’,—to this he says ‘Mayeti’.

analyzed: mayā etat jñātam iti tu sākṣi gam jñāna gocaram  jñānam eva
translated: But the cognition ‘this is known by me’ is the object of the cognition of the witness.🔽Cognition alone is the object of the cognition of the witness.

analyzed: jñānam eva mayā etat jñātam iti jñāna gocaram
translated: Cognition alone is the object of the cognition ‘this is known by me’.

original: kriyā hi kartṛsthaiva yadā kartṛprādhānyena vyavahriyate tadā kartṛdharmatayā pratīyate /
analyzed: kriyā hi kartṛ sthā eva yadā kartṛ prādhānyena vyavahriyate tadā kartṛ dharma tayā pratīyate
translated: For, an action always resides in the agent. When it is spoken of with reference to the agent as the principal factor, then it is cognised as the attribute of the agent.

analyzed: yathā devadattaḥ ghaṭam icchati dveṣyi iti
translated: For example, Devadatta desires the jar, he hates (someone).

analyzed: yadā tu karma prādhānyena tadā tad dharma tayā
translated: But when it is predominant in action, then it is as its property.

analyzed: yathā iṣyaḥ dviṣyaḥ iti
translated: As desire and hatred are wished for.

analyzed: yadā punar sva prādhānyena tadā svatantrā eva
translated: But when it is predominant in itself, then it is independent.

analyzed: yathā icchā dveṣaḥ iti
translated: As desire and hatred are.

analyzed: eva ām ātma gatam eva jñānam viṣaya dharma tayā avabhāsate iti kim anupapannam
translated: So is it not unestablished that knowledge itself, which is in the self, appears as the property of the object?

analyzed: nanu ca jñānam tāvat na pratyakṣam
translated: But surely knowledge is not perception.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Because:

original: na tāvatpūrvabhāvino jñānasya jñānaṃ viṣayaḥ /🔽tathā sati jñāsyāmītyevameva
analyzed: na tāvat pūrva bhāvinaḥ jñānasya jñānam viṣayaḥ  tathā sati jñāsyāmi iti evam eva
translated: First, the knowledge of prior knowledge is not the object.🔽If that were so, it would be I will know in this way,

analyzed: syāt na tu jānāmi iti
translated: but not I know.

analyzed: na api āgāminaḥ
translated: Nor is it of the future.

analyzed: tathātve hi ajñāsiṣam iti eva syāt
translated: For if it were so, it would be I did not know.

analyzed: na ca sahabhāvi jñāna antaram asti
translated: And there is no other knowledge coexisting with it.

original: tato jñātatālakṣaṇakāryeṇaivānumātavyamiti kathaṃ sā nābhyupagamyata ityata uktam sākṣiṇamiti //
analyzed: tatas jñāta tā lakṣaṇa kāryeṇa eva anumātavyam iti katham sā na abhyupagamyate iti atas uktam sākṣiṇam iti
translated: Therefore, it should be inferred only by the effect characterized as known. How is that not accepted? Therefore it is said: The witness.

analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ nitya tvāt na ukta doṣaḥ
translated: Because the witness is eternal, there is no fault stated.

analyzed: sa ca sva prakāśaḥ iti
translated: And that is self-luminous.

analyzed: anupalambha bādhitā ca jñāta tā iti āha tatas nyeti
translated: And knowability is contradicted by non-apprehension. Therefore it is said: From that, etc.

analyzed: tatas nyā na pramitiḥ nāma dṛśyate
translated: From that, another is not seen named ascertainment.

original: prathamajñāne hi śuddha evārtho jñāyate na jñātatāviśiṣyaḥ /
analyzed: prathama jñāne hi śuddhaḥ eva arthaḥ jñāyate na jñāta tā viśiṣyaḥ
translated: For in the first cognition, the object is known as pure, not qualified by the cognition.

analyzed: tadānīm tasyāḥ a jāta tvāt
translated: Because at that time, it has not yet arisen.

analyzed: tām utpādya punar tad viśiṣyam artham viṣayīkaroti iti pakṣe viramya vyāpāra prasaṅgāt
translated: If it is argued that after producing that [cognition], it again makes the object qualified by that its object, then there would be the undesirable consequence of a delayed operation.

analyzed: na ca prathama jñāna viṣayīkṛtāt adhikaḥ rthaḥ uttara jñāneṣu cakāsti
translated: And in the subsequent cognitions, the object does not appear as more than the object cognized in the first cognition.

original: jñāta ityatra tu jñānaṃ viṣaya ityuktameveti / /🔽idānīmīśatajjñānetyādinoktamarthamupasaṃharati māneti //
analyzed: jñātaḥ iti atra tu jñānam viṣayaḥ iti uktam eva iti  idānīm īśa tad jñāna ityādinā uktam artham upasaṃharati māna iti
translated: But in the case of known, it has already been stated that cognition is the object.🔽Now, beginning with in the cognition of the Lord, he concludes the meaning stated. He says māne (in the means of knowledge).

analyzed: māna a mātṛ prameyāṇām tad ucchittiḥ na hi kvacid
translated: The means of knowledge, the cognizer, and the objects of knowledge - their destruction is nowhere.

original: tattasmānmānādibhedena trividhameva viśvaṃ tasya kvacidapyucchittirbādho nāstī
analyzed: tat tasmāt māna ādi bhedena trividham eva viśvam tasya kvacid api ucchittiḥ bādhaḥ
translated: Therefore, the universe is of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the means of knowledge etc., and there is no contradiction anywhere of that.

analyzed: sti eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it exists.

analyzed: prakṛtam anusa
translated: Continuing the main topic,

analyzed: upasaṃharan svapnasya mithyātvam hetu antareṇa dūṣayati svāpnānām api iti
translated: he concludes and refutes the falsity of dreams with another reason, beginning with of the objects in dreams.

original: svapnānāmapi caiteṣāṃ na bādho dṛśyate kvacit // / / //
analyzed: svapnānām api ca eteṣām na bādhaḥ dṛśyate kvacid
translated: And of the objects in dreams, no contradiction is ever seen.

analyzed: caḥ hetau
translated: Ca (and) is in the sense of reason.

analyzed: yasmāt svapnānām api ete
translated: Because even of the objects in dreams,

original: ṣāṃ mānamātṛprameyāṇāṃ kvacitkāle na bādho dṛśyate ataḥ svapno mithyā naiveti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: māna mātṛ prameyāṇām kvacid kāle na bādhaḥ dṛśyate atas svapnaḥ mithyā nā evā iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: because obstruction is not seen at some time of the measured objects of the mind, sleep is not false at all.

analyzed: na kevalam bāhya prapañcaḥ iti apeḥ arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of not only is that not only the external world.

original: svapnādutthitasya nātra gajo 'bhūdityādinā bādhadarśanātkathametadityata āha jāgrattvamātramiti //
analyzed: svapnāt utthitasya na atra gajaḥ bhūt ityādinā bādha darśanāt katham etat iti atas āha jāgrat tva mātram iti
translated: Since obstruction is seen by one who has arisen from sleep, thinking there was no elephant here, etc., how is this? To this he says the mere state of being awake, etc.

analyzed: jāgrat tva mātram atra ekam anyathā dṛśyate sphuṭam
translated: The mere state of being awake is one here, but is clearly seen otherwise.

analyzed: atas mithyā na ca svapnaḥ
translated: Therefore, sleep is not false.

analyzed: anyathā a vidyamāna tvena
translated: Otherwise, as non-existent.

analyzed: vyākhyāta prāyam etat
translated: This has been explained almost completely.

analyzed: yat tu uktam rathaḥ yam ityādi
translated: But what was said, this is a chariot, etc.,

analyzed: tad pariṇāmi tām āvedayati
translated: that indicates the state of being transformed.

analyzed: na bādham iti vakṣyate
translated: It will be said that it does not indicate obstruction.

analyzed: na tatra rathāḥ
translated: There are no chariots there, etc.

analyzed: ityādi śrutiḥ tu tad prāgabhāvam
translated: But the Vedic text indicates its prior non-existence.

original: nanu svāpnapadārthānāṃ jāgrattvaṃ yadi bhramasiddhaṃ bādhitaṃ ca tadā teṣāṃ mithyātvamavarjanīyam /
analyzed: nanu svāpna padārthānām jāgrat tvam yadi bhrama siddham bādhitam ca tadā teṣām mithyātvam avarjanīyam
translated: If the state of being awake of the objects in a dream is established by error and is contradicted, then their falsity is unavoidable.

original: svāpnagajādayo mithyā bhramaviṣayatvādbādhaviṣayatvācca śaktirajatavadityanumānāditi cetkimidaṃ bhramaviṣayatvamāropyatayā vā'ropādhiṣṭhānatayā
analyzed: svāpna gaja ādayaḥ mithyā bhrama viṣaya tvāt bādha viṣaya tvāt ca śakti rajata vat iti anumānāt iti ced kim idam bhrama viṣaya tvam āropya tayā vā āropa adhiṣṭhāna tayā
translated: If it be argued that the elephant, etc., seen in a dream are false, because they are the objects of error and of contradiction, like the silver superimposed upon nacre,—[we say]—what is this being the object of error? Is it being the object of superimposition, or being the substratum of superimposition,

analyzed: vā sādhāraṇam vā
translated: or is it something common to both?

analyzed: tathā bādha viṣaya tvam api kim niṣedhya tayā uta niṣedha adhikaraṇa tayā atha sādhāraṇam
translated: Similarly, what is being the object of contradiction? Is it being the object of negation, or being the substratum of negation, or is it something common to both?

analyzed: ubhayatra api dvitīya tṛtīyayoḥ deṣam āha jāgrat vat iti
translated: With regard to both, he states the fault in the second and third alternatives in the words ‘As in the case of the waking state, etc.’

analyzed: jāgrat vat
translated: As in the case of the waking state, etc.

analyzed: jāgratā dṛṣṭam śukti ādikam yathā tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: as is the case with nacre, etc., seen in the waking state.

original: yathā śuktikāderāropabādhādhiṣṭhānatve 'pi na mithyātvaṃ tathā svāpnānāmapītyanaikāntyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā śuktikā ādeḥ āropa bādha adhiṣṭhāna tve na mithyātvam tathā svāpnānām api iti anaikāntyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: just as nacre, etc., are not false, even though they are the substratum of superimposition and contradiction, so also are the objects seen in dreams. Thus, the reason is inconclusive.

original: nanu jāgaropalabdhasya śuktyāderapyanenaiva hetunā mithyātvamasmākaṃ siṣādhayiṣitameveti kathaṃ tatrānaikāntikatvamityata āha jāgraditi //
analyzed: nanu jāgara upalabdhasya śukti ādeḥ api anena eva hetunā mithyātvam asmākam siṣādhayiṣitam eva iti katham tatra anaikāntika tvam iti atas āha jāgrat iti
translated: But, it may be argued, we also seek to prove by this very reason that nacre, etc., perceived in the waking state, are false. How then can the reason be inconclusive in that case? To this he says ‘In the waking state, etc.’

analyzed: jāgrat eva ca
translated: In the waking state, etc.

analyzed: ātma vat
translated: Like the self, etc.

analyzed: evam tarhi jāgrat svapnaḥ ca ātma vat na eva mithyā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: in that case, the waking state and the dream are not false, like the self.

analyzed: tat vivṛṇoti kvacid iti
translated: He explains that in some cases.

analyzed: kvacid ātmā ca syāt eva bhrama gocaraḥ
translated: In some cases, the self may indeed be the object of error.

original: etāvatā na mithyāsau svapne jāgarite tathā // / /d // /
analyzed: etāvatā na mithyā asau svapne jāgarite tathā
translated: To this extent, it is not false, in a dream, as in the waking state.

analyzed: kṣaṇikaḥ ham ityādi bhrama gocaraḥ
translated: The object of error is I am momentary, etc.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is an illustration.

original: na kṣaṇiko 'haṃ sthira eveti bādhagocaraścetyapi draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: na kṣaṇikaḥ ham sthiraḥ evā iti bādha gocaraḥ ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: I am not momentary, I am stable, and the object of contradiction should also be seen.

analyzed: svapne jāgarite tathā iti
translated: In a dream, as in the waking state.

analyzed: tatra upalabdhāḥ padārthāḥ api na mithyā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the objects perceived there are also not false.

analyzed: ubhaya pakṣīkāreṇa anumāne pyā
translated: Even in inference, where both sides are accepted,

analyzed: iti
translated: the contradiction in the self cannot be avoided.

original: nanu kṣaṇikatvādinā pratipanna ātmāpi mithyeti kathaṃ tatra vyabhicāra iti cet /
analyzed: nanu kṣaṇika tva ādinā pratipannaḥ ātmā api mithyā iti katham tatra vyabhicāraḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the self, which is cognized as momentary, etc., is also false, how can there be contradiction there?

analyzed: kim kṣaṇika tva ādeḥ āropitasya mithyātvāt evam ucyate uta ātma svarūpasya eva
translated: Is it said that the superimposed momentariness, etc., are false, or is it said of the very nature of the self?

analyzed: dvitīye tu apasiddhāntaḥ sphuṭaḥ eva
translated: In the second case, the contradiction with one's own doctrine is clearly seen.

analyzed: ādyam āśaṅkaya dūṣayati yadi iti
translated: Suspecting the first, he criticizes it with the words if (verse 14).

analyzed: yadi ātmani anyathā dṛśyam bhrāntam atrā api tat bhavet
translated: If what is seen differently in the self is erroneous, then it would be so here also.

analyzed: evam tarhi āropita ākārasya mithyātvam sādhyam iti uktam syāt
translated: If it is so, then it would be said that the superimposed form is to be proved as false.

analyzed: tathā ca siddha sādhana tvam jāgrat svapna avagata artheṣu āropita ākārāṇām mithyātvasya asmābhiḥ api aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: And thus there is the fallacy of proving what is already established, because we also accept the falsity of the superimposed forms in the objects perceived in the waking and dream states.

original: āropyatayā niṣedhyatayā vā bhrāntibādhaviṣayatvaṃ heturityādyapakṣe doṣamāha abādhiteti //
analyzed: āropya tayā niṣedhya tayā vā bhrānti bādha viṣaya tvam hetuḥ iti ādi apakṣe doṣam āha abādhita iti
translated: In the first alternative, where the reason is being the object of error and contradiction either as the superimponent or as the negatee, he states the fallacy thus:

analyzed: abādhita anuvṛtteḥ tu svapna ādeḥ bhrānta tā kutas
translated: How can there be the falsity of a dream, etc., when it continues unabandoned and uncontradicted?

original: jāgrattvādeḥ rajatatvādeśca bādhāduttaramapyabādhitatvena gajādeḥ śuktyādeścānuvṛtteḥ svapnāderuktavidhā bhrāntatā bādhyatā ca kutaḥ /
analyzed: jāgrat tva ādeḥ rajata tva ādeḥ ca bādhāt uttaram api abādhita tvena gaja ādeḥ śukti ādeḥ ca anuvṛtteḥ svapna ādeḥ uktavidhā bhrānta tā bādhya tā ca kutas
translated: Since the elephant, etc., and the mother-of-pearl, etc., continue even after the contradiction of the waking state, etc., and the silver, etc., by their unabandoned nature, how can there be the falsity and contradiction of the dream, etc., in the manner stated?

analyzed: tathāca svarūpa asiddhiḥ
translated: And thus there is non-establishment of the form (of the reason).

original: yathā khalu bādhottarakālamapyanuvartamāna ātmā nāropyo nāpi bādhyaḥ /
analyzed: yathā khalu bādhā uttara kālam api anuvartamānaḥ ātmā na āropyaḥ na api bādhyaḥ
translated: Just as the self, which continues even after the contradiction, is neither superimposed nor contradicted,

analyzed: tathā svapna jāgarau api
translated: so also are the dream and the waking state.

analyzed: tayoḥ api adrākṣam eva aham gajam ityādi anuvṛtteḥ iti
translated: Because of the continuation of the statement I saw the elephant and so on in both of them.

analyzed: anukūla pramāṇa abhāvāt pratikūla pramāṇa bhāvāt ca bhrānti viṣaya tva ādi hetunā jāgrat svapnayoḥ mithyātva anumānam anupapannam iti āha na ca iti
translated: Because there is no favorable evidence and because there is unfavorable evidence, the inference of the falsity of waking and dreaming by the reason of being the object of error, etc., is not proper. He says not and so on.

original: naca kācit pramā viśvabhrāntatve sarvameva ca /
analyzed: na ca kācid pramā viśva bhrānta tve sarvam eva ca
translated: And there is no valid cognition at all in the case of the falsity of the universe, and everything is

original: abhrāntatve pramāṇaṃ tu kathaṃ tadbhrāntitā bhavet // / / //
analyzed: abhrānta tve pramāṇam tu katham tad bhrānti tā bhavet
translated: in the case of non-falsity. But how can that be false, if there is a valid cognition?

analyzed: viśvam iti ubhayavidham vivakṣitam
translated: Universe is intended to refer to both kinds.

analyzed: bhrānta tve mithyātve
translated: In the case of falsity, i.e., in the case of being false.

analyzed: yat vā bhrānti viṣaya tva ādi hetu dvayasya asiddhim prakāra antareṇa sādhayitum idam vākyam
translated: Or this sentence is to prove in a different way the non-establishment of the two reasons of being the object of error, etc.

analyzed: bhrāntasya imi
translated: Of the one who is in error

analyzed: ti bādhya tvasya api upalakṣaṇam
translated: ti is a specification of being contradicted.

analyzed: yatas tasmāt iti upaskartavyam
translated: Yataḥ should be supplied.

analyzed: tad bhrānta tā tasya dvividhasya api viśvasya bhrānti viṣaya tā
translated: That falsity of that twofold universe, i.e., the state of being the object of error.

original: dṛśyatvādihetunā svapnajāgarayobhrāntatvādisādhanātkathamasiddhirityāśaṅkāṃ parihartuṃ bhrāntatvaṃ prakārāntareṇa dūṣayati kiñceti // /
analyzed: dṛśya tva ādi hetunā svapna jāgarayoḥ bhrānta tva ādi sādhanāt katham asiddhiḥ iti āśaṅkām parihartum bhrānta tvam prakāra antareṇa dūṣayati kiñca iti
translated: Because of proving the falsity, etc., of waking and dreaming by the reason of being perceptible, etc., how can there be non-establishment? In order to remove this doubt, he criticizes falsity in a different way, saying what and so on.

original: kiñca bhrāntatvavādī sa bhrāntatvaṃ svamatasya ca /
analyzed: kiñca bhrānta tva vādī sa bhrānta tvam sva matasya ca
translated: And the one who asserts falsity, he of his own opinion and of the universe,

analyzed: aṅgīkaroti niyatam
translated: He necessarily accepts...

original: bhrāntatvavādī dṛśyatvādinā dvividhasyāpi viśvasya bhrāntatvādikaṃ sā tvaṃ sādhayan /🔽svamatasyeti /
analyzed: bhrāntatvavādī dṛśya tva ādinā dvividhasya api viśvasya bhrānta tva ādikam sā tvam sādhayan  sva matasya iti
translated: The proponent of the illusory nature, proving the illusory nature etc. of the twofold universe by perceptibility etc.,🔽of his own opinion.

analyzed: sva pratijñā tharm
translated: Of his own proposition.

analyzed: niyatam iti
translated: Necessarily.

analyzed: anyathā tatra anaikāntya āpatteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that otherwise there would be non-establishment of the reason in that case.

original: na kevalaṃ pareṇa svavyāptisiddhaye svapratijñātārthasya bhrāntatvādikamaṅgīkaraṇīyam /
analyzed: na kevalam pareṇa sva vyāpti siddhaye sva pratijñāta arthasya bhrānta tva ādikam aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: Not only should the other party accept the illusory nature etc. of what is asserted by himself in order to establish his own pervasion,

analyzed: kintu vayam api tat aṅgīkurmaḥ iti āha tatra iti
translated: but we also accept it. He says there etc.

analyzed: tatra sampratipanna tā  vādinoḥ
translated: There, the agreement,🔽of the two disputants.

analyzed: para pratijñāta arthasya bhrānta tva ādau vādinoḥ vādi prativādinoḥ
translated: In the illusory nature etc. of what is asserted by the opponent, of the two disputants, the proponent and the opponent.

analyzed: etat ca vakṣyamāṇa anumānasya anyatara asiddhi nirāsa artham iti boddhavyam
translated: And this should be understood as for the purpose of refuting the non-establishment of one of the two in the inference to be stated.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha tena ca iti
translated: What then? Therefore, he says by that etc.

analyzed: tena ca abhrāntam viśvam eva bhaviṣyati
translated: And by that, the universe will be non-illusory.

original: na kevalamuktapramāṇaiḥ kintu viśvabhrāntatvāderbhrāntatvādihetunā ca viśvamabhrāntameva tathābādhyameva bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: na kevalam ukta pramāṇaiḥ kintu viśva bhrānta tva ādeḥ bhrānta tva ādi hetunā ca viśvam abhrāntam eva tathā abādhyam eva bhaviṣyati
translated: Not only by the stated proofs, but also by the reason of the illusory nature etc. of the illusory nature etc. of the universe, the universe will be non-illusory, and thus non-obstructed.

analyzed: tatra vyāptim sūcayati bhrānta tva iti
translated: There, he indicates the pervasion with if it were false.

analyzed: bhrānti tva bhrānta tā ced syāt katham nā abhrānti satya tā
translated: If it were false, how could the truth of non-error not be?

analyzed: tat etau prayogau bhavataḥ
translated: These are the two arguments.

analyzed: viśvam abhrāntam bhrānta bhrānta tvāt
translated: The universe is non-erroneous, because it is erroneous and erroneous.

analyzed: tathā viśvam abādhyam bādhya bādhya tvāt ātma vat iti
translated: Similarly, the universe is unobstructed, because it is obstructed and obstructible, like the self.

analyzed: apavyākhyāna dūṣaṇasya prayā rejanam āha aśeṣa iti
translated: He states the purpose of refuting the bad explanation with desiring to abandon.

analyzed: aśeṣa doṣa duṣyam tat matam heyam bubhūṣibhiḥ
translated: That doctrine, which is full of all faults, should be abandoned by those who desire liberation.

analyzed: tat matam iti
translated: That doctrine means

analyzed: svāpna jāgara prapañcasya mithyātvam pratipādayat matam
translated: the doctrine that teaches the unreality of the universe of waking and dreaming.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: viśvasya bhrānta tva ādikam iva abhrānta tva ādikam api mithyā kin na syāt
translated: Just as the unreality, etc. of the universe, so also its reality, etc. may not be unreal.

original: na caitadaghaṭitaṃ durghaṭatvasya bhūṣaṇatvādityāśaṅkāṃ pariharanmandametadasmadīyaṃ tanmataheyatāvyutpādānaprasakterabhāvāditi solluṇṭhamāha
analyzed: na ca etat aghaṭitam durghaṭa tvasya bhūṣaṇa tvāt iti āśaṅkām pariharan mandam etat asmadīyam tad mata heya tā vyutpāda anaprasakteḥ abhāvāt iti sa ulluṇṭham āha
translated: And this is not impossible, because the impossibility of what is well-nigh impossible is an ornament. Anticipating this doubt, he replies with irony that this is slow, because there is no connection with the teaching of the abandonment of that doctrine by us.

analyzed: yena iti
translated: With by whom he says:

analyzed: yena sva mata heya tvam svayam aṅgīkṛtam sadā
translated: By whom the abandonment of one's own doctrine is always accepted by oneself,

analyzed: bhrānti tvāt durghaṭa tvasya bhūṣaṇa tvāt ca kevalam
translated: Because of being an error and because of being an ornament of the impossible, only

analyzed: unmattaḥ pi katham tasya matam svīkartum icchati
translated: even a madman wishes to accept his opinion.

analyzed: bhrānti tvāt bhrānti viṣaya tvena aṅgīkṛta tvāt  durghaṭa tvasya bhūṣaṇa tvāt bhūṣaṇa tvena aṅgīkṛta tvāt ca
translated: Because of being an error, because of being accepted as having an erroneous object.🔽And because of being an ornament of the impossible, because of being accepted as an ornament.

analyzed: kevalam unmattaḥ pi sākṣāt unmattaḥ pi na punar unmattaka bījāt yat anena unmattaḥ
translated: Only a madman, not a madman again by eating the seeds of madness, but a madman directly.

original: na hyunmattaḥ svamataṃ bhrāntaṃ durghaṭaṃ ceti svayameva manyate /
analyzed: na hi unmattaḥ sva matam bhrāntam durghaṭam ca iti svayam eva manyate
translated: For a madman does not himself think that his opinion is erroneous and impossible.

original: tarhi kathaṃ loke pravṛttamityata āha īśeti //
analyzed: tarhi katham loke pravṛttam iti atas āha īśa iti
translated: Then how is it current in the world? Therefore he says the power of the Lord etc.

analyzed: īśa śakteḥ acintya tvāt mahā unmattaiḥ pravartitam
translated: It is set forth by great madmen because of the inconceivability of the power of the Lord.

analyzed: mahā unmattaiḥ iti hetu antaram
translated: By great madmen is another reason.🔽Having begun the explanation of the aphorism, the teaching of the undesirability of a bad explanation is irrelevant. Therefore, with the intention of strengthening his own explanation, he explains the meaning of the aphorism, and first of all

analyzed: sūtra vyākhyānam upakramya apavyākhyānasya heya tā vyutpādanam asaṅgatam iti atas sva vyākhyāna dārḍhya artham iti āśayavān uktam sūtra artham vivṛṇvan māyā śabda artham
translated: he explains the meaning of the word māyā

analyzed: tāvat āha atas iti
translated: with therefore etc.

analyzed: atas prajñā atra māyā uktā
translated: Therefore, here, in the Veda, māyā is called jīva etc.

analyzed: atas iti
translated: Therefore etc.

analyzed: anyathā vyākhyānasya duṣṭa tvāt māyāḥ vayunam abhikhya
translated: Otherwise, because the explanation is faulty, the illusion is called the cause.

analyzed: iti prajñā nāmasu pāṭhāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Because an explanation other than that is faulty, the meaning is that it is said in the names of wisdom: Maya is the cause.

analyzed: māyāyāḥ sandhya kāraṇa tvam vakṣyate
translated: The fact that Maya is the cause of the junction will be stated.

original: tatra jaivī prajñā kīdṛśaṃ kāraṇamityata āha upādānameveti //
analyzed: tatra jaivī prajñā kīdṛśam kāraṇam iti atas āha upādānam eva iti
translated: In that context, what kind of cause is the individual's wisdom? Therefore it is said: It is only the material cause.

analyzed: upādānam eva sā
translated: It is only the material cause.

analyzed: sandhyasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: of the junction.

analyzed: na kevalam jaivī prajñā atra māyā
translated: Not only is the individual's wisdom Maya here,

analyzed: kintu aiśvarī ca
translated: but also the divine one.

analyzed: sā ca sandhyasya nimittam eva iti āha nimittam iti
translated: And that is only the cause of the junction. It is said: The divine one is the primary cause.

analyzed: nimittam aiśvarī mukhyam
translated: The divine wisdom is the primary one.

analyzed: prajñā śabdaḥ ca atra lākṣaṇikaḥ vāsanā arthaḥ iti
translated: And it will be said that the word wisdom here is figurative, meaning impression.

analyzed: tat ca vyākhyānam na ubhaya sādhāraṇam iti āśayena uktam mukhya iti
translated: And that explanation is not common to both. With this in mind, it is said: The primary one.

analyzed: īśvara prajñā mukhyā eva jīva prajñā tu lākṣaṇikī
translated: The divine wisdom is the primary one, but the individual's wisdom is figurative.

analyzed: māyā mātra padam vyākhyāti nirmitam iti
translated: It explains the words mere Maya as created and protected.

original: nirmitaṃ trātameva ca // / / //🔽tābhyāṃ saha pṛthak caiva māyāmātramitīryate /
analyzed: nirmitam trātam eva ca  tābhyām saha pṛthak ca eva māyā mātram iti īryate
translated: It is created and protected.🔽It is said to be mere Maya along with those two, and separately.

original: ubhābhyāṃ mātamaiśvaryā trātaṃ saha pṛthak tataḥ // / / //
analyzed: ubhābhyām mātamaiśvaryā trātam saha pṛthak tatas
translated: The divine one is protected by both, along with and separately from that.

analyzed: tābhyām eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with those two.

analyzed: tena tuśabdaḥ vyākhyātaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, the word but is explained.

analyzed: yathā saṅkhayena anvaya parihāra artham uktam saha pṛthak eva iti
translated: As it has been said according to the order of enumeration, for the sake of inclusion and exclusion, together and separately.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ tasmāt iti arthe
translated: The word ca (and) means tasmat (therefore).

analyzed: īryate sandhyam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is is said.

analyzed: saha pṛthak iti uktam vivṛṇoti ubhābhyām iti
translated: He explains what was said as together and separately with ubhabyam (by both).

original: jīveśvaraprajñābhyāṃ mātaṃ nirmitamaiśvaryā prajñayā trātaṃ yasmāttataḥ saha pṛthagityuktam /
analyzed: jīva īśvara prajñābhyām nirmitam aiśvaryā prajñayā trātam yasmāt tatas saha pṛthak iti uktam
translated: Because it is protected by the power of the Lord's wisdom, therefore it was said together and separately.

analyzed: dhātu samudāyāt ātaḥ n upasarge kaḥ iti kaḥ
translated: Ka is used in the sense of dhātu-samudāya (collection of elements) when there is no prefix.

analyzed: adi bhūmyām hutajiti yathā
translated: Like huta in adi-bhūmi.

analyzed: yadi api ekasmāt eva dhātoḥ tra pratyayaḥ śakyaḥ kartum
translated: Even though the suffix tra can be formed from a single element,

analyzed: tathā api adhika artha lābhāya evam kṛtam
translated: it is done this way for the sake of gaining additional meaning.

analyzed: sautra tvāt nirdeśasya karmaṇi pratyayaḥ
translated: The suffix is in the accusative case because the instruction is in the sutra.

analyzed: ghañ arthe ka vidhānam iti vā
translated: Or it is the rule of ka in the sense of ghañ.

analyzed: nanu idam pūrva apara viruddham
translated: Isn't this contradictory to what was said before?

analyzed: pūrvam hi jīva vāsanā upādānakam sandhyam iti uktam
translated: For earlier it was said that the saṃdhi is produced by the impressions of the individual soul,

analyzed: idānīm tu prajñā upādanakam iti
translated: but now it is said to be produced by wisdom.

analyzed: mā evam  prajñā śabdasya api vā
translated: No, that is not so.🔽Or because the word prajñā (wisdom)

analyzed: sya vāsanā upalakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: also indicates impressions.

original: atha prajñāyā vāsanāyāśca kaḥ sambandho yena lakṣaṇā syādityata āha prajñātmakamiti //
analyzed: atha prajñāyāḥ vāsanāyāḥ ca kaḥ sambandhaḥ yena lakṣaṇā syāt iti atas āha prajñā ātmakam iti
translated: Now, what is the relation between wisdom and impressions, by which there could be definition? To this he says: The mind is of the nature of wisdom...

analyzed: prajñā ātmakam manaḥ yena manaḥ rūpāḥ ca vāsanāḥ
translated: The mind is of the nature of wisdom, and the impressions are also of the form of the mind.

analyzed: yena kāraṇena manaḥ prajñā ātmakam prajñā upādānam
translated: For what reason the mind is of the nature of wisdom, an upādāna of wisdom,

original: vāsanāśca manorūpā manaupādānakāḥ tenaitayorekakāraṇatvalakṣaṇasambandhena lakṣaṇopapadyata iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: vāsanāḥ ca manaḥ rūpāḥ mana aupādānakāḥ tena etayoḥ eka kāraṇa tva lakṣaṇa sambandhena lakṣaṇā upapadyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: and the impressions are also of the form of the mind, having the mind as their upādāna, by that very relation of having the same cause, the definition is established. The rest is understood.

analyzed: upādānam iti etat kutas iti atas āha dhīḥ iti
translated: From where is it known that wisdom and impressions are upādāna of the mind? To this he says: The wise one...

analyzed: dhīḥ bhīḥ iti manaḥ tu evā iti āha ca śrutiḥ añjasā
translated: The scripture clearly states that the wise one is indeed the mind.

analyzed: śrutau iti śabdaḥ ādi arthaḥ
translated: In the scripture, the word iti has the sense of ādi.

analyzed: tena vāsanāyāḥ api manaḥ vikāra tvam labhyate
translated: By that, it is understood that impressions are also modifications of the mind.

analyzed: iti tu iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Iti is connected with tu.

analyzed: iti śrutiḥ caśabdāt anyā ca āha prajñā ādeḥ manaḥ vikāra tvam
translated: And the scripture, along with the word ca, states that wisdom and others are modifications of the mind.

analyzed: añjasā spaṣṭam  etena ātma kāryatvam vadantaḥ nirastāḥ bhavanti
translated: Clearly means distinctly.🔽By this, those who say that wisdom and others are effects of the self are refuted.

analyzed: bāhya artha jñānasya tadānīm abhāvāt asataḥ ca upādāna tva anupapatteḥ mukhya artha tyāgaḥ
translated: Because external object knowledge does not exist at that time, and because what is non-existent cannot be an upādāna, the primary meaning is abandoned.

original: yadi ca vāsanāmātramiti mukhya eva prayogaḥ kriyeta tadeśvaraprajñā na saṅgṛhītā syātpṛthagubhayagrahaṇe ca gauravaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi ca vāsanā mātram iti mukhyaḥ eva prayogaḥ kriyeta tadā īśvara prajñā na saṅgṛhītā syāt pṛthak ubhaya grahaṇe ca gauravam syāt
translated: And if only the impressions were to be taken as the primary usage, then the divine wisdom would not be included. And if both were to be taken separately, there would be a complication.

analyzed: atas mukhya amukhya vivakṣayā ubhayasya lāghavena grahaṇāya māyā mātram iti uktam
translated: Therefore, for the sake of including both by the light of the primary and secondary meanings, it is said to be mere illusion.

original: ata eva māyaiva māyāmātramiti na vyākhyātam /
analyzed: atas eva māyā eva māyā mātram iti na vyākhyātam
translated: For this very reason, it is not explained that illusion itself is mere illusion.

analyzed: sandhyasya nimitta kāraṇa bhūtayā īśvara prajñayā tādātmya abhāvāt
translated: Because the twilight state does not have the same nature as the divine wisdom, which is the instrumental cause.

analyzed: nanu prajñā vāsanayoḥ asti kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ sambandhaḥ
translated: But there is a causal relation between wisdom and impressions.

analyzed: saḥ eva lakṣaṇā bījam astu
translated: Let that alone be the seed of the definition.

analyzed: kim dvayoḥ manaḥ kāryatva varṇanena iti atas āha cit iti
translated: What is the use of describing both as the effect of mind? To this he says consciousness etc.

analyzed: cit acit miśram eva etat manaḥ yāvat ca saṃsṛtiḥ
translated: This mind, which is a mixture of consciousness and non-consciousness, is as long as there is worldly existence.

original: tenāvasthā imāḥ sarvā jīvaḥ paśyati sarvadā // / / //
analyzed: tena avasthāḥ imāḥ sarvāḥ jīvaḥ paśyati sarvadā
translated: Therefore, the individual soul always sees all these states through that.

original: na kevalaṃ svapnaṃ kintvimāḥ sāṃsārikīḥ sarvā apyavasthāstena manasaiva sarvadā jīvaḥ paśyati /
analyzed: na kevalam svapnam kintu imāḥ sāṃsārikīḥ sarvāḥ api avasthāḥ tena manasā eva sarvadā jīvaḥ paśyati
translated: Not only dreams, but all these worldly states also the individual soul always sees through that mind alone.

original: ataḥ pradhānatvāttaddvāraka eva sambandha ādaraṇīyo nāparaḥ /
analyzed: atas pradhāna tvāt tad dvārakaḥ eva sambandhaḥ ādaraṇīyaḥ na aparaḥ
translated: Therefore, because of its predominance, the relation through that alone should be accepted, not any other.

analyzed: manaḥ ca kecana jaḍam eva manyante
translated: Some people consider the mind to be inert itself.

analyzed: apare tu acetanam eva āropita caitanyam
translated: Others consider it to be only insentient, with superimposed sentience.

analyzed: eva iti
translated: With the refutation of that, he states its nature as consisting of consciousness and insentience mixed.

analyzed: yat iti adhyāhāryam
translated: If is to be supplied.

analyzed: kevalam acetanasya ghaṭa ādi vat evambhāva asambhavāt caitanya āropasya nirākṛta tvāt cit acit miśram eva aṅgīkāryam
translated: Since it is impossible for the mere insentient to exist in this way, like a pot, and since the superimposition of sentience has been refuted, it must be accepted as consisting of consciousness and insentience mixed.

analyzed: bhavanti ca atra āgamāḥ
translated: And in this regard, there are scriptural statements.

original: yadi manasā sarvāvasthāprāptistadā mokṣe 'pi tasya bhāvādava
analyzed: yadi manasā sarva avasthā prāptiḥ tadā mokṣe
translated: If the mind attains all states, then even in liberation it would exist, and

analyzed: deva avasthāḥ syuḥ iti atas uktam yāvat saṃsṛtiḥ tāvat eva jīvasya upakāra apakārau karoti iti
translated: there would be states of being. Therefore it is said that as long as there is worldly existence, for that long the soul causes benefit and harm.

analyzed: kātsnaryena anabhivyakta svarūpa tvāt iti vyākhyāti manaḥ vikārāḥ iti
translated: He explains because its nature is not manifested in its entirety as the modifications of the mind.

original: manovikārā viṣayāḥ svāpnā yad bahyavanna te /
analyzed: manaḥ vikārāḥ viṣayāḥ svāpnāḥ yat te
translated: The objects of dreams are modifications of the mind, not like external ones.

original: sthūlā bhavantyatasteṣāṃ spaṣṭatā na tathā kvacit // / / //
analyzed: sthūlāḥ bhavanti atas teṣām spaṣṭa tā na tathā kvacid
translated: They are not gross, therefore their clarity is not the same in some cases.

original: yadyasmātsvāpnā viṣayā manojanyavāsanāvikārā ata eva hi te bāhyavat sthūlāḥ na bhavanti saṃvṛte deśe 'vakāśānarhā na bhavanti /
analyzed: yat yasmāt svāpnāḥ viṣayāḥ manaḥ janya vāsanā vikārāḥ atas eva hi te bāhya vat sthūlāḥ na bhavanti saṃvṛte deśe vakāśa anarhāḥ na bhavanti
translated: Because they are modifications of the latent impressions produced by the mind, therefore they are not like external ones, they are not gross, they are not incapable of occupying space in an enclosed place.

analyzed: teṣām tathā bāhya vat kvacid spaṣṭa tā bāhya artha kriyā kāri tā na asti
translated: Of them, like external objects, there is sometimes vividness, but not the performance of external functions.

original: yadvā yasmātte bāhyavatsthūlā na bhavanti tathā teṣāṃ kvacitspaṣṭatā nāstyataḥ svāpanā viṣayā manovikārā iti yojanā /
analyzed: yat vā yasmāt te bāhya vat sthūlāḥ na bhavanti tathā teṣām kvacid spaṣṭa tā na asti atas svāpanāḥ viṣayāḥ manaḥ vikārāḥ iti yojanā
translated: Or, the construction is: because they are not gross like external objects, so there is sometimes no vividness of them, therefore the objects of sleep are modifications of the mind.

analyzed: yathā ca etat tathā uktam purastāt
translated: And how this is so has been stated earlier.

original: nanu ca svāpnakāminīsambhogādeścaramadhātuvisargādibāhyātharkriyākāritādarśanādbhāgāsiddhirityata āha kvaciditi //🔽kvacit spaṣṭā api syuṣye / / / // / / //
analyzed: nanu ca svāpna kāminī sambhoga ādeḥ carama dhātu visarga ādi bāhya athar kriyā kāri tā darśanāt bhāga asiddhiḥ iti atas āha kvacid iti  kvacid spaṣṭāḥ api
translated: But since the performance of external functions like the emission of the final element is seen in the enjoyment of the wife in a dream etc., there is partial failure. To this he says 'sometimes'.🔽Even in those, there may be vividness sometimes.

original: te svāpnā viṣayāḥ kvacitspaṣṭā api syureva /
analyzed: te svāpnāḥ viṣayāḥ kvacid spaṣṭāḥ api syuḥ eva
translated: Those objects of sleep may indeed be sometimes vivid.

analyzed: tathā api tad atirikta pakṣīkaraṇena adoṣaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Still, by making that a separate case, there is no fault. This is the idea.

original: evaṃ tarhi tasyāṃśasya vāsanāmayatvaṃ na syādityata āha vāsaneti //
analyzed: evam tarhi tasya aṃśasya vāsanā maya tvam na syāt iti atas āha vāsanā iti
translated: If so, then that part would not be made of impressions. To this he says 'vāsanā'.

analyzed: vāsanā mānasī ca sā
translated: And that is mental.

analyzed: sā ca mānasī vāsanā siddhā
translated: And that mental impression is established.

analyzed: aspaṣṭa tā abhāve pi asthūla tvasya sattvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that even in the absence of vividness, subtlety exists.

analyzed: atas eva sautraḥ hetuḥ dvedhā vyākhyātaḥ
translated: For this very reason, the reason in the sutra is explained in two ways.

original: tadanena deśakālanimittasampattiḥ svapne nāstīti yaduktaṃ tadvāsanāmayoktyā nirastam /
analyzed: tat anena deśa kāla nimitta sampattiḥ svapne nā asti iti yat uktam tat vāsanā maya uktyā nirastam
translated: Thus, by this, it is refuted by the statement that dreams are made of impressions, what was said that there is no perfection of place, time, and cause in dreams.

analyzed: atas eva sṛṣṭi śruteḥ bhākta tva varṇanam apāstam
translated: For this very reason, the description of the creation mentioned in the scriptures as figurative is set aside.

original: prājñasya nirmātṛtvaṃ ca na vṛthā tvājyam /
analyzed: prājñasya nirmātṛ tvam ca na vṛthā tu ājyam
translated: And the creation by the wise is not to be rejected as useless.

analyzed: svayam vihatya ityādya api īśvara viṣayam anyatra vyākhyātam
translated: Even the statement having himself destroyed etc. is explained elsewhere as referring to God.

analyzed: svapna nirmāṇe śubha aśubha yoga āpattiḥ iti ca asaṅgatam
translated: And the statement that in the creation of dreams, good and bad results are obtained is irrelevant.

analyzed: vyāpti abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no pervasion.

original: jīvasya brahmabhāvopadeśa iti ca sārvajñādeḥ pāramārthikatvasamarthanādayuktam /
analyzed: jīvasya brahma bhāva upadeśaḥ iti ca sārvajña ādeḥ pāramārthika tva samarthanāt ayuktam
translated: And the statement that the teaching of the identity of the individual soul with Brahman is not proper, because it establishes the reality of omniscience etc.

analyzed: viyat ādi prapañcasya mithyātva kathanam ca tad satya tva upapādanāt nirastam
translated: And the statement that the world beginning with space is false is refuted by the establishment of its truth.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām sandhyā adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the Sāṃdhyā Adhikaraṇa in the commentary of Śrīmat Nāyavivaraṇa.
II. Parābhidhyāna Adhikaraṇa

original: atha śrīmannyāyasudhāyāṃ parābhidhyānādhikaraṇam //🔽parābhidhyānāt tu tirohitaṃ tato hy asya bandhaviparyayau / / / /
analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām para abhidhyāna adhikaraṇam  para abhidhyānāt tu tirohitam tatas hi asya bandha viparyayau  /
translated: Now, in the commentary of Śrīmat Nāyavivaraṇa, the Parābhidhyāna Adhikaraṇa.🔽But it is hidden by the contemplation of the supreme, for from that there is bondage and its opposite for him.

original: oṃ parābhidhyānāttu tirohitaṃ tato hyasya bandhaviparyayau oṃ //
analyzed: om para abhidhyānāt tu tirohitam tatas hi asya bandha viparyayau om
translated: Om. But it is hidden by the contemplation of the supreme. For from that there is bondage and its opposite for him. Om.

analyzed: para kṛtasya apavyākhyāna tām pratipādayitum para abhidhyānāt iti sūtra tātparyam āha īśa iti
translated: In order to show that the opponent's explanation is wrong, the purport of the sūtra is stated by saying by the will of the Lord etc.

analyzed: īśa icchayā antardadhāti
translated: He conceals by the will of the Lord.

analyzed: sandhyam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is at twilight.

original: na kevalaṃ svapnaḥ kintu tattirodhānamapīśvarecchādhīnamityeṣa evārtho 'nena sūtreṇocyate nānyaḥ /
analyzed: na kevalam svapnaḥ kintu tad tirodhānam api īśvara icchā adhīnam iti eṣaḥ eva arthaḥ nena sūtreṇa ucyate na anyaḥ
translated: Not only is the dream, but also its concealment dependent on the will of the Lord - this is the meaning that is stated by this sūtra, not another.

analyzed: jīvasya īśvara aṃśa tāyāḥ aprāmāṇika tvasya dvitīye bhihita tvāt
translated: Because the non-authoritativeness of the individual soul being a part of the Lord has been stated in the second [chapter].

analyzed: na ca jñāna aiśvarya śaktī brahmaṇaḥ tāttvika tayā pareṇa aṅgīkṛte
translated: And the Lord does not accept knowledge, lordship, and power as real in Brahman.

analyzed: kiñca deha yogāt tirohitam iti etāvatā alam
translated: Moreover, it is enough to say that it is concealed by the connection with the body.

analyzed: anyat asaṅgatam eva  kiñca deha yogaḥ ced tirodhāne eva
translated: The other [parts of the sūtra] are irrelevant.

analyzed: hetuḥ tadā supti pralayayoḥ āvirbhāvaḥ syāt
translated: Moreover, if the connection with the body is the cause of concealment, then manifestation would occur in sleep and dissolution.

original: avidyādyupalakṣaṇametaditi cedetadapi ta🔽t atha tathaiva kinnoktamityāstāṃ vistaraḥ /
analyzed: avidyā ādi upalakṣaṇam etat iti ced etat api te  atha tathā eva kim na uktam iti āstām vistaraḥ
translated: If it is argued that this is a metaphor for ignorance etc., then this too is the same.🔽Or why is it not stated in the same way? Let it be.

original: yadi svapno 'ntardhatte kathaṃ tarhi punastatpratītiriṣyata āha vyajyate ceti //
analyzed: yadi svapnaḥ ntardhatte katham tarhi punar tad pratītiḥ iṣyate āha vyajyate ca iti
translated: If the dream conceals, then how can the remembrance of it be accepted? It is said: and it is manifested again by that.

analyzed: vyajyate ca punar tayā
translated: And it is manifested again by that.

analyzed: etena parakīyam bādha kathanam nirastam
translated: By this, the statement of objections by others is refuted.

original: vyaktistirodhānaṃ ca na jñāyata ityato 'dhikaraṇadvayārthamupasaṃharati sṛṣṭvaiveti //
analyzed: vyaktiḥ tirodhānam ca na jñāyate iti atas dhikaraṇa dvaya artham upasaṃharati sṛṣṭvā eva iti
translated: Since the manifestation and disappearance are not known, he concludes the meaning of the two sections with Having created etc.

original: sṛṣṭvaiva vāsānabhiśca prapañcaṃ svāpnamīśvaraḥ /🔽vāsanāmātratāṃ tasya nītvāntardhāpayatyajaḥ // / / //
analyzed: sṛṣṭvā eva prapañcam svāpnam īśvaraḥ  vāsanā mātra tām tasya nītvā antardhāpayati ajaḥ
translated: Having created the world, which is like a dream, the Lord🔽brings it to the state of mere impressions and causes it to disappear.

analyzed: evaśabdena āropam vārayati
translated: By the word eva (only), superimposition is excluded.

analyzed: darśayitvā iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: Having shown should also be seen.

analyzed: tasya ca vāsanā mātra tām nītvā kṛtvā
translated: And having brought it to the state of mere impressions, having made it so.

analyzed: anyathā dvitīyā syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would be in the accusative case.

analyzed: antardhāpayati a darśanam gamayati
translated: He causes it to disappear, he makes it go out of sight.

analyzed: tasya jīvasya vāsanābhiḥ iti vā
translated: Or by the impressions of that individual soul.

analyzed: tasya antardhāpayati iti vā
translated: Or he causes it to disappear.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām para abhidhyāna adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the meditation on the Supreme in the commentary of the revered Nārāyaṇa.
III. The chapter on sleep, awakening, and delusion.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām bodha moha adhikaraṇāni
translated: Now, in the commentary of the revered Nārāyaṇa, the chapters on awakening and delusion.

analyzed: tad abhāvaḥ nāḍīṣu tad śruteḥ ātmani ca
translated: That absence is in the nāḍīs, because of the Vedic text, and in the Self.

analyzed: atas prabodhaḥ u smāt
translated: Therefore, awakening is from that.

analyzed: mugdheḥ ṛdha saṃpattiḥ pariśeṣāt
translated: In the deluded state, there is partial attainment, because of the remainder.

original: oṃ tadabhāvo nāḍīṣu tacchaterātmani ha oṃ //
analyzed: om tad abhāvaḥ nāḍīṣu tad śateḥ ātmani ha om
translated: Om, that non-existence in the nāḍīs, in the hundred of that, in the Self, Ha. Om.

analyzed: om atas prabodhaḥ smāt om
translated: Om, therefore, the awakening is from that, Om.

analyzed: om pariśeṣāt om
translated: Om, in the deluded one, due to the attainment of half, the remainder, Om.

original: atra yajjīvabrahmaṇorekatvaṃ pareṇa varṇitaṃ tatsūtrākṣarāpratītaṃ tadviruddhaṃ cāpekṣaṇīyameveti jñāpayitumadhikaraṇatrayasya tātparyamāha
analyzed: atra yat jīva brahmaṇoḥ ekatvam pareṇa varṇitam tat sūtra akṣara apratītam tad viruddham ca apekṣaṇīyam eva iti jñāpayitum adhikaraṇa trayasya tātparyam āha
translated: Here, the identity of the individual soul and Brahman, which has been described by the opponent, is not accepted by the words of the sūtras, and is to be disregarded as contradictory to them. To make this known, he states the purport of the three sections.

analyzed: suṣuptī iti  suṣupti moha bodhān ca svavaśaḥ tad vaśam sadā
translated: With the words In deep sleep, delusion, and awakening.

analyzed: jīvam nayati jīva īśaḥ
translated: The Lord of the individual soul always leads the individual soul under His control, under His control.

analyzed: suṣupti bodha ādeḥ kāraṇa antara darśanāt katham etat iti atas uktam svavaśaḥ tad vaśam iti
translated: Since the cause of deep sleep, awakening, etc. is seen elsewhere, how is this? Therefore it is said: Under His control, under His control.

original: svatantro 'pīśvaro līlayā tāni kāraṇānyupādāya jīvaṃ tadvaśatāṃ nītvā suṣuptyādikaṃ prāpayatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: svatantraḥ pi īśvaraḥ līlayā tāni kāraṇāni upādāya jīvam tad vaśa tām nītvā suṣupti ādikam prāpayati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: although independent, the Lord, by His play, taking up those causes, leads the individual soul under His control, and brings about deep sleep, etc.

analyzed: etat ca bhāṣya ādau spaṣṭam
translated: And this is clear from the Bhāṣya (commentary) and so on.

analyzed: iti suṣupti bodha moha adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on deep sleep, awakening, and delusion.
IV. The section on the remembrance of past actions.

analyzed: atha karma anusmṛti adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, the section on the remembrance of past actions.

original: oṃ sa eva ca karmānusmṛtiśabdavidhibhyaḥ oṃ //
analyzed: om saḥ eva ca karma anusmṛti śabda vidhibhyaḥ om
translated: Om, and He alone, because of the remembrance of past actions, the words, and the injunctions. Om.

analyzed: kecid evam vyācakṣate
translated: Some explain it thus:

original: suṣuptau brahmasampanno ya eva jīvaṣaḥ kiṃ
analyzed: suṣuptau brahma sampannaḥ yaḥ eva jīvaṣaḥ kim
translated: In deep sleep, the individual self is united with Brahman. Is it

original: sa evottiṣṭhatyutānyo 'pīti saṃśaye mahājalanidhau kṣiptasyodabindoriva brahmaṇaikībhūtasyoddharaṇāsambhavādaniyama iti prāpte samādhīyate
analyzed: saḥ eva uttiṣṭhati uta anyaḥ pi iti saṃśaye mahā jalanidhau kṣiptasya uda bindoḥ iva brahmaṇā ekībhūtasya uddharaṇa asambhavāt aniyamaḥ iti prāpte samādhīyate
translated: the same one who wakes up, or is it another? Since it is like a drop of water thrown into the great ocean, which becomes one with Brahman and cannot be extracted, there is no rule. When this is reached, it is concluded:

analyzed: saḥ eva uttiṣṭhati yaḥ suptaḥ
translated: The same one wakes up who was asleep.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: karma śeṣa samāpanāt pratyabhijñānāt śabdebhyaḥ vidhibhyaḥ ca  suptasya mukta tva āpattyā vidhi anupapatteḥ iti
translated: Because of the completion of the remainder of the action, recognition, and injunctions.🔽Because of the impossibility of injunctions due to the consequence of the liberated state of the one who is asleep.

analyzed: tat etat apavyākhyānam iti sūcanāya adhikaraṇa tātpayarma āha na anyaḥ iti
translated: This is an improper explanation. To indicate this, the purpose of the section is stated as not another.

analyzed: saḥ eva ca karma anusmṛti śabda vidhibhyaḥ
translated: And it is the same one because of the remembrance of action, words, and injunctions.

analyzed: na anyaḥ kartā asya kaścana
translated: No other maker of this at all.🔽When it is stated that dreams and so on are made by the Supreme Lord, in the doubt of whether there is another maker in another place and time, or only the Lord,

original: svapnādīnāṃ parameśvarakṛtatve 'bhihite kiṃ deśakālāntare 'nyo 'pi kartāstyuteśvara eveti saṃśaye laukikeśvarāṇāṃ deśakālavyavasthayaiśvaryadarśanādayamapi
analyzed: svapna ādīnām parameśvara kṛta tve bhihite kim deśa kāla antare kartā asti uta īśvaraḥ eva iti saṃśaye laukika īśvarāṇām deśa kāla vyavasthayā aiśvarya darśanāt ayam api
translated: since the power of worldly lords is seen to be limited by place and time, this one is also

analyzed: tathāvidhaḥ iti prāpte
translated: like that. When this is reached,

original: sa eveśvaro 'sya svapnādeḥ kartā natu deśakālāntare 'nyaḥ kaścanetyeṣa evārtho 'tra pratipādyata iti /
analyzed: saḥ eva īśvaraḥ sya svapna ādeḥ kartā na tu deśa kāla antare kaścana iti eṣaḥ eva arthaḥ tra pratipādyate iti
translated: He alone is the maker of this dream, etc., and not some other person in another place and time. This very meaning is being taught here.

original: nahi yaḥ suptaḥ sa evottiṣṭhatyanyo veti kasyacitsaṃśayo 'sti /
analyzed: nahi yaḥ suptaḥ saḥ eva uttiṣṭhati anyaḥ vā iti kasyacid saṃśayaḥ sti
translated: For no one has any doubt as to whether it is the same person who goes to sleep that wakes up, or whether it is someone else.

original: naca suptasya brahmaṇaikyaṃ pramāṇadṛṣṭamiṣyaṃ vā parasyeti yatkiñcidetat /
analyzed: na ca suptasya brahmaṇā aikyam pramāṇa dṛṣṭam iṣyam vā parasya iti yat kiñcid etat
translated: And the identity of Brahman with the sleeping person is neither admitted nor established by any means of valid knowledge. So this is all mere verbiage.

analyzed: lāghava artham krama ullaṅghanena vyākhyānam iti
translated: It should be understood that the explanation is given by skipping over [some topics] for the sake of brevity.

original: sūtrakṛtā ca svapnādivanna mohaḥ svatantrāvastheti jñāpanāya vyavadhānaṃ kṛtamiti /
analyzed: sūtrakṛtā ca svapna ādi vat na mohaḥ svatantrā avasthā iti jñāpanāya vyavadhānam kṛtam iti
translated: And the author of the aphorisms has made an interruption in order to show that delusion is not an independent state like sleep, etc.

analyzed: iti karma anusmṛti adhikaraṇam  sthānāt pya
translated: Thus ends the section on the remembrance of past actions.

analyzed: bheda adhikaraṇam  atha sthānataḥ pya
translated: VI. The section on non-difference even from the point of view of location.

analyzed: bheda adhikaraṇam
translated: The section on non-difference even from the point of view of location.

original: oṃ na sthānato 'pi parasyobhayaliṅgaṃ sarvatra hi oṃ //
analyzed: om na parasya ubhaya liṅgam sarvatra hi om
translated: Om. Even from the point of view of location, the highest [Self] has both characteristics everywhere. Om.

analyzed: kecid idam ittham vyācakṣate
translated: Some explain this as follows.

original: dvirūpaṃ brahma śrūyate sarvakarmā sarvakāma ityādau saviśeṣamasthūlamanaṇvityādau nirviśeṣam /
analyzed: dvi rūpam brahma śrūyate sarva karmā sarva kāmaḥ ityādau sa viśeṣam asthūlam an aṇu ityādau nirviśeṣam
translated: Brahman is said to be of two forms: in passages such as He who has all actions, all desires, it is said to have attributes; in passages such as It is neither coarse nor fine, it is said to be without attributes.

analyzed: tatra kim ubhaya rūpam brahma pratipattavyam uta anyatara rūpam
translated: There, is Brahman to be understood as having both forms or as having one of the two forms?

analyzed: yadā api anyatara rūpam tadā api
translated: Even when it is of one of the two forms,

original: kiṃ saviśeṣamuta nirviśeṣamiti saṃśaye dvividhaśrutyanurodhādubhayarūpameva brahmeti prāpte idamucyate /
analyzed: kim saviśeṣam uta nirviśeṣam iti saṃśaye dvividha śruti anurodhāt ubhaya rūpam eva brahma iti prāpte idam ucyate
translated: then also, is it with special attributes or without special attributes? In this doubt, Brahman is of both forms, because it accords with the two kinds of Vedic texts. This being the conclusion, this is said:

original: na tāvatsvata eva parasya brahmaṇa ubhayarūpatvaṃ sambhavati virodhāt /
analyzed: na tāvat svatas eva parasya brahmaṇaḥ ubhaya rūpa tvam sambhavati virodhāt
translated: First, Brahman, the Supreme, cannot have both forms by itself, because of contradiction.

analyzed: astu tarhi sthānataḥ pṛthivī ādi upādhi yogāt
translated: Then let it be so by location, by the connection of limiting adjuncts like earth.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: na hi upādhiḥ anyat anyathā karoti kintu avidyā upasthāpitāḥ pṛthivī ādi upādhayaḥ bhramam upajanayanti
translated: For a limiting adjunct does not make another thing otherwise; rather, the limiting adjuncts like earth, established by ignorance, generate delusion.

analyzed: atas ca anyatara parigrahe nirasta samasta viśeṣam eva brahma pratipattavyam
translated: And therefore, even in the acceptance of one of the two, Brahman is to be understood as devoid of all distinctions.

analyzed: sarvatra a śabdam a sparśam ityādi vākyeṣu tathābhūtam eva hi brahma upadiśyate
translated: For in all passages like soundless, touchable not Brahman of that nature alone is taught.

analyzed: na bhedāt iti ced na pratyekam a tad vacanāt
translated: If it be said that it is not so because of difference, no; because of the declaration of each as not that.

analyzed: na nirviśeṣam eva brahma
translated: Brahman is not devoid of distinctions.

analyzed: catuṣpād brahma ṣoḍaśa kalam brahma ityādau bhedena upadeśāt iti ced na
translated: If it be said that Brahman is with distinctions, because it is taught as different in such passages as Brahman with four feet, Brahman with sixteen parts, no.

analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam asyām pṛthivyām ityādinā pratyupādhi bheda abhāva vacanāt
translated: And this is because of the statement about the absence of difference due to limiting adjuncts in the passage beginning with He who is in this earth (Br. 3.7.3).

analyzed: api ca evam eke
translated: Moreover, some say this.

original: neha nānāsti kiñcanetyādau bhedadarśananindāpūrvakamabhedameke śākhinaḥ samāmanantīti /
analyzed: na iha nānā asti kiñcana ityādau bheda darśana nindā pūrvakam abhedam eke śākhinaḥ samāmananti iti
translated: In passages such as There is no diversity here of any kind (Br. 1.4.11), some branches of the Veda declare non-difference after first condemning the view of difference.

original: tadidaṃ vyākhyānaṃ samyagvyākhyānenaivāpahastitaṃ bhaviṣyati kiṃ punaḥ prayatnenetyāśayavānvyākhyānamevārabhate /
analyzed: tat idam vyākhyānam samyak vyākhyānena eva apahastitam bhaviṣyati kim punar prayatnena iti āśayavān vyākhyānam eva ārabhate
translated: This explanation will be set aside by the correct explanation itself, so why make an effort? With this intention, he begins the explanation.

analyzed: sarva śarīreṣu
translated: In all bodies.

analyzed: pratiśarīram ca dakṣiṇa akṣi ādi sthāneṣu
translated: And in the places of the right eye, etc., in each body.

analyzed: sthitaḥ paramapuruṣaḥ svapana ādi avasthāḥ pravartayati iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the Supreme Person, residing there everywhere, brings about the states of dreaming, etc.

original: tatra sarvatra sthitaḥ kimeka evota parasparaṃ bhinna iti saṃśaye yadyugapadbhinnasthānaṃ tadbhinnaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: tatra sarvatra sthitaḥ kim ekaḥ eva uta parasparam bhinnaḥ iti saṃśaye yat yugapad bhinna sthānam tat bhinnam dṛṣṭam
translated: There, if it is asked whether He, residing everywhere, is the same or mutually different, if He were in different places simultaneously, He would be different,

analyzed: yathā ghaṭa ādi
translated: like a pot, etc.

analyzed: bhinna sthānaḥ ca ayam iti atas bhinnaḥ eva bhavet
translated: And He is in different places, so He would be different.

original: bhinnānāṃ ca tāratamyamanugrāhyānugrāhakabhāvaścopalabdha iti tatprasaṅgo 'pīti kathaṃ sa eva cetyuktamiti prāpte prativihitaṃ sūtrakṛtā na
analyzed: bhinnānām ca tāratamyam anugrāhya anugrāhaka bhāvaḥ ca upalabdhaḥ iti tad prasaṅgaḥ api iti katham saḥ eva ca iti uktam iti prāpte prativihitam sūtrakṛtā na
translated: And a difference in the degree of perfection of the different manifestations, and the relation of the superior and inferior, are observed. Therefore, how can it be said that He alone is the cause? This being the prima facie view, the author of the Sūtra replies:

original: sthānato 'pīti /🔽tadvayācaṣṭe neti //🔽na sthānato 'pi parasyobhayaliṅgaṃ sarvatra hi / / / /
analyzed: sthānataḥ pi iti  tat vayācaṣṭe na iti  na parasya ubhaya liṅgam sarvatra hi
translated: Not even from the place.🔽He explains that: No,🔽not even from the difference of place is there any difference in the Supreme Lord, for He is everywhere.

analyzed: na sthāna bhedataḥ pi asya bhedaḥ kaścid pareśituḥ
translated: Not even from the difference of place is there any difference in the Supreme Lord.🔽Here, the word 'place' is said to be an indication of its difference.

analyzed: atra sthāna śabdaḥ tad bhedasya upalakṣaṇaḥ iti uktam bhavati  saptamī arthe tasiḥ
translated: The suffix 'tasi' has the sense of the locative case.

analyzed: ādi ādibhyaḥ upasaṅkhayānāt
translated: From the enumeration of the first and so on.

analyzed: bhedaḥ iti vadatā ubhaya liṅgam
translated: By saying 'difference', 'having both genders' is stated.

analyzed: iti etat bhinna svarūpa tvam iti vyākhyātam
