translated: This is explained as having a different form.

original: sthānānāṃ suranarādiśarīrāṇāṃ tatrāpi dakṣiṇākṣyādīnāṃ bhede satyapyasya tatra tatra sthitasya pareśituḥ kaścit anyonyābhāvalakṣaṇo hīnādhikatvarūpo
analyzed: sthānānām sura nara ādi śarīrāṇām tatra api dakṣiṇa akṣi ādīnām bhede sati api asya tatra tatra sthitasya pareśituḥ kaścid anyonya abhāva lakṣaṇaḥ hīna adhika tva rūpaḥ
translated: Even though there is a difference in the places, the bodies of gods, humans, etc., and even there, in the right eye, etc., there is no difference in the Supreme Lord who abides there in different ways, in the form of mutual absence, in the form of being less or more,
or in the form of being the object of grace and the granter of grace.

analyzed: bhedaḥ na asti
translated: There is no difference.

original: kuta ityataḥ sarvatra hītyuktaṃ vyācaṣṭe sarvatreti //
analyzed: kutas iti atas sarvatra hi iti uktam vyācaṣṭe sarvatra iti
translated: Why? Therefore, it is said everywhere and explained as everywhere.
Everywhere, free from all faults, full of auspicious, intelligent qualities...

analyzed: sarvatra sthāneṣu nirbhedaḥ ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: Everywhere, in all places, without distinction, should also be seen.

analyzed: aśeṣa doṣa ujkhaḥ ca asau pūrṇa kalyāṇa cit guṇaḥ ca iti vigrahaḥ
translated: It is analyzed as being free from all faults and full of auspicious, intelligent qualities.

analyzed: kalyāṇāḥ vināśa ādi rahitāḥ
translated: Auspicious means free from destruction and so on.

analyzed: yat vā guṇa śabdaḥ duḥkha ādiṣu api iti atas kalyāṇa iti uktam
translated: Or, the word quality is used even for suffering and so on, therefore auspicious is said.

analyzed: cit śabdāt paratas ādi padam adhyāhāryam
translated: The word beginning should be supplied after the word intelligence.

analyzed: athavā cit rūpā na tu acetanā iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning is that it has the form of intelligence, not that it is non-intelligent.

analyzed: sarveṣu bhūteṣu etam eva brahma iti ācakṣate
translated: In all beings, they call this very Brahman.

original: ityādau paramātmā śrūyate yata iti śeṣaḥ / /
analyzed: ityādau paramātmā śrūyate yatas iti śeṣaḥ
translated: In this way, the supreme self is heard, the rest is understood.

original: oṃ na bhedāditi cenna pratyekamatadvacanāt oṃ //
analyzed: om na bhedāt iti ced na pratyekam a tad vacanāt om
translated: Om. It is not so because of difference. If it is argued that it is not so because of difference, it is not so, because each is not stated to be that.

analyzed: uktam artham ākṣipya samādhātum sūtram na bhedāt iti
translated: In order to raise the objection and resolve the stated meaning, the aphorism is not because of difference.

original: nirbhedaṃ sarvatra sarvadoṣadūraṃ sakalaguṇaparipūrṇaṃ brahmeti nopapadyate /
analyzed: nirbhedam sarvatra sarva doṣa dūram sakala guṇa paripūrṇam brahma iti nā upapadyate
translated: It is not proper to say that Brahman is without distinction, free from all faults everywhere and at all times, and full of all qualities.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa baddhau tau
translated: They are bound by effect and cause.

analyzed: ityādi śruti purāṇa ādi vākyaiḥ bhinnatva doṣitva alpa guṇa tva ādeḥ bheda śabda upalakṣitasya uktatvāt iti ākṣepa arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the objection is that the faults of difference, being defective, having few qualities, etc., which are indicated by the word difference, have been stated by the statements in the scriptures, Puranas, etc., beginning with this.

analyzed: na iti parihāra aṃśam vyācaṣṭe tad viruddham tu iti
translated: He explains the part of the answer beginning with No as But that which is contradictory to it.

original: na bhedād iti cen na pratyekam atadvacanāt / / / /
analyzed: na bhedāt iti ced na pratyekam a tad vacanāt
translated: If it is argued that it is not due to difference, it is not so, because each one does not state that.

original: tadviruddhaṃ tu yat tatra mānaṃ naiva bhavet kvacit // / / //
analyzed: tad viruddham tu yat tatra mānam nā eva bhavet kvacid
translated: But that which is contradictory to it would never be a valid means of knowledge anywhere.

original: yattu vākyaṃ tasyoktārthasya viruddhaṃ pratīyate tattatra uktaviruddhe kvacidarthe mānaṃ naiva bhavetkintvanya eva tasyārthaḥ pratipattavyaḥ
analyzed: yat tu vākyam tasya ukta arthasya viruddham pratīyate tat tatra ukta viruddhe kvacid arthe mānam nā eva bhavet kintu anyaḥ eva tasya arthaḥ pratipattavyaḥ
translated: But that sentence which is understood to be contradictory to the stated meaning would never be a valid means of knowledge for any meaning contradicted by the stated meaning. Rather, its meaning should be understood to be different.

analyzed: kutas iti atas pratyekam a tad vacanāt iti uktam
translated: As to why, therefore it is said because each one does not state that.

analyzed: tat anupapannam iva ābhāti
translated: That appears to be unestablished.

analyzed: sarvatra hi iti uktasya pratipakṣa codanāyām punar tad mātra upanyāsasya vyartha tvāt
translated: Because in the case of a counter-argument, the mere restatement of what was said before everywhere is pointless.

analyzed: atas tātparyam āha mahā tātparya iti
translated: Therefore, he states the purport with Due to the great purport.

analyzed: mahā tātparya rodhena katham tat mānam atra tu
translated: How can that be a valid means of knowledge here, in contradiction to the great purport?

original: sakalasmṛtītihāsapurāṇānāṃ parameśvarasyāśeṣadoṣadūratve samastaguṇaparipūrṇatve ca yanmahātātparyaṃ tadvirodhena tat vākyaṃ atra bhagavato
analyzed: sakala smṛti itihāsa purāṇānām parameśvarasya aśeṣa doṣa dūra tve samasta guṇa paripūrṇa tve ca yat mahā tātparyam tad virodhena tat vākyam atra bhagavataḥ
translated: The purport of all the Smritis, Itihasas and Puranas is that the Supreme Lord is far removed from all defects and is replete with all perfections. The statements that contradict that are to be rejected here.

analyzed: doṣi tva ādau katham mānam bhavet
translated: How can such a statement be a valid means of knowledge regarding the Lord's possession of faults, etc.?

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ mahāvākya tva avāntaravākya tva lakṣaṇa viśeṣa arthaḥ
translated: The word 'tu' (but) is for the purpose of a specific distinction between being a great statement and being an intermediate statement.

analyzed: dṛṣṭam hi nirṇīta mahāvākya artha viruddhasya tad avāntaravākyasya tatra aprāmāṇyam
translated: For it is seen that an intermediate statement contradicting the meaning of a well-established great statement is not a valid means of knowledge in that context.

analyzed: yathā svarga prayojana agnihotra para mahāvākya artha viruddhasya yadi amuṣmin loke sti vā na vā ityādeḥ tat avāntaravākyam
translated: For example, the intermediate statement beginning with whether it exists in that world or not contradicts the meaning of the great statement about the Agnihotra sacrifice, which has heaven as its purpose.

analyzed: tad athar pratipatti hetu tvāt
translated: Because it is the cause of understanding that meaning.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: yadi parameśvarasya sakalaguṇaparipūrṇatve nirastasamastadoṣatve ca vedādīnāṃ mahātātparyamityarthaḥ pramāṇavānsyāt /
analyzed: yadi parameśvarasya sakala guṇa paripūrṇa tve nirasta samasta doṣa tve ca veda ādīnām mahā tātparyam iti arthaḥ pramāṇavān syāt
translated: If the great purport of the Vedas, etc. regarding the completeness of all qualities and the absence of all faults in the Supreme Lord were to be a valid object,

original: tadeva tu na paśyāma ityata āha duḥkheti //
analyzed: tat eva tu na paśyāmaḥ iti atas āha duḥkha iti
translated: we would see that very thing. But we do not see that. Therefore he says duḥkha (suffering), etc.

analyzed: duḥkha apyaya sukha avāpti hetu tvena eva veda vāc
translated: The Vedic statement is a valid means of knowledge only as the cause of the destruction of suffering and the attainment of happiness.

analyzed: bhavet mānam
translated: It is a valid means of knowledge in that alone.

analyzed: mokṣa hetu tvena iti vaktavye duḥkha apyaya ityādi vacanam vādi vipratipatteḥ mokṣa svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham ātyantika duḥkha nivṛttiḥ niratiśaya sukha abhivyaktiḥ ca
translated: When it should be said to be the cause of liberation, the statement beginning with the destruction of suffering is for the purpose of determining the nature of liberation due to the disagreement of the disputants, as the cessation of suffering beyond measure and the manifestation of unsurpassed bliss

analyzed: muktiḥ iti
translated: is liberation.

analyzed: yat vā a pradhāna prayojana svarga ādi saṅgraha artham idam
translated: Or this is for the purpose of including heaven, which is the principal aim.

analyzed: ittham bhūta lakṣaṇe tṛtīyā
translated: The instrumental case is in the sense of having such a nature.

analyzed: duḥkha apyaya sukha avāpti hetu tvena eva tad hetu tvam yathā nirvahet tathā eva
translated: The cause of liberation is just that which serves as the cause by means of being the cause of the destruction of suffering and the attainment of bliss.

analyzed: mānam kasyacid arthasya pratipādikā bhavet
translated: It may be an indicator of the meaning of something for someone.

analyzed: veda vāc iti smṛti ādeḥ upalakṣaṇam
translated: The word Veda is a metonym for Smriti and so on.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: śāstreṇa hi viṣaya prayojanavatā bhāvyam
translated: For a treatise must have a subject matter and a purpose.

analyzed: pramāṇa tvāt parārtha tvāt ca
translated: Because it is a means of knowledge and because it is for the sake of others.

original: tatra yadā viṣayaḥ sandigdhaḥ prayojanaṃ ca niścitaṃ tadā /
analyzed: tatra yadā viṣayaḥ sandigdhaḥ prayojanam ca niścitam tadā
translated: There, when the subject matter is doubtful and the purpose is certain,

original: niścitena prayojanenāniścito viṣayo niścetavyaḥ /🔽nahi śāstraṃ sākṣātprayojanasya kārakam /
analyzed: niścitena prayojanena aniścitaḥ viṣayaḥ niścetavyaḥ  nahi śāstram sākṣāt prayojanasya kārakam
translated: the uncertain subject matter should be ascertained by the certain purpose.🔽For a treatise is not directly the maker of the purpose.

analyzed: kintu viṣaya pratipādana dvārā eva
translated: But only by means of indicating the subject matter.

original: tathāca tatprayojanaṃ yasminjñāpite sampadyate sa eva viṣayo 'vadhāryate /
analyzed: tathā ca tat prayojanam yasmin jñāpite sampadyate saḥ eva viṣayaḥ vadhāryate
translated: And thus, that which is understood when its purpose is indicated is determined to be the subject matter.

analyzed: anyathā viṣaya prayojanayoḥ asambaddha tvena śāstrasya anupādeya tā āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, due to the irrelevance of the subject matter and purpose, the scripture would be unacceptable.

analyzed: veda ādeḥ ca mokṣaḥ eva pradhānam prayojanam
translated: And for the Veda, liberation alone is the primary purpose.

analyzed: teṣām duḥkha prahāṇāya śrutiḥ eṣā pravartate ityādeḥ
translated: As it is said, This scripture proceeds for the cessation of their suffering.

original: svargādikaṃ cāpradhānam /🔽ataḥ sa eva viṣayaḥ kalpanīyo yasminjñāpi
analyzed: svarga ādikam ca a pradhānam  atas saḥ eva viṣayaḥ kalpanīyaḥ
translated: And heaven etc. are not primary.🔽Therefore, that alone should be considered the subject matter, upon the understanding of which liberation etc.

analyzed: te mokṣa ādikam sampadyate
translated: is accomplished.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha tat iti
translated: Then what? To this he says that.

analyzed: tad īśānāt prasannāt eva na anyathā
translated: From the grace of that Lord alone, not otherwise.

analyzed: tat duḥkha āpyaya ādi rūpam kaivalyam
translated: That liberation in the form of the cessation of suffering etc.

analyzed: īśānāt viṣṇoḥ eva bhavet na anyasmāt
translated: Should come from Vishnu alone, the Lord, not from another.

analyzed: sa hi tasya iṣye na anyaḥ
translated: For He is its bestower, not another.

original: astu tarhi sa eva viṣayaḥ kiṃ guṇapūrṇatvādinetyata uktaṃ prasannādeva nānyathā na jñātamātrāditi /
analyzed: astu tarhi saḥ eva viṣayaḥ kim guṇa pūrṇa tva ādinā iti atas uktam prasannāt eva na anyathā na jñāta mātrāt iti
translated: Then let that alone be the subject matter. What about the fullness of qualities etc.? To this it is said: From the grace of the Lord alone, not from mere knowledge.

analyzed: tatas pi kim iti atas āha prasanna tā iti
translated: Then what? To this he says the grace.

analyzed: prasanna tā guṇa utkarṣa jñānāt eva hi kevalam
translated: The grace is only from the knowledge of the excellence of qualities.

analyzed: nirdoṣa tā parijñānāt api nā anyena kenacid
translated: And by the knowledge of being free from faults, and by no other means whatsoever.

original: viṣṇoḥ prasannatā ca tadīyaguṇotkarṣajñānādeva kevalaṃ nirdeṣatāparijñānācca bhavati /
analyzed: viṣṇoḥ prasanna tā ca tadīya guṇa utkarṣa jñānāt eva kevalam bhavati
translated: And the satisfaction of Vishnu arises only from the knowledge of His excellence of qualities and from the knowledge of His being absolutely faultless.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ pramāṇa prasiddhim dyotayati
translated: The word 'hi' (in fact) indicates the well-known fact of the matter.

analyzed: tat ca vakṣyate
translated: And that will be stated.

analyzed: kevala śabdaḥ vadāraṇa arthaḥ
translated: The word 'kevala' (only) has the sense of exclusion.

analyzed: na anyena kenacid iti etad pratirūpeṇa alpa guṇa tva ādi jñānena karma ādinā vā na iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it does not arise from the knowledge of His having lesser qualities etc. or from actions etc. which are similar to the knowledge of His being absolutely faultless.

analyzed: tathā ca mokṣa ādi prayojanena śāstreṇa tat sādhana bhūtam bhagavat guṇa utkarṣa nirdeṣatā jñānam eva
translated: And thus, by the scripture which has the purpose of liberation etc., the knowledge of the excellence of the qualities of the Lord and of His being absolutely faultless, which is the means to that,

analyzed: jīvānām utpādanīyam iti atas sakala guṇa paripūrṇe nirasta samasta doṣe nārāyaṇaḥ eva aśeṣa śāstrasya
translated: is to be produced in the individual souls. Therefore, in Narayana alone, who is full of all qualities and devoid of all faults,🔽it is ascertained that the great purport of the entire scripture
resides.

original: syādetadyadi tadīśānādityādinoktaṃ prāmāṇikaṃ syādityatastatrāgamavākyānyudāharati yo māmiti //
analyzed: syāt etat yadi tat īśānāt ityādinā uktam prāmāṇikam syāt iti atas tatra āgama vākyāni udāharati yaḥ mām iti
translated: This may be argued: If what is stated by 'He is the Lord' etc. were authoritative. Therefore, in that context, he cites scriptural statements: 'He who...'

analyzed: yaḥ mām aśeṣa doṣa ujkham guṇa sarvasva bṛṃhitam
translated: He who is devoid of all faults and is full of all the qualities,

analyzed: jānāti asmai prasannaḥ ham dadyām muktim na ca anyathā
translated: I know him, being pleased with him, I would grant liberation, not otherwise.

original: yo māmaśeṣābhyadhikaṃ vijānāti sa eva mām /
analyzed: yaḥ mām aśeṣa abhyadhikam vijānāti saḥ eva mām
translated: He alone who knows Me as superior to all, knows Me.

analyzed: vijānāti akhilān tasya dadyām kāmān param padam
translated: To him I would grant all desires, the highest position.

original: yo māmevamasammūḍhaḥ kiṃ mā nindanti śatravaḥ // / / //
analyzed: yaḥ mām evam asammūḍhaḥ kim mā nindanti śatravaḥ
translated: He who thus, unconfused, knows Me, what can my enemies do to him?

analyzed: bṛṃhita śabdena pratyekam api guṇānām anavadhika tvam ācaṣṭe
translated: By the word brimhana (expansion), he declares the infinity of the qualities individually.

analyzed: aśeṣa abhyadhikam guṇaiḥ sarva uttamam
translated: Superior to all in qualities and devoid of faults, the best of all.

analyzed: saḥ eva mām vijānāti
translated: He alone knows Me.

analyzed: anya jñānasya mad prasāda a hetu tvāt  yaḥ mām evam iti anena kṛtakṛtyaḥ ca bhārata
translated: Because the knowledge of others is not the cause of My grace.

analyzed: ityantam bhagavat vākyam saṅgṛhṇāti
translated: He who thus - by this, he includes the statement of the Lord ending with having accomplished his purpose, O descendant of Bharata.

analyzed: evam samastaiḥ guṇaiḥ
translated: Thus, by all the qualities and by the absence of faults,

analyzed: kṣara akṣara uttamaḥ hi puruṣottamaḥ
translated: the Supreme Person is indeed superior to the perishable and the imperishable.

analyzed: sa sarva vid ityādi stutyā prasanna tā dyotyate
translated: His praise as he who knows all and so on indicates his satisfaction.

analyzed: sarva bhāvena sarveṇa prakāreṇa
translated: With all, with every kind.

analyzed: anyathā vyāghātāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be a contradiction.

analyzed: kṛtakṛtyaḥ muktaḥ
translated: Having accomplished his purpose, he is liberated.

analyzed: kim mām iti anena abhī
translated: What can my enemies do to him? - by this, O Arjuna.

original: idamekameka asmi niṣṣāḷabhī dvā kimau trayaḥ karanti /
analyzed: idam ekam eka asmi niṣṣāḍabhī dvā kimau trayaḥ karanti
translated: This one alone I bear, the single grain; what do these three do to me?

original: khale na parṣānprati hanmi bhūri kimmā nindanti śatravo 'nindrā' / ṛ /
analyzed: khale na parṣān prati hanmi bhūri kim mā nindanti śatravaḥ n indrā
translated: I crush many against the wicked; what do the powerless enemies revile?

analyzed: iti śrutim upādatte
translated: Thus he takes up the Vedic text.

original: idamekaṃ viśvaṃ abhi prati ahameko niṣpaḷasmi nitarāṃ sahata iti niṣpāṭ dvau prapañcāvabhi prati ahameko niṣṣāḷasmi /
analyzed: idam ekam viśvam abhi prati aham ekaḥ niṣpaḷ asmi nitarām sahate iti niṣpāṭ dvau prapañcau abhi prati aham ekaḥ niṣṣāh asmi
translated: This one alone, the universe, I bear, the single grain, I bear very well. The two worlds are the single grain.

original: trayo 'pi prapañcā mama kimeva kurvanti na kimapi mamāniṣyaṃ kartumīśate /
analyzed: trayaḥ pi prapañcāḥ mama kim eva kurvanti na kim api mama aniṣyam kartum īśate
translated: What do even these three worlds do to me? They are not able to do me any harm.

original: kintvahameva khala iva khalasthitāni dhānyānīva bhūri bhūrīnbahūnbahuvaraṃ vā tānniṣṭhurānnindakānpratihanmi tasmādanīśvarāste śatravo māṃ
analyzed: kintu aham eva khalaḥ iva khala sthitāni dhānyāni iva bhūri bhūrīn bahūn bahu varam vā tān niṣṭhurān nindakān pratihanmi tasmāt anīśvarāḥ te śatravaḥ mām
translated: But I, like a wicked man, crush many, many excellent ones, like much grain remaining in a wicked place, against the wicked, the revilers. Therefore, those powerless enemies

analyzed: kim nindanti iti arthaḥ
translated: what do they revile me? This is the meaning.

analyzed: etat bhagavataḥ vākyam
translated: This is the Blessed One's statement.

analyzed: atra nindakeṣu bhagavataḥ prasādaḥ  niṣya avāptiḥ ca śrūyate
translated: Here, the Blessed One's displeasure towards the revilers, the attainment of misfortune,

analyzed: nindā ca doṣa jñāna ādikā iti prasiddham eva
translated: and the reviling, which is well-known to be due to the knowledge of faults etc., are heard.

analyzed: vākya udāharaṇa phalam āha ityādi iti
translated: The result of citing the statement is said to be thus etc.

analyzed: ityādi veda smṛti ga vākyaiḥ eva avasīyate  avadhāraṇena prābalyam sūcayati
translated: This is ascertained by such Vedic and Smṛti texts as have been cited.🔽By the word 'only' he indicates the superiority of grace.

analyzed: prasādena muktiḥ sa guṇa vedanāt  iti vakṣyamāṇam atra api sambaddhayate
translated: That liberation is by grace, from the knowledge of the Lord's qualities,🔽will be stated later, and is connected here also.

analyzed: atra anumānam api āha lokataḥ ca iti
translated: Here he states the inference also, from the world, etc.

analyzed: lokataḥ ca prasādena muktiḥ sa guṇa vedanāt
translated: And from the world, liberation is by grace, from the knowledge of the Lord's qualities.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ dhyāhāryaḥ avasīyate iti vartate
translated: The word 'iti' is to be supplied. The meaning 'is ascertained' continues.

analyzed: bhagavat prasādena saṃsārāt muktiḥ bhavati sa bhagavat prasādaḥ tad guṇa utkarṣa vedanāt doṣa abhāva vedanāt ca bhavati iti ayam arthaḥ lokataḥ loka dṛṣṭānta upeta anumānataḥ ca anumīyate vasīyate
translated: Liberation from saṃsāra occurs by the grace of the Lord. That grace of the Lord occurs from the knowledge of His excellences and from the knowledge of the absence of faults. This meaning is inferred from the world, from the inference based on the analogy of worldly experience, and is ascertained.

analyzed: tathā ca prayogaḥ
translated: And thus the argument is as follows.

analyzed: samartha puruṣa prasāda sādhyā mukti tvāt nigaḍa mukti vat
translated: Liberation from saṃsāra is to be accomplished by the grace of the Supreme Person, because it is liberation, like liberation from shackles.

analyzed: na ca hi bhagavataḥ samarthaḥ sti
translated: And no one else but the Lord is capable of that.

analyzed: vimataḥ bhagavat prasādaḥ guṇa utkarṣa jñāna sādhyaḥ mahā prasāda tvāt rājasa prasāda vat
translated: The grace of the Lord, which is under dispute, is to be accomplished by the knowledge of His excellences, because it is great grace, like the grace of a great king.

analyzed: pakṣa tulya tvāt na vyabhicāraḥ codanīyaḥ
translated: And it should not be objected that there is no invariable concomitance, because the subject and the example are the same.

analyzed: mahā tātparya rodhena ityādinā uktam upasaṃharan para kṛta apavyākhyāna nirāse pi uktām yuktim atidiśati mahā tātparya iti
translated: Having concluded what was said beginning with by obstructing the great purport, he directs the argument stated in the refutation of others' bad explanations to the great purport.

analyzed: mahā tātparya mukhyasya virodhāt atas eva hi
translated: Because of the contradiction of the primary great purport,🔽the meaning of the scriptures and Puranas etc. is in no way

analyzed: doṣi tva nirguṇa tva alpa guṇa tva ādi kathañcana
translated: defective, qualityless, or of little quality, etc.

analyzed: na arthaḥ śruti purāṇa ādeḥ
translated: The meaning of the scriptures and Puranas etc. is in no way🔽defective, qualityless, or of little quality, etc.
of the supreme great purport.

analyzed: nirguṇa tva grahaṇam apavyākhyāna nirāsa artham
translated: The mention of qualitylessness is for the purpose of refuting bad explanations.

analyzed: kathañcana iti upādhi sambandha ādinā iti arthaḥ  na kevalam ānumānikam sakala veda ādīnām
translated: In no way means by the connection with limiting adjuncts, etc.🔽The great purport of all the Vedas etc.
is not only inferential in the excellence of the Lord's qualities, etc.

analyzed: kintu vācanikam ca iti āha tad viruddhaḥ iti
translated: But it is also verbal. He says this with contradictory to that.

analyzed: tad viruddhaḥ khilasya ca
translated: Contradictory to that of all,

analyzed: arthaḥ svayam vinirṇītaḥ vāsudevena sādaram
translated: the meaning has been decisively determined by Vasudeva himself with respect.

analyzed: doṣi tva ādeḥ viruddhaḥ
translated: Contradictory to defectiveness, etc.

analyzed: akhilasya śāstrasya
translated: Of all the scriptures.

analyzed: tad vākyam paṭhati iti guhyatamam iti
translated: He quotes that statement with this is the most secret doctrine.

analyzed: iti guhyatamam śāstram idam uktam mayā anagha
translated: This most secret doctrine has been declared by Me, O sinless one,

original: etad buddhvā buddhimān syāt kṛtakṛtyaśca bhārata // / / //
analyzed: etat buddhvā buddhimān syāt kṛtakṛtyaḥ ca bhārata
translated: Understanding this, one becomes wise and successful, O descendant of Bharata.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus...

original: iti yanmayā mama puruṣottamatvādikamuktaṃ idaṃ guhyatamaṃ śāstraṃ tātparyeṇa sarvaśāstraiḥ pratipādyo 'rthaḥ /
analyzed: iti yat mayā mama puruṣottama tva ādikam uktam idam guhyatamam śāstram tātparyeṇa sarva śāstraiḥ pratipādyaḥ rthaḥ
translated: Thus, what has been said by me about my being the Supreme Person and so on, this most secret scripture, the meaning taught by all scriptures with their purport,

analyzed: etat buddhvā iti praśaṃsayā ādaraḥ pratīyate
translated: By understanding this, praise is understood with respect.

analyzed: yat uktam sthāna bheda anumānam tat anyathā asiddham iti pareśituḥ iti anena sūcitam
translated: What has been said about the inference of the difference of abode is otherwise established, as indicated by the word of the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: aiśvaryāt rūpam ekam ca sūrya vat bahudhā iyatas iti
translated: By His lordship, the one form becomes many like the sun.

analyzed: kāla atītam ca iti āha atas iti
translated: And it is beyond time, he says therefore.

analyzed: atas khila sat śāstra viruddha tvena na anumā
translated: Therefore, being contrary to all true scriptures, it is not an inference.

analyzed: vartate tatra
translated: It does not operate there...

analyzed: tatra parameśvara bheda ādau
translated: There, in the difference of the Supreme Lord and so on.

analyzed: adhikaraṇa artham upasaṃharati tena iti
translated: He concludes the meaning of the section with therefore.

analyzed: tena īśaḥ khila sat guṇaḥ
translated: Therefore, the Lord, who is determined, is the possessor of all good qualities...

analyzed: sat śabdaḥ nirdeṣa arthaḥ
translated: The word sat means without fault.

analyzed: nirbhedaḥ iti upasaṃhartavye tad phala upasaṃhāraḥ yam apavyākhyāna nirāsam api upasaṃhartum
translated: Although it should be concluded as without difference, this is the conclusion of the result, in order to conclude the refutation of the false explanation.🔽Thus, even from the point of view of abode...

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus, it is also from the point of view of location.

analyzed: bheda adhikaraṇam
translated: The section on difference.
VI. The section on analogy.

analyzed: atha upamā adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, the section on analogy.

original: oṃ ata eva copamā sūryakādivat oṃ //
analyzed: om atas eva ca upamā sūryaka ādi vat om
translated: Therefore, the analogy is like the sun's rays, etc.

analyzed: iha parameśvare jīvasya ātyantika bhakti siddhaye bheda abheda matam nirākriyate
translated: Here, in order to establish the ultimate devotion of the individual soul to the Supreme Lord, the doctrine of difference and non-difference is refuted.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Indeed, it is as follows.

analyzed: jīva brahmaṇoḥ bhedaḥ tāvat siddhāntinā aṅgīkriyate eva
translated: The difference between the individual soul and Brahman is certainly accepted by the proponent of the conclusion.

analyzed: abhedaḥ tu anumānataḥ siddhaḥ
translated: But non-difference is established by inference.

analyzed: jīvaḥ brahma abhinnaḥ cetana tvāt brahmavataḥ
translated: The individual soul is non-different from Brahman because of being conscious, like Brahman.

analyzed: brahma aṃśa tvāt
translated: Because of being a part of Brahman.

original: yo yadaṃśaḥ sa tadabhinno yatheśvarāṃśā matsyādistadabhinna iti /
analyzed: yaḥ yad aṃśaḥ sa tad abhinnaḥ yathā īśvara aṃśāḥ matsya ādiḥ tad abhinnaḥ iti
translated: He who is a part of that is non-different from that, just as the fish, etc., which are parts of the Lord, are non-different from Him.

original: ato bhinnābhinnā brahmaṇā jīva ityevaṃ prāpte prativihitaṃ sūtrakṛtā sūryakādivaditi sūtrakhaṇḍena /
analyzed: atas bhinna abhinnāḥ brahmaṇā jīvaḥ iti evam prāpte prativihitam sūtrakṛtā sūryaka ādi vat iti sūtrakhaṇḍena
translated: Therefore, the individual soul is different and non-different from Brahman. When this is the conclusion, the author of the aphorisms has refuted it with the phrase like the sun's rays, etc. in the sutra.

original: tadetaddṛṣṭāntavacanamātraṃ na kasyacidarthasya sādhakaṃ bādhakaṃ vetyataḥ pūvarpakṣaniṣedhapūrvakaṃ pratijñāhetū darśayati naceti //
analyzed: tat etat dṛṣṭānta vacana mātram na kasyacid arthasya sādhakam bādhakam vā iti atas pūvarpakṣa niṣedha pūrvakam pratijñā hetū darśayati na ca iti
translated: This statement of an analogy does not establish or refute any meaning for anyone. Therefore, after refuting the prima facie view, he shows the thesis and reason with the words not and so on.

analyzed: atas eva ca upamā sūryaka ādi vat
translated: Therefore, the analogy is like the sun's rays, etc.

analyzed: na ca cit tvāt abhinna tvam jīvasya īśa vat āpyate
translated: And the individual soul's non-difference from Brahman is not accepted because of being conscious, even like the Lord.

analyzed: yatas ābhāsa tām eva śrutiḥ asya vadati alam
translated: For the scripture clearly declares that it is only an appearance of that [Brahman].

analyzed: cit tvāt iti aṃśa tvasya api upalakṣaṇam
translated: The word citta (consciousness) is also a reference to the aspect of being a part of Him.

analyzed: abhinna tvam brahmaṇā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is that [the individual soul] is non-different from Brahman.

analyzed: īśa vat brahma vat īśvara avatāra vat ca
translated: Like the Lord, like Brahman, and like the incarnations of the Lord.

analyzed: āpyate yujyate
translated: Is obtained, is proper.

analyzed: asya jīvasya
translated: Of this individual soul.

analyzed: asya brahmaṇaḥ ābhāsatām
translated: Of this Brahman, the state of being an appearance.

analyzed: eva iti avigānena alam vispaṣṭam
translated: Only, without any doubt, clearly.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: na cetana tva ādi anumānena jīvasya brahma abheda sādhanam yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to prove the non-difference of the individual soul from Brahman by inference based on having consciousness and so on.

original: jīvo brahmābhinno na bhavati tadābhāsatvādyo yadābhāso nāsau tadabhinno yathāsūryakādiḥ sūryādinetyanumānavirodhāt /
analyzed: jīvaḥ brahma abhinnaḥ na bhavati tad ābhāsa tvāt yaḥ yad ābhāsaḥ na asau tad abhinnaḥ yathā asūryaka ādiḥ sūrya ādinā iti anumāna virodhāt
translated: The individual soul is not non-different from Brahman, because it is an appearance of Brahman, because what is an appearance of something is not non-different from it, like the sun's rays are not non-different from the sun.

analyzed: na ca asiddhaḥ hetuḥ vispaṣṭa śruti siddha tvāt iti
translated: And the reason is not unestablished, because it is well-established by clear scriptures.

original: kāsau śrutirityatastāmudāharati yatheti //🔽yathaiṣā puruṣe cchāyā etasminnetadātatam // / / //
analyzed: kā asau śrutiḥ iti atas tām udāharati yathā iti  yathā eṣā puruṣe chāyā etasmin etat ātatam
translated: Which is that scripture? To cite it, he says Yathe (just as).🔽Just as this shadow is in the man, in the same way this [world] is spread out in Him.

analyzed: chāyā ātatā tathā etasmin paramātmani etat jīva jātam ātatam āyattam iti yāvat
translated: The shadow is spread out, in the same way this group of individual souls is spread out, dependent, in the Supreme Self.

analyzed: etat eva viśada śrutibhyām darśayati chāyā iti
translated: He illustrates this very [fact] with two clear scriptures, with Chāyā (shadow).

original: chāyā yathā puṃsadṛśā pumādhīnā ca dṛśyate /
analyzed: chāyā yathā puṃsadṛśā ca dṛśyate
translated: Just as a shadow is seen to be dependent on a person and has the form of a person,

analyzed: evam eva ātmakāḥ sarve brahma ādyāḥ paramātmanaḥ
translated: in the same way, all beings from Brahmā onwards are dependent on the Supreme Self.

analyzed: sattā pratīti kāryeṣu pum adhīnaḥ yathā iyate
translated: Just as a person is said to be dependent in the matters of existence, perception, and action,

analyzed: ābhāsaḥ eva puruṣāḥ muktāḥ ca paramātmanaḥ
translated: the individual souls are mere reflections of the Supreme Self, and the liberated ones are also so.

analyzed: ātmakāḥ alpa cetanāḥ
translated: The word ātmaka means having limited consciousness.

analyzed: puruṣāḥ saṃsāriṇaḥ
translated: The word puruṣa refers to the individual souls in the cycle of birth and death.

analyzed: tad adhīna tva ādikam eva ābhāsa tvam iti vakṣyati
translated: It will be said that being a reflection means being dependent on Him and so on.

analyzed: parameśvara ābhāsa tvam na sarveṣām sā
translated: The state of being a reflection of the Supreme Lord is not for all.

original: ca sākṣātkintu pāramparyeṇeti svarūpakathanāya śrutidvayaṃ paṭhati chāyā viṣṇoriti //
analyzed: ca sākṣāt kintu pāramparyeṇa iti svarūpa kathanāya śruti dvayam paṭhati chāyā viṣṇoḥ iti
translated: And that is not directly, but indirectly. To explain the nature, two Vedic passages are quoted: The shadow of Viṣṇu..., etc.

original: chāyā viṣṇo ramā tasyāśchāyā dhātā viśeṣakau /🔽tasyendrakāmau ca tayostayoranye 'khilā api // / / //🔽harerbrahmāsya gīstasyā viśeṣāvindra etayoḥ /
analyzed: chāyā viṣṇoḥ ramā tasyāḥ chāyā dhātā viśeṣakau  tasya indra kāmau ca tayoḥ tayoḥ anye khilāḥ api  hareḥ brahma asya gīḥ tasyāḥ viśeṣau indraḥ etayoḥ
translated: The shadow of Viṣṇu is Lakṣmī, the shadow of her is Brahmā, the special ones are Indra and Kāma.🔽Of them, all others are also so.🔽Of Brahmā, the shadow is speech, of him, the special ones are Indra and Māra.

analyzed: māraḥ ca ābhāsakāḥ sarve etayoḥ tad adhīnataḥ
translated: All these are reflections of Him, dependent on Him.

analyzed: sarve lpa śaktayaḥ ca eva pūrṇa śaktiḥ paraḥ hariḥ
translated: All of them have limited power, the Supreme Lord Hari has complete power.

analyzed: cetana tve pi bhinnāḥ te tasmāt etena sarvadā
translated: Even though they are conscious, they are always different from Him.

analyzed: chāyā iva chāyā
translated: The word chāyā means a shadow.

analyzed: viśeṣakau garuḍa śeṣau
translated: Garuda and Sesha are the distinguishing features.

analyzed: tasya dhātuḥ chāye tayoḥ garuḍa śeṣayoḥ
translated: Of that element, of those two, Garuda and Sesha.

analyzed: punar tayoḥ indra kāmayoḥ
translated: Again, of those two, Indra and Kama.

analyzed: hareḥ brahmā
translated: Of Hari, Brahma.

analyzed: abhāsaḥ iti sarvatra sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is abhasa (appearance) everywhere.

analyzed: ābhāsa tva vyākhyānam tad adhīnatas iti
translated: The explanation of abhasatva (appearance) is tadadhinatvat (being dependent on that).

analyzed: sarve iti anena sarveṣām parameśvara ābhāsa tvam upapādayati
translated: By sarva (all), he establishes the appearance of all as the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ hariḥ tu iti tuśabda arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of tu (but) in Hari tu (but Hari).

analyzed: ābhāsa tve kim iti atas uktam cetana tve pi iti
translated: What is the purpose of appearance? To this he says even in consciousness.

analyzed: atra api tad aṃśa tvasya upa
translated: Here also, the indication of the part of that (Supreme Lord) is

analyzed: tva upalakṣaṇam
translated: a mere indication.

analyzed: tasmāt ābhāsa tvāt
translated: Therefore, because of appearance.

analyzed: sarvadā iti anena bhinnāḥ eva iti avadhāraṇam sūcayati
translated: By sarva (all), he indicates the determination bhinna eva (are different only).

analyzed: udāhṛta śrutīnām phalam āha ityādi iti
translated: He states the result of the quoted scriptures as ityadi.

analyzed: ityādi śruti vākyebhyaḥ jñāyate bhedaḥ eva hi
translated: From the scriptural statements beginning with this, difference alone is known.

original: jīvasya parameśvarābhāsatvaṃ jñāyate tenātyantabhedaśca jñāyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: jīvasya parameśvara ābhāsa tvam jñāyate tena atyanta bhedaḥ ca jñāyate iti arthaḥ
translated: It is understood that the individual soul is an appearance of the Supreme Lord, and by that, absolute difference is also understood - this is the meaning.

analyzed: na para anumānayoḥ sat pratipakṣa tvam ucyate
translated: The existence of a counter-argument in the other inferences is not stated.

analyzed: kintu asmadīya anumānasya śrauta tvena prabala tvāt bādhita tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But the intended meaning is that our inference is contradicted by being stronger due to being based on scripture.

analyzed: idānīm atas eva ca upamā
translated: Now, therefore, it is a simile.

original: iti sūtrāvayavaṃ vyākhyātuṃ tannivartanīyāmāśaṅkāmāha ābhāsatvaṃ hīti //🔽ābhāsatvaṃ hi nirṇītaṃ jīvasya paramātmanaḥ /
analyzed: iti sūtra avayavam vyākhyātum tad nivartanīyām āśaṅkām āha ābhāsa tvam hi iti  ābhāsa tvam hi nirṇītam jīvasya paramātmanaḥ
translated: In order to explain the part of the sutra, he states the doubt to be refuted: For the manifestation of the individual soul in the supreme self is ascertained.

analyzed: tat na yuktam
translated: That is not proper.

original: yajjīvasya paramātmana ābhāsatvaṃ śrutibalena nirṇītaṃ tadyuktiviruddham /🔽nahi niravakāśayuktiviruddho 'rthaḥ śrutyāpi pratipādayituṃ śakyate /
analyzed: yat jīvasya paramātmanaḥ ābhāsa tvam śruti balena nirṇītam tat yukti viruddham  nahi niravakāśa yukti viruddhaḥ rthaḥ śrutyā api pratipādayitum śakyate
translated: The manifestation of the individual soul in the supreme self, which is ascertained by the power of the scriptures, is contrary to reason.🔽For an object that is contrary to reason, which has no scope, cannot be taught even by the scriptures.

analyzed: tathā sati abhimāni adhikaraṇa anārambha prasaṅgāt
translated: Because in that case, it would follow that the section on the one who has self-conceit would not be begun.

analyzed: atas sā kathañcid yojanīyā iti
translated: Therefore, that [manifestation] should be somehow connected.

analyzed: katham na yuktam iti atas āha yat iti
translated: How is it not proper? For this reason, he says when [the manifestation].

analyzed: yad ābhāsaḥ upādhyāyattaḥ īyate
translated: When the manifestation depends on the limiting adjunct.

analyzed: yasmāt ābhāsaḥ sūryaka ādiḥ jala ādi upādhyāyattaḥ jñāyate
translated: Because the manifestation of the sun, etc. is known to depend on the limiting adjuncts such as water, etc.

analyzed: ābhāsa tvasya upādhi āyattatvam vyāpaka tvena sarvatra niścitam iti arthaḥ
translated: The pervasion that manifestation depends on limiting adjuncts is ascertained everywhere. This is the meaning.

original: tathāpi kuto na yuktamityata āha upādhīti //
analyzed: tathā api kutas na yuktam iti atas āha upādhi iti
translated: Even so, how is it not proper? For this reason, he says limiting adjunct [is not proper].

analyzed: upādhyāyatta tā bhāvāt
translated: Because of the absence of dependence on limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: jīvānām iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is of the individual souls.

analyzed: vyāpakasya upādhi āyatta tvasya jīveṣu abhāvāt vayāpyam api ābhāsatvam na yuktam
translated: Because the pervader, which is dependent on the limiting adjunct, is absent in the individual souls, the pervaded, namely, the state of being an appearance, is also not proper.

analyzed: tatas hetoḥ asiddheḥ duṣyam anumānam  itas ca duṣyam iti āha ābhāsa tva iti
translated: Therefore, the inference is faulty due to the reason being unestablished.

analyzed: ābhāsa tva virodhataḥ
translated: And for this reason also it is faulty, he says: due to the contradiction with being an appearance.

analyzed: ābhāsa tvasya bhinna tvena virodhataḥ ca anumānam duṣyam
translated: Due to the contradiction of being an appearance with being different, the inference is faulty.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.

original: darpaṇādinā sannikṛṣṭāḥ pratihatāḥ parāvṛttā nāyanaraśmayo mukhena sannikṛṣṭāstadeva viṣayīkurvanti /
analyzed: darpaṇa ādinā sannikṛṣṭāḥ pratihatāḥ parāvṛttāḥ nāyana raśmayaḥ mukhena sannikṛṣṭāḥ tat eva viṣayīkurvanti
translated: The eye rays, which are reflected back and turned away by being in contact with a mirror etc., in contact with a face, make that very object.

analyzed: na tu tatas nyaḥ ābhāsaḥ nāma asti
translated: But there is no other appearance than that.

original: tatra vyavacchedaḥ parāktvaṃ savyetaravyatyāsaścetyādikaṃ bhrāntyaiva pratīyate /
analyzed: tatra vyavacchedaḥ parāktvam savya itara vyatyāsaḥ ca iti ādikam bhrāntyā eva pratīyate
translated: The distinction there, the remoteness, the reversal of the left and right, etc., are understood only through error.

original: sopādhikaścāyaṃ bhrama iti yāvadupādhibhāvaṃ na nivartate /
analyzed: sa upādhikaḥ ca ayam bhramaḥ iti yāvat upādhi bhāvam na nivartate
translated: And this error has a limiting adjunct, so long as the limiting adjunct exists, it does not cease.

analyzed: evam ca ābhāsa tvasya abhedena vyāpta tvāt bheda sādhane viruddha tvam iti
translated: And thus, because the state of being an appearance is pervaded by non-difference, it is contradictory in establishing difference.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is an indication.

analyzed: tattvamasya ādi śruti viruddha tvena kāla atīta tvam api draṣṭavyam
translated: The fact that it is beyond time due to contradicting the scriptures beginning with That art thou should also be seen.

original: evamābhāsatvānumāne duṣye kim iti cennirābādhena prāguktānumānadvayenaikyaṃ siddhamityāha cetanatveneti // /
analyzed: evam ābhāsatva anumāne duṣye kim iti ced nirābādhena prāgukta anumāna dvayena aikyam siddham iti āha cetana tvena iti
translated: If it be asked, What is the fault in the inference of manifestation? he says, By the two inferences stated above, which are unobstructed, oneness is established.

analyzed: cetana tvena ca aṃśa tvāt samudāya aikyam āpatet
translated: By the fact of being conscious and being parts, there would be oneness of the whole.

analyzed: aṃśa tvāt ca iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it follows from being parts.

original: aikyaṃ ca sādhyamānaṃ na māyāvādināmivetyuktam samudāyeti //
analyzed: aikyam ca sādhyamānam na māyā vādinām iva iti uktam samudāya iti
translated: And the oneness that is being proved is not like that of the Mīmāṃsakas, hence it is said of the whole, etc.

analyzed: māyā vādinaḥ hi jīvānām pratyekam brahmaṇā atyanta abhedam aṅgīkurvate
translated: For the Mīmāṃsakas accept the absolute non-difference of the individual souls from Brahman.

analyzed: na ca evam asmad matam
translated: But this is not our view.

analyzed: samudāya aikye bhedasya api sattvāt iti
translated: Because even in the oneness of the whole, difference exists.

original: atyantābhedaṃ parityajya samudāyaikyaṃ kuto 'ṅgīkriyata ityata āha ata iti // /🔽ataḥ pṛthaktavamuditaṃ samudāyāṃśayorbhavet // / / //
analyzed: atyanta abhedam parityajya samudāya aikyam kutas ṅgīkriyate iti atas āha atas iti  atas pṛthak tavam uditam samudāya aṃśayoḥ bhavet
translated: How is it that, abandoning absolute non-difference, oneness of the whole is accepted? To this he says Therefore, etc.🔽Therefore, separateness would be stated to exist between the whole and its parts.

original: samudāyaikyāṅgīkārato yacchatyādyuktaṃ pṛthaktvaṃ tatsamudāyasya tadaṃśasya ca jīvasya bhavet /
analyzed: samudāya aikya aṅgīkārataḥ yat śati ādi uktam pṛthaktvam tad samudāyasya tad aṃśasya ca jīvasya bhavet
translated: From the acceptance of the oneness of the whole, the separateness stated earlier would be of the whole and of its part, the individual soul.

analyzed: samudāyasya yau aṃśau jīveśvarau tayoḥ bhavet iti vā
translated: Or it would be of the two, the whole and its part, the individual soul and the Lord.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: yadi jīvasya brahmaṇā atyanta abhedaḥ sādhyeta
translated: If the absolute non-difference of the individual soul from Brahman were to be proved,

analyzed: dhyate tadā bheda śrutayaḥ uparudhyeran  māyika bheda
translated: Then the statements of difference would cease.

analyzed: paratva abhidhāne ca apramāṇam āpadyeran
translated: And in the statement of the supremacy of the difference due to māyā, they would become unauthoritative.

analyzed: na ca ayam asmākam asti doṣaḥ
translated: And this fault does not belong to us.

analyzed: jīva brahmaṇoḥ jīva īśvarayoḥ ca bheda sadbhāvena tad viṣaya tva upapatteḥ iti
translated: Because it is proper that they have that for their object, since the difference between the individual soul and Brahman, and between the individual soul and the Lord, exists.

analyzed: etena cetana tva ādi anumānasya ābhāsa uddhāraḥ kṛtaḥ bhavati
translated: By this, the false refutation of the inference based on sentience, etc. is made.

analyzed: samudāya aikyam iti uktam  tat kiñcid prapañcayati īśa ākhyā iti
translated: It has been said that there is unity of the whole.🔽He explains that a little, with (the words) 'in the whole called Lord', etc.

analyzed: īśa ākhyā samudāye syāt
translated: In the whole called Lord, etc.

analyzed: īśa śabdaḥ brahma paraḥ
translated: The word 'Lord' refers to Brahman.

analyzed: samudāye cetanānām
translated: And in the whole of the sentient beings.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: brahma aikyam eva svabhāva siddham tattvam tat paramārtha bhūtam māyā sambandhāt īśvara tām āpadyate
translated: That truth, which is unity with Brahman itself, established by its own nature, becomes the state of being the Lord, due to the connection with māyā, which is the highest reality.

analyzed: sa ca sarvajñaḥ sarva īśvaraḥ jagat janana ādi kartā
translated: And He is omniscient, the Lord of all, the maker of the creation, sustenance and dissolution of the world.

original: jīvāstu brahmaṇoṃ'śāścitsvabhāvā vahneriva viṣphuliṅgā ata eva brahmaṇo bhinnābhinnāḥ /
analyzed: jīvāḥ tu brahmaṇaḥ oṃśāḥ cit svabhāvāḥ vahneḥ iva viṣphuliṅgāḥ atas eva brahmaṇaḥ bhinna abhinnāḥ
translated: But the individual souls are parts of Brahman, of the nature of consciousness, like sparks from fire. For this very reason, they are different and non-different from Brahman.

analyzed: parasparam īśvarāt ca bhinnāḥ eva
translated: They are different from each other and from the Lord.

analyzed: brahma tu sakala cetana samudāya ātmakam atiriktam ca iti
translated: But Brahman is the super-abundant Self of the whole collection of sentient beings.

analyzed: atra dṛṣṭāntam āha īśa iti  īśa rūpeṣu iva uditā
translated: Here he gives an example with the word Iśa.🔽As if manifested in the forms of the Lord...

original: yathā bhagavadrūpāṇāṃ matsyādīnāṃ samudāye bhagavatsaṃjñā na sthānato 'pītyādau siddhāntinoditā tathā /
analyzed: yathā bhagavat rūpāṇām matsya ādīnām samudāye bhagavat saṃjñā na sthānatas pi ityādau siddhāntinā uditā tathā
translated: Just as the name Lord is applied to the collection of the Lord's forms such as the Fish, etc., as stated by the Siddhāntin in Not even in terms of place, so...

original: etenātyantābhedaṃ parityajya bhedābhedāṅgīkāre śrutidvayamivāṃśatvānumānaṃ coktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: etena atyanta abhedam parityajya bheda abheda aṅgīkāre śruti dvayam iva aṃśa tva anumānam ca uktam bhavati
translated: By this, abandoning complete non-difference, accepting difference and non-difference, and the inference of being a part, as stated by the two scriptures, are explained.

original: yadi matsyādayaḥ parameśvarasyeva jīvā brahmaṇoṃ'śāḥ syustadā matsyādīnāmaiśvaryādivajjīvānāṃ nirduḥkhatvādikaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi matsya ādayaḥ parameśvarasya iva jīvāḥ brahmaṇaḥ oṃśāḥ syuḥ tadā matsya ādīnām aiśvarya ādi vat jīvānām nirduḥkha tva ādikam syāt
translated: If the individual souls were parts of Brahman like the Fish and others are of the Supreme Lord, then the individual souls would have freedom from suffering etc. like the Fish and others have lordship etc.

analyzed: aṃśeṣu aṃśi sādharmyasya avyabhicārāt
translated: Because the similarity of the part to the whole is invariable.

original: kiñca yadi jīvasya brahmaṇābhedo 'pi paramārthaḥ syāttadā brahmaiva bhavatītyuktā muktirayuktā syādityata āha ata iti //🔽ato dehādyupādhīnāmapāye samatā bhavet /
analyzed: kiñca yadi jīvasya brahmaṇā abhedaḥ paramārthaḥ syāt tadā brahma eva bhavati iti uktā muktiḥ ayuktā syāt iti atas āha atas iti  atas deha ādi upādhīnām apāye samatā bhavet
translated: Moreover, if the non-difference of the individual soul with Brahman were also ultimate, then the liberation stated as one becomes Brahman would be improper. Hence he says therefore etc.

analyzed: īśa rūpaiḥ
translated: Therefore, in the absence of the limiting adjuncts such as the body, there would be equality.🔽With the forms of the Lord...

analyzed: buddhi sannihitam tadīya siddhānta mate iti parāmṛśati
translated: He refers to the doctrine of the other party, which is present in the mind.

analyzed: na jīvānām brahmaṇā bheda abhedau svābhāvikau
translated: The difference and non-difference of the individual souls with Brahman are not natural.

analyzed: kintu abhedaḥ svābhāvikaḥ bhedaḥ tu aupādhikaḥ
translated: But non-difference is natural, difference is adventitious.

analyzed: yathā īśvara aṃśānām matsya ādīnām īśvareṇa iyān tu viśeṣaḥ
translated: As in the case of the parts of the Lord, such as the Fish etc., with the Lord. There is this difference, however:

analyzed: matsya ādyāḥ jagat anugraha artham līlā vigraha upādhi bhinnāḥ a tiraskṛta aiśvarya ādimantaḥ
translated: The Fish etc. are distinguished by the limiting adjuncts of playful bodies for the benefit of the world, and have their lordship etc. obscured.

analyzed: jīvāḥ tu anādya vidyā kāma karma ādi nibandhana deha indriya ādi upādhi bhinnāḥ tiraskṛta brahma svabhāvāḥ upādhi nibandhana duḥkha ādi bhājaḥ ca iti
translated: But the individual souls are distinguished by the limiting adjuncts of bodies, sense organs etc. bound up with beginningless ignorance, desire, action etc., have their Brahman nature obscured, and partake of sorrow etc. bound up with the limiting adjuncts.

original: yata evamaupādhika eva bhedo 'to jñānakarmābhyāṃ dehādyupādhīnāmātyantike 'pāye sati jīvānāmīśarūpaiḥ samatā bhavet /
analyzed: yatas evam aupādhikaḥ eva jñāna karmābhyām deha ādi upādhīnām ātyantike pāye sati jīvānām īśa rūpaiḥ samatā bhavet
translated: Since difference is thus only adventitious, therefore when the limiting adjuncts such as the body etc. are destroyed entirely by knowledge and action, the individual souls would become equal to the forms of the Lord.

analyzed: yathā īśvara rūpāṇi kārya avasāne sva icchayā eva līlā vigraha tyāgena īśvara tām āpadyante
translated: Just as the forms of the Lord, at the end of creation, attain lordship by the abandonment of playful bodies by their own will.

original: tathā jīvā apyanuṣyitajñānakarmasamuccayāḥ prārabdhakarmāvasāne dehādyupādhibhiratyantavimuktāḥ svābhāvikaṃ brahmatvamāpadyanta iti na kaściddoṣaḥ
analyzed: tathā jīvāḥ api anuṣyita jñāna karma samuccayāḥ prārabdha karma avasāne deha ādi upādhibhiḥ atyanta vimuktāḥ svābhāvikam brahmatvam āpadyante iti na kaścid doṣaḥ
translated: In the same way, the individual souls also, having practised the combination of knowledge and action, become liberated from the limiting adjuncts such as the body etc. at the end of the prārabdha karma, and attain their natural Brahmanhood. Thus there is no fault.

analyzed: yat uktam upādhyāyatta tā bhāvāt iti tat asiddham
translated: What was said, that it is not so because of dependence on limiting adjuncts, that is not established.

original: jīvānāmapi sūryakādivadābhāsatvāṅgīkāre bādhakābhāvāditi bhāvenāśaṅkate atheti //🔽athābhāsā mukhyataḥ sūryakādivat // / / //
analyzed: jīvānām api sūryaka ādi vat ābhāsatva aṅgīkāre bādhaka abhāvāt iti bhāvena āśaṅkate atha iti  atha ābhāsāḥ mukhyatas sūryaka ādi vat
translated: If the individual souls are secondary like the sun's rays, etc.,

analyzed: yadā
translated: when...

analyzed: athaśabdaḥ śaṅkā upakrame pakṣa antare vā
translated: The word atha (then) is used at the beginning of a doubt or in a different view.

analyzed: ābhāsāḥ jīvāḥ
translated: The individual souls are the appearances.

analyzed: mukhyatas iti upādhyāyattatvena
translated: Mukhyata (primarily) means depending on limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: sūryaka ādinā tulyam vartate iti sūryaka ādi vat
translated: It is like the sun's rays, etc., because it occurs like the sun's rays, etc.

analyzed: uttara vākye vā asya sambandhaḥ
translated: It is connected with the following sentence.

analyzed: pariharati tadā iti
translated: He answers with tadā (then).

analyzed: tadā upādhyāya tta rūpāṇām nāśitā bhavet
translated: Then, the destructibility of those that are dependent on limiting adjuncts would be...

original: yadi jīvānāmupādhyāyattatā syāttarhyupādhināśe sūryakādīnāmiva teṣāṃ nāśitā bhavet /
analyzed: yadi jīvānām upādhyā āyatta tā syāt tarhi upādhi nāśe sūryaka ādīnām iva teṣām nāśi tā bhavet
translated: If the individual souls were dependent on limiting adjuncts, then upon the destruction of the limiting adjuncts, they would have destructibility like the sun's rays, etc.

original: athopādhayo 'vināśinastadā pratyakṣādivirodhaḥ sarvadā saṃsāritvaṃ ca syādityubhayathā mokṣaśāstravaiyarthyam /
analyzed: atha upādhayaḥ vināśinaḥ tadā pratyakṣa ādi virodhaḥ sarvadā saṃsāri tvam ca syāt iti ubhayathā mokṣa śāstra vaiyarthyam
translated: If the limiting adjuncts are indestructible, then there would be contradiction with perception, etc., and there would always be transmigration. Thus, in both cases, the scriptures on liberation would be useless.

analyzed: tasmāt upādhi adhīna tve ṅgīkartum aśakye susthā eva ābhāsa tvasya asiddhiḥ iti
translated: Therefore, when it is impossible to accept dependence on limiting adjuncts, the non-establishment of appearance remains well-established.

analyzed: etad āśaṅkā nivartaka tvena sūtra avayavam avatārayati iti āśaṅkā iti
translated: In order to remove this doubt, he introduces a part of the sutra with ityāśaṅkā (thus the doubt).

analyzed: iti āśaṅkā nivṛtti artham āha veda adhipaḥ prabhuḥ
translated: In order to remove this doubt, the Lord, the master of the Vedas, says:

analyzed: atas eva upamā iti eva ca
translated: Therefore, it is said to be like...

analyzed: te eva ca upamā iti bhinna kramaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) is in a different sequence.

original: etāvadeva vākyametadāśaṅkānirāsārthaṃ na punaridaṃ sūtrasya pratīkagrahaṇamiti evaśabdaḥ /
analyzed: etāvat eva vākyam etad āśaṅkā nirāsa artham na punar idam sūtrasya pratīka grahaṇam iti eva śabdaḥ
translated: This much statement is for removing this doubt, and not for grasping the sūtra's topic. The word eva (only) is for this purpose.

analyzed: anyathā hi sūryaka ādi vat iti asya avṛttiḥ āśaṅkayeta
translated: Otherwise, it might be suspected that like the sun, etc. is repeated.

analyzed: yat vā ekavākya tā nirāsena para kṛtasya apavyākhyāna tām āha
translated: Or, by denying the unity of the statement, he says that it is a false explanation made by others.

original: yata evāyamātmā caitanyasvarūpo nirviśeṣo vāṅmanasātītaḥ parapratiṣedhopadeśyo 'ta
analyzed: yatas eva ayam ātmā caitanya svarūpaḥ nirviśeṣaḥ vāc manasā atītaḥ
translated: Since this Self is of the nature of consciousness, without distinctions, beyond speech and mind, to be taught by the negation of others,

analyzed: eva ca asya upādhi nimittam apāramārthikīm viśeṣavat tām abhipretya jala sūryaka ādi vat iti upamā upādīyate mokṣa śāstreṣu iti
translated: therefore, with the intention of attributing to it a non-ultimate particularity due to limiting adjuncts, a simile is employed in the scriptures on liberation, saying like the sun in water, etc.

analyzed: yadi api evam ekavākya tā lābhaḥ tathā api artha doṣaḥ tatra tatra vyutpāditaḥ eva
translated: Although in this way the unity of the statement is obtained, still the fault in the meaning has been explained there and there.

analyzed: vateḥ vaiyarthyam ca
translated: And the word vat (like) is useless.

analyzed: sūryaka ādiḥ iti etāvatā pūrṇa tvāt
translated: Because it is complete with just like the sun, etc.

analyzed: iti śabda adhyāhāraḥ ca evam na kartavyaḥ iti
translated: And the word iti (thus) should not be supplied in this way.

analyzed: sūtrakhaṇḍasya tātparyam āha anyā iti
translated: He states the purport of the sutra portion with the word anyat.

analyzed: anya ābhāsa viśeṣitām
translated: Distinguished by the particular manifestation of another (verse 17).

original: anyasmātsūryakāderābhāsājjīvānāṃ viśeṣitāṃ vilakṣaṇatāṃ anena sūtrakhaṇḍenāha sūtrakāraḥ /
analyzed: anyasmāt sūryaka ādeḥ ābhāsāt jīvānām viśeṣitām vilakṣaṇa tām anena sūtrakhaṇḍena āha sūtrakāraḥ
translated: The author of the sutra states with this sutra portion the distinction, the difference of the individual souls, from the manifestation of another, from the sun etc.

original: tadetattātparyaṃ sūtrākṣaraiḥ kataṃ labhyata ityata etacchabda
analyzed: tat etat tātparyam sūtra akṣaraiḥ katam labhyate iti atas etad śabda
translated: How is this purport understood from the words of the sutra? For this reason, he mentions the word etad (this).

analyzed: idam śabda parāmṛṣṭam artham tāvat darśayati yat uktam iti
translated: He first shows the meaning referred to by the word idam (this) with the words yat uktam (what has been said).

analyzed: yat uktam tad adhīna tvam sarva avasthāsu aśeṣatas
translated: The dependence on that in all states without exception,

analyzed: jīvasya sadṛśa tvam ca cit tva mātram na ca aparam
translated: and the similarity with the individual soul, which is mere sentience and nothing else,
dependence on that means dependence on the supreme self.

analyzed: aśeṣatas śeṣeṣu vyāpāreṣu
translated: without exception means in all activities.

analyzed: sandhye sṛṣṭiḥ āha hi ityādau
translated: In the Sandilya creation, it is said etc.

analyzed: sadṛśa tvam ca parama ātmanā
translated: and the similarity with the supreme self.

analyzed: yat uktam puṃstva ādi vat ityādau kim tad sadṛśatvam
translated: What is that similarity mentioned in the passage beginning with like masculinity etc.?

analyzed: cit tva mātram
translated: Mere sentience.

analyzed: na ca aparam svātantrya ādikam
translated: And nothing else like independence etc.

analyzed: yena hetoḥ viruddha tā syāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: By which there would be contradiction in the reason, this is the idea.

original: idānīmata eva copameti vākyaṃ yojayati tāvanmātreṇa ceti //
analyzed: idānīm atas eva ca upamā iti vākyam yojayati tāvat mātreṇa ca iti
translated: Now he connects the sentence and this very is the simile with the words tavatma (to that extent) etc.

analyzed: tāvat mātreṇa ca ābhāsaḥ rūpam eṣām cit ātmanām
translated: And by that alone, the appearance of these conscious selves is their form.

analyzed: tad adhīna tva tad sadṛśa tva mātreṇa eṣām cit ātmanām rūpam svarūpam asmābhiḥ ābhāsaḥ iti uktam
translated: The form, the nature, of these conscious selves is said by us to be appearance, by mere dependence on that and similarity to that.

analyzed: sūryaka ādi upamā ca tāvat mātreṇa ca upapatteḥ iti ca arthaḥ
translated: And the simile of the sun's rays, etc. is appropriate by that alone. This is the meaning.

original: jīva iti vaktavye eṣāṃ cidātmanāṃ rūpamiti vacanaṃ mukteṣvidaṃ dvayamastīti darśayitum /🔽anena ata eva prakṛtābhyāṃ tadadhīnatvatatsadṛśatvābhyāmeva / /
analyzed: jīvaḥ iti vaktavye eṣām cit ātmanām rūpam iti vacanam mukteṣu idam dvayam asti iti darśayitum  anena atas eva prakṛtābhyām tad adhīna tva tad sadṛśa tvābhyām eva
translated: Although it should be said living beings, the word form of these conscious selves is used to show that these two exist in the liberated ones.

original: ābhāsatvaṃ sūryakādyupamā cokteti svābhiprāyaprakaṭanaṃ sūtrāthar ityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: ābhāsa tvam sūryaka ādi upamā ca uktā iti sva abhiprāya prakaṭanam iti uktam bhavati
translated: By this, it is said that the meaning of the sutra is the revelation of one's own intention, namely, that the state of being an appearance and the simile of the sun's rays, etc. are stated by just those two mentioned earlier, dependence on that and similarity to that.

analyzed: evaśabda vyāvartyam darśayati na iti  na upādhi adhīna tā ādyaiḥ ca
translated: He shows what is excluded by the word eva (only). He says no.🔽Not by being dependent on limiting adjuncts, etc.

analyzed: upādhi adhīna tva tad nāśa naśya tva ḍa tva ādyaiḥ api na iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not even by being dependent on limiting adjuncts, by being subject to their destruction, by being an effect, etc.

analyzed: iha bahuvacana prayogāt nāśitā bhavet iti āpādanam api upalakṣaṇam boddhavyam
translated: Here, it should be understood that the use of the plural is an indication of the consequence that it would be destroyed.

analyzed: nanu evam sati dṛṣṭānta dārṣyāntika bhāvaḥ na syāt
translated: If that is so, then there would be no relation between the example and the subject to be illustrated.

analyzed: atyanta sāmye hi sa bhavati
translated: For it occurs only when there is absolute similarity.

original: anyathā prameyatvādimātrasāmyasya sarvatra sambhavena maśako 'pi mātaṅgasya dṛṣṭāntaḥ syādityata āha nātisāmyamiti //
analyzed: anyathā prameya tva ādi mātra sāmyasya sarvatra sambhavena maśakaḥ api mātaṅgasya dṛṣṭāntaḥ syāt iti atas āha na ati sāmyam iti
translated: Otherwise, since the mere similarity of being an object of knowledge etc. is possible everywhere, even a mosquito could be an example for an elephant. To this he says: Not absolute similarity in the example...

analyzed: na ati sāmyam nidarśane
translated: Not absolute similarity in the example...

original: nidarśyate sādhyena sādhanasya vyāptiratreti hi nidarśanam /
analyzed: nidarśyate sādhyena sādhanasya vyāptiḥ atra iti hi nidarśanam
translated: For here the pervasion of the means of knowledge by the probandum is shown, thus it is an example.

analyzed: atas sādhya sādhana dharma sāmyam eva dārṣya antikena tatra anveṣyavyam
translated: Therefore, the similarity of the properties of the probandum and the means of knowledge should be sought there by the philosopher.

analyzed: na tu ati sāmyam
translated: Not absolute similarity.

analyzed: tathā sati sarva anumāna uccheda prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if that were so, there would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of all inference.

analyzed: maśaka ādeḥ api vivakṣita dharma sāmye dṛṣṭānta tvam na aniṣyam iti
translated: And it is not undesirable that even a mosquito etc. would be an example if there were similarity of the intended property.

analyzed: nanu cit tva mātram iti asat
translated: But it is not right to say mere sentience.

analyzed: muktau sukha ādi aṅgīkāra virodhāt iti atas āha kiñcid iti  kiñcid sukha ādi sādṛśyam api īśena īsuḥ anṛte
translated: Because it would contradict the acceptance of happiness etc. in liberation. To this he says: And...🔽And there is some similarity of happiness etc. with the Lord, except for the gods...

analyzed: asurān vihāya anyeṣām jīvānām īśena kiñcid sukha ādi sādṛśyam api asti eva
translated: Except for the gods, there is some similarity of happiness etc. with the Lord for other living beings.

analyzed: sukha ādi sādṛśyam vidyamānam api asarvagāmi tvāt na uktam
translated: Although the similarity of happiness etc. exists, it is not stated because it does not apply to all.

analyzed: cit tva sādṛśyam tu sarva gāmi tvāt uktām iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But the similarity of sentience is stated because it applies to all. This is the meaning.

analyzed: niravadhika sukha ādi vyavacchedāya kiñcid iti uktam
translated: The word 'something' is used to exclude unlimited happiness etc.

analyzed: anyathā hi hetoḥ viruddha tā syāt
translated: Otherwise, the reason would be contradictory.

analyzed: ayam samudāya arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the compound.

analyzed: brahma ābhāsa tvāt iti hetoḥ brahma adhīna tvāt tad sadṛśa tvāt ca iti arthaḥ na tu sūryaka ādi vat pratibimba tvāt iti
translated: The meaning of the reason 'because of being an appearance of Brahman' is 'because of being dependent on Brahman' and 'because of being similar to that', not 'because of being a reflection like the sun's rays etc.'

analyzed: na ca ayam arthaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: And this meaning is not unestablished.

analyzed: nipuṇataram prāk upapādita tvāt
translated: Because it has been established more carefully earlier.

original: na copādhyadhīnatvena vyāpto yena tadvayāvṛttyā vyāvarteta /
analyzed: na ca upādhi adhīna tvena vyāptaḥ yena tad vayāvṛttyā vyāvarteta
translated: And it is not excluded by the exclusion of that, by which it is pervaded by being dependent on limiting conditions.

analyzed: upādhi adhīna tā rahiteṣu api bhāvāt
translated: Because it exists even in those devoid of being dependent on limiting conditions.

analyzed: na ca bhāga asiddhiḥ iddhaḥ
translated: And it is not partially unestablished.

analyzed: cit ātma svarūpa tayā upapādita tvāt
translated: Because it has been established as having the nature of the conscious self.

analyzed: na api viruddhaḥ
translated: Nor is it contradictory.

analyzed: bhinneṣu eva bhāṣu api bhāvāt
translated: Because it exists even in different things.

analyzed: tathā api bimba pratibimbayoḥ aikyāt sūryaka ādi dṛṣṭāntaḥ sādhya sādhana vikalaḥ iti ced na
translated: Even so, if it is argued that the example of the sun's rays etc. is devoid of the probandum and probans because of the identity of the original and the reflection, it is not so.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: na tāvat pratyakṣam
translated: To begin with, it is not perception.

analyzed: tasya pratyak tva parak tva ādinā bheda grāhi tvāt
translated: Because it grasps difference by means of being directly perceived and being related.

analyzed: pratyabhijñānam tu asiddham eva
translated: But recognition is indeed unestablished.

analyzed: na api anumānam liṅga abhāvāt
translated: Nor is it inference, because there is no probans.

analyzed: atyanta sādṛśyasya savyetara kara ādinā vyabhicārāt
translated: Because of the fallacy of over-extension by the left and right hands, etc., of absolute similarity.

analyzed: vaidharmya abhāvasya ca asiddha tvāt

analyzed: kriyā sāmyasya chāyā ādau anaikāntyāt
translated: Because the similarity of action is inconclusive in shadows, etc.

analyzed: pṛthak kāraṇa abhāvasya nityeṣu vyabhicārāt  bimba kāraṇa mātra janya tvasya sandigdha tvāt
translated: Because the absence of separate causes is fallacious in the eternal.🔽Because the mere being produced from the cause of the original is doubtful.

analyzed: pṛthak dṛṣṭa kārya anurodhena hi adṛṣṭam api pṛthak kāraṇam kalpyate
translated: For, in accordance with the seen effect produced separately, even the unseen separate cause is imagined.

analyzed: na tu kāraṇa adarśanena dṛṣṭa kārya apalāpaḥ
translated: But not, when the cause is not seen, is the seen effect denied.

analyzed: tathā sati bahu viplava āpatteḥ
translated: Because, if that were so, many fallacies would result.

analyzed: tatas kāraṇam upādhiḥ eva kalpyate  āgamāḥ tu
translated: Therefore, the cause is imagined to be only a limiting adjunct.

analyzed: rodhāt upacarita arthāḥ eva
translated: But the scriptures are only figurative in meaning due to the contradiction with perception, etc.

original: yadi ca jalādinā pratihatā nayanaraśmayo mukhamīkṣante tadā śilādipratihatā apīkṣeran /🔽na cāsyāṃ prakriyāyāṃ svacchatāyāḥ ko 'pyupayogo 'stītyalam /
analyzed: yadi ca jala ādinā pratihatāḥ nayana raśmayaḥ mukham īkṣante tadā śilā ādi pratihatāḥ api īkṣeran  na ca asyām prakriyāyām svaccha tāyāḥ kaḥ pi upayogaḥ sti iti alam
translated: And if the eye-rays, obstructed by water, etc., see the face, then they would also see when obstructed by stone, etc.🔽And in this process, transparency is of no use at all. That is enough.

analyzed: tattvamasi ādi śruti virodhaḥ tu parihariṣyate

analyzed: atas nirdeṣam eva ābhāsa tva anumānam iti
translated: Therefore, the inference of being an appearance is faultless.

original: nanu brahmābhāsaśabdo jīvasya brahmādhīnatāṃ brahmasadṛśatāṃ ca kayā vṛttyā vakti /

translated: But how does the word 'Brahmābhāsa' (reflection of Brahman) denote the dependence of the individual soul on Brahman and its similarity to Brahman?

analyzed: gauṇyā iti ced
translated: If it is said to be figurative,

original: evaṃ tarhyasmadāyatte śabdaprayoge 'vācakaṃ kimiti prayokṣyāmaha iti prayojanaṃ vācyam /

analyzed: mā evam

analyzed: yoga āśrayaṇāt iti āha tatas iti

analyzed: tatas ābhāsate nityam tadvat ābhāsate ca

analyzed: bhānam astitvam api ca eva asamantāt yatas tatas
translated: And because of the existence and all-pervasiveness of that light,

analyzed: jīvaḥ ābhāsaḥ uddiṣṭaḥ sadā eva paramātmanaḥ

analyzed: tadvat brahma vat ābhāsate iti anena tad sadṛśa tvam

analyzed: api ca iti vyākhyāna samuccaye

analyzed: bhānam jñānam

analyzed: astitvam sattvam

analyzed: asti śabdaḥ vyayam

analyzed: asti svatī iti pāṭhāt  api śabdaḥ bhā nāstitvayoḥ samuccaye

analyzed: caśabdaḥ vyākhyāna samuccaye

analyzed: eva śabdasya tatas eva iti sambandhaḥ

analyzed: ā iti anuvādena samantāt iti vyākhyānam

analyzed: yatas kāraṇāt tatas paramātmanaḥ eva jīvasya bhavataḥ tatas kāraṇāt iti āvṛttyā yojyam

analyzed: bhā ca āmā ca bhāse

analyzed: ā sarva kāla vartinyau bhāse ābhāse

analyzed: paramātma adhīne ābhāse yasya asau paramātma ābhāsaḥ  pūrva anta vat svaraḥ sandhau kvacid eva para ādi vat

analyzed: sūrya ādi pratibimbāḥ yathā jala ādi upādhyāyattāḥ tathā upādhyāyatta tvena ābhāsaḥ na iti arthaḥ

analyzed: nanu ayam arthaḥ na upādhi adhīna tā ādyaiḥ iti anena eva uktaḥ

analyzed: na api ābhāsa pada upādāne niyāmakam asti

analyzed: tasmāt asaṅgatam etat

translated: This is not so.🔽Because the author of the aphorisms intends the reason here to be the statement only appearance, which is stated in Brahma is only appearance.

analyzed: brahma aṃśa tvena ākṣepe tad adhikaraṇa gata arthasya eva tu
translated: When it is objected that it is a part of Brahma, the meaning of the section on that

analyzed: nanu upādhimattvena eva jīvasya bhagavat pratibimba tvam iti siddhānta

analyzed: upādheḥ api nitya cetana tvena doṣa parihāraḥ

analyzed: yathā uktam

analyzed: sva rūpa tvāt upādheḥ ca na bhinna upādhi kalpanā iti

analyzed: tat katham etat

analyzed: ittham

analyzed: dvividhaḥ hi jīva upādhiḥ
translated: The limiting adjuncts of the individual soul are of two kinds.

analyzed: abhyantaraḥ bāhyaḥ ca

analyzed: tatra  pratibhāsa hetuḥ ābhyantaraḥ

analyzed: sautraḥ caśabdaḥ ābhāsa tva samuccaya arthasya vyākhyātaḥ

analyzed: avadhāraṇa arthaḥ vā pratipattavyaḥ

analyzed: evam tarhi punarukti doṣaḥ

analyzed: samprakāśayataḥ sūtra gatau

analyzed: eva iti śabdaḥ tad adhīnatvam eva iti artham caḥ ca
translated: The word eva means that dependence alone. And the word ca

translated: The word also indicates both meanings, slight similarity and dependence on that.🔽The word only indicates dependence on that.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati

analyzed: atas iti artha dvayam hetu tvena uktam

analyzed: pratyekam ca upādhi adhīna tva ādikam vyāvartanīyam

analyzed: tad adhīna tvāt eva tad sadṛśa tvāt eva iti

analyzed: tasmāt ubhau api sārthakau iti  evaśabdena ekena evaśabdena ubhaya avadhāraṇam pratiṣedhati
translated: Therefore both are meaningful.🔽By the word only, by the single word only, he denies the specification of both.

analyzed: nanu ekaikena eva śabdena artha dvayasya ukta tvāt ekena eva ādhāraṇena alam
translated: But since the two meanings are stated by each individual word only, it is sufficient to specify with one.

analyzed: mā evam

analyzed: buddhayā viviktena artha dvayena sambandhāt

analyzed: atha artha dvayam ekīkṛtya kasmāt na avadhāryate
translated: Then, why is it not specified by combining the two meanings?

analyzed: asti atra sūcanīyaḥ rthaḥ
translated: There is a meaning to be indicated here.

original: yadyata evetyetāvadevocyeta tadekasyaivārthasyāyaṃ parāmarśo na dvitayasya parāmarśo dvitīyaparāmarśe'pi militasya hetutvamiti jñāyeta /
analyzed: yadi atas eva iti etāvat evā ucyeta tat ekasya eva arthasya ayam parāmarśaḥ na dvitayasya parāmarśaḥ dvitīya parāmarśe pi militasya hetu tvam iti jñāyeta
translated: If only this much were stated: 'from that very', then this reference would be to only one meaning, not to a pair. It would be known that even in the reference to the second, the combined one is the cause.

original: avadhāraṇadvayaprayoge tu tadanyathānupapattyā pratyekaṃ hetubhūtārthadvayaparāmarśo vijñāyate /

translated: But in the use of the two determinatives, by the impossibility of that, the reference to the two meanings that are the individual causes is understood.

original: tathāca bādhakasyānekatvena prābalyaṃ viśeṣaṇakṛtyagaveṣaṇaprayāsanirāso 'pi na syā
analyzed: tathāca bādhakasya aneka tvena prābalyam viśeṣaṇa kṛtya gaveṣaṇa prayāsa nirāsaḥ pi na syāḥ
translated: And thus, since the refutation is many, the special function of the qualifier is not to be sought, and the effort to remove it is also not.

analyzed: ca labdham syāt
translated: And the taste is obtained.

analyzed: tat idam uktam sūtra gatau iti  evam cetana tva ādi anumānasya bādhaka tayā uktam ābhāsa tva anumānam samarthitam
translated: This is what is said: 'in the aphorism'.🔽And thus, the inference of appearance, stated as the refutation of the inference of sentience, etc., is supported.

analyzed: tat idam pramāṇa antara upalakṣaṇam iti āśayavān āha akhila iti
translated: With the intention that this is the indication of another means of knowledge, he says 'from all valid cognitions'.

analyzed: akhila mānataḥ  jīva īśa bheda dṛṣṭayā eva samudāya ekatā kutas
translated: From all valid cognitions.🔽How can there be unity of the whole by the mere view of the difference between the individual soul and the Lord?

analyzed: na kevalam ābhāsa tva anumānena kintu akhilaiḥ api mānaiḥ
translated: Not only by the inference of appearance, but also by all valid cognitions.

analyzed: bheda dṛṣṭayā iti ukte siddhasādhana tā syāt
translated: If it is said by the view of difference, there would be the fallacy of proving what is already established.

analyzed: pareṇa api bhedasya aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because even the opponent accepts the difference.

analyzed: ataeva śabdaḥ
translated: Therefore, the word 'but'.

original: sa ca samāse guṇabhūtenāpi buddhayā viviktena bhedaśabdena sambaddhayate 'bhedanirāsena bhedasya darśanāditi /
analyzed: sa ca samāse guṇa bhūtena api buddhayā viviktena bheda śabdena sambaddhayate bheda nirāsena bhedasya darśanāt iti
translated: And that is connected by the word 'difference', which is distinguished by the intellect even as a subordinate factor, by the negation of non-difference, because difference is seen by the negation of non-difference.

analyzed: kutas pramāṇāt siddhayet
translated: From what means of valid knowledge would it be established?

analyzed: tatra aikya bādhakam pratyakṣam tāvat prasiddha
translated: Among them, perception, which is the refuter of oneness, is indeed well-known.

analyzed: t siddham eva
translated: It is indeed established.

analyzed: na aham sarvajñaḥ ityādi anubhavāt
translated: Because of experiences such as 'I am not omniscient, faultless', etc.

original: yathā hi stambhe kumbhatādātmyābhāvaḥ pratyakṣastathā'tmani sārvajñādilakṣaṇabrahmatādātmyābhāvaḥ sākṣiṇā siddha eva /
analyzed: yathā hi stambhe kumbha tādātmya abhāvaḥ pratyakṣaḥ tathā ātmani sārvajña ādi lakṣaṇa brahma tādātmya abhāvaḥ sākṣiṇā siddhaḥ eva
translated: Just as the absence of the identity of a pot in a pillar is directly perceived, so the absence of the identity of the self with Brahman characterized by omniscience, etc. is indeed established by the witness.

analyzed: tad abhrānta tā ca prāk evā upapāditā
translated: And the non-error of that has been explained before.

analyzed: āgamāḥ tu tatra tatra udāhṛtāḥ draṣṭavyāḥ  anumāna antaram tu āha
translated: The scriptures should be seen as quoted here and there.

analyzed: ca āha aśeṣa iti
translated: But as for another inference, he says🔽and says 'free from all faults'.

analyzed: aśeṣa doṣa rāhityam sarva śakti tvataḥ hareḥ
translated: The absence of all faults belongs to Hari because of the possession of all powers.

analyzed: sarva upetā iti kathitam atas aikyam kva doṣiṇā
translated: Thus, the identity is said to be with the possessor of all, so where is the fault in the faulty?

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: jīva brahmaṇī na abhedavatī viruddha dharma adhikaraṇāt
translated: The individual soul and Brahman do not have non-difference, because they are the substrata of contradictory properties.

analyzed: chāyā ātapa vat
translated: Like shadow and sunlight.

analyzed: na ca asiddhaḥ hetuḥ
translated: And the reason is not unestablished.

original: sarvopetā ca taddarśanāditi sarvaśaktitvena hetunā brahmaṇo 'śeṣadoṣarāhityasya samarthitatvāt /
analyzed: sarva upetā ca tad darśanāt iti sarva śakti tvena hetunā brahmaṇaḥ śeṣa doṣa rāhityasya samarthita tvāt
translated: And because of the statement that it is endowed with all (qualities), by the reason of being endowed with all powers, Brahman's freedom from all faults has been established.

analyzed: jīve duḥkha ādi doṣāṇām anubhava siddha tvāt
translated: Because the faults of suffering, etc. are established by experience in the individual soul.

analyzed: viruddha dharma adhikaraṇayoḥ api aikye stambha kumbhayoḥ api aikyam syāt iti
translated: And if there were identity between two things having contradictory properties, then even a pillar and a pot would be identical.

original: nanvastu paramātmā sarvaśaktiraśeṣadoṣarahitaśca /🔽tathāpyupādhibhinnastadaṃśo jīvāstannimittadoṣavāṃśca bhaviṣyati ko virodhaḥ /
analyzed: nanu astu paramātmā sarva śaktiḥ aśeṣa doṣa rahitaḥ ca  tathā api upādhi bhinnaḥ tad aṃśaḥ jīvāḥ tad nimitta doṣavān ca bhaviṣyati kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: But let the Supreme Self be endowed with all powers and free from all faults.

analyzed: prakāra bhedasya virodha śānti hetu tvāt iti atas āha aśeṣa iti
translated: Even so, the individual souls, which are different from It by limiting adjuncts, will have faults caused by those adjuncts. What is the contradiction? Because the difference in modes is the cause of the removal of contradiction. To this he says:

analyzed: aśeṣa śakti yuktaḥ ced svātantryāt doṣavān katham
translated: If endowed with all powers, how can It be faulty due to Its independence?

original: yadyaśeṣaśaktiyuktaḥ paramātmāṅgīkṛtastadā tasyopādhau tannimitte ca svātantryātkathaṃ tannimittadoṣavānsyāt /
analyzed: yadi aśeṣa śakti yuktaḥ paramātmā aṅgīkṛtaḥ tadā tasya upādhau tad nimitte ca svātantryāt katham tad nimitta doṣavān syāt
translated: If the Supreme Self is accepted as endowed with all powers, then how can It, due to Its independence, be faulty due to limiting adjuncts and what is caused by them?

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intention:

original: bhavatu vānena prakārabhedena virodhaśāntirmā vā bhūt /
analyzed: bhavatu vā anena prakāra bhedena virodha śāntiḥ mā vā bhūt
translated: Let there be the removal of contradiction by this difference in modes, or let there not be.

analyzed: prakāra bhedaḥ eva ayam anupapannaḥ
translated: This difference in modes itself is not logically possible.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

original: antaḥkaraṇādayupādhayo 'vidyānimittamittāni ca svaśaktyā paramātmānaṃ vicchidya tadaṃśasya jīvasya duḥkhādidoṣānkurvantīti tāvanna yujyate
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa ādi upādhayaḥ vidyā nimitta mittāni ca sva śaktyā paramātmānam vicchidya tad aṃśasya jīvasya duḥkha ādi doṣān kurvanti iti tāvat na yujyate
