translated: Because, like Dharma etc., God also is fit to be the cause of results, as it is established by the Vedas, and cannot be abandoned.🔽Because there is no contradiction, it is not proper to assume that the meaning of the Vedas is figurative.

analyzed: gauravasya aprāmāṇika viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because the burden of proof lies on the one who asserts something contrary to the evidence.

original: parasya brahmaṇaḥ karmaṇaścobhayorhetutve sāmyāpattirityapi na vācyam / /
analyzed: parasya brahmaṇaḥ karmaṇaḥ ca ubhayoḥ hetutve sāmya āpattiḥ iti api na vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that if the supreme Brahman and action are both causes, there is an equality (of status between them).

original: yataḥ phaladāne parameśvaraḥ kartṛtvena karma tu kāraṇatvena puṇyena puṇyamityādau vyapadiśyate /
analyzed: yatas phala dāne parameśvaraḥ kartṛ tvena karma tu kāraṇa tvena puṇyena puṇyam ityādau vyapadiśyate
translated: Because in the bestowal of results, the supreme Lord is designated as the agent, and action as the cause, in such statements as by merit, by demerit.

analyzed: karaṇam ca kartṛ prayojyam iti prasiddham eva iti
translated: And it is well known that an instrument is employed by an agent.

analyzed: tatra idam āśaṅkayate
translated: There, this is suspected.

original: tathāpi karmāpekṣasyeśvarasya phaladāne 'nupacaritaṃ svātantryaṃ na siddhayati /
analyzed: tathā api karma apekṣasya īśvarasya phala dāne nu upacaritam svātantryam na
translated: Still, the independence of God, who depends on karma, in giving fruits is not established.

analyzed: tatas ca na tasmin bahu māna atiśayaḥ iti
translated: And therefore there is no great respect for Him.

analyzed: etat parihāra tvena pūrva padam vyākhyāti saḥ eva iti
translated: In order to answer this, the first part is explained as He alone.

analyzed: pūrvam tu bādarāyaṇaḥ hetu vyapadeśāt
translated: But previously, Bādarāyaṇa, because of the designation of cause.

analyzed: phalamataḥ upapatteḥ  saḥ eva aśeṣa jīva stha nissaṅkhaya anādikālikān
translated: The result is not proper.

analyzed: dharma adharmān sadā paśyan sva icchayā bodhayati ajaḥ
translated: He alone, always seeing the innumerable virtues and vices that exist in all living beings from beginningless time,🔽the unborn one awakens some at his will.

original: kāṃścit teṣāṃ phalaṃ caiva dadāti svayamacyutaḥ /
analyzed: kāṃścid teṣām phalam ca eva dadāti svayam acyutaḥ
translated: And that imperishable one himself gives the fruit of those to some.

original: na te viśeṣaṃ kamapi preraṇādikamucyate /🔽kuryuḥ kadāpi tenāyaṃ svatantro 'nupacārataḥ // / / //
analyzed: na te viśeṣam kam api preraṇa ādikam ucyate  kuryuḥ kadāpi tena ayam svatantraḥ n upacārataḥ
translated: They are not said to perform any special function like instigation.🔽Therefore, he is independent without figurative speech.

original: anādikālatvaṃ ca pravāhāpekṣayoktam kāṃścit bodhayati savyāpārīkaroti svayameveti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: anādi kāla tvam ca pravāha apekṣayā uktam kāṃścid bodhayati savyāpārīkaroti svayam eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: And the beginninglessness is stated in relation to the stream. He awakens some, he makes them engaged in action himself, is the connection.

original: līlayā karaṇīkaroti na tu tena vinā dātuṃ na śaknotīti bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: līlayā karaṇīkaroti na tu tena vinā dātum na śaknoti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: He makes them act playfully, but the meaning is that he is not able to give without that.

original: yadetadatroktaṃ dharmādharmadarśanaṃ tatpreraṇaṃ tatphaladānaṃ tadapreryatvādikaṃ ceśvarasya /
analyzed: yat etat atra uktam dharma adharma darśanam tad preraṇam tad phala dānam tad aprerya tva ādikam ca īśvarasya
translated: The doctrine of Dharma and Adharma, their instigation, their bestowal of fruits, their non-instigation, etc., of God, which have been stated here,

original: tadeva vicāryamāṇaṃ tasminmahāntaṃ bahumānamutpādayiṣyati kimu samastapadārtha ityāśayavānkamarṇāṃ svarūpaṃ tāvatprapañcayati karmāṇīti //
analyzed: tat eva vicāryamāṇam tasmin mahāntam bahu mānam utpādayiṣyati kimu samasta padārthe iti āśayavān kamarṇām svarūpam tāvat prapañcayati karmāṇi iti
translated: when considered, will produce great respect for Him, what to speak of all things. With this intention, he first explains the nature of the Karmas.

original: karmāṇi tāni ca pṛthak cetanānyeva sarvaśaḥ /
analyzed: karmāṇi tāni ca pṛthak cetanāni eva sarvaśas
translated: The Karmas are all sentient beings individually,

analyzed: acetana śarīrāṇi sva karma phala bhāñci ca
translated: and have insentient bodies and enjoy the fruits of their own actions.

analyzed: pratyekam teṣu ca ananta karmāṇi evaṃvidhāni ca
translated: And in each of them there are infinite such Karmas,

analyzed: tāni ca evam
translated: and they are also like that.

analyzed: tāni iti aśeṣa jīva stha ityādi ukta viśeṣaṇāni
translated: The word they refers to those qualified as being in all living beings, etc. as stated earlier.

analyzed: pṛthak iti ekaika dharma adharma adhiṣṭhātṛ
translated: Individually means each one is the controller of Dharma and Adharma.

analyzed: na bhūtāni mukta vyāvṛttaye cetana śarīrāṇi iti uktam
translated: The word insentient bodies is used to exclude the liberated ones.

analyzed: tatas eva sva karma phala bhāñji ca
translated: And therefore they enjoy the fruits of their own actions.

analyzed: teṣu karma abhimāniṣu
translated: In those Karmas that are identified with the Self.

original: evaṃvidhānīti cetanatvādyuktadharmavanti tāni teṣvapi karmasu vartamānāni /
analyzed: evaṃvidhāni iti cetana tva ādi ukta dharmavanti tāni teṣu api karmasu vartamānāni
translated: And of that kind means having the qualities mentioned such as sentience, etc. They exist in those Karmas also.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha iti īśasya iti
translated: What then? Therefore he says thus of the Lord.

analyzed: iti īśasya nissīmā śaktiḥ uttamā
translated: Thus, the supreme power of the Lord is unlimited.

analyzed: evaṃbhūtānām karmaṇām darśana ādimataḥ
translated: Of one who has the view of such actions, etc.
Supreme, because free from obstacles, etc.

analyzed: karmaṇām evaṃvidha tvam kutas iti atas āha ekā eva iti
translated: From where do such actions come? Therefore it is said:

analyzed: ekā eva brahmahatyā hi varāhahariṇā uditā
translated: Brahmahatya alone is mentioned by Varāha and Hari.

analyzed: hariṇā eva na tu arvācīnena
translated: By Hari alone, not by the later one.

analyzed: varāha grahaṇena vārāhapurāṇe iti sūcitam
translated: By mentioning Varāha, it is indicated that it is from the Vārāha Purāṇa.

analyzed: uditā cetana tva ādi rūpeṇa iti śeṣaḥ
translated: And it is mentioned in the form of consciousness, etc. This is the remainder.

analyzed: tat eva darśayati brahma pāra iti
translated: He shows that very thing with Brahmapāra and so on.

analyzed: brahmapāra stavena eva niṣkrāntāḥ rāja dehataḥ
translated: By the praise of Brahma, she came out from the king's body.

original: stotrasya tasya māhātmyād vyādhatvaṃ gamitā punaḥ /
analyzed: stotrasya tasya māhātmyāt vyādha tvam gamitā punar
translated: By the greatness of that hymn, she was again brought to the state of a hunter.

original: prāpya jñānaṃ paraṃ cāpa tathānyānyapi sarvadā // / / //
analyzed: prāpya jñānam param ca āpa tathā anyāni api sarvadā
translated: Having attained the highest knowledge and others, always.

analyzed: anantāni uditāni evam prabhuṇā kapilena hi
translated: Thus, endless ones are mentioned by the lord Kapila.

analyzed: saṃsāre pacyamānāni karmāṇi api pṛthak pṛthak
translated: Even the actions being cooked in the world, separately.

analyzed: anena samagram itihāsam saṃkṣepeṇa smārayanti
translated: By this, they remind of the entire history in brief.

analyzed: vyādha tva ādi prāptyā cetana tva ādikam gamyate
translated: And by attaining the state of a hunter, etc., consciousness, etc. are understood.

analyzed: tathāśabdaḥ pramāṇa samuccaye
translated: The word 'tathā' (thus) is for including other means of knowledge.

analyzed: anyāni brahmahatyāyāḥ
translated: Other than Brahman-slaughter,

analyzed: pṛthak pṛthak uditāni
translated: are mentioned separately.

analyzed: evam cetana tva ādinā
translated: And in the same way, by sentience etc.,

analyzed: hi iti parama  sāṅkhye
translated: The word 'hi' (for)

analyzed: ṅkhya prasiddhim darśayati
translated: shows the well-known meaning in Sāṅkhya.

analyzed: katham cetana tva ādinā pratītiḥ teṣām iti atas uktam saṃsāra iti
translated: And how is their cognition by sentience etc.? To this it is said: 'in the world' etc.

analyzed: pāda artham upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: He concludes the meaning of the chapter with 'tasmāt' (therefore).

analyzed: tasmāt ananta māhātmya guṇa pūgaḥ janārdanaḥ
translated: Therefore, Janārdana, the mass of qualities of infinite greatness,

analyzed: bhaktyā paramayā ārādhyaḥ iti pādārthaḥ īryate
translated: is to be worshipped with supreme devotion - this is stated to be the meaning of the chapter.

analyzed: māhātmyam śaktiḥ guṇāḥ ānanda ādyāḥ
translated: Greatness is power, and the qualities are bliss etc.

analyzed: ārādhyaḥ upāsyaḥ iti uttara pāda arthena saṅgatim asya sūcayati
translated: By saying 'to be worshipped', he indicates the connection of this with the meaning of the next chapter.

analyzed: iti śrīmat pūrṇapramati bhagavat pāda su kṛteḥ anuvyākhyānasya praguṇa jayatīrtha ākhya yatinā
translated: Thus, by the ascetic named Praguṇajayantīrtha, who is very meritorious due to the grace of the revered Pūrṇapramati Bhagavatpāda,

original: kṛtāyāṃ ṭīkāyāṃ viṣamapadavākyārthavivṛtau tṛtīyādhyāyasya dvitīyaḥ pādaḥ //
analyzed: kṛtāyām ṭīkāyām viṣama pada vākya artha vivṛtau tṛtīya adhyāyasya dvitīyaḥ pādaḥ
translated: in the commentary written by him, the exposition of the meanings of the difficult words and sentences, the second quarter of the third chapter is completed.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām tṛtīya adhyāyasya dvitīyaḥ pādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the second quarter of the third chapter in the auspicious Nāya-sudhā.

analyzed: upāsanā asmin pāde ucyate iti bhāṣyam
translated: The topic of meditation is said in this quarter - this is the commentary.

original: tatropāsanārthasyāsya pādasya kā pūrveṇottareṇa vā saṅgatirityato 'sya pādasya saṅgatiṃ vadanprasaṅgādetadadhyāyagatapādacatuṣyayasyāpyāha
analyzed: tatra upāsana arthasya asya pādasya kā pūrveṇa uttareṇa vā saṅgatiḥ iti atas pādasya saṅgatim vadan prasaṅgāt etad adhyāya gata pāda catuṣyayasya api āha
translated: Here, what is the connection of this section, which is for the purpose of meditation, with the preceding or the following? Therefore, stating the connection of this section, he mentions, as an incidental matter, the connection of all the four sections in this chapter.

analyzed: vairāgyataḥ iti
translated: In this regard, what is the connection of this section, which is for the purpose of meditation, with the preceding or the following? Therefore, stating the connection of this section, he mentions, as an incidental matter, the sequence of the four sections of this chapter, beginning with from detachment.

analyzed: vairāgyataḥ bhakti dārḍhyam tena upāsā yadā bhavet
translated: From detachment, from that, the firmness of devotion, by that, when there is meditation,

analyzed: āparokṣyam bhavet viṣṇoḥ iti pāda kramaḥ bhavet
translated: there would be the realization of Viṣṇu. Thus would be the sequence of the sections.

analyzed: mīmāṃsā sādhyāt vairāgyāt prāk eva bhakteḥ bhāvya tvāt dārḍhyam iti uktam
translated: Since detachment, which is to be accomplished by inquiry, should be brought about before devotion, firmness is mentioned.

analyzed: yadā śabdaḥ yasmāt iti arthe
translated: The word yada (when) means yasmāt (because).

analyzed: tayā āparokṣyam bhavet
translated: By that, there would be realization.

analyzed: iti tasmāt
translated: Thus, for that reason.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: sādhana vicāraḥ yam tāvat adhyāyaḥ
translated: This chapter is, for the time being, an inquiry into the means.

analyzed: mokṣa sādhanam ca bhagavat prasādaḥ eva
translated: And the means to liberation is indeed only the grace of the Lord.

original: tatsādhanāni ca viṣayavairāgyaṃ bhagavadbhaktistadupāsanā tatsākṣātkāra iti catvāri /
analyzed: tad sādhanāni ca viṣaya vairāgyam bhagavat bhaktiḥ tad upāsanā tad sākṣātkāraḥ iti catvāri
translated: And the means to that are four: detachment from objects, devotion to the Lord, meditation on Him, and the realization of Him.

analyzed: tāni ca na sama kakṣyāṇi
translated: And these are not on the same level.

analyzed: kintu ādau vairāgyam sādhyam
translated: But first, detachment is to be accomplished.

analyzed: tena bhaktiḥ
translated: By that, devotion.

original: na hi heye rāgavata upādeye pramotpattirasti /
analyzed: na hi heye rāgavataḥ upādeye pramā utpattiḥ asti
translated: For one who has attachment to what is to be abandoned does not have the arising of delight in what is to be accepted.

analyzed: dṛśyate tāvat iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is seen,

analyzed: na asau dṛḍhaḥ premā
translated: That is not firm love.

analyzed: atas evam ca uktam bhakti dārḍhyam iti
translated: Therefore, it is said thus: the firmness of devotion.

analyzed: tena vairāgyeṇa bhakti dārḍhyena ca upāsā bhavet
translated: By that detachment and by the firmness of devotion, there should be meditation.

analyzed: na hi anyatra rāgavataḥ tatra bhakti rahitasya ādara nairantaryābhyām anucintanam upapad padyate
translated: For one who is attached to something else and devoid of devotion to that, the continuous and respectful contemplation is not possible.

analyzed: upāsanayā ca ati dīgha ṛkālam anuṣṭhitayā prasannaḥ bhagavān ātmānam darśayati
translated: And by meditation practiced for a very long time, the pleased Lord shows Himself.

original: yasmādevaṃ vairāgyādīnāṃ kramastasmāttadviṣayāṇāmeṣāṃ pādānāmapyayaṃ kramo bhavediti /🔽evametadadhyāyagatānāṃ caturṇāmapi pādānāmānantaryalakṣaṇāṃ saṅgatimabhidhāya tatprasaṅgātprathamasūtramārabhyātītānāṃ
analyzed: yasmāt evam vairāgya ādīnām kramaḥ tasmāt tad viṣayāṇām eṣām pādānām api ayam kramaḥ bhavet iti  evam etad adhyāya gatānām caturṇām api pādānām ānantarya lakṣaṇām saṅgatim abhidhāya tad prasaṅgāt prathama sūtram ārabhya atītānām
translated: Since this is the sequence of detachment and so on, therefore this sequence should be of these feet which have those as their objects.🔽Thus, having stated the sequence characterized by immediate succession of all four feet contained in this chapter, he, desiring to explain the mutual sequence of all the sūtras beginning with the first one,

original: sarveṣāmapi sūtrāṇāṃ parasparaṃ saṅgatiṃ vivakṣuḥ prathamasūtrārthaṃ tāvadanuvadati
analyzed: sarveṣām api sūtrāṇām parasparam saṅgatim vivakṣuḥ prathama sūtra artham tāvat anuvadati
translated: mentions first of all the meaning of the first sūtra,

analyzed: yuktitaḥ iti ārabhya viśiṣya
translated: beginning with by reasoning up to

analyzed: ācārya sampadā iti antena  yuktitaḥ jñāta veda arthaḥ nirasya samayān parān
translated: the excellence of the teacher.🔽Having understood the meaning of the Veda through reasoning, having refuted the other traditions,

analyzed: paraspara virodham ca praṇudya aśeṣa vākya gam
translated: and having removed all mutual contradictions in the statements,🔽...🔽...

analyzed: adhyātma praṇavaḥ bhūtvā tasya sannihita tvataḥ
translated: Having become the internal Pranava (Om) of that (Lord), due to His proximity,

analyzed: bahu yukti virodhānām bhānāt tad sahita śruteḥ
translated: and due to the appearance of many contradictions with reason, of the Sruti (Veda) along with that (reason),

analyzed: virodham ca nirākṛtya śrutīnām prāṇataḥ tu agān
translated: having refuted the contradictions of the Srutis, and due to the Prana (vital air),

analyzed: parihṛtya virodhān ca tad prasāda anurañjitaḥ
translated: having removed the contradictions, being delighted by His grace,

analyzed: deha kartṛ tvam īśasya jñātvā tad pitṛ tā smṛteḥ
translated: having known the Lord's authorship, due to the remembrance of Him as the Father,

analyzed: viśeṣa sneham āpādya sarva kartṛ tvataḥ dhikam
translated: having produced special affection more than all other authors,

analyzed: niṣpādya bahu mānam ca tad anyatra ati duḥkhataḥ
translated: having produced great respect, and elsewhere great sorrow,

original: utpādyādhikavairāgyaṃ tadguṇādhikyavedanāt // / / //🔽sarvasya tadvaśatvācca dārḍhyaṃ bhakteravāpya ca /
analyzed: utpādya adhika vairāgyam tad guṇa ādhikya vedanāt  sarvasya tad vaśa tvāt ca dārḍhyam bhakteḥ avāpya ca
translated: having produced greater detachment, due to the knowledge of His superior qualities,🔽and having attained firmness in devotion due to all being under His control,

analyzed: yateta upāsanāya eva viśiṣṭa ācārya sampadā
translated: one should strive for meditation itself with excellent teacher-wealth.

analyzed: tatra yateta upāsanāya eva iti anena brahma jijñāsā kartavyā iti etat vayākhyātam
translated: There, by one should strive for meditation itself this explains Brahma-jijñāsā should be performed.

analyzed: anyat sarvam api atha śabda vyākhyānam
translated: All else is an explanation of the word atha (now).

analyzed: yadi api saṅgati mātra vivakṣayā idam ārabdham
translated: Although this was begun with the intention of stating the connection (of the topic with the Veda),

original: tathāpi prāgathaśabdasyāvyākhyātatvāt tasya ca kevalasya vyākhyātumaśakyatvātsūtrārthānuvādaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api prāk atha śabdasya a vyākhyāta tvāt tasya ca kevalasya vyākhyātum aśakya tvāt sūtra artha anuvādaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: Still, since the word 'atha' has not yet been explained, and since it cannot be explained by itself, the meaning of the sutra has been restated.

original: atītena sārdhenādhyāyadvayena yāvānartho mīmāṃsitastāvataḥ sāmānyato jñānādimattvamathaśabdasyārtha iti saṅkṣepaḥ /
analyzed: atītena sārdhena adhyāya dvayena yāvān arthaḥ mīmāṃsitaḥ tāvataḥ sāmānyataḥ jñāna ādimattvam atha śabdasya arthaḥ iti saṅkṣepaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the meaning of the word 'atha' is the general possession of knowledge etc. of the extent of the subject matter discussed in the first two chapters.

analyzed: viśiṣya ācārya sampadā iti sarvatra anvayaḥ
translated: The qualification 'of the teacher' is to be construed with all [the above].

original: tatra jñātavedārtha iti sarvavedānāṃ bhagavānevārtha iti jñānavānityanena prathamādhyāyaprameyamuktam /
analyzed: tatra jñāta veda arthaḥ iti sarva vedānām bhagavān eva arthaḥ iti jñānavān iti anena prathama adhyāya prameyam uktam
translated: Among them, 'knowing the meaning of the Vedas' means that he is one who knows that the Lord alone is the meaning of all the Vedas. By this, the subject matter of the first chapter is stated.

original: yaktita iti lyablopanimittā pañcamī /🔽vedārthavirodhiyuktīḥ sāmānyato nirākṛtyeti dvitīyādhyāyā
analyzed: yaktitaḥ iti lyap lopa nimittā pañcamī  veda artha virodhi yuktīḥ sāmānyatas nirākṛtya iti dvitīya adhyāyā
translated: The fifth case ending in 'yuktyā' is due to the elision of the verbal root.

analyzed: dya pādasya
translated: Having generally refuted the arguments contradicting the meaning of the Vedas, [this refers to] the first quarter of the second chapter.

analyzed: parān vaiṣṇava samayāt anyān sāṅkhaya ādi samayān sāmānyatas nirākṛtye
translated: Having generally refuted the systems of Sāṃkhya and others, which are different from the Vaiṣṇava system,

analyzed: nirasya iti dvitīya pādasya
translated: having rejected them, [this refers to] the second quarter.

analyzed: paraspara virodham ca iti tṛtīya caturthayoḥ
translated: And the mutual contradictions [refer to] the third and fourth [quarters].

original: kathaṃ tarhi pādabheda ityato 'dhyātmapravaṇo bhūtveti bahuyuktivirodhānāṃ bhānātkāraṇācchatīnāṃ yuktisahitaśrutervirodhaṃ ca nirākṛtyeti
analyzed: katham tarhi pāda bhedaḥ iti atas dhyā ātma pravaṇaḥ bhūtvā iti bahu yukti virodhānām bhānāt kāraṇāt śatīnām yukti sahita śruteḥ virodham ca nirākṛtya iti
translated: How then is there a division into four quarters? To this he says, 'having become inclined towards the internal', because many contradictions with reasoning are seen, and the contradiction with reasoning-supported scripture is refuted.

analyzed: caturthasya viśeṣaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: The distinction of the fourth is shown.

analyzed: adhyātma viṣaya śruti virodha parihāra jñānasya carama tva upapādanāya tasya iti uktam
translated: The word 'its' is used to explain the reason why the knowledge of the removal of contradictions with scriptures having the internal as their subject is the last.

analyzed: ādhyātmikā hi
translated: For internal things,

analyzed: bhāvāḥ mithyā samyak vā viditāḥ bandha mokṣayoḥ antaraṅga tām aśnuvate
translated: whether known falsely or correctly, attain to being the inner part of bondage and liberation.

analyzed: na tathā bāhyāḥ
translated: External things do not do so to the same extent.

analyzed: prāṇa tattva gān iti anena caturtha pāda gatānām eva mukhya prāṇa viṣayāṇām adhikaraṇānām prameyam adhyātma iti anena eva
translated: By 'the truth of the vital breath' and so on, the topics in the fourth quarter, which are primarily about the chief vital breath, are shown to be included in the topic 'the knowable is internal'.

analyzed: labdham etat kasmāt punar ucyate iti atas viśeṣeṇa etat bhāvyam tad prasāda āyatta tvāt jijñāsāyāḥ
translated: Why is this stated again? With this in mind, he says 'for the favor of that', because the desire to know depends on the favor of that.

analyzed: iti āśayavatā uktam tad prasāda iti
translated: He who has this intention says 'for the favor of that'.

analyzed: anurañcitaḥ samīcīnaḥ kṛtaḥ iti yāvat
translated: It is said to be well-disposed, meaning it is done properly.

original: dehakartṛtvamityādinā trivṛtkurvata ityadhikaraṇasya sarvakartṛtvata iti sarvakartṛtvaṃ vijñāya tataśca bhagavadbhaktimānbhūtvetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: deha kartṛ tvam ityādinā trivṛt kurvataḥ iti adhikaraṇasya sarva kartṛ tvataḥ iti sarva kartṛ tvam vijñāya tatas ca bhagavat bhaktimān bhūtvā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the passage beginning with the creator of the body is that one should understand the omnipotence of the Lord from the section on the one who makes the threefold and then become devoted to the Lord.

analyzed: atra api punarvacanasya tātparyam pūrvavat avadheyam
translated: Here also, the purpose of the repetition should be understood as before.

analyzed: ati duḥkha sādhana tvam vijñāya
translated: Having understood that it is a means of extreme suffering.

analyzed: tat anyatra bhagavataḥ nyatra adhikam vairāgyam utpādya iti tṛtīya ādyasya
translated: Having produced excessive detachment elsewhere, i.e., from things other than the Lord, is the meaning of the third and first.

analyzed: ajijñāsūnām api kadācid kvacid vairāgyam jāyate dhikam iti uktam ati iti ca
translated: Detachment may arise for some people from some things even without the desire to know Brahman. Therefore, excessive and before are mentioned.

analyzed: tad guṇa ādhikyā iti dvitīyasya
translated: The meaning of the second is the superiority of His qualities.

analyzed: tad vaśa tvāt tad vaśa tvam vijñāya bhakteḥ prāk siddha tvāt dārḍhyam iti uktam
translated: Having understood that it is due to His control, it is said to be firmness because devotion is already established before that.

analyzed: na ca etat sarvam anupāsita guroḥ bhavati iti atas viśiṣya iti abhihitam iti
translated: And all this does not happen for one who has not served a guru. Therefore, specifically is stated.

analyzed: katham ayam atha śabdasya arthaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked how this is the meaning of the word atha,

analyzed: ucyate
translated: it is said:

analyzed: yadi api athaśabdaḥ na eka arthaḥ
translated: Although the word atha has many meanings,

analyzed: tathā api artha antarāṇām atra ayogāt ānantarya arthaḥ parigṛhyate iti avivādam
translated: nevertheless, since other meanings are not appropriate here, it is accepted without dispute that it means immediate sequence.

analyzed: ānantaryam na yatas kutaśricat abhidhātavyam
translated: Nor is the immediacy to be stated from any place whatsoever.

analyzed: vaiyarthyāt
translated: Because it is useless.

original: kintu yena vinā na brahmajijñāsā bhavati yasmiṃśca sati bhavatyeva tadānantaryam /
analyzed: kintu yena vinā na brahma jijñāsā bhavati yasmin ca sati bhavati eva tad ānantaryam
translated: But immediacy is that without which the desire to know Brahman does not occur, and in the presence of which it must occur.

analyzed: tathāvidham ca veda artha jñāna ādi iti
translated: And such is the knowledge of the meaning of the Veda, etc.

analyzed: kiñca jijñāsā nāma vicāra apara paryāyam mananam
translated: Moreover, desire to know is the same as reflection, which is synonymous with investigation.

original: naca tacchravaṇamantareṇa sambhavatītyato yāvadarthajātamatra śāstre vicāryaṃ tāvataḥ śravaṇajanyaṃ jñānaṃ pūrvavṛttam /
analyzed: na ca tat śravaṇam antareṇa sambhavati iti atas yāvat artha jātam atra śāstre vicāryam tāvataḥ śravaṇa janyam jñānam pūrva vṛttam
translated: And that is not possible without hearing. Therefore, the knowledge produced by hearing as much of the subject matter as is to be considered in this treatise must precede.

original: sati ca tasmiñjanmāntarānuṣṭhitasatkarmaṇaḥ satkulaprasūtasya sāttvikaprakṛtervairāgyādikamavaśyaṃ bhavatyeva /
analyzed: sati ca tasmin janmāntara anuṣṭhita sat karmaṇaḥ sat kula prasūtasya sāttvika prakṛteḥ vairāgya ādikam avaśyam bhavati eva
translated: And when that exists, renunciation, etc. of one born in a good family, whose good karma has been performed in other lives, must certainly occur.

original: yattu parairnityānityavastuvivekaḥ śamadamādisādhanasampadihāmutraphalabhogavairāgyaṃ mumukṣutā ceti sādhanacatuṣyayaṃ pūrvavṛttamuktaṃ tadasmādukta
analyzed: yat tu paraiḥ nitya anitya vastu vivekaḥ śama dama ādi sādhana sampad iha amutra phala bhoga vairāgyam mumukṣu tā ca iti sādhana catuṣyayam pūrva vṛttam uktam tat asmāt ukta
translated: But what has been stated by others as the set of four means - discrimination of the eternal and non-eternal things, possession of the means such as tranquility, self-control, etc., renunciation towards the enjoyment of fruits in this world and the next, and desire for liberation - that is included in what has been stated by us.

analyzed: eva antarbhavati iti aviruddham
translated: So it is not contradictory.

analyzed: uttama bhaktānām mumukṣu tā na asti iti ācāryeṇa na saṅkīrtitā
translated: The teacher has not mentioned the desire for liberation for the best devotees.

analyzed: etena jijñāsā sādhyasya vairāgya ādeḥ tad sādhana tve nyonya āśraya tvam syāt iti api nirastam
translated: By this (argument) is also refuted the (objection that) there would be mutual dependence if non-attachment etc., which are to be accomplished by inquiry, were the means of that (inquiry).

analyzed: sāttvika prakṛteḥ sat saṅga vaśāt īṣat vairāgya ādimataḥ śravaṇena tad abhivṛddhau kṛta manana ādeḥ bhūyas tad abhivṛddhiḥ iti
translated: For one who has a little non-attachment etc. due to the influence of association with the good, from the sāttvika nature, by hearing (the scriptures), when that (non-attachment etc.) increases, there is the increase of reflection etc. which have been done.

analyzed: evam prathama sūtra artham abhidhāya tena dvitīya sūtrasya
translated: Having thus stated the meaning of the first aphorism, he states the connection of the second aphorism

analyzed: saṅgatim āha kartavyā iti
translated: with that (first aphorism) by (the words) to be done etc.

analyzed: kartavyā brahma jijñāsā iti ukte kim iti saṃśaye
translated: When it is said that the inquiry into Brahman is to be done, there is doubt as to why (it should be done).

original: ukte sati kimiti kartavyā prayojanābhāvānna kartavyeti saṃśayo bhavati /
analyzed: ukte sati kim iti kartavyā prayojana abhāvāt na kartavyā iti saṃśayaḥ bhavati
translated: When it is said, why should it be done? (The doubt arises) that it should not be done because there is no purpose.

analyzed: saṃśaya śabdena atra viparyayaḥ abhidhīyate
translated: Here, by the word doubt, contrariety is meant.
Because of similarity in being false knowledge.

original: saṃśaye sati tatparihārāya janmādyasya yata ityāheti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: saṃśaye sati tad parihārāya janma ādyasya yatas iti āha iti śeṣaḥ
translated: When there is doubt, in order to remove it, he said janmādyasya yataḥ etc.

original: yadvā kiṃ kartavyā na veti saṃśaye prayojanābhāvānna kartavyeti pūrvapakṣe ca satīti vyākhyeyam /🔽ityāheti vakṣyamāṇenaivavā
analyzed: yat vā kim kartavyā na vā iti saṃśaye prayojana abhāvāt na kartavyā iti pūrvapakṣe ca satī iti vyākhyeyam  iti āha iti vakṣyamāṇena eva vā
translated: Or, when there is doubt as to whether it should be done or not, in the prima facie view that it should not be done because there is no purpose, it should be explained as when it is.

analyzed: sambandhaḥ
translated: Or, the connection is with the (words) he said which will be stated (later).

original: prathamasūtre 'taḥ śabdena jijñāsāyā mokṣārthatvātkathaṃ punarāśaṅketyata āha ata iti //🔽ata ityudite 'pyasya viśeṣānuktitaḥ punaḥ // / / //
analyzed: prathama sūtre taḥ śabdena jijñāsāyāḥ mokṣa artha tvāt katham punar āśaṅkā iti atas āha atas iti  atas iti udite pi asya viśeṣa anuktitaḥ punar
translated: In the first aphorism, the word 'ataḥ' (therefore) indicates that the desire to know is for the sake of liberation. How then is there doubt? To this he says 'ataḥ' (therefore).🔽Even though 'ataḥ' (therefore) has been stated, due to the non-mention of a particular reason,

original: ataḥśabdena jijñāsāyā mokṣārthatve udite 'pyasya mokṣārthatvasya viśeṣānuktito hetoḥ punaḥ saṃśaya iti pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: atas śabdena jijñāsāyāḥ mokṣa artha tve udite pi asya mokṣa artha tvasya viśeṣa anuktitaḥ hetoḥ punar saṃśayaḥ iti pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ
translated: there is doubt again. The connection is with the previous statement.

original: evaṃ tarhi janmādisūtreṇāpi naiṣā śaṅkā nivartate /
analyzed: evam tarhi janma ādi sūtreṇa api nā eṣā śaṅkā nivartate
translated: If so, then this doubt is not removed even by the aphorism beginning with 'janma' (birth).

analyzed: tatra api hi mokṣaḥ samāsa artha tayā vyākhyātavyaḥ eva
translated: There also, liberation must be explained as the meaning of the compound.

analyzed: na tu viśeṣeṇa uktaḥ iti ced na
translated: But it is not stated specifically. If this is said, it is not so.

analyzed: pramāṇa viśeṣa anuktitaḥ iti vyākhyānāt
translated: Because it is explained as 'due to the non-mention of a particular means of knowledge'.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: mokṣa prayojana tvāt brahma jijñāsā kartavyā iti atas śabdena udite punar āśaṅkā bhavati eva
translated: Even though it has been stated by the word 'ataḥ' (therefore) that the desire to know Brahman is to be done because it has liberation as its purpose, doubt arises again.

analyzed: tatra pramāṇasya anukta tvāt iti
translated: Because the means of knowledge has not been stated there.

analyzed: evam ced dvitīya sūtram api katham etat āśaṅkām nivartayet
translated: If this is so, how can the second aphorism also remove this doubt?

analyzed: na hi atra ayam arthaḥ pramāṇena upapāditaḥ iti atas tat vayācaṣṭe sṛṣṭi iti
translated: For here this meaning has not been established by a means of knowledge. Therefore he explains it with 'sṛṣṭi' (creation).

analyzed: sṛṣṭi bandhana mokṣa ādi kartṛ tvasya śruta tvataḥ
translated: Because of the statement of His being the cause of creation, bondage, and liberation,

analyzed: yatas mokṣa ādi dātā asau atas jijñāsyaḥ eva vaḥ
translated: Since He is the giver of liberation etc., He is certainly to be known by you.

original: ityāha tat paraṃ brahma vyāsākhyaṃ jñānaraśmimat // / / //
analyzed: iti āha tat param brahma vyāsa ākhyam jñāna raśmimat
translated: Thus, that supreme Brahman, called Vyasa, possessing the rays of knowledge,

analyzed: śruta tva toap sau mokṣa ādi dātā
translated: is the giver of liberation etc. because of being stated.

original: yataśca mokṣādidātāsāvato vo yuṣmākaṃ mumukṣūṇāṃ jijñāsya evetyetamarthaṃ janmādisūtreṇāhetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yatas ca mokṣa ādi dātā asau atas vaḥ yuṣmākam mumukṣūṇām jijñāsyaḥ eva iti etam artham janma ādi sūtreṇa āha iti arthaḥ
translated: And since He is the giver of liberation etc., He is certainly to be known by you who are desirous of liberation. This is the meaning stated by the aphorism beginning with birth etc.

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intention.

original: janmādyasya yata iti sūtre śrutamiti vākyaśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: janma ādyasya yatas iti sūtre śrutam iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: The aphorism from which is the birth etc. is supplemented by the words because of being stated.

original: tathāca parameśvarasya mokṣadātṛtve śrutiḥ pramāṇamityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tathā ca parameśvarasya mokṣa dātṛ tve śrutiḥ pramāṇam iti uktam bhavati
translated: And thus it is said that the Veda is the means of knowing the supreme Lord's being the giver of liberation.

analyzed: kiñca atra mokṣa dātṛ tvam pradhānam
translated: Moreover, here the giving of liberation is primary.

analyzed: sṛṣṭayā ādi kartṛ tvam tu tatra hetu tvena uktam
translated: The being the cause of creation etc. is stated as the reason for that.

analyzed: kevala vyatirekī ca ayam hetuḥ  tasya ca asiddhi parihārāya śruta tvam abhihitam iti
translated: And this reason is a negative one.🔽And in order to avoid the fallacy of its being unestablished, because of being stated is mentioned.

original: kṛtyānāṃ kartari veti va iti ṣaṣṭhī / /
analyzed: kṛtyānām kartari vā iti vaḥ iti ṣaṣṭhī
translated: In the agent of actions - the genitive ending is used with the verb to be.

analyzed: nanu mokṣa ādi kartṛ tvasya ityādi katham
translated: But how can it be said that of the being the cause of liberation etc.?

analyzed: kartari ca iti tṛc antena ṣaṣṭhayāḥ samāsa pratiṣedhāt
translated: Because the genitive ending is prohibited in compounds with the verb to be ending in the third person singular.

analyzed: tṛn nayam tad śīla ādau vihitaḥ
translated: This is prescribed for the one who has that nature and so on.

original: tena ca śritādiṣu gāmigamyādīnāmupasaṅkhayānamiti dvitīyāyāḥ samāsaḥ / /
analyzed: tena ca śrita ādiṣu gāmi gami ādīnām upasaṅkhayānam iti dvitīyāyāḥ samāsaḥ
translated: And by that, the enumeration of the cow-goer, cow-non-goer, etc. is in the cow, etc., so the compound is with the second case.

analyzed: jñānam raśmayaḥ iva jñāna raśmayaḥ
translated: The rays of knowledge are like rays, the rays of knowledge.

analyzed: vyāpta jñāna vat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is like the all-pervading knowledge.

analyzed: apām taratamaḥ nāma kaścana muniḥ vyāptaḥ babhūva
translated: There was a sage named Taratamo of the waters who was all-pervading.

original: iti pravādadarśanācchiṣyāṇāṃ sūtrakāre bhaktimāndyaṃ mā bhūdityato viśeṣeṇopādanam / /
analyzed: iti pravāda darśanāt śiṣyāṇām sūtrakāre bhakti māndyam mā bhūt iti atas viśeṣeṇa upādanam
translated: Seeing this rumor, the author of the aphorisms, in order to prevent his disciples from becoming slack in devotion, therefore specifically mentions it.

original: jijñāsāyā mokṣasādhanatve pramāṇābhāvenākṣipte bhagavato mokṣasādhanatvasamarthanamasaṅgatamityata āha yenaiveti //
analyzed: jijñāsāyāḥ mokṣa sādhanatve pramāṇa abhāvena ākṣipte bhagavataḥ mokṣa sādhanatva samarthanam asaṅgatam iti atas āha yena eva iti
translated: When the means of knowledge of the inquiry into liberation is doubted due to the absence of a means of valid knowledge, the support of the Lord as the means of liberation is irrelevant. Therefore he says: by whom alone.

original: yenaiva bandhamokṣaḥ syāt sa ca jijñāsayā gataḥ /
analyzed: yena eva bandha mokṣaḥ syāt sa ca jijñāsayā gataḥ
translated: By whom alone there would be liberation from bondage, and that is attained by inquiry.

analyzed: su prasannaḥ bhavet īśaḥ mukti dā
translated: The Lord would be well-pleased, and from that inquiry, there would be liberation for him.

analyzed: bandhāt mokṣaḥ bandha mokṣa  pañcamī iti yogavibhāgāt samāsaḥ
translated: Liberation from bondage is liberation from bondage.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭhī samāsaḥ vā
translated: The compound is by the rule of the fifth case, or it is a compound with the sixth case.

analyzed: yena prasannena iti śeṣaḥ
translated: By whom pleased, is the remainder.

analyzed: gataḥ jñātaḥ  gati arthānām avagati artha tvāt
translated: Attained, known.🔽Because the words of going have the meaning of understanding.

analyzed: caḥ yasmāt iti arthe
translated: And has the meaning of because.

analyzed: prasāda mātrasya mokṣa sādhana tva abhāvāt su śabdaḥ
translated: The word 'well' is used because mere grace is not the means of liberation.

analyzed: asya īśasya jijñāsā asya jīvasya mukti dā
translated: The inquiry into this Lord grants liberation to this individual soul.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: jijñāsā tāvat na sākṣāt mokṣa sādhanatvena asmākam abhimatā
translated: The inquiry is not accepted by us as directly the means of liberation.

analyzed: kintu su prasannaḥ bhagavān eva
translated: But the well-pleased Lord alone.

analyzed: sa ca utkṛṣṭa tayā jñātaḥ su prasannaḥ bhavati
translated: And He becomes well-pleased by being known as excellent.

analyzed: utkarṣa jñānam ca jijñāsayā iti evam paramparayā
translated: And the knowledge of excellence is by inquiry. Thus it is indirectly.

analyzed: tatra bhagavataḥ mokṣa dātṛ tvam tāvat pramāṇaiḥ samarthitam
translated: There, the Lord's being the giver of liberation is first established by the means of valid knowledge.

original: prasanna eva dadātītyutkarṣajñānātprasīdatīti jijñāsayotkṛṣṭatayā jñāyata iti ca lokata eva siddham /
analyzed: prasannaḥ eva dadāti iti utkarṣa jñānāt prasīdati iti jijñāsayā utkṛṣṭa tayā jñāyate iti ca lokataḥ eva siddham
translated: And it is well known in the world that He gives only when pleased, and He becomes pleased by the knowledge of excellence, and so He is known as excellent by inquiry.

analyzed: kim tatra pramāṇa upanyāsena
translated: What is the use of stating the means of valid knowledge there?

original: ato bhagavajjijñāsāya mokṣahetutvaṃ pramitamiti manyate sūtrakāra iti /
analyzed: atas bhagavat jijñāsāya mokṣa hetu tvam pramitam iti manyate sūtrakāraḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the author of the aphorisms thinks that the inquiry into the Lord is the cause of liberation, as it is well-known.

analyzed: nanu sthāna antare sūtrasya anyathā saṅgatiḥ uktā
translated: But elsewhere the connection of this aphorism is stated differently.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: satyām tasyām iyam aparātrā uktā iti
translated: When that is true, this is stated here as another.

analyzed: tṛtīya sūtra nivartyām āśaṅkām abhidhāya tad parihāra tvena tat paṭhati mokṣa ādi iti
translated: Having stated the doubt to be refuted by the third aphorism, he quotes it as the answer to that.

analyzed: mokṣa ādi da tvam īśasya katham evā avagamyate
translated: How is it known that the Lord bestows liberation etc.?

analyzed: iti ced śāstra yoni tvāt śāstra gamyaḥ hi mokṣa daḥ
translated: If it is asked thus, because of being born from the scriptures, for one who bestows liberation is known from the scriptures.

original: pradhānaṃ mokṣadātṛtvaṃ tatsādhanaṃ sṛṣṭayādikartṛtvaṃ ceśasyaiveti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: pradhānam mokṣa dātṛ tvam tad sādhanam sṛṣṭayā ādikartṛ tvam ca īśasya eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The principal thing is the Lord's bestowal of liberation, and the quality of being the agent of creation etc. is a means to that. This is the connection.

analyzed: katham avagamyate
translated: How is it known?

analyzed: na kathañcid
translated: In no way.

analyzed: anumānaiḥ tad tad āgamaiḥ ca anyeṣām tathā avagamāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that others are known thus by inference and those scriptures.

analyzed: iti ced tatra uktam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: If it is asked thus, the rest is stated there.

analyzed: katham idam sūtram etad āśaṅkāyāḥ nivartakam iti atas tat vyācaṣṭe śāstra gamyaḥ hi iti
translated: How is this aphorism a remover of this doubt? Therefore, he explains it: For one who is to be known from the scriptures alone is to be known thus, not to be imagined by inference etc.

analyzed: mokṣa grahaṇam sṛṣṭayā ādeḥ api upalakṣaṇam
translated: The mention of liberation is a synecdoche for creation etc.

original: yasmānmokṣādidaḥ puruṣaḥ śāstramātrasya viṣayo 'to vedādikaṃ yaṃ tathāvidhaṃ pratipādayati sa eva tathā pratipattavyo nānumādinā kalpanīya
analyzed: yasmāt mokṣa ādi daḥ puruṣaḥ śāstra mātrasya veda ādikam yam tathāvidham pratipādayati saḥ eva tathā pratipattavyaḥ na anumādinā kalpanīya
translated: Because the person who bestows liberation is the object of the scriptures alone, therefore the Veda etc. teach him who is of that nature. He alone is to be known thus, not to be imagined by inference etc.

analyzed: mokṣa ādi dātuḥ śāstra eka samadhigamya tvam kutas
translated: From where does the Lord who bestows liberation have the quality of being known only from the scriptures?

analyzed: pariśeṣāt iti āśayavān pratyakṣa gamya tvam tāvat dūṣayati pratyakṣa iti
translated: With the intention that the rest [of the reasons] are to be refuted in the same way, he first refutes the possibility of being perceived by direct perception.

analyzed: pratyakṣa avasitebhyaḥ syāt yadi mokṣaḥ kathañcana
translated: If liberation were somehow possible from [a teacher] ascertained by direct perception,

analyzed: kim iti anādi saṃsāra magnāḥ sarvāḥ imāḥ prajāḥ
translated: why are all these beings, immersed in beginningless worldly existence,

analyzed: yadi mokṣa ādi dātā pratyakṣaḥ syāt iti yāvat
translated: not liberated? [The answer is:] because [liberation] is not possible from [a teacher] ascertained by direct perception.

analyzed: kathañcana tad sevā ādinā
translated: Somehow, by serving him and so on.

analyzed: tadā sarve api yuktāḥ syuḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Then all would be justified. This is the meaning.

original: mokṣadātuḥ pratyakṣatve kutaḥ sarvairmuktairbhāvyamityata āha yasmāditi /
analyzed: mokṣa dātuḥ pratyakṣa tve kutas sarvaiḥ muktaiḥ bhāvyam iti atas āha yasmāt iti
translated: If the giver of liberation were perceived by direct perception, why should all be liberated? To this he says:

analyzed: yasmāt niyamataḥ duḥkha hāniḥ pratyakṣataḥ bhavet
translated: Because the cessation of suffering would be by direct perception,

analyzed: dhāvanti eva tam uddiśya rāja ādyam akhilāḥ prajāḥ
translated: all beings run to him, the king and so on, as if [he were] the goal.

analyzed: yasmāt puruṣāt hetoḥ
translated: From whom, from which person, as the reason.

analyzed: amumukṣu tvāt na dhāvanti iti āśaṅkā nivāraṇāya mokṣa svarūpam vyākhyātam duḥkha hāniḥ iti
translated: In order to prevent the doubt that they do not run because they are not desirous of liberation, the nature of liberation is explained as the cessation of suffering.

original: na hi ko 'pi duḥkhī duḥkhaṃ na jihāsati iti sambhavati /
analyzed: na hi kaḥ api duḥkhī duḥkham na jihāsati iti sambhavati
translated: For it is not possible that anyone who is suffering does not detest suffering.

analyzed: pratyakṣatas pratyakṣa gamyāt
translated: By direct perception, by what is perceived by direct perception.

analyzed: rāja ādyam iti sambhāvanayā uktam
translated: The king and so on is said hypothetically.

analyzed: dāridraya duḥkham jihāsavaḥ vadānyam rāja ādyam iva iti vā
translated: Or, those who wish to avoid the suffering of poverty should seek a generous king, etc.

analyzed: anumāna gamya tvam dūṣayati anumā iti
translated: He refutes the idea that liberation is to be known through inference with the words If liberation is to be known through inference, etc.

analyzed: anumāna gamyataḥ mokṣaḥ yadi tasya anumā eva hi
translated: If liberation is to be known through inference, then that inference itself

analyzed: dṛṣṭa pūruṣa vat mokṣa dātṛ tām vinivārayet
translated: would preclude the bestowal of liberation by a person seen in this world.

analyzed: tad śāstra gamyaḥ eva ekaḥ mokṣa daḥ bhavati dhruvam
translated: Only he who is known through the scriptures is certainly the bestower of liberation.

analyzed: yadi kaścid mokṣa dātṛ tvena anumīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that if someone is inferred to be the bestower of liberation.

analyzed: anumā eva puruṣa tva ādikā
translated: The inference itself is based on being a person and so on.

analyzed: anumānam sa pratipakṣa tvāt na tatra bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that inference is not possible there due to having an opponent.

analyzed: āgamāḥ tu āpteḥ aniścayāt asamarthāḥ eva iti āśayavān pariśeṣam upasaṃharati tat iti
translated: With the intention that the scriptures are indeed incapable due to the uncertainty of the trustworthy person, he concludes the remainder with the word therefore.

original: tattasmānmokṣadaḥ puruṣo dhruvaṃ lokaṃ śāstragamya eva bhavediti yojanā / /
analyzed: tat tasmāt mokṣa daḥ puruṣaḥ dhruvam lokam śāstra gamyaḥ eva bhavet iti yojanā
translated: Therefore, the person who bestows liberation must certainly be known through the scriptures. This is the construction.

analyzed: astu evam tathā api mokṣa da tvena śāstra gamya tvam anyeṣām bhaviṣyati
translated: Even if this is so, the knowability through the scriptures of others will be by the bestowal of liberation.

original: tathā pratibhāsāditi caturthasūtrasya saṅgatiṃ sūcayaṃstattviti padadvayaṃ vyākhyāti śāstreti //
analyzed: tathā pratibhāsāt iti caturtha sūtrasya saṅgatim sūcayan tat tu iti pada dvayam vyākhyāti śāstra iti
translated: Indicating the connection of the fourth aphorism Thus, etc. with that, he explains the two words that and etc. with the words through the scriptures.

analyzed: śāstra gamyaḥ ca na anyaḥ sti mokṣa da tvena keśavāt
translated: And there is none other than Keshava who is known by the scriptures as the giver of liberation.

analyzed: mokṣa da tvena śāstra gamyaḥ ca keśavāt anyaḥ nā asti
translated: And there is none other than Keshava who is known by the scriptures as the giver of liberation.

original: kintu sa eva kuta ityataḥ sautraṃ hetuṃ vyākhyāti mokṣado hīti //
analyzed: kintu saḥ eva kutas iti atas sautram hetum vyākhyāti mokṣa daḥ hi iti
translated: But how is he alone? Therefore, he explains the reason stated in the sutra: For he who gives liberation would be independent.

analyzed: mokṣa daḥ hi svatantraḥ syāt
translated: For he who gives liberation would be independent.

analyzed: svatantraḥ eva hi mokṣa daḥ syāt iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that only an independent person can give liberation.

analyzed: svātantryeṇa samanvayaḥ ca bhagavataḥ eva na anyeṣām
translated: And the connection with independence belongs only to the Lord, not to others.

original: yasya ca pratīyate śrutyādau sa eva bhagavānviṣṇuriti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yasya ca pratīyate śruti ādau saḥ eva bhagavān viṣṇuḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the meaning is that he alone is Lord Vishnu, who is understood in the scriptures and elsewhere.

analyzed: paratantraḥ mokṣa daḥ kin na syāt iti ced
translated: If it is asked how can one who is dependent on another not be the giver of liberation,

original: sa kiṃ svatantramanāśritya svayameva mokṣaṃ dadyāduta svatantramanyamāśritya /
analyzed: sa kim svatantram an āśritya svayam eva mokṣam dadyāt uta svatantram anyam āśritya
translated: would he give liberation himself without depending on an independent [person], or depending on another who is independent?

analyzed: ādye doṣam āha paratantraḥ iti
translated: In the first case, he states the fault: Dependent...

analyzed: paratantraḥ svayam sṛtau
translated: Dependent on another's will.

original: vartamānaḥ kathaṃ śaktaḥ paramokṣāya kevalam // / /d //🔽paratantra eva /
analyzed: vartamānaḥ katham śaktaḥ para mokṣāya kevalam  paratantraḥ eva
translated: How is he able, merely by himself, to liberate others?🔽He is dependent on another alone.

analyzed: kevalam para anapekṣayā
translated: Merely without depending on others.

original: yadyasau svatantramanapekṣyaiva svabhaktamokṣāya śaktaḥ syāttarhi svātmānamapi mocayediti na saṃsārī syādityāśayaḥ /
analyzed: yadi asau svatantram an apekṣya eva sva bhakta mokṣāya śaktaḥ syāt tarhi sva ātmānam api mocayet iti na saṃsārī syāt iti āśayaḥ
translated: The idea is that if He, without depending on another, were able to liberate His devotees, then He would liberate even His own Self, and would not be subject to worldly existence.

analyzed: dvitīyam dūṣayati anyā iti
translated: He refutes the second view with If He.

original: anyāśrayeṇa yadyeṣa dadyānmokṣaṃ sa eva hi /
analyzed: anya āśrayeṇa yadi eṣa dadyāt mokṣam saḥ eva hi
translated: If He, depending on another, were to grant liberation, then

analyzed: tena ananusṛtaḥ mokṣam na dadyāt anya vākyataḥ
translated: He, not followed by that [other], would not grant liberation by the words of another.

original: eṣo 'vāntareśvaro 'nyasya svatantrasya viṣṇorāśrayeṇa svabhaktāya mokṣaṃ dadyāditi🔽yadyucyate tadā sa svatantrastena mumukṣuṇānusṛto 'sevito 'nyasyāvāntareśvarasya
analyzed: eṣaḥ vā antareśvaraḥ nyasya svatantrasya viṣṇoḥ āśrayeṇa sva bhaktāya mokṣam dadyāt iti  yadi ucyate tadā sa svatantraḥ tena mumukṣuṇā anusṛtaḥ sevitaḥ nyasya avāntareśvarasya
translated: If it is said that this subordinate Lord would grant liberation to His devotee depending on another independent Viṣṇu,

original: mama bhaktāya mokṣaṃ dehīti prārthanāvākyamātreṇa mokṣaṃ naiva dadyādityapi sambhāvitameva /
analyzed: mama bhaktāya mokṣam dehi iti prārthanā vākya mātreṇa mokṣam nā eva dadyāt iti api sambhāvitam eva
translated: then it is possible that that independent one, not followed by that seeker of liberation, not served, would not grant liberation merely by the words of a request from another subordinate Lord, Give liberation to my devotee.

original: tathā loke darśanāditi hiśabdaḥ /🔽tataḥ kimityata āha ata iti // /
analyzed: tathā loke darśanāt iti hi śabdaḥ  tatas kim iti atas āha atas iti
translated: Thus it is seen in the world, the word Hi [indicates] that.

analyzed: atas tad artham api sa jñeyaḥ viṣṇuḥ mumukṣibhiḥ
translated: What then? For that reason also, He should be known by those seeking liberation.

analyzed: tad artham api avāntareśvarāt mokṣa prāpti artham api sa svatantraḥ
translated: For that purpose also, for the sake of attaining liberation from the subordinate Lord, that independent one,

analyzed: tathā ca bhagavat jijñāsāyāḥ aparihārya tvāt vayarthā avāntareśvarasya mokṣa da tva kalpanā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the meaning is that, since inquiry into the Lord is unavoidable, it is useless to assume that some other limited Lord gives liberation.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa hetum vyācaṣṭe yam eva iti
translated: He explains the reason in another way, beginning with Yameva.

original: yamevaiṣa iti śrutyā tameveti ca sādaram /
analyzed: yam eva eṣa iti śrutyā tam eva iti ca sādaram
translated: By the scriptural statement Yameva and the respectful Tam eva,

analyzed: śāstra yoni tvam asya eva jñāyate veda vādibhiḥ
translated: It is known by the expounders of the Vedas that He alone is the source of the scriptures.

original: anena yamevaiṣa vṛṇute tena labhya iti śrutimupādatte /
analyzed: anena yam eva eṣa vṛṇute tena labhyaḥ iti śrutim upādatte
translated: By this, the scripture Yameva is referred to.

analyzed: tam eva ca iti śrutyā
translated: And by the scripture Tam eva.

analyzed: tam evam viditvā api mṛtyum eti
translated: Even one who knows Him thus goes to death.

analyzed: iti śrutiḥ anena upāttā
translated: This scripture is referred to by this.

analyzed: na anyaḥ panthāḥ vidyate
translated: There is no other path.

analyzed: iti vākya śeṣeṇa ādaraḥ gamyate
translated: By this continuation of the sentence, respect is understood.

analyzed: mokṣa da tvena śāstra yoni tvam asya viṣṇoḥ eva
translated: The state of being the source of the scriptures belongs to Vishnu alone, by virtue of giving liberation.

original: anena śrutīnāṃ samyak sādaramanvayaḥ samanvaya ityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: anena śrutīnām samyak sādaram anvayaḥ samanvayaḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: By this, it is said that the proper respectful connection of the scriptures is the Samanvaya.

original: nanvetayoḥ śrutyoreṣa iti tamiti ca bhagavānucyata ityetatkutaḥ /
analyzed: nanu etayoḥ śrutyoḥ eṣaḥ iti tam iti ca bhagavān ucyate iti etat kutas
translated: But how is it known that the Lord is referred to by these two scriptures by the words Yameva and Tam?

analyzed: prakaraṇa ādi paryālocanayā tad avadhāraṇam
translated: That is determined by considering the context and other factors.

analyzed: tat idam uktam veda vādibhiḥ iti
translated: This is what is said by the expounders of the Vedas.

analyzed: atra śruti antaram āha yaḥ enam iti
translated: Here he quotes another scripture, beginning with Ya enam.

original: ya enaṃ viduramṛtā / / / // / / //🔽ya enaṃ viduramṛtāste bhavanti' /🔽iti ca śrutyeti pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ /🔽mīmāṃsārthamasyāḥ śruteḥ pṛthaggrahaṇam /🔽atrainamityukto harirityetatkuta ityata āha ityukta iti //🔽ityuktastu samudragaḥ // / / //
analyzed: ye enam viduḥ amṛtāḥ  ye enam viduḥ amṛtāḥ te bhavanti  iti ca śrutyā iti pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ  mīmāṃsā artham asyāḥ śruteḥ pṛthak grahaṇam  atra enam iti uktaḥ hariḥ iti etat kutas iti atas āha iti uktaḥ iti  iti uktaḥ tu samudragaḥ
translated: Those who know this, O Vidura, become immortal.🔽Thus it is said in the Upanishad.🔽The connection is with the previous sentence.🔽This scripture is mentioned separately for the purpose of investigation.🔽Here, the one referred to as this is Hari. This is understood from the following.🔽Thus it is said that he is in the ocean.🔽🔽

original: ya enaṃ viduriti śrutau mokṣahetujñānatvenoktastuyamantaḥ samudre kavayo vayanti' /🔽iti samudraga uktaḥ /🔽tacca harerliṅgamityarthaḥ /🔽pramāṇāntaramāha tadeveti //🔽tadeva brahma paramamiti śrutyāvadhāritaḥ // / / //🔽ityukta iti vartate /🔽tadeva brahma paramaṃ kavīnāmiti' /🔽śrutyā brahmatvenāvadhāritaḥ /🔽etaduktaṃ bhavati /🔽enamityukte brahmapadaśravaṇāttasya ca bhagavannāmatvādbhagavānevāyamiti jñāyate /🔽yadyapi brahmapadasyānyatrāpi vṛttirasti tathāpyamukhyaiva /
analyzed: ye enam viduḥ iti śrutau mokṣa hetu jñāna tvena ukta stuyam antar samudre kavayaḥ vayanti 🔽iti samudra gaḥ uktaḥ 🔽tat ca hareḥ liṅgam iti arthaḥ 🔽pramāṇa antaram āha tat eva iti 🔽tat eva brahma paramam iti śrutyā avadhāritaḥ 🔽iti uktaḥ iti vartate 🔽tat eva brahma paramam kavīnām iti 🔽śrutyā brahma tvena avadhāritaḥ 🔽etat uktam bhavati 🔽enam iti ukte brahma pada śravaṇāt tasya ca bhagavat nāma tvāt bhagavān eva ayam iti jñāyate 🔽yadi api brahma padasya anyatra api vṛttiḥ asti tathā api amukhyā eva
translated: Those who know Him as the one who is to be known in the Upaniṣads, as the one who is to be known in the Vedas, as the one who is to be known in the Purāṇas, as the one who is to be known in the Itihāsas, as the one who is to be known in the Smṛtis, as the one who is to be known in the Āgamas, as the one who is to be known in the Tantras, as the one who is to be known in the Purāṇa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Itihāsa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Smṛti-s, as the one who is to be known in the Āgama-s, as the one who is to be known in the Tantra-s, as the one who is to be known in the Purāṇa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Itihāsa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Smṛti-s, as the one who is to be known in the Āgama-s, as the one who is to be known in the Tantra-s, as the one who is to be known in the Purāṇa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Itihāsa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Smṛti-s, as the one who is to be known in the Āgama-s, as the one who is to be known in the Tantra-s, as the one who is to be known in the Purāṇa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Itihāsa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Smṛti-s, as the one who is to be known in the Āgama-s, as the one who is to be known in the Tantra-s, as the one who is to be known in the Purāṇa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Itihāsa-s, as the one who is to be known in the Smṛti-s, as the one who is to be known in the Āgama-s, as the one who is to be known in the Tantra-s, as the one who is to be known in the Purāṇa-s

analyzed: na ca evam atra śakyate grahītum
translated: And this cannot be understood here in that way.

analyzed: tat eva iti avadhāraṇa virodhāt
translated: Because it contradicts the determination that it is that very [Brahman].

original: idaṃ khalvasya mukhyato brahmatvamācaṣṭe /🔽anyatra brahmaśabdavṛttimātrasya prāmāṇikatvena niṣedhānupapatteriti /
analyzed: idam khalu asya mukhyatas brahmatvam ācaṣṭe  anyatra brahma śabda vṛtti mātrasya prāmāṇika tvena niṣedha anupapatteḥ iti
translated: This indeed declares His Brahmanhood primarily.🔽Because the mere occurrence of the word Brahman elsewhere cannot be denied as being authoritative.

original: yuktyantaramāha yata iti //🔽yataḥ prasūteti tataḥ sṛṣṭimāha / / / // / / //
analyzed: yukti antaram āha yatas iti  yatas prasūtā iti tatas sṛṣṭim āha
translated: He states another reason, saying from which (verse 1).🔽From which He causes to be born - this refers to the creation from that [Brahman].

analyzed: yatas prasūtā jagataḥ prasūtiḥ
translated: The scripture says, From which the creation of the world was born.

analyzed: iti śrutiḥ tatas yaḥ etam iti uktāt mūlaprakṛteḥ sṛṣṭim āha
translated: This refers to the creation from the original Nature mentioned in the passage He who is that Self, the innermost soul of all beings.

analyzed: na ca mūlaprakṛteḥ kāraṇa tvam paramapuruṣāt anyasya sambhavati
translated: And the status of being the cause of the original Nature is not possible for anyone other than the Supreme Person.

analyzed: atas pi ayam bhagavān iti
translated: Therefore, this [Lord] is also [the Supreme Person].

original: etena mokṣādikartṛtvasya śrutatvata ityuktamapi vivṛtaṃ veditavyam / /
analyzed: etena mokṣa ādi kartṛ tvasya śruta tvataḥ iti uktam api vivṛtam veditavyam
translated: By this, it should be understood that even what was stated as because of the mention of being the agent of liberation, etc. has been explained.

analyzed: dvitīyam hetu vyākhyānam upasaṃharati tatas iti
translated: He concludes the second explanation of the reason, saying therefore (verse 2).

analyzed: tatas hariḥ
translated: Therefore, Hari.

analyzed: śāstra yoniḥ na ca anyaḥ sti mukhyatas tu iti gamyate
translated: The source of scripture, and no other, is understood to be primary.

analyzed: mukhyatas iti mokṣa da tvena iti yāvat
translated: Primary means as the giver of liberation.

original: viṣṇorivānyeṣāmapi śāstrayonitvaṃ pratīyata iti yaduktaṃ tatparihārāthartvenāpi sautraṃ hetuṃ vyācaṣṭe śāstreti //
analyzed: viṣṇoḥ iva anyeṣām api śāstra yoni tvam pratīyate iti yat uktam tad parihāra athartvena api sautram hetum vyācaṣṭe śāstra iti
translated: The Sūtra's reason is explained as having the meaning of refuting the statement that, like Viṣṇu, the Vedas are the source of knowledge of other deities.

analyzed: śāstra yoni tvam etasya jñāyate hi samanvayāt
translated: The fact that this (Veda) has the Veda as its source is known from the harmony (of the various parts of the Veda).

analyzed: anvayaḥ upapatti ādi liṅgam
translated: Harmony is the inferential mark such as logical possibility.

original: yato vāco nivartante ityādiśrutibhirbrahmaṇo 'vācyatvamāśaṅkaya vācyatvamīkṣatyadhikaraṇe sādhyate /
analyzed: yatas vācaḥ nivartante ityādi śrutibhiḥ brahmaṇaḥ vācya tvam āśaṅkaya vācya tvam īkṣati adhikaraṇe sādhyate
translated: In the Iṣṭāpūrta adhikaraṇa, it is argued that Brahman is expressible, doubting its inexpressibility stated in the śruti passages beginning with Where speech turns back (Tait. Up. 2.4.1).

analyzed: tat asaṅgatam
translated: That is irrelevant.

analyzed: prāc vācya tāyāḥ anukta tvāt
translated: Because expressibility was not mentioned before.

original: śāstrayonitvasya lakṣaṇādināpi sambhavādityato 'dhikaraṇaṃ saṅgamayituṃ saṃśabdaṃ vyākhyāti samiti //🔽samiti hyupasargeṇa paramukhyāthartocyate // / / //
analyzed: śāstra yoni tvasya lakṣaṇa ādinā api sambhavāt iti atas dhikaraṇam saṅgamayitum saṃśabdam vyākhyāti sam iti  sam iti hi upasargeṇa para mukhyā atha ṛtā ucyate
translated: Because having the Veda as its source is possible even by definition, etc. Therefore, in order to connect the adhikaraṇa, the word sa is explained as sama.🔽For, by the prefix sa, the primary and principal meaning is stated.

analyzed: parama mukhya artha tā ucyate  saṅkoca ipramāṇā
translated: The primary and principal meaning is stated.🔽The reason for the restriction is

analyzed: kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: the absence of a cause.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha evam iti
translated: What follows from that? Therefore it is said evam.

analyzed: evam parama mukhya arthaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ iti śruteḥ
translated: Thus, by the śruti, Nārāyaṇa is the primary and principal meaning.

analyzed: nirdhāraṇāya na aśabdam iti vedapatiḥ jagau
translated: The Lord of the Veda said na to determine (the meaning of the word brahman).

original: evaṃ mokṣādidatvena nārāyaṇaḥ śruteḥ paramamukhyārtha ityasyārthasya nirdhāraṇāyeti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: evam mokṣa ādi da tvena nārāyaṇaḥ śruteḥ parama mukhya arthaḥ iti asya arthasya nirdhāraṇāya iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Thus, the connection is that in order to determine the meaning that Nārāyaṇa is the supreme and primary meaning of the Veda by giving liberation etc.

analyzed: yasmāt sam iti upasargeṇa parama mukhya artha tā ucyate
translated: Because the prefix sam indicates the supreme and primary meaning.

analyzed: evam tasmāt saṅgati sadbhāvāt na aśabdam iti jagau iti vā
translated: Thus, therefore, because of the presence of connection, he said not not by the Veda.

analyzed: atra adhikaraṇe gati sāmānyāt iti sūtram
translated: In this section, the sūtra is gatisaṃyogāt.

analyzed: tad prāgvācyatā samarthana param na bhavati iti na vyākhyātam
translated: It is not explained that it is not intended to support the priority of that.

analyzed: tasya idānīm saṅgatim āha katham iti
translated: Now, he states its connection by saying how.

analyzed: katham samanvayaḥ jñeyaḥ su alpa śākhā vidām nṛṇām
translated: How is the connection to be known by men who know only a few branches?

analyzed: sam śabdaḥ dvayarthaḥ mukhya vṛttyā iti sarva vedānām iti ca
translated: The word sam has two meanings, the primary one and of all the Vedas.

analyzed: tatra
translated: Among them, the second meaning is raised here.

analyzed: atra eva eka adhikaraṇa tvam eṣām sūtrāṇām
translated: Here, these sūtras have the same section.

analyzed: saṃ śabda artha ākṣepa samādhānasya eka tvāt
translated: Because the raising and resolving of the meaning of the word sam is one.

original: upakramādiliṅgairjagajjanmādikāraṇatvena parameśvare sarvavedānāṃ samanvayo na jñātuṃ śakyaḥ /
analyzed: upakrama ādi liṅgaiḥ jagat janma ādi kāraṇa tvena parameśvare sarva vedānām samanvayaḥ na jñātum śakyaḥ
translated: The connection of all the Vedas with the supreme Lord as the cause of the creation etc. of the world cannot be known through the indications such as the introductory passage.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: nṛṇām su alpa āyuḥ prajñā ādimatām su alpa śākhā vedita
translated: Of men with little life, wisdom, etc., who know only a few branches of the Veda,

analyzed: tu asya eva sambhavena sarva veda jñāna asambhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible for anyone to know all the Vedas.

original: vedānāmapi svalpatve śakyata eva tatsamanvayo jñātumasmadādibhirapītyata āha vedā iti //
analyzed: vedānām api su alpa tve śakyate eva tad samanvayaḥ jñātum asmat ādibhiḥ api iti atas āha vedāḥ iti
translated: Even if the Vedas are small, it is possible for us and others to know the meaning of the Vedanta. Therefore it is said: The Vedas.

analyzed: vedāḥ hi anantāḥ iti hi śrutiḥ āha api ananta tām
translated: For the Vedas are endless. Thus the Upanishad declares their endlessness.

analyzed: anantāḥ vai vedāḥ iti śrutim anena upādatte
translated: By this, he accepts the Upanishad that the Vedas are indeed endless.

analyzed: ādyaḥ hi śabdaḥ śrauta vaiśabda arthaḥ
translated: The first word 'hi' means 'as it is said'.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ śruteḥ prasiddha tvam dyotayati
translated: The second illuminates the well-known nature of the Upanishad.

analyzed: apiḥ samuccaye
translated: 'Api' means 'and'.

analyzed: na kevalam puruṣāḥ su alpa veda vidaḥ
translated: Not only are the men knowers of a small part of the Vedas,

analyzed: kintu vedāḥ api anantāḥ iti
translated: but the Vedas are also endless.

analyzed: ananta tā vedānām iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that the Vedas are endless.

original: santu puruṣāḥ svalpavido vedāścānantāstathāpi kathaṃ samanvayajñānamaśakyamityata āha ananteti //🔽anantavedanirṇītirmahāpraḷayavāridheḥ /
analyzed: santu puruṣāḥ su alpa vidaḥ vedāḥ ca anantāḥ tathā api katham samanvaya jñānam aśakyam iti atas āha ananta iti  ananta veda nirṇītiḥ mahā praḷaya vāridheḥ
translated: Let the men be knowers of a small part and the Vedas be endless, even then how is the knowledge of the meaning of the Vedanta impossible? Therefore it is said: The endless.

analyzed: uttāraṇa upamā  su alpa śākhā vidām iti vartate
translated: The ascertainment of the endless Vedas is like the crossing of the great ocean of dissolution.

analyzed: mahā pralaya vāridheḥ uttāraṇa upamā iti gamaka tvāt samāsaḥ
translated: It is like the crossing of the great ocean of dissolution.🔽The remainder is that the men are knowers of a small part of the Vedas.

analyzed: devadattasya guru kulam iti yathā
translated: The compound is based on the suggestive meaning, like Devadatta's gurukula.

original: yo yadvākyaṃ svarūpato na jānāti sa tatropakramādyanusandhāya vākyārthamavadhārayatītyasambhāvitametaditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ yat vākyam svarūpataḥ na jānāti sa tatra upakrama ādi anusandhāya vākya artham avadhārayati iti asambhāvitam etat iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it is not possible that one who does not know the form of a statement should ascertain the meaning of that statement by connecting it with the introduction etc.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: vimatāḥ puruṣāḥ na sarva veda samanvaya jñāna arhāḥ sarva veda ajña tvāt
translated: The persons in question are not worthy of knowing the connection of all the Vedas, because they do not know all the Vedas.

original: yo yadvākyaṃ na jānāti nāsau tatsamanvayamapi jānāti /
analyzed: yaḥ yat vākyam na jānāti na asau tad samanvayam api jānāti
translated: One who does not know a certain statement does not know even its connection.

analyzed: yathā sammataḥ
translated: As is commonly accepted.

original: vimatā na sarvavedavedanārhā alpaprajñādimattvāt yo yadapekṣayālpaprajñādimānnāsau tadveti yathā sammataḥ /
analyzed: vimatāḥ na sarva veda vedanā arhāḥ alpa prajñā ādimat tvāt yaḥ yad apekṣayā alpa prajñā ādimān na asau tat vā iti yathā sammataḥ
translated: The persons in question are not worthy of knowing all the Vedas, because they possess limited wisdom etc., one who possesses limited wisdom etc. in relation to something does not know that. As is commonly accepted.

analyzed: vedāḥ vā na etad puruṣa vedyāḥ
translated: Or, the Vedas are not to be known by these persons.

analyzed: etad prajñā ādi atikrānta tvāt
translated: Because they transcend their wisdom etc.

analyzed: ākṣepam upasaṃharati iti asmāt iti
translated: He concludes the objection with for this reason.

analyzed: iti asmāt na jñeyaḥ samanvayaḥ
translated: For this reason, the connection here should not be known.

original: atra viṣṇau /🔽tataśca śākhāntare pratipādyāntaraśaṅkayā noktārthāvadhāraṇaṃ sambhavatīti bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: atra viṣṇau  tatas ca śākhā antare pratipādya antara śaṅkayā na ukta artha avadhāraṇam sambhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Here, in Vishnu.🔽And therefore, due to the suspicion of another subject taught in another branch, the ascertainment of the meaning stated is not possible. This is the idea.

analyzed: etad parihāra artha tvena sūtram avatārayati iti āśaṅkā iti
translated: In order to answer this, he introduces the sutra with thus, if this is suspected.

analyzed: iti āśaṅkā apanoda artham saḥ āha karuṇākaraḥ
translated: In order to remove this doubt, he, the compassionate one, says:

analyzed: āha gati sāmānyāt iti sūtram iti śeṣaḥ
translated: He says: Because of the common goal, the rest of the sutra.

analyzed: nanu asya sūtrasya kaḥ rthaḥ
translated: But what is the meaning of this sutra?

original: sarvābhiḥ śākhābhirutpādyāyā brahmāvagaterekarūpatvātsarvā api śākhāḥ paramapuruṣamekameva jagajjanmādikāraṇatvenāvagamayantīti na kvacidapya🔽nyathāpratipādanaṃ śaṅkanīyamiti cet /
analyzed: sarvābhiḥ śākhābhiḥ utpādyāyāḥ brahma avagateḥ eka rūpa tvāt sarvāḥ api śākhāḥ paramapuruṣam ekam eva jagat janma ādi kāraṇatvena avagamayanti iti na kvacid api a  nyathā pratipādanam śaṅkanīyam iti ced
translated: Since the understanding of Brahman to be produced by all the branches is of one form, all the branches teach only one supreme person as the cause of the creation etc. of the world. Therefore, in no case should it be suspected that anything is taught differently. If this is argued,

original: nanvetadeva vedānāmanantatvena jñātumaśakyatvādupakramādibhistannirṇayo dūre nirasta ityākṣiptam /
analyzed: nanu etat eva vedānām ananta tvena jñātum aśakya tvāt upakrama ādibhiḥ tad nirṇayaḥ dūre nirastaḥ iti ākṣiptam
translated: is it not objected that this itself is far removed from being determined by the introductory passages etc. because it is impossible to know the Vedas as infinite?

original: punastadevocyata iti kimanena kṛtaṃ syādityataḥ sūtrakṛto 'bhisandhimāha aśakyeti //
analyzed: punar tat eva ucyate iti kim anena kṛtam syāt iti atas sūtrakṛtaḥ abhisandhim āha aśakya iti
translated: If it is stated again, what would be done by this? Therefore, the author of the sutra states his intention with asakya etc.

analyzed: aśakya uttaraṇa tve pi hi āgama apāra vāridheḥ
translated: Even though the ocean of scriptures is impossible to cross,

analyzed: nirṇīyate mayā eva ayam romakūpala yodinā
translated: I alone will determine it with the light of a hair-pore.

analyzed: mad anyaiḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is by others than me.

analyzed: hi śabdena para upanyastam pramāṇam abhyupaiti
translated: The word hi accepts the proof stated by the opponent.

analyzed: uttāraṇam pāra gamanam
translated: Uttaraṇa means to reach the other shore.

analyzed: upakrama ādibhiḥ nirṇayanam iti yāvat
translated: It means to determine by the introductory passages etc.

analyzed: udam udakam asya asti iti udī
translated: She has water above her, thus she is Udi.

analyzed: bhūma vivakṣāyām iniḥ
translated: In the sense of earth, it is Ini.

analyzed: samudraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is ocean.

analyzed: romakūpe yasya asau tathā uktaḥ
translated: He who has dissolution and rise in the pores of his hair is said to be so.

analyzed: pralaya samudra samānaḥ pi vedaḥ madīya jñāne ntarbhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even the Veda, which is like the ocean of dissolution, is included in my knowledge.

analyzed: etat eva vivṛṇoti yadi api iti
translated: He explains this very thing with Although and so on.

analyzed: yadi api aśeṣa veda arthaḥ khila mānavaiḥ  prāpnoti paramāṇu tām
translated: Although the meaning of the entire Veda is difficult to understand for all people,🔽It attains the state of an atom in the unmanifest space of my knowledge.

analyzed: avyākṛta ākāśe paramāṇuḥ iva mad jñāne ntarbhavati
translated: It is included in my knowledge like an atom in unmanifest space.

analyzed: bhūtākāśasya parimita tvāt avyākṛta grahaṇam
translated: The unmanifest is mentioned because the elemental space is limited.

analyzed: vivaraṇa abhāve pūrva śloka uktam kiñcid vyāhatam kiñcid ca asaṅgatam pratīyeta
translated: If there were no explanation, some of what was said in the previous verse would be contradicted and some would be considered irrelevant.

analyzed: abhiprāyam upasaṃharati iti iti  iti prakāśayan viśvapatiḥ āha prameya tām
translated: He concludes the intention with Thus and so on.🔽Thus, revealing the measurability of the entire Veda,

analyzed: nikhilasya api vedasya gati sāmānyam añjasā
translated: The Lord of the universe declares the common path of all.

original: uktaprakāreṇa nikhilyāpi vedasya svenāñjasā prameyatāṃ prakāśayansūcayangatisāmānyamāha na tu nirabhisandhiryenoktadoṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: ukta prakāreṇa vedasya svena añjasā prameya tām prakāśayan sūcayan gati sāmānyam āha na tu nirabhisandhiḥ yena ukta doṣaḥ syāt
translated: Revealing, indicating, the measurability of the entire Veda in the manner stated, he declares the common path, not without intention, lest the aforementioned fault occur.

analyzed: viśvapatiḥ iti sarva veda vid tve pramāṇam
translated: The word Viśvapati is the proof for being a knower of all the Vedas.

analyzed: nahi pālanīyam avidvān pālakaḥ bhavati
translated: For one who does not know what is to be protected cannot be a protector.

analyzed: viśva antargatāḥ ca sarve vedāḥ iti
translated: And all the Vedas are included in the universe.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati sūtrakāreṇa
translated: This is what is said by the author of the aphorisms.

original: sarvavedajñānāsambhavena sarvavedasamanvayajñānaṃ kiṃ mānavādīnāmucyate uta sūtrakarturmama /
analyzed: sarva veda jñāna asambhavena sarva veda samanvaya jñānam kim mānava ādīnām ucyate uta sūtra kartuḥ mama
translated: Is the knowledge of the harmony of all the Vedas stated for human beings etc. due to the impossibility of knowing all the Vedas, or for me, the author of the aphorisms?

analyzed: ādye pi kim
translated: In the first case, is it stated specifically or even generally?

analyzed: ādyaḥ bhyupagamyate eva
translated: The first is accepted.

analyzed: dvitīye tu vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: But in the second we will say.

analyzed: na tṛtīyaḥ
translated: Not the third.

analyzed: mama sarvajña tvena asiddhayā ādi prāpteḥ iti
translated: Because if I were omniscient, it would lead to the fallacy of unestablished conclusion etc.

original: evaṃ cedyadi kaścidanyaḥ sūtrakāravadviṣayāntare gatisāmānyaṃ brūyāttadā punaranirṇaya evetyata āha ko nāmeti //🔽ko nāma gatisāmānyamanantāgamasampadaḥ /
analyzed: evam ced yadi kaścid anyaḥ sūtrakāra vat viṣaya antare gati sāmānyam brūyāt tadā punar anirṇayaḥ eva iti atas āha kaḥ nāma iti  kaḥ nāma gati sāmānyam ananta āgama sampadaḥ
translated: If someone else like the author of the aphorisms were to state the common path in another subject, then there would be uncertainty again. Therefore he says:🔽Who else but that one Bādarāyaṇa,

original: jñānasūryamṛte brūyāt tamekaṃ bādarāyaṇam // / / //🔽jñānena sūyar iva jñānasūryaḥ /
analyzed: jñānasūryam ṛte brūyāt tam ekam bādarāyaṇam  jñānena sūyar iva jñāna sūryaḥ
translated: the sun of knowledge, could state the common path of infinite scriptural wealth?🔽The sun of knowledge is like the sun in knowledge.

original: yathā sūryaḥ svatejasā viśvasya prakāśakastathāyaṃ jñāneneti /
analyzed: yathā sūryaḥ sva tejasā viśvasya prakāśakaḥ tathā ayam jñānena iti
translated: Just as the sun illuminates the universe with its own radiance, so does this one with knowledge.

original: vinā vātam' / ityādiprayogadarśanādvināyoga iva ṛte 'pi dvitīyā bhavatyeva /
analyzed: vinā vātam ityādi prayoga darśanāt vinā ayoge iva ṛte dvitīyā bhavati eva
translated: The instrumental case is used even with the word ṛte, as in the usage vinā vātam, etc.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.🔽Would the omniscient one speak of a general motion that is contrary?

analyzed: kim sarvajñaḥ viparītam gati sāmānyam brūyāt  uta aparaḥ
translated: Or another?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: sarvajña uktyoḥ virodha ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible for the statements of an omniscient being to contradict each other.

analyzed: yoge vā dvayoḥ sārvajña anupapatteḥ
translated: Or if it were possible, then the existence of two omniscient beings would be impossible.

analyzed: dvitīye sampratipanna sarvajña sūtra kāra vacana virodhāt mithyādṛṣṭiḥ vā apratārakaḥ vā asau syāt iti katham anirṇayaḥ iti
translated: In the second case, he would either be one who has false views or a deceiver, because of contradicting the words of the author of the sutra who is accepted as omniscient. So how can there be no definite conclusion?

analyzed: astu bhagavataḥ sarvajña tvena gati sāmānya jñānam
translated: Let it be that the Blessed One knows the general motion by his omniscience.

original: parasya tu kathaṃ yadarthamidaṃ śāstramityataḥ sūtrasyārthāntaramāha anyo 'ṣīti //
analyzed: parasya tu katham yad artham idam śāstram iti atas sūtrasya artha antaram āha
translated: But how about others, for whose sake this treatise is? Therefore, he states another meaning of the sutra: Other...

analyzed: śākhā catuṣpañca gatam vasu
translated: Even another person of limited intellect, knowing the wealth contained in four or five branches,

analyzed: jānan na anumita tvena brūyāt tasya prasādataḥ
translated: could speak of the general motion by inference, through his grace.

original: alpamatirapyanyastasya prasādataḥ śākhācatuṣpañcagataṃ vasu jānannanumitatvenānantāgamasampado gatisāmānyaṃ brūyāditi yojanā /
analyzed: alpa matiḥ api anyaḥ tasya prasādataḥ śākhā catuṣpañca gatam vasu jānan anumita tvena ananta āgama sampadaḥ gati sāmānyam brūyāt iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: Even another person of limited intellect, knowing the wealth contained in four or five branches, could speak of the general motion of the infinite scriptures by inference, through his grace.

analyzed: yāsām śākhānām udāharaṇena sūtrakṛtā parameśvara samanvayaḥ bhihitaḥ tat dṛṣṭāntīkṛtya
translated: The author of the aphorisms has stated the agreement with the Supreme Lord by an example of those branches. Taking that as an example,

analyzed: śākhā tvāt vipratipanna śākhānām api tad paratva anumāna sambhavāt anyeṣām api gati sāmānya jñānam yuktam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: it is reasonable to know the general conclusion of others also, because it is possible to infer that the branches in dispute also have that as their purport, because they have the nature of being branches.

analyzed: anena gati sāmānya anumānāt iti sūtram vyākhyātam iti
translated: The meaning is that the aphorism by the inference of the general conclusion is explained by this.

analyzed: nanu catuṣpañca śākhā gatam iti vaktavyam
translated: But it should be said contained in four or five branches.

analyzed: taddhita artha uttara pada samāhāre ca iti saṅkhayāyāḥ upasarjana tvāt
translated: Because number is subordinate in a compound consisting of a word ending in a taddhita affix and a word denoting a collection.

analyzed: kaḍārāḥ karmadhārayaḥ iti upasarjanasya para nipātaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: The subordinate word will be placed after the other in a tatpurusa compound.

analyzed: varga arthau vā catuṣpañca śabdau
translated: Or the words four and five denote a class.

analyzed: prapañcaḥ yadi vidyeta iti yathā
translated: Just as in if the elaborations exist.
