analyzed: idam eva astu sūtra vyākhyānam śrotṛ pratyāyana aṅga tvāt
translated: Let this alone be the explanation of the aphorism, because it is a means of conveying knowledge to the listener.

analyzed: na pūrvam
translated: Not the former.

analyzed: śaṅkā nirāsa ahetu tvāt
translated: Because it is not a means of removing doubt.

original: na hi sūtrakāraḥ sarvajñatvāt sarvavedagatagatisāmānyaṃ vettītyetāvatānyeṣāṃ śaṅkā nivartata ityata āha iti mukhyatayeti //
analyzed: na hi sūtrakāraḥ sarvajña tvāt sarva veda gata gati sāmānyam vetti iti etāvatā anyeṣām śaṅkā nivartate iti atas āha iti mukhya tayā iti
translated: For the author of the aphorisms, knowing only this much, the doubt of others does not cease, that he knows the general conclusion contained in all the Vedas because he is omniscient. Therefore he says as the primary meaning.

analyzed: iti mukhya tayā aśeṣa gati sāmānya vid prabhuḥ
translated: Thus, the Lord, who knows the common meaning of all the scriptures primarily,

analyzed: pratijajñe dṛḍham yasmāt devānām api pūryate
translated: firmly promised, and even the doubts of the gods are removed.

analyzed: iti pratijajñe iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: Thus, he promised.

analyzed: mukhya tayā iti anumāna ādinā vinā aśeṣa veda gati sāmānya vid
translated: Primarily means knowing the common meaning of all the scriptures without inference etc.

analyzed: devānām iti uttama adhikāriṇām
translated: Of the gods means of the best qualified.

analyzed: apiḥ padārthe
translated: Even means in reality.

analyzed: śaṅkā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: doubt.

analyzed: madhunā u pi syāt iti yathā
translated: As in it would be of honey also.

analyzed: pūryate nivāryate
translated: Is removed means is warded off.

original: ye sūtrakārasya paramāptatvaṃ jānantyuttamādhikāristeṣāṃ tadīyapratimāmātreṇa śaṅkā nivartata eveti tānprati pūrvavyākhyānam /
analyzed: ye sūtrakārasya parama āpta tvam jānanti uttama adhikāriḥ teṣām tadīya pratimā mātreṇa śaṅkā nivartate eva iti tān prati pūrva vyākhyānam
translated: For those who know the author of the sutras to be supremely trustworthy, the best qualified, their doubt is removed merely by his promise. For them, the previous explanation is given.

analyzed: anyān prati tu dvitīyam
translated: But for others, the second one.

original: tathā bhāṣyoktaṃ gatisāmānyaśruteriti tṛtīyaṃ ceti bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: tathā bhāṣya uktam gati sāmānya śruteḥ iti tṛtīyam ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the third is the statement of the common meaning of the scriptures as stated in the commentary. This is the idea.

original: nanvanayā pañcādhikaraṇyā vaktavyasyoktvatvātkimadhyāyaśeṣeṇetyataḥ prapañcyaprapañcanarūpāṃ saṅgatiṃ darśayannāha ata iti //
analyzed: nanu anayā pañca adhikaraṇyā vaktavyasya uktvā tvāt kim adhyāya śeṣeṇa iti atas prapañcya prapañcana rūpām saṅgatim darśayan āha atas iti
translated: But since what is to be stated by this fifth section has been stated, what is the use of the rest of the chapter? With this question in mind, showing the connection in the form of elaboration and what is to be elaborated, he says therefore etc.

analyzed: atas nikhila vedānām siddhaḥ evam samanvayaḥ
translated: Therefore, the reconciliation of all the Vedas is thus established.

analyzed: iti pṛthak ca āha samanvayam
translated: Thus, even though the meaning has been well explained, he separately states the connection.

analyzed: atīta prabandhena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is by a past series.

analyzed: pṛthak vistareṇa adhyāya śeṣeṇa iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that it is separately in detail by the rest of the chapter.

original: tatra prathamapāde anyatra prasiddhānāṃ śabdānāṃ samanvayo 'bhidhīyate /🔽dvitīye 'nyatra prasiddhānāṃ liṅgātmakānām /
analyzed: tatra prathama pāde anyatra prasiddhānām śabdānām samanvayaḥ abhidhīyate  dvitīye ni atra prasiddhānām liṅga ātmakānām
translated: There, in the first section, the connection of words well-known elsewhere is stated.🔽In the second, of those having the nature of indications well-known elsewhere.

analyzed: tṛtīye tatra anyatra prasiddhānām ubhaya rūpāṇām
translated: In the third, of those having both forms well-known there and elsewhere.

analyzed: caturthe nyatra eva prasiddhānām iti uktam
translated: In the fourth, of those well-known only elsewhere, it is said.

analyzed: tam etam kramam upapādayan āha tatra iti
translated: Explaining that order, he says there and so on.

analyzed: tatra prathamatas nyatra prasiddhānām samanvayaḥ
translated: There, first, the connection of words well-known elsewhere is stated.

analyzed: śabdānām vācyaḥ evā atra mahā mat leśa bhaṅga vat
translated: Of the words, the connection is stated only in the denotation, like the breaking of a great wrestler.

analyzed: tatra prathama adhyāye
translated: There, in the first chapter.

analyzed: prathama pāde
translated: In the first section.

analyzed: śabdānām nāma ātmakānām
translated: Of the words having the nature of names.

analyzed: atra viṣṇau
translated: Here, in Vishnu.

analyzed: mahā mad leśa bhaṅgena tulyam vartate iti tathā
translated: It proceeds like the breaking of a great wrestler, thus.

original: yathānekeṣu malleṣu pratyarthitayāvasthiteṣvapi bhagavatā kṛṣṇena pradhānatvāccāṇūrādimallānāmevādau bhaṅgo vihitastathetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā anekeṣu malleṣu pratyarthitayā avasthiteṣu api bhagavatā kṛṣṇena pradhāna tvāt cāṇūra ādi mallānām eva ādau bhaṅgaḥ vihitaḥ tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as, when many wrestlers are present as opponents, but Krishna, being the chief, first defeated the wrestlers such as Chānūra and others.

original: ubhayatra prasiddhānāṃ hi śabdānāṃ samanvaye 'nyatraprasiddhinivāraṇamātre yatno vidheyaḥ /
analyzed: ubhayatra prasiddhānām hi śabdānām samanvaye nyatra prasiddhi nivāraṇa mātre yatnaḥ vidheyaḥ
translated: For in the case of words well-known in both senses, effort should be made only to preclude their application elsewhere.

analyzed: anyatra prasiddhānām tu bhagavati prasiddhiḥ api upapādanīyā iti
translated: But in the case of those well-known elsewhere, their application to the Lord also has to be established.

analyzed: tatas eteṣām prādhānyam
translated: Therefore, these are primary.

analyzed: liṅga ātmakaḥ ca dharma vacanāḥ vyavadhānena anya buddhim janayanti
translated: And the statements of attributes, being in the form of indications, produce the understanding of something else through intervention.

original: nāmātmakāstu sattvavacanāḥ sākṣādeveti tatsamanvaye yatnagauravamastīti liṅgātmakebhyo nāmātmakānāṃ prādhānyamiti / /
analyzed: nāma ātmakāḥ tu sattva vacanāḥ sākṣāt eva iti tad samanvaye yatna gauravam asti iti liṅga ātmakebhyaḥ nāma ātmakānām prādhānyam iti
translated: But the statements of existence, being in the form of names, do so directly. Therefore, there is the gravity of effort in their application. Thus, the statements in the form of names are primary to those in the form of indications.

original: yadi prādhānyādanyatra prasiddhānāṃ nāmātmakānāṃ śabdānāṃ samanvayaḥ prathamapāde
analyzed: yadi prādhānyāt anyatra prasiddhānām nāma ātmakānām śabdānām samanvayaḥ prathama pāde
translated: If the application of the statements in the form of names, which are well-known elsewhere, were to be stated first in the first chapter due to their primacy,

original: vaktavyaḥ syāttadā caturthaṣādoditasyānyatraiva prasiddhānāṃ śabdānāṃ samanvayasyeto
analyzed: vaktavyaḥ syāt tadā caturtha sāda uditasya anyatra eva prasiddhānām śabdānām samanvayasya itas
translated: then the application of the statements well-known elsewhere, stated in the fourth chapter, would be primary and should come first,

analyzed: pi prādhānyāt prāthamyam bhavet
translated: because of its primacy.

original: anyatra prasiddheranyatraiva prasiddhirbalīyasītyata āha ita iti //
analyzed: anyatra prasiddheḥ anyatra eva prasiddhiḥ balīyasī iti atas āha itas iti
translated: Because the well-known meaning in one place is stronger than the well-known meaning elsewhere, he says 'from here'.

analyzed: i taḥ t yabhyadhika tve turya pāda uditasya tu  turya pāda uditasya
translated: Even though it is more excellent than that stated in the fourth section,

analyzed: pi abhyadhika tve pi asau atra adhyāye prāthamyena nā eva uditaḥ iti sambandhaḥ
translated: even though the harmony stated in the fourth section is more excellent than that, it is not stated here in this chapter as the first, this is the connection.

analyzed: tat tu samanvayāt iti saṅkṣepeṇa tasya api atra ukta tvāt añjasā iti uktam
translated: But that is stated here in brief as 'easily' because it is stated here in brief as 'from that harmony'.

analyzed: kutas na uditaḥ utsargasya apavāda viśeṣa sadbhāvāt iti tuśabdaḥ
translated: From where is it not stated? Because there is a special exception to the general rule, the word 'but' is used.

analyzed: tam eva apavāda hetum darśayati mahā samanvayaḥ iti
translated: He shows that very reason for the exception, saying 'the great harmony'.

analyzed: mahā samanvaye tasmin na adhikāraḥ khilasya hi
translated: In that great harmony, all are not entitled,

analyzed: brahmā eva adhikṛtaḥ tatra mukhyatas nye yathākramam  durgama tvāt ca nā evā atra prāthamyena uditaḥ ñjasā
translated: Brahman alone is primarily entitled there, others in order.🔽And because it is difficult to understand, it is not stated here as the first in an easy way.

analyzed: tarhi na vaktavyaḥ eva niradhikārika tvāt
translated: Then it should not be stated at all because it is not for anyone.

original: nahi gāyamāno badhireṣu gāyatītyata uktaṃ brahmaiveti /
analyzed: nahi gāyamānaḥ badhireṣu gāyati iti atas uktam brahma eva iti
translated: For one does not sing among the deaf. Therefore it is said 'Brahman alone'.

analyzed: na aikādhikārikam śāstram iti atas nyaḥ ityādi uktam
translated: The scripture is not for one alone. Therefore 'others' etc. is said.

analyzed: sarva adhikāri sādhāraṇam artham ādau abhidhāya asādhāraṇam paścāt vakṣyāmi iti āśayaḥ sūtrakārasya
translated: The intention of the author of the aphorisms is that having first stated the common purpose of all, he will later speak of the uncommon one.

analyzed: tatra sādhāraṇe tu idam tāratamyam cintitam iti
translated: There, this gradation is considered in the common one.

analyzed: durgama tvāt ca iti hetvantaram
translated: And because it is difficult to understand - this is another reason.

analyzed: prathamam buddhau anārohāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because it does not first ascend to the intellect.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: brahma ādīnām eva tatra yadi api mukhya adhikāri tā
translated: Although Brahman and others indeed have the primary right to that,

analyzed: tathā api asmat ādīnām īṣat adhikāraḥ sti eva
translated: nevertheless, we and others do have some right.

analyzed: na ca mandānām asau samanvayaḥ prathamam buddhim adhirohati
translated: And that agreement of the dull-witted does not first ascend to the intellect.

original: sādhāraṇasamanvayajñānena vaidikavyutpattyanuraktā tu buddhiḥ krameṇa tatrāpyavataratīti /
analyzed: sādhāraṇa samanvaya jñānena vaidika vyutpatti anuraktā tu buddhiḥ krameṇa tatra api avatarati iti
translated: But the intellect, attracted by the knowledge of the common agreement and by the understanding of the Vedas, gradually enters there also.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha atas iti
translated: What then? To this he says 'ataḥ' (therefore).

analyzed: atas nyatra prasiddhānām śabdānām nirṇayāya tu
translated: Therefore, for the determination of words well-known elsewhere,

analyzed: pravṛttaḥ prathamam devaḥ
translated: the Lord has first engaged in...

analyzed: prādhānyāt atiprādhānya anyasya upapādita tvāt ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because of primacy and because of its being well-established.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word 'tu' (but) is for emphasis.

analyzed: tatra ānanda maya adhikaraṇasya ādya tve hetum sūcayan āha tatra iti
translated: There, indicating the reason for the first position of the section on the bliss-filled one, he says there (in the commentary).

analyzed: tatra ānanda ādayaḥ guṇāḥ
translated: There, bliss and so on are qualities.

analyzed: īśasya eva iti nirṇītāḥ śruti yukti samāśrayāt
translated: Of the Lord alone, it is determined, based on scripture and reasoning.

analyzed: tatra samanvaya prapañcane
translated: There, in the elaboration of the connection (of all things with the Supreme Self),

analyzed: prathamam iti anuvartate
translated: first is continued.

analyzed: sarveṣu hi śubheṣu mūrdha abhiṣiktāḥ ānanda vijñāna ādayaḥ
translated: For all auspicious things, bliss, consciousness, and so on are the chief ones.

analyzed: atas māṅgalikam ācāryaḥ tad śabda samanvayam ādau āha iti
translated: Therefore, the teacher, as auspicious, first mentions the connection with that word.

original: antaradhikaraṇasyākāśādhikaraṇasya cānandamayādhikaraṇasaṅgatatve samāne kutaḥ krama ityatastatra hetuṃ sūcayannantaradhikaraṇatātparyamāha
analyzed: antar adhikaraṇasya ākāśa adhikaraṇasya ca ānandamaya adhikaraṇa saṅga tatve samāne kutas kramaḥ iti atas tatra hetum sūcayan antar adhikaraṇa tātparyam āha
translated: When the section on the inner self and the section on space are equally connected with the section on the bliss-filled one, why is there this order? Therefore, indicating the reason there, he states the purpose of the section on the inner self:

analyzed: devatā iti
translated: The deities (in the commentary).

analyzed: devatā antara gāḥ sarve śabda vṛtti nimittataḥ
translated: All the deities, due to the basis of the occurrence of the words,

analyzed: viṣṇum eva vadanti addhā
translated: certainly speak of Vishnu alone.

analyzed: devatāḥ khalu jaḍebhyaḥ mukhyāḥ
translated: The deities are indeed superior to the insentient ones.

analyzed: atas tad vācinām ākāśa ādi jaḍa vācibhyaḥ utkarṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, those denoting them are superior to those denoting the insentient space and so on.

analyzed: sarve śabdāḥ addhā vacana vṛttyā eva na upacāreṇa
translated: All the words certainly speak only by the mode of statement, not figuratively.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: śabda vṛttyoḥ yoga rūḍhyoḥ nimittānām bahula prayoga ādīnām harau vidyamāna tvāt
translated: Because the reasons for the application of words, such as frequent usage, are present in Hari, in the case of both primary and secondary meanings.

analyzed: tat kim anyatra śabdānām vṛttiḥ eva na asti
translated: Then, is there no application of words to anything else?

analyzed: yena viṣṇum eva iti avadhāryate iti atas āha tad saṅgāt iti
translated: By which it is determined that it refers only to Vishnu. Therefore he says due to its association etc.

analyzed: tad saṅgāt upacārataḥ
translated: Due to its association, figuratively...

analyzed: anya devān vadanti iha viśeṣa guṇa vaktṛtaḥ
translated: Here they speak of other gods due to speaking of specific qualities.

analyzed: viṣṇum eva param brūyuḥ
translated: They would speak of Vishnu alone as supreme...

analyzed: upacāra prakāraḥ ca prāk eva vivṛtaḥ
translated: And the manner of figurative usage has already been explained.

original: akṣādiśabdavadubhayatra sāmyena pravṛttiḥ kiṃ na syādityata āha iheti //
analyzed: akṣa ādi śabda vat ubhayatra sāmyena pravṛttiḥ kim na syāt iti atas āha iha iti
translated: Why should not the application be equal in both cases, like the word dice etc.? To this he says here etc.

analyzed: indra ādi śabdāḥ hi parama aiśvarya ādi guṇān vadati
translated: For the words Indra etc. speak of qualities such as supreme lordship.

original: te ca bhagavata evāsādhāraṇā iti tameva paraṃ mukhyaṃ brūyuḥ /
analyzed: te ca bhagavataḥ eva asādhāraṇāḥ iti tam eva param mukhyam brūyuḥ
translated: And those are not common to anyone else but the Lord. Therefore they would speak of him alone as supreme and primary.

analyzed: iha devatā antare
translated: Here, among the other gods.

analyzed: tathā na iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is not so.

original: yadvā iha deveṣu tatsaṅgāditi pūrvatra sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: yat vai iha deveṣu tat saṅgāt iti pūrvatra sambandhaḥ
translated: Or, the connection in the previous sentence is here among the gods, due to its association.

analyzed: rūḍhi nimitta atiśayasya api etat upalakṣaṇam
translated: This is also a metonym for the excess of primary meaning.

analyzed: uttara adhikaraṇeṣu api evam krama nimitta ādikam svayam ūhanīyam iti āśayavān āha evam iti
translated: With the intention that the order, reason etc. should be understood by oneself in the subsequent sections also, he says thus etc.

analyzed: evam anye pi aśeṣatas
translated: In the same way, all the others without exception.

analyzed: viṣṇum eva param brūyuḥ iti vartate
translated: The continuation is: They should declare Vishnu alone as supreme.

original: anyatra prasiddhānāṃ nāmātmakānāṃ śabdānāmanantatvātkathaṃ pādaparisamāptirityāśaṅkāṃ nirākurvanprathamapādārthamanūdya dvitīyapādasya saṅgatimāha
analyzed: anyatra prasiddhānām nāma ātmakānām śabdānām ananta tvāt katham pāda parisamāptiḥ iti āśaṅkām nirākurvan prathama pāda artham anūdya dvitīya pādasya saṅgatim āha  /
translated: Since the names and words well-known elsewhere are infinite, how can the first section be completed? Disposing of this doubt, he mentions the topic of the first section and connects it with the second section.

analyzed: iti anyatra iti  iti anyatra prasiddha uru śabdarāśeḥ aśeṣatas
translated: Thus, he says elsewhere.🔽Thus, having fully understood the connection of the multitude of words well-known elsewhere,

analyzed: jñāte samanvaye viṣṇau liṅgaiḥ hi eṣa samanvayaḥ
translated: this connection is indeed with Vishnu through the indications.

original: teṣāmanyagatatve tu na syāt samyak samanvayaḥ /
analyzed: teṣām anya gata tve tu na syāt samyak samanvayaḥ
translated: But if they belong to something else, there would not be a proper connection.

analyzed: iti eva aśeṣa liṅgānām brahmaṇi eva samanvayam
translated: Thus, he says that the connection of all the indications is indeed only with Brahman.

analyzed: āha
translated: He says.

analyzed: samāna nyāya sañcāra viṣaya tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the topic is the same, and the reasoning is applicable.

analyzed: jñāte prathama pādena
translated: Having been known through the first section.

analyzed: śaṅkā jāyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that doubt arises.

analyzed: katham iti
translated: How?

analyzed: prāyeṇa liṅga balena hi eṣa nāma ātmaka śabda samanvayaḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: For the most part, this connection of words consisting of names has been stated through the power of indications.

analyzed: liṅgānām ca anya gata tvam pratīyate
translated: And it is understood that the indications belong to something else.

original: tataśca viruddhatavāttaiḥ pratītaḥ samanvayaḥ samyaṅ na syādeva /
analyzed: tatas ca viruddha tavāt taiḥ pratītaḥ samanvayaḥ samyak na syāt eva
translated: And therefore, the connection that has been understood through them would not be proper at all, due to contradiction.

analyzed: nahi kṛtaka tvena nitya tva jñānam samyak utpadyate
translated: For the knowledge of eternality by the quality of being produced does not arise correctly.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ śaṅkā samāptau
translated: The word iti (thus) is at the end of the doubt.

analyzed: tad parihārāya anyatra prasiddhānām aśeṣa liṅgānām
translated: For the removal of that, of all the indications well-known elsewhere,

analyzed: āha dvitīya pāde
translated: it is said in the second section.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi yāni antastaddharmopadeśādityādau samudrāntasthatvādīni liṅgāni sādhanatvenoktāni teṣāmiha vicāraḥ karaṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi yāni antar tad dharma upadeśāt ityādau samudra anta stha tva ādīni liṅgāni sādhana tvena uktāni teṣām iha vicāraḥ karaṇīyaḥ
translated: If so, then the indications such as being within the ocean, etc., which are stated as proofs in the passage beginning with because of the teaching of His attributes within, should be considered here.

original: na caivam /🔽kintu yānyuktāni na tāni vicāryante /
analyzed: na ca evam  kintu yāni uktāni na tāni vicāryante
translated: But it is not so.🔽Rather, those that are stated are not considered.

analyzed: yāni ca vicāryante na tāni aktāni
translated: And those that are considered are not stated.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: sarvaśrutigatāḥ sarve 'pyanyatra prasiddhāḥ nāmātmakāḥ śabdā bhagavadviṣayā eva tatra tatra śrutaiḥ sarvairliṅgairiti hi prathamapādasyārthaḥ
analyzed: sarva śruti gatāḥ sarve pi anyatra prasiddhāḥ nāma ātmakāḥ śabdāḥ bhagavat viṣayāḥ eva tatra tatra śrutaiḥ sarvaiḥ liṅgaiḥ iti hi prathama pādasya arthaḥ
translated: All the words that occur in all the scriptures, which are well-known elsewhere, and which have names as their essence, are indeed about the Lord, by all the indications heard here and there. This is the meaning of the first section.

original: tatra yāni liṅgānyasandigdhāni tāni vihāyetarāṇi vicāryanta iti ko virodhaḥ /
analyzed: tatra yāni liṅgāni asandigdhāni tāni vihāya itarāṇi vicāryante iti kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: There, leaving aside the non-doubtful indications, the others are considered. What is the contradiction?

analyzed: atas eva aśeṣatas iti uktam prāk
translated: For this very reason, in entirety was said before.

analyzed: tṛtīya pada asya prathama dvitīyābhyām saṅgatim āha ubhaya iti
translated: He states the connection of the third section with the first and second by saying both and so on.

analyzed: ubhaya gata tvam ca syāt atas liṅga śabdayoḥ
translated: And there would be the presence of both, therefore of the indicative and the word.

analyzed: iti saṃśaya nutti artham
translated: Thus, for the purpose of removing doubt, etc., etc.
The subject matter of the indicative and the word is the Lord and others.

analyzed: atas nyatra prasiddhānām bhagavat para tvasya samarthanam
translated: Therefore, the establishment of the supremacy of the Lord over those well-known elsewhere.

analyzed: liṅga ātmakānām ca śabdānām
translated: And of the words having the nature of indicatives.

original: nanvanyavācitvanirāso 'pi tatraiva netara ityādinā vihita eva /
analyzed: nanu anya vāci tva nirāsaḥ api tatra eva na itaraḥ ityādinā vihitaḥ eva
translated: But the denial of the denotation of others is also done there itself by not that and so on.

analyzed: tat katham śaṅkā udayaḥ
translated: Then how is the doubt raised?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

original: anyatra tātparyābhāvo hi netara ityādinā darśitaḥ /
analyzed: anyatra tātparya abhāvaḥ hi na itaraḥ ityādinā darśitaḥ
translated: The absence of purport elsewhere is shown by not that and so on.

analyzed: śaktiḥ tu ubhayatra syāt eva
translated: But the power may be present in both.

analyzed: tarhi te eva punar vicāryāḥ
translated: Then those very [passages] should be considered again.

analyzed: satmay
translated: That is true.

analyzed: teṣu eva yatra yatra vicāya prāptiḥ te vicāryante
translated: Those very [passages] are considered where the doubt arises.

original: yadā yatrānupapattyādīnāṃ sañcāraḥ sugamastanvihāyānyatrobhayagatatvaṃ śaṅketaiveti yuktamuktam /
analyzed: yadā yatra anupapatti ādīnām sañcāraḥ sugamaḥ tan vihāya anyatra ubhaya gata tvam śaṅketa eva iti yuktam uktam
translated: When the transference of inconsistency and so on is easily understood there, the presence of both elsewhere should be suspected. Thus it is rightly said.

analyzed: tathā ca tat tu iti avadhāraṇa anupapattiḥ iti śaṅkā śeṣaḥ
translated: And thus the remainder of the doubt is that the restriction by that is not proper.

analyzed: iti āśaṅkā nivṛtti artham tṛtīya pādam ārabdhavān iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that the third section was begun for the purpose of removing that doubt.

analyzed: iti āha iti vakṣyamāṇena vā sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with what is to be said, thus he said.

analyzed: katham iyam āśaṅkā tṛtīye parihṛtā iti atas tātparyam āha ubhayatra iti
translated: How is this doubt removed in the third chapter? Therefore, the purport is stated as follows:

analyzed: ubhayatra pratītitaḥ
translated: In both cases, due to cognition...

analyzed: śabdānām vartamānānām sa liṅgānām viśeṣataḥ
translated: Of the present words, especially those with gender,

analyzed: samanvayaḥ harau eva
translated: The correspondence is only in Hari...

analyzed: harau tad itaratra ca
translated: In Hari and elsewhere,

original: pratītito na tu vastuto vartamānānāṃ saliṅgānāṃ śabdānāṃ nāmnāṃ liṅgānāṃ ca harāveva viśeṣataḥ paramamukhyayā vṛttyā tātparyeṇa ca samanvayaḥ
analyzed: pratītitaḥ na tu vastutas vartamānānām sa liṅgānām śabdānām nāmnām liṅgānām ca harau eva viśeṣataḥ parama mukhyayā vṛttyā tātparyeṇa ca samanvayaḥ
translated: The correspondence of the present words, names, and genders, not in reality, but due to cognition, is only in Hari, with the highest primary meaning and purport.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha yat iti
translated: Why is it so? Therefore it is said:

analyzed: yat na eva anyatra mukhyatas
translated: Because it is not primary elsewhere...

analyzed: śabdāḥ liṅgāni ca
translated: The words and genders...

analyzed: yadi asmāt vartate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is because it exists.

original: etadapi kuta ityata āha yata iti //
analyzed: etat api kutas iti atas āha yatas iti
translated: Why is this so? Therefore it is said: because...

analyzed: yatas na eva anyatra svatantra tā
translated: Because there is no independence elsewhere...

original: svatantratāstīti śeṣaḥ /🔽svātantryābhāve 'pi kuto 'nyatra śabdānāṃ mukhyavṛttyabhāva ityata āha asvatantreṣviti //
analyzed: svatantra tā asti iti śeṣaḥ  svātantrya abhāve pi kutas nyatra śabdānām mukhya vṛtti abhāvaḥ iti atas āha asvatantreṣu iti
translated: The remainder is there is independence.🔽Even in the absence of independence, why is there no primary usage of words elsewhere? Therefore it is said: in the non-independent...

analyzed: asvatantreṣu śabdasya vṛtti hetuḥ na mukhyatas
translated: The usage of words in the non-independent is not the cause of the primary...

analyzed: ya taḥ taḥ  /
translated: Therefore, from that...

original: nanvanyeṣāmasvatantratvātteṣu mukhyataḥ śabdapravṛttihetorguṇāderabhāvānmukhyataḥ śabdā na vartanta iti cet /
analyzed: nanu anyeṣām asvatantra tvāt teṣu mukhyatas śabda pravṛtti hetoḥ guṇa ādeḥ abhāvāt mukhyatas śabdāḥ na vartante iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the words do not primarily apply to others because the quality, which is the primary cause of the application of words, is absent in them due to their dependence on something else,

analyzed: mā vartiṣata
translated: let them not apply.

original: tathāpi viśeṣataḥ samanvayo harāvevetyetatkuta ityata āha ata iti //
analyzed: tathā api viśeṣataḥ samanvayaḥ harau eva iti etat kutas iti atas āha atas iti
translated: Even so, how is it known that the primary application is only to Hari? To this he says 'ataḥ' (therefore).

analyzed: itarasya mukhya artha tva abhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because the other does not have the primary meaning.

analyzed: bhāvyam khalu śabdasya mukhya arthena
translated: Indeed, the primary meaning of a word must be accepted.

analyzed: anyathā tad apekṣasya amukhyasya anupapatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, the secondary meaning, which depends on it, would not be possible.

analyzed: tathā ca dvayoḥ prasaktayoḥ ekasya mukhya artha tva anupapattau itarasya mukhya artha tvam āvaśyakam eva
translated: And thus, when one of the two possible meanings is not possible as the primary meaning, the other must necessarily be the primary meaning.

analyzed: yad adhīnāḥ te ityādinā yukti antaram āha
translated: With the words 'yadadhīnāḥ' etc., he states another reason.

analyzed: yad adhīnāḥ te śabda artha tvam upāgatāḥ
translated: Those [words] have come to be the meanings of words,

original: atyalpenaiva śabdasya vṛttihetuguṇena tu // / /d //🔽ayo yathā dāhakatvaṃ sa eveśaḥ svatantrataḥ /
analyzed: ati alpena eva śabdasya vṛtti hetu guṇena tu  ayaḥ yathā dāhaka tvam saḥ evā īśaḥ svatantrataḥ
translated: but only with a very small cause of the application of the word.

analyzed: mukhya śabda arthaḥ iti hi svīkartavyaḥ manīṣibhiḥ
translated: Just as fire has the quality of burning, that Lord alone is the primary meaning of the word, due to His independence. This must be accepted by the wise.

analyzed: iti āha
translated: Thus it is said...

original: te bhagavato 'nye padārthā bhagavadapekṣayātyalpenaiva śabdapravṛttihetunā guṇādinā
analyzed: te bhagavataḥ nye padārthāḥ bhagavat apekṣayā ati alpena eva śabda pravṛtti hetunā guṇa ādinā
translated: Those other entities of the Lord, in relation to the Lord, have very little by way of qualities etc. which are the causes of the application of words.

original: yasminbhagavatyāyattāḥ santaḥ śabdāthartvamupagatāḥ sa bhagavāneveśo niravadhikaśabdapravṛttinimittatvāt /
analyzed: yasmin bhagavati āyattāḥ santaḥ śabda athar tvam upagatāḥ sa bhagavān eva īśaḥ niravadhika śabda pravṛtti nimitta tvāt
translated: In whom, being dependent on the Lord, the words have come to have the meaning of the object, that Lord alone is the supreme, because He is the cause of the application of words without limit,

analyzed: svatantra tvataḥ ca mukhya śabda arthaḥ iti hi svīkartavyaḥ
translated: and because He is independent, He should be accepted as the primary meaning of the word.

analyzed: itareṣu śabda pravṛtti nimittāni alpāni eva tāni api bhagavat adhīnāni
translated: In the others, the causes of the application of words are very few, and even those are dependent on the Lord.

original: bhagavati tu niravadhikaparādhīnāni cetyetadasiddhamityata uktaṃ manīṣibhiriti /
analyzed: bhagavati tu niravadhika para adhīnāni ca iti etat asiddham iti atas uktam manīṣibhiḥ iti
translated: But in the Lord, they are without limit and completely dependent on others. This is not established. Therefore it is said: by the wise.

original: śrutyādiparicayavadbhiḥ /🔽yo yadadhīnaḥ śabdārthaḥ so 'mukhya itarastu mukhya ityatra dṛṣṭāntaḥ /
analyzed: śruti ādi paricayavadbhiḥ  yaḥ yad adhīnaḥ śabda arthaḥ saḥ mukhyaḥ itaraḥ tu mukhyaḥ iti atra dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: By those who are acquainted with the Vedas etc.🔽The example here is: that which is dependent on another is secondary, while the other is primary.

original: ayo yathānyādhīnaṃ sad dāhakatvaṃ dāhakaśabdārthatvamupagatam ata eva dahatīti śabdastasminnamukhyo 'gnau tu mukhyastathetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: ayaḥ yathā anya adhīnam sat dāhaka tvam dāhaka śabda artha tvam upagatam atas eva dahati iti śabdaḥ tasmin amukhyaḥ gnau tu mukhyaḥ tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as iron, being dependent on another, has come to have the meaning of the word 'burner' in the sense of burning, and for that very reason the word 'burns' is secondary in that, but primary in fire. The meaning is: it is so.

original: atretarasyāmukhyārthatvamanūdyata eveti na punaruktiḥ ka ityāha tṛtīyapādeneti śeṣaḥ / /
analyzed: atra itarasya a mukhya artha tvam anūdyate eva iti na punaruktiḥ kaḥ iti āha tṛtīya pādena iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Here, the secondary meaning of the other [word] is indeed being referred to, so there is no repetition. He says this is the remainder of the third quarter.

original: caturthapādasya saṅgatiṃ karoti evañceti //🔽evañca śabdānāṃ nārāyaṇasamanvaye /
analyzed: caturtha pādasya saṅgatim karoti evam ca iti  evam ca śabdānām nārāyaṇa samanvaye
translated: He establishes the connection of the fourth quarter with In this way, etc.🔽In this way, even though the connection of words with Narayana is established,

analyzed: siddhe pi aśeṣa śabdānām na kathañcana yujyate
translated: The connection of all words with Narayana is not at all proper,

analyzed: virodhau avara tva ādeḥ api prāptiḥ yatas bhavet
translated: Because the attainment of contradiction, inferiority, etc. would occur.

analyzed: iti ced
translated: If so, etc.

original: evañcetyasyaiva vivaraṇamatītena pādatrayeṇa keṣāñcicchabdānāṃ nārāyaṇasamanvaye siddhe 'pīti /
analyzed: evam ca ityasya eva vivaraṇam atītena pāda trayeṇa keṣāñcid śabdānām nārāyaṇa samanvaye siddhe pi iti
translated: The explanation of in this way is given by the previous [verse]: Even though the connection of some words with Narayana is established by the first three quarters.

analyzed: aśeṣa śabdānām nārāyaṇe samanvayaḥ na yujyate
translated: The connection of all words with Narayana is not proper.

original: yaḥ pratijñāto duḥkhibaddhāvarādiśabdānāṃ karmādiviṣayāṇāṃ ca kathañcana yogena rūḍhyā vā pravṛttyanupapatteriti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ pratijñātaḥ duḥkhi baddha avara ādi śabdānām karma ādi viṣayāṇām ca kathañcana yogena rūḍhyā vā pravṛtti anupapatteḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: What was promised - the words suffering, bound, inferior, etc. and those referring to karma, etc. - is not logically possible in any way, either through figurative usage or through conventional usage, the remainder.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: yatas vara ādi śabda vācya tve bhagavataḥ prāptiḥ bhavet
translated: Because if the Lord were denoted by the words inferior, etc., the fault of inferiority, etc. would occur.

analyzed: tasyāḥ ca sarva pramāṇa virodhāt
translated: And because that [fault] is contradicted by all means of knowledge.

analyzed: karma krama ādi virodhāt ca iti
translated: And because it is contradicted by the order of karma, etc.

analyzed: iti ced tatra prativihitam sūtrakāreṇa iti śeṣaḥ
translated: If it be said that this has been refuted by the author of the commentary.

analyzed: katham iti atas prathama adhikaraṇa tātparyam āha avara tva ādi iti
translated: How? Therefore, he states the purport of the first topic as inferiority, etc.

analyzed: avara tva ādi dvividham hi upalabhyate
translated: For, inferiority, etc. are of two kinds, as is perceived...

analyzed: avara ādi śabda apravṛtti nimittam upalabhyate pramāṇaiḥ
translated: The cause of the non-application of words like inferior is perceived by means of the means of knowledge.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ teṣām prasiddhim dyotayati
translated: The word hi (for) indicates their well-known nature.

analyzed: katham dvividham iti atas āha parasya iti
translated: How is it of two kinds? Therefore, he says of the other, etc.

analyzed: parasya avara tā hetuḥ yaḥ svayam paraḥ eva san
translated: That which is the cause of the inferiority of the other, being itself the other,

original: so 'pi hyavaraśabdārtho yathā rājā jayī bhavet // / / //
analyzed: saḥ pi hi avara śabda arthaḥ yathā rājā jayī bhavet
translated: that also is the meaning of the word inferior, just as the king would be the conqueror.

analyzed: anyaḥ vara tva anubhavī
translated: The other is the experiencer of inferiority...

original: svayaṃ para eva sanniti na pravṛttinimittakathanaṃ kintu svasyāvaratvābhāve 'pīti pradaśarnārtham /
analyzed: svayam paraḥ eva san iti na pravṛtti nimitta kathanam kintu svasya avara tva abhāve pi iti
translated: Being itself the other is not a statement of the cause of application, but rather to show that even in the absence of one's own inferiority.

analyzed: parasmin avara tva ādi dharma niyantṛ tvam ekam nimittam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the control of the qualities of inferiority, etc. in the other is one cause.

analyzed: tasya pramita tva darśanam yathā iti
translated: The statement of the perception of its being known is just as, etc.

original: paragatasya jayasya rājādhīnatvena yathā rājā jayiśabdavācyo bhavettathetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: para gatasya jayasya rāja adhīna tvena yathā rājā jayi śabda vācyaḥ bhavet tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that just as the king would be denoted by the word conqueror due to the dependence of the other's victory on the king.
The meaning of the word 'lower' is that which has the experience of inferiority.

analyzed: avara tva ādimattvam aparam nimittam iti yāvat
translated: The second cause is having inferiority etc.

analyzed: etat ca su prasiddham iti na pramāṇam uktam
translated: And this is well-known, so no proof is stated.

original: tataḥ kiṃ prakṛta ityata āha tayoriti /
analyzed: tatas kim prakṛte iti atas āha tayoḥ iti
translated: Then what is the point? To this he says 'of those two'.

analyzed: tayoḥ pūrvaḥ asti keśave
translated: Of those two, the first exists in Keshava.

analyzed: tayoḥ pravṛtti hetvoḥ madhye
translated: In the middle of those two causes of activity.

analyzed: ca iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is that it is denoted by the words 'lower' etc.

original: kutaḥ pūrva evāṅgīkriyate na dvitīya ityata āha dvitīya iti //
analyzed: kutas pūrvaḥ eva aṅgīkriyate na dvitīyaḥ iti atas āha dvitīyaḥ iti
translated: From where is the first alone accepted, not the second? To this he says 'the second'.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ jīvaḥ eva asti
translated: The second exists only in the individual soul.

analyzed: jīvaḥ iti jaḍasya api upalakṣaṇam
translated: The word 'individual soul' is a designation even for the insentient.

analyzed: tathā ca sati īśvaratva hāniḥ syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus there would be the loss of being God. This is the meaning.

analyzed: adhikaraṇa phalam āha svātantryāt iti
translated: He states the result of the topic, 'because of independence'.

analyzed: svātantrāt na ca dūṣaṇam
translated: And because of independence, there is no fault.

analyzed: hareḥ
translated: Of Hari.

original: paragatāvaratvādau svātantryasyaiva nimittatvāṅgīkārāddhareravaratvādikaṃ dūṣaṇaṃ na prasajyata iti /
analyzed: na prasajyate iti
translated: Because the cause of independence alone is accepted in the inferiority etc. of others, the fault of Hari's inferiority etc. does not arise.

analyzed: evam uttara adhikaraṇa tātparyam api vaktavyam
translated: In this way, the purport of the subsequent topics should also be stated.

analyzed: prathama adhyāya artha anuvādena dvitīya adhyāyasya saṅgatim āha evam iti
translated: He states the connection of the second chapter by way of a summary of the meaning of the first chapter, saying Thus.

analyzed: evam aśeṣeṇa sarva śabda samanvaye
translated: Thus, with the inclusion of all words,

analyzed: ukte virodha hīnasya syāt samanvaya tā yatas
translated: since there would be the state of being in accord with that which is free from contradiction,

analyzed: atas śeṣa virodhānām kṛta īśena nirākṛtiḥ
translated: therefore, the Lord has refuted all contradictions.

analyzed: sarva śabda artha vivaraṇam aśeṣeṇa iti
translated: The explanation of the meaning of all words is with the inclusion of all.

original: ukte sati dvitīye 'śeṣavirodhānāṃ nirākṛtirīśena kṛteti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: ukte sati dvitīye śeṣa virodhānām nirākṛtiḥ īśena kṛtā iti sambandhaḥ
translated: When stated, the connection is that the Lord has refuted all contradictions in the second chapter.

analyzed: virodha hīnasya eva samanvayasya
translated: Of only the accord that is free from contradiction.

analyzed: samanvaya avirodhābhyām sañjāte vastu nirṇaye
translated: When the determination of the object is produced by accord and non-contradiction,

analyzed: tṛtīya adhyāyasya saṅgatim āha samanvaya iti
translated: he states the connection of the third chapter, saying accord and so on.

analyzed: kim mayā kāryam iti eva syāt buddhiḥ adhikāriṇaḥ
translated: The thought of the qualified person would be What should I do?

analyzed: tad arthayoḥ adhyāyayoḥ upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a metonym for those two chapters.

analyzed: vastu nirṇaye brahma nirṇaye
translated: In the determination of the object, the determination of Brahman.

analyzed: kim mayā kāryam iti
translated: What should I do?

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: yadi api brahma vicāraḥ kartavyaḥ iti uktam
translated: Although it has been said that the investigation of Brahman should be done,

analyzed: kṛtaḥ ca asau
translated: and it has been done,

original: tathāpi sādhanaphalavicārasahitasya brahmavicārasya kartavyatayoktatvātkṛtabrahmavicārasyādhikāriṇo yanmayā kāryaṃ sādhanaṃ tatkiṃ kathambhūtamiti
analyzed: tathā api sādhana phala vicāra sahitasya brahma vicārasya kartavya tayā ukta tvāt kṛta brahma vicārasya adhikāriṇaḥ yat mayā kāryam sādhanam tat kim kathaṃbhūtam iti
translated: Still, since the consideration of Brahman along with the consideration of the means and the end has been declared to be what ought to be done, the idea of one who has finished the consideration of Brahman would be: What is that means which I have to perform? What is it like?

original: buddhiḥ syāditi /🔽phalaviṣaye kuta evaṃ buddhirna syāditi cetsyādeva /
analyzed: buddhiḥ syāt iti  phala viṣaye kutas evam buddhiḥ na syāt iti ced syāt eva
translated: Thus.🔽If it be asked: Why should not the idea be with regard to the end also? it may be so.

analyzed: kintu phala apekṣayā sādhanasya pūrva bhāvi tvāt tad viṣayā eva ādau syāt
translated: But since the means is antecedent to the end with regard to that, it would be with regard to that alone in the beginning.

analyzed: tat idam uktam evaśabdena
translated: This is what is meant by the word eva (alone).

analyzed: tad artham tṛtīyaḥ dhyāyaḥ pravṛttaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: For that purpose, the third chapter has been undertaken. This is the remainder.

original: etadgatānāṃ trayāṇāṃ pādānāṃ prāguktāmeva saṅgatiṃ sphuṭīkaroti tatreti //
analyzed: etad gatānām trayāṇām pādānām prāc uktām eva saṅgatim sphuṭīkaroti tatra iti
translated: He makes clear the connection already stated of the three quarters contained in it, with the words tatra (therein).

analyzed: tatra bhakti vidhāna artham abhakta anartha santatau
translated: Therein, for the purpose of enjoining devotion, in the series of evils of those who are not devoted,

analyzed: uktāyām bhakti dārḍhyāya prokte śeṣa guṇa uccaye
translated: when it has been stated, for the purpose of strengthening devotion, in the abundance of all virtues that have been stated,

analyzed: vaktavyā upāsanā nityam kartavyā iti ādareṇa hi
translated: the meditation that is to be stated should always be performed with respect, indeed.

analyzed: tatra tṛtīye dhyāye
translated: Therein, in the third chapter.

analyzed: bhakti vidhāna artham bhakti utpādana artham vairāgya artham iti yāvat
translated: For the purpose of enjoining devotion, for the purpose of producing devotion, up to the purpose of non-attachment.

analyzed: abhaktānām kāmya artha karmiṇām pāpinām dveṣiṇām ca
translated: Of the non-devotees, those who perform rites for desired ends, the sinful, and the haters.

analyzed: uktāyām prathama pādena
translated: In the first quarter, which has been stated.

analyzed: aśeṣa guṇā ucyate parameśvarasya prokte dvitīyena
translated: The remaining qualities of the Supreme Lord are mentioned in the second.

analyzed: upāsanā asmin pāde vaktavyā avasara prāptā
translated: Upasana, which is to be stated in this quarter, has come to the occasion.

original: nanūpāsanāyāṃ ko bhakterupayogo yatastadānantaryasyetyata āha nityamiti //
analyzed: nanu upāsanāyām kaḥ bhakteḥ upayogaḥ yatas tad ānantaryasya iti atas āha nityam iti
translated: But what is the use of devotion in upasana, for which there is the immediacy? Therefore he says: Nitya.

analyzed: yasmāt upāsanā nityam ādareṇa kartavyā
translated: Because upasana should always be done with respect.

analyzed: ādara nairantaryābhyām eva saṃskāra atiśayasya utpādāt
translated: Because only through respect and continuity is the excess of purification produced.

analyzed: ādara nairantarye ca upāsanāyām na abhaktasya bhavataḥ
translated: And respect and continuity in upasana do not occur for one who is not devoted.

analyzed: iti tasmāt idānīm upāsanā vaktavyā iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Therefore, upasana should now be stated - this is the connection.

analyzed: evam tarhi upāsanā eva vicāraṇīyā
translated: In that case, upasana itself should be considered.

original: sarvaśāstraparijñānaṃ prathamādhikaraṇe kasmādvicāryata ityata āha seti // /
analyzed: sarva śāstra parijñānam prathama adhikaraṇe kasmāt vicāryate iti atas āha sā iti
translated: Why is the knowledge of all scriptures considered in the first section? Therefore he says: Sa.

analyzed: sa upāsanā ca dvividhā śāstra abhyāsa svarūpiṇī
translated: And upasana is of two kinds, consisting of the practice of scriptures,

analyzed: dhyāna rūpā parā ca eva
translated: And the highest consisting of meditation.

analyzed: yā vaktavya tayā avasara prāptā sā ca upāsanā dvividhā eva
translated: That upasana which has come to the occasion to be stated is of two kinds only.

analyzed: na tu eka rūpā eva
translated: And not of one form only.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: ekā śāstra abhyāsa svarūpiṇī
translated: One is in the form of the practice of scriptures.

analyzed: parā ca dhyāna rūpā
translated: The other is in the form of meditation.

analyzed: atas yuktaḥ prathama adhikaraṇasya atra antarbhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is proper for the first topic to be included here.

analyzed: tathā api ayam kramaḥ kutas
translated: But why is this sequence?

analyzed: dhyānasya śāstra abhyāsa sādhya tvāt
translated: Because meditation is accomplished by the practice of scriptures.

analyzed: tat idam uktam parā iti
translated: This is what is said by the other.

analyzed: dhyāna samādhyoḥ anatibhinna tvaddha yāna śabdena samādhiḥ api gṛhyate
translated: Since meditation and concentration are not very different, concentration is also included by the word meditation.

analyzed: dhāraṇā pratyāhāra prāṇāyāma āsana yama niyamānām api upāsanā bhedānām sattvāt katham dvaividhyam iti atas āha tad aṅgam iti
translated: Since there are also other types of meditation such as retention, withdrawal, breath control, posture, restraint and observances, how can there be a twofold division? To this he says that limb etc.

analyzed: tad aṅgam dhāraṇā ādikam
translated: The limb of that is retention etc.

analyzed: tasya dhyānasya aṅgam eva na tu svatantram upāsanam
translated: It is only a limb of that meditation, not an independent meditation.

analyzed: yoga śāstre ca etat spaṣṭam avagantavyam
translated: And this should be clearly understood in the Yoga scriptures.

analyzed: śāstra abhyāsasya dhyāna aṅga tve svatantra upāsana tvam ca asti
translated: Even though the practice of scriptures is a limb of meditation, it is also an independent meditation.

analyzed: brahma sākṣātkāra hetu tvāt
translated: Because it is the cause of the direct realization of Brahman.

analyzed: citta vṛtti nirodha aka tvāt ca
translated: And because it leads to the cessation of mental fluctuations.

analyzed: athavā satatam śāstra vimarśena bhaviṣyati iti
translated: Or it will be by constantly reflecting on the scriptures.

analyzed: kim atas yadi upāsana avasara prāptā dvividhā ca iti
translated: What follows if meditation is of two kinds when it has come to the time for meditation?

analyzed: tatra āha tathā iti
translated: To that he says thus etc.

analyzed: tathā ubhaya ātmakam ca eva pāde smin bādarāyaṇaḥ
translated: And in this section, Bādarāyaṇa has also stated the two-fold nature.

analyzed: āha upāsanam addhava vistarāt śruti pūrvakam
translated: Now, the detailed meditation along with the Śruti passages,

analyzed: tathā tasmāt avasara prāpta tvāt
translated: Similarly, because it has come to the occasion.

analyzed: asmin eva iti sambandhaḥ

analyzed: upāsanam eva iti ca vā
translated: And also with meditation only.

original: tena pareṣāmidānīṃ tu prativedāntaṃ vijñānāni bhidyante na veti vicāryata iti pādārthakathanaṃ nirākaroti /
analyzed: tena pareṣām idānīm tu prati vedāntam vijñānāni bhidyante na vā iti vicāryate iti pāda artha kathanam nirākaroti

analyzed: tathā hi  kim bheda abhedau  virodha avirodhau

analyzed: uta vilakṣaṇa tva avilakṣaṇa tve

analyzed: na ādyaḥ

analyzed: gatārtha tvāt

analyzed: dvitīye brahmaṇaḥ khaṇḍa tvena prāpti abhāvaḥ

analyzed: sa guṇa brahma viṣayā prāṇa ādi viṣayā ca iyam cintā iti ced na

analyzed: prakṛta viṣaya prayojana viruddha tvena akartavya tvāt iti

analyzed: addhā upayukta prameyeṇa saha

analyzed: atas eva vistarāt

analyzed: anena keṣāñcid adhikaraṇānām anantarbhāva śaṅkā nirākṛtā bhavati

analyzed: śruti grahaṇam upalakṣaṇam

analyzed: pṛthak dṛṣṭiḥ aśakya tvam anirṇītiḥ samuccayaḥ
translated: Separate view, impossibility, indecision, combination,

translated: Specific view, omission of duty, various statements, quickness,🔽Delusion, non-description, mark, qualified by infinite regress,

analyzed: aprayojana tā ca atiprasaṅgaḥ dūra saṃśrayaḥ
translated: Lack of purpose, over-extension, close reliance,

analyzed: puṃsāmyam prāpta san tyāgaḥ kāraṇa anirṇayaḥ bhramaḥ

analyzed: viśeṣa darśi tā ālāpaḥ guṇa sāmyam pṛthak dṛśiḥ
translated: Specific view, statement, equality of qualities, separate view,

analyzed: agamya vartma sandhānam iṣṭam phalam akalpanā

analyzed: śuddha vairūpyam aṅga tvam aviśeṣa dṛśiḥ kriyā

analyzed: yuktayaḥ pūrvapakṣa sthāḥ su jñeya tvam vidhi kriyā

analyzed: māhātmyam alpa śakti tvam yathāyogya phalam bhavaḥ

analyzed: phala sāmyam viśeṣaḥ ca guṇa ādhikyam pradhāna tā
translated: The similarity of result, the distinction, the superiority due to more qualities, the importance,

analyzed: yathāśakti kriyā sandhiḥ pramāṇa balam ānatiḥ

analyzed: kāraṇam kārya vaiśeṣyam svabhāvaḥ vastu dūṣaṇam
translated: The cause, the peculiarity of the effect, the nature, the criticism of the object,

analyzed: pratikriyā virodhaḥ ca pratisandhiḥ anūna tā  saṃskāra pāṭavam sva icchā niyatiḥ vastu vaibhavam
translated: The counteraction, the contradiction, the non-deficiency of the counter-covenant,🔽The skill in refinement, the self-control of one's own will, the greatness of the object,
The special statement, the non-measurability, the importance, the affection, the scripture,

analyzed: su sthira tvam kṛta prāptiḥ anādi guṇa vistaraḥ

analyzed: sādhana uttama tā nānā dṛṣṭiḥ śiṣṭiḥ anūna tā

analyzed: avighna tva virodhau ca guṇa vaiśeṣyam āgamaḥ  siddhānta nirṇaye hi etāḥ yuktayaḥ vyāhatāḥ sadā

The statement are always unobstructed supports the fact that they are the arguments of the conclusion.

analyzed: iti nyāya mālā sthalāni
translated: Thus end the topics in the Nyāyamālā.
I. The section on the acceptance of all Vedānta texts

analyzed: atha sarva vedānta pratyayā  dhikaraṇam
translated: being based on all the Vedāntas.

analyzed: om sarva vedānta pratyayam codana ādi aviśeṣāt om
translated: Om. It is based on all the Vedāntas, because of the non-distinction of injunction etc.

original: atra dhyānopāsanārthibhiḥ kiṃ svaśākhā evādhyayanaśravaṇamananairjñātavyāḥ kiṃ vā🔽sarve 'pi vedā iti saṃśaye śākhābhedasya suprasiddhatvādanyathā tadanupapatteḥ prathamapakṣa
analyzed: atra dhyāna upāsana arthibhiḥ kim sva śākhāḥ eva adhyayana śravaṇa mananaiḥ jñātavyāḥ kim vā  sarve vedāḥ iti saṃśaye śākhā bhedasya su prasiddha tvāt anyathā tad anupapatteḥ prathama pakṣa
translated: Here, those who seek meditation and worship should know from their own branches alone through study, listening, and reflection, or🔽from all the Vedas? In doubt, because the difference of branches is well-known, and otherwise that would be impossible, the first

analyzed: eva jyāyān iti prāpte siddhāntitam sarva vedānta pratyayam iti
translated: view is indeed greater. Having reached this, it is concluded that it is based on all the Vedāntas.

analyzed: tatra sarva śabdaḥ saṅkucita vṛttiḥ iti pratīti nirāsāya vyācaṣṭe yaśa śakti iti
translated: There, in order to remove the understanding that the word all has unrestricted application, it is explained as the power of fame etc.

analyzed: sarva vedānta pratyayam codanā ādi aviśeṣāt  yathāśaktaya akhilān vedān vijñāya upāsanam bhavet
translated: It is based on all the Vedāntas, because of the non-distinction of injunction etc.🔽One should perform worship after understanding all the Vedas according to one's ability.

analyzed: vijñāya avasthitasya iti adhyāhārāt samāna kartṛkatā siddhiḥ  upāsanam kurvāṇaḥ bhavet iti vā
translated: By supplying the understood words of one who has understood and is established, the identity of the agent is established.🔽Or, one should perform worship while becoming.

analyzed: upāsanam kurvīta iti vā  bhavet iti asya uttara vākye nvayaḥ
translated: Or, one should perform worship.🔽The word should be is connected with the subsequent sentence.

analyzed: atra yathāśakti akhilān vedān vijānīyāt iti eva vaktavyam
translated: Here, it should be said that one should understand all the Vedas according to one's ability.

analyzed: tathā api atra ucyamānam sarva parijñānam dhyāna upāsana aṅgam iti daśaryitum evam uktam
translated: Still, in order to show that the complete knowledge mentioned here is a part of the meditation and contemplation, it is stated thus.

analyzed: tatas ca parā iti uktam vivṛtam bhavati
translated: And therefore, what was said later becomes explained.

original: yathāśruta evārtho 'stu kiṃ viśeṣeṇenetyata āha tatreti //
analyzed: yathāśrutaḥ eva arthaḥ astu kim viśeṣeṇa inā iti atas āha tatra iti
translated: Let the meaning be just as heard. What is the use of this distinction? To this he says 'tatra' (in that case).

original: tatrākhilasya vijñaptiḥ samyag brahmaṇa eva hi // / / //
analyzed: tatra akhilasya vijñaptiḥ samyak brahmaṇaḥ eva hi
translated: In that case, the complete knowledge of the entire Veda is proper only for Brahman, not for others.

analyzed: tat anyeṣām yathāyogyam akhila jñaptiḥ iṣyate
translated: The complete knowledge of others is accepted according to their capacity.

original: tatropāsakeṣu yasmātsamyagakhilasya vedasya vijñaptirbrahmaṇa eva yuktā bhavennānyeṣāṃ tasmādanyeṣāṃ yathāyogaṃ yathāśaktyevākhilajñaptireṣyavyā
analyzed: tatra upāsakeṣu yasmāt samyak akhilasya vedasya vijñaptiḥ brahmaṇaḥ eva yuktā bhavet na anyeṣām tasmāt anyeṣām yathāyogam yathāśakti eva akhila jñaptiḥ eṣya vyā
translated: In that case, among the devotees, since the complete knowledge of the entire Veda is proper only for Brahman, not for others, therefore the complete knowledge of others should be accepted according to their capacity, according to their ability.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: sarva adhikāri sādhāraṇam tāvat idam sūtram
translated: This aphorism is common to all who are entitled to it.

analyzed: codanā ādi aviśeṣa ādi yuktibhiḥ tad avagamāt
translated: Because of the non-distinction of injunction etc., and because of the understanding of that through reasoning.

analyzed: saṃśaya pūrvapakṣa asaṅgata tva prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because of the consequence of the connection with doubt and the prima facie view.

analyzed: na ca sarveṣām sarva veda vijñānam sambhavati
translated: And the knowledge of the entire Veda is not possible for all.

analyzed: vedānām ananta tvāt
translated: Because the Vedas are infinite.

analyzed: alpa prajñā ādimat tvāt ca ā puṃsām
translated: And because men have limited intelligence etc.

analyzed: tatas yuktam uktam iti
translated: Therefore, what was said is proper.

analyzed: yat vā prathama vākye eva bhavet iti anena eva eṣaḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: Or, this is stated by the very phrase 'should be in the first sentence itself'.

analyzed: yasmāt evam eva upapannam bhavet iti
translated: Because it would be logically possible in this way.

original: tataḥ kasya kīdṛśī śaktiriti jijñāsāyāmidaṃ vākyam /
analyzed: tatas kasya kīdṛśī śaktiḥ iti jijñāsāyām idam vākyam
translated: Then, when there is a desire to know whose power is of what kind, this sentence [is spoken].

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ prasiddhau
translated: The word 'hi' [means] 'it is well known'.

analyzed: yogaḥ yogyatā
translated: 'Yoga' [means] 'fitness'.

analyzed: jñaptiḥ jñapti śaktiḥ
translated: 'Jñapti' [means] 'the power of being known'.

analyzed: upāsanā yogya tā samanvaye khalu atra sarva vijñānam ucyate
translated: In this [verse], the connection of being fit for meditation and the knowledge of everything is spoken of.

analyzed: na ca alpa veda jñasya sā bhavati
translated: And that [fitness] does not exist for one who knows only a little of the Vedas.

original: sarvaiśca vedaiḥ paramo hi devo jijñāsyo 'sau nālpavedaiḥ prasiddhayet' /🔽ityādiśruteḥ /
analyzed: sarvaiḥ ca vedaiḥ paramaḥ hi devaḥ jijñāsyaḥ u sau na alpa vedaiḥ  ityādi śruteḥ
translated: For it is said in the scriptures: 'The highest God is to be known by all the Vedas, not by knowing only a little of the Vedas.'

analyzed: atas sarva śabdaḥ mukhya arthe eva vyākhyātavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the word 'all' should be explained to have its primary meaning.

analyzed: atas eva yadi api asmad ādīnām asmin janmani sarva veda jñānam asambhavi
translated: For this very reason, although for us and others the knowledge of all the Vedas is impossible in this birth,

original: tathāpi tādṛśaṃ janma kalpanīyaṃ yatredaṃ sambhavatītyata āha tāvateti //
analyzed: tathā api tādṛśam janma kalpanīyam yatra idam sambhavati iti atas āha tāvatā iti
translated: nevertheless, such a birth should be imagined where this [knowledge] is possible. Therefore he says 'by that much' [in the next verse].

analyzed: tāvatā upāsane yogyaḥ bhavet eva akhilaḥ pumān
translated: By that much, every man would be fit for meditation.

analyzed: yathāśakti vijñāna mātreṇa
translated: By the knowledge of as much as one can, [he would be fit].

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intention.

analyzed: dhyāna upāsane veda jñānasya katham upayogaḥ
translated: How can the knowledge of the Vedas be useful for meditation and contemplation?

analyzed: dhyeya ajñāne dhyāna ayogāt iti ced
translated: If it be said that it is due to the absence of knowledge of the object of meditation and the absence of yoga in meditation,

analyzed: tarhi sarveṣām sarva veda artha dhyāna abhāvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt na sarva veda jñānam upayuktam
translated: then, since it will be said that all do not meditate on the meaning of all the Vedas, knowledge of all the Vedas is not useful.

analyzed: satyam  tathā api adhigata eka śākhasya śākhā antare nyathā ukti śaṅkayā dhyāna asambhavāt sarva veda
translated: True.

analyzed: parijñānam āvaśyakam iti ced na
translated: Nevertheless, if one has understood one branch, due to the doubt of being stated differently in another branch, meditation is impossible. Therefore, the complete knowledge of all the Vedas🔽is necessary. If it be said that it is not so,

analyzed: gati sāmānya anumānena eva śaṅkā nirāsasya ukta tvāt
translated: because the removal of doubt is stated by inference of the general course of action itself,

analyzed: anyathā paraspara virodhena veda aprāmāṇya āpatteḥ
translated: otherwise, due to mutual contradiction, there would be the undesirable consequence of the Vedas being invalid.

analyzed: tatas śrutiḥ yathāśakti iti eva vyākhyeyā iti
translated: Therefore, it should be explained only as according to one's ability.

original: yathāśakti vedajñānaṃ bhagavadupāsanopayuktaṃ na sarvavedajñānāvaśyambhāva ityatra purāṇavākyamapi paṭhati mahattvasyeti //
analyzed: yathāśakti veda jñānam bhagavat upāsana upayuktam na sarva veda jñāna avaśyambhāvaḥ iti atra purāṇa vākyam api paṭhati mahat tvasya iti
translated: The knowledge of the Vedas according to one's ability is useful for the worship of the Lord, not the necessity of knowing all the Vedas. In this matter, he also quotes a statement from the Puranas, beginning with mahattvasya.

analyzed: mahattvasya param pāram viditvā eva janārdanaḥ
translated: Having known the highest limit of greatness, Janardana,

original: stoṣyatāmeti tuṣṭatvamiti nāstyeva nārada // / / //🔽kintu niścalayā bhaktayā hyātmajñānānurūpataḥ /
analyzed: stoṣyatām eti tuṣṭa tvam iti na asti eva nārada  kintu niścalayā bhaktayā hi ātma jñāna anurūpataḥ
translated: the satisfied one, does not come to those who wish to praise. O Narada, it is not so.

original: yaḥ stoṣyati sadā bhaktastuṣyastasya sadā hariḥ // / / //
analyzed: yaḥ stoṣyati sadā bhaktaḥ tuṣyaḥ tasya sadā hariḥ
translated: But the Lord is always pleased with the devotee who always praises with unwavering devotion, according to his knowledge of the self.
Thus, from the context of these statements, the knowledge of everything as appropriate.

analyzed: mahattvasya param pāram viditvā iti sarva veda jña tvam ucyate
translated: Having known the highest limit of greatness, it is said that he knows all the Vedas.

analyzed: vedena vinā bhagavat mahattvasya jñātum āśakya tvāt
translated: Without the Veda, it is impossible to know the greatness of the Lord.

analyzed: stoṣyatām iti dhyānasya api upalakṣaṇam
translated: For those who wish to praise, meditation is also indicated.

analyzed: samāna nyāya tvāt
translated: Because the same principle applies.

original: nāstyeveti niyamaniṣedhaḥ yathāyogyākhilajñatā dhyānopayoginīti vijñāyata iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: na asti eva iti niyama niṣedhaḥ yathāyogya akhila jña tā dhyāna upayoginī iti vijñāyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: It is understood that the knowledge of everything as appropriate is useful for meditation, this is the remainder.

analyzed: yathāyogyā iti katham
translated: How is it appropriate?

analyzed: avyayībhāvasya napuṃsaka tvena yathāyogyam iti bhāvyam
translated: Since an avyayībhāva compound is neuter, it should be yathāyogyam.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: yathāyogya akhila jña tā iti samāsaḥ yam iti adoṣaḥ
translated: This is a compound yathāyogyākhiljñatā, so there is no fault.

original: yadvā yathā yādṛśī yogyā tathaiveti bhinne evaite pade / /
analyzed: yat vā yathā yādṛśī yogyā tathā evā iti bhinne eva ete pade
translated: Or, yathā means in whatever way, and yogya means appropriate, so these are two different words.

analyzed: nanu atra ātma jñānam eva upāsana upayogi tvena ucyate
translated: But here, only the knowledge of the self is said to be useful for meditation,

analyzed: na tu yathāśakti jñānam
translated: not the knowledge of everything as much as possible.

original: ato na prakṛtopayogīdaṃ vākyamityata āha ātmeti //
analyzed: atas na prakṛta upayogi idam vākyam iti atas āha ātmā iti
translated: Therefore, this statement is not useful for the present context. To this, he says ātma (self).

analyzed: ātma jñāna anurūpa tvam yathāśakti vicāraṇāt
translated: Because of the consideration according to one's ability, there is conformity with the knowledge of the self.

analyzed: atra upāsanasya ātma jñāna anurūpa tvam nāma yathāśakti veda vicāraṇāt bhāvi tvam eva
translated: Here, the suitability of the meditation to the knowledge of the self is simply the state of being imbued by the examination of the Vedas according to one's ability.

analyzed: anyathā vākyasya asaṅgata tva prasaṅgāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be the consequence of the sentence being irrelevant. This is the idea.

original: sarvajñānaniyame nirākṛte kintvityāśaṅkāyāṃ yathāśaktijñānaṃ hi vaktavyam /
analyzed: sarva jñāna niyame nirākṛte kintu iti āśaṅkāyām yathāśakti jñānam hi vaktavyam
translated: When the restriction to all knowledge is refuted, in the doubt expressed by but, knowledge according to one's ability should be stated.

analyzed: na tu ātma jñānam
translated: But not knowledge of the self.

analyzed: nahi para jñānam prāk nirākṛtam
translated: For the knowledge of others has not been refuted earlier.

analyzed: tasmāt ātma jñānam nāma ātma yogyam jñānam iti eva vyākhyeyam iti
translated: Therefore, knowledge of the self should be explained as simply knowledge suitable for the self.

analyzed: kutas savar veda jñānam iti atas codanā ādi aviśeṣāt iti uktam
translated: From where is the knowledge of all the Vedas? Therefore, it is said because of the non-distinction of injunction etc.

original: tatra śākhābhedasya suprasiddhatvāccodanādikamapi viśeṣaniṣṭhaṃ vyākhyātamityato yuktyantaramāha sūtrakāraḥ oṃ svādhyāyasya tathātvena hi samācāre 🔽'dhikārācceti oṃ //
analyzed: tatra śākhā bhedasya su prasiddha tvāt codana ādikam api viśeṣa niṣṭham vyākhyātam iti atas yukti antaram āha sūtrakāraḥ om svādhyāyasya tathātvena hi samācāre  dhikārāt ca iti om
translated: There, because the difference of branches is well-known, even injunction etc. is explained as restricted to the particular. Therefore, the author of the aphorism states another reason: Because of the authority in the practice of the Veda as such.

original: tatra hīyantaṃ vyācaṣṭe veda iti //🔽svādhyāyasya tathātvena hi samācāre 'dhikārāc ca savavac ca / / / /
analyzed: tatra hi iyantam vyācaṣṭe vedaḥ iti  svādhyāyasya tathātvena hi samācāre dhikārāt ca sava vat ca  /
translated: There, he explains this: The Veda etc.

analyzed: vedaḥ kṛtsnaḥ dhik antavyaḥ svādhyāya adhyayanam bhavet
translated: The Veda should be understood in its entirety, there should be the study of one's own Veda.

original: ityādivākyavaiyarthyamanyathā na nivāryate // / / //🔽anenavedaḥ kṛtsno 'dhigantavyaḥ sarahasyo dvijanmanā' /
analyzed: ityādi vākya vaiyarthyam anyathā na nivāryate  kṛtsnaḥ dhik antavyaḥ sa rahasyaḥ dvijanmanā
translated: Otherwise, the uselessness of such statements as these cannot be warded off.

analyzed: iti smṛtim upādatte
translated: By this (verse), the Smṛti text The entire Veda, along with the esoteric teachings, should be studied by the twice-born is referred to.

analyzed: svādhyāya adhyayanam kartavyam bhavet iti anena svādhyāyaḥ dhyetavyaḥ iti śrutim
translated: By the words the study of one's own Veda should be done, the Śruti text One's own Veda should be studied is referred to.

analyzed: anyathā sva sva śākhā mātra jñāna aṅgīkāre
translated: Otherwise, if only the knowledge of one's own branch were accepted,

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: this is what is said.

original: svādhyāyasya svādhyāyavidhestathātvena sāmānyataḥ sarvavedādhyayanavidhāyakatvena hetunā sarvajñānamaṅgīkaraṇīyam /
analyzed: svādhyāyasya svādhyāya vidheḥ tathātvena sāmānyatas sarva veda adhyayana vidhāyaka tvena hetunā sarvajñānam aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: The knowledge of all (Vedas) should be accepted as the reason for the injunction to study one's own Veda, which is of that nature as a general injunction to study all the Vedas.

analyzed: adhyayanasya artha jñāna paryantana asthiteḥ
translated: Because the study does not end until the meaning is known.

analyzed: sva sva śākhā mātra jñāna aṅgīkāre ca asya vidheḥ vaiyarthya āpatteḥ
translated: And if only the knowledge of one's own branch were accepted, this injunction would become useless.

analyzed: na ca vācyam śākhā bhedasya prasiddhayā svādhyāya pada kṛtsna pada darśanāt
translated: And it cannot be said that because of the well-known difference in branches and the use of the words 'one's own' and 'entire,'

analyzed: śākhā bhedasya aśakti nimitta tva upapatteḥ iti
translated: it is reasonable that the difference in branches is due to incapacity.

original: nanu śrutyantaraṃ hiśabdena smṛtiḥ sūtrakṛtopāttā tatkathamatra viparyayaḥ /
analyzed: nanu śruti antaram hi śabdena smṛtiḥ sūtra kṛtā upāttā tat katham atra viparyayaḥ
translated: But the author of the aphorisms has quoted the Smṛti text with the word 'hi' (in the aphorism), so how is there a reversal here?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: ākāṅkṣā krameṇa sūtram
translated: The aphorism is according to the order of expectancy.

original: vyākhyānaṃ tūpodghātaprakriyayeti na virodhaḥ /🔽śrutismṛtibalādeva yathāśakti savarvijñānasyaiva niśśaṅkatāhetutvaṃ kalpyate /
analyzed: vyākhyānam tu upodghāta prakriyayā iti na virodhaḥ  śruti smṛti balāt eva yathāśakti niśśaṅka tā hetu tvam kalpyate
translated: But the explanation is by the method of introduction, so there is no contradiction.🔽The reason for the absence of doubt about the entire knowledge is imagined to be the power of the Vedas and Smritis themselves.

analyzed: bhūyas darśanam ca anumāna aṅgam iti su prasiddham
translated: And it is well known that repeated observation is a part of inference.

analyzed: āha na adhyayana vidhi prayuktam adhyayanam
translated: It is said that study is not prompted by the injunction to study.

analyzed: kintu adhyāpana vidhi prayuktam eva
translated: But it is prompted only by the injunction to teach.

analyzed: adhyayana vidheḥ niyojya rahita tvāt
translated: Because the injunction to study is devoid of one to be enjoined.

analyzed: na hi atra svarga kāmaḥ yajeta iti vat kaścid niyojyaḥ śrūyate
translated: For here, unlike in One who desires heaven should sacrifice, no one to be enjoined is heard.

analyzed: nā api viśvajit ādau iva kalpayitum śakyate
translated: Nor can it be imagined as in the case of the Vishvajit and others.

analyzed: adhyāpana vidhinā eva adhyayana siddhau kalpaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no reason for the establishment of study by the injunction to teach alone.

analyzed: na ca adhyāpana vidhiḥ api niyojya rahitaḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that the injunction to teach is also devoid of one to be enjoined.

analyzed: ācārya karaṇa kāmasya tatra niyojya tvāt
translated: Because one who desires to make oneself an Acharya is the one to be enjoined there.

analyzed: naṣṭa varṣam brāhmaṇam upanayīta iti ātmanepada śravaṇāt
translated: Because the Atmanepada ending is heard in One should initiate a Brahmana who has lost his year.

analyzed: sammānana utsañjana ācārya karaṇa jñāna bhṛti vigaṇana vyayeṣu niyamaḥ
translated: The rule is in the case of honouring, engaging, making oneself an Acharya, knowing, wages, counting, and expenses.

analyzed: iti ācāyar karaṇe nayateḥ ātmanepada vidhānāt
translated: Because the Atmanepada ending is prescribed for nayate in the case of making oneself an Acharya.

analyzed: tam adhyāpayīta iti upanayana adhyāpanayoḥ eka kartṛkatā pratīteḥ
translated: Because it is understood that the Upanayana and teaching are done by the same person.

original: na hyadhyāpanamadhyayanena vinā bhavatīti svasiddhaye parāpekṣa kṣepa
analyzed: na hi adhyāpanam adhyayanena vinā bhavati iti sva siddhaye para apekṣa kṣepa
translated: For teaching does not occur without study. Thus, for its own accomplishment, it depends on another.

analyzed: lakṣaṇena upādāna upādānena adhyāpana vidhiḥ eva adhyāpana vidhiḥ eva adhyayanam prayuṅkte
translated: The teaching injunction itself employs the study through the injunction of the means of accomplishment, which has the nature of rejection.

analyzed: kiñca adhyayane sati vidhi jñānam tatas ca adhyayanam iti itaretarāśraya tvam syāt
translated: Moreover, if there is study, there is knowledge of the injunction, and then study. Thus there would be mutual dependence.

analyzed: atas na etad vākya udāharaṇam atra saṅgatam iti
translated: Therefore, this example of a sentence is not relevant here.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: syāt evam yadi adhyāpana vidhi prayuktam adhyayanam syāt
translated: This would be so if study were employed by the teaching injunction.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: adhyāpanasya jīvīkā artha tvāt
translated: Because teaching is for the sake of livelihood.

analyzed: trīṇi karmāṇi jīvikā iti vacanāt
translated: Because of the statement The three actions are for livelihood.

analyzed: adhyayanasya ca nitya tvāt
translated: And because study is obligatory.

analyzed: yaḥ n adhītya dvijaḥ vedān
translated: One who has not studied the Vedas...

analyzed: iti akaraṇe pratyavāya śravaṇāt
translated: Because of the statement of the consequence of not doing it.

analyzed: na ca nityam anityena prayujyate
translated: And the obligatory is not employed by the non-obligatory.

analyzed: kiñca ekasya māṇavakasya adhyāpanena caritārtha tve māṇavaka antarasya anadhyayana prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Moreover, if the purpose is served by teaching one student, there would be the undesirable consequence of another student not studying.

original: yo yenopanītaḥ sa tenādhyāpanīya iti cet / /
analyzed: yaḥ yena upanītaḥ sa tena adhyāpanīyaḥ iti ced
translated: If it be said that he by whom a boy is initiated should teach him,

analyzed: tarhi upanāyake parete dhyayana abhāvaḥ syāt
translated: then, after the death of the preceptor, there would be no study.

analyzed: yat punar itaretara āśraya tvam uktam tat prātar sandhyām upāsīta ityādau api samānam
translated: As for the mutual dependence (of the preceptor and the pupil), that is the same in the case of such injunctions as 'he shall worship the morning Sandhya'.

analyzed: ayam api ācāryasya eva vidhiḥ
translated: This also is an injunction for the preceptor.

analyzed: śauca ācārān ca śikṣayet ityādeḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is not so, because of such texts as 'he should teach him the rules of purity and conduct', we reply: No.

analyzed: ācārye parete tad abhāva āpātāt
translated: Because, after the death of the preceptor, there would be absence of that (study).

analyzed: atas dhyayana ādi vidhim vṛddhāḥ kathañcid māṇavakam bodhayanti iti aṅgīkāryam iti alam
translated: Therefore, it must be admitted that the elders somehow instruct the boy in the injunctions regarding study, etc. Enough of this.

analyzed: samācāra adhikārāt ca iti etat vayācaṣṭe adya api iti
translated: And because of the authority in the performance of the duties. This he explains: Even now, etc.

analyzed: samācāre dhikārāt ca
translated: And because of the authority in the performance of the duties.

original: adyāpi tena devādyāḥ śṛṇvate manvate sadā /
analyzed: adyā api tena deva ādyāḥ śṛṇvate manvate sadā
translated: Even now, the gods and others always listen to and reflect upon it,

analyzed: dhyāyanti ca yathāyogam
translated: and meditate on it as appropriate.

analyzed: yatas sarva vijñānam āvaśyakam
translated: Because the knowledge of everything is necessary.

original: tenaiva hi kāraṇena devādyā adyāpi śravaṇamanane kurvanti sadā dhyāyanti ca /
analyzed: tena eva hi kāraṇena deva ādyāḥ adyā api śravaṇa manane kurvanti sadā dhyāyanti ca
translated: For that very reason, the gods and others even now always perform listening and reflection, and meditate on it.

original: anyathā mahāmatīnāṃ teṣāmekaikaśākhāśravaṇāderalpīyasaiva kālena kartuṃ śakyatvenādyāpi tatkaraṇaṃ na syāditi /
analyzed: anyathā mahāmatīnām teṣām ekaika śākhā śravaṇa ādeḥ alpīyasā eva kālena kartum śakya tvena adya api tat karaṇam na syāt iti
translated: Otherwise, since it would be possible for them, who have great intelligence, to perform (the duties of the four āśramas) by listening to each branch etc. in a very short time, it would not be the case that they do not perform them even today.

analyzed: yathāyogam yathāśakti iti pratyekam viśeṣaṇam
translated: The qualification as is proper and as is possible are to be taken with each (of the four āśramas).

analyzed: śṛṇvantaḥ iti ātmanepade uktam
translated: The reflexive pronoun śṛṇvanti (listening) is used.

original: samācāraccetyevokte devādīnāṃ vedādhikāritvābhāvātkathametadityato devatādhikaraṇanyāyaṃ mā vismārṣīriti sūcayituṃ sūtrakṛtā samācāre 'dhikārāccetyuktam
analyzed: samācārat ca iti eva ukte deva ādīnām veda adhikāri tva abhāvāt katham etat iti atas devatā adhikaraṇa nyāyam mā vismārṣīḥ iti sūcayitum sūtrakṛtā samācāre dhikārāt ca iti uktam
translated: If it were said simply because of the practice, since gods and others are not entitled to the Vedas, it would be asked how this is so. Therefore, in order to indicate that the reasoning of the section on deities should not be forgotten, the author of the sūtra said because of the practice and because of the entitlement.

original: yadi brahmasākṣātkāravanto 'pi devādyāḥ śravaṇādyanutiṣṭhanti tarhi tasya niravadhikatvaṃ prasaktamityata āha tathāpīti //
analyzed: yadi deva ādyāḥ śravaṇa ādi anutiṣṭhanti tarhi tasya niravadhika tvam prasaktam iti atas āha tathā api iti
translated: If gods and others, even though they have realized Brahman, perform listening etc., then it follows that that (performance of listening etc.) is without limit. To this he says: Even so...

analyzed: tathā āpyāḥ vastu nirṇayāt
translated: Even so, because of the ascertainment of the object.

original: śravaṇaṃ mananaṃ caiva kartavyaṃ sarvathaiva hi // / /f //
analyzed: śravaṇam mananam ca eva kartavyam sarvathā eva hi
translated: Listening and reflection must be done in every way.

analyzed: yadi api sūtrakāreṇa deva ādi ācāraḥ pramāṇīkṛtaḥ tathā api
translated: Even though the practice of gods and others has been accepted as authoritative by the author of the sūtra, still...

analyzed: vastu para brahma ādikam
translated: The object is the supreme Brahman etc.

analyzed: nirṇayaḥ yathā arthaḥ parokṣaḥ niścayaḥ
translated: Ascertainment is the true, indirect, determination.

analyzed: prathamasya eva śabdasya avastu nirṇayāt eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: because the first word 'eva' (only) is not determined in the matter.

analyzed: vastu nirṇaya hetu tvāt śravaṇa ādeḥ iti hi śabda atharḥ
translated: The meaning of the word 'hi' is: because listening etc. are the causes for determining the matter.

analyzed: vastu nirṇaya paryantam śravaṇa manane kartavye iti asat
translated: It is not right to say that listening and reflection should be done up to the determination of the matter.

original: nirṇīte 'pyarthe punaḥ kāraṇāntaropanipātena saṃśayādyutpādasya darśanena vastunirṇayasyāvadhārayitumaśakyatvādityata āha matīti //
analyzed: nirṇīte pi arthe punar kāraṇa antara upanipātena saṃśaya ādi utpādasya darśanena vastu nirṇayasya avadhārayitum aśakya tvāt iti atas āha mati iti
translated: Because even when the meaning is determined, doubt etc. are seen to arise again due to the presence of other causes, and the determination of the matter cannot be ascertained. Therefore he says:

analyzed: mati śruti dhyāna kāla viśeṣam guruḥ uttamaḥ
translated: The best teacher knows the specific time of reflection, listening, and meditation.

analyzed: vetti tasya ukti mārgeṇa kurvataḥ syāt hi darśanam
translated: For one who acts according to his instructions, there will be realization.

analyzed: matiḥ mananam śrutiḥ śravaṇam
translated: Reflection is pondering, listening is hearing.

analyzed: uttamaḥ śiṣya yogyatā abhijñaḥ
translated: The best one is one who knows the disciple's aptitude.

analyzed: kurvataḥ śravaṇa ādikam
translated: For one who performs listening etc.

analyzed: darśanam brahma sākṣātkāḥ
translated: Realization is the direct experience of Brahman.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

analyzed: brahma darśana artham hi śravaṇa ādikam
translated: For the purpose of realizing Brahman, listening etc. are performed.

analyzed: na ca tat yathā kathañcid anuṣṭhitam tat sādhanam
translated: And that is not a means of attaining it when performed in any way.

analyzed: kintu śiṣya yogyatā abhijña guru pradāna pūrvakam eva iti vakṣyati
translated: But it will be said that it is only when preceded by the bestowal of the teacher who knows the disciple's aptitude.

analyzed: atas tādṛśaḥ guruḥ eva śravaṇa ādi kāla viśeṣam upadekṣyati
translated: Therefore, such a teacher will instruct about the specific time for listening etc.

original: yataḥ paraṃ kāraṇaśatopanipāte 'pi na saṃśayādyutpādaḥ syāditi / /
analyzed: yatas param kāraṇa śata upanipāte na saṃśaya ādi utpādaḥ syāt iti
translated: Because even when hundreds of causes come together, doubt etc. would not arise.

analyzed: deva ādyāḥ śravaṇa ādikam adya api kurvanti iti na yuktam
translated: It is not proper to say that gods and others are still listening etc.

analyzed: syāt hi darśanam iti śravaṇa ādeḥ tattva darśana sādhana tvasya ukta tvāt
translated: This is because it has been said that listening etc. are the means of realizing the truth.
