translated: And there the words 'association with objects' etc. indicate yama and maatra-abhava (non-attachment to the objects of senses).🔽And since the absence of devotion etc. is also a fault, it is said 'free from these faults'.

original: yamānāmavaśyānuṣṭheyatve yuktimapyāha doṣā iti //🔽doṣā anādisambaddhāste muktiparipanthinaḥ /
analyzed: yamānām avaśya anuṣṭheya tve yuktim api āha doṣāḥ iti  doṣāḥ anādi sambaddhāḥ te mukti paripanthinaḥ
translated: He states the reason for the necessity of practicing yama thus: 'dosa' etc.🔽The faults are eternally connected with the soul and are obstacles to liberation.

original: santyeva prāyaśaḥ puṃsu tena mokṣo na jāyate // / / //
analyzed: santi eva prāyaśas puṃsu tena mokṣaḥ na jāyate
translated: They exist mostly in men, therefore liberation does not occur.

original: te viṣṇubhaktyabhāvādyā viṣayasaṃsargādyāśca doṣā muktiparipanthinaḥ prācuryeṇa puruṣeṣvanādisambandhāḥ santyeva /
analyzed: te viṣṇu bhakti abhāva ādyāḥ viṣaya saṃsarga ādyāḥ ca doṣāḥ mukti paripanthinaḥ prācuryeṇa puruṣeṣu anādi sambandhāḥ santi eva
translated: Those faults, such as lack of devotion to Vishnu and association with objects, which obstruct liberation, are indeed eternally connected with men.

original: tena kāraṇena teṣāṃ mokṣo na jāyate /
analyzed: tena kāraṇena teṣām mokṣaḥ na jāyate
translated: For that reason, their liberation does not occur.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: mokṣa yogyānām mumukṣūṇām api idānīm tāvat mokṣaḥ na jāyate
translated: Even now, liberation does not occur for those fit for liberation, those who desire liberation.

analyzed: tat kutas iti cintyam
translated: The question arises: why is that?

analyzed: bhagavat prasāda abhāvāt iti ced saḥ pi kutas
translated: If it is said: due to lack of grace from the Lord, then why is that?

analyzed: jñāna abhāvāt iti ced asau api kutas
translated: If it is said: due to lack of knowledge, then why is that?

analyzed: dhyāna abhyāsa asattvāt iti ced na
translated: If it is said: due to lack of practice of meditation, that is not so.

analyzed: vidveṣiṇām tad sattve pi asattvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because even for those who hate [the Lord], it will be said that it does not exist.

original: api ca dhyānābhyāso 'pi kuto neti vācyam /
analyzed: api ca dhyāna abhyāsaḥ kutas na iti vācyam
translated: Moreover, it must be said: why is there no practice of meditation?

analyzed: śravaṇa ādi abhāvāt iti ced
translated: If it is said: due to lack of listening and so on,

analyzed: tad bhāvaḥ pi na kutas
translated: then why is that existence also not so?

original: ato doṣā eva tattadutpattiṃ pratibadhnanto mokṣaparipanthina iti jñāyate /
analyzed: atas doṣāḥ eva tad tad utpattim pratibadhnantaḥ mokṣa paripanthinaḥ iti jñāyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that the faults themselves, obstructing the arising of that and that, are obstacles to liberation.

original: na ca doṣāṇāmāgantukānāmanādimokṣābhāvahetutvaṃ na sambhavatīti sāmpratam /
analyzed: na ca doṣāṇām āgantukānām anādi mokṣa abhāva hetu tvam na sambhavati iti sāmpratam
translated: And it is not right that the adventitious faults cannot be the cause of the beginningless absence of liberation.

analyzed: pravāhataḥ na ādi tvāt iti
translated: Because of beginninglessness in the stream.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam
translated: And it is said thus:

analyzed: doṣa gṛhīta guṇām iti
translated: Those whose qualities are seized by faults.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: santi kecid saṃsāriṇaḥ rāga ādi doṣa rahitāḥ jīvāḥ bāla mugdha ādayaḥ
translated: There are some living beings in saṃsāra who are free from faults like passion, such as children, fools, etc.

original: tatkathaṃ doṣāṇāṃ mokṣābhāvahetutvamityata āha sarva iti //
analyzed: tat katham doṣāṇām mokṣa abhāva hetu tvam iti atas āha sarve iti
translated: How then is it that faults are the cause of the absence of liberation? To this he says 'all' etc.

original: sarve ta ete jīveṣu dṛśyante tāratamyataḥ // / / //
analyzed: sarve te ete jīveṣu dṛśyante tāratamyataḥ
translated: All these are seen in living beings in varying degrees.

original: udāhṛteṣvapi bālamugdhādijīveṣu ta ete magavadbhaktyabhāvādyā doṣāstāvatpratyakṣānumānābhyāṃ dṛśyanta eva /
analyzed: udāhṛteṣu api bāla mugdha ādi jīveṣu te ete magavat bhakti abhāva ādyāḥ doṣāḥ tāvat pratyakṣa anumānābhyām dṛśyante eva
translated: Even in the living beings mentioned, such as children, fools, etc., these faults beginning with the absence of devotion to the Lord are indeed seen by perception and inference.

analyzed: rāga dveṣa ādayaḥ pi puruṣeṣu tāratamyataḥ santi
translated: Passion, hatred, etc. also exist in men in varying degrees.

analyzed: caturvidhāḥ hi te prasupta tanu vicchinna udāra bhedena
translated: For they are of four kinds, distinguished as dormant, small, interrupted, and great.

analyzed: atas bāla ādiṣu udārāṇām teṣām abhāvāt abhāva abhimānaḥ
translated: Therefore, in children and others, due to the absence of those great ones, there is the conception of non-existence.

analyzed: stanya ādi kāma ādeḥ teṣu api darśanāt tathā ca āgamaḥ
translated: And because desire for breast milk and so on is seen even in them, so says the scripture:

analyzed: garbhe bālye pi a pauṣkalyāt ityādiḥ
translated: 'In the womb and even in childhood, due to lack of maturity,' and so on.

original: tadevaṃ sarve 'pi doṣāḥ sarveṣvapi pramitā iti yuktamuktam /
analyzed: tat evam sarve doṣāḥ sarveṣu api pramitāḥ iti yuktam uktam
translated: Thus, since all faults are indeed ascertained in all, it is rightly said.

analyzed: atha api syāt
translated: Now, this may be said:

original: ṛjavo nāma hiraṇyagarbhapadaprāptiyogyāḥ santi saṃsāriṇaḥ puruṣāḥ /
analyzed: ṛjavaḥ nāma hiraṇyagarbha pada prāpti yogyāḥ santi saṃsāriṇaḥ puruṣāḥ
translated: There are men in saṃsāra who are fit for attaining the state of Brahmā.

analyzed: na ca te doṣiṇaḥ iti yuktam
translated: And it is not right to say that they are faulty.

analyzed: ṛju tva virodhāt
translated: Because it is contrary to their being straightforward.

analyzed: ṛjavaḥ samīcīnāḥ iti anarthāntaram
translated: Straightforward, upright, and faultless are synonymous.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha ṛjūnām iti
translated: How is this? To this he says:

analyzed: ṛjūnām ekaḥ eva asti parama utsāha varjanam
translated: For the straightforward, there is only one, the avoidance of supreme enthusiasm.

original: ṛjūnāmapi mokṣārthaṃ mahodyogavarjanaṃ nāma doṣo 'stītyato noktamayuktam /
analyzed: ṛjūnām api mokṣa artham mahā udyoga varjanam nāma doṣaḥ sti iti atas na uktam ayuktam
translated: Even for the straightforward, there is a fault called the avoidance of great effort for the sake of liberation. Therefore, what was said is not improper.

analyzed: anyathā mokṣa vilamba asambhavāt
translated: Otherwise, the delay in liberation would be impossible.

analyzed: na ca evam ṛju tva virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with being straightforward in this way.

analyzed: yatas sau ekaḥ eva  doṣa bāhulya abhāva abhiprāyam ṛju tva vacanam
translated: Because that is only one.🔽The statement about being straightforward is intended to show the absence of many faults.

analyzed: alpa sve niḥsva prayoga darśanāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it is seen that those with little wealth engage in activities for the sake of wealth.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa virodham pariharati saḥ iti
translated: In another way, he avoids the contradiction, saying that (s).

analyzed: sa guṇa alpa tva mātra tvāt na ṛju tvena viruddhayate
translated: That is not contradicted by being straightforward due to the mere smallness of the qualities.

analyzed: sa parama utsāha varjanam nāma doṣaḥ
translated: That is the fault called the avoidance of supreme enthusiasm.

analyzed: yadi api mahā udyama abhāvaḥ doṣaḥ eva heya tvāt
translated: Although the absence of great effort is indeed a fault because it is to be abandoned,

analyzed: tathā api na rāga ādiḥ iva bhāva rūpaḥ
translated: nevertheless, it is not of the nature of existence like attachment and so on.

analyzed: na api guṇa abhāva rūpaḥ
translated: Nor is it of the nature of the absence of qualities.

analyzed: kinnāma utsāha lakṣaṇa guṇa alpa tā mātram iti adoṣaḥ pi ucyate iti na ṛju tvena
translated: Is it merely the smallness of the qualities characterized by enthusiasm? Thus, it is said to be faultless, and so it is not contradicted as being unrighteous.

original: kimato yadyevaṃ doṣāḥ saṃsārahetavo muktiparipanthina ityata āha ata iti //
analyzed: kim atas yadi evam doṣāḥ saṃsāra hetavaḥ mukti paripanthinaḥ iti atas āha atas iti
translated: What then? If it is so, that faults are the cause of worldly existence and obstruct liberation, therefore it is said ataḥ (therefore).

analyzed: atas viṣṇau parā bhaktiḥ tad bhakteṣu rama ādiṣu
translated: Therefore, devotion to Viṣṇu and to his devotees like Ramā,

analyzed: tāratamyena kartavyā puruṣa artham abhīpsitā
translated: should be done with gradation, desiring the human goal.

analyzed: idam ca sarva yama upalakṣaṇam
translated: And this is an indication of all the restraints.

analyzed: puruṣa artham mokṣam
translated: The human goal is liberation.

analyzed: ayam atra saṅkṣepaḥ
translated: This is the summary here.

analyzed: viṣṇu bhakti abhāva ādyāḥ viṣaya saṃsarga ādyāḥ ca doṣāḥ mumukṣā ādimatā tyājyāḥ
translated: Faults such as lack of devotion to Viṣṇu and association with objects should be abandoned by one who desires liberation, etc.

analyzed: mokṣa ādi virodhi tvāt
translated: Because they are opposed to liberation, etc.

analyzed: yat yad virodhi tat tat arthinā tyājyam dṛṣṭam
translated: Whatever is opposed, that should be abandoned by one who desires that, as is seen.

analyzed: yathā ārogya virodhi apathyam tad arthinā
translated: Just as unwholesome food, which is opposed to health, is abandoned by one who desires health.

analyzed: tathā ca viṣṇu bhakti ādikam kāryam iti siddhayati
translated: And thus it is established that devotion to Viṣṇu, etc. should be done.

analyzed: bhāva anuṣṭhānena vinābhāva parityāga ayogāt iti
translated: Because it is not possible to abandon a thing without practicing the corresponding attitude.

original: viṣṇau parānyatra tāratamyenetyuktaṃ vivṛṇoti svādara iti //
analyzed: viṣṇau parā anyatra tāratamyena iti uktam vivṛṇoti sva ādare iti
translated: It is said that devotion to Viṣṇu and others should be done with gradation, which is explained by svādaras (own enthusiasm), etc.

analyzed: su ādaraḥ sarva jantūnām saṃsiddhaḥ hi svabhāvataḥ
translated: For all beings, own enthusiasm is indeed established by nature.

analyzed: tatas dhikaḥ sva uttameṣu tad ādhikya anusārataḥ
translated: Then, more than that, in one's own superiors, in accordance with the increase,

analyzed: kartavyaḥ vāsudeva antam sarvathā śubham icchatā
translated: should be made by one who desires all kinds of auspiciousness up to Vāsudeva.

analyzed: ādaraḥ snehaḥ
translated: Respect is affection.

analyzed: svabhāvataḥ saṃsiddhaḥ iti upakāra ādi karaṇam an apekṣya anādi siddhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Naturally accomplished means established from beginningless time without depending on the performance of helpful acts and so on.

original: anyathā sukhinaiva mayā bhāvyaṃ na jātu duḥkhinetyāśīrna syāditi hiśabdārthaḥ /
analyzed: anyathā sukhinā eva mayā bhāvyam na jātu duḥkhinā iti āśīḥ na syāt iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word hi is that otherwise, the wish I should always be happy, never unhappy would not be possible.

analyzed: tatas sva viṣayāt ādarāt adhikaḥ ādaraḥ sākṣāt sva uttameṣu kartavyaḥ
translated: Then, more respect than one's own object should be made directly in one's own superiors.

analyzed: evam teṣām teṣām ādhikya anusārataḥ dhikaḥ kartavyaḥ vāsudeva antam
translated: Thus, in accordance with the increase of each, more should be made up to Vāsudeva.

analyzed: vāsudeve tu niratiśayaḥ
translated: But in Vāsudeva, it is unsurpassed.

analyzed: śubham dhyāna ādikam
translated: Auspiciousness is meditation and so on.

analyzed: etat ca upapāda diṣyate
translated: And this will be explained later.

analyzed: sakṛt anuṣṭheya asakṛt anuṣṭheya sadā anuṣṭheya bhedāt aṅgam anekavidham
translated: The limbs are of many kinds due to the difference of being to be performed once, to be performed repeatedly, and to be constantly performed.

analyzed: ayam tu katham iti apekṣāyām āha na iti
translated: But how is this? When this is expected, he says no (na).

original: na kadācit tyajet taṃ ca krameṇainaṃ vivardhayet // / / //
analyzed: na kadācid tyajet tam ca krameṇa enam vivardhayet
translated: And one should never abandon that, and gradually increase it.

analyzed: tam viṣṇu ādi ādaram
translated: That is the respect for Viṣṇu and others.

original: na kevalaṃ na tyajetkintu kālakrameṇainaṃ vivardhayecca /
analyzed: na kevalam na tyajet kintu kāla krameṇa enam vivardhayet ca
translated: One should not only not abandon it, but should also gradually increase it.

analyzed: svasameṣu svatas dhameṣu ca katham iti apekṣāyām āha sameṣu iti
translated: When there is doubt about how to treat those equal to oneself and those inferior to oneself, he says towards those equal.

original: sameṣu svātmavat snehaḥ satsvanyatra tato dayā /
analyzed: sameṣu sva ātma vat snehaḥ satsu anyatra tatas dayā
translated: Towards those equal, love like towards oneself, towards others than that, compassion.

analyzed: kāryā evam āparokṣyeṇa dṛśyate kṣipram īśvaraḥ
translated: The Lord is seen quickly in this way by one who has the desire for the highest good.

analyzed: kartavyaḥ iti vartate
translated: Should be done is understood.

original: tata uttamasamebhyo 'nyatrādhameṣu satsu dayā kāryā /🔽yadi satsvityevocyeta tadottamasameṣvapi prasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tatas uttama samebhyaḥ nyatra adhameṣu satsu dayā kāryā  yadi satsu iti eva ucyeta tadā uttama sameṣu api prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Compassion should be done towards those who are good, other than those who are equal or superior.🔽If only towards those who are good were said, then there would be the possibility of (compassion) towards those who are equal or superior also.

analyzed: tatas nyatra iti eva uktau asatsu api prasaktiḥ
translated: If only other than that were said, then there would be the possibility of (compassion) towards those who are not good also.

analyzed: tatas varga trayāt anyatra ajñeṣu odāsīnyam
translated: Therefore, towards those who are not in the three classes, towards the ignorant, neutrality.

analyzed: viparīteṣu vaiparītyam ca iti api yojyam
translated: And towards those who are opposite, the opposite should be done - this should also be connected.

original: evaṃ kriyamāṇe yamānāmupāsanotpattau jñānotpāde mokṣatiśaye cāṅgatvamiti sūcanāya puruṣārthamabhīpsatā śubhamicchatā dṛśyate kṣipramīśvara
analyzed: evam kriyamāṇe yamānām upāsana utpattau jñāna utpāde mokṣa atiśaye ca aṅga tvam iti sūcanāya puruṣa artham abhīpsatā śubham icchatā dṛśyate kṣipram īśvara
translated: When this is done, in order to indicate that the observances are subsidiary in the production of knowledge, in the production of knowledge, and in the excellence of liberation, the Lord is seen quickly by one who desires the highest good.

analyzed: iti vicitra uktiḥ
translated: This is said in various ways.

analyzed: atas eva upasaṃhāre trayasya api saṅkīrtanam
translated: For this very reason, in the conclusion, all three are mentioned.

analyzed: doṣa parityāge pi asti viśeṣaḥ
translated: Even in the abandonment of faults, there is a difference.

analyzed: rāga ādayaḥ hi saṃsāram ātanvate
translated: For attachment and so on weave the cycle of birth and death.

original: viparītajñānādayastu nityaṃ narakaṃ prāpayantītyato rāgādito 'tiśayena tyājyā ityāśayavāṃstatra śrutimāha taditi //
analyzed: viparīta jñāna ādayaḥ tu nityam narakam prāpayanti iti atas rāga ādeḥ utiśayena tyājyāḥ iti āśayavān tatra śrutim āha tat iti
translated: But wrong knowledge etc. always lead to hell. Therefore, with the intention that they are to be abandoned more than attachment etc., he quotes the scripture there as tat.

analyzed: tat tamaḥ vrajet viṣṇu sama tvam yaḥ nupaśyati
translated: One who sees Vishnu as equal would go to that blind darkness.

analyzed: ramā brahma śiva ādīnām api muktau kathañcana
translated: Even in the case of Lakshmi, Brahma, Shiva etc., in any way,

analyzed: kim uta ādhikya dṛṣṭeḥ tat guṇa abhāva mateḥ api
translated: what to speak of one who sees superiority, and also of one who thinks Vishnu has no qualities,

analyzed: doṣa vettuḥ abhedasya draṣṭuḥ draṣṭuḥ tathā ubhayoḥ
translated: of one who knows faults, of one who sees non-difference between the seer and the seen, and of one who sees both in that way,

analyzed: iti āha sat śrutiḥ
translated: thus says the true scripture.

analyzed: tat prasiddham
translated: That is well-known.

original: na kevalaṃ saṃsāre kintu muktāvapi kathañcana kenāpi dharmeṇa samatvam /
analyzed: na kevalam saṃsāre kintu muktau api kathañcana kena api dharmeṇa samatvam
translated: Not only in the world, but even in liberation, in any way, by any means, equality.

analyzed: ramā brahma śiva ādīnām viṣṇoḥ ādhikya dṛṣṭeḥ puruṣasya andhatamasā avāptiḥ bhavati iti kim uta iti yojyam
translated: One who sees Vishnu as superior to Lakshmi, Brahma, Shiva etc. would attain blind darkness. What to speak of one who sees superiority, one should be joined with would attain.

analyzed: viṣṇoḥ guṇa abhāva mateḥ viṣṇoḥ jīvaiḥ jaḍaiḥ ca abhedasya draṣṭuḥ
translated: Of one who thinks Vishnu has no qualities, of one who sees non-difference between Vishnu and the individual souls and the insentient.

analyzed: ubhayoḥ bheda abhedayoḥ
translated: Of both difference and non-difference.

analyzed: sva pakṣa sādhanam upasaṃharati tena iti
translated: He concludes the proof of his own position with tenaiva.

analyzed: tena samprokta guṇa saṃyutam
translated: Therefore, endowed with the qualities mentioned.

original: upāsīta hariṃ dṛṣṭvā muktistenaiva jāyate // / /d // /🔽prāk samproktairviṣayasaṃsargavarjanādibhirguṇaiḥ saṃyutaḥ /
analyzed: upāsīta harim dṛṣṭvā muktiḥ tena eva jāyate  prāk samproktaiḥ viṣaya saṃsarga varjana ādibhiḥ guṇaiḥ saṃyutaḥ
translated: By seeing Hari through that very [devotion], liberation is attained.🔽Endowed with the qualities such as avoidance of association with objects etc. mentioned earlier.

analyzed: yat vā yoga śāstre samproktaiḥ yama ādibhiḥ guṇaiḥ aṅgaiḥ saṃyutaḥ
translated: Or, endowed with the qualities such as yama etc. mentioned in the Yoga scriptures, which are the limbs.

original: tenaiva tathāvidhenaivopāsena hariṃ dṛṣṭvā karmāṇi kṣapayato muktirjāyate /
analyzed: tena eva tathāvidhena eva upāsena harim dṛṣṭvā karmāṇi kṣapayataḥ muktiḥ jāyate
translated: By that very such devotion, by seeing Hari, liberation is attained for one who destroys his actions.

original: idānīṃ yatpūrvapakṣiṇoktaṃ bhagavaddveṣiṇāmapi purāṇe muktiḥ kathyata iti tannirākaroti dveṣāditi //
analyzed: idānīm yat pūrvapakṣiṇā uktam bhagavat dveṣiṇām api purāṇe muktiḥ kathyate iti tat nirākaroti dveṣāt iti
translated: Now, he refutes what was stated by the proponents of the prima facie view, that even for those who hate the Lord, liberation is described in the Puranas. He says because of hatred etc.

analyzed: dveṣāt yat mukti kathanam śruti vākya virodhi yat
translated: That description of liberation due to hatred, which is contrary to the statements of the Vedas,

analyzed: tasmāt anyathā vyākhyātavyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, it should be explained in another way - this is the idea.

analyzed: tad prakāram ca vakṣyati
translated: And he will state the manner of that.

original: kiṃ tacchativākyamityatomā nastenebhyo ye abhidruhaspade nirāmiṇo ripavo 'nneṣu jāgṛdhuḥ' /
analyzed: kim tat śativākyam iti atomāḥ nastenebhyaḥ ye abhidruhaḥ pade nirāmiṇaḥ ripavaḥ nneṣu jāgṛdhuḥ
translated: What is that statement of the Vedas? Therefore, he recites the meaning of this: Those who hate them at every step, the enemies who are devoid of food, are awake in the foods.

analyzed: iti etad arthataḥ paṭhati ripavaḥ iti
translated: He recites the meaning of this as enemies.

analyzed: ripavaḥ ye tu rāmasya vimukha tvāt nirāmiṇaḥ
translated: But those who are enemies of Rama, due to turning away from him, are devoid of food.

analyzed: abhidroha pade nityam andhe tamasi te sthitāḥ
translated: They always dwell in blinding darkness at the step of hostility.

analyzed: hari dviṣaḥ tamaḥ yānti ye ca eva tad abhedinaḥ
translated: And those who are not different from them go to darkness.

analyzed: tad nirguṇa tva vettāraḥ tasya doṣa vidaḥ api ca
translated: And those who know him to be without qualities, and those who know his faults,

original: rāmo ramaṇaṃ tadasyāstīti rāmī bhagavannāmastasmānniṣkrāntāstasya vimukhā nirāmiṇa ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: rāmaḥ ramaṇam tat asya asti iti rāmī bhagavat nāmaḥ tasmāt niṣkrāntāḥ tasya vimukhāḥ nirāmiṇaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Rama is one who delights in that, thus Rama is the name of the Lord. Those who have turned away from him are called nirāmiṇa, meaning those who are devoid of him.

analyzed: atas eva tasya ripavaḥ
translated: For this very reason, they are his enemies.

analyzed: abhidroha pade iti asya eva vyākhyānam andha itamasi iti
translated: The explanation of the word abhi-droha-pada is in the blinding darkness.

analyzed: nityam sthitāḥ bhavanti iti śeṣa uktiḥ
translated: The addition always remain is implied.

original: anena ye nirāmiṇo ripavo 'nneṣu bhogeṣu jāgṛdhurabhikāṅkṣāvantaste 'bhidruho 'bhito drohasya pade sthāne sthātuṃ yogyā yato 'tastebhyaḥ stenebhyo
analyzed: anena ye nirāmiṇaḥ ripavaḥ nneṣu bhogeṣu jāgṛdhuḥ abhikāṅkṣāvantaḥ te bhidruhaḥ bhitas drohasya pade sthāne sthātum yogyāḥ tastebhyaḥ stenebhyaḥ
translated: By this, those who are nirāmiṇa, enemies, who are greedy for enjoyments in food, who are desirous, are fit to stand in the place of abhi-droha, all-around hostility. Therefore, from those thieves,

analyzed: smāt mā avocaḥ
translated: do not speak of us.

analyzed: na hi asmad śravaṇavān duḥkham arhati iti yojanā sūcitā bhavati
translated: For one who hears this is not worthy of suffering - this construction is indicated.

original: idaṃ ca vāyuṃ prati vidyādevatāyā vacanam /
analyzed: idam ca vāyum prati vidyā devatāyāḥ vacanam
translated: And this is the statement of the knowledge deity to Vayu.

analyzed: tad abhedinaḥ tasya hareḥ jīva ādi abheda vādinaḥ
translated: Those who are not different from him, who propound the non-difference of the individual soul and so on from that Hari,

analyzed: katham etad śati virodhaḥ iti atas āha ityādi iti
translated: How is there a contradiction with the Śruti? To this he says thus and so on.

analyzed: ityādi śruti sandarbhāt dveṣiṇaḥ tamaḥ īyate
translated: Thus and so on, from the collection of Śruti passages, the haters go to darkness.

original: smṛtiviruddhaṃ ca dveṣiṇāṃ mokṣakathanamityāśayavāṃstāḥ paṭhati hiraṇyakaśipuśceti //
analyzed: smṛti viruddham ca dveṣiṇām mokṣa kathanam iti āśayavān tāḥ paṭhati hiraṇyakaśipuḥ ca iti
translated: And it is contrary to the Smritis to say that haters attain liberation. With this intention he recites the story of Hiranyakasipu.

analyzed: hiraṇyakaśipuḥ ca api bhagavat nindayā tamaḥ
translated: And Hiranyakasipu also, O Lord, by reviling You,

analyzed: vidhikṣuḥ atyagāt sūno prahlādasya anubhāvataḥ
translated: attained darkness, O Lord, by the power of his son Prahlada.

original: yadanindat pitā mahyaṃ tvadbhakte mayi cāghavān /
analyzed: yat anindat pitā mahyam tvad bhakte mayi ca aghavān
translated: Since my sinful father reviled You, O Lord, in me, Your devotee,

original: tasmāt pitā me pūyeta durantād dustarādaghāt // / / //
analyzed: tasmāt pitā me pūyeta durantāt dustarāt aghāt
translated: therefore may my father be purified from that great and difficult sin.

analyzed: nindām bhagavataḥ śṛṇvan tad parasya janasya vā
translated: He who does not turn away from hearing the reviling of the Lord or of one devoted to Him,

original: tato nāpaiti yaḥ so 'pi yātyaghaḥ sukṛtāccyutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: tatas na apaiti yaḥ saḥ u pi yāti aghaḥ sukṛtāt cyutaḥ
translated: that sin of his also departs, falling away from his good deeds.

analyzed: avajānanti mām mūḍhāḥ mānuṣīm tanum āśritam
translated: The foolish ones disregard Me, who have taken up a human body,

original: paraṃ bhāvamajānanto mama bhūtamaheśvaram // / / //🔽moghāśā moghakarmāṇo moghajñānā vicetasaḥ /
analyzed: param bhāvam a jānantaḥ mama bhūta maheśvaram  mogha āśāḥ mogha karmāṇaḥ mogha jñānāḥ vicetasaḥ
translated: not knowing My supreme nature as the great Lord of all beings.🔽Their desires are futile, their actions are futile, their knowledge is futile, their minds are confused,

analyzed: rākṣasīm āsurīm ca eva prakṛtim mohanīm śritāḥ
translated: they have resorted to the deluding natures of the Rakshasa and Asura.

analyzed: mām ātma para deheṣu pradviṣantaḥ bhyasūyakāḥ
translated: They who hate Me and are envious in the bodies of themselves and others,

analyzed: tān aham dviṣataḥ krūrān saṃsāreṣu nara adhamān
translated: those haters, those cruel ones, the worst of men, I cast into the demoniacal nature again and again.

analyzed: kṣipāmi ajasram aśubhān āsurīṣu eva yoniṣu
translated: I cast them off incessantly into the very wombs of demons.

analyzed: āsurīm yonim āpannāḥ mūḍhāḥ janmani janmani
translated: Having attained the demoniac nature, deluded in birth after birth,

analyzed: mām a prāpya eva kaunteya tatas yānti adhamām gatim
translated: not attaining Me, O son of Kunti, they then go to the lowest state.

original: yo dviṣṭād vibudhaśreṣṭhaṃ devaṃ nārāyaṇaṃ prabhum /
analyzed: yaḥ dviṣṭāt vibudha śreṣṭham devam nārāyaṇam prabhum
translated: He who hates the best of gods, Lord Narayana,

original: kathaṃ sa na bhaved dveṣya ālokāntasya kasyacit // / / //
analyzed: katham sa na bhavet dveṣyaḥ āloka antasya kasyacid
translated: how can he not be hated by anyone until the end of worldly existence?

original: yo dviṣṭād vibudhaśreṣṭhaṃ devaṃ nārāyaṇaṃ prabhum /
analyzed: yaḥ dviṣṭāt vibudha śreṣṭham devam nārāyaṇam prabhum
translated: He who hates the best of gods, Lord Narayana,

analyzed: majjanti pitaraḥ tasya narake śāśvatīḥ samāḥ
translated: his ancestors sink into hell for eternal years.

analyzed: ityādi vākya sandohāt dveṣiṇaḥ tamaḥ eva tu
translated: Thus, from the collection of such statements, the hater goes to darkness alone.

analyzed: vivikṣuḥ veśana sambhāvanā viṣayaḥ
translated: One who is about to die is the object of the possibility of entering.

analyzed: āśaṅkāyām acetaneṣu upasaṅkhayānam iti vacanāt
translated: Because of the statement In doubt, there is enumeration regarding insentient things.

analyzed: śvā mumūrṣati iti yathā
translated: Like The dog is about to die.

analyzed: a tyāgāt tamaḥ
translated: Darkness is due to non-abandonment.

analyzed: mama pitā mahyam mad nimittam tvam anindat
translated: My father, for my sake, blamed you.

analyzed: mayi mad viṣaye ca aghavān aparādhavān
translated: In me and in my realm, he was sinful, guilty.

analyzed: tasmāt viṣṇu vaiṣṇava nindā aparādha jāt aghāt nitya nirayāt
translated: Therefore, from the eternal hell arising from the sin of blaming Vishnu and his devotees,

analyzed: nindā ādikam ca dveṣa mūlam iti prasiddham eva
translated: and blaming etc. are well-known to have hatred as their root.

analyzed: naraharim prati prahlādasya vākyam idam
translated: This is the statement of Prahlada to Narahari.

analyzed: tatas sthānāt
translated: From that place.

analyzed: nindām śṛṇvataḥ yadā adhaḥpātaḥ tadā nindakasya kimu
translated: When there is downfall for one who hears slander, then what about the slanderer?

analyzed: mānuṣīm manuṣya sadṛśīm
translated: Human, like a human.

analyzed: ye mām avajānanti te mogha āśādimantaḥ bhavanti
translated: Those who despise me have vain desires and so on.

analyzed: teṣām sukha leśaḥ pi na bhavati
translated: They do not have even a bit of happiness.

analyzed: ātma para deheṣu preraka tvena sthitam
translated: It exists as the instigator in one's own and others' bodies.

analyzed: saṃsaranti atra iti saṃsārāḥ dehāḥ
translated: The bodies that wander here are saṃsāra.

analyzed: tasya vivaraṇam āsurīṣu eva ityādi
translated: The explanation of that is only in the demonesses and so on.

analyzed: lokaḥ janaḥ tasya antaḥ caṇḍāla ādiḥ tad paryantasya
translated: The world is the people, and the end of that is the outcaste and so on.

analyzed: katham etad smṛti virodhaḥ iti atas āha ityādi iti
translated: How is there a contradiction with Smṛti? To this he says thus and so on.

analyzed: ityādi vākya sandohāt dveṣiṇaḥ tamaḥ eva tu
translated: Thus, from the collection of statements beginning with thus, the haters are indeed only in darkness.

analyzed: jñāyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is understood.

analyzed: nirutthānam iti tuśabdaḥ  atas yama ādi aṅgam avaśya anuṣṭheyam iti siddham
translated: And darkness is also without origination. The word but (is used).🔽Therefore, it is established that the limbs such as yama must be necessarily performed.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām anubandha adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the Anubandha Adhikarana in the auspicious Nyaya Sudha.
IV. The Vidhya Adhikarana

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām vidyā adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the auspicious Nyaya Sudha, the Vidhya Adhikarana.

analyzed: om vidyā eva tu nirdhāraṇāt om
translated: Om. But only knowledge, because of the determination.

original: yadyapīdamadhikaraṇamanubandhādibhya ityataḥ pūrvaṃ tathāpyupāsanasvarūpāvagame satyeva tatsātharkyasamarthanasyāvasaro nānyatheti vyutkrameṇa
analyzed: yadi api idam adhikaraṇam anubandha ādibhyaḥ iti atas pūrvam tathā api upāsana svarūpa avagame sati eva tad sātharkya samarthanasya avasaraḥ na anyathā iti vyutkrameṇa
translated: Although this section comes after the section on the basis of connection etc., still, only when the nature of meditation is understood, there is an occasion to establish its rationality, not otherwise. Therefore, in reverse order,

analyzed: vyākhyātam
translated: Although this section comes before because of connection, etc., still, only when the nature of meditation is understood, there is an opportunity to establish its purpose, not otherwise. Therefore, it is explained in reverse order.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus it is.

analyzed: na bhagavat upāsanam kartavyam vaiyarthyāt
translated: Indeed, meditation on the Lord should not be done, because it is useless.

analyzed: na ca sākṣātkāra artham
translated: Nor is it for the sake of direct realization.

analyzed: tasya api vyartha tvāt
translated: Because that also is useless.

analyzed: na ca mokṣa prayojanā sau iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that it is for the sake of liberation.
Because liberation itself does not exist according to the Cārvāka view.

original: bhāve vā jainādimatānusāreṇa sādhanāntarasādhyatvāditi prāpte mokṣasadbhāvaṃ tasyāpi bhagavaddarśanasādhyatvaṃ ca sādhayitumidamārabhyate /
analyzed: bhāve vā jaina ādi mata anusāreṇa sādhana antara sādhya tvāt iti prāpte mokṣa sadbhāvam tasya api bhagavat darśana sādhya tvam ca sādhayitum idam ārabhyate
translated: Or if it exists, it is to be accomplished by other means according to the Jaina and other doctrines. This being the case, this is begun in order to establish the existence of liberation and also that it is to be accomplished by the vision of the Lord.

analyzed: yadi api samaya pāde cārvāka ādi matāni nirākṛtāni
translated: Although the Cārvāka and other doctrines have been refuted in the section on time,

analyzed: tathā api mokṣa tad sādhana viyat ūṣaṇa viśeṣa vyutpādana arthaḥ yam prayatnaḥ
translated: nevertheless, this effort is made in order to explain the special refutation of liberation and its means.

analyzed: tatra cārvāka matam tāvat anuvadati na eva iti
translated: Among them, he first repeats the Cārvāka view with naiva.

analyzed: vidyā eva tu nirdhāraṇāt
translated: But it is knowledge alone, because of the specification.

analyzed: na eva mokṣaḥ iti prāhuḥ lokāyata mate sthitāḥ
translated: Those who adhere to the Lokāyata doctrine say that there is no liberation at all.

analyzed: eva śabdaḥ svarūpa niṣedha dyotana arthaḥ
translated: The word 'eva' (only) is used to indicate the negation of the form.

analyzed: anyathā puruṣa viśeṣa ādi sambandhena niṣedhaḥ pi jñāyeta
translated: Otherwise, the negation could be understood in relation to a particular person and so on.

analyzed: tasmāt upāsanam vyartham iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the remainder is that meditation is useless.

original: tarhi kaḥ puruṣārtho 'stītyata āha bhoga iti //
analyzed: tarhi kaḥ puruṣa arthaḥ sti iti atas āha bhogaḥ iti
translated: Then what is the human goal? To this he says 'enjoyment' etc.

analyzed: bhogaḥ
translated: Enjoyment is...

original: srakcandanādiviṣayasukhānubhavo bhogaḥ sa puruṣārtho 'stīti prāhuriti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: srak candana ādi viṣaya sukha anubhavaḥ bhogaḥ sa puruṣa arthaḥ sti iti prāhuḥ iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The experience of pleasure in objects like garlands, sandalwood etc. is enjoyment. That is the human goal, they say. This is the connection.

original: bhogaścaihika eva na tu svargādigata ityāha śarīreti //
analyzed: bhogaḥ ca aihikaḥ eva na tu svarga ādi gataḥ iti āha śarīra iti
translated: And enjoyment is only in this world, not in heaven etc. He says 'as long as the body' etc.

analyzed: śarīra paryantam
translated: As long as the body...

analyzed: śarīrapāta paryantam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is up to the fall of the body.

analyzed: kutas svarga apavargayoḥ asattvam iti atas āha bhasmībhāvaḥ iti
translated: From where do heaven and liberation not exist? To this he says 'becoming ashes' etc.

analyzed: bhasmībhāvaḥ tatas bhavet
translated: Becoming ashes would then be...

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus...

analyzed: tatas pāta anantaram śarīrasya bhasmībhāvaḥ bhavet
translated: After that, the body would become ashes.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: śarīrapāta uttara kālam ātmanaḥ svarga apavargau vaktavyau
translated: Heaven and liberation of the self should be stated after the fall of the body.

analyzed: ātmā ca na śarīra atiriktaḥ sti
translated: And the self does not exist apart from the body.

analyzed: śarīram ca pāta uttara kālam naśyati eva
translated: And the body perishes after the fall.

analyzed: tatas kasya tau syātām iti
translated: Then whose would they be?

analyzed: iti prāhuḥ iti sambandhaḥ  śaṅkā samāptau vā iti śabdaḥ
translated: The connection is: thus they say.🔽The word iti is at the end of the doubt.

analyzed: tat etat pramāṇa abhāvena dūṣayan tāvat pṛcchati tat iti
translated: Refuting this with the absence of a means of valid knowledge, he asks first: That...

analyzed: tat kena mānena dṛṣṭam
translated: By what means of valid knowledge is it seen...

analyzed: mokṣaḥ na eva asti iti vākya artham tat iti parāmṛśati
translated: ...that there is no liberation at all? He refers to the meaning of the sentence with the word tat.

analyzed: kena mānena iti
translated: By what means of valid knowledge?

analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa vā tad itareṇa vā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: either by perception or by something else.

analyzed: dṛṣṭam avagatam
translated: Seen means known.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ tāvat cārvākeṇa na aṅgīkartum śakyate iti āśayavān āha pratyakṣa iti  pratyakṣa vādinā
translated: Thinking that the second cannot be accepted by the Cārvāka, he says: By perception...

analyzed: pratyakṣam ekam eva pramāṇam na anyat iti abhyupagacchatā
translated: By one who maintains that perception is the only means of valid knowledge, not another.

analyzed: pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with the previous.

analyzed: ādyam nirākaroti nahi iti
translated: He refutes the first with: For...

analyzed: nahi pratyakṣa mānena mokṣa abhāvaḥ vasīyate
translated: For the absence of liberation is not ascertained by the means of valid knowledge of perception...

analyzed: anumāna ādikam tāvat parasya mānam na bhavati
translated: Inference etc. are not a means of valid knowledge for the opponent.

analyzed: yat ca māna tvena aṅgīkṛtam pratyakṣam tena iti yāvat
translated: And what is accepted as a means of valid knowledge, namely perception, by that, up to here.

analyzed: mokṣaḥ hi nāma paramānanda avāpti viśiṣya ātyantikī duḥkha nivṛttiḥ
translated: Liberation is indeed the cessation of suffering distinguished by the attainment of supreme bliss.

analyzed: tad abhāvaḥ ca evam avagantavyaḥ
translated: And the non-existence of that should be understood in the same way.

original: nāsti ko 'pi puruṣaḥ paramānandānubhavī sarvo 'pi duḥkhī ceti /
analyzed: na asti kaḥ pi puruṣaḥ parama ānanda anubhavī sarvaḥ pi duḥkhī ca iti
translated: There is no person at all who experiences supreme bliss, but everyone is miserable.

original: naca puruṣāntaravartinī sukhaduḥkhe tadabhāvau vā puruṣāntarapratyakṣaviṣayāviti kathaṃ mokṣābhāvaḥ pratyakṣeṇāvasīyeteti hiśabdārthaḥ / /
analyzed: na ca puruṣa antara vartinī sukha duḥkhe tad abhāvau vā puruṣa antara pratyakṣa viṣayau iti katham mokṣa abhāvaḥ pratyakṣeṇa avasīyeta iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: And the happiness and suffering or their non-existence that exist in another person are not the objects of the perception of another person. So how can the non-existence of liberation be ascertained by perception? This is the meaning of the word indeed.

analyzed: mā bhūt pramāṇa abhāvena mokṣa abhāva niścayaḥ
translated: Let there be no certainty of the non-existence of liberation due to the absence of a means of knowledge.

analyzed: tad sadbhāva niścayaḥ durghaṭaḥ eva
translated: But the certainty of its existence here is indeed difficult to accomplish.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because of the absence of a means of knowledge.

analyzed: tāvat tatra pratyakṣam pramāṇam
translated: To begin with, perception is a means of knowledge in that matter.

analyzed: para puruṣa vartinoḥ parama ānanda duḥkha abhāvayoḥ para pratyakṣasya sāmarthya abhāvāt
translated: Because the perception of another person is not capable of the non-existence of supreme bliss and suffering that exist in another person.

analyzed: sva niṣṭhaḥ tu tad abhāvaḥ eva pratyakṣeṇa ukṣyate
translated: But the non-existence of that in one's own self is indeed seen by perception.

analyzed: na api pratyakṣāt anyat
translated: Nor is it anything other than perception.

analyzed: tad prāmāṇya siddheḥ
translated: Because the validity of that is established.

original: tataśca sādhakabādhakapramāṇābhāvādapratipattirnityasaṃśayo vā mokṣe syāditi nopāsanānuṣṭhānaṃ sambhavatīti /
analyzed: tatas ca sādhaka bādhaka pramāṇa abhāvāt apratipattiḥ nitya saṃśayaḥ vā mokṣe syāt iti nā upāsana anuṣṭhānam sambhavati iti
translated: And therefore, due to the absence of a means of knowledge that establishes or refutes it, there would be non-understanding or constant doubt regarding liberation. So the performance of meditation is not possible.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa tāvat mokṣa niścaya upapatteḥ
translated: Because the ascertainment of liberation is possible by perception.

original: nanūktamatra pratyakṣasya tatra sāmarthyaṃ nāstīti tatrāha ghaṭata iti //
analyzed: nanu uktam atra pratyakṣasya tatra sāmarthyam na asti iti tatra āha ghaṭataḥ iti
translated: But it has been said that perception has no power in that case. There, he says it is possible.

analyzed: ghaṭate mukti dṛṣṭiḥ tu puruṣeṇa mahīyasā
translated: But the vision of liberation by the great person is possible.

original: yadyapi prākṛtānāṃ pratyakṣaṃ na mokṣaṃ gocarayituṃ kṣamate /
analyzed: yadi api prākṛtānām pratyakṣam na mokṣam gocarayitum kṣamate
translated: Even though the perception of ordinary people is not able to experience liberation,

analyzed: tathā api mahattama puruṣa pratyakṣeṇa mokṣa niścayaḥ yujyate eva
translated: still, the ascertainment of liberation by the perception of the greatest person is indeed proper.

analyzed: tadīya pratyakṣa avagamaḥ ca pareṣām tad vākyena bhaviṣyati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the understanding of his perception will be for others through his words. This is the idea.

original: nanu kartṛkarmaṇoḥ kṛtītyatra ṣaṣṭhayā bhavitavyaṃ kathaṃ tṛtīyā /
analyzed: nanu kartṛ karmaṇoḥ kṛti iti atra ṣaṣṭhayā bhavitavyam katham tṛtīyā
translated: But in kṛti (doing) of the agent and object, the genitive case should be used. How is the instrumental case used?

analyzed: śeṣa vivakṣāyām ṣaṣṭhī vihitā
translated: The genitive case is prescribed when there is an idea of remainder.

analyzed: na ca atra śeṣa vivakṣā iti ced na
translated: And here there is no idea of remainder. If this is said, it is not so.

analyzed: asmin yoge śeṣa grahaṇasya nivṛtta tvāt
translated: Because in this yoga, the use of the word remainder is excluded.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: hetau eṣā tṛtīyā
translated: This instrumental case is in the cause.

analyzed: na kartari karaṇe vā
translated: Not in the agent or instrument.

original: mahīyasā puruṣeṇa hetunā karaṇena vā tadīyapratyakṣeṇeti yāvat /🔽itareṣāṃ muktidṛṣṭirmuktisadbhāvaniścayo ghaṭata iti /
analyzed: mahīyasā puruṣeṇa hetunā karaṇena vā tadīya pratyakṣeṇa iti yāvat  itareṣām mukti dṛṣṭiḥ mukti sadbhāva niścayaḥ ghaṭate iti
translated: By the great person, by the cause or instrument, that is, by his perception, up to that.🔽The vision of liberation of others, the ascertainment of the existence of liberation, is possible.

analyzed: yat vā mukti viṣayā pratyakṣa dṛṣṭiḥ ghaṭate
translated: Or, the vision of perception having liberation as its object is possible.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: yato mahīyasā puruṣeṇaṣakṣyate mokṣa iti vadāma iti yojanā /
analyzed: yatas mahīyasā mokṣaḥ iti vadāmaḥ iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: because we say that liberation is attained by a great person.

analyzed: athavā kriyamāṇā iti pada adhyāhāre na doṣaḥ
translated: Or, there is no fault in supplying the word 'being done'.

original: evaṃ tarhi mayāpi vaktuṃ śakyata eva /
analyzed: evam tarhi mayā api vaktum śakyate eva
translated: If it is so, then I can also say:

analyzed: yadi api para puruṣa vartī mokṣa abhāvaḥ smat ādīnām na pratyakṣaḥ
translated: Even though the absence of liberation in other persons is not directly perceived by us,

original: tathāpi mahīyasaḥ puruṣasya lokāyatācāryasya pratyakṣa eva /🔽tadavagamaścāsmākaṃ tadvākyena bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: tathā api mahīyasaḥ puruṣasya lokāyata ācāryasya pratyakṣaḥ eva  tad avagamaḥ ca asmākam tad vākyena bhaviṣyati iti
translated: nevertheless, it is directly perceived by the great person, the teacher of materialism.🔽And we will know that through his statement.

original: tathāca satpratipakṣatayā punaraniścaya evetyata āha netīti //
analyzed: tathā ca sat pratipakṣa tayā punar aniścayaḥ eva iti atas āha na iti iti
translated: And thus, due to having a counter-argument, there is again uncertainty. To this he says 'no'.

original: neti vakturmahattvaṃ tu kathañcana na vidyate // / / //
analyzed: na iti vaktuḥ mahat tvam tu kathañcana na vidyate
translated: The greatness of the speaker is in no way known.

original: kasminnapi puruṣe vartamāno 'nāgato vā mokṣo nāstyevetyahaṃ pratyakṣeṇekṣa iti vaktustviti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: kasmin api puruṣe vartamānaḥ na agataḥ vā mokṣaḥ na asti eva iti aham pratyakṣeṇa īkṣaḥ iti vaktuḥ tu iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The construction is: I directly see that liberation does not exist in any person, either present or future.

original: mahattvameva na vidyate kuto mahīyastvamityevaśabdārtho vā tuśabdaḥ /
analyzed: mahat tvam eva na vidyate kutas mahīyaḥ tvam iti evaśabda arthaḥ vā tuśabdaḥ
translated: The word 'eva' (only) means that there is no greatness, let alone greatness.

analyzed: mahat tvam iha bahu prakāram apekṣitam
translated: Here, greatness is required in many ways.

analyzed: itara puruṣa apratyakṣa artha sākṣātkāri tvam tad upayukta asādhāraṇa dharmavat tvam yathārtha vādi tvam ca iti
translated: The knowledge of the truth not perceived by other men, the possession of extraordinary qualities conducive to that knowledge, and the truthfulness of speech.

analyzed: tatra eka prakāram api na lokāyata ācāryasya vidyate
translated: Among these, the teacher of materialism does not possess even one quality.

original: kutastena satpratipakṣatāśaṅkā mokṣavādināṃ mahāpuruṣāṇām /🔽kuta ityata āha sādhayanniti //
analyzed: kutas tena sat pratipakṣa tā āśaṅkā mokṣa vādinām mahāpuruṣāṇām  kutas iti atas āha sādhayan iti
translated: How then can he be suspected of being a counter-disputant to the great men who propound liberation?

analyzed: sādhayan sarva sāmānyam katham eva viśeṣavān
translated: To this he says: Establishing the universality of all, how can he be special?

original: dharmādyabhāvapratipādanena sarveṣāṃ puṃsāṃ samānatvaṃ sādhayaṃllokāyatācāryaḥ kathamevetarebhyo 'tiśayavānbhavati /
analyzed: dharma ādi abhāva pratipādanena sarveṣām puṃsām samāna tvam sādhayan lokāyata ācāryaḥ katham eva itarebhyaḥ atiśayavān bhavati
translated: The teacher of materialism, establishing the equality of all men by teaching the non-existence of Dharma etc., how can he be superior to others?

analyzed: na kathañcid
translated: In no way at all.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

original: puruṣāntarāpratyakṣasya parapuruṣagatasya mokṣābhāvasya sākṣātkaraṇe lokāyatācāryasyetarebhyo viśeṣeṇa bhāvyam /
analyzed: puruṣa antara apratyakṣasya para puruṣa gatasya mokṣa abhāvasya sākṣātkaraṇe lokāyata ācāryasya itarebhyaḥ viśeṣeṇa bhāvyam
translated: In perceiving the absence of liberation in another man, which is not perceived by other men, the teacher of materialism should be superior to others.

analyzed: anyathā itareṣām api tad prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, it would follow that others also have it.

analyzed: na ca asau asti
translated: But that is not so.

analyzed: tapasā yogena vā janitaḥ dharma viśeṣaḥ tathā
translated: And that special Dharma produced by austerity or yoga,

original: sa cetareṣāmiva svātmano 'pi nāstīti tenaiva sādhitam /
analyzed: sa ca itareṣām iva svātmanaḥ u pi na asti iti tena eva sādhitam
translated: and that is not present in his own self as in others, has been established by him alone.

analyzed: atas kāraṇa abhāvāt itara vat tasya api para puruṣa varti mokṣa abhāva sākṣātkaraṇam na asti eva iti niścīyate
translated: Therefore, it is ascertained that, due to the absence of a cause, he too does not directly perceive the absence of liberation in another person, just like others.

analyzed: tatas eva aham mokṣa abhāvam sākṣātkaromi iti tadīya vacanam ayathārtham eva
translated: Therefore, his statement I directly perceive the absence of liberation is not true.

analyzed: bhūta pariṇāma viśeṣaḥ eva atiśayaḥ stu iti ced
translated: If it is argued that there may be a special transformation of elements, which is a higher state,

analyzed: sa kim pratyakṣaḥ pratyakṣaḥ vā
translated: is that higher state perceptible or imperceptible?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not possible.

analyzed: anupalambhāt
translated: Because it is not perceived.

analyzed: yādṛśa tādṛśasya prakṛta phala hetu tve māna abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no evidence that something of that kind can be the cause of the result in question.

analyzed: anyathā atiprasakteḥ
translated: Otherwise, it would lead to an absurd consequence.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is also not possible.

analyzed: atīndriya artham nirākurvatā tena eva itara vat ātmani api tad abhāvasya sādhita tvāt iti
translated: Because he himself has proved the absence of that [higher state] in the self, just as in others, while refuting imperceptible objects.

original: yathā yuṣmābhirabhidhīyate nāstyeva mokṣābhāvasākṣātkārī mahāpuruṣa iti tathā ahamapi vadāmi /
analyzed: yathā yuṣmābhiḥ abhidhīyate na asti eva mokṣa abhāva sākṣātkārī mahāpuruṣaḥ iti tathā aham api vadāmi
translated: Just as you say that there is no great person who directly perceives the absence of liberation, so I also say:

analyzed: na asti eva asau mahīyān puruṣaḥ yaḥ pratyakṣeṇa mokṣam īkṣeta
translated: There is no such great person who can directly perceive liberation.

original: pramāṇābhāvāditi /🔽tathāca punaraniścaya evetyata āha dṛśyanta iti //
analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt iti  tathā ca punar aniścayaḥ eva iti atas āha dṛśyante iti
translated: Because there is no evidence.🔽And thus, there is again only uncertainty. To this, he says:

analyzed: dṛśyante puruṣāḥ loke parāvara vidaḥ pi ca
translated: They are seen, the men in the world, and also those who know the highest and the lowest.

analyzed: aparokṣa dṛśaḥ yoga niṣṭhāḥ ca amala cakṣuṣaḥ
translated: Those who have direct vision, who are devoted to yoga, and who have pure eyes,

analyzed: pratyakṣam devatām dṛṣṭvā tad prasāda āpta bhūtayaḥ
translated: Having seen the deity directly and having obtained the elements through her grace,

analyzed: jñāna vijñāna pāra jñā
translated: Who are the knowers of the other shore of knowledge and wisdom,

analyzed: na kevalam ekaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is not only one.

analyzed: loke smin eva bhū maṇḍale
translated: In this very world-sphere.

analyzed: te ca vasiṣṭha ādayaḥ
translated: And those are Vashishtha and others.

analyzed: teṣām mahīyaḥ tvam āha jñāna vijñāna pāra jñāḥ iti
translated: He says their greatness: Who are the knowers of the other shore of knowledge and wisdom.

analyzed: atra viṣayibhyām viṣayau upalakṣyete
translated: Here the objects are indicated by the subjects.

analyzed: sāmānya viśeṣa ākāra pāra jñāḥ
translated: They are the knowers of the general and specific aspects.

original: na kevalaṃ vartamānāśeṣavidaḥ kinnāma parāvaravido 'pi /🔽tatkimanumānādinā netyāha aparokṣadṛśaśceti //
analyzed: na kevalam vartamāna aśeṣa vidaḥ kinnāma parāvara vidaḥ pi  tat kim anumāna ādinā na iti āha aparokṣa dṛśaḥ ca iti
translated: Not only the knowers of all the present, but also the knowers of the past and future.🔽Then, is it not by inference etc.? He says and who have direct vision.

original: asmadādibhyaḥ ko viśeṣasteṣāmityata uktaṃ yoganiṣṭhāścāmalacakṣuṣa iti /
analyzed: asmat ādibhyaḥ kaḥ viśeṣaḥ teṣām iti atas uktam yoga niṣṭhāḥ ca amala cakṣuṣaḥ iti
translated: What is the difference between them and us? Therefore it is said who are devoted to yoga and have pure eyes.

analyzed: yoga niṣṭhā janita viśiṣya adṛṣṭena divya dṛṣṭayaḥ
translated: They have divine vision generated by the special unseen effect of devotion to yoga.

analyzed: kim tena eva na iti āha pratyakṣam iti
translated: But is it only by that? He says who have seen the deity directly.

analyzed: yoga sāmarthyena para devatām sākṣāt upalabhya tad prasāda āsādita prakāśa ādi aiśvaryavantaḥ
translated: Having directly perceived the supreme deity by the power of yoga, they possess the lordship of light etc. obtained through her grace.

original: vasiṣṭhādayo yogardhisampannayā divyayā dṛṣṭayā paramapuruṣavartinaṃ mokṣaṃ sākṣātkurvāṇāḥ pratyakṣeṇaiva dṛśyante 'to na mokṣāniścaya iti
analyzed: vasiṣṭha ādayaḥ yoga ṛdhi sampannayā divyayā dṛṣṭayā paramapuruṣa vartinam mokṣam sākṣātkurvāṇāḥ pratyakṣeṇa eva dṛśyante na mokṣa aniścayaḥ iti
translated: Vasistha and others, endowed with the perfection of yoga, are seen by their divine vision directly realizing liberation residing in the Supreme Person. Therefore, there is no uncertainty about liberation.

original: asmadādibhiranupalabdhatvātte na santītyata āha niṣiddhayanta iti //
analyzed: asmat ādibhiḥ anupalabdha tvāt te na santi iti atas āha niṣiddha yantaḥ iti
translated: They do not exist because they are not perceived by us and others. To this he says they are being refuted.

analyzed: niṣiddha yante katham nṛbhiḥ
translated: How are they being refuted by men?

analyzed: nṛbhiḥ iti anena mandabhāgyaiḥ parimitā vivikta deśa paricayavadbhiḥ iti sūcayati
translated: By men he indicates those of limited fortune, who are familiar with secluded places.

analyzed: nahi te vaṇij vīthyām vartante
translated: For they do not dwell in the marketplace,

analyzed: yena yuṣmābhiḥ upalabhyeran
translated: by which they could be perceived by you.

original: ato viprakarṣādanupalabhyamānā na niṣeddhuṃ śakyanta iti bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: atas viprakarṣāt anupalabhyamānāḥ na niṣeddhum śakyante iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, being imperceptible due to distance, they cannot be refuted. This is the point.

analyzed: nanu puruṣa svarūpa mātre na vipratipattiḥ
translated: But there is no disagreement about the nature of the Person alone.

original: teṣāṃ mahīyastvaṃ tu kuta ityata āha dṛśyate ceti // /
analyzed: teṣām mahīyaḥ tvam tu kutas iti atas āha dṛśyate ca iti
translated: But how can their greatness be known? To this he says and it is seen, etc.

original: na kevalaṃ puruṣāḥ kintu teṣāmatimāhātmyaṃ mahīyastvaṃ ca dṛśyate /
analyzed: na kevalam puruṣāḥ kintu teṣām ati māhātmyam mahīyaḥ tvam ca dṛśyate
translated: Not only are the Persons, but their extreme greatness and excellence are seen.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: ati mahā ojasām
translated: Of those of extreme great power.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: dṛśyante tāvat vindhya sthagana samudra pāna ādīni teṣām ati mahānti ojāṃsi
translated: The great powers of those (sages) are seen, such as stopping the Vindhya mountain and drinking up the ocean.

analyzed: tāni ca mahā aiśvarya kāryāṇi
translated: And those great powers are the effects of great lordship.

analyzed: na ca kāryāṇi vinā kāraṇaiḥ bhavitum arhanti
translated: And effects cannot exist without causes.

original: mahaiśvaryeṣu ca sārvajñāparanāmakaṃ prākāśyamiti teṣāṃ mahīyastvasiddhiriti / /
analyzed: mahā aiśvaryeṣu ca sārvajña apara nāmakam prākāśyam iti teṣām mahīyaḥ tva siddhiḥ iti
translated: And in great lordships, there is clarity which is synonymous with omniscience. Thus their greatness is established.

original: nanu tadīyaṃ mokṣaviṣayaṃ pratyakṣaṃ pareṣāṃ kutaḥ siddham /
analyzed: nanu tadīyam mokṣa viṣayam pratyakṣam pareṣām kutas siddham
translated: But how is their perception regarding liberation established for others?

analyzed: tad vākyāt iti ced na
translated: If it is said it is from their statements, no.

analyzed: teṣām vipralambhaka tva upapatteḥ iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: Because their deception is possible. Therefore he says if (they are refuted).

original: yadi te 'pi niṣiddhayante kiṃ noktiste niṣiddhayate // / / //
analyzed: yadi te niṣiddhayante kim na uktiḥ te niṣiddhayate
translated: If they are also refuted, why is not their statement refuted?

analyzed: vipralambhaḥ hi prayojana mūlaḥ bhavati
translated: For deception occurs with a purpose as its root.

analyzed: na ca teṣām prayojana anusandhānam sambhavati  āpta samasta aiśvayar tvāt
translated: And for them, the recollection of a purpose is not possible.🔽Because they have attained all lordship.

analyzed: prayojana antarasya ca apramita tvāt
translated: And because another purpose is not known.

original: evaṃbhūtā api te yogino yadi vipralambhakā iti niṣiddhayante /
analyzed: evaṃbhūtāḥ api te yoginaḥ yadi vipralambhakāḥ iti
translated: Even if those yogis are like that, if they are refuted as deceivers,

original: tadīyaṃ vākyaṃ vipralambhamūlatvena nirākriyata iti yāvat /
analyzed: tadīyam vākyam vipralambha mūla tvena nirākriyate iti yāvat
translated: their statement is denied as having deception as its basis. This is the meaning.

original: tadā te tvadabhyupagatā lokāyatācāryoktiḥ kiṃ tathaiva na niṣidhyate /
analyzed: tadā te tvad abhyupagatā lokāyata ācārya uktiḥ kim tathā eva na niṣidhyate
translated: Then why do not those who accept you reject the words of the Lokāyata teacher in the same way?

analyzed: sā api vipralambha mūlā iti kalpayitvā an ādaraṇīyā syāt
translated: That also should be disregarded, supposing it to be based on deception.

analyzed: aviśeṣāt iti yāvat
translated: The meaning is that there is no distinction.

analyzed: etena etat api nirastam
translated: By this, this is also refuted.

original: viprakaṣarvaśādasmābhiranupalabhyamānā api yoginastanmāhātmyaṃ tadīyaṃ svapratyakṣaviṣayaṃ vākyaṃ cāsmābhiḥ kuto 'vagantavyam /🔽itihāsapurāṇebhya iti cenna /
analyzed: viprakaṣa rvaśāt asmābhiḥ anupalabhyamānāḥ api yoginaḥ tat māhātmyam tadīyam sva pratyakṣa viṣayam vākyam ca asmābhiḥ kutas vagantavyam  itihāsa purāṇebhyaḥ iti ced na
translated: Even though the yogis are not perceived by us due to their remoteness, how can their greatness and their own words, which are the object of their direct perception, be understood by us?

analyzed: teṣām apramāṇa tvāt iti
translated: If it is said that it is from the Itihāsas and Purāṇas, no, because they are not valid.

analyzed: doṣa darśanena hi teṣām aprāmāṇyam kalpyam
translated: For their invalidity is supposed due to the perception of faults.

analyzed: na ca tatra pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no valid means of knowledge for that.

analyzed: vākya tvena eva prāmāṇya pratiṣedhe lokāyata ācārya ukteḥ api tad pratiṣedha prasaṅgāt iti
translated: Because of being a statement alone, the words of the Lokāyata teacher would also be refuted, so it is said.

original: na lokāyatācāryoktirvipralambhaśaṅkayā nirākriyate /🔽pratyakṣasaṃvādena prāmāṇyaniścayāditi cetsamaṃ prakṛte 'pītyāha yadukteti //
analyzed: na lokāyata ācārya uktiḥ vipralambha śaṅkayā nirākriyate  pratyakṣa saṃvādena prāmāṇya niścayāt iti ced samam prakṛte pi iti āha yat ukta iti
translated: The words of the Lokāyata teacher are not refuted out of suspicion of deception.🔽If it is said that the validity is ascertained by the agreement with perception, it is the same in the present case also, he says: What is said...

analyzed: yat ukta vākya prāmāṇyam pratyakṣeṇa upalabhyate
translated: The validity of the statement is perceived by perception...🔽...

original: yairyogibhiruktānāṃ vākyānāṃ prāmāṇyaṃ pratyakṣeṇa pratyakṣasaṃvādenopalabhyante te 'pīti pūrveṇānvayaḥ /
analyzed: yaiḥ yogibhiḥ uktānām vākyānām prāmāṇyam pratyakṣeṇa pratyakṣa saṃvādena upalabhyante te pi iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is: those yogis by whom the truthfulness of the statements is perceived by direct perception or by agreement with direct perception, they also are.

original: kathamityata āha varādayo 'pīti //🔽varādayo 'pi taddattāḥ sadā satyā bhavanti hi // / / //
analyzed: katham iti atas āha vara ādayaḥ pi iti  vara ādayaḥ pi tad dattāḥ sadā satyāḥ bhavanti hi
translated: How? To this he says: Even the boons, etc.🔽Even the boons and curses given by them are always true.

original: tairyogibhirdattā varāḥ śāpāśca sadāvyabhicāreṇa satyā bhavanti /
analyzed: taiḥ yogibhiḥ dattāḥ varāḥ śāpāḥ ca sadā avyabhicāreṇa satyāḥ bhavanti
translated: The boons and curses given by those yogis are always infallible and true.

analyzed: hi yasmāt tasmāt iti pūrveṇa eva sambandhaḥ
translated: For this reason, this is connected only with the previous sentence.

original: te prasannāḥ santastavedaṃ bhadraṃ bhaviṣyatīti vā kupitāḥ santastavedamabhadraṃ bhaviṣyatīti vā yadāhustattathaiva bhavatpratyakṣeṇopalabhyata
analyzed: te prasannāḥ santaḥ tava idam bhadram bhaviṣyati iti vā kupitāḥ santaḥ tava idam abhadram bhaviṣyati iti vā yat āhuḥ tat tathā eva bhavat pratyakṣeṇa upalabhyata
translated: When they are pleased, they say This will be auspicious for you, or when they are angry, they say This will be inauspicious for you, and that is exactly how it turns out, as is perceived by direct perception.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: pratyakṣayogyārthe bhavatu tatsaṃvādena tadīyaṃ vākyaṃ pramāṇam /
analyzed: pratyakṣa yogya arthe bhavatu tad saṃvādena tadīyam vākyam pramāṇam
translated: Let their statement be a means of valid knowledge regarding an object suitable for direct perception by agreement with that.

analyzed: atīndriye tu mokṣa ādau katham iti
translated: But how about in the case of the supersensible, such as liberation?

original: evaṃ tarhi lokāyatācāryavacanamapi pratyakṣayogyārthe tatsaṃvādena pramāṇamastu /
analyzed: evam tarhi lokāyata ācārya vacanam api pratyakṣa yogya arthe tad saṃvādena pramāṇam astu
translated: If so, then let the statement of the Lokāyata teacher also be a means of valid knowledge regarding an object suitable for direct perception by agreement with that.

analyzed: atīndriye tu mokṣa abhāva ādau katham iti samānam
translated: But how about in the case of the supersensible, such as the absence of liberation? It is the same.

original: atha manyase pratyakṣayogyārthe tāvattadīyaṃ vacanaṃ pratyakṣasaṃvādyevopalabdham /
analyzed: atha manyase pratyakṣa yogya arthe tāvat tadīyam vacanam pratyakṣa saṃvādi eva upalabdham
translated: Now, if you think that in the case of an object that is capable of being perceived, its statement is found to be in agreement with perception,

analyzed: tena atīndriya artha viṣaye tatra viśvasimaḥ
translated: then we trust it even in the case of objects beyond the senses.

analyzed: loke tathā upalambhāt iti
translated: Because it is observed to be so in the world.

analyzed: tat idam prakṛte samānam
translated: This is the same even in the present case.

analyzed: tat idam uktam anukta samuccaya arthena api padena
translated: This is what is said - by the word 'api' (even), which has the sense of including what is not stated.

analyzed: evam sat pratipakṣa tā nirāsāya yoginām mokṣa pratyakṣa vādasya prāmāṇyam
translated: Thus, in order to remove the counter-argument, the validity of the Yogis' statement of the perception of liberation is established.

analyzed: aprāmāṇyam ca lokāyata ācāryasya mokṣa abhāva pratyakṣa ukteḥ upapāditam
translated: And the invalidity of the Lokāyata teacher's statement of the perception of the absence of liberation is explained.

analyzed: hetu antareṇa api tat aprāmāṇyam upapādayati aprāmāṇyam iti
translated: He explains its invalidity by another reason also, with the word 'ca' (and).

analyzed: aprāmāṇyam tad ukteḥ ca vṛthā vācā avasīyate
translated: Invalidity is also concluded from his statement, which is useless speech.

analyzed: hetu samuccaye caśabdaḥ
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for the cumulative force of the reasons.

analyzed: vṛthā vācā iti bhāva pradhānaḥ nirdeśaḥ
translated: The word 'vṛthāvāc' (useless speech) is a nominal stem in the instrumental case.

analyzed: vṛthātvāt iti eva ukte tṛṇa ādi darśane vyabhicāraḥ syāt
translated: If it is said simply 'because it is useless', there would be an error in the case of grass etc. being seen.

analyzed: tad artham vāc grahaṇam
translated: Therefore, the word 'vāc' (speech) is used.

analyzed: katham lokāyata ācārya ukteḥ vṛthātvam iti atas āha na hi iti
translated: How is the statement of the Lokāyata teacher useless? To this he says 'na hi' (indeed not).

analyzed: na hi prayojanam kiñcid para loka nivāraṇāt
translated: For there is no purpose at all in preventing the next world.

analyzed: para lokasya mokṣa ādeḥ nivāraṇāt nāstitva pratipādanāt labhyam kiñcid prayojanam na asti iti etat prasiddham eva
translated: It is well known that there is no purpose at all to be gained by teaching non-existence, by preventing the next world, liberation, etc.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: tad ukteḥ adṛṣṭam vā prayojanam syāt dṛṣṭam vā
translated: The purpose may be unseen or seen.

analyzed: na tāvat adṛṣṭam
translated: Not the unseen first,

analyzed: para loka nivāraṇāt
translated: because the next world is prevented.

original: adṛṣṭaṃ hi svargādāvupabhogyaṃ vā syāddehāntareṇehaiva vā /
analyzed: adṛṣṭam hi svarga ādau upabhogyam vā syāt deha antareṇa iha eva vā
translated: For the unseen is either to be enjoyed in heaven, etc. by another body, or here itself.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first,

analyzed: svarga ādeḥ para lokasya pareṇa pratiṣiddha tvāt
translated: because heaven, etc. the next world is denied by the opponent.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second,

analyzed: deha ātma vādinā asya ātmanaḥ para lokasya deha antarasya nivāraṇāt
translated: because the next world, the other body, of the self which is identified with the body is prevented.

analyzed: na api dṛṣṭam  pratipādaka pratipādyayoḥ artha kāma lābha anupalambhāt iti  vaidikānām dharma adharma vyavasthāpakaiḥ va vacanaiḥ uparuddha kāma bhogānām prāṇinām dharma ādi abhāva a pratipādanena
translated: Nor is the seen purpose.🔽Because the teacher and the taught are not seen to gain wealth or desire.🔽For those who follow the Vedas, who are obstructed in the enjoyment of desire by the statements establishing dharma and adharma, by teaching the non-existence of dharma, etc.

analyzed: kāma upabhoga uparodha nivṛtti rūpa para upakāraḥ tāvat ācāryasya prāṇinām dharma ādi abhāva pratipādanena
translated: The benefit to others in the form of the cessation of the obstruction to the enjoyment of desire is indeed the teacher's, by teaching the non-existence of dharma, etc. to living beings.

analyzed: kāma upabhoga uparodha nivṛtti rūpa para upakāraḥ tāvat ācāryasya prayojanam asti
translated: The purpose of the teacher is to help others by preventing them from indulging in sensual pleasures.

analyzed: yadi api upakāraḥ na sva rūpeṇa prayojanam
translated: Although help is not a purpose in itself,

analyzed: na api adṛṣṭa hetu tvena
translated: nor is it a purpose because it leads to unseen results,

analyzed: tathā api upakartāram pratyupakurvanti eva
translated: nevertheless, those who are helped do help the one who helps them.

analyzed: vineyānām ca kāma upabhoga uparodha nivṛttiḥ evā asti prayojanam
translated: And for the disciples, the purpose is only to prevent indulgence in sensual pleasures.

analyzed: tat katham vṛthātvam iti atas āha vṛthā vācam iti
translated: How then can it be useless? To this he says:

original: vṛthāvācaṃ vṛthā hanyād yadi tasya kimuttaram // / / //
analyzed: vṛthā vācam vṛthā hanyāt yadi tasya kim uttaram
translated: If one would kill a person speaking useless words, what reply would he have?

analyzed: atra vṛthāvācam iti sādhya nirdeśaḥ
translated: Here, useless words is the statement of the conclusion.

analyzed: evam api vṛthāvāc tvam na parihāryam iti
translated: Even so, the state of speaking useless words cannot be avoided.

analyzed: adṛṣṭa prayojana rahita vācam iti vā
translated: Or, words devoid of a purpose in the unseen world.

original: yadi kaścittamācāryaṃ vineyaṃ vā vṛthaiva hanyāttadā taṃ prati tasya kimuttaram /
analyzed: yadi kaścid tam ācāryam vineyam vā vṛthā eva hanyāt tadā tam prati tasya kim uttaram
translated: If someone would kill that teacher or disciple for no reason, then what reply would he have to that?

analyzed: na kiñcid
translated: Nothing at all.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

analyzed: na staḥ eva dharma adharmau
translated: Dharma and Adharma do not exist at all.

original: atastvayā niraṅkuśena kāmopabhogaḥ karaṇīya ityācāryeṇa bodhito 'ntevāsī tadīyakamanīyakāntādyapahārārthaṃ taṃ hanyādeva /
analyzed: atas tvayā niraṅkuśena kāma upabhogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ iti ācāryeṇa bodhitaḥ ntevāsī tadīya kamanīya kānta ādi apahāra artham tam hanyāt eva
translated: Therefore, having been instructed by the teacher that one should indulge in sensual pleasures without restraint, the disciple would indeed kill him in order to take away his beautiful wife and so on.

analyzed: tadā asya kā pratikriyā
translated: What is the proper response to him?

analyzed: upakartuḥ apakāraḥ mahā pratyavāya hetuḥ iti chāndasa ukteḥ tena eva tyājita tvāt
translated: Because he has been abandoned by him alone, since the Vedic statement that harming a benefactor is the cause of great demerit is made.

analyzed: upakartāram pratyupakurvanti iti etat api dharma ādi vāsanāyām satyām eva
translated: And this [statement] that one acts in return for a benefactor is also true only when there is a predisposition towards Dharma and so on.

analyzed: sā tu tena eva niśśeṣitā
translated: But that has been completely destroyed by him alone.

analyzed: atas na asti eva ācāryasya prayojanam
translated: Therefore, the teacher has no purpose at all.

original: pratyuta svajīvanahānilakṣaṇo 'nartha eva evaṃ vineyānāmapyanyonyadhanavanitādyapahārāyaparasparavadhādāveva pravṛttiḥ na tu kāmopabhogāvasaraḥ
analyzed: pratyuta sva jīvana hāni lakṣaṇaḥ narthaḥ eva evam vineyānām api anyonya dhana vanitā ādi apahārāya paraspara vadha ādau eva pravṛttiḥ na tu kāma upabhoga avasaraḥ
translated: On the contrary, there is only harm in the form of loss of one's own life. In this way, the disciples also engage only in mutual theft of wealth, women, etc., and mutual killing, and not in the opportunity to enjoy sensual pleasures.

analyzed: mahatā anarthena ākrāntaḥ lpīyān kāma upabhogaḥ narthaḥ eva iti
translated: A small enjoyment of sensual pleasures, overwhelmed by great harm, is harm itself.

analyzed: astu evam lokāyata ācārya ukteḥ vṛthātvam anartha hetu tvam ca
translated: Let it be so that the statement of the Lokāyata teacher is useless and a cause of harm.

analyzed: tathā api aprāmāṇyam kutas iti atas āha sva iti
translated: Even so, why is it not authoritative? To this he says 'his own' [life].

analyzed: sva jīvana virodhāya vadan kim nāma buddhimān
translated: Speaking for the contradiction of his own life, what indeed is a wise man?

analyzed: sva śabdaḥ pareṣām api upalakṣakaḥ
translated: The word 'his own' is also suggestive of others.

analyzed: vyartham ca iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is 'useless' and so on.

analyzed: vyartha anartha hetu vāc tvena lokāyata ācāryasya a prekṣāvat tvam anumīyate
translated: The Lokāyata teacher's lack of foresight is inferred from his statement that is useless and a cause of harm.

analyzed: tatas tad vacanasya aprāmāṇyam iti śeṣaḥ  uktaḥ ca ayam arthaḥ prayojana adhikaraṇe
translated: Then, the meaning is that the statement is not authoritative.🔽And this meaning has been stated in the section on purpose.

analyzed: uktam artham buddhayā ārohāya saṅkṣipya āha prāmāṇyam iti
translated: To make the stated meaning easy to understand, he summarizes with authoritativeness and so on.

original: prāmāṇye saṃśayaḥ kiṃ syāt tayoḥ puruṣayorapi /
analyzed: prāmāṇye saṃśayaḥ kim syāt tayoḥ puruṣayoḥ api
translated: If there is doubt about authoritativeness, what would happen to those two men also?

analyzed: sva jīvana viruddha uktiḥ ajñaḥ dṛṣṭasya ca api saḥ
translated: He is ignorant of what is contrary to his own life, and even of what is seen.

analyzed: yaḥ ca atīndriya deva ukti śrotā dṛṣṭa parāvaraḥ
translated: And he who hears the statements of the gods beyond the senses, and sees the highest and the lowest,

analyzed: atīta anāgatam sarvam loka anubhavam āpayan
translated: Bringing all that is past and future to the experience of the world.

analyzed: atra prāmāṇya śabdena āpta tvam ucyate
translated: Here, by the word authoritativeness, reliability is meant.

analyzed: kim iti ākṣepe
translated: What? is an expression of doubt.

analyzed: apiśabdaḥ garhāyām
translated: The word also is used in the sense of reproach.

analyzed: sva iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: His own is a synecdoche.

analyzed: dṛṣṭasya darśana yogyasya api bahoḥ arthasya
translated: Of many things that are seen, i.e., fit to be seen.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ viśeṣaṇa samuccaye
translated: The word ca (and) is for the inclusion of a particular.

analyzed: deva ukti iti atīndriya antarasya api upalakṣaṇam
translated: The statements of the gods is a synecdoche for something else beyond the senses.

original: svoktaṃ sarvaṃ pratyakṣasaṃvādena lokānubhavaṃ lokāśvāsaṃ prāpayan /
analyzed: sva uktam sarvam pratyakṣa saṃvādena loka anubhavam loka āśvāsam prāpayan
translated: Bringing all that is said by himself to the experience of the world, i.e., the assurance of the people, by means of agreement with perception.

original: yaḥ svajīvanaviruddhoktitvādiviśeṣaṇo lokāyatācāryo yaścātīndriyadevoktiśrotṛtvādiviśeṣaṇo yogī tayorapi puruṣayoḥ prāmāṇye saṃśayaḥ syātkiṃ /
analyzed: yaḥ sva jīvana viruddha ukti tva ādi viśeṣaṇaḥ lokāyata ācāryaḥ yaḥ ca atīndriya deva ukti śrotṛ tva ādi viśeṣaṇaḥ yogī tayoḥ api puruṣayoḥ prāmāṇye saṃśayaḥ syāt kim
translated: Even in the case of the Lokāyata teacher who is characterized by propounding doctrines contrary to his own life, and the yogi who is characterized by being a hearer of statements about supersensible gods, there would be doubt about the validity of those two persons.

analyzed: na syāt eva
translated: It would not be so.

original: kintvādyasyāprāmāṇyameva dvitīyasya prāmāṇyameva niścīyata iti yojanā / /🔽evaṃ nimittābhāvenāsambhāvitātīndriyajñānasya kāmukatvādinā sambhāvitavipralambhasya
analyzed: kintu ādyasya aprāmāṇyam eva dvitīyasya prāmāṇyam eva niścīyate iti yojanā  evam nimitta abhāvena asambhāvita atīndriya jñānasya kāmuka tva ādinā sambhāvita vipralambhasya
translated: But it is ascertained that the first one is indeed invalid, and the second one is indeed valid. This is the construction.🔽Thus, for the Lokāyata teacher whose knowledge of supersensible things is not possible due to the absence of a cause, and whose deception is possible due to lust and so on,

analyzed: lokāyata ācāryasya yoga ṛdhi sampadā sambhāvita sārvajña avāpta samasta aiśvaryavat tva ādinā atyanta asambhāvita vañcaka tvāt pratyakṣa saṃvādi vacasaḥ yoginaḥ prati
translated: for the yogi whose words are in agreement with perception, whose omniscience is possible by the wealth of yoga and meditation, and whose possession of all kinds of prosperity is completely possible, whose deceptiveness is utterly impossible,

analyzed: pratipakṣa tva asambhave na
translated: in the absence of a counter-argument,

analyzed: tad vacana avagatena tad pratyakṣeṇa mokṣaḥ siddhayati iti uktam
translated: it is said that liberation is not accomplished by the perception of that yogi understood through his words.

original: idānīṃ vedenāpi taṃ siṣādhayiṣustatprāmāṇye vipratipannaṃ prati kiṃ saṃvādarahitatvādvedasyāprāmāṇyamucyate /
analyzed: idānīm vedena api tam siṣādhayiṣuḥ tad prāmāṇye vipratipannam prati kim saṃvāda rahita tvāt vedasya aprāmāṇyam ucyate
translated: Now, wishing to establish that by the Veda also, for one who is doubtful about its validity, is it said that the Veda is invalid because it lacks agreement?

analyzed: uta vākya tvāt unmatta vākya vat
translated: Or because it is a statement, like the statement of a madman?

original: athavonmattavākyādaniścitaviśeṣatvādathavā🔽bādhitatvaditi vikalpyādye 'pi kiṃ sarvasya saṃvādo nāsti utaikadeśasyeti vikalpyādyaṃ nirācaṣṭe ata iti //
analyzed: athavā unmatta vākyāt aniścita viśeṣa tvāt athavā  bādhita tvat iti vikalpya ādye pi kim sarvasya saṃvādaḥ na asti uta eka deśasya iti vikalpya ādyam nirācaṣṭe atas iti
translated: Or, it is because the statement of the insane is uncertain in its particulars, or because it is contradicted. Having thus considered, if the first is accepted, then also, is there no agreement with anything at all, or is there agreement with a part? Having thus considered, he rejects the first by saying for this reason.🔽🔽

analyzed: atas pratyakṣa gamya tvāt veda mā tvasya ca sphuṭam
translated: Or, because of the uncertain nature of the statement of a madman, or because it is contradicted, thus considering. Even in the first case, is there no agreement of all, or of a part? Thus considering, he rejects the first: Therefore, because it is perceptible by direct perception, and because the authority of the Veda is clear,

analyzed: vaidika anuṣṭhānavatām tad phala siddheḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: because the attainment of its fruit is seen for those who perform Vedic rites, this is the meaning.

analyzed: pratyakṣa gamya tvāt pratyakṣa saṃvādena siddha tvāt
translated: Because it is perceptible by direct perception, because it is established by agreement with direct perception.

analyzed: pramāṇa samuccaye caśabdaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) is in the compound of two means of knowledge.

analyzed: vedena ca mokṣa siddhiḥ iti
translated: And because liberation is established by the Veda.

analyzed: anena sarvasya api vedasya pramāṇa antara saṃvādaḥ na asti iti etat asiddham
translated: By this it is said that it is not established that there is no agreement with another means of knowledge of the entire Veda.

analyzed: aiśvarya ādi sādhanatayā yoga ādikam upadiśataḥ veda bhāgasya saṃvāda darśanāt iti uktam bhavati
translated: Because it is seen that a part of the Veda which teaches yoga etc. as the means of attaining lordship etc. has agreement.

original: mokṣapratipādakāni ca vedavākyāni tatra tatrodāhṛtānyeva draṣṭavyāni /
analyzed: mokṣa pratipādakāni ca veda vākyāni tatra tatra udāhṛtāni eva draṣṭavyāni
translated: And the Vedic statements teaching liberation should be seen as cited here and there.

analyzed: phala visaṃvādaḥ pi vedasya dṛśyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that disagreement regarding the fruit is also seen in the Veda, it is not so.

analyzed: tasya kartṛ karma ādi vaiguṇya hetu tāyāḥ prāc ukta tvāt
translated: Because it has been said earlier that it is caused by defects in the agent, object etc.

analyzed: tat idam uktam sphuṭam iti
translated: This is what is clearly stated.

analyzed: ādye dvitīyam dūṣayati yadi iti
translated: In the first, he criticizes the second, saying if etc.

analyzed: yadi āgamasya naḥ mā tvam akṣajasya tathā bhavet
translated: If the validity of the scripture is not accepted, then that of the sense-perception also would not be accepted.

original: yadi bhāgaviśeṣasya saṃvādābhāvena kṛtsnasyāpi āgamasya no mānatvam apramāṇatvamityucyate tarhi akṣajasya pratyakṣamātrasya tathā apramāṇatvaṃ 🔽bhavet /
analyzed: yadi bhāga viśeṣasya saṃvāda abhāvena kṛtsnasya api āgamasya no māna tvam apramāṇa tvam iti ucyate tarhi akṣa jasya pratyakṣa mātrasya tathā apramāṇa tvam  bhavet
translated: If it is said that the validity of the entire scripture is not accepted due to the absence of agreement in a particular part, then the validity of sense-perception alone would not be accepted.

analyzed: asthāt sukha ādi viṣayasya pratyakṣasya saṃvāda abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no agreement regarding the sense-perception of pleasure etc.

original: yadi ca saṃvādarahitasyaiva vedabhāgasya no mānatvamityucyate tadāsmatsukhādiviṣayasya pratyakṣasyāprāmāṇyaṃ bhavedeveti /
analyzed: yadi ca saṃvāda rahitasya eva veda bhāgasya no māna tvam iti ucyate tadā asmad sukha ādi viṣayasya pratyakṣasya aprāmāṇyam bhavet eva iti
translated: And if it is said that the part of the Veda which is devoid of agreement is not valid, then the invalidity of our sense-perception of pleasure etc. would indeed occur.

analyzed: yadi api yogi pratyakṣa saṃvādaḥ sti tathā
translated: Although there is agreement with the sense-perception of the yogi,

analyzed: prāk uktaḥ tathā api tad itara pramāṇa apekṣayā idam uditam veditavyam
translated: it was stated earlier. Nevertheless, this should be understood in relation to other means of knowledge.

original: syādetat /🔽pratyakṣaṃ svata eva pramāṇaṃ tatra kiṃ saṃvādenetyata āha yadyakṣajasyeti // /
analyzed: syāt etat  pratyakṣam svatas eva pramāṇam tatra kim saṃvādena iti atas āha yadi akṣajasya iti
translated: This may be said.🔽Sense-perception is a means of valid knowledge by itself, so what is the use of agreement? To this he says if etc.
