original: yadyakṣajasya mātvaṃ syādāgamasya kathaṃ na tat // / / //
analyzed: yadi akṣa jasya mā tvam syāt āgamasya katham na tat
translated: If the validity of sense-perception is accepted, then how is not that of the scripture also accepted?

original: yadi saṃvādena vinākṣajasya svata eva pramāṇatvaṃ syāttarhi āgamasya tat svata eva prāmāṇyaṃ kathaṃ na bhavet aviśeṣādbhavedeva / /
analyzed: yadi saṃvādena vinā akṣajasya svatas eva pramāṇa tvam syāt tarhi āgamasya tat svatas eva prāmāṇyam katham na bhavet aviśeṣāt bhavet eva
translated: If the cognition produced by the senses were to be valid by itself, independently of agreement, then why should not the validity of the scriptures be self-sufficient? It would certainly be so, there being no difference.

analyzed: dvitīyam nirākaroti yadi āgamasya iti
translated: He refutes the second view (with the words), 'If the validity of the scriptures'.

analyzed: yadi vākya tva mātreṇa unmatta vākya vat āgamasya na māna tvam iti ucyate
translated: If it is said that the scriptures are not authoritative merely because they are statements, like the ravings of a madman,

analyzed: tarhi akṣa ja tvena śukti rajata ādi viṣaya akṣaja vat stambha ādi akṣajasya api aprāmāṇyam syāt aviśeṣāt  nirdeṣa tvāt stambha ādi viṣayam akṣa jam pramāṇam iti atas āha yadi akṣa jasya iti
translated: then the cognition produced by the senses regarding a post, etc. would also be invalid, because of the absence of any difference, like the cognition produced by the senses regarding the silver in a shell, etc.🔽(He says), 'If the cognition produced by the senses' (with the intention of saying that) the cognition produced by the senses regarding a post, etc. is valid because it is free from defects.

original: yadi nirdeṣatvātstambhādiviṣayasyākṣajasya pramāṇatvaṃ syāttarhyāgamasyāpi tata eva kathaṃ na bhavet /
analyzed: yadi nirdeṣa tvāt stambha ādi viṣayasya akṣa jasya pramāṇa tvam syāt tarhi āgamasya api tatas eva katham na bhavet
translated: If the cognition produced by the senses regarding a post, etc. were to be valid because it is free from defects, then why should not the scriptures also be so?

analyzed: na hi apauruṣeyasya sa doṣa tā sambhavati
translated: For, it is not possible for what is not of human origin to have defects.

original: veda ityupakramāttathaiva vaktavye yadāgamasyeti vadati tadanenaiva nyāyena pauruṣeyāgamasyāpi prāmāṇyaṃ sādhanīyamiti sūcayitum / /
analyzed: vedaḥ iti upakramāt tathā eva vaktavye yat āgamasya iti vadati tat anena eva nyāyena pauruṣeya āgamasya api prāmāṇyam sādhanīyam iti sūcayitum
translated: Although it should be said in the same way as 'the Veda' when it is begun, he says 'of the scriptures' in order to indicate that the validity of the scriptures composed by men is also to be established by this very reasoning.

analyzed: tṛtīyam nirākaroti loka iti
translated: He refutes the third view (with the words), 'In the world'.

analyzed: loka vākyāt viśeṣaḥ ca avyabhicāreṇa siddhayati
translated: And the distinction of the Vedic statement from ordinary statements is established by the absence of contradiction.

analyzed: unmatta ādi vākyāt
translated: From the statement of a madman, etc.

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ vedasya
translated: The distinction of the Veda.

analyzed: avyabhicāreṇa bādha rāhityena
translated: By the absence of contradiction, by the absence of sublation.

original: nahi vaidiko 'rthaḥ pratyakṣasiddho yena tattatra bādhakatayāvakāśaṃ labheta /
analyzed: nahi vaidikaḥ rthaḥ pratyakṣa siddhaḥ yena tat tatra bādhaka tayā avakāśam labheta
translated: For the meaning of the Veda is not established by perception, by which it could obtain room as a sublater there.

analyzed: etena caturthaḥ pi nirastaḥ
translated: By this, the fourth [objection] is also refuted.

original: tadevaṃ pratyakṣāgamābhyāṃ mokṣaṃ sādhayatehāmutra phalabhogavairāgyavatāṃ yogināṃ pravṛttiḥ saphalā prekṣāvatpravṛttitvātsammatavadityanumānamapi 🔽sūcitam /
analyzed: tat evam pratyakṣa āgamābhyām mokṣam sādhayata iha amutra phala bhoga vairāgyavatām yoginām pravṛttiḥ sa phalā prekṣāvat pravṛtti tvāt sammata vat iti anumānam api  sūcitam
translated: Thus, the inference is also indicated here: The activity of the yogis who are detached from the enjoyment of fruits in this world and the next establishes liberation by perception and scripture, because it is fruitful, like the activity of the wise.

analyzed: anumāna prāmāṇyam ca prāk eva samarthitam
translated: And the validity of inference has already been established.

analyzed: apare puras an anumimate
translated: Others, however, infer as follows:

analyzed: duḥkha santatiḥ atyantam ucchidyate santati tvāt dīpa jvālā santati vat iti
translated: The continuum of suffering is utterly destroyed, because it is a continuum, like the continuum of a lamp-flame.

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not correct.
Because it is contradicted in part by accepting the continuum of suffering belonging to all living beings.

analyzed: nitya saṃsāriṇām keṣāñcid sattvasya taiḥ api aṅgīkṛta tvāt samarthayiṣyamāṇa tvāt ca
translated: Because they [the Samkhyas] also accept the existence of some eternal transmigrators and because [we] will establish [the existence of such].

analyzed: tad vayatirikta jīva gata duḥkha santati pakṣīkāre tu tatra eva vyabhicārāt
translated: But if you accept the continuity of suffering in the soul other than that, then there is deviation right there.

original: pārthivaparamāṇurūpādisantāne vyabhicārācca /🔽sarvamuktipakṣe phalamūlayorabhāvena so 'pyatyantamucchidyata eveti cenna /
analyzed: pārthiva paramāṇu rūpa ādi santāne vyabhicārāt ca  sarva mukti pakṣe phala mūlayoḥ abhāvena saḥ u pi atyantam ucchidyate eva iti ced na
translated: And because there is deviation in the continuity of form etc. of an earth atom.🔽If you say that because there is no fruit or root in the case of the theory of universal liberation, it is utterly destroyed, that is not so.

analyzed: sarva mukti pakṣasya eva nirākariṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because the theory of universal liberation itself is to be refuted.

analyzed: kāla kṣaṇa santāne vyabhicārāt ca
translated: And because there is deviation in the continuity of moments of time.

original: kiñca duḥkhasantatiśabdena duḥkhānyevocyante uta taddharmaḥ kaścit /
analyzed: kiñca duḥkha santati śabdena duḥkhāni eva ucyante uta tad dharmaḥ kaścid
translated: Moreover, by the word 'continuity of suffering', are sufferings themselves meant, or some property of them?

analyzed: ādye siddha sādhana tā
translated: If the first, then there is the establishment of what is already established.

analyzed: mokṣam an aṅgīkurvatā api duḥkhānām vināśi tā abhyupagamāt
translated: Even one who does not accept liberation must accept the destruction of sufferings.

analyzed: atas eva atyantam iti uktam iti ced
translated: If you say it is stated as 'utterly' for this very reason,

analyzed: kaḥ sya arthaḥ
translated: what is the meaning of this?

analyzed: kim sarvāṇi api duḥkhāni ucchidyante iti
translated: Is it that all sufferings are destroyed?

analyzed: uta niḥśeṣa tayā ucchidyante iti
translated: Or are they destroyed without remainder?

analyzed: athavā tatra duḥkha antara anutpādena iti
translated: Or is it that no other suffering arises there?

analyzed: na prathamaḥ  siddha sādhana tā nistārāt
translated: Not the first.🔽Because it cannot escape being the establishment of what is already established.

analyzed: sarveṣām api duḥkhānām pareṇa anitya tāyāḥ svīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because the other accepts the impermanence of all sufferings.

analyzed: atas eva na dvitīyaḥ
translated: For this very reason, not the second.

analyzed: na hi duḥkham sa avayava dravyam
translated: For suffering is not a composite substance,

analyzed: yena sa śeṣam ucchidyate iti śaṅkayeta
translated: so one could not suspect that it is destroyed with a remainder.

analyzed: na tṛtīyaḥ
translated: The third is not so.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntasya sādhya vikala tvāt
translated: Because the example lacks what is to be proven.

analyzed: nahi dīpa jvālā santatiḥ evam ucchidyate
translated: For the flame of a lamp is not extinguished in this way.

analyzed: tatra eva punar jvālā antara udaya sambhavāt
translated: Because another flame can arise there again.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: duḥkha dharmaḥ hi jātiḥ vā tad anyaḥ vā
translated: For birth is the characteristic of suffering, or something else.

analyzed: ādye pa siddhāntaḥ
translated: In the first case, there is a contradiction with what is established.

analyzed: jāteḥ nitya tva aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because the eternality of birth is accepted.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ  āśraya asiddheḥ
translated: Not the second.🔽Because the basis is not established.

analyzed: guṇeṣu jāti vyatirikta dharma anaṅgīkārāt
translated: Because qualities other than birth are not accepted.

analyzed: aṅgīkāre pi artha antara tā syāt
translated: Even if accepted, there would be a different meaning.

analyzed: nahi duḥkha dharmasya kasyacid vināśa siddhau mokṣa siddhiḥ iti
translated: For the establishment of liberation is not by the establishment of the destruction of any characteristic of suffering.

original: ātmā kadāciddhvastāśeṣaviśeṣaguṇo vibhutve sati kāryaviśeṣaguṇavattvāt mahāpralayāvasthāyāmākāśavaditi cāsat /
analyzed: ātmā kadācid dhvasta aśeṣa viśeṣa guṇaḥ vibhu tve sati kārya viśeṣa guṇavat tvāt mahāpralaya avasthāyām ākāśa vat iti ca asat
translated: It is not so that the self, sometimes having all its specific qualities destroyed, being all-pervading, possesses specific qualities of effects, like space in the state of the great dissolution.

analyzed: sarva ātma pakṣīkāre parameśvara ātmani bādhāt
translated: Because there is contradiction in the view of the supreme self, the supreme Lord.

analyzed: asiddheḥ ca
translated: And because it is not established.

original: jīvātmapakṣīkāre 'pi saṃsāryekasvabhāvānāṃ jīvānāṃ svayamevorarīkṛtatvena tatra bādhāt /
analyzed: jīvātma pakṣīkāre pi saṃsāri eka svabhāvānām jīvānām svayam evā urarīkṛta tvena tatra bādhāt
translated: Even if the individual self is accepted, there is contradiction because the individual souls, of the same nature in saṃsāra, are themselves refuted.
If the soul other than that is accepted, then there is no fallacy there.

analyzed: jīvātmanām vibhu tva abhāvena asiddheḥ ca
translated: And because the non-existence of omnipresence in the individual souls is not established.

analyzed: ātma tvam kadācid dhvasta aśeṣa viśeṣa guṇa dravya niṣṭham iti pratijñā arthaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the meaning of the proposition is that atmanhood is sometimes based on a substance with all specific qualities destroyed, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati hetoḥ asiddhi prasaṅgāt
translated: Because in that case, the reason would be inconclusive.

analyzed: jāti tvam hetuḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the reason is the quality of being a universal, it is not so.

analyzed: pūrva anumāna doṣa aparihārāt
translated: Because the fault of the previous inference is not avoided.

analyzed: ghaṭa tva ādau anaikāntika tvāt ca
translated: And because it is inconclusive in the case of pot-ness, etc.

analyzed: aśeṣa viśeṣa guṇa śūnya dravya niṣṭham iti pratijñā arthaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the meaning of the proposition is that it is based on a substance devoid of all specific qualities, it is not so.

analyzed: sa guṇānām eva dravyāṇām utpādasya samarthita tvāt
translated: Because the production of substances with qualities has been established.

original: vibhukāryaviśeṣaguṇavadvṛttijātitvasya hetutvānna ko 'pi doṣa iti cenna /
analyzed: vibhu kārya viśeṣa guṇavat vṛtti jāti tvasya hetu tvāt na kaḥ pi doṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the reason is the quality of being a universal that occurs in substances with specific effects and qualities, then there is no fault.

analyzed: kārya viśeṣa guṇavat padasya vaiyarthyāt
translated: Because the word with specific effects and qualities is meaningless.

analyzed: tad tyāge pi artha antara tvāt
translated: Even if it is omitted, it is extraneous.

analyzed: aśeṣa viśeṣa guṇa dhvaṃsaḥ na mokṣaḥ iti vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because it will be said that the destruction of all specific qualities is not liberation.

analyzed: etena devadattaḥ devadatta adharma samāna kālīna devadatta gatatva anadhikaraṇa duḥkha dhvaṃsa adhikaraṇam duḥkhi tvāt yajñadatta vat iti viśiṣya vyatireki anumānam api
translated: By this, the inference based on specific positive and negative concomitance, that Devadatta's destruction of the substratum of suffering, which is not the substratum of Devadatta's existence at the same time as Devadatta's dharma, is due to his being a sufferer, like Yajnadatta, is also refuted.

analyzed: nirastam  artha antara tā parihārāt iti āstām prapañcaḥ
translated: [This is because] the property of the subject is not established.🔽Let this elaboration be enough.

analyzed: idānīm jaina ukta mokṣa sādhanam dūṣayitum anuvadati asti iti
translated: Now, in order to refute the means of attaining liberation stated by the Jains, he repeats [the statement] There is [in the verse].

analyzed: asti mokṣaḥ pi dharmeṇa yathārtha jñānataḥ pi ca
translated: There is liberation by dharma and also by true knowledge.

original: yadidaṃ mokṣāstitvaṃ samarthitaṃ tatsādhviti jaināḥ prāhuriti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: yat idam mokṣa astitvam samarthitam tat sādhu iti jaināḥ prāhuḥ iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: The Jains say that this existence of liberation is established, and that is good.

analyzed: aṅgīkṛtaḥ ced mokṣa sadbhāvaḥ tadā tad sādhanam api kiñcid aṅgīkāyarma eva
translated: If the existence of liberation is accepted, then some means of attaining it must also be accepted.

analyzed: tathā ca kā vipratipattiḥ iti āśayavān pṛcchati api iti
translated: With this intention, he asks Also [in the verse].

analyzed: kim tarhi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: What then?

analyzed: uttaram āha dharmeṇa iti
translated: He answers By dharma [in the verse].

analyzed: labhyate iti āhuḥ
translated: They say it is attained.

analyzed: api cau itaretara samuccaye
translated: And also means either... or.

original: yadyapi mokṣaṃ tatsādhanaṃ cābhyupayanti jaināstathāpi tadviśeṣe vipratipadyante /
analyzed: yadi api mokṣam tad sādhanam ca abhyupayanti jaināḥ tathā api tad viśeṣe vipratipadyante
translated: Although the Jains accept liberation and its means, they disagree on its particulars.

analyzed: yatas samyak jñāna samyak cāritrya samuccaya sādhyam mokṣam āhuḥ iti āśayaḥ
translated: Because they say that liberation is to be accomplished by the combination of right knowledge and right conduct, such is the intention.

analyzed: samyak darśanam yadi aparokṣa jñānam tadā yathārtha grahaṇena eva gṛhītam
translated: If right view is direct knowledge, then it is included by the word 'true'.

original: yadi ca svasamayaparipālanaṃ tadā dharmagrahaṇeneti pṛthaggrahaṇaṃ vyarthamiti sūcayituṃ dvayoreva grahaṇam /
analyzed: yadi ca sva samaya paripālanam tadā dharma grahaṇena iti pṛthak grahaṇam vyartham iti sūcayitum dvayoḥ eva grahaṇam
translated: And if it is the observance of one's own doctrine, then it is included by the word 'Dharma'. Thus the separate mention is useless. To indicate this, only two are mentioned.

analyzed: dharma jñāna samuccaya sādhya tvam mokṣasya kathañcid asmābhiḥ api aṅgīkriyate
translated: We also somehow accept that liberation is to be accomplished by the combination of Dharma and knowledge.

analyzed: atas vipratipatti anantaram darśayati prāmāṇyam iti
translated: Therefore, after the disagreement, he shows the authoritativeness.

analyzed: prāmāṇyam anumāyāḥ ca jinasya āpta tva sādhane
translated: And in establishing the trustworthiness of the Jina through inference,

analyzed: tad vākyāt dharma sat jñāna vijñaptiḥ bhavati iti ca
translated: And in the cognition of Dharma and right knowledge from his words,

analyzed: caśabdāt jina darśinām vākyasya ca
translated: The Jina is trustworthy because his words are true, etc. are the inferences.🔽The word 'ca' (and) includes the words of the Jina's disciples.

analyzed: tad vākyāt jina vākyāt
translated: From his words, from the words of the Jina.

analyzed: iti ca jaināḥ prāhuḥ
translated: Thus the Jains say.

analyzed: anumāna ādi avagata āpta bhāva jina vākyāt mokṣa sādhana siddhim āhuḥ
translated: They say that the means of attaining liberation is established from the words of the Jina, whose trustworthiness is understood through inference, etc.

analyzed: na tu svatas pramāṇāt vedāt iti āśayaḥ
translated: But not from the Veda, which is authoritative by itself, such is the intention.

analyzed: mokṣa sādhana viṣayām vipratipattim darśayitum upakramya pramāṇa vipratipatti pradarśanam asaṅgatam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the introduction of the topic of the means of right knowledge is irrelevant, after having shown the divergence of opinion regarding the means of attaining final release, it is not so;

analyzed: sādhana jñāpakasya api sādhana tvāt
translated: because the means of knowing is also a means.

analyzed: dharma jñāna svarūpe vipratipattim darśayati dharmaḥ iti
translated: He shows the divergence of opinion regarding the nature of the knowledge of dharma also, with the word dharma.

analyzed: dharmaḥ hiṃsā paraḥ na anyaḥ jñānam pudgala darśanam
translated: Dharma is nothing but non-violence; knowledge is the vision of the soul.

analyzed: iti jaināḥ
translated: Thus say the Jains.

analyzed: ahiṃsā parā pradhāna bhūtā yasmin sa tathā uktaḥ
translated: That in which non-violence is supreme and primary is so described.

original: etadasmākamapi sammatamityata uktamanyo hiṃsāsahito yajñādirna dharma iti /🔽ātmaviviktatvādirūpeṇa pudgalasya dehasya darśanam /
analyzed: etat asmākam api sammatam iti atas uktam anyaḥ hiṃsā sahitaḥ yajña ādiḥ na dharmaḥ iti  ātma vivikta tva ādi rūpeṇa pudgalasya dehasya darśanam
translated: This is also accepted by us. Therefore it is said that sacrifice etc. accompanied by violence is not dharma.🔽The vision of the soul, in the form of being distinct from the body etc.

analyzed: yat vā pudgalasya ātmanaḥ deha ādi vivikta tayā darśanam
translated: Or, the vision of the soul, the self, as distinct from the body etc.

analyzed: atra api na anyat yat siddhāntinā vivakṣitam iti anuvartate
translated: Here also, what is meant by the proponent is not different, this is continued.

analyzed: dūṣayati katham iti  katham tat syāt pramāṇam anumānataḥ
translated: He criticizes it with the word how.🔽How can that be a means of knowledge through inference?

analyzed: tat jina vākyam anumānena pramāṇam iti pratipattavyam katham syāt
translated: How can it be understood that the words of the Jina are a means of knowledge through inference?

original: anumānena vākyena ca jinasyāptatvamavadhāryāptavākyatvānumānena mokṣasādhanaṃ dharmaṃ jñānaṃ ca pratipādayato jinavākyasya prāmāṇyāvadhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: anumānena vākyena ca jinasya āpta tvam avadhārya āpta vākya tva anumānena mokṣa sādhanam dharmam jñānam ca pratipādayataḥ jina vākyasya prāmāṇya avadhāraṇam
translated: Or, having ascertained the trustworthiness of the Jina through inference and statement, the determination of the authoritativeness of the Jina's statement, which teaches the Dharma and knowledge, the means to liberation, through the inference of the statement of a trustworthy person,

analyzed: yat uktam tat na upapadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that what is said does not hold.

original: kuto nopapadyata ityato hetuṃ vaktumupodghātatvena pratyakṣānumānāgamasvarūpaṃ krameṇa tāvadāha viṣayāniti //
analyzed: kutas na upapadyate iti atas hetum vaktum upodghāta tvena pratyakṣa anumāna āgama svarūpam krameṇa tāvat āha viṣayān iti
translated: From where does it not hold? Therefore, in order to state the reason, he first states the nature of perception, inference, and scripture in order, saying the sense organs and so on.

original: viṣayān prati sthitaṃ hyakṣaṃ pratyakṣamiti gīyate /
analyzed: viṣayān prati sthitam hi akṣam pratyakṣam iti gīyate
translated: The sense organ that abides in relation to the objects is called perception.

analyzed: pratyakṣa śabda anusārāt anumā iti prakītiḥ tā
translated: Due to the similarity with the word perception, inference is well-known.

original: ā samantād gamayati dharmādharmau paraṃ padam /
analyzed: ā samantāt gamayati dharma adharmau param padam
translated: It conveys from all sides the Dharma and Adharma to the highest state.

analyzed: yat ca api atīndriyam tu anyat tena asau āgamaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: And also what is beyond the senses, by that it is remembered as scripture.

analyzed: viṣayān nirdeṣān prati sthitam taiḥ sat nikṛṣṭam akṣam aduṣyam indriyam
translated: The sense organ that abides in relation to the faultless objects, that is proximate to them, that is undamaged, is the sense faculty.

analyzed: jātau ekavacanam
translated: The singular is used for the class.

analyzed: yasya indriyasya yaḥ viṣayaḥ nvaya vyatirekābhyām avagataḥ tena adoṣeṇa sannikṛṣṭam aduṣyam tat pratyakṣam iti arthaḥ
translated: The object of which sense organ is known through positive and negative concomitance, that which is proximate to it without fault, that is undamaged, that is perception. This is the meaning.

analyzed: anena pra ādi samāsaḥ yam na avyayībhāvaḥ iti sūcitam
translated: This indicates that this is a tatpurusa compound beginning with a preposition, not an avyayibhava compound.

original: tathā sati pratyakṣasyeti ṣaṣṭhī na śrūyeta /
analyzed: tathā sati pratyakṣasya iti ṣaṣṭhī na śrūyeta
translated: If that were the case, the genitive ending in 'pratyaksasya' would not be heard.

analyzed: yadi api pratisthitam akṣam pratyakṣam
translated: Although the sense organ is present, it is pratyaksa (perception).

original: tathāpi yogyatayā viṣayāṇāṃ sambandha iti hiśabdenācaṣṭe / /
analyzed: tathā api yogyatayā viṣayāṇām sambandhaḥ iti hi śabdena ācaṣṭe
translated: Nevertheless, by suitability, there is a connection with the objects. This is indicated by the word 'hi'.

analyzed: pratyakṣa śabda anusārāt
translated: Following the word 'pratyaksa'.

analyzed: pratyakṣa āgama anusāreṇa eva māna tvam
translated: Validity is only in accordance with pratyaksa and agama.

analyzed: anusaraṇam ca tad gṛhīta dharmi ādimattvam tad abādhita apratibaddha viṣayatvam ca
translated: And following means having the dharma etc. grasped by it, and having an unobstructed and unhindered object.

analyzed: prakīrtitā anumā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is 'is declared as inference'.

analyzed: yā anumā prasiddhā sā asmāt nimittāt anumā iti prakītiḥ tā
translated: That inference which is well-known is declared as inference from these reasons.

original: yadyapyanusṛtā mānumā tathāpi sāmarthyātpratyakṣādisambandhaḥ /🔽anumānamūlānumāpyantataḥ pratyakṣādimūlaivetyuktaṃ prāk /
analyzed: yadi api anusṛtā mā anumā tathā api sāmarthyāt pratyakṣa ādi sambandhaḥ  anumāna mūlā anumā api antatas pratyakṣa ādi mūlā eva iti uktam prāk
translated: Although inference is followed, by implication it has a connection with pratyaksa etc.🔽Inference based on inference is ultimately based on pratyaksa etc., as stated earlier.

analyzed: ā iti anuvādena samantāt iti vyākhyānam
translated: The word 'ā' is a restatement, and 'samantāt' is explained as 'all around'.

analyzed: samyak ca iti api grāhyam
translated: 'Samyak' should also be taken.

analyzed: gamayati jñāpayati
translated: 'Gamayati' means to make known.

analyzed: karaṇe kartṛ tva upacāraḥ
translated: The instrument is figuratively spoken of as the agent.

original: grahavṛdṛniścigamaścetyakartari kārake bhāve vā apo vidhānāt /
analyzed: graha vṛ dṛ niḥ ci gamaḥ ca iti a kartari kārake bhāve vā apaḥ vidhānāt
translated: 'Graha', 'vṛd', 'ṛ', 'nic', 'gam' - these are used in the sense of the non-agent or the state, according to the rule.

analyzed: anupramāṇa viṣayam ca idam vyākhyānam jñātavyam
translated: And this explanation should be understood to refer to the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: yat ca dharma ādibhyaḥ nyat atīndriyam api śabdāt ananumitam ca
translated: And that which is other than Dharma etc., and is also supersensible, and is also not inferred, by the word 'api' (also).

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word 'tu' (but) is for emphasis.

analyzed: tena eva iti sambaddhayate
translated: It is connected with 'tena eva' (by that alone).

analyzed: samyak samantāt sarvam gamyate anena iti āgamaḥ
translated: Although 'āgama' (scripture) is that by which everything is known completely on all sides,

analyzed: tathā api pratyakṣa anumāna āgate rthe tasya vaiyarthyāt atīndriyam api iti uktam
translated: still, since it is useless in the case of an object known through perception and inference, it is said to be supersensible.

analyzed: tasya vivaraṇam dharma ityādi
translated: The explanation of that is 'Dharma' etc.

analyzed: yaḥ āgamaḥ prasiddhaḥ sau
translated: That which is well-known is scripture.

analyzed: nirvacana mātram eva etat pratyakṣa ādi śabdānām
translated: This is merely the etymological explanation of the words 'perception' etc.

analyzed: naca nirvacana labhyaḥ rthaḥ tivyāpti parihāreṇa avaśyambhāvi iti asti niyamaḥ
translated: And it is not necessary that the meaning obtained from the etymological explanation should necessarily be present in order to avoid over-extension.

analyzed: vyāghraparṇī ādiṣu abhāvāt iti na mantavyam iti āśayavān āha etena iti
translated: It should not be thought that it is not so because of the absence of 'vyāghraparṇī' etc. With this intention, he says 'by this' etc.

analyzed: etena kāreṇena eva tad tad māna tvam iṣyate
translated: By this reason alone, the status of being a means of valid knowledge is accepted for each of them.

analyzed: tat tad māna tvam pratyakṣa ādīnām pratyakṣa ādi tvam pratyakṣa ādi śabda vācya tvam iṣyate prāmāṇikaiḥ
translated: The status of being a means of valid knowledge for each of perception etc., i.e., the state of being called 'perception' etc., is accepted by those who accept valid knowledge.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādiṣu pratyakṣa ādi śabda pravṛttau nimittam eva etat
translated: This is the very reason for the use of the words 'perception' etc. in regard to perception etc.

original: natu nirvacanamātralabhyo 'rtha ityarthaḥ /🔽kuta ityata āha svarūpaṃ hīti //
analyzed: na tu nirvacana mātra labhyaḥ rthaḥ iti arthaḥ  kutas iti atas āha sva rūpam hi iti
translated: The meaning is that the meaning is not merely obtained from the etymology.🔽Why is it so? To this he says 'For that is their nature' etc.

analyzed: svarūpam hi tat eteṣām
translated: For that is their nature, etc.

original: tat nirdeṣaviṣayasannikṛṣṭanirdeṣendriyatvādikam eteṣāṃ pratyakṣādīnāṃ svarūpaṃ lakṣaṇaṃ hi ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tat eteṣām pratyakṣa ādīnām svarūpam lakṣaṇam hi iti arthaḥ
translated: That is, the nature of these perception etc. is the definition, which consists of having faultless objects and faultless senses etc.

analyzed: lakṣaṇam hi śabda pravṛtti nimittam bhavati
translated: For a definition is the reason for the use of a word.

analyzed: etat api kutas iti atas āha anyathā iti
translated: Why is this so? To this he says 'Otherwise' etc.

analyzed: anyathā asiddhi mānataḥ
translated: Otherwise, it would be established by that means of knowledge.

analyzed: anyathā asiddhiḥ ca tad mānam ca
translated: Otherwise, it would be established and that is the means of knowledge.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa pratyakṣa ādi lakṣaṇānām nirūpayitum aśakya tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the definitions of perception etc. cannot be determined in any other way.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam
translated: And this has been stated.

original: tataḥ kiṃ yadyevaṃ pratyakṣādisvarūpamityata āha ata iti //
analyzed: tatas kim yadi evam pratyakṣa ādi svarūpam iti atas āha atas iti
translated: So what? If perception etc. are thus the nature of perception etc., to this he says 'Therefore' etc.

original: ato 'numā kathaṃ dharmaṃ pudgalaṃ cāpi darśayet // / / //🔽anumetyanumānāvagataprāmāṇyaṃ jinavākyamucyate /
analyzed: atas numā katham dharmam pudgalam ca api darśayet  anumā iti anumāna avagata prāmāṇyam jina vākyam ucyate
translated: Therefore, how can inference show the Dharma and also the person?🔽Inference is said to be the speech of the Jina whose validity is understood through inference.

analyzed: ca api śabdau itaretara samuccaye
translated: The words 'also' and 'and' are for including each other.

analyzed: darśayet pratipādayet
translated: He should show, he should teach.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: jina vākyāt dharma ādi siddhiḥ iti vadatā kim pramāṇam uktam bhavati
translated: By one who says that the establishment of Dharma, etc. is from the words of the Victor, what is said as the means of valid knowledge?

analyzed: āgamaḥ iti ced na  samyak pratyakṣa ādi an avaga
translated: If it is said to be scripture, no.

analyzed: dhigata artha pratipādakasya eva āgama tvāt
translated: Because scripture is that which teaches a meaning not ascertained by perception, etc. properly.

analyzed: jina vākyasya ca tad asiddheḥ
translated: And because that is not established for the words of the Victor.

original: jino hi pramāṇenārthamupalabhya vākyaṃ praṇītavānanyathā vā /
analyzed: jinaḥ hi pramāṇena artham upalabhya vākyam praṇītavān anyathā vā
translated: For the Victor has composed a statement either having perceived an object by a means of valid knowledge or otherwise.

original: dvitīye pauruṣeyasya nirmūlasyonmattavākyavatsamyaktvaṃ durlabham /🔽ādye pratyakṣeṇānumānena vāvagatau tadanadhigatārthārthatā'sambhavaḥ /
analyzed: dvitīye pauruṣeyasya nirmūlasya unmatta vākya vat samyaktvam durlabham  ādye pratyakṣeṇa anumānena vā avagatau tad anadhigata artha artha tā sambhavaḥ
translated: In the second case, for a human statement that is rootless, like the statement of a madman, correctness is difficult to obtain.🔽And if it is ascertained by perception or inference, it is impossible for it to have a meaning that is not already known.

analyzed: vākya antareṇa ced andha paramparā āpattyā punar asamyaktvam eva  etena vimatam pramāṇam āpta vākya tvāt
translated: And if it is by another statement, there is the consequence of an infinite regress, so again it is simply incorrect.

original: jina āpto 'sskhalitavākyatvādityanumānaṃ jinadarśināṃ vākyaṃ ca pratyuktam /
analyzed: jinaḥ āptaḥ skhalita vākya tvāt iti anumānam jina darśinām vākyam ca pratyuktam
translated: By this, the inference of the opponent is refuted: The statement of the Victor is a means of valid knowledge because it is the statement of a trustworthy person, the Victor is trustworthy because his statement is unmistaken.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For thus:

analyzed: āpta tva viṣayam vākyam tāvat nirmūlam ced asamyak eva
translated: First, if a statement about trustworthiness is rootless, it is simply incorrect.

analyzed: vākya antara mūla tve pi tathā
translated: Even if it has another statement as its root, it is the same.

analyzed: na ca pratyakṣam mūlam
translated: And perception is not the root.

analyzed: viṣayān prati sthitasya akṣasya pratyakṣa tvāt
translated: Because the sense organ, which is situated in relation to the object, is perception.

analyzed: na ca āpta tva rūpa apara cittavṛttiḥ aparokṣa viṣaya tām aśnute
translated: And the mental activity of another person, which is in the form of being trustworthy, does not attain the state of being non-apparent to the object.

analyzed: atas skhalita vāc tva ādi anumāna mūlam iti eva vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, it should be said that the inference based on the fact of being a trustworthy person is the basis of the statement that is not erroneous.

analyzed: na ca etat anumānam
translated: And this is not an inference.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi anusaraṇena artha gamakasya anumāna tvāt
translated: Because that which conveys the meaning by following perception etc. is an inference.

original: nacaitatprakṛte asti /🔽āptavākyatvādityasya hi yathāśrutārthatve kvacidāptasya vipralambhakasyājñasya vākye vyabhicāraḥ /🔽āptimūlavākyatvādityabhiprāye viśeṣaṇāsiddhiḥ /
analyzed: na ca etat prakṛte asti  āpta vākya tvāt ityasya hi yathāśruta artha tve kvacid āptasya vipralambhakasya ajñasya vākye vyabhicāraḥ  āpti mūla vākya tvāt iti abhiprāye viśeṣaṇa asiddhiḥ
translated: And this is not present in the present case.🔽For if the meaning of because it is the statement of a trustworthy person is taken as stated, there is deviation in the statement of a trustworthy person who is deceptive or ignorant.🔽If the intended meaning is because it is the statement of a person whose trustworthiness is based on that, the qualifier is not established.

analyzed: tattva jñāna ādi lakṣaṇā khalu āptiḥ
translated: For trustworthiness is characterized by knowledge of reality etc.

original: tatra dharmādiviṣayaṃ tattvajñānaṃ tāvanna jinasya pratyakṣajanyam /
analyzed: tatra dharma ādi viṣayam tattva jñānam tāvat na jinasya pratyakṣa janyam
translated: Among them, the knowledge of reality regarding dharma etc. is not, for a Jina, produced by perception.

analyzed: viṣayān prati sthitasya akṣasya pratyakṣa tvāt
translated: Because the sense organ, which is situated in relation to the object, is perception.

analyzed: dharma ādeḥ ca akṣa aviṣaya tvāt
translated: And because dharma etc. is not the object of the senses.

analyzed: tathātve vā anyeṣām api tad adhigati prāpteḥ
translated: If it were so, then others would also attain the knowledge of it.

analyzed: atas eva na anumāna janyam
translated: For this very reason, it is not produced by inference.

analyzed: vākya antara abhyupagame tu andha paramparā eva
translated: If another statement is accepted, then it is like the blind leading the blind.

analyzed: evam avipralipsā api duradhigamā
translated: In the same way, non-deception is also difficult to understand.

analyzed: atas eva āpta tva sādhakam anumānam kāla atyaya apadiṣyam
translated: Therefore, the inference proving the authoritativeness is contradicted by time.

analyzed: āpteḥ ukta vidhayā bādhita tvāt
translated: Because authoritativeness is contradicted in the way stated.

original: anyeṣāmapratyakṣe 'rthe 'sya pratyakṣaṃ pravartata ityato na virodha iti cenna /
analyzed: anyeṣām apratyakṣe rthe sya pratyakṣam pravartate iti atas na virodhaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there is no contradiction because his perception operates in a matter imperceptible to others, it is not so.
Because there is a counter-argument based on being a human being, etc.

original: asskhalitavākyaṃ ca kvacidvā prakṛte vā sarvatra vā /
analyzed: a skhalita vākyam ca kvacid vā prakṛte vā sarvatra vā
translated: And his speech is infallible in some cases, in the given case, or in all cases.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

original: yaḥ kvacidasskhalitavāgasau viṣayaviśeṣa āpta iti vyāptyabhāvāt /
analyzed: yaḥ kvacid asskhalita vāc asau viṣaya viśeṣaḥ āptaḥ iti vyāpti abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no pervasion that he who is infallible in some cases is authoritative regarding a particular subject.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: nirdhāraṇa upāya abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no means of determining it.

analyzed: phala prāpti anumeyam khalu etat
translated: For this is to be inferred from the attainment of the result.

original: ata eva na tṛtīyo 'pi /🔽yattu niḥsvedatvādikaṃ liṅgamucyate tattāvatsandigdhāsiddham /
analyzed: atas eva na tṛtīyaḥ pi  yat tu niḥsveda tva ādikam liṅgam ucyate tat tāvat sandigdha asiddham
translated: For this very reason, the third is also not so.🔽As for the reason stated as being free from sweat, etc., that is doubtful and unestablished.

analyzed: auṣadha ādinā sambhavat anyathā asiddham ca
translated: And it is also otherwise established as possible by means of medicine, etc.

analyzed: na ca ayam manu ādi vākyeṣu api prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And this is not applicable to the statements of Manu and others.

analyzed: apauruṣeya tayā mūla anapekṣa veda mūla tvāt
translated: Because they are not dependent on a basis, being not composed by a person, and having the Veda as their basis.

analyzed: yat vai kiñcana manuḥ avadat tat bheṣajam
translated: Whatever Manu has said is a remedy.

analyzed: iti ādi vedena eva āpta tva ādi niścayāt ca
translated: And because authoritativeness, etc. are ascertained by the Veda itself, such as this.

analyzed: atas pratyakṣa ādīnām ukta lakṣaṇa tvāt jina tad darśita pratyakṣe para upanyasta anumāne jina ādi vākye ca tad abhāvāt anumāna ādi siddha āpta bhāva jina vākyāt dharma ādi siddhiḥ iti asat iti
translated: Therefore, since perception and so on have the characteristics stated, and since they are absent in the inference presented by others, in the statements of the Jina and others, and in the words of the Jina and so on that have been established by inference and so on, the establishment of Dharma and so on is not possible.

analyzed: na kevalam jinasya asskhalita vāc tvam niścāyaka abhāva ādi siddham
translated: Not only is the Jina's infallibility established due to the absence of a valid means of knowledge and so on,

analyzed: kintu iti āśayena āha svarūpe iti
translated: but also because of the perception of his fallibility. With this intention, he says in his own nature and so on.

analyzed: svarūpam pudgalasya uktāḥ doṣāḥ
translated: The faults of the pudgala have been stated in his own nature.

analyzed: viṣaya saptamīyam
translated: The locative case refers to the object.

analyzed: apudgala śabdena tañ iva yukta nyāyena pudgalāt dehāt anyaḥ tad sadṛśaḥ ca ātmā ucyate pudgala śabdena eva vā
translated: By the word pudgala, either the self which is different from the body and similar to it by the same reasoning as in the case of the pudgala, or the self itself is meant by the word pudgala.

analyzed: uktāḥ evam ca ātmā kātsnaryam ityādinā
translated: And it has been stated thus: The self is the totality and so on.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: jinena ātma svarūpam śarīra parimāṇam rūpavat ca uktam
translated: The Jina has stated the nature of the self to be the size of the body and to have form.

analyzed: tat prāk dūṣitam iti skhalita vāc asau iti
translated: That has been refuted earlier, so he is one whose speech falters.

original: yadyapi saptabhaṅginayo 'pi tadukto dūṣitastathāpi mokṣasādhanaṃ yatpudgaladaśarnamuktaṃ tatraiva skhalanapradarśanāyeyamuktiḥ /
analyzed: yadi api tad uktaḥ dūṣitaḥ tathā api mokṣa sādhanam yat tatra eva skhalana pradarśanāya iyam uktiḥ
translated: Although the doctrine of the seven modes of non-eternality has also been refuted by him, still this statement is made in order to show his fallibility in regard to the very doctrine of the pudgala which he has stated to be the means of attaining liberation.

analyzed: nanu etat api pūrva vākyena siddham
translated: But isn't this also established by the previous statement?

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: prapañca arthaḥ uttarabandhaḥ iti adoṣaḥ
translated: The subsequent connection is for the sake of elaboration, so there is no fault.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa ātma svarūpe jina vacana skhalanam darśayati ānandam eva iti
translated: In another way, he shows the Jina's words faltering in the nature of the self, saying bliss alone, etc.

analyzed: ānandam eva ca
translated: And bliss alone,

analyzed: na manyate pudgalam sa
translated: The person does not conceive of the self as different from bliss, etc.

analyzed: atra api apudgala pudgala śabdābhyām ātmā ucyate
translated: Here too, the words non-person and person refer to the self.

analyzed: tattva vidaḥ ātmānam ānāndam eva ānandena atyanta abhinnam manyante
translated: The knowers of reality consider the self, which is bliss, to be absolutely non-different from bliss.

analyzed: sa jinaḥ tam ānandam eva na manyante
translated: That Jina does not consider bliss alone.

analyzed: bhinna tva ādinā sapta prakāram bravīti
translated: He speaks of it as having seven kinds, such as being different, etc.

analyzed: tad sapta bhaṅgī naya nirāsena puṃstva ādi vat iti ātmanaḥ sukha ādi atyanta abheda sādhanena ca nirastam
translated: That is refuted by the refutation of the doctrine of seven modes and by the proof that the self is absolutely non-different from pleasure, etc., like masculinity, etc.

analyzed: atas ca skhalita vāgasau iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And therefore, he is one whose speech falters.

analyzed: itas ca tathā iti āha duḥkha iti
translated: And for this reason also, he says suffering and so on.

analyzed: duḥkha abhāvaḥ sukham tu iti
translated: Suffering is the absence of pleasure.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ ātma vyāvṛtti arthaḥ
translated: The word but is for the purpose of excluding the self.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The word iti is in the sense of reason.

analyzed: pūrveṇa eva sambandhaḥ
translated: It is connected with the previous [statement].

analyzed: yasmāt ātmā bhāvaḥ
translated: Because the self is an existent,

analyzed: sukham tu duḥkha abhāvaḥ
translated: but pleasure is the absence of suffering.

analyzed: na ca viruddha svabhāvayoḥ atyanta abhedaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: And it is not seen that two things having contradictory natures are absolutely non-different.

original: tasmādātmā na sukhātyantābhinna iti jino brūte /
analyzed: tasmāt ātmā na sukha atyanta abhinnaḥ iti jinaḥ brūte
translated: Therefore, the Jina says that the self is not absolutely non-different from pleasure.

analyzed: tat ca ayuktam iti atas skhalita vāgasau
translated: And that is improper, therefore he is one whose speech falters.

analyzed: kutas tat ayuktam iti atas āha mātrā iti
translated: From where is that improper? Therefore it is said mātrā and so on.

analyzed: mātrā bhoga atirekeṇa sukha ādhikyasya darśanāt
translated: Because the excess of pleasure is seen over the excess of the object and enjoyment.

analyzed: mīyante iti mātrāḥ śabda ādyāḥ viṣayāḥ
translated: Mātrā means objects such as sound, etc.

analyzed: bhogaḥ nubhavaḥ
translated: Bhoga means experience.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is an indication.

analyzed: viṣaya bhoga alpatvena sukha alpatva darśana tvāt iti api grāhyam
translated: Because the smallness of pleasure is seen due to the smallness of the object and enjoyment, this should also be accepted.

analyzed: sukham bhāvaḥ tāratamya upeta tvāt duḥkha ādi vat iti pramāṇa viruddha tvāt sukhasya duḥkha abhāva tva vacanam ayuktam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because pleasure is contradicted by valid cognition, the statement that pleasure is the absence of pain is improper, because pleasure is a positive entity endowed with degrees, like pain and so on.

original: sukhasya tāratamyopetatvasamarthanāya darśanāditi sākṣī tatra pramāṇatvena darśitaḥ /
analyzed: sukhasya tāratamya upeta tva samarthanāya darśanāt iti sākṣī tatra pramāṇa tvena darśitaḥ
translated: In order to establish that pleasure is endowed with degrees, the witness is shown there as the means of valid knowledge by the word darśanāt (because of seeing).

original: yastu tatrāpi vipratipannastaṃ pratyaniṣyaprasaṅgaṃ sūcayituṃ mātrābhogātirekeṇetyuktam /
analyzed: yaḥ tu tatra api vipratipannaḥ tam prati aniṣya prasaṅgam sūcayitum mātrā bhoga atirekeṇa iti uktam
translated: But for one who disagrees even there, in order to indicate the undesirable consequence, mātrābhogātirekeṇa (over the excess of the object and enjoyment) is stated.

original: yadi sukhaṃ niratiśayaṃ syāttadā prekṣāvatāṃ viṣayabhogātirekopādanaṃ vyarthaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi sukham niratiśayam syāt tadā prekṣāvatām viṣaya bhoga atireka upādanam vyartham syāt
translated: If there were an unsurpassed happiness, then the pursuit of excessive sensual pleasures by the wise would be pointless.

analyzed: dṛśyate ca tat iti
translated: And that is seen.

original: nanu na sukhaṃ tāratamyopetaṃ kintu duḥkhaṃ bhāvabhūtaṃ tāratamyopetaṃ tadabhāvaśca sukham /
analyzed: nanu na sukham tāratamya upetam kintu duḥkham bhāva bhūtam tāratamya upetam tad abhāvaḥ ca sukham
translated: But it is not happiness that is accompanied by degrees of intensity, but rather the existing misery that is accompanied by degrees of intensity, and the absence of that is happiness.

analyzed: tat yāvat yāvat nivartate tāvat tāvat sukham iti pratīyate
translated: And as long as that is removed, to that extent happiness is perceived.

analyzed: na ca pratiyoga rūpa upādhi nimittā tāratamya upalabdhiḥ tāttvikam tat upapādayitum īṣye
translated: And the perception of degrees of intensity due to the limiting conditions in the form of the counter-correlate cannot be accepted as establishing the reality of that.

analyzed: viṣaya bhoga atireka upādānam ca duḥkha atireka vyāvṛtti artham
translated: And the pursuit of excessive sensual pleasures is for the sake of avoiding excessive misery.

analyzed: viṣaya bhoga sādhya tvāt duḥkha abhāvasya iti atas āha sukhasya iti
translated: Because the absence of misery is accomplished by sensual pleasures. To this he says 'of happiness' etc.

analyzed: sukhasya abhāva tā kena
translated: By whom is the state of non-existence of happiness ascertained?

analyzed: bhavet etat pratīti ādeḥ aupādhika tva varṇanam
translated: This description of the superimposition of the perception etc. would be true,

analyzed: yadi sukhasya abhāvatā pramāṇena siddhā syāt
translated: if the state of non-existence of happiness were established by a means of valid knowledge.

original: sukhasyābhāvatā kena na kenāpi pramāṇena siddhetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: sukhasya abhāva tā kena na kena api pramāṇena siddhā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the state of non-existence of happiness is not established by any means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: evam eva pratīti ādeḥ aupādhika tva varṇane bādhakam āha na ca iti
translated: In the same way, he states the contradiction in the description of the superimposition of the perception etc. by saying 'not' etc.

analyzed: na ca syāt kim viparyayaḥ
translated: And why should there not be a contrary conclusion?

analyzed: yadi nirnibandhanam eva kalpyate
translated: If the fact of the gradation, etc. of pleasure being due to extraneous circumstances is assumed without any basis,

analyzed: tadā sukham bhāva rūpam duḥkham tad abhāvaḥ
translated: then pleasure is of the nature of an entity, and pain is the absence of that.

analyzed: tatra tāratamya darśanam pratiyogi sukha upādhi nimittam
translated: The perception of gradation in that (pleasure) is due to the extraneous circumstance in the shape of the counter-entity (pain).

analyzed: sukha nivṛtti arthāni ca ahi kaṇṭaka ādīni iti kim na syāt
translated: And the acts of biting one's lips, etc. are for the purpose of removing pleasure. Why should there not be a contrary conclusion as stated by the opponent?

analyzed: syāt eva
translated: It would indeed be so.

analyzed: atas dvayoḥ api anupalabhyamāna viśeṣa tvāt svābhāvika tāratamyoḥ bhāva tvam aṅgīkartavyam iti
translated: Therefore, since both (pleasure and pain) are not found to be different, their natural gradation should be accepted as being of the nature of entities.

original: sukhamabhāvo vastutvātsammatābhāvavaditi pramāṇasadbhāvātkathaṃ sukhasyābhāvatā kenetyuktamiti cet /
analyzed: sukham abhāvaḥ vastu tvāt sammata abhāva vat iti pramāṇa sadbhāvāt katham sukhasya abhāvatā kena iti uktam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that since there is a valid means of knowledge that pleasure is an absence because it is an entity, like an accepted absence, how can pleasure be said to be an absence by whom?

analyzed: kim evaṃvādinaḥ mate kaścid bhāvaḥ vidyate
translated: If so, is there any entity in the opinion of one who speaks thus?

analyzed: uta sarve pi abhāvāḥ
translated: Or are all of them absences?

original: ādye doṣamāha yadīti //🔽yadi bhāvo 'pi kaścit syāt tasyaivābhāvatā kutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: ādye doṣam āha yadi iti  yadi kaścid syāt tasya eva abhāvatā kutas
translated: In the first case, he states the fault with the word 'if'.🔽If there were any entity at all, how could that very thing be an absence?

original: vastutvena sukhasyābhāvatāmanumimānasya mate yadi kaścitpadārtho bhāvo 'pi syāt /
analyzed: vastu tvena sukhasya abhāva tām anumimānasya mate yadi kaścid padārthaḥ syāt
translated: If in the opinion of one who infers the absence of pleasure as an entity because it is an entity, there were any thing that is an entity,

analyzed: tarhi tasya sukhasya eva abhāva tā kutas
translated: Then how can that pleasure be non-existent?

analyzed: api tu bhāva tvena aṅgīkṛtasya api padārthasya abhāva tā syāt
translated: Moreover, even if a thing is accepted as existent, it would be non-existent.
Otherwise, there would be the fault of the non-existence of the thing being contradicted.

original: nanu sarve 'pi padārthā abhāvā bhavantyevati nokto doṣaḥ /
analyzed: nanu sarve pi padārthāḥ abhāvāḥ bhavanti eva iti na uktaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: Is it not said that all things are non-existent?

analyzed: yadi api ghaṭa ādīnām anādi tva ādi āpattyā prāk pradhvaṃsa atyanta abhāva tvam anupapannam
translated: Although it is not proper to say that a pot, etc. are absolutely non-existent before destruction, due to their beginninglessness,

analyzed: tathā api anyonya abhāva tvam yujyate eva
translated: nevertheless, their mutual non-existence is proper.

analyzed: ghaṭe hi paṭa ādi anyonya abhāvaḥ pramāṇa siddhaḥ
translated: For in a pot, the mutual non-existence of a cloth, etc. is established by valid cognition.

analyzed: na ca anyonya abhāvaḥ dharmiṇaḥ sti
translated: And the mutual non-existence is not different from the substratum.

analyzed: atas ghaṭaḥ eva paṭa ādi anyonya abhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the pot itself is the mutual non-existence of a cloth, etc.

original: evaṃ paṭādayo 'pīti dvitīyaṃ śaṅkate yadi sarve 'pīti //🔽yadi sarve 'pyabhāvāḥ syuranyonyamiti // / / //
analyzed: evam paṭa ādayaḥ pi iti dvitīyam śaṅkate yadi sarve pi iti  yadi sarve pi abhāvāḥ syuḥ anyonyam iti
translated: In the same way, a cloth, etc. are also like that. The second doubt is raised: If all are also mutual non-existences, etc.🔽If all things are mutual non-existences, etc.🔽The meaning is: if you think that all things are mutual non-existences.

original: sarve'pi padārthā anyonyābhāvāḥ syuriti yadi manyasa ityarthaḥ /🔽uttaramāha bhāvateti //
analyzed: sarve api padārthāḥ anyonya abhāvāḥ syuḥ iti yadi manyase iti arthaḥ  uttaram āha bhāvatā iti
translated: The answer is: If they are existent, etc.

analyzed: bhāvatā
translated: If they are existent, etc.

original: abhāvābhāvatā yat syāt kiṃ naśchinnaṃ tadā bhavet // / / // /
analyzed: abhāva abhāvatā yat syāt kim naḥ chinnam tadā bhavet
translated: If there is the non-existence of non-existence, what is cut off for us then?

analyzed: tadā evam sarva padārthānām anyonya abhāva tva vyutpādanena no smākam kim chinnam bhavet
translated: Then, when all things are thus shown to be mutual negations, what is cut off for us?

analyzed: na kim api
translated: Nothing at all.

analyzed: katham
translated: How so?

analyzed: yatas bhāva abhāvatā bhāvatā eva syāt
translated: Because the negation of negation would be just existence.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: sukhasya vastu tvena sādhyamānam abhāva tvam kim prāgabhāva ādi traya anyatama tvam
translated: The negation of pleasure, which is being proved as a real entity, is it being one of the three, prior non-existence, etc.?

analyzed: athavā anyonya abhāva tvam
translated: Or is it mutual negation?

analyzed: uta sāmānyam
translated: Or is it a universal?

analyzed: ādye prāk ukta doṣa parihāraḥ
translated: In the first case, the previously stated fault is avoided.

analyzed: dvitīya tṛtīyayoḥ siddhasādhanam
translated: In the second and third, the proof is superfluous.

analyzed: asmābhiḥ api sukha ādīnām sarva padārthānām anyonya abhāva tā svīkārāt
translated: Because we also accept that pleasure, etc. are mutual negations of all things.

analyzed: na ca bhāva tva aṅgīkāra virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with accepting existence.

analyzed: sukham hi sva anyonya abhāva duḥkha ādya
translated: For pleasure, which is a real entity, is the mutual negation of pain, etc.

analyzed: nyonya abhāvaḥ
translated: It is a mutual negation.

analyzed: abhāva abhāvaḥ ca bhāvaḥ eva
translated: And the negation of negation is just existence.

analyzed: evambhūtam ca abhāva tvam sukhasya na ātma svarūpa tām viruṇaddhi
translated: And such negation of pleasure does not contradict its being the nature of the self.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ pi tathātvāt iti  abhāva abhāvatā bhāvatā eva syāt iti uktam
translated: Because the self also has that nature.🔽It was said that the negation of negation would be just existence.

analyzed: tat upapādayitum bhāva abhāva svarūpam tāvat āha bhāva tvam iti
translated: To explain that, he first states the nature of existence and non-existence as existence, etc.

original: bhāvatvaṃ vidhirūpatvaṃ niṣedhatvamabhāvatā // / / //🔽bhāvatvaṃ nāma vidhirūpatvamabhāvatvaṃ nāma niṣedhatvamiti yojanā /
analyzed: bhāva tvam vidhi rūpa tvam niṣedha tvam abhāva tā  bhāva tvam nāma vidhi rūpa tvam abhāva tvam nāma niṣedha tvam iti yojanā
translated: Existence is the nature of affirmation, non-existence is the nature of negation.🔽The construction is: existence is the nature of affirmation, non-existence is the nature of negation.

analyzed: śabda pravṛtti nimitta niṣkarṣa artham bhāva pratyayaḥ
translated: The suffix 'tva' is used to extract the reason for the application of the word.

analyzed: anyathā indraḥ purandaraḥ itivat syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would be like 'Indra' and 'Purandara'.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha niṣedhasya iti
translated: What then? Therefore it is said: of negation.

original: niṣedhasya niṣedho 'pi bhāva eva balād bhavet // / / //
analyzed: niṣedhasya bhāvaḥ eva balāt bhavet
translated: The negation of negation would also necessarily be existence.

original: yasmādabhāvo nāma niṣedhastasmādabhāvasyābhāva iti niṣedhasyāpi niṣedha ityuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yasmāt abhāvaḥ nāma niṣedhaḥ tasmāt abhāvasya abhāvaḥ iti niṣedhasya api niṣedhaḥ iti uktam syāt
translated: Because non-existence is called negation, therefore the negation of non-existence would be said to be the negation of negation.

analyzed: sa ca vidhiḥ eva syāt  darśana balāt
translated: And that would be an affirmation.🔽By the force of perception.

analyzed: dṛṣṭaḥ hi neyaṅ uvaṅ sthānau
translated: For the negation of the affix and the verbal root has been seen.

analyzed: iti niṣedhasya a strī iti niṣedhaḥ vidhiḥ
translated: Thus the negation of negation is an affirmation.

analyzed: vakṣyate ca etat
translated: And this will be stated.

analyzed: vidhiḥ ca bhāvaḥ eva iti uktam
translated: And affirmation is only existence, it has been said.

analyzed: tasmāt abhāva abhāvatā bhāvatā eva iti yuktam
translated: Therefore it is right that the negation of non-existence is existence itself.

original: evaṃ tarhi dravyādayo bhāvāḥ prāgabhāvādayo 'bhāvā ityanyatroktaniyamo na syāt /
analyzed: evam tarhi dravya ādayaḥ bhāvāḥ prāgabhāva ādayaḥ bhāvāḥ iti anyatra ukta niyamaḥ na syāt
translated: If that is so, then the rule stated elsewhere that substances etc. are existents and prior non-existence etc. are non-existents would not be correct.

original: ghaṭasyāpi na paṭa iti niṣedharūpatāyāḥ prāgabhāvasyāpi prameya iti vidhirūpatāyā darśanādityataḥ prāguktaṃ smārayati prathameti //
analyzed: ghaṭasya api na paṭaḥ iti niṣedha rūpa tāyāḥ prāgabhāvasya api prameyaḥ iti vidhi rūpa tāyāḥ darśanāt iti atas prāguktam smārayati prathama iti
translated: Because it is seen that even a pot has the form of negation, as in 'not a cloth', and even prior non-existence has the form of affirmation, as in 'knowable'. Therefore, he reminds of what was said earlier with 'first' etc.
But the first cognition is the regulator of the existence of existence.

analyzed: kṛta vyākhyānam etat
translated: This has been explained.

analyzed: evam jinasya skhalita vāc tva pradarśanena tad uktasya mokṣa sādhanasya aprāmāṇika tvam uktam
translated: Thus, by showing the fallibility of the Jina's speech, the author has stated the lack of authority of what he has said as a means to liberation.

original: yuktiviruddhatvaṃ ca darśayannātmajñānasya yanmokṣasādhanatvamuktaṃ tatkiṃ sākṣādutātmaprasādadvāreti vikalpyādyaṃ tāvannirākaroti naceti
analyzed: yukti viruddha tvam ca darśayan ātma jñānasya yat mokṣa sādhanatvam uktam tat kim sākṣāt uta ātma prasāda dvārā iti vikalpya ādyam tāvat nirākaroti na ca iti
translated: Showing the contradiction with reasoning, he refutes the first option, which is whether the knowledge of the self that was said to be the means to liberation is direct or through the grace of the self. He first refutes the first option with 'not' etc.

original: na ca pudgalavijñānaṃ mokṣadaṃ bhavati kvacit // / / //
analyzed: na ca pudgala vijñānam mokṣa dam bhavati kvacid
translated: And the knowledge of the pudgala does not give liberation anywhere.

original: ātmavijñānaṃ mokṣadaṃ na bhavati acetanatvātpaṭavaditi śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: ātma vijñānam mokṣa dam na bhavati acetana tvāt paṭa vat iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The knowledge of the self does not give liberation, because it is insentient, like a cloth. This is the remainder.

analyzed: asya vyāptim ucapapādayati kvacid iti
translated: He explains the pervasion of this with 'anywhere' etc.

analyzed: na iti vartate
translated: 'Not' is used.

analyzed: mokṣa dam iti ca
translated: And 'giving liberation'.

analyzed: tat ca bhāva pradhānam
translated: And that is predominant in the positive sense.

analyzed: nahi kvacid api acetane mokṣa da tvam dṛṣṭam
translated: For the giving of liberation is not seen anywhere in the insentient.

analyzed: yena vyāptiḥ na syāt
translated: By which there would be no pervasion.

analyzed: karmaṇaḥ tathātvam nirākariṣyate
translated: The reality of action will be refuted.

original: jñānaṃ tu caitanyameva na cetanamiti prasiddhameva / /
analyzed: jñānam tu caitanyam eva na cetanam iti prasiddham eva
translated: But knowledge is consciousness itself, not the conscious self, as is well known.

original: ātmā jñātaḥ prasanno mokṣaṃ dadātīti dvitīyaṃ dūṣayati asvātantryāditi //
analyzed: ātmā jñātaḥ prasannaḥ mokṣam dadāti iti dvitīyam dūṣayati asvātantryāt iti
translated: The second view that the known and pleased self grants liberation is refuted with Because of non-independence, etc.

original: asvātantryāt pudgalasya jñāto 'pi sukhado na hi // / / //
analyzed: asvātantryāt pudgalasya sukha daḥ na hi
translated: Because of non-independence, the self, even when known, does not grant happiness.

original: jñāta ātmāpi sukhado mokṣado na bhavati /
analyzed: jñātaḥ ātmā api sukha daḥ mokṣa daḥ na bhavati
translated: Even when the self is known, it does not grant happiness or liberation.

analyzed: kutas svātantryāt
translated: Why? Because of the non-independence of the self, the individual soul.

analyzed: hi śabdena paṭa ādau vyāptiḥ sphuṭā iti sūcayati
translated: The word hi indicates that the pervasion is clear in the cloth and other examples.

analyzed: asvātantryam ca anupadam eva jñāsyate
translated: And non-independence will be known immediately.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ sukha mātra dānam na upapadyate
translated: The giving of mere happiness by the self is not possible.

analyzed: kim uta ananta sukha mokṣa dānam iti sūcayitum sukha daḥ iti uktam
translated: What to speak of the giving of infinite happiness and liberation? To indicate this, the giver of happiness is said.

original: pakṣadvayaṃ hetvantareṇa nirākaroti na hīti // /🔽na hi duḥkhiparijñānād duḥkhitvaṃ vinivartate // / / //
analyzed: pakṣa dvayam hetu antareṇa nirākaroti na hi iti  na hi duḥkhi parijñānāt duḥkhi tvam vinivartate
translated: The two positions are refuted with another reason with Because, etc.🔽Because the state of being miserable does not cease by the knowledge of the miserable one.

analyzed: ātma jñānam ātyantika duḥkha nivṛtti hetuḥ na bhavati duḥkhi jñāna tvāt devadatta jñāna vat
translated: The knowledge of the self is not the cause of the complete cessation of misery, because it is the knowledge of the miserable one, like the knowledge of Devadatta.

analyzed: jainena api sva ātma jñānam eva mokṣa sādhanam ucyate na ātma jñāna mātram
translated: Even the Jaina declares that the knowledge of one's own self alone is the means to liberation, not merely the knowledge of the self.

analyzed: īśvara jñāne vyabhicāra nirāsāya duḥkhī iti uktam
translated: The word suffering is used to rule out the fallacy in the case of the knowledge of God.

analyzed: tasya api sākṣāt mokṣa sādhanatva abhāva vivakṣāyām jñāna tvāt iti eva vaktavyam
translated: If it is intended that even that is not the direct means to liberation, then it should simply be said that it is because it is knowledge.

analyzed: yat vā ātmā duḥkham nivartayitum aśaktaḥ
translated: Or, the self is incapable of removing suffering.

original: duḥkhitvādyo yadanarthavānnāsau tannivartate śakto yathā daridro dāridrayanivartane iti tātparyātharḥ /
analyzed: duḥkhi tvāt yaḥ yat anarthavān na asau tat nivartate śaktaḥ yathā daridraḥ dāridraya nivartane iti tātparyātharḥ
translated: The meaning is that one who is suffering and unfortunate is not able to remove that, just as a poor person is not able to remove poverty.

original: duḥkhitvoktyāsvātantryaṃ samarthitaṃ svātantrye hi jātu na duḥkhī bhavediti / /
analyzed: duḥkhi tva uktyā asvātantryam samarthitam svātantrye hi jātu na duḥkhī bhavet iti
translated: By stating that it is suffering, self-dependence is established, for if there were self-dependence, one would never be suffering.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: na ātma jñānam devadattaḥ gām iva mokṣam dadāti
translated: The knowledge of the self does not bestow liberation like Devadatta giving a cow.

analyzed: kintu prakāśaḥ ndhakāram iva virodhāt duḥkham nivartayati
translated: But like light removing darkness, it removes suffering by contradiction.

analyzed: tatra kim acaitanyam kariṣyati
translated: What will non-sentience do there?

original: svātmajñānameva ca svaduḥkhavirodhi nātmajñānamātramiti dvitīyaheturapyaprayojaka ityāśaṅkayāha yadīti //
analyzed: sva ātma jñānam eva ca sva duḥkha virodhi na ātma jñāna mātram iti dvitīya hetuḥ api aprayojakaḥ iti āśaṅkayā āha yadi iti
translated: And the knowledge of one's own self is contradictory to one's own suffering, not merely the knowledge of the self. Thus, the second reason is also not a proper reason. Anticipating this doubt, he says if (the following verse).

analyzed: yadi pudgala vijñānāt aduḥkhī syāt kathañcana
translated: If one would become non-suffering in any way from the knowledge of the individual self,

analyzed: dehavān api nā aduḥkhī kim jñānāt uttaram sadā
translated: Even though embodied, he would not be unhappy, always after knowledge.

analyzed: kathañcana duḥkha ātma jñānayoḥ viruddha tvena
translated: Because knowledge and the nature of unhappiness are contradictory.

original: tarhi jñānāduttarakālaṃ dehavānapi sadā nirantaramaduḥkhī kinna syāt / syādeva /
analyzed: tarhi jñānāt uttara kālam dehavān api sadā nirantaram aduḥkhī kim na syāt syāt eva
translated: Then, even though embodied after knowledge, why would he not always be continuously without unhappiness? It would indeed be so.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati /🔽prakāśaḥ khalvandhakāravirodhitvāttannivartayan utpattyanantarameva nivartayati na tu vilambena /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  prakāśaḥ khalu andhakāra virodhi tvāt tat nivartayan utpatti anantaram eva nivartayati na tu vilambena
translated: This is what is said.🔽Light, being opposed to darkness, removes it immediately after arising, not with delay.

analyzed: vilambe virodhasya eva anirvāhāt
translated: Because if there were delay, the contradiction itself would not be established.

analyzed: tathā ātma tattva jñānam yadi duḥkha ādi anartha virodhi tvāt tat nivartya ātmānam muktam kuryāt
translated: Similarly, if the knowledge of the truth of the self, being opposed to unhappiness and other evils, were to make the self liberated by removing them,

analyzed: tarhi jina ādayaḥ tattva jñāna sampannāḥ jñāna utpatti anantaram eva muktāḥ syuḥ
translated: then the Jinas and others, endowed with true knowledge, would be liberated immediately after the arising of knowledge.

analyzed: na ca evam  deha ādimat tvena upalambhāt
translated: But it is not so.🔽Because they are perceived to have a body and so on.

analyzed: tathāvidhānām ca duḥkha ādeḥ avarjanāt iti
translated: And because they do not avoid such unhappiness and so on.

analyzed: iṣi āpatti nirāsāya sadā ityādi uktam
translated: To remove the undesirable consequence, always and so on is stated.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: The argument here is as follows:

original: duḥkhādikamātmatattvajñānavirodhi na bhavati bahulaṃ kālaṃ tena saha sthitatvātsammatavaditi /
analyzed: duḥkha ādikam ātma tattva jñāna virodhi na bhavati bahulam kālam tena saha sthita tvāt sammata vat iti
translated: And sorrow, etc., are not opposed to the knowledge of the truth of the self, because they exist together with it for a long time, like what is accepted.

analyzed: kiñca ātma tattva jñānam na tāvat āmokṣāt ekam
translated: Moreover, the knowledge of the truth of the self is not, to begin with, one, until liberation.

analyzed: jñānānām kṣaṇika tva darśanāt
translated: Because the momentariness of cognitions is seen.

original: tathāca yadanantaraṃ mokṣo 'bhilaṣṭate tajjinasya caramajñānaṃ na mokṣasādhanamātmajñānatvātprathamādijñānavat /
analyzed: tathā ca yat anantaram mokṣaḥ bhilaṣṭate tat jinasya carama jñānam na mokṣa sādhanam ātma jñāna tvāt prathama ādi jñāna vat
translated: And thus, the last cognition of the Jina, immediately after which liberation is desired, is not the means of liberation, because it is the knowledge of the self, like the first and other cognitions.

analyzed: anyathā prathamam eva mokṣam sādhayet aviśeṣāt iti
translated: Otherwise, it would bring about liberation even at the beginning, because there is no difference.

analyzed: nanu bhavadbhiḥ īśvara jñānam mokṣa sādhanam abhyupeyate
translated: But is not the cognition of God accepted by you as the means of liberation?

analyzed: tatra api samānam idam dūṣaṇam iti atas āha īśa iti
translated: Even there, this same fault is applicable, to which (the author) replies (with the verse beginning with) 'Iśa'.

analyzed: īśa kḷpti anusāreṇa syāt kālāt īśa vādinaḥ
translated: For one who holds that time, etc. are created by God, liberation would occur in accordance with the arrangement of God.

original: īśavādino mama mate tadicchāviśeṣānusāreṇa kālātkañcana kālamativāhya muktiḥ syāt /
analyzed: īśa vādinaḥ mama mate tad icchā viśeṣa anusāreṇa kālāt kañcana kālam ativāhya muktiḥ syāt
translated: In my view, as one who holds that God exists, liberation would occur after passing some time according to the particular will of that (God).

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intention (of the author).

analyzed: na vayam īśvara jñānam mokṣa sādhanam ācakṣmahe
translated: We do not say that the cognition of God is the means of liberation.

analyzed: kinnāma prasannaḥ parameśvaraḥ eva
translated: Rather, it is the supremely blissful God Himself, who is pleased (with the devotee).

analyzed: jñānam tu prasāda sādhana tvāt mokṣa sādhanam iti gīyate
translated: But knowledge, being the means of attaining grace, is said to be the means of attaining liberation.

original: sa ca cetanaḥ kāmapi kālakalpanāṃ karoti /
analyzed: sa ca cetanaḥ kām api kāla kalpanām karoti
translated: And that conscious [God] makes some kind of temporal determination,

analyzed: asmin samaye mum muktam kariṣyāmi iti
translated: saying, At this time I will liberate that one.

original: tatkalpanānusāreṇa bhavatyevāsau mukta iti na kaściddoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tad kalpanā anusāreṇa bhavati eva asau muktaḥ iti na kaścid doṣaḥ
translated: And in accordance with that determination, he becomes liberated, so there is no fault at all.

original: yathā brāhmaṇasya vidyācaraṇādinā prasanno 'pi prabhuścetasā kalpayati /
analyzed: yathā brāhmaṇasya vidyā caraṇa ādinā prasannaḥ pi prabhuḥ cetasā kalpayati
translated: Just as a lord, though pleased with a Brahmin's learning, conduct, etc., mentally makes a determination,

analyzed: āgāmini sūrya uparāge smai gām dāsyāmi iti
translated: saying, I will give him a cow at the upcoming solar eclipse.

original: sa brāhmaṇasya vidyācaraṇādinā prasanno 'pi prabhuścetasā kalpayati /
analyzed: sa brāhmaṇasya vidyā caraṇa ādinā prasannaḥ pi prabhuḥ cetasā kalpayati
translated: Though pleased with the Brahmin's learning, conduct, etc., the lord mentally makes a determination,

analyzed: āgāmini sūrya uparāge smai gām dāsyāmi iti
translated: saying, I will give him a cow at the upcoming solar eclipse.

analyzed: sa tad anusāreṇa tasmāt gām labhate tathā eva iti
translated: He obtains the cow in accordance with that, so it is the same.

original: evamātmajñānasya mokṣasādhanatvaṃ nirākṛtya dharmasyāpi taṃ nirācaṣṭe karmeti // /
analyzed: evam ātma jñānasya mokṣa sādhana tvam nirākṛtya dharmasya api tam nirācaṣṭe karma iti
translated: Thus, having refuted the means of attaining liberation through knowledge of the self, he refutes the means of attaining liberation through dharma, saying karma (action).

analyzed: karma hetu tvam api tu niścaitanyāt nahi kvacid
translated: But the causal nature of action is also not possible, because it is insentient, nowhere...

analyzed: karmaṇā hetu tvam karma hetu tvam mokṣam prati
translated: The causal nature of action, the causal nature of action with respect to liberation,

analyzed: yat vā karma hetu tvam iti bahuvrīhiḥ
translated: or the causal nature of action is a bahuvrīhi compound.

analyzed: mokṣasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Liberation is understood.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word 'tu' (but) is for emphasis.

analyzed: na eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is 'not at all'.

analyzed: niścaitanyāt karmaṇaḥ
translated: Because of the insentience of action.

original: vimataṃ karma na mokṣasādhanaṃ bhavati acetanatvātpaṭavadityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vimatam karma na mokṣa sādhanam bhavati acetana tvāt paṭa vat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the disputed action is not a means to liberation because it is insentient, like a cloth.

analyzed: vyāptim upapādayati nahi iti
translated: He explains the pervasion with 'not' (na hi).

analyzed: na iti ubhayatra
translated: 'Not' is connected to both.

analyzed: nahi kvacid acetane mokṣa sādhana tvam āvayoḥ sammatam
translated: For we do not agree that anything insentient is a means to liberation.

original: yenātra vyāptirna syādityarthaḥ /🔽nanvacetanatve 'pi viśiṣyaṃ karmedaṃ mokṣasādhanaṃ kinna syāditi cet /
analyzed: yena atra vyāptiḥ na syāt iti arthaḥ  nanu acetana tve pi viśiṣyam karma idam mokṣa sādhanam kin na syāt iti ced
translated: The meaning is that therefore there would be no pervasion here.🔽If it is asked how, even though it is insentient, this action specifically could not be a means to liberation,

analyzed: kim ā mokṣa prāpteḥ kriyamāṇam ekam eva karma uta anekāni
translated: is it that only one action is performed for the attainment of liberation, or many?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: kriyāṇām aneka tva darśanāt
translated: Because many actions are seen.

analyzed: pratikriyam karma utpatteḥ
translated: Because the action arises for each action.

original: ekatve ca jātasyaiva janma vā kriyāṇāṃ vaiyarthyaṃ vā viramyavyāpāro vā'padyeta /
analyzed: eka tve ca jātasya eva janma vā kriyāṇām vaiyarthyam vā viramya vyāpāraḥ vā āpadyeta
translated: And in oneness, there would be either the birth of what is already born or the futility of the actions or the operation after cessation.

analyzed: abhyupagamya ekatvam bādhakam āha aśeṣa iti
translated: Accepting oneness, he states the contradiction with 'all' (aśeṣa).

analyzed: aśeṣa duḥkha vilaye na idānīm kāraṇam yathā
translated: Just as there is no cause now for the dissolution of all suffering,

analyzed: tathā uttaram ca na eva syāt
translated: so it would not be so later.

original: yathedānīṃ prathamakriyottarakālaṃ jātaṃ karmāśeṣaduḥkhavilaye mokṣasya kāraṇaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: yathā idānīm prathama kriyā uttara kālam jātam karma aśeṣa duḥkha vilaye mokṣasya kāraṇam na bhavati
translated: Just as the action that arises after the first action is performed does not become the cause of liberation in the destruction of all remaining suffering,

analyzed: tathā uttara kālam vivakṣita kāle pi mokṣa kāraṇam na syāt
translated: in the same way, it would not be the cause of liberation at the time intended later on.

analyzed: karma tvāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: because it is an action.

analyzed: ekasya api karmaṇaḥ kāla bhedena bhedāt pakṣa sapakṣa tvam yujyate
translated: Even for a single action, there can be distinction by difference in time, so it can be a similar instance or a dissimilar instance.

analyzed: vipakṣe tu utpatti anantaram eva mokṣam sādhayet aviśeṣāt iti
translated: But in the case of a dissimilar instance, it would bring about liberation immediately after arising, because there would be no distinction.

analyzed: dvitīye pi bādhakam pramāṇam āha aśeṣa iti
translated: In the second case also, he states a countering proof: without remainder...🔽Here, now refers to the present manifestation of action.

analyzed: atra idānīm iti idānīntanī karma vyaktiḥ ucyate  uttaram iti antimā
translated: Later refers to the final one.

analyzed: anyat samānam
translated: The rest is the same.

analyzed: na ca antima karma vyatiriktānām karmaṇām mokṣa sādhana tvam asti
translated: And the remaining actions do not have the nature of being the means of attaining liberation.

analyzed: tathā sati tad anantaram eva mokṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because in that case, liberation would occur immediately after that.

analyzed: na ca pūrva sahakṛtyā antimasya karmaṇaḥ mokṣa sādhana tvam vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that the final action, in conjunction with the previous ones, has the nature of being the means of attaining liberation.

analyzed: iyattā abhāvena aniyata kāraṇakatva āpatteḥ
translated: Because in that case, it would follow that the cause is not determined due to the absence of a limit.

original: nahi jñānodayānantaramiyataiva kāleneyantyeva karmāṇi kṛtvāpavrajyata iti niyamaḥ pramāṇavān /
analyzed: nahi jñāna udaya anantaram iyatā eva kālena iyanti eva karmāṇi kṛtvā apavrajyate iti niyamaḥ pramāṇavān
translated: For there is no authoritative rule that one should go forth after performing only so many actions in so short a time after the arising of knowledge.

analyzed: na ca jainaiḥ iṣyate
translated: And it is not accepted by the Jains.

analyzed: jinānām viṣama kāla tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because the Jinas accept that there are different times (for different people).

analyzed: ābhāsa uddhāram karoti dṛṣṭi iti
translated: He removes the apparent contradiction by saying vision and so on.

analyzed: dṛṣṭi pūrvā anumā yatas
translated: Because it is inference preceded by vision.

analyzed: yasmāt iyam dṛṣṭi pūrvā pramāṇa gṛhīta vyāpti ādimatī
translated: Because this (inference) is preceded by vision, it has a pervasion etc. grasped by a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: tatas numā na tu ābhāsaḥ iti arthaḥ  yat uktam īśa kḷpti anusāreṇa iti tat asat
translated: Therefore it is inference, not an apparent one, is the meaning.🔽What was said about following the arrangement by the Lord is not correct.

analyzed: jñānāt īśvara prasādaḥ tatas muktiḥ iti atra pramāṇa abhāvāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there is no means of valid knowledge for the statement liberation is from the grace of God through knowledge and so on, that is not so.

analyzed: śruteḥ sadbhāvāt
translated: Because the Veda exists.

analyzed: tad prāmāṇyasya sādhita tvāt
translated: Because the validity of that (Veda) has been established.

analyzed: ābhāsāt an uddharan eva vā
translated: Or, without removing it from the apparent contradiction,

analyzed: ca anumānam api āha dṛṣṭi iti
translated: he also states the inference by saying vision and so on.

analyzed: śaktasya anyasya vijñānam tat prīti janakam yadi
translated: If the knowledge of another who is capable generates that pleasure,

original: tayaiva bandhahāniḥ syāditi kiṃ nāma dūṣaṇam // / / //
analyzed: tayā eva bandha hāniḥ syāt iti kim nāma dūṣaṇam
translated: then by that alone there would be the destruction of bondage. What is the fault in that?

analyzed: śaktasya anyasya vijñānam viśiṣya jñānam guṇa utkarṣa ādi jñānam iti yāvat
translated: The knowledge of another who is capable is the knowledge of something special, which is the knowledge of the excellence of qualities and so on, up to that.

analyzed: tat prīti janakam iti yadi anumīyate
translated: If it is inferred that it generates that pleasure,

original: yadi ca tayā tatprītyaiva bandhahāniḥ syādityanumīyate /
analyzed: yadi ca tayā tad prītyā eva bandha hāniḥ syāt iti anumīyate
translated: And if it is inferred that the destruction of bondage would be due to that, i.e., to the satisfaction of that [Lord],

analyzed: tadā kinnāma dūṣaṇam
translated: then what is the fault?

analyzed: na kim api  kutas
translated: Nothing at all.🔽Why?

analyzed: yatas dṛṣṭi pūrvā pramāṇa gṛhīta vyāpti ādimatī iyam anumā iti arthaḥ
translated: Because it is said that this [inference] is based on the previously seen [perception] and has a pervasion etc. grasped by a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: artha mātram idam uktam
translated: This much has been stated as the meaning [of the inference].

analyzed: eṣā tu prayoga prakriyā
translated: But this is the procedure of the argument:

analyzed: saṃsāra bandha hāniḥ samartha puruṣa antara prīti nibandhanā bandha hāni tvāt rāja prasāda adhīna bhṛtya nigaḍa bandha hāni vat
translated: The destruction of the bondage of worldly existence is based on the satisfaction of another capable person, because it is a destruction of bondage, like the destruction of the bondage of a servant's fetters which depends on the king's favor.

analyzed: yaḥ ca asau puruṣaḥ saḥ eva īśvaraḥ
translated: And that person is none other than God.

analyzed: vipratipannā prītiḥ guṇa utkarṣa ādi jñāna jā anija prīti tvāt rāja prīti vat
translated: The disputed satisfaction is born from the knowledge of the excellence of qualities etc., because it is a non-deviating satisfaction, like the satisfaction of a king.

original: karmādinā bhavannīśvaraprasādo 'pi guṇotkarṣādijñāne satyeveti na doṣaḥ /
analyzed: karma ādinā guṇa utkarṣa ādi jñāne sati evā iti na doṣaḥ
translated: Even the grace of God which arises from karma etc. is only when there is the knowledge of the excellence of qualities etc. So there is no fault.

analyzed: yat vā īśvara viṣayam guṇa utkarṣa ādi jñāna tvāt saṃmata vat
translated: Because it is the knowledge of the excellence of qualities etc. with regard to God, like what is accepted.

analyzed: na ca īśvara siddhayā doṣaḥ
translated: And there is no fault in establishing God.

analyzed: prathama anumānena tasya siddha tvāt
translated: Because He is established by the first inference.

analyzed: tat idam uktam śaktasya anyasya iti
translated: This is what is meant by by another who is capable.
