analyzed: asya puruṣasya etāvān mahimā yaḥ pūrva vākya uktaḥ iti uttara vākya balāt tat puruṣaḥ eva idam iti etat puruṣasya mahimnaḥ vācakam vacaḥ iti tāvat jñāyate
translated: The greatness of this person is just as described in the previous statement. By the force of the subsequent statement, it is understood that the statement That is the person expresses the greatness of that person.

analyzed: tatas ca mahima pratipādakam yathā syāt tathā vyākhyeyam
translated: And then it should be explained in such a way that it conveys greatness.

analyzed: na ca sarva ātma tvam mahimā
translated: And the greatness is not the state of being the Self of all.

analyzed: apakaṣar hetu tvāt
translated: Because that would be a cause of diminution.

analyzed: kintu sarva ādhipatyam eva  na ca tad atirikta ktam
translated: But it is only the lordship over all.

analyzed: mahimnaḥ vacanam
translated: And there is no statement of greatness apart from that.

analyzed: saṅkoce kāraṇa abhāvāt  itas u pi etat evam iti āha saḥ mṛtasya iti
translated: Because there is no reason for restriction.

original: so 'mṛtasyābhayasyeśo martyamannaṃ yadatyagāt /🔽ityamuktādhipatyaṃ tu pūrvārdhoktamanūdya ca // / / //
analyzed: saḥ mṛtasya abhayasya īśaḥ martyam annam yat atyagāt  tu pūrva ardha uktam anūdya ca
translated: And for this reason also it is so, he says: He is the Lord of immortality and fearlessness, whom mortal food has surpassed.🔽Having referred to the lordship over the unenlightened, which was stated in the first half,

analyzed: uta amṛtasya īśaḥ iti vidhatte mukti ga īśa tām
translated: He is the Lord of immortality, thus the Shruti enjoins the lordship over liberation.

analyzed: iti bhāgavata vacanāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: by the statement of the Bhagavata.

analyzed: anūdya yat annena atirohati iti vacanena hetutayā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Having referred to, the rest is: by the statement He surpasses by food, as the reason.

analyzed: vidhatte śrutiḥ
translated: The Shruti enjoins.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: uttarārdhe tāvadamuktādhipatyaṃ hetutvenopādāya muktādhipatyaṃ prati jānīte śrutiriti jñāyate /
analyzed: uttara ardhe tāvat amukta ādhipatyam hetu tvena upādāya mukta ādhipatyam prati jānīte śrutiḥ iti jñāyate
translated: In the latter half, it is understood that the Veda recognizes the lordship of the liberated one in relation to the lordship of the unliberated one, taking it as the cause.

analyzed: puruṣasūkta vyākhyāna prasaṅge saḥ mṛtasya iti bhāgavata vacanena uttara ardhasya tathā eva vyākhyāta tvāt
translated: Because the latter half is explained in the same way by the Bhagavata statement He is of immortality in the context of the explanation of the Purusha Sukta.

original: ata evaannena divyabhogena yadatirohatyadhirohatyedhate tasyāmṛtatvasya devatvasyeśānaḥ' /🔽iti vyākhyānamayuktam /
analyzed: atas eva annena divya bhogena yat atirohati adhirohati edhate tasya amṛta tvasya deva tvasya īśānaḥ  iti vyākhyānam ayuktam
translated: For this very reason, the explanation He is the lord of that immortality, of divine enjoyment, which one rises above, ascends, and flourishes is incorrect.

analyzed: bhāva bhavitroḥ ekatva abhiprāyeṇa amṛta tvasya iti etat amṛtasya iti hi vyākhyātam
translated: Because the word of immortality is explained as of immortality with the intention that the experiencer and the experienced are one.

analyzed: deva vyāvṛtti artham eva ca abhayasya iti uktam
translated: And the word of fearlessness is used just to exclude the gods.

analyzed: annena iti tṛtīyā ca dvitīyā arthā iti abhihitam
translated: And the instrumental case ending in by food is said to have the sense of the accusative case.

original: annaṃ ca na prasiddhamiti martyamityuditam /🔽so 'yamuttarārdhārthaḥ pūrvārdhasyāsmadvayākhyāna eva yujyate /
analyzed: annam ca na prasiddham iti martyam iti uditam  saḥ yam uttara ardha arthaḥ pūrva ardhasya asmat vayākhyāne eva yujyate
translated: And food is not well-known, so it is said to be mortal.🔽This meaning of the latter half is appropriate only in our explanation of the former half.

analyzed: pūrva ardhe mukta ādhipatyam vihitam
translated: In the former half, the lordship of the unliberated one is enjoined.

original: uttarārdhe tatpūrvārdhoktamamuktādhipatyaṃ hetutvenānūdya puruṣasya muktigeśatāṃ vidhatte śrutiriti /
analyzed: uttara ardhe tad pūrva ardha uktam amukta ādhipatyam hetutvena anūdya puruṣasya mukti geśatām vidhatte śrutiḥ iti
translated: In the latter half, the lordship of the unliberated one mentioned in the former half is referred to as the cause, and the Śruti enjoins the lordship of the person in liberation.

original: parakīyavyākhyāne tu parasparavyāghātenānupapanna eveti / /🔽etenapuruṣaśabdasya viṣṇuviṣayatve sarvātmakatvaṃ bādhakam /
analyzed: parakīya vyākhyāne tu paraspara vyāghātena anupapannaḥ eva iti  etena puruṣa śabdasya viṣṇu viṣaya tve sarva ātmaka tvam bādhakam
translated: But in the explanation of others, it is indeed unestablished due to mutual contradiction.🔽By this, in the case of the word person referring to Viṣṇu, the doctrine of being the soul of all is a contradiction.

analyzed: nahi viṣṇoḥ sarva ātmaka tvam bhavadbhiḥ api abhyupagamyate
translated: For you do not accept even that Viṣṇu is the soul of all.

analyzed: paśoḥ tu deha yoga vaśāt bhūta tva ādikam yujyate
translated: But for the individual soul, being a part, etc. are proper due to the connection with the body.

analyzed: iti tṛtīya pakṣaḥ pi nirastaḥ
translated: Thus, the third view is also refuted.

analyzed: upasaṃharati atas iti
translated: He concludes with therefore.

analyzed: atas viṣṇu parijñānāt eva muktiḥ na ca anyatas
translated: Therefore, liberation is only from the knowledge of Viṣṇu, not from anything else.

analyzed: parijñānāt parijñāna uditāt prasādāt
translated: From knowledge, from grace arising from knowledge.

analyzed: anyatas śiva ādīnām anugrahāt
translated: From anything else, from the grace of Śiva and others.

analyzed: pāśupatāḥ api jñāninaḥ bhogena eva karma kṣayam ācakṣate
translated: Even the Pāśupatas say that the actions of the knowers are destroyed only by enjoyment.

analyzed: tat api anupapannam iti āha tat yathā iti
translated: That is also unestablished, he says with that as.

original: tadyatheṣīkātūlamagnau protaṃ padūyetaivaṃ haivāsya sarve pāpmanaḥ pradūyante' / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā iṣīkā tūlam agnau protam padūyeta evam ha eva asya sarve pāpmanaḥ pradūyante iti śruteḥ
translated: Just as a piece of cotton thrown into a fire would be consumed, so all his sins would be consumed.

analyzed: iṣyakā iṣī kāmālānām cita tūla bhāriṣu
translated: In the desires of the desirous, in the cotton of the cotton-bearing trees.

analyzed: iti hrasvatā śruti tvāt na bhavati  protam praviṣyam
translated: Thus, shortness is not due to being heard.🔽Entangled, means entered.

analyzed: pradūyeta paritaptam bhavet bhasmībhavet
translated: Would be burnt, would be heated, would become ashes.

analyzed: iti tat nidarśanam yathā
translated: This is the example, as it is.

analyzed: asya jñāninaḥ
translated: Of this knower.

analyzed: pradūyante vinaśyanti iti atharṣaḥ
translated: Are destroyed, means perish.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ pūrva udāhṛta vākya samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for the purpose of including the previously quoted sentences.

analyzed: tatas eva viṣṇu parijñānāt eva
translated: From that alone, from the knowledge of Vishnu alone.

original: nanvasyāṃ śrutau jñāninaḥ karmaṇāṃ paritāpaḥ śrūyate natu jñānena vināśa iti vivakṣito 'rtha ityato bhagavadvākyasamākhyāmāha yatheti //
analyzed: nanu asyām śrutau jñāninaḥ karmaṇām paritāpaḥ śrūyate na tu jñānena vināśaḥ iti vivakṣitaḥ rthaḥ iti atas bhagavat vākya samākhyām āha yathā iti
translated: But in this scripture, the burning of the actions of the knower is heard, not the intended meaning of destruction by knowledge. Therefore, he mentions the name of the Lord's statement as 'yathā' (as).

analyzed: yathā edhāṃsi samiddhaḥ gniḥ bhasmasāt kurute rjuna
translated: As a fire, well-kindled, reduces firewood to ashes, O Arjuna,

analyzed: jñāna agniḥ sarva karmāṇi bhasmasāt kurute tathā
translated: So does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ashes.

analyzed: yadi api atra jñānasya kāraṇa tvam sphuṭam pratīyate
translated: Even though here the causality of knowledge is clearly understood,

original: tathāpi karmaṇāṃ bhasmasātkaraṇaṃ nāma mukhyāsambhavātkiṃ kalpanīyamiti na jñāyate 'tovākyāntaraṃ paṭhati sarveti //
analyzed: tathā api karmaṇām bhasmasātkaraṇam nāma mukhya asambhavāt kim kalpanīyam iti na jñāyate
translated: Still, since the reduction of actions to ashes is not possible in the primary sense, it is not known what should be imagined. Therefore, he quotes another sentence as 'sarva' (all).

analyzed: sarva dharmān parityajya mām ekam śaraṇam vraja
translated: Having renounced all other things, take refuge in Me alone.

original: ahaṃ tvā sarvapāpebhyo mokṣayiṣyāmi mā śucaḥ /
analyzed: aham tvā sarva pāpebhyaḥ mokṣayiṣyāmi mā śucaḥ
translated: I will deliver you from all sins. Do not grieve.

analyzed: ityādi bhagavat vākyaiḥ ukta arthaḥ ca avasīyate
translated: Thus, the meaning stated is ascertained by the words of the Lord, etc.

analyzed: dharmān avaiṣṇavān kāmya arthān ca
translated: The non-Vaisnava religious duties and those performed for the sake of desired objects.

analyzed: śaraṇa prāptiḥ ca sarva uttama tva vijñāna pūrvam
translated: And the taking of refuge is preceded by the knowledge of the Lord as the highest of all,

analyzed: ityādinā anyatra bhagavat pādaiḥ eva vyākhyātā
translated: as has been explained elsewhere by the Lord's own disciples.

analyzed: tatas prasannaḥ ham
translated: Then I am pleased.

analyzed: mā śucaḥ
translated: Do not grieve.

analyzed: na śociṣyasi muktaḥ bhaviṣyasi  ādi padena gata saṅgasya muktasya
translated: You will be liberated and will not grieve.

analyzed: ityādeḥ saṅgrahaḥ bhagavat vākyaiḥ ca iti sambandhaḥ
translated: By the word 'etc.' is included 'of one who has gone beyond attachment, who is liberated,' etc. The connection is: by the words of the Lord.

analyzed: tat yathā iti śruteḥ ukta arthaḥ bhagavat vākyaiḥ avasīyate iti vā
translated: The meaning of the Vedic text 'Just as...' is ascertained by the words of the Lord, or the meaning stated is ascertained by the words of the Lord.

analyzed: bhāṭṭānām mokṣa sādhanam anuvadati nitya iti
translated: He mentions the means of liberation according to the Bhattas, with the words 'nitya' etc.

analyzed: nitya naimittikam karma kurvan anyat parityajan
translated: Performing the obligatory and occasional rites, abandoning everything else,

analyzed: mucyate saṃsṛteḥ ca  nityam nāma yat akaraṇe
translated: one is liberated from the cycle of birth and death.🔽What is called obligatory is that for not performing which there is a prohibition.

analyzed: brāhmaṇī ādikam eva ca nimittam upādāya vihitam tat ucyate
translated: And what is enjoined on the basis of the occasion such as being a Brahmin, etc. is called occasional.

analyzed: yathā sandhyā vandana ādi
translated: Like the worship of the evening twilight, etc.

original: naimittikaṃ nāma yadakaraṇe pratyavāyaḥ pitṛmaraṇādyāgantukaṃ ca nimittamupādāya vihitaṃ taducyate /
analyzed: naimittikam nāma yat akaraṇe pratyavāyaḥ pitṛ maraṇa ādi āgantukam ca nimittam upādāya vihitam tat ucyate
translated: What is called occasional is said to be that which is enjoined taking as the occasion the death of a parent, etc., and the like, where there is a transgression if it is not done.

analyzed: yathā pitṛ śrāddha ādi
translated: Like the ancestral offering, etc.

analyzed: anyat kāmyam niṣiddham ca
translated: Other [actions] are optional and prohibited.

analyzed: tatra yatkāraṇe phalam akaraṇe na pratyavāyaḥ
translated: Among them, that which has a result as its cause, and no transgression if it is not done,

analyzed: kāmān animittam tad kāmyāt
translated: is optional because it is not caused by desire.

analyzed: yathā jyotiṣyoma ādi
translated: Like the Jyotiṣṭoma and Soma sacrifices, etc.

analyzed: pratiṣiddham niṣiddham
translated: The prohibited is prohibited.

analyzed: yathā brahmahatyā ādi
translated: Like the murder of a Brahmin, etc.

original: upāttaṃ ca karma bhogena kṣapayanniti caśabdārthaḥ /
analyzed: upāttam ca karma bhogena kṣapayan iti caśabda arthaḥ
translated: And the meaning of the word 'and' is that one who is engaged in action destroys it by experience.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ
translated: This is the intention.

analyzed: sukha duḥkha tad kāraṇa rūpaḥ hi saṃsāraḥ
translated: For the world is of the nature of pleasure, pain, and their causes.

analyzed: sa ca karma nimittaḥ eva
translated: And that is caused by action alone.

analyzed: nitya naimittikayoḥ akaraṇe tu adharma pravacayena duḥkha tad sādhana avāptiḥ asya bhavati
translated: But if one does not perform the obligatory and occasional [duties], he attains pain and its means by the propagation of demerit.

analyzed: niṣiddha karaṇe pi tathā
translated: It is the same even if one performs the prohibited [duties].

analyzed: kāmya karaṇe tu dharma utpādanena sukha tad sādhana avāptiḥ jāyate
translated: But if one performs the optional [duties], he attains pleasure and its means by the production of merit.

original: mumukṣustu nityaṃ naimittikaṃ ca nityameva karoti /
analyzed: mumukṣuḥ tu nityam naimittikam ca nityam eva karoti
translated: But one who desires liberation always performs the obligatory and occasional [duties] as obligatory [duties].

analyzed: parityajati ca niṣiddham iti na durita upacaya
translated: And he abandons what is prohibited, so there is no accumulation of sin.

analyzed: kāmyam api parityajati iti na dharma upacayaḥ
translated: And he abandons even what is desired, so there is no accumulation of dharma.

original: evamanāgatayordharmādharmayoranutpāde prāgupāttau ca bhogena kṣapayannirbījāyāḥ saṃsṛtermucyata iti /
analyzed: evam anāgatayoḥ dharma adharmayoḥ anutpāde prāc upāttau ca bhogena kṣapayan nirbījāyāḥ saṃsṛteḥ mucyate iti
translated: Thus, by not producing future dharma and adharma, and by consuming what was previously obtained through enjoyment, he is freed from the seedless cycle of rebirth.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: mokṣa arthī na pravarteta tatra kāmya niṣiddhayoḥ
translated: One seeking liberation should not engage in what is desired or prohibited.

analyzed: nitya naimittike kuryāt pratyavāya javāṃsayā iti
translated: One should perform the obligatory and occasional rites to remove obstacles.

analyzed: na ca pañcamī karma vidhā asti
translated: And there is no fifth injunction of action.

analyzed: yad karaṇe karaṇe vā dharma adharma udayaḥ syāt iti
translated: By performing or not performing which there would be the arising of dharma or adharma.

analyzed: nirākaroti etat api iti
translated: He refutes this by saying this is also refuted by that.

analyzed: etat api etena nirākṛtam  vidyā eva iti imam eva artham svayam eva āha vedarāj
translated: This is also refuted by that.🔽The Lord of the Vedas himself states this very meaning: There is no other path.

analyzed: etena na anyaḥ panthāḥ iti śrautena bhagavat jñāna vyatirikta mokṣa sādhana niṣedhena
translated: By this, the Vedic prohibition of means of liberation other than the knowledge of the Lord,

original: api ca nityanaimittikakarmaṇāṃ niyamena samyaganuṣṭhānaṃ tāvadaśakyameva /
analyzed: api ca nitya naimittika karmaṇām niyamena samyak anuṣṭhānam tāvat aśakyam eva
translated: Moreover, the proper performance of obligatory and occasional rites is indeed impossible.

original: caranti devā vihitaṃ samastamardhameva munayo daśāṃśato manuṣyāḥ' /
analyzed: caranti devāḥ vihitam samastam ardham eva munayaḥ daśa aṃśataḥ manuṣyāḥ
translated: The gods perform the entire duty, the sages half, and men one-tenth.

analyzed: ityādi śruteḥ
translated: Thus it is heard.

analyzed: na api niṣiddha akaraṇam sambhāvitam
translated: Nor is the non-performance of what is prohibited possible.

analyzed: prāmādikānām mānasa vācika kāyikānām aparihārya tvāt
translated: Because mental, verbal and bodily acts due to inadvertence cannot be avoided.

analyzed: prāyaścittāt tad kṣayaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that they are destroyed by expiation, it is not so.

analyzed: prāyaścittasya api samyak anuṣṭhātum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because even expiation cannot be properly performed.

analyzed: pūrva upārjita karmaṇām bhogena kṣayaḥ tu atyanta asambhāvitaḥ eva
translated: And the destruction of previously accumulated actions by experience is utterly impossible.

analyzed: ananta tvāt iti alam
translated: Because they are infinite. Enough of this.

original: nanvetatsarvaṃ sūtrānuktaṃ kasmādvarṇyata ityata āha vidyaiveti //🔽vidyaivetīmamevārthaṃ svayamevāha vedarāṭ // / / //
analyzed: nanu etat sarvam sūtra anuktam kasmāt varṇyate iti atas āha vidyā eva iti  vidyā eva iti imam eva artham svayam eva āha vedarāj
translated: But all this, not mentioned in the sutra, why is it described? To this he says 'vidya' etc.

analyzed: vidyā eva tu nirdhāraṇāt iti sūtreṇa
translated: The Lord of the Vedas himself declares this very meaning with the sutra 'Vidya eva tu nirधारणat'.

analyzed: svayam eva na tu arthataḥ
translated: By himself, not by the meaning.

analyzed: vājasaneyinaḥ dhīyate
translated: The Vājasaneyins recite:

analyzed: ṣaṭtriṃśat sahasrāṇi apaśyat ātmanaḥ gnīn arkān manaḥ mayān manaḥ citaḥ ityādi
translated: 'He saw thirty-six thousand fires of his own, consisting of mind, constructed by mind.' Thus it is stated.

analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ
translated: There is doubt there.

original: kimete 'gnayaḥ kriyānupraveśinastaccheṣabhūtā uta svatantrāḥ kevalavidyātmakā iti /
analyzed: kim ete gnayaḥ kriyā anupraveśinaḥ tad śeṣa bhūtāḥ uta svatantrāḥ kevalavidyā ātmakāḥ iti
translated: Are these fires engaged in action, being its remnants, or are they independent, consisting solely of knowledge?

analyzed: kriyā mayasya agneḥ prakaraṇāt tad viṣayaḥ eva ayam upadeśaḥ iti prāpte bhidhīyate
translated: Having arrived at the conclusion that this teaching is only about the fire of action, because of the context, it is said:

analyzed: vidyā ātmakāḥ eva ete gnayaḥ na kriyā śeṣa bhūtāḥ
translated: These fires are of the nature of knowledge, not merely a part of the ritual.

analyzed: te ha ete vidyā citaḥ eva iti nirdhāraṇāt
translated: Because of the restriction that they are indeed knowledge-based.

analyzed: iti pareṣām vyākhyānam asat eva iti bhāvena uktam imam eva artham iti
translated: With the idea that the explanation of others is indeed false, it is said this very meaning.

analyzed: viphala tvāt asyāḥ cintāyāḥ
translated: And because this consideration is fruitless.

analyzed: pakṣa dvaye pi abhyudayaḥ eva hi asya prayojanam
translated: For in both cases, its purpose is only prosperity.

analyzed: yaḥ tu nitya anitya vastu viveka vāc śama dama ādi sampannaḥ sarva bhoga vairāgya upetaḥ mumukṣuḥ atha śabdena uttara mīmāṃsāyām adhikārī sūcitaḥ sa katham etāsu
translated: But he who is endowed with the discrimination of the eternal and non-eternal, who is endowed with tranquility, self-control, etc., who is detached from all enjoyments, who is desirous of liberation, who is indicated by the word athā in the later Mīmāṃsā, how can he engage in these

analyzed: phalgu cintāsu pravartate iti
translated: frivolous considerations?

original: evaṃ sūtrakṛtā pūrvapakṣitāni matāni nirākṛtyedānīṃ ye sūtrāṇāṃ vṛttikārā anyathā bhāṣante teṣāṃ matāni nirākurvāṇaḥ samuccayaniyamavādināṃ
analyzed: evam sūtrakṛtā pūrvapakṣitāni matāni nirākṛtya idānīm ye sūtrāṇām vṛtti kārāḥ anyathā bhāṣante teṣām matāni nirākurvāṇaḥ samuccaya niyama vādinām
translated: Thus, having refuted the views presented by the author of the aphorisms, now, in order to refute the views of others who speak differently about the aphorisms, he first refutes the view of those who maintain the necessity of combination,

analyzed: matam tāvat apākaroti vinā iti
translated: saying without (karma).

original: vinā karma na mokṣaḥ syājjñānenetyapi sā śrutiḥ /
analyzed: vinā karma na mokṣaḥ syāt jñānena iti api sā śrutiḥ
translated: Without karma, there would be no liberation through knowledge - this is also stated in the scriptures.

original: nānyaḥ panthā iti hyeva nivārayati sādaram // / / //
analyzed: na anyaḥ panthāḥ iti hi eva nivārayati sa ādaram
translated: For the Lord clearly and emphatically declares, There is no other path.

analyzed: saṃsāra nivṛtti mātram kevalena jñānena bhavati
translated: The mere cessation of worldly existence occurs through mere knowledge.

analyzed: ānanda vṛddhiḥ tu kamarsa apekṣeṇa eva jñānena iti bhagavataḥ panthāḥ
translated: But the increase of bliss occurs only through knowledge dependent on action. This is the Lord's path.

analyzed: yat vakṣyati sahakāri tvena ca iti
translated: As he will say, And as a cooperating factor.

original: ato jñānakarmabhyāṃ mokṣa ityanuktvā karma vinā kevalajñānena na mokṣaḥ kintu karmasahitenetyuktam /
analyzed: atas jñāna karmabhyām mokṣaḥ iti an uktvā karma vinā kevala jñānena na mokṣaḥ kintu karma sahitena iti uktam
translated: Therefore, without saying that liberation is through knowledge and action, it is said that there is no liberation through mere knowledge without action, but through that accompanied by action.

original: ityetadapi mataṃ saiva sūtragṛhītaiva nānyaḥ panthā iti śrutiḥ spaṣṭaṃ nivārayati /
analyzed: iti etat api matam sā eva sūtra gṛhītā eva na anyaḥ panthāḥ iti śrutiḥ spaṣṭam nivārayati
translated: This view is also clearly refuted by the Vedic text, There is no other path, which is quoted in the sutra itself.

original: tamevaṃ viditveti jñānamātrasya mokṣasādhanatvamuktvā punarnānyaḥ panthā itrata vacanādādaro 'vagamyate /
analyzed: tam evam viditvā iti jñāna mātrasya mokṣa sādhana tvam uktvā punar na anyaḥ panthāḥ vacanāt ādaraḥ vagamyate
translated: Having said that the mere knowledge of Him who is to be thus known is the means of liberation, the emphatic statement There is no other path is understood again.

analyzed: na ca samuccaya niyame kim api pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no evidence whatsoever for the necessity of combination.

analyzed: andhantamaḥ praviśanti ityādīnām anya artha tvāt
translated: Because statements such as Entering into blind darkness have a different meaning.

analyzed: yathā annam madhu saṃyuktam madhu ca annena saṃyutam
translated: Just as food mixed with honey, and honey mixed with food,

original: evaṃ tapaśca vidyā ca saṃyukte bheṣajaṃ mahad' /
analyzed: evam tapaḥ ca vidyā ca saṃyukte bheṣajam mahat
translated: So austerity and knowledge combined are a great remedy.

analyzed: ityādīnām parokṣa jñāna viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because these and other passages are the subject matter of indirect knowledge.

analyzed: a parokṣa jñāna viṣaya tve pi ānanda vṛddhi artha tvāt
translated: Even if they are the subject matter of direct knowledge, because they serve the purpose of increasing bliss.

analyzed: māyā vādinaḥ vadanti
translated: The Māyāvādins say:

analyzed: dvividhaḥ mokṣaḥ para apara bhedāt
translated: Liberation is of two kinds, distinguished as supreme and inferior.

analyzed: tatra aparaḥ vaikuṇṭha satya loka ādi prāpti lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: Among them, the inferior one is characterized by attaining Vaikuṇṭha, Satyaloka, and so on.

analyzed: paraḥ tu avidyā astamaye sati advaita brahma avasthāna rūpaḥ
translated: The supreme one is of the nature of abiding in nondual Brahman upon the disappearance of ignorance.

analyzed: pratīka ādi viṣayam anyathā upāsanam aparasya sādhanam
translated: The worship of other deities and so on is the means of attaining the inferior one.

analyzed: parasya tu eka tva jñānam iti
translated: But the knowledge of non-difference is the means of attaining the supreme one.

analyzed: tatra anyathā upāsanasya vaikuṇṭha ādi prāpti sādhanatvam tāvat apākaroti anyathā iti
translated: Among them, he first refutes the means of attaining Vaikuṇṭha and so on, which is the worship of other deities, with the words otherwise (verse 10).

analyzed: anyathā upāsanam api tam evam iti vādinī
translated: The worship of other deities, as stated in the passage he who thus,

analyzed: nivārayati ādareṇa
translated: warns with respect to...

original: evaṃ yathāsthitenaiva prakāreṇa na tvanyatheti vadantī śrutiranyathopāsanamapi puruṣārthasādhanaṃ nivārayati /
analyzed: evam yathā sthitena eva prakāreṇa na tu anyathā iti vadantī śrutiḥ anyathā upāsanam api puruṣa artha sādhanam nivārayati
translated: The Vedic text, which states in this way, as it is, not otherwise, warns against the worship of other deities as a means of attaining the human goal.

analyzed: na kevalam parama puruṣa jñāna vyatirikta pakṣān
translated: Not only against the alternatives other than the knowledge of the supreme person.

analyzed: tam iti anena yathā artha jñānam labdham eva
translated: By the word him, the correct knowledge is already obtained.

analyzed: sa prakārasya prakṛtasya parāmarśa upapattau eka deśa viṣaya tva kalpanā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not proper to assume that the reference is to a part when the whole with its details is capable of being referred to.

analyzed: tathā api yat evam iti vadati tad ādara sūcana artham iti
translated: Even so, when one says in this way, it is to indicate respect.

analyzed: parama mokṣa viṣayā iyam śrutiḥ astu
translated: Let this scripture be about the supreme liberation.

analyzed: aparaḥ tu puruṣa arthaḥ nyathā upāsanena bhaviṣyati iti atas āha na iti
translated: But the other human goal will be accomplished by worshipping in another way. To this he says No.

analyzed: na pratīke iti prabhuḥ
translated: The Lord is not a mere symbol.

analyzed: na pratīke na hi saḥ
translated: Not in the symbol, for He is not.

analyzed: iti sūtra kāraḥ nyathā upāsanasya sarvathā api akartavya tvam vakṣyati
translated: The author of the aphorisms will say that worshipping in another way is not to be done at all.

analyzed: atas na tatpuruṣa artha leśa hetuḥ
translated: Therefore, it is not the cause of even a part of the human goal.

original: sūtrasyārthāntaraṃ vakṣyāmīti vadantaṃ prati śrutivirodhamāha andhamiti //
analyzed: sūtrasya artha antaram vakṣyāmi iti vadantam prati śruti virodham āha andham iti
translated: To one who says I will state another meaning of the aphorism, he points out the contradiction with scripture, saying Blind and so on.

analyzed: andham tamaḥ praviśanti ye vidyām upāsate
translated: Those who worship ignorance enter into blind darkness.

analyzed: iti śruti virodhāt ca na anyathā upāsanam bhavet
translated: And because there is also a contradiction with scripture, worshipping in another way cannot be.

analyzed: puruṣāthar sādhanam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is the means of accomplishing the human goal.

analyzed: śrutiḥ tu anyatra smṛti sammati pradarśanena vyākhyātā
translated: The scripture has been explained elsewhere by showing the agreement with smrti.

analyzed: idānīm ekatva jñānasya para mokṣa sādhanatvam nirākaroti na ca iti
translated: Now he refutes the idea that the knowledge of oneness is the means of attaining supreme liberation, saying No and so on.

analyzed: na ca api eka tva vijñānāt ukta nyāyena mucyate
translated: And he is not liberated by the knowledge of identity, for the reason stated.

analyzed: caḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for emphasis.

analyzed: eka tva vijñānāt api puruṣaḥ saṃsārāt na mucyate
translated: The person is not liberated from the cycle of birth and death even by the knowledge of identity.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: ukta nyāyena tam evam vidvān
translated: For the reason stated - 'One who knows this thus' (Br. 4.4.22).

analyzed: sahasraśiraḥ tva ādi mahā mahima upetasya bhagavataḥ jñānam amṛta tva sādhanam abhidhāyana anyaḥ panthāḥ
translated: Having stated that the knowledge of the Lord endowed with great glory such as having a thousand heads is the means of immortality,

analyzed: iti sādhana antara abhāvasya ukta tvāt  puruṣaḥ eva idam sarvam
translated: it has been stated that there is no other means, by saying 'There is no other path' (Br. 4.4.22).

analyzed: iti uktam eka tvam evaṃśabdena parāmṛśyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the oneness stated as 'The person is all this' (Ch. 7.25.2) is referred to by the word 'evam' (thus), it is not so.

original: uktanyāyena tasya vākyasyaikatvaviṣayatāyā abhāvāt /🔽tadyo yo devānāṃ pratyabuddhayate' /
analyzed: ukta nyāyena tasya vākyasya eka tva viṣaya tāyāḥ abhāvāt  tat yaḥ yaḥ devānām pratyabuddhayate
translated: Because, for the reason stated, that statement does not have oneness as its subject.

analyzed: ityādi śrutayaḥ tu tad guṇa sāra tvāt iti ukta nyāyena na aikya jñānasya mokṣa sādhanatām vadanti
translated: As for the statements beginning with 'He who is known as the gods' (Ch. 7.25.2), they do not state that the knowledge of oneness is the means of liberation, for the reason stated as 'because he is the essence of his qualities'.

analyzed: kiñca aikya jñānam anyathā jñānam iti pṛthak upadeśāt iti ukta nyāyena siddham
translated: Moreover, it is established by the reason stated as 'because it is taught separately' that the knowledge of oneness is a different knowledge.

analyzed: mithyājñānam ca anartha sādhanam iti uktam
translated: And it has been stated that false knowledge is the means of bringing about evil.

analyzed: api ca advaita jñānasya na tāvat yāga ādi vat rāja sevā ādi vat vā mokṣa sādhana tvam
translated: Moreover, the knowledge of non-duality is not the means of attaining liberation like sacrifice, service to the king, etc.

analyzed: kintu avidyā virodhi tvena
translated: But it is by being opposed to ignorance.

original: virodhinādvaitasākṣātkāreṇāvidyāyāṃ nivṛttāyāṃ tadupādānako bandhaḥ svayameva nivartata iti /
analyzed: virodhinā advaita sākṣātkāreṇa avidyāyām nivṛttāyām tad upādānakaḥ bandhaḥ svayam eva nivartate iti
translated: When ignorance ceases due to the opposing direct realization of non-duality, the bondage that has it as its material cause ceases by itself.

analyzed: tathā ca sākṣātkṛta advaitānām uttara kṣaṇe eva deha ādi dvaita darśana abhāvaḥ prāpnoti
translated: And so, for those who have directly realized non-duality, the absence of the perception of the duality of the body, etc. would occur in the very next moment.

analyzed: aṅgīkriyate ca jīvanmuktiḥ
translated: And liberation while living is accepted.

analyzed: jñānena avidyāyām nivṛttāyām api tad saṃskāreṇa dvaita darśana anuvṛttiḥ bhavati iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that even when ignorance ceases due to knowledge, the continuation of the perception of duality is due to its impressions, that is not so.

analyzed: saṃskārasya avidyā kārya tve
translated: Because if the impression is the effect of ignorance, its persistence is not logically possible.

analyzed: na hi upādāne nivṛtte kāryam avasthitam dṛṣṭam
translated: For an effect is not seen to persist when its material cause has ceased.

analyzed: anyathā satya tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Otherwise, it would lead to the undesirable consequence of its being real.

analyzed: jñāna udaye pi anivṛttasya tasya nivartaka antara abhāvāt sarvadā anivṛtta
translated: Even at the rise of knowledge, if it does not cease, there is no other means to make it cease. Therefore, it would never cease.

analyzed: nuvṛttau na kadāpi syāt
translated: And if it continues, the perception of duality would never cease at any time.

analyzed: asaṅgasya ātmanaḥ vinā eva avidyā sambandhena saṃskāra āśraya tvam ca ayuktam eva
translated: And it is indeed illogical for the unattached Self to be the substratum of impressions without any connection with ignorance.

analyzed: etena prārabdha karma vaśāt dvaita darśana a nivṛ
translated: By this, the non-cessation of the vision of duality due to the power of the karma that has begun to bear fruit,

analyzed: nirastam
translated: By this (argument) it is also refuted that the non-cessation of the appearance of duality is due to the power of the karma that has begun to bear fruit.

analyzed: jñānena nivṛttā api avidyā dagdha paṭa nyāyena kiñcid kālam avatiṣṭhate
translated: Even though ignorance has ceased by knowledge, it remains for some time like a burnt piece of cloth.

analyzed: tena dvaita darśana anuvṛttiḥ ghaṭate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that therefore the continuation of the appearance of duality is possible, it is not so.

analyzed: ātyantika nivṛttau kāraṇa abhāvena dvaita darśana anuparama prasaṅgāt
translated: Because in the case of absolute cessation, there is no cause for the non-cessation of the appearance of duality.

analyzed: etena avidyā leśa avasthāna pakṣaḥ pi pratikṣiptaḥ
translated: By this (argument), the theory of the remaining of a part of ignorance is also refuted.

original: leśaśca paṭasya tanturivāvayavo vā syātpradeśo vā dharmo vā /
analyzed: leśaḥ ca paṭasya tantuḥ iva avayavaḥ vā syāt pradeśaḥ vā dharmaḥ vā
translated: And the part would be either a part of the cloth like a thread, or a part of space, or a property.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: akārya tvāt avidyāyāḥ
translated: Because ignorance is not an effect.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: pradeśa anaṅgīkārāt
translated: Because space is not accepted.

analyzed: pradeśinaḥ nivṛttau pradeśa avasthāna asambhavāt ca
translated: And because when the possessor ceases, the existence of the part is not possible.

analyzed: na tṛtīyaḥ
translated: Not the third.

analyzed: upagame dharma anapagama anupapatteḥ
translated: Because when the possessor ceases, it is not possible for the property to remain.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is the opinion (that the part of ignorance remains),

analyzed: saṃsāra mūla kāraṇa bhūtā avidyā yadi api ekā eva
translated: although ignorance, which is the root cause of worldly existence, is indeed one,

analyzed: tathā api tasyāḥ santi eva bahavaḥ ākārāḥ
translated: nevertheless, it has many aspects.

analyzed: tatra ekaḥ bandhasya paramārtha satya tva vibhrama hetuḥ
translated: Among them, one is the cause of the delusion that bondage is ultimately real.
The second is the one that imagines things capable of effective action.

analyzed: tṛtīyaḥ tu aparokṣya pratibhāsa viṣaya ākāra kalpakaḥ
translated: The third is the one that imagines the form of the object of the appearance of non-transcendence.

analyzed: tatra advaitasya satya tva adhyavasāyena samasta dvaita satya tva kalpakaḥ ākāraḥ nivartate
translated: There, by the determination of the truth of non-duality, the form that imagines the truth of all duality ceases.

analyzed: arthakriyā samartha prapañca upādānam māyākāraḥ tattva sākṣātkāreṇa vilīyate
translated: The form of māyā, which is the material cause of the world capable of effective action, dissolves by the realization of reality.

original: aparokṣapratibhāsayogyārthāsajanakastu māyāleśo jīvanmuktasya nivṛttaḥ samādhyavasthāyāṃ tirohito 'nyadā dehābhāsajanakābhāsahetutayānuvartate
analyzed: aparokṣa pratibhāsa yogya artha āsa janakaḥ tu māyā leśaḥ jīvanmuktasya nivṛttaḥ samādhi avasthāyām tirohitaḥ nyadā deha ābhāsa janaka ābhāsa hetutayā anuvartate
translated: But the trace of māyā, which produces the appearance of objects suitable for the appearance of non-transcendence, ceases for the liberated while living, is hidden in the state of samādhi, and continues as the cause of the appearance of the body in other times.

analyzed: prārabdha karma phala upabhoga avasāne tu nivartate iti
translated: But it ceases at the end of the enjoyment of the fruits of the karma begun.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: asyāḥ kalpanāyāḥ niṣpramāṇaka tvāt
translated: Because this imagination has no valid means of knowledge.

original: indro māyābhiḥ pururūpa īyata iti śrutiratra pramāṇamiti cenna /
analyzed: indraḥ māyābhiḥ puru rūpaḥ īyate iti śrutiḥ atra pramāṇam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the Vedic text Indra moves with many forms by means of illusions is the valid means of knowledge here, it is not so.

analyzed: atra pārameśvara śakti pratipādanāt
translated: Because here the supreme power of the Lord is taught.

analyzed: jñāna bādhya anirvācya māyā kāra pratipādana a pratibhāsanāt
translated: Because the form of the inexpressible māyā, which is to be negated by knowledge, is not taught.

analyzed: tasya abhidhyānāt yojanāt tattva bhāvāt bhūyas ca ante viśva māyā nivṛttiḥ iti śvetāśvatara mantre
translated: And by the repeated concentration of the mind on that, by the attainment of the truth, and finally by the cessation of all worldly illusion, it is said in the Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad:

analyzed: bhūyas bhūyas tasmin manasaḥ yojanāt yaḥ jāyate tattva bhāvaḥ tattva jñānam tasmāt uditāt tasya
translated: By the repeated concentration of the mind on that, the attainment of the truth, the knowledge of truth, from that arising,

analyzed: parameśvarasya abhidhyānāt anugrahāt karma kṣaya ante viśva bandhaka māyā nivṛttiḥ bhavati iti ucyate
translated: by the grace of that Supreme Lord, at the end of the destruction of karma, the cessation of the worldly illusion that binds all, occurs.

analyzed: na tu anirvācya vidyākārāṇām krameṇa nivṛttiḥ bādha lakṣaṇā
translated: But it is not said that the forms of indescribable ignorance cease gradually, being negated.

original: kiñca yo 'pi māyākāro 'nuvartata ityucyate tattvajñānaṃ tasya virodhi na vā /
analyzed: kiñca māyākāraḥ nuvartate iti ucyate tattva jñānam tasya virodhi na vā
translated: Moreover, even that illusion which is said to continue, is it opposed to the knowledge of truth or not?

analyzed: ādye katham na nivartate
translated: If the former, how does it not cease?

analyzed: dvitīye jñānena na nivarteta
translated: If the latter, it would not cease due to knowledge.

analyzed: tathā ca satyaḥ syāt
translated: And if that were so, it would be true.

original: karmakṣaye sati nivartata iti vadatā karmaṇāṃ tatkāraṇatvamuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: karma kṣaye sati nivartate iti vadatā karmaṇām tad kāraṇa tvam uktam syāt
translated: By saying that it ceases when karma is destroyed, it would be said that karma is its cause.

analyzed: anyathā tad nivṛttau nivṛtteḥ anupapatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, its cessation would be impossible in its absence.

analyzed: atha manyase
translated: Now, if you think:

analyzed: jñānam eva avidyā leśasya nivartakam
translated: Knowledge itself is what removes the remnants of ignorance.

original: kintu prabalena prārabdhakarmaṇā pratibaddhaṃ na nivartayati /
analyzed: kintu prabalena prārabdha karmaṇā pratibaddham na nivartayati
translated: But it does not remove them when obstructed by powerful prārabdha karma.

analyzed: phala bhogena tu pratibandhake kṣīṇe nivartayati iti
translated: But when the obstruction in the form of the enjoyment of the fruits is destroyed, it ceases.

analyzed: tat api ayuktam
translated: That also is not proper.

analyzed: nirupādāna karma avasthāna anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for an action to remain without a substratum.

analyzed: saḥ eva avidyā leśaḥ karma upādānam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that that very trace of ignorance is the substratum of the action, it is not so.

analyzed: karma avasthāne vidyā leśa avasthānam tad avasthāne ca karma avasthānam iti paraspara āśraya tva āpatteḥ
translated: Because in the remaining of the action, the trace of ignorance remains, and in its remaining, the action remains, thus there would be the fault of mutual dependence.

analyzed: utpatti ādau iva avasthāne pi tasya doṣa tvāt
translated: Because even if it remains in the same way as in origination etc., that is a fault.

analyzed: kiñca asya arthasya na kiñcid sphuṭam jñāpaka antaram asti
translated: Moreover, there is no clear other proof for this meaning.

analyzed: tatas mā nāma bhūt avasthitau itaretara āśraya tvam
translated: Therefore, let there not be mutual dependence in remaining.

analyzed: jñaptau tu bhavati eva
translated: But in cognition, it does exist.

analyzed: jīvanmukti anyathā anupapattyā eva eṣaḥ rthaḥ kalpyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that this meaning is imagined only by the impossibility of liberation of the living being, it is not so.

original: paramapuruṣānugraheṇaiva mokṣa ityasya sakalaśrutītihāsapurāṇādisiddhasyārthasyāṅgīkāreṇaiva sarvasyopapattāvasyāḥ kalpanāyā anavakāśāditi
analyzed: paramapuruṣa anugraheṇa eva mokṣaḥ iti asya sakala śruti itihāsa purāṇa ādi siddhasya arthasya aṅgīkāreṇa eva sarvasya upapattau asyāḥ kalpanāyāḥ anavakāśāt iti
translated: Because in accepting the meaning established by all the Vedas, histories, Puranas etc. that liberation is only by the grace of the Supreme Being, everything is possible, and there is no scope for this imagination.

analyzed: adhikaraṇa artham upasaṃharati iti sarvam iti
translated: He concludes the meaning of the section with Thus all...

analyzed: iti sarvam pravijñāya sarvaiḥ tarka sat āgamaiḥ
translated: Having understood all this through all reasoning and true scriptures,

analyzed: upāsīta harim nityam guṇaiḥ eva sva yogataḥ
translated: One should always worship Hari with His own qualities through one's own yoga.

original: nāstyeva mokṣaḥ sattve vā sādhanāntarasādhya ityetadanupapannam /
analyzed: na asti eva mokṣaḥ sattve vā sādhana antara sādhyaḥ iti etat anupapannam
translated: That there is no liberation at all, or that if there is, it is to be accomplished by some other means, is not correct.

analyzed: kinnāma niṣkāma bhagavat artha śruti ādi vihita karma anuṣṭhānena śuddha antaḥkaraṇasya rāga ādi doṣa kṣaye
translated: What is it? By performing the duties enjoined by the scriptures etc. with no desire for results but for the Lord, with the mind purified, with the faults of attachment etc. destroyed,

original: jātabhagavadbhakteḥ śravaṇamanananididhyāsanābhyāsavataḥ paramabhāgavatasya bhagavatsākṣātkāre🔽jāte prasanno bhagavānaprārabdhāni karmāṇi vināśya bhāgavatadharmapravṛttaye jñāninaṃ🔽kamapi kālaṃ vyavasthāpayaṃstadarthaṃ prārabdhāni karmāṇyavaśeṣya tatphalopabhoge
analyzed: jāta bhagavat bhakteḥ śravaṇa manana nididhyāsana abhyāsavataḥ parama bhāgavatasya bhagavat sākṣātkāre  jāte prasannaḥ bhagavān a prārabdhāni karmāṇi vināśya bhāgavata dharma pravṛttaye jñāninam  kam api kālam vyavasthāpayan tad artham prārabdhāni karmāṇi avaśeṣya tad phala upabhoge
translated: with devotion to the Lord born, with practice of hearing, reflection and meditation, when the Supreme devotee has realized the Lord,🔽the pleased Lord, destroying the actions that have not yet begun, establishing the knower for some time to engage in the duties of a devotee, leaving aside the actions that have begun for that purpose,

original: sati tānyapi vināśya prakṛtibandhānmocayatīti sarvaṃ pratijñāya guṇaireva natu so
analyzed: sati tāni api vināśya prakṛti bandhāt mocayati iti sarvam pratijñāya guṇaiḥ eva na tu saḥ
translated: when the fruits of those actions are enjoyed, destroying even those, liberates him from the bondage of Prakṛti. Thus all this is promised.

analyzed: rodīt ityādinā pratītaiḥ api aguṇaiḥ iti samāne ca iti sūtrakhaṇḍasya artham anuvadati
translated: He repeats the meaning of the sutra portion Sama ane etc. with He is not born etc., which are not accepted as qualities, but are well-known.

analyzed: yuktam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is correct.

analyzed: sva yogyataḥ eva na tu yogyatā atikrameṇa iti prāpteḥ ca ityādi sū
translated: because it is obtained only by one's own fitness, not by exceeding fitness, etc.

analyzed: ti sūtra artha anuvādaḥ
translated: and because it is obtained only by one's own eligibility, not by exceeding eligibility, etc. This is the explanation of the meaning of the sutra.

analyzed: prayojanam ca uttareṇa saṅgati sūcanam iti
translated: And the purpose is indicated by the next sutra on connection.

analyzed: sva yogyataḥ iti uktam
translated: It is said by one's own eligibility.

analyzed: tām eva yogyatām vivṛṇoti brahma iti
translated: He explains that very eligibility with the word Brahma.

analyzed: brahmā sarva guṇaiḥ ca eva kriyā sāmānyataḥ ca gīḥ
translated: Brahma is endowed with all qualities and also with the general action.

analyzed: guṇa sāmānyataḥ rudraḥ dravya sāmānyataḥ pare
translated: Rudra is endowed with the general qualities, and the others with the general substance.

analyzed: brahma eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is Brahma alone.

analyzed: sarvaiḥ veda uditaiḥ
translated: With all those mentioned in the Vedas.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ kriyā dravya samuccaya atharḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of including action and substance.

analyzed: harim upāsīta iti vartate
translated: The verb upāsīta (should worship) is continued.

analyzed: veda ukta samasta guṇa kriyā upeta tayā ananta rūpam harim upāsitum brahmā eva yogyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that Brahma alone is eligible to worship Hari, whose form is infinite, by being endowed with all the qualities and actions mentioned in the Vedas.

analyzed: caḥ tu arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of tu (but).

analyzed: sarasvatī tu kriyā sāmānyataḥ kriyā saṅkocena upāste
translated: However, Sarasvati worships by the general action, by the contraction of action.

analyzed: sakala veda ukta guṇa upeta tayā ananta rūpam harim upāste
translated: She worships Hari, whose form is infinite, by being endowed with all the qualities mentioned in the Vedas.

analyzed: trivikrama tva ādi kriyāḥ tu nitya vikrānti ādiṣu antarbhāvayati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that she includes the actions such as the three steps in the eternal valor, etc.

analyzed: guṇa sāmānyataḥ samasta rūpāṇi upāste
translated: By the general qualities, she worships all the forms.

analyzed: guṇān kriyān ca saṅkocayati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it contracts qualities and actions.

analyzed: pare śakra ādayaḥ
translated: The supreme ones are Indra and others.

original: dravyāṇi rūpāṇi guṇakriyāsaṅkocastu siddha eva /🔽etenasamāna evaṃ cābhedāt' /
analyzed: dravyāṇi rūpāṇi guṇa kriyā saṅkocaḥ tu siddhaḥ eva  etena samānaḥ evam ca abhedāt
translated: The substances are forms. But the contraction of qualities and actions is already established.

analyzed: iti adhikaraṇa tātparyam uktam bhavati
translated: By this, it is said that the purport of the section is that it is the same as that, and because there is no difference.🔽This is the purport of the section on knowledge.

analyzed: vidyā eva tu nirdhāraṇāt iti atas pūrvam eva idam adikaraṇam
translated: But it is knowledge alone, because of the specification. This section is before that.

analyzed: tat kutas vyatyāsena vyākhyānam
translated: Then why is it explained in reverse?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: prakaraṇa śuddhau prameyam su graham bhavati iti atas krama bhaṅgaḥ
translated: When the topic is pure, the object of knowledge is easily grasped. Therefore, the sequence is broken.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

original: upāsanasvarūpāniścaye na ko 'pi vicāro 'vakāśaṃ labhata iti tatsvarūpamādau darśitam /
analyzed: upāsana svarūpa aniścaye na kaḥ pi vicāraḥ vakāśam labhate iti tad svarūpam ādau darśitam
translated: When the nature of meditation is not determined, no consideration can find an opportunity. Therefore, its nature is shown first.

analyzed: tatas tasya kartavya tā samarthitā
translated: Then its performance is established.

analyzed: anantaram tad itikartavya tā jijñāsāyām yogyatā ādi vicāraḥ iti
translated: After that, when the desire to know its procedure arises, the consideration of suitability and so on.

analyzed: iti vidyā adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on knowledge.
VI. The section on the extent of authority.

analyzed: atha yāvat adhikāra adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, the section on the extent of authority.

analyzed: om yāvadadhikāram avasthitiḥ ādhikārikāṇām om
translated: Om. The state of those with authority is up to the extent of their authority. Om.

analyzed: etat yathā yathā ityādinā bhāṣye vyākhyātam
translated: This is explained in the commentary by as it is and so on.

analyzed: tat avispaṣṭam
translated: That is not clear.

analyzed: adhikāra viśeṣasya kāraṇa tva an abhidhānāt
translated: Because the cause of the difference in authority has not been stated.

analyzed: muktau iti uktyā saṃsāre na evam iti pratīteḥ  ānanda mātra grahaṇāt guṇa anantara vyāvṛtti prāpteḥ
translated: Because it is understood that this is not so in the case of worldly existence by the statement about liberation.🔽Because the exclusion of the qualities is obtained by the mention of bliss alone.

analyzed: dharmiṇām anirdeśāt ca
translated: And because the substrata are not specified.

analyzed: atas spaṣṭam vyācaṣṭe adhikāra iti
translated: Therefore, he clearly explains with adhikara etc.

analyzed: yāvadadhikāram avasthitiḥ ādhikārikāṇām
translated: The state of the authorized ones is until the end of their authority.

analyzed: adhikāra viśeṣeṇa bhakti jñāna sukha ādibhiḥ
translated: By the difference in authority, by devotion, knowledge, bliss, etc.,

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ devatā ādīnām
translated: There is a difference in the deities, etc.

analyzed: adhikāraḥ yogyatā
translated: Authority is eligibility.

original: atra sāmānyoktyā muktau saṃsāre ceti gamyate /
analyzed: atra sāmānya uktyā muktau saṃsāre ca iti gamyate
translated: Here, by the general statement, it is understood to be in liberation and in worldly existence.

original: tarhi muktāviti kasmāduktamityata āha mokṣe ceti //
analyzed: tarhi muktau iti kasmāt uktam iti atas āha mokṣe ca iti
translated: Then, why is it said in liberation? To this he says in liberation etc.

analyzed: mokṣe ca eva viśeṣataḥ
translated: And especially in liberation.

analyzed: caḥ tu arthaḥ
translated: Cha has the meaning of tu.

analyzed: viśeṣataḥ tu mokṣaḥ eva iti anvayaḥ
translated: The connection is that especially in liberation alone.

analyzed: saṃsāre vikṣepa vaśāt yogyatā anusāri tvam kiñcid vihanyate
translated: In worldly existence, due to the influence of distraction, the conformity with eligibility is slightly obstructed.

original: mokṣe tadabhāvādyogyatānusāryeva niyamena bhaktyādikaṃ bhavatītyato muktāvityuktamiti /
analyzed: mokṣe tad abhāvāt yogyatā anusāri eva niyamena bhakti ādikam bhavati iti atas muktau iti uktam iti
translated: In liberation, due to the absence of that, devotion etc. necessarily conform to eligibility. Therefore, it is said in liberation.

original: evaṃ tarhi muktānāṃ parasparaṃ dveṣerṣyādiprasaṅgena muktatvavirodhaḥ syādityāśaṅkāparihārārthaṃ sūtramakṣaradhiyāṃ tvavirodhaḥ sāmānyatadbhāvābhyāmaupasadavattaduktam' /
analyzed: evam tarhi muktānām parasparam dveṣa īrṣyā ādi prasaṅgena mukta tva virodhaḥ syāt iti āśaṅkā parihāra artham sūtram akṣara dhiyām tu avirodhaḥ sāmānya tad bhāvābhyām aupasada vat tat uktam  /
translated: If this be so, then, in the case of the released souls, there would be a contradiction of their being released, on account of the possibility of mutual hatred, envy, etc. In order to remove this doubt, the Sūtra says, But there is no contradiction in the case of those whose mind is fixed on the syllable, on account of the general and special state of things, as in the case of the Upavasatha day; thus it has been declared.🔽🔽

analyzed: iti
translated: If so, then there would be a contradiction with being liberated due to the possibility of mutual hatred, envy, etc. among the liberated. To remove this doubt, the aphorism is: But there is no contradiction for those with the knowledge of the imperishable, due to sameness and that state, like the Upasads, that is said.

analyzed: etat api a viśadam
translated: This is also unclear.

analyzed: doṣa abhāva sāmyāt iti atra sāmya pada prayojana adarśanāt
translated: Because the word sameness is not seen to have a purpose in due to the sameness of the absence of faults.

analyzed: uttamebhyaḥ nyeṣām bhāvāt iti asya utpatteḥ iti pratīteḥ
translated: And because it is understood as due to arising for because of the existence of others than the best.

analyzed: śiṣya vat iti ca ayuktam
translated: And like a disciple is also improper.

analyzed: kvacid śiṣyasya api gurau dveṣa ādi darśanāt
translated: Because hatred, etc. towards the teacher is sometimes seen even in a disciple.

analyzed: atas vyākhyāti na iti
translated: Therefore, he explains: No.

analyzed: akṣara dhiyām tu avarodhaḥ sāmānya tad bhāvābhyām aupasada vat tat uktam
translated: But there is no contradiction for those with the knowledge of the imperishable, due to sameness and that state, like the Upasads, that is said.

analyzed: na tāvatā virodhaḥ sti nirdoṣa tvāt samastaśas
translated: There is no contradiction to that extent, due to being faultless in every way.

analyzed: ābhāsa tvāt pareṣām tad avarāṇām ca sarvaśas
translated: Because the others are appearances, and those below them are in every way.

analyzed: tāvatā parasparam asāmyena dveṣa ādi prasaṅgena mukta tva virodhaḥ sti
translated: There is no contradiction to being liberated due to the possibility of hatred, etc. by dissimilarity among themselves to that extent.

analyzed: sāmya śabdasya arthaḥ samastaśas iti
translated: The meaning of the word sameness is in every way.

analyzed: uttamebhyaḥ iti asya vivaraṇam ābhāsa tvāt iti
translated: The explanation of from the best is because of being appearances.

analyzed: tad avarāṇām sarveṣām parābhāsa tvāt ca iti yojanā
translated: And because all those who are inferior to them are reflected in them. This is the construction.

analyzed: etat eva vivṛṇvan dṛṣṭāntam vyākhyāti yatas iti
translated: Explaining this very example, he says yat (therefore).

original: yato 'varāṇāṃ sarve 'pi guṇāḥ sarvāḥ kriyā api /
analyzed: yatas varāṇām sarve guṇāḥ sarvāḥ kriyāḥ api
translated: Because all the qualities and all the actions of those who are inferior

analyzed: niyamena eva pūrveṣām su prasāda nibandhanāḥ
translated: are invariably based on the grace of those who are superior,

analyzed: atas sat śiṣya vat teṣām na eva īrṣyā ādiḥ kathañcana
translated: therefore, like a good disciple, there is never any envy etc. towards them.

analyzed: gurau sat śiṣyasya iva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is like a good disciple towards the teacher.

analyzed: etat ca uttaratra sphuṭīkariṣyati ācāryaḥ
translated: And this the teacher will make clear later on.

analyzed: cirantanāḥ tu vṛtti kārāḥ sūtra dvayam idam anyathā vyācakṣate
translated: But the ancient commentators explain these two aphorisms differently.

original: viduṣāṃ kiṃ jñānodayānantarameva muktiḥ kiṃvā neti saṃśaye pūrvasminpakṣe satīdamucyate /
analyzed: viduṣām kim jñāna udaya anantaram eva muktiḥ kiṃvā na iti saṃśaye pūrvasmin pakṣe sati idam ucyate
translated: When there is doubt as to whether liberation for the wise comes only after the rise of knowledge or not, in the former case, this is said:

original: ādhikārikāṇāṃ parameśvaradattādhikāre vartamānānāṃ viduṣāmapi devādīnāṃ yāvadadhikāraṃ saṃsāre 'vasthitiḥ /
analyzed: ādhikārikāṇām parameśvara datta adhikāre vartamānānām viduṣām api deva ādīnām yāvadadhikāram saṃsāre
translated: Even for the wise gods etc., who are engaged in the authority given by the Supreme Lord, there is continuance in the world as long as that authority lasts.

analyzed: na tadā eva muktiḥ
translated: Not liberation at that very time.

analyzed: tathā śruti ādiṣu darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen in the scriptures etc.

original: satyāmapi sādhanasampattau yadi na mokṣastadā na teṣāṃ kadāpi mokṣaḥ syādityāśaṅkāparihārāya dvitīyaṃ sūtram /
analyzed: satyām api sādhana sampattau yadi na mokṣaḥ tadā na teṣām kadāpi mokṣaḥ syāt iti āśaṅkā parihārāya dvitīyam sūtram
translated: If, even when the means are complete, there is no liberation, then there would never be liberation for them. To remove this doubt, there is the second aphorism.

analyzed: brahma vidām na mokṣa abhāva rūpaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: There is no contradiction in the form of absence of liberation for those who know Brahman.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

original: sāmānyatadbhāvābhyāṃ sāmānyaviśeṣabhāvābhyām /🔽yadyapi kṣīyante cāsya karmāṇīti sāmānyataḥ sarvakarmaṇāṃ jñānena kṣayo 'bhihitastathāpi tasya tāvadeva ciramiti viśeṣavacanātprārabdhakarmaṇāmavaśeṣo
analyzed: sāmānya tad bhāvābhyām sāmānya viśeṣa bhāvābhyām  yadi api kṣīyante ca asya karmāṇi iti sāmānyatas sarva karmaṇām jñānena kṣayaḥ bhihitaḥ tathā api tasya tāvat eva ciram iti viśeṣa vacanāt prārabdha karmaṇām avaśeṣaḥ
translated: By general and particular, by general and specific.

analyzed: gamyate
translated: Even though the destruction of all actions is stated in general by the knowledge of actions through the general statement His actions are destroyed, still, due to the specific statement For him, that much is a long time, the remainder of the commenced actions is understood.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: a prārabdhāni karmāṇi nivartante
translated: Uncommenced actions cease.

analyzed: prārabdhasya tu bhogena eva kṣayaḥ
translated: But the commenced [action] is destroyed only by experience.

analyzed: atas tad phala bhūte dhikāre sthitvā tad kṣaye pravrajyante iti
translated: Therefore, remaining in the office which is the fruit of that [experience], they go forth when that [experience] is destroyed.

original: māyāvādinastu prathamasūtrasyaivāyaṃ samasto 'rtha iti varṇayanto 'kṣaradhiyāmityetadadhikaraṇāntaraṃ vyācakṣate /
analyzed: māyā vādinaḥ tu prathama sūtrasya eva ayam samastaḥ rthaḥ iti kṣara dhiyām iti etat adhikaraṇa antaram vyācakṣate
translated: But the Mimamsakas explain that this is the entire meaning of the first aphorism itself, and they explain this as a separate section beginning with akṣara-dhiyā.

analyzed: tra ādyam matam nirākaroti na ca iti
translated: He refutes the first view with But that is not so.

analyzed: na ca saṃsāri devānām kāla iyattā pare ime
translated: And these are not about the limited duration of the worldly gods.

analyzed: sūtre
translated: In the sutra...

original: saṃsārāvasthānasya kāleyattā kālamaryādā prārabdhakarmaphalabhogāvasānarūpā sā parā uddeśyā pratipādyā yayoste tathokte /
analyzed: saṃsāra avasthānasya kāla iyattā kāla maryādā prārabdha karma phala bhoga avasāna rūpā sā parā uddeśyā pratipādyā yayoḥ te tathā ukte
translated: The limited duration of the worldly existence, which is the limit of time in the form of the end of enjoying the fruits of the previously performed actions, is the supreme object to be taught. Those two are said to be like that.

analyzed: kutas na iti atas āha hi iti
translated: Why not? Therefore he says hi (indeed).

original: hyārabdhamātrasya bhogenaiva kṣayo dhruvaḥ // / / //🔽anārabdhakārye bhogena tvitare iti coditaḥ // / / //
analyzed: hi ārabdha mātrasya bhogena eva kṣayaḥ dhruvaḥ  anārabdha kārye bhogena tu itare iti coditaḥ
translated: Indeed, the destruction of only what has been begun is certain only through enjoyment.🔽But it has been stated that the other (actions) whose fruits have not begun are destroyed by knowledge.

original: yasmādanārabdhasya jñānenaiva kṣaya ārabdhamātrasya bhogenaiva kṣayo dhruva ityeṣo 'thaanārabdhakārye eva tu pūrve tadavadheḥ' /🔽iti sūtreṇa /
analyzed: yasmāt anārabdhasya jñānena eva kṣayaḥ ārabdha mātrasya bhogena eva kṣayaḥ dhruvaḥ eva tu pūrve tad avadheḥ  iti sūtreṇa
translated: Because the destruction of what has not begun is only by knowledge, and the destruction of only what has been begun is certain only through enjoyment, this is stated in the sutra But the previous (actions) whose fruits have not begun are destroyed by knowledge, because their time has come.

analyzed: bhogena tu itare kṣapayitvā atha sampatsyate
translated: And in the sutra But the other (actions) whose fruits have not begun are destroyed by enjoyment, and then he will attain liberation.

analyzed: iti ca sūtreṇa uditaḥ
translated: It has been stated.

analyzed: tasmāt na iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Therefore, the connection is not.

original: evamuditatve 'pi kuto netyāśaṅkāṃ pariharannapavyākhyānirāsasya prayojanamāha paunaruktyeneti //
analyzed: evam udita tve pi kutas nā iti āśaṅkām pariharan apavyākhyā nirāsasya prayojanam āha paunaruktyena iti
translated: Even though it has been stated thus, he removes the doubt of why not? and states the purpose of refuting the wrong explanation. He says due to repetition etc.

analyzed: paunaruktayena tena ete ukta arthe iti niścayaḥ
translated: Due to repetition, it is certain that these (actions) have been stated in the sutra.

analyzed: etena māyā vādinām api vyākhyānam
translated: By this, the explanation of the Mādhyamikas

analyzed: matam nirastam
translated: is also rejected.

analyzed: tātparya bhedāt prapañcana bhāvāt vā na paunaruktyam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that there is no repetition due to the difference in purport or the elaboration,

analyzed: syāt evam
translated: it may be so.

analyzed: yadi asaṅkīrṇam vyākhyāna antaram na syāt
translated: If there were no unmixed other explanation.

analyzed: tat idam uktam iti niścayaḥ iti
translated: This is what is meant by certainty.

analyzed: iti yāvat adhikara adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the extent of authority.

analyzed: iyat āmanana adhikaraṇa
translated: VI. The section on the non-reflection on this much.

analyzed: atha iyat āmanana adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, the section on the non-reflection on this much.

analyzed: om iyat āmananāt om
translated: Om. Because of the non-reflection on this much.

analyzed: yeṣām jñāna yogyānām idam mukti saṃsārayoḥ tāratamyam samarthitam
translated: For those who are fit for the knowledge yoga, this gradation of liberation and worldly existence has been established.

analyzed: te chandogānām upaniṣadi nāma vāc ādi krameṇa prāṇa antāḥ uktāḥ
translated: They are mentioned in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad, from name, speech, etc., up to prāṇa.

original: tatra kiṃ prāṇa evādhikāritāratamyasyāvadhiḥ utādhiko 'pyastīti saṃśaye satīyadeva devatātāratamyamiti siddhāntitam /
analyzed: tatra kim prāṇaḥ eva adhikāri tāratamyasya avadhiḥ uta adhikaḥ pi asti iti saṃśaye satī iyat eva devatā tāratamyam iti siddhāntitam
translated: There, is prāṇa alone the limit of the gradation of authority, or is there something higher? In doubt, the conclusion is that the gradation of deities is just this much.

original: tatra na jñāyate kāstā nāmādyā devatā iti /
analyzed: tatra na jñāyate kāḥ tāḥ nāma ādyāḥ devatāḥ iti
translated: There, it is not known what are those deities beginning with name, etc.

original: kathaṃ ca pañcadaśaiva adhikānāmapi bhāvādityāśaṅkānirāsārthaṃ bṛhatsaṃhitāvacanameva paṭhati uṣā iti //
analyzed: katham ca pañcadaśa eva adhikānām api bhāvāt iti āśaṅkā nirāsa artham bṛhatsaṃhitā vacanam eva paṭhati uṣāḥ iti
translated: And how are there only fifteen, even though there are more? To remove this doubt, he quotes the statement from the Bṛhatsaṃhitā itself, beginning with Uṣā.

analyzed: iyat āmananāt
translated: Because of the non-reflection on this much.

original: uṣāḥ svāhā ca parjanyo mitro 'gnirvaruṇo vidhuḥ /
analyzed: uṣāḥ svāhā ca parjanyaḥ mitraḥ gniḥ varuṇaḥ vidhuḥ
translated: Uṣā, Svāhā, Parjanya, Mitra, Agni, Varuṇa, Vidhu,

original: pravaho 'niruddha indrome rudro vāṇī ca mārutaḥ /
analyzed: pravahaḥ niruddhaḥ indra ume rudraḥ vāṇī ca mārutaḥ
translated: Pravaha, Aniruddha, Indra, Rudra, Vāṇī, and Marut,

analyzed: uttarottarataḥ tu ete guṇaiḥ sarvaiḥ ca mukti gāḥ

analyzed: uṣāḥ aśvinoḥ bhāryā

analyzed: svāhā agneḥ bhāryā

analyzed: parjanyaḥ mitraḥ ca ādityau

analyzed: pravahaḥ marut

analyzed: aniruddhaḥ kāmasutaḥ

analyzed: ete saṃsāra gāḥ ca sarvaiḥ guṇaiḥ uktam eva uttaratas eva vartante iti arthaḥ
translated: These attain liberation and are subject to the cycle of birth and death. The meaning is that they exist progressively with all the qualities mentioned.

analyzed: adhika sadbhāva śaṅkā nirāsāya eteṣām sama anantara avasthitān ca āha sūrya ityādinā
translated: To remove doubts about the existence of superior beings, he mentions those who are immediately below them, beginning with Surya.

analyzed: sūrya dharmau yathā somaḥ manuḥ dakṣaḥ bṛhaspatiḥ

analyzed: śacī ratiḥ ca aniruddha samāḥ tārā ca mitravat

analyzed: soma vat śata rūpā tu prasūtiḥ vahni vat virāj
translated: Shatarupa is like Soma, Prasūti is like Agni, Virāṭ is like Parjanya,

analyzed: parjanya vat vāruṇī ca tathā sañjñā ca rohiṇī
translated: Vāruṇī is like Parjanya, and Sañjñā is like Rohinī.

analyzed: dharmī ca mitravat tvena prāvahī parikīrtitā

analyzed: mitrapa jarnya madhya sthau aśvinau vighna vittapau

analyzed: bhṛguḥ agni samaḥ mitra tad madhye brahma putrakāḥ

analyzed: niṛtiḥ mitra sadṛśaḥ viśvāmitraḥ ka sūnu vat

analyzed: tad anye tu tatas varāḥ

analyzed: tathā iti śeṣaḥ

analyzed: tārā bṛhaspati bhāryā

analyzed: caḥ tu arthaḥ

analyzed: satyam

translated: The wives of the Prajāpatis are mentioned separately now because they are the subject at hand.🔽Prasūti, the wife of Dakṣa, is like Agni.

analyzed: pravahasya iyam pravāhī tu mitra vat eva prakīrtitā

analyzed: aśvinau vighnapa vittapau mitra parjanya madhya sthau iti pratyekam sambandhaḥ

analyzed: ete catvāraḥ parasparam samāḥ mitrāt adhamāḥ

analyzed: brahma putrāḥ marīci ādyāḥ mitra tad madhye mitra agnyoḥ madhye

analyzed: parasparam samāḥ mitrāt uttamāḥ agneḥ adhamāḥ iti arthaḥ

original: tatra teṣu brahmaputreṣu nārado varuṇāgnyantarā vāruṇādadhamo 'gneruttama ityarthaḥ /

analyzed: prāya grahaṇena īṣat nyūnaḥ

analyzed: suparṇī garuḍa bhāryā

analyzed: viśvāmitraḥ ka sūnu vat brahma putraiḥ macīcya ādyaiḥ samānaḥ
translated: Viśvāmitra is equal to the sons of Brahmā, beginning with Marīci.

analyzed: te śvibhyām paścāt parjanyāt uttamāḥ

analyzed: cyavana ādyāḥ ca tadvat

analyzed: ekādaśa manu samānāḥ

analyzed: atra eteṣu api vipra rājanya tva nimittaḥ kaścana viśeṣaḥ sti

analyzed: muktau api vipra tva ādeḥ bhāvāt

analyzed: atra cyavana ucathyau viprau

analyzed: anye rājanyāḥ priyavrataḥ u pi tat avaram anuvadeva

analyzed: parjanyāt uttamā mitrāt adhamā aśvinoḥ samānāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The highest are from Parjanya, the lowest from Mitra, equal to the Ashvins, is the meaning.

analyzed: tad anye uktebhyaḥ nye tu devāḥ tatas śata antargata devatābhyaḥ varāḥ
translated: The others, different from those mentioned, are the gods inferior to those deities within the hundred.

analyzed: avaram anusamānāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is, they are equal to the inferior ones.

analyzed: nanu mahā lakṣmīḥ prāṇāt api uttamā asti
translated: But there is Mahalakshmi who is higher than even Prana.

analyzed: tat katham prāṇa avasāna tvam adhikāriṇām iti atas āha etebhyaḥ iti
translated: How then is it that the qualified ones end with Prana? To this he says:

analyzed: etebhyaḥ bhyadhikā śrīḥ astu sadā muktā viśeṣataḥ
translated: Let Shri be superior to these, always liberated, especially.

analyzed: tad samaḥ nā asti paramaḥ hariḥ eva na ca aparaḥ
translated: There is none equal to her, the highest is Hari alone, and no other.

analyzed: saṃhitāyām bṛhatyām tu svayam bhagavatā uditam
translated: In the Brihat Sanhita, it is declared by the Lord Himself:

analyzed: tat etat akhilam
translated: All this...

analyzed: yadi api śrīḥ etebhyaḥ viśeṣataḥ bhyadhikā
translated: Even though Shri is especially superior to these,

original: tathāpi sadā muktā bandharahiteti nādhikārivarge gṛhyate /
analyzed: tathā api sadā muktā bandha rahitā iti na adhikāri varge gṛhyate
translated: still, being always liberated, free from bondage, she is not included in the group of qualified ones.

analyzed: tasyāḥ samaḥ na asti iti svarūpa kathanam
translated: The statement that there is none equal to her is a description of her nature.

original: etena kāmāditaratra tatra cāyatanādibhya ityadhikaraṇasya tātparyamuktaṃ bhavati /🔽paramo harireva na cāpara ityanenavyatihāro viśiṃṣanti hītaravat'saiva hi satyādayaḥ' /
analyzed: etena kāmāt itaratra tatra ca āyatana ādibhyaḥ iti adhikaraṇasya tātparyam uktam bhavati  paramaḥ hariḥ eva na ca aparaḥ iti anena vyatihāraḥ viśiṃṣanti hi itara vat sā eva hi satya ādayaḥ
translated: By this it is said that the purport of the section beginning with from desire and elsewhere, and there also from the sense-organs etc. is stated.

analyzed: iti adhikaraṇa dvayasya tātparyam uktam veditavyam
translated: By this the highest is Hari alone, not another it should be understood that the purport of the two sections beginning with they distinguish, like the others and those very are truth etc. is stated.

analyzed: nanu upaniṣadi nāma ādyāḥ prāṇa antāḥ pañcadaśa uktāḥ
translated: Now, in the Upanishad, fifteen are mentioned beginning with name and ending with prana.

original: atra coṣāḥ svāhetyādinā caturdaśaśaiva tatkathaṃ na visaṃvāda ityato bṛhatsaṃhitāvacanenānuktamekaṃ svayamāha prāṇa iti //
analyzed: atra ca uṣāḥ svāhā ityādinā tat katham na visaṃvādaḥ iti atas bṛhatsaṃhitā vacanena anuktam ekam svayam āha prāṇaḥ iti
translated: And here, with Ushah, Svaha etc. only fourteen are mentioned. How then is there no contradiction? Therefore, he himself mentions one not mentioned in the Brihat-samhita by saying prana.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ āhaṅkārikaḥ eva ca
translated: And prana is born of ahamkara alone.

analyzed: indrāt anantaraḥ

analyzed: taijasa ahaṅkārāt utpannaḥ prāṇaḥ ca aparaḥ sti
translated: There is another prana born from taijasa ahamkara.

analyzed: sa ca indrāt anantaram eva aniruddhāt uttamaḥ jñātavyaḥ

analyzed: para prāṇa vyāvṛtti artham āhaṅkārikaḥ eva iti uktam
translated: In order to exclude the highest prana, it is said born of ahamkara alone.

analyzed: ayam atra saṅgrahaḥ
translated: Here is the summary:

analyzed: puṣkaraḥ nāma sarva avaraḥ devaḥ
translated: The god named Pushkara is the lowest of all.

analyzed: kalābhyaḥ ca anyā devebhyaḥ karma pratyavaram yatas
translated: Because karma is lower than other gods due to the kalas.

analyzed: pṛthak uktam tat puṣkaraḥ karma ca ucyate
translated: That is said to be separate from the Kalas, and Pushkara is said to be the action.

analyzed: iti anyatra ukta tvāt
translated: Because it is said elsewhere.

analyzed: tatas śanaiścaraḥ dhikaḥ
translated: Then Saturn is greater.

analyzed: pṛthivī ātmā śaniḥ ca iti vacanāt
translated: Because it is said that Saturn is the soul of the earth.

analyzed: tatas uṣāḥ upā
translated: Then Ushas.

analyzed: tatas budhaḥ
translated: Then Mercury.

analyzed: udaka ātmakaḥ budhaḥ ca iti vacanāt
translated: Because it is said that Mercury is of the nature of water.

analyzed: tatas svāhā
translated: Then Svaha.

original: tataḥ parjanyo vāruṇī saṃjñā rohiṇī dhārmī virāṭ /
analyzed: tatas parjanyaḥ vāruṇī saṃjñā rohiṇī dhārmī virāj
translated: Then Parjanya, Varuni, Samjna, Rohini, Dharmi, and Viraj.

analyzed: tatas ekādaśa manaścyavana ucathya vainya śaśabindu haihaya priyavrata gayāḥ anuktadevāḥ ca
translated: Then the eleven mental ones, Chyavana, Uchchaihshrava, Vainya, Shashabindu, Haihaya, Priyavrata, Gaya, and the unnamed gods.

analyzed: priyavrataḥ gayaḥ ca eva karma deva samau matau
translated: Priyavrata and Gaya are considered equal to Karmadeva.

analyzed: iti anyatra ukta tvāt
translated: Because it is said elsewhere.

analyzed: tatas śvinau vighneśa vittapau viṣvaksenaḥ ca
translated: Then the Ashvins, Vighnesha, Kubera, and Vishvaksena.

original: viṣvakseno vāyujaḥ svena tulya iti vacanāt /
analyzed: viṣvaksenaḥ vāyu jaḥ svena tulyaḥ iti vacanāt
translated: Because it is said that Vishvaksena, born from Vayu, is equal to himself.

analyzed: tatas mitraḥ nirṛtiḥ tārā prāvahi iti ca
translated: Then Mitra, Nirriti, Tara, and Pravaha.

original: tato marīciratryaṅgirāḥ pulastyaḥ pulahaḥ kraturvasiṣṭho viśvāmitro vaivasvatamanuśca /
analyzed: tatas marīciḥ atri aṅgirāḥ pulastyaḥ pulahaḥ kratuḥ vasiṣṭhaḥ viśvāmitraḥ vaivasvata manuḥ ca
translated: Then Marichi, Atri, Angiras, Pulastya, Pulaha, Kratu, Vasishtha, Vishvamitra, and Vaivasvata Manu.

analyzed: tatas gniḥ bhṛguḥ prasūtiḥ ca
translated: Then Agni, Bhrigu, and Prasooti.

analyzed: tatas nāradaḥ
translated: Then Narada.

analyzed: tatas varuṇaḥ
translated: Then Varuna.

analyzed: tatas candra sūrya dharmāḥ śatarūpā ca
translated: Then the laws of the moon and sun, and Śatarūpā.

analyzed: tatas pravahaḥ
translated: Then Pravaha.

analyzed: tatas niruddha svāyambhuva bṛhaspati dakṣāḥ śacī ratiḥ ca
translated: Then Aniruddha, Svāyaṃbhuva, Bṛhaspati, Dakṣa, Śacī, and Rati.

analyzed: tatas āhaṅkārikaḥ prāṇaḥ
translated: Then the vital breath belonging to the ego.

analyzed: tatas indra kāmau
translated: Then Indra and Kāma.

analyzed: tatas umā suparṇī umā ātmaka tvāt śeṣa bhāryā ca
translated: Then Umā and Suparṇī, because of being of the nature of Umā, and also the wife of Śeṣa.

analyzed: tatas jāmbavatī ādyāḥ bhagavat mahiṣī aṣṣaṭ
translated: Then Jāmbavatī and the other six wives of the Lord.

analyzed: anyatra ukta tvāt
translated: Because it is stated elsewhere.

analyzed: anyatra ukta tvāt
translated: Because it is stated elsewhere.

analyzed: tatas rudra ātmaka tvāt śeṣaḥ ca  tatas bhāratī tad ātmaka tvāt sarasvatī ca
translated: Then Śeṣa, because of being of the nature of Rudra.🔽Then Sarasvatī, because of being of the nature of Bhāratī.

analyzed: tatas mukhya vāyuḥ tad ātmaka tvāt brahmā ca
translated: Then Brahmā, because of being of the nature of the principal wind.

analyzed: tatas mahālakṣmīḥ
translated: Then Mahālakṣmī.

analyzed: tatas bhagavān iti
translated: Then the Lord.

analyzed: iti iyadāmana adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the creation of the elements.
VII. The section on the differences in views

analyzed: atha darśana bheda adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, the section on the differences in views

analyzed: om prajñā antara pṛthaktva vat dṛṣṭiḥ ca tat uktam om
translated: Om. The view is stated to be like the difference in knowledge. Om.

analyzed: etat vayākhyātam bhāṣye upāsanā bheda vat darśana bhedaḥ iti
translated: This has been explained in the commentary as the difference in views being like the difference in worship.

analyzed: tat aspaṣṭam
translated: That is not clear.

analyzed: darśana bhede mūla kāraṇasya an ukta tvāt
translated: Because the fundamental cause of the difference in views is not stated.

analyzed: tatas vyākhyāti dṛṣṭiḥ iti
translated: Therefore, he explains it as view in the commentary.

analyzed: prajñā antara pṛthaktva vat dṛṣṭiḥ ca tat uktam
translated: And the view is stated to be like the difference of other cognitions.

analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ api yogya anusārataḥ
translated: And the view is also according to the capacity of the aspirant.

analyzed: nānāvidhā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is of various kinds.

analyzed: iti darśana bheda adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the differences in views.
VIII. The section on the bestowal of grace by the teacher.

analyzed: atha pradāna adhikaraṇa guru prasāda adhikaraṇau
translated: Now, the sections on the bestowal and the grace of the teacher.

analyzed: om pradāna vat eva tat uktam om
translated: Om. It is said to be like the bestowal. Om.

analyzed: atra prakṛṣṭam dānam pradānam
translated: Here, the excellent gift is the bestowal.

analyzed: pra śabdaḥ na sphuṭam vyākhyātaḥ bhāṣye
translated: The word 'pra' is not clearly explained in the commentary.

analyzed: atas sūtra artham āha samyak iti
translated: Therefore, he says the meaning of the sutra is 'perfectly' etc.

analyzed: pradāna vat eva tat uktam  /
translated: It is said to be like the bestowal.

original: liṅgabhūyastvāt tad dhi balīyas tad api / / / /
analyzed: liṅga bhūyaḥ tvāt tat hi balīyaḥ tat api
translated: Because of the abundance of indications, that is stronger, and that also.

analyzed: samyak guru prasādaḥ ca mukhyatas dṛṣṭi kāraṇam
translated: And the perfect grace of the teacher is the primary cause of vision.

analyzed: na kevalam śravaṇa ādi kintu samyak guru prasādaḥ ca
translated: Not only listening etc., but also the perfect grace of the teacher.

original: samyak prasādapūrvakaṃ guroryadvidyādānaṃ tacca bhagavaddṛṣṭeḥ kāraṇamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: samyak prasāda pūrvakam guroḥ yat vidyā dānam tat ca bhagavat dṛṣṭeḥ kāraṇam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the bestowal of knowledge by the teacher preceded by perfect grace is also the cause of seeing the Lord.

original: nanuprajñāntarapṛthaktvavat' /🔽iti sūtraṃ pradānavadevetyataḥ paścāttanaṃ tatkuto vyutkramaḥ /
analyzed: nanu prajñā antara pṛthaktva vat 🔽iti sūtram pradānavat eva iti atas paścāttanam tat kutas vyutkramaḥ
translated: But the sutra is like the difference of other cognitions.🔽How is it out of order when it comes after like the bestowal?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: yogyatācintāsaṅgataṃ taditi prakaraṇaśuddhaye pūrvameva vyākhyātamiti na doṣaḥ /
analyzed: tat iti prakaraṇa śuddhaye pūrvam eva vyākhyātam iti na doṣaḥ
translated: Since it has been explained earlier for the sake of clarifying the context, there is no fault.

analyzed: om liṅga bhūyaḥ tvāt tat hi balīyaḥ tat api om  atra guru prasāda
translated: Om. Because of the abundance of indications, that is stronger. That also is so.🔽Here, the strength of the grace

analyzed: dānasya balavat tvam uktam
translated: of the guru and giving is stated.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: śravaṇa āditaḥ hi balavat tvam
translated: For, strength comes from listening and so on.

analyzed: tat ca pradāna śabda artha antargatam eva
translated: And that is included in the meaning of the word giving itself.

original: nahi svasmādeva svaya balīya iti sambhavatītyato vyācaṣṭe samyagiti //
analyzed: nahi svasmāt eva svayam balīyaḥ iti sambhavati iti atas vyācaṣṭe samyak iti
translated: It is not possible that something is stronger than itself. Therefore, he explains it as correct and so on.

analyzed: mukhyatas śravaṇa ādi apekṣayā atiśayena
translated: Mainly, in relation to listening and so on, it is extremely strong.

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intention:

analyzed: pradāna śabdena hi samyak guru prasāda pūrvakam dānam prakṛtam
translated: For, by the word giving, giving preceded by the correct grace of the guru is the subject.

original: tatra samyagguruprasādamātraṃ taditi atra parāmṛśyata iti /
analyzed: tatra samyak guru prasāda mātram tat iti atra parāmṛśyate iti
translated: There, the correct grace of the guru alone is referred to here as that.

analyzed: liṅga bhūyaḥ tvāt iti uktam
translated: It is said because of the abundance of indications.

original: yāsvākhyāyikāsu liṅgāni dṛśyante tatra guruprasādenaiva jñānaprāptiśravaṇāt śravaṇādikaṃ na karaṇīyamiti śaṅkā syāttāṃ nivārayituṃ tadapītyuktam
analyzed: yāsu ākhyāyikāsu liṅgāni dṛśyante tatra guru prasādena eva jñāna prāpti śravaṇāt śravaṇa ādikam na karaṇīyam iti śaṅkā syāt tām nivārayitum tat api iti uktam
translated: In those stories where indications are seen, there is the doubt that knowledge is obtained only through the grace of the guru, so listening and so on need not be done. To remove that doubt, that also is stated.

analyzed: tat vayākhyāti śravaṇa ādi ca iti
translated: He explains it as listening and so on.

original: śravaṇādi ca kartavyaṃ nānyathā darśanaṃ kvacit // / / //
analyzed: śravaṇa ādi ca kartavyam na anyathā darśanam kvacid
translated: And listening etc. should be done, not otherwise, anywhere.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha na anyathā iti
translated: Why? Therefore it is said: not otherwise.
