original: anvayavyatirekābhyāṃ śrutyā ca pramāṇānāmeva prameyādhigatisādhanatvaniścayāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: anvaya vyatirekābhyām śrutyā ca pramāṇānām eva prameya adhigati sādhanatva niścayāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the means of valid knowledge are ascertained to be the means of attaining the object of knowledge only through positive and negative concomitance and verbal testimony.

analyzed: ākhyāyikāsu api śravaṇa ādīnām anukti mātram
translated: Even in the stories, there is mere non-mention of listening etc.

analyzed: na punar abhāva uktiḥ asti
translated: But there is no statement of non-existence.

analyzed: iti pradāna adhikaraṇa guru prasāda adhikaraṇau
translated: Thus end the sections on the gift and on the grace of the teacher.
IX. The section on the prior option.

analyzed: atha pūrva vikalpa adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, the section on the prior option.

original: oṃ pūrvavikalpaḥ prakaraṇātsyātkriyāmānasavat oṃ //🔽kiṃ prathamaprāpta eva gururuta taṃ parityajyānyo 'pi svīkartuṃ śakyata iti saṃśayegurumantraparityāgī rauravaṃ narakaṃ vrajet' /
analyzed: om pūrva vikalpaḥ prakaraṇāt syāt kriyā mānasa vat om  kim prathama prāptaḥ eva guruḥ uta tam parityajya anyaḥ svīkartum śakyate iti saṃśaye guru mantra parityāgī rauravam narakam vrajet
translated: Om. The prior option would be due to the context, like the mental act. Om.🔽Whether the first-obtained teacher alone is to be accepted or another can be accepted after abandoning him, this being a doubt,🔽since the fault of abandoning the teacher is remembered as one who abandons the teacher and the mantra goes to the Raurava hell,

original: iti guruparityāge doṣasmaraṇātprathamaprāpta eveti prāpte vikalpa ucyate /
analyzed: iti guru parityāge doṣa smaraṇāt prathama prāptaḥ eva iti prāpte vikalpaḥ ucyate
translated: it is obtained that the first-obtained alone is to be accepted. The option is stated.

original: sa hīnasamottameṣu kiṃviṣaya iti na jñāyate /
analyzed: sa hīna sama uttameṣu kiṃviṣayaḥ iti na jñāyate
translated: It is not known what the scope of that is in the inferior, equal, and superior [teachers].

original: doṣasmaraṇasya kā gatirityato vyaktaṃ vyākhyāti guṇādhikamiti //
analyzed: doṣa smaraṇasya kā gatiḥ iti atas vyaktam vyākhyāti guṇa adhikam iti
translated: What is the course of remembering faults? Therefore, he clearly explains with superior in qualities.

analyzed: pūrva vikalpaḥ prakaraṇāt syāt kriyā mānasa vat
translated: The former option would be due to the context, like in the case of mental action.

original: guṇādhikaṃ guruṃ prāpya taddhīnaṃ nāpnuyāt kvacit // / / //
analyzed: guṇa adhikam gurum prāpya tad hīnam na āpnuyāt kvacid
translated: Having obtained a guru superior in qualities, one should not at any time obtain one inferior in qualities.

analyzed: kvacid prayojana viśeṣe pi
translated: Even in the case of a specific purpose.

analyzed: doṣa smaraṇam tad viṣayam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that remembering faults is with regard to that.

original: evaṃ tarhi sautro vikalpo 'dhikaguruprāptiviṣayaḥ kimiti netyāha viparyayastviti //
analyzed: evam tarhi sautraḥ vikalpaḥ dhika guru prāpti viṣayaḥ kim iti na iti āha viparyayaḥ tu iti
translated: If so, why not take the option in the sutra as referring to obtaining a superior guru? He says but the opposite.

analyzed: viparyayaḥ tu kartavyaḥ sarvathā muktim icchatā
translated: But the opposite should be done in every way by one desiring liberation.

analyzed: adhama guru parityāgena uttama guru svīkāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that by abandoning a guru of lower status, one should accept a guru of higher status.

original: anyathā daivādādāvalpaṃ guruṃ prāptasya śiṣyasya prajñotkarṣavato jātayoḥ saṃśayaviparyāsayorajñānasya ca nivṛttirna syāt /
analyzed: anyathā daivāt ādau alpam gurum prāptasya śiṣyasya prajñā utkarṣavataḥ jātayoḥ saṃśaya viparyāsayoḥ ajñānasya ca nivṛttiḥ na syāt
translated: Otherwise, for a disciple who has by chance obtained a lesser guru at the beginning, and who has superior wisdom, there would be no cessation of doubt, error, and ignorance that have arisen.

analyzed: tat idam uktam śubham icchatā iti
translated: This is what is said with desiring the auspicious.

original: evaṃ tarhyanupadiśata uttamasya tyāgenopadiśato 'dhamasya svīkāro 'pi kartavyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: evam tarhi anupadiśataḥ uttamasya tyāgena upadiśataḥ dhamasya svīkāraḥ api kartavyaḥ syāt
translated: If so, then the abandonment of a superior one who does not teach, and the acceptance of an inferior one who does teach, should also be done.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: pratiṣedha vacanena tatra apoditaḥ yam nyāyaḥ
translated: This rule is rejected there by the word of prohibition.

original: tarhi sautrasya vikalpasya ko viṣaya ityata āha sama iti // /
analyzed: tarhi sautrasya vikalpasya kaḥ viṣayaḥ iti atas āha samaḥ iti
translated: Then what is the object of the option mentioned in the sutra? To this he says 'sama' (equal).

analyzed: same vikalpaḥ eva syāt
translated: There would be an option only in the case of an equal (guru).

original: pūrvasvīkṛtena guruṇā same gurau svayameva prāpte sati svīkārasya vikalpa eva syāt /
analyzed: pūrva svīkṛtena guruṇā same gurau svayam eva prāpte sati svīkārasya vikalpaḥ eva syāt
translated: When a guru who has been previously accepted is equal to another guru who has come by himself, then the acceptance would be an option only.

analyzed: na tu niyamaḥ
translated: But there is no rule.

analyzed: samaḥ eva iti vā sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is 'sama eva' (only in the case of an equal).

analyzed: doṣa smṛteḥ viṣaya antaram ca darśayitum āha pūrva iti
translated: To show another object of the remembrance of faults, he says 'pūrva' (previous).

analyzed: pūrva anujñā ca sarvathā
translated: And the permission of the previous (guru) is always necessary.

original: samagurvantarasvīkāre pūrvasyānujñā ca sarvathā bhāvyā /🔽vinānujñayā samānapūrvaparityāgaviṣayaṃ doṣasmaraṇamiti bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: sama guru antara svīkāre pūrvasya anujñā ca sarvathā bhāvyā  vinā anujñayā samāna pūrva parityāga viṣayam doṣa smaraṇam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: When accepting an equal or superior guru, the permission of the previous one is always to be sought.🔽The meaning is that without permission, the remembrance of faults has an object of abandoning the previous equal (guru).

analyzed: pūrvā anujñā ca iti etat guru antara prāpti mātra viṣayam iti manda pratīti nirāsāya āha tad uttamā iti
translated: To remove the slow understanding that this (verse) refers only to the attainment of another guru, he says 'taduttama' (superior).

analyzed: tad uttama guru prāptyai pūrvā anujñā na mṛgyate
translated: For the attainment of a superior guru, the permission of the previous one is not sought.

analyzed: tat iti pūrva prāptasya parāmarśaḥ
translated: 'Tada' refers to the previously attained (guru).

original: tasmāduttamasya guroḥ prāptyai pūrvasyānujñā na mārgaṇīyā /
analyzed: tasmāt uttamasya guroḥ prāptyai pūrvasya anujñā na mārgaṇīyā
translated: For the attainment of a superior guru, the permission of the previous one is not to be sought.

analyzed: guru prasādaḥ sarvathā bhāvyaḥ iti sūtrakṛtā uktam
translated: The author of the Sutra has said that the grace of the Guru should be obtained in every way.

analyzed: tad vidyā devatayoḥ api prasādasya upalakṣaṇam iti vivakṣuḥ guru vidyā devatā svarūpam tāvat āha guruḥ iti
translated: Desiring to illustrate the grace of the Vidya and the Deity also, he first describes the nature of the Guru, the Vidya and the Deity, saying The Guru etc.

analyzed: ca vidyā ca eva sarasvatī
translated: The Guru is the Brahman of all, and the Vidya is Sarasvati,

analyzed: devatāḥ bhagavān viṣṇuḥ sarveṣām aviśeṣatas
translated: and the Deity is Lord Vishnu, of all without distinction.

analyzed: yeṣām teṣām iti viśeṣam vihāya sarveṣām eva
translated: Of those who have these, it is a special (rule), but of all without distinction.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha tat iti
translated: Then what follows from that? Therefore he says That etc.

analyzed: tad prasādena muktiḥ syāt na anyathā tu kathañcana
translated: Liberation would be by His grace, not otherwise in any way.

analyzed: na kevalam guru prasādena kintu vidyā devatayoḥ api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is not only by the grace of the Guru, but also by the Vidya and the Deity.

analyzed: muktiḥ iti jñāna ādeḥ upalakṣaṇam
translated: Liberation illustrates knowledge and other (means).

analyzed: sādhāraṇa gurum uktvā asādhāraṇān āha
translated: Having described the common Guru, he describes the uncommon ones, saying The best etc.

analyzed: sva uttamāḥ tu krameṇa eva sarveṣām guravaḥ śrutāḥ
translated: The best ones are indeed the Gurus of all in due order.

analyzed: krameṇa eva iti sākṣāt uttamaḥ garuḥ tatas pi uttamaḥ gurutaraḥ ityādi
translated: In due order means the best Guru directly, then the even better Guru, and so on.

analyzed: evam vidyā viśeṣe tad devatā viśeṣaḥ jñātavyaḥ
translated: Thus, in the case of the particular Vidya, the particular Deity should also be known.

analyzed: nanu astu vidyā tvam vidyā abhimāni tvāt sarasvatī ādīnām
translated: But let there be the nature of knowledge for Sarasvatī and others, because of their being identified with knowledge.

analyzed: devatā tvam ca vidyā pratipādya tvāt viṣṇoḥ
translated: And let there be the nature of deity for Viṣṇu, because of being the subject matter of knowledge.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ guru tvam tu kutas
translated: But how can Brahmā be the teacher?

analyzed: vidyā upadeṣyṛ tvam hi guru tvam
translated: For being a teacher consists in being the instructor in knowledge.

original: naca sarvānprati brahmaṇastadastītyata āha upadeśa iti //
analyzed: na ca sarvān prati brahmaṇaḥ tat asti iti atas āha upadeśaḥ iti
translated: And that does not exist for Brahmā with regard to all. Hence he says: The instruction...

analyzed: upadeśaḥ brahmaṇaḥ tu sarveṣām eva muktaye
translated: The instruction of Brahmā is for the liberation of all.

original: iha janmāntare vā hiraṇyagarbhopadeśena vinā na kasyāpi muktirityatastasya gurutvamupapannam /
analyzed: iha janmāntare vā hiraṇyagarbha upadeśena vinā na kasya api muktiḥ iti atas tasya guru tvam upapannam
translated: For no one is liberated without the instruction of Hiraṇyagarbha, either in this life or in another. Therefore his being the teacher is proper.

analyzed: tad itareṣām api uttamānām vidyā sampradāya pravartaka tvāt guru tvam apravartakānām tu anugrāhaka tva ādinā iti
translated: And for others also, the best ones, there is the nature of being the teacher because of being the propagators of the tradition of knowledge. But for those who are not propagators, it is because of being the benefactor, etc.

analyzed: iti pūrva vikalpa adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the previous alternatives.

analyzed: tādvidya adhikaraṇa
translated: X. The section on the knowledge of that.

analyzed: atha tādvidya adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, the section on the knowledge of that.

original: oṃ pareṇa ca śabdasya tādvidhvaṃ bhūyastvāttvanubandhaḥ oṃ //
analyzed: om pareṇa ca śabdasya bhūyas tvāt tu anubandhaḥ
translated: Om. And because of the abundance of that kind of word by the supreme one, the connection is with that. Om.

analyzed: bhaktiḥ eva enam nayati ityādi śruteḥ bhaktiḥ eva mokṣa ādi sādhanam na paramātmā
translated: Because of scriptural statements like Devotion alone leads him, devotion alone is the means of attaining liberation, not the supreme self.

original: yathaikalavyasya gurubhaktireva vidyāprāptisādhanaṃ na gururityevaṃ prāpte idamuktam /
analyzed: yathā aikalavyasya guru bhaktiḥ eva vidyā prāpti sādhanam na guruḥ iti evam prāpte idam uktam
translated: When it is thus concluded that just as Eklavya's devotion to the teacher was the means of attaining knowledge, not the teacher, this is said.

analyzed: tatra bhāṣyam
translated: There the commentary says:

analyzed: pradhāna sādhana tvāt bhaktiḥ karaṇa tvena ucyate iti
translated: Devotion is mentioned as the instrument because it is the primary means.

original: tatraprakṛtatvādbhagavadapekṣayaiva bhakteḥ prādhānyamiti pratītiḥ sayāttāṃ nivārayitumāha sādhanebhya iti //
analyzed: tatra prakṛta tvāt bhagavat apekṣayā eva bhakteḥ prādhānyam iti pratītiḥ sayāt tām nivārayitum āha sādhanebhyaḥ iti
translated: There, because it is the subject, the idea may arise that devotion is primary only in relation to the Lord. To prevent that, he says from the means.

original: pareṇa ca śabdasya tādvidhyaṃ bhūyastvāt tv anubandhaḥ / / / /
analyzed: pareṇa ca śabdasya tādvidhyam bhūyaḥ tvāt tu anubandhaḥ  /
translated: And by the next [verse], the word is shown to have that nature, because of abundance, the connection is...

analyzed: sādhanebhyaḥ dhikā bhaktiḥ
translated: Devotion is superior to the means...

analyzed: mokṣa sādhanebhyaḥ jñāna ādibhyaḥ
translated: To the means of liberation, such as knowledge and so on.

original: etadapi tādṛgeva bhagavato 'pi mokṣasādhanatvādityata āha naiveti //
analyzed: etat api tādṛś eva mokṣa sādhanatvāt iti atas āha nā eva iti
translated: This too is similar, because even the Lord is a means of liberation. Therefore he says not at all.

analyzed: na eva anyat tādṛśam kvacid
translated: Nothing else is like it anywhere...

original: kvacinmuktau jñānādau vā bhagavatonyatsādhanaṃ bhaktisadṛśaṃ naivāstītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: kvacid muktau jñāna ādau vā bhagavataḥ nyat sādhanam bhakti sadṛśam na eva asti iti arthaḥ
translated: Nowhere else in liberation or knowledge is there any means equal to devotion to the Lord. This is the meaning.

original: bhaktiriti sāmānyenoktaṃ na jñāyate kiṃviṣayā kathaṃ ceti /
analyzed: bhaktiḥ iti sāmānyena uktam na jñāyate kiṃviṣayā katham ca iti
translated: Devotion is said in general, but it is not known to what it refers or how.

analyzed: atas āha bhaktiḥ ca iti
translated: Therefore he says devotion and so on.

analyzed: bhaktiḥ ca eva harau eva mukhyāni atra yathākramam
translated: And devotion is indeed foremost towards Hara alone, in this context, in due order.

analyzed: harau eva mukhyā sarva adhikā na tathā anyatra
translated: Towards Hara alone it is foremost, most excellent, not so towards others.

original: anyatrāpi yathākramameva na tu sāmyenākrameṇa vetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: anyatra api yathākramam eva na tu sāmyena ākrameṇa vā iti arthaḥ
translated: Towards others also, it is indeed in due order, not in equality or disorder, is the meaning.

analyzed: tad iyat tām āha svādhika iti
translated: He states its extent as follows:

original: svādhikā tveva sarvatra svottameṣu krameṇa ca // / / //
analyzed: sva adhikā tu eva sarvatra sva uttameṣu krameṇa ca
translated: But it is indeed superior everywhere, and in due order towards one's superiors.

analyzed: sākṣāt sva uttame sva adhikā eva kartavyā
translated: Towards one's direct superior, it should be only superior.

analyzed: anyatra sva uttameṣu tad uttama tva krameṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: In other cases, towards one's superiors, in the order of their superiority, is the meaning.

analyzed: yadi api eṣaḥ tharḥ prāk uktaḥ tathā api tātparya atiśaya dyotanāya punar uktaḥ
translated: Although this meaning has been stated earlier, it is repeated again to highlight the excess of purpose.

original: bhaktiḥ sādhanaṃ cenmuktiprāptyanantaraṃ nāstīti pratītiḥ syāt /
analyzed: bhaktiḥ sādhanam ced mukti prāpti anantaram na asti iti pratītiḥ syāt
translated: If devotion and means were to cease after attaining liberation, that would be the understanding.

analyzed: phala prāptau sādhana nivṛtti darśanāt  tad nivṛtti artham āha anuvartate ca iti
translated: Because the cessation of the means is seen upon attaining the fruit.

analyzed: anuvartate ca sā bhaktiḥ muktau ānanda rūpiṇī
translated: To counter that cessation, he says: And that devotion continues, in the form of bliss, for the liberated one.

analyzed: prema viśeṣaḥ hi bhaktiḥ nāma
translated: For devotion is named a special kind of love.

original: upakārakatvajñānājjātā hi premā kṛtamahopakāre nitarāṃ vardhata ityeva khalu yuktaṃ na tu hīyata iti /
analyzed: upakāraka tva jñānāt jātā hi premā kṛta mahā upakāre nitarām vardhate iti eva khalu yuktam na tu hīyate iti
translated: For love, born from the knowledge of being helpful, indeed increases greatly towards one who has done great help, and it is indeed proper to say so, but not that it diminishes.

analyzed: tat etat asti iti an uktvā anuvartate iti vadatā sūcitam
translated: This is indicated by the author, without saying it exists, by saying it continues.

original: tarhi tasyāḥ phalamapi kiñcitsyādityata āha ānandarūpiṇīti //
analyzed: tarhi tasyāḥ phalam api kiñcid syāt iti atas āha ānanda rūpiṇī iti
translated: Then, it should have some result also. To this he says in the form of bliss.

analyzed: prāc kartavya tayā prakṛtā
translated: It is presented as what should be done first.

analyzed: atas sādhana rūpā
translated: Therefore, it is in the form of a means.

analyzed: muktau tu svabhāva bhūta āvirbhūta a phala rūpā eva
translated: But in liberation, it is only the result in the form of manifestation that becomes its nature.

analyzed: pāda artham upasaṃharati tat iti
translated: He concludes the meaning of the chapter with that.

analyzed: tad pūrvakā upāsanā evam kartavyā muktaye guṇaiḥ
translated: Thus, worship preceded by that should be performed for liberation with qualities.

analyzed: bhakti pūrvā
translated: Preceded by devotion.

analyzed: evam iti yogyatā ādeḥ
translated: Thus, with regard to eligibility and so on.

original: guṇairupetasya hareḥ /🔽iti śrīmatpūrṇapramatibhagavatpādasukṛteranuvyākhyānasya praguṇajayatīrthākhyayatinā kṛtāyāṃ ṭīkāyāṃ viṣamapadavākyārthavivṛtau
analyzed: guṇaiḥ upetasya hareḥ  iti śrīmat pūrṇapramati bhagavat pāda sukṛteḥ anuvyākhyānasya praguṇa jayatīrtha ākhya yatinā kṛtāyām ṭīkāyām viṣama pada vākya artha vivṛtau
translated: Of Hari endowed with qualities.

analyzed: tṛtīye tra upāsā viṣaya caraṇaḥ paryavasitaḥ
translated: Thus ends the third chapter on the feet that are the subject of meditation in this commentary called Vivrti on the difficult words and meanings written by the ascetic named Praguṇajayantīrtha, the disciple of the illustrious and fully wise Lord Pūrṇapramati.🔽I. The section on human goals

analyzed: atha puruṣa artha adhikaraṇam
translated: Now begins the section on human goals.

analyzed: jñāna sāmarthyam asmin pāde ucyate iti pāda pratipādyam bhāṣye bhihitam
translated: The subject-matter of this section is stated in the commentary to be the capability of knowledge.

analyzed: saṅgatiḥ tu prāk uktā eva  nanu ca jñānasya svātantryeṇa
translated: The connection is the same as stated before.

analyzed: mokṣa sādhana tvam sāmarthyam
translated: But is not the capability of knowledge the means of attaining liberation by itself?

analyzed: tat ca vidyā eva iti uktam  kim aparam avaśiṣyate
translated: And that is stated to be knowledge itself.🔽What else remains

analyzed: yad artham pāda ārambhaḥ
translated: for the sake of which the section is begun?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: siddha iddham
translated: When it is established that

analyzed: svatantrasya eva jñānasya mokṣa sādhana tva itvam
translated: knowledge alone, independently, is the means of attaining liberation,

analyzed: viṣaya antare tu samarthyate
translated: its capability in other matters is proved.

original: yadyapi sādhakena mokṣārthamevedaṃ sādhitaṃ tathāpi svabhāvabalāyataṃ tatsāmarthyamupapadyate /
analyzed: yadi api sādhakena mokṣa artham evā idam sādhitam tathā api svabhāva balāyatam tad sāmarthyam upapadyate
translated: Even though this is accomplished by the aspirant only for the sake of liberation, that capability arises naturally by the power of its own nature.

analyzed: yathā dahana artham utpāditaḥ u pi dahanaḥ svabhāva vaśāt prakāśayati api iti
translated: Just as fire, even though produced for the sake of burning, illuminates by the power of its own nature.

analyzed: om śabdāt iti bādarāyaṇaḥ om
translated: Om. Badarayana says that liberation is from the word denoting human goal. Om.

original: kiṃ karmānupraveśena jñānaṃ mokṣasādhanaṃ kiṃ vā svatantrameveti saṃśaye svatantrasyaiva jñānasya mokṣasādhanatvamanena samarthyata iti kecidvayācakṣate
analyzed: kim karma anupraveśena jñānam mokṣa sādhanam kim vā svatantram eva iti saṃśaye svatantrasya eva jñānasya mokṣa sādhana tvam anena samarthyate iti kecid vayācakṣate
translated: Some explain that when there is doubt whether knowledge is the means of attaining liberation by entering into action or independently, this proves that knowledge alone, independently, is the means of attaining liberation.

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is wrong.

analyzed: vidyā eva iti atra eva asya arthasya samarthita tvāt
translated: Because the meaning of this [verse] has already been established by the very statement knowledge alone.

original: kintu jñānaṃ kiṃ mokṣameva sādhayatyutānyamapi puruṣārthamiti saṃśaye jñānināṃ puruṣāntare
analyzed: kintu jñānam kim mokṣam eva sādhayati uta anyam api puruṣa artham iti saṃśaye jñāninām puruṣa antare
translated: But when there is doubt as to whether knowledge accomplishes only liberation or also another human goal,🔽when it is concluded that knowledge is the means of attaining liberation only because of the absence of passion in the wise, this [verse] is stated with the intention that

original: rāgābhāvānmokṣasyaiva sādhakaṃ jñānamiti prāpte satīdamucyata ityāśayavānpuruṣārtho
analyzed: rāga abhāvāt mokṣasya eva sādhakam jñānam iti prāpte sati idam ucyate iti āśayavān
translated: the human goal is

analyzed: te iti etāvat vayācaṣṭe evam iti
translated: thus, he explains only this much as thus.

analyzed: puruṣa arthaḥ taḥ śabdāt iti bādarāyaṇaḥ
translated: Bādarāyaṇa [says] that the human goal is from the word ataḥ (therefore).

analyzed: evam utpanna nirdoṣa bhagavat darśanāt sadā
translated: Thus, from the arising of the faultless vision of the Lord,

analyzed: apekṣita phala prāptiḥ
translated: the attainment of the desired fruit is...

analyzed: atas iti jñāna parāmarśaḥ na upapadyate
translated: Atha (therefore) does not fit as a reference to knowledge.

analyzed: pūrvatra prādhānyena upāsanasya eva prakṛta tvāt iti atas uktam evam utpannā iti
translated: Because in the previous [verse], meditation alone is the main topic. Therefore, it is said thus, from the arising [of meditation].

original: na khalūpāsanaṃ svātantryeṇa prakṛtaṃ kinnāma bhagavaddaśarnārthatvena /
analyzed: na khalu upāsanam svātantryeṇa prakṛtam kinnāma
translated: For meditation is not taken up independently, but rather for the purpose of seeing the Lord.

analyzed: atas sādhya tayā tat api prakṛtam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, it too is the main topic as something to be accomplished. This is the idea.

analyzed: evam ukta rūpa upāsana utpannāt
translated: From the arising of the meditation of the form described thus,

analyzed: tad upapādanāya pātanika artham jñātavyam
translated: the knowledge of the faultlessness of the Lord should be known for the purpose of establishing that.

original: yadvā bhagavaddarśanādityevokte daityādīnāṃ yadavatāradarśanaṃ tasyāpi puruṣātharhetutvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yat vā bhagavat darśanāt iti eva ukte daitya ādīnām yat avatāra darśanam tasya api puruṣāthar hetu tvam syāt
translated: If it is said that if it is said that by seeing the Lord etc., then the seeing of the Lord's incarnation by the demons etc. would also be the cause of human goal.

analyzed: evam utpannā iti anena eva tat parihṛtam iti ced na
translated: If it is said that this is refuted by the phrase when arisen itself, it is not so.

analyzed: tasya prakṛta tā pradarśane eva caritārtha tvāt
translated: Because that has served its purpose only in showing that it is the subject matter.

analyzed: tat na teṣām bimba darśanam iti ced
translated: If it is said that that is not the seeing of the image of those (demons etc.),

analyzed: mā bhūt
translated: let it be so.

analyzed: tasya mokṣa artha tvāt
translated: Because that (seeing of the Lord's incarnation) is for the sake of liberation.

analyzed: atra tu puruṣa artha antarasya prastuta tvāt
translated: But here, another human goal is being discussed.

analyzed: atas nirdeṣāt bhagavat darśanāt iti uktam
translated: Therefore, it is said that from the faultless seeing of the Lord.

analyzed: bhagavat grahaṇena advaita jñānam atra gṛhyate iti nirācaṣṭe
translated: By the word Lord, the knowledge of non-duality is included here, this is denied.

analyzed: sāda jñāna udaya kṣaṇāt ārabhya sva udayāt phala dam jñānam iti vacanāt
translated: Because it is said that knowledge gives its fruit from the moment of the arising of the knowledge of non-duality until its own arising.

analyzed: apekṣita phala prāptiḥ bhavati iti mokṣa mātram
translated: The attainment of the desired fruit takes place, thus it excludes mere liberation.

analyzed: nanu etat asat
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: jñāninām api abhiprāyasya kadācid mogha tva darśanāt iti atas āha ārabdhasya iti
translated: Because the intention of even the wise is sometimes seen to be futile, therefore it is said of what has begun etc.

analyzed: ārabdhasya an atikramāt
translated: Of what has begun, because it cannot be transgressed.

analyzed: prārabdha karmaṇaḥ atikramam a vidhāya iti pūrveṇa eva sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with the previous phrase without transgressing the prārabdha karma.

original: prārabdhapratibaddhaṃ hi jñānaṃ mokṣamapi na karoti /
analyzed: prārabdha pratibaddham hi jñānam mokṣam api na karoti
translated: For knowledge, being obstructed by the results of past actions, does not even bring about liberation.

analyzed: atas tad pratibandhaka  vaśāt jñāninām āpi abhiprāyāḥ moghāḥ syuḥ
translated: Therefore, due to the obstruction of that [karma],🔽the intentions of even the wise would be futile.

analyzed: jñānasya puruṣa artha hetu tve pi viśeṣaḥ sti iti āha deva iti
translated: Even though knowledge is the means to human goals, there is a distinction, he says with divine etc.

analyzed: deva ṛṣi mānuṣa ādīnām tad tad jāti anusārataḥ
translated: According to the respective species of gods, sages, humans, and so on,

analyzed: jāti śabdena atra yogyā ucyate
translated: the word species here refers to the qualified.

analyzed: apekṣita phala prāptiḥ bhavati iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is that the desired result is obtained.

analyzed: etena na aviśeṣāt ityasya api tātparyam ukatam bhavati
translated: By this, the purport of not due to non-distinction is also stated.

original: atra na jñānaṃ svatantrameva svargādisādhanaṃ kintu karmaiva /
analyzed: atra na jñānam svatantram eva svarga ādi sādhanam kintu karma eva
translated: Here, knowledge is not the means to heaven etc. independently, but rather action.

analyzed: jñānam tu karma śeṣa tvāt tat sādhana tvena ucyate
translated: However, knowledge is said to be the means to that [heaven etc.] because it is a remainder of action.

original: śeṣatvaṃ ca karmaṇaiva siddhayati puruṣārthe 'tiśayādhāyakatvamiti śeṣatvātpuruṣārthavādo
analyzed: śeṣa tvam ca karmaṇā eva siddhayati puruṣa arthe tiśaya ādhāyaka tvam iti śeṣa tvāt puruṣa artha vādaḥ
translated: And the remainder is established only by action, as it causes the excess in the human goal. Therefore, the statement about the human goal is

analyzed: yathā anyeṣu iti jaiminiḥ ityādi sūtraiḥ pūrvapakṣayitvā adhika upadeśāt tu bādarāyaṇasya evam
translated: Having presented the prima facie view with the sutras beginning with just as in the others, [Badarayana] says: But because of the teaching of something more, Badarayana's view is

original: taddarśanādityādinā svatantrasyaiva jñānasya svargādisādhanatvaṃ punaḥ siddhāntitam /
analyzed: tad darśanāt ityādinā svatantrasya eva jñānasya svarga ādi sādhanatvam punar siddhāntitam
translated: The author of the Nyāyasudhā has again established the fact that the knowledge of the self alone is the means of attaining heaven, etc., by the statement beginning with because it is seen there.

analyzed: tatra pūrvapakṣi upanyasta pramāṇa nirāsaḥ sphuṭaḥ bhāṣye
translated: The author of the Bhāṣya has clearly refuted the proofs adduced by the Pūrvapakṣa.

analyzed: jaimini mata virodha parihāraḥ tu katham iti atas āha jaiminī uktam iti
translated: But how is the contradiction with the opinion of Jaimini to be avoided? To this he says:

analyzed: jaiminī uktam mānuṣāṇām tad viśeṣāḥ ca kecana
translated: What is stated by Jaimini, and some of its special features, are for human beings.

analyzed: jñāna śeṣasya karmaṇaḥ eva svarga ādi sādhana tvam mānuṣa jñāni viṣayam
translated: The fact that the rite, which is a subsidiary of knowledge, is the means of attaining heaven, etc., is the subject-matter of human knowledge.

original: na kevalaṃ jaiminyuktaṃ kintu svargādayaḥ karmaṇaiva nānyenetyapare viduḥ /
analyzed: na kevalam jaiminī uktam kintu svarga ādayaḥ karmaṇā eva na anyena iti apare viduḥ
translated: Not only what is stated by Jaimini, but others know that heaven, etc., are only by action, not by anything else.

analyzed: adṛṣṭam eva jñānena dṛṣṭam na eva upalabhyate
translated: The unseen itself is seen by knowledge, it is never perceived.

analyzed: iti kecid vidaḥ prāhuḥ
translated: Thus some scholars say.

original: ityādinoktāstadviśeṣā jaiminimataikadeśā ye kecana te 'pi mānuṣāṇām /
analyzed: ityādinā uktāḥ tad viśeṣāḥ jaimini mata ekadeśāḥ ye kecana te mānuṣāṇām
translated: Those special features mentioned beginning with this, which are some of the parts of Jaimini's opinion, they are also for human beings.

analyzed: katham eteṣām jaimini mata eka deśa tvam iti ced
translated: If it is asked how these are parts of Jaimini's opinion,

original: svatantrasya jñānasya ca svargādisādhanatvamityetāvatyaṃśe sāmyāditi brūmaḥ /
analyzed: svatantrasya jñānasya ca svarga ādi sādhanatvam iti etāvati aṃśe sāmyāt iti brūmaḥ
translated: we say it is because of similarity in the part that independent knowledge is the means of attaining heaven, etc.

original: mānuṣā apyuttamamadhyamādhamabhedabhinnā iti yathāyogyaṃ vicitramataviṣayā bhavanyeva / /
analyzed: mānuṣāḥ api uttama madhyama adhama bheda bhinnāḥ iti yathāyogyam vicitra mata viṣayāḥ bhavani eva
translated: Even human beings are divided into superior, middling, and inferior classes, so they are bound to have various kinds of opinions according to their suitability.

analyzed: evam jaimini mata viṣayam uktvā sūtrakāra mata viṣayam darśayati sāmānyam iti
translated: Having thus stated the topic of Jaimini's view, he shows the topic of the author of the aphorisms with the word general.
The general is stated by the Lord...

original: jñānaṃ sakalapuruṣārthasādhanaṃ bhavatīti sāmānyameva bhagavatā proktam /
analyzed: jñānam sakala puruṣa artha sādhanam bhavati iti sāmānyam eva bhagavatā proktam
translated: Knowledge is stated by the Lord as the general means of attaining all human goals.

analyzed: na tu puruṣa viśeṣa niṣṭham jñānam iti
translated: But not that knowledge is restricted to a particular person.

analyzed: atas sāmānya viśeṣa niyata tvāt na etayoḥ matayoḥ virodhaḥ
translated: Therefore, due to being restricted to general and specific [persons], there is no contradiction between these two views.

analyzed: nanu sāmānyena api kvacid viśeṣe vasthātavyam
translated: But even a general [statement] must rest somewhere in a specific [case].

analyzed: tat idam api kva avatiṣṭhate iti atas āha deva ādīnām iti
translated: And where does this also rest? To this he says of the gods, etc.

analyzed: deva ādīnām viśeṣataḥ
translated: Of the gods, etc., specifically...

analyzed: bhagavat matam viśeṣataḥ upavādaiḥ apoditam deva ādi viṣayam vyavatiṣṭhate
translated: The Lord's view, which is restricted to the gods, etc., rests, being excepted by exceptions.

analyzed: yadi api ayam arthaḥ lokataḥ eva siddhaḥ
translated: Although this meaning is established by common sense itself.

analyzed: yat apavāda viṣayam parityajya sāmānyam vyavatiṣṭhate iti
translated: That a general [statement] rests, abandoning the subject of exceptions.

analyzed: tathā api manda prabodhanāya ācāryaiḥ abhihitaḥ
translated: Nevertheless, it is stated by the teachers for the sake of awakening the slow-witted.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa matayoḥ viṣaya bhedam darśayati balavat iti
translated: In another way, he shows the difference in the object of the two opinions with the word strong.

analyzed: balavat virodhi sadbhāve jaiminī ādi uktiḥ iṣyate
translated: When there is the existence of a strong opposing factor, the statement of Jaimini and others is accepted.

analyzed: atra api sāmānyam bhagavat proktam iti vartate
translated: Here also, the general statement made by the Lord continues.

analyzed: bhagavatā jñānam sakala puruṣa artha sādhanam iti sāmānyena uktam
translated: The Lord has stated in general that knowledge is the means of attaining all human goals.

analyzed: jaimini ādayaḥ tu balavat pratibandhaka karma sadbhāve jñānasya puruṣa artha asādhanatvam abhipretya na svatantra jñānāt svarga ādi prāptiḥ bhavati iti uktavantaḥ
translated: But Jaimini and others, thinking that knowledge is not a means of attaining human goals when there is the existence of strong obstructing karma, have said that heaven and so on are not attained by knowledge alone.

analyzed: tatas ca sāmānya viśeṣa viṣaya tvāt na virodhaḥ
translated: Therefore, because it has a general and specific object, there is no contradiction.

analyzed: tathā ca apratibaddha jñāna viṣayam bhagavat matam vyavatiṣṭhate
translated: And thus, the opinion of the Lord is established to have knowledge as its object, which is not obstructed.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: ārabdhasya an atikramāt iti
translated: Because what has begun cannot be transgressed.

original: nanu nāyaṃ jaiminyādimatasya viṣayo vaktuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: nanu nā ayam jaimini ādi matasya viṣayaḥ vaktum śakyate
translated: But this cannot be said to be the object of the opinion of Jaimini and others.

analyzed: balavat virodha sadbhāve karmaṇaḥ pi svarga ādi sādhanatva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because when there is the existence of a strong opposing factor, the attainment of heaven and so on by karma also becomes impossible.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

original: nahi yajjñānasya pratibandhakaṃ kamar tatkarmaṇo 'pītyasti niyamaḥ /
analyzed: nahi yat jñānasya pratibandhakam tat karmaṇaḥ pi iti asti niyamaḥ
translated: For there is no rule that what is an obstruction to knowledge is also an obstruction to karma.

analyzed: loke nyathā darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen otherwise in the world.

analyzed: phala pratibandhaka karma sadbhāve katham iti ced
translated: If it is asked how it is when there is the existence of karma that obstructs the result,

analyzed: tadā svarga ādi sādhanam karma eva na utpadyate
translated: then the karma itself that is the means of attaining heaven etc. does not arise.

original: utpannaṃ vā pratibaddhaṃ tiṣṭhatīti ko virodhaḥ /
analyzed: utpannam vā pratibaddham tiṣṭhati iti kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: Or if it has arisen, it remains obstructed. What is the contradiction?

analyzed: nahi balavat virodhi sadbhāve sarvatra eva
translated: For it has been said that when there is the existence of a powerful contradiction, it is not accepted everywhere

analyzed: jaiminī ādi uktiḥ iṣyate iti uktam
translated: that the statement of Jaimini etc. is true.

analyzed: iyam ca vyavasthā pūrva vyavasthayā upaska tarvyā
translated: And this arrangement should be supplemented by the previous arrangement.

analyzed: anyathā virodha āpatteḥ iti
translated: Otherwise, because of the contradiction that would ensue.

analyzed: iti puruṣa artha adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the human goal.
II. The section on those who act as they please

analyzed: atha kāmacāra adhikaraṇam
translated: Now begins the section on those who act as they please.

analyzed: om stutaye numatiḥ vai om
translated: Om. Is it praise or permission? Om.

analyzed: atra adhikaraṇe jñāninaḥ sat asat pravṛttibhyām viśeṣa sadbhāvaḥ samarthyate
translated: In this section, the existence of a special quality through the good and bad conduct of the knower is established.

original: tathā cājñānisāmānyasamarthanārthasyāsya na jñānasāmarthyapratipādanārthe 'sminpāde 'ntarbhāvaḥ sambhavatītyato 'dhikaraṇasya tātparyamāha 🔽vikarmeti //
analyzed: tathā ca ajñāni sāmānya samarthana arthasya asya na jñāna sāmarthya pratipādana arthe smin pāde ntarbhāvaḥ sambhavati iti atas dhikaraṇasya tātparyam āha  vikarma iti
translated: And thus, since this is for the purpose of establishing the generality of the ignorant, it cannot be included in this chapter which is for the purpose of teaching the ability of knowledge. Therefore, he states the purpose of the section🔽with vikarma etc.

analyzed: stutaye numatiḥ vā
translated: Is it praise or permission?

original: vikarmalepo naivāsti samyagdṛṣṭimatāṃ kvacit // / / //🔽yadyapyatra mukhato jñānināṃ sadasatpravṛttibhyāṃ viśeṣasadbhāvaḥ pratipādyate /
analyzed: vikarma lepaḥ na evā asti samyak dṛṣṭimatām kvacid  yadi api atra mukhatas jñāninām sat asat pravṛttibhyām viśeṣa sadbhāvaḥ pratipādyate
translated: There is no stain of wrong action at all for those with right vision.🔽Although here it is directly taught that there is a difference between the wise due to their engagement in good and bad actions,

original: tathāpi samyagdṛṣṭimatāṃ kvacidapi vikarmalepo vakṣyamāṇarūpo naivāstītyasyārthasya phalato lābhādyukto 'syāntarbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api samyak dṛṣṭimatām kvacid api vikarma lepaḥ vakṣyamāṇa rūpaḥ na evā asti iti asya arthasya phalataḥ lābhāt yuktaḥ sya antarbhāvaḥ
translated: nevertheless, the meaning that there is no stain of wrong action at all for those with right vision, which is to be stated, is indirectly obtained, so its inclusion is proper.

analyzed: na hi ajñāninām vikarma lepa abhāvaḥ sti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no absence of the stain of wrong action for the ignorant.

analyzed: yathā uktam kāmacāreṇa ca eke iti
translated: As it is said: And some by the conduct of desire.

analyzed: vikarma lepa abhāve katham asat pravṛttyā viśeṣa sadbhāvaḥ ṅgīkriyate iti ced
translated: If it is asked how the existence of a difference due to engagement in bad actions is accepted when there is no stain of wrong action,

analyzed: ānanda ādi guṇa hānaḥ viḥ karma kartuḥ viśeṣasya svīkārāt
translated: it is because the difference of the doer of wrong actions, which is the loss of the qualities of bliss etc., is accepted.

analyzed: tatas nyaḥ iti vakṣyate
translated: It will be said that the absence of stain is different from that.

original: kiṃ sarveṣāmapi jñānināṃ vikarmasambhavo guṇahāniścāstītyapekṣāyāmāha guṇahāniśceti //
analyzed: kim sarveṣām api jñāninām vikarma sambhavaḥ guṇa hāniḥ ca asti iti apekṣāyām āha guṇa hāniḥ ca iti
translated: When there is a doubt as to whether the stain of wrong action and the loss of qualities exist for all the wise, he says and the loss of qualities etc.

analyzed: guṇa hāniḥ ca nā evā asti brahmaṇaḥ tu avikarmataḥ
translated: And there is no loss of qualities for Brahman due to the absence of wrong action.

analyzed: devānām api na prāyas
translated: ...and for the gods it is not usually...

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ tu sarvathā vikarma na asti
translated: But for Brahman there is no wrong action at all.

analyzed: na bhāratī me ṅga mṛṣā upalakṣyate
translated: Nor is the Vedic speech seen by me to be false.

analyzed: iti ādi vacanāt
translated: And so on.

analyzed: avikarmataḥ guṇa hāniḥ ca na eva asti
translated: And there is no loss of qualities due to wrong action.

analyzed: hiraṇyagarbha itara devānām api prāyas vikarma guṇa hānī na staḥ
translated: Even for gods other than Hiraṇyagarbha, there is generally no loss of qualities due to wrong action.

analyzed: īṣat vikama ṛtat nimittā guṇa hāniḥ ca asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is a slight loss of qualities caused by wrong action.

original: yadi devānāṃ vikarma sambhavati tena cānandādiguṇahāniḥ syāttadāyamasmādetāvatā nyūno 'smādetāvatādhiko 'nena samāna iti śāstrīyaniyamo bhajyeta
analyzed: yadi devānām vikarma sambhavati tena ca ānanda ādi guṇa hāniḥ syāt tadā ayam asmāt etāvatā smāt etāvatā adhikaḥ nena samānaḥ iti śāstrīya niyamaḥ bhajyeta
translated: If wrong action is possible for the gods and if there is a loss of qualities such as bliss due to that, then the scriptural rule that this one is less than this by so much, more than this by so much, equal to this by this would be broken.

original: tathāca śāstrasyāprāmāṇyaṃ syāt /🔽naca tadaiva pratiyogiparamparā vikṛtiḥ pramāṇavatītyata āha kḷptasyeti //
analyzed: tathā ca śāstrasya aprāmāṇyam syāt  na ca tadā eva pratiyogi paramparā vikṛtiḥ pramāṇavatī iti atas āha kḷptasya iti
translated: And in that case, the scriptures would be invalid.🔽And it is not reasonable that the series of counteragents should be modified at that very time. Therefore he says 'of what is established' etc.

analyzed: kṛptasya tu kathañcana
translated: But of what is established somehow...

original: hānirneti vartate /🔽yasyā devasya yāvad guṇatvaṃ kḷptaṃ tasya tu kathañcana kenāpi vikarmaṇā hānirna bhavatītyarthaḥ / /
analyzed: hāniḥ na iti vartate  yasyāḥ devasya yāvat guṇa tvam kḷptam tasya tu kathañcana kena api vikarmaṇā hāniḥ na bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The loss is not, continues.🔽The meaning is that for which god the extent of qualities is established, there is no loss of it somehow by any wrong action.

original: tarhi devanāṃ vikarmaṇeṣadguṇahānirbhavatītyasya ko 'thar ityata āha prāpteti //
analyzed: tarhi devanām vikarmaṇā īṣat guṇa hāniḥ bhavati iti asya iti atas āha prāptā iti
translated: Then what is the meaning of this that there is a slight loss of qualities due to wrong action of the gods? Therefore he says 'when attained' etc.

original: prāptahrāso bhavet kvāpi mahatā tu vikarmaṇā // / / //
analyzed: prāpta hrāsaḥ bhavet kvāpi mahatā tu vikarmaṇā
translated: Sometimes there may be a decrease of what has been attained, due to a great misdeed.

analyzed: prāpta śabdena prasaktam ucyate
translated: By the word 'prāpta' (attained), what is connected is meant.

original: devānāmalpena vikarmaṇā na kiñciddhīyate /🔽kvāpi prāptena mahatā tu vikarmaṇā prāptasyaiva guṇasya hrāso
analyzed: devānām alpena vikarmaṇā na kiñcid hīyate  kvāpi prāptena mahatā tu vikarmaṇā prāptasya eva guṇasya
translated: For the gods, nothing is lost due to a small misdeed.

analyzed: bhavet
translated: But sometimes, due to a great misdeed of what has been attained, there may be a decrease of the very quality that has been attained.

original: svayogyaparipūrtaye yāvatsādhanamanuṣṭheyaṃ tato 'tiriktena sādhanenānuṣṭhitena yadānandādikaṃ prasaktaṃ tasyābhāvo bhavet /
analyzed: sva yogya paripūrtaye yāvat sādhanam anuṣṭheyam tatas tiriktena sādhanena anuṣṭhitena yat ānanda ādikam prasaktam tasya abhāvaḥ bhavet
translated: For the sake of fulfilling one's own capacity, the means should be practiced up to that extent. If bliss etc. that has been connected is absent due to practicing the means in excess of that,

original: yadi svayogyaparipūrtyarthaṃ sādhanātiriktamapi sādhanaṃ devairanuṣṭhīyate tadā tāratamyaniyamo bhajyeta /
analyzed: yadi sva yogya paripūrti artham sādhana atiriktam api sādhanam devaiḥ anuṣṭhīyate tadā tāratamya niyamaḥ bhajyeta
translated: if the gods practice the means in excess of what is necessary for fulfilling their own capacity, then the rule of gradation would be broken.

original: yo hi devo 'ratiriktasādhanamanuṣṭhāya na mahadvikarma karoti tasyotpattavyameva tena guṇena /
analyzed: yaḥ hi devaḥ rati rikta sādhanam anuṣṭhāya na mahat vikarma karoti tasya utpattavyam eva tena guṇena
translated: For that god who practices the means in excess and does not commit a great misdeed, that quality should certainly arise in him.

analyzed: īśvara ārādhanasya vaiphalya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the worship of God cannot be considered fruitless.

analyzed: na ca tadā eva anyeṣām vikriyāyām pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no evidence that the other gods are affected at that time.

analyzed: tatas ca śāstrasya aprāmāṇyam iti atas āha tathā api iti
translated: Therefore, the scriptures are not authoritative. To this he says 'tathāpi' (nevertheless).

analyzed: tathā api tat kṷptam eva
translated: Nevertheless, that is indeed established.

analyzed: yadi api devaiḥ sva yogya paripūrti artham sādhana atiriktam api sādhanam anuṣṭhīyate
translated: Even though the gods perform a means of attainment in addition to the means for the sake of fulfilling their own eligibility,

original: tathāpi teṣāṃ tadvighātakaṃ tadvikarma mahatkḷptaṃ niyatameva /
analyzed: tathā api teṣām tat vighātakam tat vikarma mahat kḷptam niyatam eva
translated: nevertheless, for them, that which obstructs that, that great adverse action, is certainly established.

analyzed: sva adhikāra adhikaḥ yatnaḥ kathañcid nā upapadyate
translated: Exertion in excess of one's authority is in no way possible.

analyzed: kathañcid adhike yatne doṣaḥ kaścid samāpatet
translated: In some way, if there is excessive exertion, some fault would ensue.

analyzed: iti vacanāt
translated: Because of this statement.

analyzed: kḷptasya tu kathañcana tathā api tat kḷptam eva iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that even if it is somehow established, it is indeed established.

analyzed: dvayasya api sādhyam āha tasmāt iti
translated: He states the conclusion of both: therefore, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt na niyama ujkhitiḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no violation of the rule.

analyzed: kḷpta hāya bhāvāt adhika anuṣṭhāne vikarma patti niyamāt ca
translated: Because there is no loss of what is established, and because there is adverse action in the performance of what is in excess, and because there is a rule.

analyzed: śrauta tāratamya niyama bhaṅgaḥ na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no violation of the rule of gradation as heard.

analyzed: ukta artham udāharati candra iti  candra sugrīvayoḥ ca eva sva ucca dāra parigrahāt
translated: And he gives an example of the stated meaning: with the moon, etc.

analyzed: prāpta hāniḥ abhūt na eva kṛpta hāniḥ yathañcana
translated: And there was no loss of what was attained by the moon and Sugrīva in taking a wife from their own high caste, but there was no loss of what was established in any way.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ yathā iti arthe
translated: The word ca (and) means yathā (as).

analyzed: evaśabdasya prāpta hāniḥ eva iti anvayaḥ
translated: The word eva (only) is to be connected with prāptahānir eva (only the loss of what was attained).

analyzed: mānuṣa ādīnām ānandasya vikarmaṇā
translated: Even the decrease of bliss of humans and others is due to adverse action.

analyzed: bhavet muktau viśeṣeṇa sva uccānām aparādhataḥ
translated: There is decrease even of what is ordained, especially in the case of those who are in high positions, due to the fault of transgressing their duties.

original: devānāṃ vikarmaṇā prasaktahānireva bhavati na tu kḷptahānirityuktam /
analyzed: devānām vikarmaṇā prasakta hāniḥ eva bhavati na tu kḷpta hāniḥ iti uktam
translated: It has been said that for gods, there is only loss of what is acquired by engaging in improper actions, but not loss of what is ordained.

analyzed: tad atiriktānām tu katham iti apekṣāyām āha  kḷptasya api iti apeḥ arthaḥ  ānandasya iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: But for those other than that, what is the case? To this question, it is said: decrease also.🔽The meaning of api (also) is even of what is ordained.🔽Of bliss is by way of illustration.

analyzed: hrāsaḥ nāma anabhivyaktiḥ
translated: Decrease means non-manifestation.

analyzed: sā ca īśvara icchā adhīnā  prakṛti ādi āvaraṇānām apāsta tvāt
translated: And that is dependent on the will of God.🔽Because the obscurations of prakṛti (primordial matter) and others have been removed.

analyzed: vikarmasu api adhikam nirdhārayan āha viśeṣeṇa iti
translated: Specifying further even in the case of improper actions, it is said: especially.

analyzed: sva uttama viṣaya aparādhāt viśeṣeṇa ānanda hrāsaḥ bhavati
translated: There is especially decrease of bliss due to the fault of transgressing one's own superior duties.

analyzed: om kāmacāreṇa ca eke om
translated: Om. Some say by the practice of desire. Om.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be the case.

original: atrādhikaraṇe kāmacāreṇa caika iti sūtreṇa jñānottarakālaṃ kṛtena vikarmaṇā jñānino lepābhāvo 'bhidhīyate /
analyzed: atra adhikaraṇe kāmacāreṇa ca ekaḥ iti sūtreṇa jñāna uttara kālam kṛtena vikarmaṇā jñāninaḥ lepa abhāvaḥ abhidhīyate
translated: In this section, by the sutra Some say by the practice of desire, it is stated that the knower is not affected by improper actions done after knowledge.

original: tathopamardaṃ ceti sūtreṇa jñānātpūrveṣāṃ karmaṇāṃ jñānena vināśaḥ /
analyzed: tathā upamardam ca iti sūtreṇa jñānāt pūrveṣām karmaṇām jñānena vināśaḥ
translated: Similarly, by the sutra And by destruction, the actions done before knowledge are destroyed by knowledge.

analyzed: etat ubhayam caturthe dhyāye tad adhigame uttara pūrva aghayoḥ aśleṣa vināśau iti sūtreṇa ucyate
translated: Both of these are stated in the fourth chapter by the sutra After attaining that, there is no connection with past and future sins, and their destruction.

original: tatkathaṃ ca punaruktidoṣa ityatastāvatkāmacāreṇa caika ityasya punaruktidoṣaṃ pariharati jñānottarasyeti //
analyzed: tat katham ca punarukti doṣaḥ iti atas tāvat kāmacāreṇa ca ekaḥ ityasya punarukti doṣam pariharati jñāna uttarasya iti
translated: How then is there the fault of repetition? To this, he first avoids the fault of repetition of the phrase and some by their own will by saying of the sin after knowledge etc.

analyzed: kāmakāreṇa ca eke
translated: And some by their own will...

analyzed: jñāna uttarasya pāpasya caturthe lepaḥ ucyate
translated: The non-adherence of the sin after knowledge is said in the fourth (verse).

original: caturthe 'dhyāye uttarāghasyāśleṣa ityanena jñānottarasya pāpasyālepastatphalanarākādiprāptyabhāva ucyate /
analyzed: caturthe dhyāye uttara aghasya āśleṣaḥ iti anena jñāna uttarasya pāpasya ālepaḥ tad phala narāka ādi prāpti abhāvaḥ ucyate
translated: In the fourth chapter, by the phrase the non-adherence of the sin after knowledge, the non-adherence of the sin after knowledge, i.e., the absence of attaining its fruit, rebirth in hell etc., is stated.

original: viṣayāntaramāha aśucitvādikaṃ ceti //🔽aśucitvādikaṃ tasya na bhavediti tatphalam // / / //
analyzed: viṣaya antaram āha aśuci tva ādikam ca iti  aśuci tva ādikam tasya na bhavet iti tad phalam
translated: He states a different topic: and the state of impurity etc.🔽That is its fruit.🔽The state of impurity, unapproachability etc. are not its fruit.

original: asya jñāninarastatphalaṃ jñānottarapāpaphalamaśucitvāsambhāṣyatvādikaṃ na bhavediti cottarāghasyāśleṣa ityanenocyate /
analyzed: asya jñāni naraḥ tad phalam jñāna uttara pāpa phalam aśuci tva asaṃbhāṣya tva ādikam na bhavet iti ca uttara aghasya āśleṣaḥ iti anena ucyate
translated: This is stated by the phrase the non-adherence of the sin after knowledge.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha atra iti
translated: What then? To this he says here etc.

analyzed: atra jñāna phalasya eva mukteḥ niyata tā ucyate
translated: Here, the certainty of the fruit of knowledge, i.e., liberation, is stated.

original: atra tṛtīye 'dhyāye kāmacāreṇa caika ityanena jñānaphalasya mukterniyatatā /
analyzed: atra tṛtīye dhyāye kāmacāreṇa ca ekaḥ iti anena jñāna phalasya mukteḥ niyata tā
translated: Here, in the third chapter, by the phrase and some by their own will, the certainty of the fruit of knowledge, i.e., liberation,

original: jñāninā kṛtāni pāpāni jñānaphalaṃ mokṣaṃ na vihantumalabhityeṣo 'rtha ucyate /
analyzed: jñāninā kṛtāni pāpāni jñāna phalam mokṣam na vihantum alam iti eṣaḥ rthaḥ ucyate
translated: It is said that the fruits of knowledge do not obstruct the liberation that is the fruit of knowledge.

analyzed: atas na punarukti doṣaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, there is no fault of repetition.

analyzed: om upamardam ca om
translated: Om. And destruction. Om.

original: dvitīyāṃ punaruktiṃ parihartumupamardaṃ cetyasya pratipādyamāha prārabdheti //
analyzed: dvitīyām punaruktim parihartum upamardam ca ityasya pratipādyam āha prārabdha iti
translated: To avoid the second repetition, he explains what is to be taught by and destruction with of what has begun, etc.

analyzed: upamardam ca
translated: And destruction.

analyzed: prārabdha karma jasya eva viṣa bhakṣāt mṛteḥ iva
translated: Of what has begun, like death from eating poison.

analyzed: prāptasya api a nivartyasya kiñcid bhuktasya saṃvidā
translated: Even of what has been attained and is inevitable, some is consumed by knowledge.

analyzed: upamardaḥ iha proktaḥ
translated: Here, destruction is said to be...

analyzed: caturthe pūrva ardhasya svarūpa vināśaḥ kathyate
translated: In the fourth chapter, the destruction of the nature of the first half is described.

analyzed: anārabdha kārye eva iti vacanāt
translated: Because of the statement only of what has not begun to bear fruit.

original: iha tṛtīye 'dhyāye tūpamardaṃ ceti sūtreṇa prārabdhakarmajasya phalasyaiva saṃvidopamardaḥ proktaḥ /
analyzed: iha tṛtīye dhyāye tu upamardam ca iti sūtreṇa prārabdha karma jasya phalasya eva saṃvidā upamardaḥ proktaḥ
translated: But here, in the third chapter, in the sutra and destruction, the destruction of the fruit itself of what has begun to bear fruit is said to be by knowledge.

original: natu prārabdhasyāprārabdhasya vā karmaṇo nāśa iti na punaruktidoṣaḥ /
analyzed: na tu prārabdhasya a prārabdhasya vā karmaṇaḥ nāśaḥ iti na punarukti doṣaḥ
translated: But there is no destruction of what has begun to bear fruit or what has not begun to bear fruit. Therefore, there is no fault of repetition.

original: nanvatra prārabdhakarmaṇa ityeva kasmānnoktaṃ kiṃ tajjanitaphalagrahaṇena /
analyzed: nanu atra prārabdha karmaṇaḥ iti eva kasmāt na uktam kim tad janita phala grahaṇena
translated: But why is it not said here simply of what has begun to bear fruit? What is the point of mentioning the fruit generated by that?

analyzed: śaṅkayam
translated: This should not be suspected.

analyzed: bhogena tu itare
translated: But the other (two) by enjoyment.

analyzed: iti prārabdhasya karmaṇaḥ bhoga vināśya tva ukteḥ
translated: Thus, since it is said that the karma that has begun to operate is to be destroyed by enjoyment,🔽if the destruction by consciousness is accepted, there would be a contradiction with that.

analyzed: īṣat vināśaḥ tu phala dvāreṇa eva
translated: However, partial destruction is only through the effect.

analyzed: karmaṇām nirbhāga tvāt
translated: Because actions are partless.

original: nanu ca phalopamarde karmopamarda evokto 'rthataḥ syāt /
analyzed: nanu ca phala upamarde karma upamardaḥ eva uktaḥ ṛthataḥ syāt
translated: But isn't it that when the effect is destroyed, the destruction of the action would be stated in meaning?

original: tathāca bhogeneti sūtravirodhastadavastha ityata uktaṃ kiñcid bhuktasyeti /
analyzed: tathā ca bhogena iti sūtra virodhaḥ tad avasthaḥ iti atas uktam kiñcid bhuktasya iti
translated: And so, the contradiction with the sutra by enjoyment remains. To this it is said: of what has been partially enjoyed.

analyzed: na sarvasya prārabdha karma phalasya upamardaḥ saṃvidā ucyate
translated: The destruction of all the fruits of the karma that has begun to operate is not being stated by consciousness.

analyzed: kinnāma kiñcid bhuktasya atas na sūtra virodhaḥ
translated: What then? Of what has been partially enjoyed. Therefore there is no contradiction with the sutra.

original: karmāṇi jñāninaṃ na tāvatsvaphalaṃ bhojayanti yāvadajñāninamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: karmāṇi jñāninam na tāvat sva phalam bhojayanti yāvat ajñāninam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that actions do not first give their fruits to the knower of the Self as long as they do not give them to the non-knower of the Self.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

original: na vai jano jātu kathañcanāvrajenmukundasevyanyavadaṅga saṃsṛtim' / iti /
analyzed: na vai janaḥ jātu kathañcana āvrajet mukunda sevi anya vat aṅga saṃsṛtim iti
translated: O limb, people will never, by any means, go to worldly existence like one who serves Mukunda.

analyzed: nanu avaśyam anubhoktavyam kṛtam karma śubha aśubham iti
translated: But isn't it that one must necessarily experience the good and bad actions that have been done?

analyzed: prārabdha karma phala upabhogasya a parihāya ṛtu asmaraṇāt katham etat iti atas uktam anivartyasya prāptasya api iti
translated: Since it is remembered that the experience of the fruits of the karma that has begun to operate cannot be avoided, how is this? To this it is said: Even of what has been attained and cannot be averted.

analyzed: aparihārya tayā prasaktasya api iti arthaḥ  anivartya tayā prasaktasya api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even of what is engaged by the inevitability of occurrence.🔽The meaning is: even of what is engaged by the inevitability of occurrence.

analyzed: anivartyasya api iti etāvati eva vaktavye prāptasya iti anena virodha parihāram sūcayati
translated: When it should have been said simply even of what is inevitable, by saying of what is obtained he indicates the avoidance of contradiction.

analyzed: atra dṛṣṭāntam āha viṣa iti
translated: Here he gives an example: Just as with poison...

analyzed: yathā viṣa bhakṣaṇāt mṛttiḥ anivartya tayā prasaktā eva na punar ativartyā eva
translated: Just as death from eating poison is engaged by the inevitability of occurrence, not by the inevitability of non-occurrence.

analyzed: viṣa hara mantra auṣadha ādinā nivṛtteḥ darśanāt
translated: Because its cessation is seen by means of antidotes to poison such as mantras and herbs.

original: tathā prārabdhakarmaphalabhogo 'pyanivartyatayā prasakta eva na tvanivartya eva /
analyzed: tathā prārabdha karma phala bhogaḥ pi anivartya tayā prasaktaḥ eva na tu anivartyaḥ eva
translated: Similarly, the enjoyment of the fruits of commenced karma is engaged by the inevitability of occurrence, not by the inevitability of non-occurrence.

analyzed: jñāna ādinā nivṛtteḥ upapādayiṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because its cessation by means of knowledge and so on will be established.

analyzed: tathā ca viṣa bhakṣaṇāt maraṇam avaśyam bhāvi iti vacana vat avaśyam anubhoktavyam iti vacanasya api arthaḥ vagantavyaḥ
translated: And thus the meaning of the statement it must certainly be experienced should be understood, just like the statement death from eating poison is certain.

analyzed: utsargataḥ prārabdha karma phalāni bhoktavyāni eva
translated: By nature, the fruits of commenced karma are to be experienced.

analyzed: apavādena tu upamṛdyante iti
translated: But by exception, they are destroyed.

original: kiṃ sarveṣāṃ jñānināṃ prārabdhakarmaphalopamarda ekavidha evota nānāvidha ityapekṣāyāmāha devādīnāmiti // /
analyzed: kim sarveṣām jñāninām prārabdha karma phala upamardaḥ ekavidhaḥ eva uta nānāvidhaḥ iti apekṣāyām āha deva ādīnām iti
translated: What is the nature of the destruction of the fruits of the prārabdha karma of all the jñānins? Is it of one kind or of various kinds? Anticipating this question, he says 'of the gods etc.'

original: kiṃ sarveṣāṃ jñānināṃ prārabdhakarmaphalopamarda ekavidha evota nānāvidha ityapekṣāyāmāha devādīnāmiti /
analyzed: kim sarveṣām jñāninām prārabdha karma phala upamardaḥ ekavidhaḥ eva uta nānāvidhaḥ iti apekṣāyām āha deva ādīnām iti
translated: What is the nature of the destruction of the fruits of the prārabdha karma of all the jñānins? Is it of one kind or of various kinds? Anticipating this question, he says 'of the gods etc.'

analyzed: deva ādīnām yathākramam
translated: Of the gods etc., in order...

analyzed: yeṣām adhikam jñānam teṣām adhikaḥ ityādi
translated: For those whose knowledge is greater, their destruction is greater, and so on.

analyzed: etena na aviśeṣāt
translated: By this, 'because there is no distinction'

original: iti madhye paṭhitasya sūtrasya pūrvatrottaratra copayoga🔽ityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: iti madhye paṭhitasya sūtrasya pūrvatra uttaratra ca upayoga  iti uktam bhavati
translated: It is said that the sūtra which is recited in the middle is useful both before and after.

analyzed: prārabdha karmaṇām bhogena vinā na kṣayaḥ
translated: The prārabdha karmas are not destroyed without being experienced.

analyzed: kintu brahma jñānena phala hrāsaḥ bhavati iti uktam
translated: But it is said that by the knowledge of Brahman, their fruits are diminished.

analyzed: tatra eke manyante
translated: In that regard, some think:

analyzed: acintyaḥ hi brahma jñānasya mahimā
translated: For the greatness of the knowledge of Brahman is inconceivable.

analyzed: atas tad sāmarthyāt aprārabdhāni iva prārabdhāni api karmāṇi abhukta phalāni kṣīyante
translated: Therefore, by its power, even the prārabdha karmas, as if they were not prārabdha, are destroyed without their fruits being experienced.

analyzed: na abhuktam kṣīyate karma ityādi vākyāni tu ajñāni viṣayāṇi
translated: But the statements beginning with 'what is not experienced is not destroyed' refer to those who are ignorant.

analyzed: tatas ca jñāna agniḥ sarva karmāṇi iti sarva śabdaḥ syāt iti
translated: And then the word 'all' in the text 'the fire of knowledge burns all actions' would be meaningless.

original: anye tu parameśvarecchopodbalitāni prārabdhāni bhojayantyeva sarvaṃ svaphalam /
analyzed: anye tu parameśvara icchā upodbalitāni prārabdhāni bhojayanti eva sarvam sva phalam
translated: But others say that the prārabdha [karmas] strengthened by the supreme Lord's will indeed make one experience all one's own fruits.

original: na kaścidapi phalahrāso 'stīti /🔽tatrādyaṃ mataṃ tāvadapākaroti sarvātmaneti //
analyzed: na kaścid api phala hrāsaḥ sti iti  tatra ādyam matam tāvat apākaroti sarva ātmanā iti
translated: There is not even the slightest reduction in the fruits.

analyzed: sarva ātmanā tu abhogaḥ hi prārabdhasya eva karmaṇaḥ
translated: Among them, he first refutes the first view, saying 'in fact, the experience of the prārabdha [karmas] is complete'.

analyzed: na brahma darśinaḥ pi syāt
translated: In fact, the experience of the prārabdha [karmas] of even one who has seen Brahman would not be complete.🔽...

original: brahmadarśino 'pi prārabdhasya karmaṇaḥ sarvātmanā tvabhogo na syādeva /
analyzed: brahma darśinaḥ u pi prārabdhasya karmaṇaḥ sarva ātmanā tu abhogaḥ na syāt eva
translated: The experience of the prārabdha [karmas] of even one who has seen Brahman would not be complete in every way.

original: vinā bhogena brahmajñānādeva prārabdhānyapi karmāṇi kṣīyanta iti matamanupapannamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vinā bhogena brahma jñānāt eva prārabdhāni api karmāṇi kṣīyante iti matam anupapannam iti arthaḥ
translated: The view that even the prārabdha [karmas] are destroyed by the knowledge of Brahman alone, without experience, is not correct. This is the meaning.

original: tathā sati brahmavidāṃ saṃsārāvasthānaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: tathā sati brahma vidām saṃsāra avasthānam na syāt
translated: If that were so, those who know Brahman would not remain in saṃsāra.

analyzed: nirbīja tvāt
translated: Because they would be without seeds.

analyzed: loka anugraha artham eva vigrahān te bibhrati iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that they assume bodies only for the sake of blessing the world, that is not so.

analyzed: śāpa ādi nimittānām āpādām api itihāsa purāṇeṣu bahulam upalambhāt
translated: Because the causes of curses and so on are often found in the Itihāsas and Purāṇas even for those who have attained liberation.

original: tasya tāvadeva ciramityādiśrutyā cāvagamyate karmāvasthānamiti hiśabdārthaḥ /
analyzed: tasya tāvat eva ciram ityādi śrutyā ca avagamyate karma avasthānam iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the word 'hi' (therefore).

analyzed: dvitīyam matam apākartum āha phala iti
translated: To refute the second opinion, he says 'phala' (fruit).

analyzed: phala hrāsaḥ tu vidyate
translated: But there is a decrease in the fruit.

analyzed: prārabdhasya kamarṇaḥ iti vartate
translated: Of the commenced action, it continues.

original: oṃmityaccāryāntarimamātmānamabhipaśyopamṛdya puṇyaṃ ca pāpaṃ ca kāmamācaranto brahmānuvrajanti' /
analyzed: om iti at ca ārya antar imam ātmānam abhipaśya upamṛdya puṇyam ca pāpam ca kāmam ācarantaḥ brahma anuvrajanti
translated: Having seen this Self, which is to be meditated upon with the syllable Om, having destroyed merit and demerit, they who desire go to Brahman.

analyzed: iti āgamāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: yastvāgamaprārabdhaviṣayaṃ vyākhyāya prārabdhakarmaphalasyeṣadapi hrāso nāstīti brūyāntaṃ pratyāha sarvātmaneti //
analyzed: yaḥ tu āgama prārabdha viṣayam vyākhyāya prārabdha karma phalasya īṣat api hrāsaḥ na asti iti brūyān tam pratyāha sarva ātmanā iti
translated: But one who explains that the commenced action refers to the scriptures and says that there is not even the slightest decrease in the fruit of commenced action, to him he says 'sarvātmanā' (entirely).

analyzed: sarva ātmanā phala hrāsaḥ yadi na ārabdha karmaṇaḥ
translated: If there is a decrease in the fruit of commenced action entirely,

analyzed: syāt kāmya vidhi vaiyarthyam
translated: there would be the futility of the injunctions of desired actions.

analyzed: īṣat api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is even a little.

analyzed: brahmahatyā ādi karma vipāka kṣaya roga ādi nivṛtti arthāḥ prāyaścitta vidhayaḥ tra kāmya vidhayaḥ vivakṣitāḥ
translated: The injunctions of expiation, which are for the purpose of removing the diseases etc. that are the results of actions such as Brahman-slaying, are here intended as the injunctions of desired actions.

analyzed: ayam atra uttara kramaḥ
translated: The sequence of the answer here is this.

analyzed: brahma hā kṣaya rogī syāt
translated: A Brahman-slayer would have the disease of consumption.

analyzed: iti smaraṇāt kṣaya ādikam tāvat brahmahatyā ādeḥ phalam
translated: Because of this remembrance, the fruit of Brahman-slaughter etc. is destruction etc.

analyzed: tatas utpādita kṣaya ādikam brahmahatyā ādi prārabdham eva
translated: Therefore, the destruction etc. produced by it is only the prārabdha (i.e., the results of actions whose effects have already begun) of Brahman-slaughter etc.

original: tasya ca prārabdhakarmaphalasya kṣayādeḥ prāyaścittakaraṇe nivṛttirdṛśyate /
analyzed: tasya ca prārabdha karma phalasya kṣaya ādeḥ prāyaścitta karaṇe nivṛttiḥ dṛśyate
translated: And the cessation of that fruit of the prārabdha karma, destruction etc., is seen when the expiation is performed.

analyzed: tat katham prārabdha karmaka phalasya sarvathā api anupamardaḥ
translated: How then is the fruit of the prārabdha karma never destroyed at all?

analyzed: atha manyeta
translated: If he thinks:

original: prāyaścittaṃ na kṣayanivṛttihetuḥ kintu bhoganimittakarmakṣaya eveti /
analyzed: prāyaścittam na kṣaya nivṛtti hetuḥ kintu bhoga nimitta karma kṣayaḥ eva iti
translated: The expiation is not the cause of the cessation of destruction, but only the destruction of the karma that causes enjoyment.

analyzed: tadā prāyaścitta viṣayaḥ vyarthāḥ syuḥ
translated: Then the subjects of expiation would be useless.

analyzed: gṛha dāha iṣyayā ādi vat prāyaścittānām naimittika tvam bhaviṣyati iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the expiations will be occasional like the burning of the house etc., it is not so.

analyzed: kṣaya ādi saṃyogena vidhīyamānānām eṣām tad vighāta phala sambhave phala antara kalpanā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because when these, being enjoined in connection with destruction etc., are capable of having that as their fruit, it is not proper to assume another fruit.

analyzed: kiñca atra niyata paścādbhāvi tvam asamāhitam eva
translated: And what is said here about the fixed subsequent occurrence is not well-coordinated.

analyzed: tat idam uktam kāmyā iti
translated: This is said to be like the desirable (acts).

original: tathāpi brahmajñānaṃ na tadarthaṃ vihitamiti cenna /
analyzed: tathā api brahma jñānam na tad artham vihitam iti ced na
translated: Even so, if it is argued that the knowledge of Brahman is not enjoined for that purpose, it is not so.

analyzed: phala śrayaṇena eva vidhi kalpanāt
translated: Because the injunction is assumed only by reference to the fruit.

analyzed: anena eva nyāyena prāyaścittānām kama ṛkṣaya hetu tva abhāvaḥ pi nirastaḥ
translated: By this very reasoning, the absence of expiation rites as the cause of the destruction of sin is also refuted.

analyzed: tathā sati prāyaścitta vidhīnām vaiyarthya āpatteḥ
translated: For if that were so, the injunctions of expiation rites would be pointless.

analyzed: naimittika tva pakṣasya ca dṛṣṭa adṛṣṭa hāna upādāna prasaṅgena nirasta tvāt
translated: And because the view that they are occasional is refuted by the consequence of the loss and gain of seen and unseen [results].

analyzed: atha karmaṇaḥ dvayī śaktiḥ
translated: Now, if it is said that an action has two powers:

analyzed: ekā tāvat phala jananī aparā tu asaṃvyavahārya tva hetuḥ
translated: One is the producer of the result, the other is the cause of unserviceability,

analyzed: prāyaścittaiḥ dvitīyā apākriyate iti ced
translated: and the second is removed by expiation rites,

original: evaṃ tarhi karmavipākaprāyaścittānāmapīyameva gatiriti kathaṃ nopamardaḥ /
analyzed: evam tarhi karma vipāka prāyaścittānām api iyam eva gatiḥ iti katham na upamardaḥ
translated: then in that case, this is the very course of action, ripening, and expiation rites, so how is there no destruction [of the result]?

original: kiñca na sarvo rogaḥ sarvaṃ ca duritamasaṃvyavahāryatāheturiti tatra prāyaścittavaiyarthyameva syāt /
analyzed: kiñca na sarvaḥ rogaḥ sarvam ca duritam asaṃvyavahārya tā hetuḥ iti tatra prāyaścitta vaiyarthyam eva syāt
translated: Moreover, not all disease and all misfortune are the cause of unserviceability, so in that case, expiation rites would be pointless.

original: api ca kṣayakuṣṭhādyupahato 'pi na prāyaścittācaraṇamātreṇa saṃvyavahāryaḥ /
analyzed: api ca kṣaya kuṣṭha ādi upahataḥ u pi na prāyaścitta ācaraṇa mātreṇa saṃvyavahāryaḥ
translated: Furthermore, one afflicted with consumption, leprosy, etc. is not made serviceable merely by performing expiation rites.

analyzed: kintu kṣaya ādi apagamaḥ evā iti tad kāraṇa tvam eva prāyaścittānām aṅgīkāryam
translated: But only by the removal of consumption, etc. So the causal nature of expiation rites must be accepted.

analyzed: maraṇa antika prāyaścittānām ānarthakyam ca syāt
translated: And the expiation rites ending with death would be pointless.

analyzed: śrāddha ādi vyavahāra siddhaya artham tat iti ced na
translated: If it be said that this is for the sake of establishing the usage of śrāddha etc., it is not so.

analyzed: parivrājakānām tad abhāva āpātāt iti alam
translated: Because for the wandering ascetics, that would lead to its absence. So much is enough.

analyzed: upasaṃharati iti uktā iti
translated: He concludes with the words Thus it is said.

analyzed: iti ukta niyamaḥ bhavet
translated: Thus the rule stated would be...

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ tasmāt iti arthe
translated: The word iti means tasmāt (therefore).

original: prārabdhakarmaṇāṃ bhogādeva kṣayastathāpi phalahrāso 'pi vidyata ityuktaniyamo bhavedupapanna iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: prārabdha karmaṇām bhogāt eva kṣayaḥ tathā api vidyate iti ukta niyamaḥ bhavet upapannaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The destruction of the commenced actions is only through experience. Even so, there is also a decrease in the fruit. Thus the stated rule would be proper. This is the remainder.

analyzed: evam utpanna nirdeṣaḥ
translated: Thus, having produced faultlessness...

analyzed: ityādinā ukta arthe smṛti sammatim āha evamādi iti
translated: He states the agreement with Smṛti regarding the meaning stated beginning with this. He says Evamādi (and so on).

analyzed: evam adyā api samproktam tantrabhāgavate sphuṭam
translated: Thus, even today, it is clearly stated in the Tantra Bhāgavata...

analyzed: ādi padena etat upayuktam anyat  bhāṣya ādau udāhṛta eva ṛcanaiḥ api iti apeḥ arthaḥ
translated: By the word ādi (and so on), other things related to this are included.🔽The meaning of api (also) is that it is quoted even in the Bhāṣya and other commentaries.

analyzed: yat vā evamādi iti etat adhikaraṇa prameyam tat upayuktam ca gṛhyate
translated: By the word evamādi (and so on), the conclusion of this section and what is related to it is taken.

analyzed: api padena prathama adhikaraṇa prameyasya samuccayaḥ  athavā adhikaraṇa prameyasya samuccayaḥ
translated: By the word api (also), the conclusion of the first section is included.

analyzed: athavā adhikaraṇa dvaya athar evamādi iti anena gṛhītaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning of the two sections is taken by evamādi (and so on).

analyzed: dvitīya ādi adhikaraṇa artha grahaṇāya api śabdaḥ
translated: The word 'api' (even) is used to include the meaning of the second and subsequent sections.

analyzed: puruṣa artha adhikaraṇe stuti adhikaraṇe ca jñāna phalasya tāratamyam abhihitam
translated: In the section on human goals and the section on praise, the gradation of the fruits of knowledge has been stated.

original: tatsaṃsārikaphalasya na vipratipannamiti muktigatasya sādhayitumuttaro granthaḥ /
analyzed: tat saṃsārika phalasya na vipratipannam iti mukti gatasya sādhayitum uttaraḥ granthaḥ
translated: That is not disputed in the case of worldly fruits, so the subsequent text is to establish it in the case of liberation.

original: ye mokṣe bhedameva nāṅgīkuvarte ye cāṅgīkṛtyāpi bhedamānandādikaṃ nābhyupayanti na tānprati tāratamyasādhanasyāvakāśaḥ /
analyzed: ye mokṣe bhedam eva na aṅgīkuvarte ye ca aṅgīkṛtya api bhedam ānanda ādikam na abhyupayanti na tān prati tāratamya sādhanasya avakāśaḥ
translated: For those who do not accept even the difference in liberation, and those who, even accepting the difference, do not accept bliss etc., there is no scope for establishing gradation.

analyzed: kintu bheda ādi sādhanam eva
translated: But the means of establishing difference etc. should be done.

analyzed: kariṣyate ca caturthe dhyāye
translated: And that will be done in the fourth chapter.

original: ye punarbhedamānandādikaṃ cāṅgīkṛtyāpi tāratamyaṃ na manyante tānpratyaya prayatnaḥ kriyate /
analyzed: ye punar bhedam ānanda ādikam ca aṅgīkṛtya api tāratamyam na manyante prayatnaḥ kriyate
translated: But effort is made for those who, even accepting difference and bliss etc., do not consider gradation.

analyzed: yāvadadhikāram iti adhikaraṇa arthasya eva ayam prapañcaḥ iti na doṣaḥ
translated: This is an elaboration only of the meaning of the section 'up to the extent of authority', so there is no fault.

analyzed: tatra tāvacchatyā muktau ānanda tāratamyam upapādayati tāratamyam iti
translated: There, he first establishes the gradation of bliss in the liberated soul, saying 'if there is no gradation in the fruit' etc.

original: tāratamyaṃ phale no ced brahmādīnāṃ kathaṃ śrutiḥ /
analyzed: tāratamyam phale no ced brahma ādīnām katham śrutiḥ
translated: If there is no gradation in the fruit, then how is it stated in the scriptures about Brahma and others?

analyzed: a vṛjinaḥ kāma hataḥ iti muktim nigadya ca
translated: And having declared liberation as 'free from sin' and 'not struck down by desire',

original: ānandatāratamyaṃ ca teṣāṃ brūyāt pṛthak pṛthak // / / // /
analyzed: ānanda tāratamyam ca teṣām brūyāt pṛthak pṛthak
translated: he would speak of the gradation of bliss of each of them separately.

original: brahmādīnāṃ jñānaphale muktigāmityānande yadi yadi tāratamya no bhavettarhi kathaṃsa yo havai manuṣyāṇāṃ rāddha' /
analyzed: brahma ādīnām jñāna phale mukti gām iti ānande yadi yadi tāratamya no bhavet tarhi katham sa yaḥ manuṣyāṇām rāddha
translated: If there were no gradation in the bliss that leads to liberation, the fruit of knowledge of Brahma and others, then how could there be the statement in the Taittiriya Upanishad: 'He who is the best among men'?

analyzed: ityādikā vājasaneyinām sā eṣā ānandasya mīmāṃsā bhavati
translated: And the statement in the Vājasaneyi Upanishad: 'This is the investigation of bliss.'🔽And the statement in the Taittiriya Upanishad: 'This is the investigation of bliss.'

original: ityādikā taittirīyāṇāṃ ca śrutisteṣāṃ brahmādīnāmānandasya tāratamyaṃ brūyāt /
analyzed: ityādikā taittirīyāṇām ca śrutiḥ teṣām brahma ādīnām ānandasya tāratamyam brūyāt
translated: These statements would speak of the gradation of bliss of Brahma and others.

analyzed: sarve pi uttarottaram śataguṇa nandāḥ iti an abhidhāya pṛthak pṛthak eva bravīti
translated: Without saying that all are a hundred times more blissful than the previous one, he speaks of each separately.

analyzed: tena tatra tātparya sadbhāvaḥ ca avagamyate
translated: Therefore, the presence of the purport there is also understood.

original: brahmādīnāmānandasya yaśca śrutirbravīti muktānāṃ tu tatsādhyata iti kiṃ kena saṅgatamityata uktamavṛjina iti /
analyzed: brahma ādīnām ānandasya yaḥ ca śrutiḥ bravīti muktānām tu tat sādhyate iti kim kena saṅgatam iti atas uktam avṛjinaḥ iti
translated: And the statement in the Vedas about the bliss of Brahma and others is accomplished for the liberated ones. What is related to whom? To this, it is said: 'free from sin'.

analyzed: yaḥ ca śrotriyaḥ vṛjinaḥ kāma hataḥ ityādyā
translated: And the statement beginning with 'one who is learned, free from sin, not struck down by desire', etc.

analyzed: śrotriyasya ca a kāma hatasya iti dvitīyā
translated: And the second statement: 'of one who is learned and not struck down by desire'.

analyzed: yadi api śrotriya tvam api mukti jñāpakam iti anyatra uktam
translated: Although it has been said elsewhere that being a learned Brahmin is also an indicator of liberation,

original: tathāpi bahusaṃvidhānasādhyaṃ taditi na saṅkītirtam muktiṃ ca nigadya teṣāṃ muktānāmānandatāratamyaṃ ca bravīti /
analyzed: tathā api bahu saṃvidhāna sādhyam tat iti na saṅkītiḥ tam muktim ca nigadya teṣām muktānām ānanda tāratamyam ca bravīti
translated: still, since that is accomplished by many arrangements, it is not mentioned. And after mentioning liberation, he speaks of the gradation of bliss of those who are liberated.

analyzed: caśabdau mithas samuccaye
translated: The words ca (and) are for mutual combination.

analyzed: taittirīya śrutiḥ api atra upalakṣitā iti uttaratra jñāsyate
translated: It will be known later that the Taittiriya scripture is also indicated here.

original: śrutidvayoktamānandatāratamyaṃ saṃsāraviṣayameva na muktiviṣayamityāśaṅkaya pariharati saṃsāra iti //
analyzed: śruti dvaya uktam ānanda tāratamyam saṃsāra viṣayam eva na mukti viṣayam iti āśaṅkaya pariharati saṃsāre iti
translated: Suspecting that the gradation of bliss mentioned in the two scriptures pertains only to the cycle of birth and death and not to liberation, he answers with If this gradation is only in the cycle of birth and death, not primarily...

original: saṃsāra eva cedetat tāratamyaṃ na mukhyataḥ /
analyzed: saṃsāraḥ eva ced etat tāratamyam na mukhyatas
translated: If this gradation is only in the cycle of birth and death, not primarily,

analyzed: a kāma hata śabda arthaḥ vṛjina tvam ca naḥ bhavet
