original: yadi muktāstāratamyopetāstadā dveṣādimantaḥ syuriti vadatā na dveṣādimantastasmātsamā eveti vācyam /
analyzed: yadi muktāḥ tāratamya upetāḥ tadā dveṣa ādimantaḥ syuḥ iti vadatā na dveṣa ādimantaḥ tasmāt samāḥ eva iti vācyam
translated: If the liberated ones are endowed with degrees of excellence, then they would have hatred and so on. By saying this, it should be said that they do not have hatred and so on, therefore they are equal.

analyzed: na ca sāmyam api aṅgīkartum śakyate
translated: And equality cannot be accepted either.

original: yadi muktāḥ samāḥ syustadā dveṣādimantaḥ syuriti tatrāpyaniṣyaprasaṅgādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yadi muktāḥ samāḥ syuḥ tadā dveṣa ādimantaḥ syuḥ iti tatra api aniṣya prasaṅgāt iti arthaḥ
translated: If the liberated ones were equal, then they would have hatred and so on. The meaning is that even there, undesirable consequences would follow.

original: sāmye kathaṃ dveṣādiprasaṅga ityata paraprasaṅgavatsāmyasyāpi dveṣādisāhacaryaṃ dṛṣṭamityāha tapyamānā iti //
analyzed: sāmye katham dveṣa ādi prasaṅgaḥ iti ata para prasaṅga vat sāmyasya api dveṣa ādi sāhacaryam dṛṣṭam iti āha tapyamānāḥ iti
translated: How can hatred and so on arise if there is equality? Therefore, like the undesirable consequences of others, equality is also seen to be concomitant with hatred and so on. He says this with Those who are suffering...

analyzed: tapyamānāḥ samān dṛṣṭvā dveṣa īrṣyā ādi yutāḥ api
translated: Even those who are endowed with hatred, envy, and so on are seen to be suffering when they see equals.

original: dṛśyante bahavo loke doṣā evātra kāraṇam // / /f //
analyzed: dṛśyante bahavaḥ loke doṣāḥ eva atra kāraṇam
translated: Many faults are seen in the world, and that alone is the cause here.
Mere equality of existence is not intended to be the reason for the undesirable consequence.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Because of over-extension.

original: kintu samadarśanamevetyāśayenoktam samāndṛṣṭveti //🔽pratibandīgrahaṇasya prayojanamāha doṣā iti //
analyzed: kintu sama darśanam eva iti āśayena uktam samān dṛṣṭvā iti  pratibandī grahaṇasya prayojanam āha doṣāḥ iti
translated: But only equal vision is intended. With this in mind, it is said when seeing equals...🔽The purpose of the counter-argument is stated with faults...

analyzed: doṣāṇām samuditānām eva kāraṇa tvam iti ekavacanam
translated: The singular is used because the collection of faults alone is the cause.

analyzed: evam asmābhiḥ sāmya vādinam prati atiprasaṅge bhihite tena etat eva vaktavyam
translated: Thus, when an absurd consequence is stated against the one who asserts equality with us, he should say this:

original: atra loke doṣā eva dveṣādeḥ kāraṇam /
analyzed: atra loke doṣāḥ eva dveṣa ādeḥ kāraṇam
translated: In this world, faults alone are the cause of hatred etc.

analyzed: anvaya vyatirekābhyām tad niścayāt
translated: Because that is ascertained by positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: na tu sāmyam  sati api sāmye sakhiṣu abhāvāt
translated: But not equality.🔽Even when there is equality, because there is no [hatred etc.] towards friends.

analyzed: asati api kvacid bhāvāt
translated: And because there is [hatred etc.] even when there is no [equality].

original: naca mukteṣu doṣāssanti /🔽ataḥ sāmye 'pi na dvai
analyzed: na ca mukteṣu doṣāḥ santi  a taḥ sāmye pi na dvai
translated: And faults do not exist in the liberated ones.

analyzed: doṣa ādi prasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, even in equality, there is no hatred etc. towards them.

analyzed: atas kim iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: So what? To this he says 'if' etc.

analyzed: yadi nirdoṣa tā tatra kim ādhikyena dūṣyate
translated: If faultlessness is accepted there, what is spoiled by superiority?

analyzed: yadi evam doṣāṇām eva dveṣa ādi kāraṇa tvam
translated: If so, faults alone are the cause of hatred etc.

analyzed: tatra mukteṣu
translated: There, in the liberated ones.

analyzed: ca aṅgīkṛtā
translated: And faultlessness is accepted.

analyzed: tadā ādhikyena hīna adhika bhāvena aṅgīkṛtena
translated: Then, by what is accepted as superior or inferior,

original: kiṃ dūṣyate na kimapi /🔽sāmyamaṅgīkurvāṇenāpi nirdeṣatayaiva dveṣādiprasaṅgo vāraṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: kim dūṣyate na kim api  sāmyam aṅgīkurvāṇena api nirdeṣatayā eva dveṣa ādi prasaṅgaḥ vāraṇīyaḥ
translated: what is spoiled? Nothing at all.🔽Even one who accepts equality must ward off the consequence of hatred etc. due to faultlessness alone.

analyzed: tāratamyam aṅgīkurvāṇaiḥ asmābhiḥ api tathā eva nirākariṣyate
translated: We who accept gradation will also refute it in the same way.

analyzed: iyān tu viśeṣaḥ
translated: This is the difference:

analyzed: yat tāratamyam pramitam na sāmyam iti samudāya arthaḥ
translated: That gradation is known, not equality. This is the overall meaning.

analyzed: śaṅkate yadi iti
translated: He raises an objection:

analyzed: yadi anya darśana abhāvāt īrṣyā ādiḥ vinivāryate
translated: If envy, etc. are prevented due to the absence of seeing others,

original: bhavedetadyadi sāmyena prasaktaṃ dveṣādikaṃ nirdeṣatayā nivārayāmaḥ /
analyzed: bhavet etat yadi sāmyena prasaktam dveṣa ādikam nivārayāmaḥ
translated: this would be so if we were to prevent envy, etc. that arise through equality by faultlessness.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But that is not so.

analyzed: kinnāma sama sattā mātram hi na dveṣa ādi kāraṇam atiprasaṅgāt
translated: For mere equality of existence is not the cause of envy, etc., as that would lead to absurdity.

analyzed: api tarhi sama darśanam
translated: But rather, it is the perception of equality.

original: naca muktaḥ samaṃ muktāntaraṃ paśyatyato na dveṣādīti /
analyzed: na ca muktaḥ samam mukta antaram paśyati atas na dveṣa ādi iti
translated: And the liberated one does not see another liberated one as equal, therefore there is no envy, etc.

original: evaṃ tarhi na tāratamyasattāmātraṃ dveṣādikāraṇaṃ kintu svato 'dhikadarśanameva /
analyzed: evam tarhi na tāratamya sattā mātram dveṣa ādi kāraṇam kintu svatas dhika darśanam eva
translated: If so, then mere existence of gradation is not the cause of envy, etc., but rather the perception of oneself as superior.

analyzed: na ca muktaḥ svatas dhikam mukta antaram paśyati
translated: And the liberated one does not see another liberated one as superior to oneself.

original: tasmātsatyapi tāratamye na dveṣādiprasaṅga iti kuto na santoṣyavyamiti parihāro 'tra śakyate vaktum /
analyzed: tasmāt sati api tāratamye na dveṣa ādi prasaṅgaḥ iti kutas na santoṣyavyam iti śakyate vaktum
translated: Therefore, even when there is gradation, there is no possibility of envy, etc. How then can it not be accepted? This answer can be said here.

original: tathāpi nāsau tāttvika ityanyadarśanābhāvameva dūṣayati adarśanāditi //
analyzed: tathā api na asau tāttvikaḥ iti anya darśana abhāvam eva dūṣayati adarśanāt iti
translated: Nevertheless, that is not real. Therefore, he criticizes only the absence of seeing others, saying due to non-seeing.

analyzed: adarśanāt arati ādiḥ katham tena nivāryate
translated: How is love, etc. prevented by that due to non-seeing?

original: evamanyadarśanābhāvena dveṣādikaṃ nivārayatā tenādarśanātprasaktamaratyādikaṃ kathaṃ nivāryate /
analyzed: evam anya darśana abhāvena dveṣa ādikam nivārayatā tena adarśanāt prasaktam arati ādikam katham nivāryate
translated: In the same way, by one who has warded off hatred, etc. by the absence of seeing another, how is the desire, etc. which are implied by that absence of seeing warded off?

analyzed: aratiḥ sukha abhāvaḥ
translated: Discontent is the absence of happiness.

analyzed: ādi padena tandrī bhayam ca gṛhyate
translated: By the word etc. laziness and fear are included.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

analyzed: syāt ayam parihāraḥ yadi muktasya anya darśana abhāvaḥ sambhavet
translated: This would be an answer if the absence of seeing another were possible for the liberated one.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: muktaḥ hi na tāvat acetanaḥ
translated: For the liberated one is not, to begin with, insentient.

analyzed: apasiddhānta prasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the consequence of contradicting one's own doctrine.

analyzed: tatas cetanasya sataḥ nyadarśana abhāve rati ādikam prasajyate iti
translated: And then, for the sentient one who exists, if there is an absence of seeing another, discontent, etc. would be implied.

original: nanu bahirmukhā evānyadarśanābhāve 'ratyādikaṃ prāpnuvanti naca muktāstathāto nāratyādiprasaṅga ityata āha brahmaṇo 'pīti //
analyzed: nanu bahirmukhāḥ eva anya darśana abhāve rati ādikam prāpnuvanti na ca muktāḥ tathā atas na arati ādi prasaṅgaḥ iti atas āha brahmaṇaḥ pi iti
translated: But surely only those who are turned outward would obtain discontent, etc. in the absence of seeing another, and the liberated ones are not so. Therefore there is no implication of discontent, etc. To this he says Even of Brahman, etc.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ pi aratiḥ dṛṣṭvā pūrvam ekākinaḥ śrutau
translated: Even of Brahman, discontent is seen in the Veda, previously, when alone.

analyzed: jñānam apratigham yasya vairāgyam ca jagatpateḥ
translated: He whose knowledge is unobstructed, whose detachment is that of the Lord of the world,

analyzed: aiśvaryam ca eva dharmaḥ ca sahasiddham catuṣyayam
translated: whose sovereignty and righteousness are spontaneously accomplished, these four are his.

analyzed: iti evam pramitasya api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: of one who is thus known.

analyzed: pūrvam ādi kāle
translated: Previously, in the beginning.

analyzed: śrutau iti jātau ekavacanam
translated: The singular number in 'śruti' is used for the plural.

analyzed: tāḥ śrutīḥ arthataḥ paṭhati na eva iti
translated: He quotes the meaning of those śrutis, saying 'not at all' etc.

original: naiva reme sa caikākī tasamānna ramate kvacit /
analyzed: nā eva reme sa ca ekākī ramate kvacid
translated: He did not enjoy at all, being alone. He does not enjoy anywhere without a companion.

analyzed: dvitīyam aicchat tena asau iti śrutayaḥ ūdire
translated: He desired a second. Therefore the śrutis declare thus.

original: anena sa vai naiva reme tasmādekākī na ramate sa dvitīyamaicchaditi vākyamupādatte /
analyzed: anena sa vai nā eva reme tasmāt ekākī na ramate sa dvitīyam aicchat iti vākyam upādatte
translated: By this, he accepts the sentence 'He did not enjoy at all. Therefore, being alone, he does not enjoy. He desired a second.'

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: yadi anya darśana abhāva mātram arati ādeḥ kāraṇam syāt
translated: If the mere absence of seeing another were the cause of non-enjoyment etc.,

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: and it is not so.

analyzed: kintu anya darśana icchāyām tad abhāvaḥ
translated: But in the desire to see another, there is the absence of that.

original: muktasya tvicchaiva nāstyato 'nyadarśanābhāve 'pi nāratyādikaṃ prasajyata ityāśaṅkayāha yadīti //
analyzed: muktasya tu icchā eva nā asti atas nyadarśana abhāve nārati ādikam prasajyate iti āśaṅkayā āha yadi iti
translated: But for the liberated one, there is no desire at all. Therefore, even in the absence of seeing another, non-enjoyment etc. do not follow. Fearing this, he says 'if' etc.

original: yadīcchā tatra naivāstītyeva tat kalpyate mṛṣā /
analyzed: yadi icchā tatra na evā asti iti eva tat kalpyate mṛṣā
translated: If it is merely imagined that there is no desire there,

analyzed: śruti ukta nirdoṣa tā eva kim nā aṅgīkriyate svayam
translated: why is the faultlessness stated in the śruti not accepted by oneself?

analyzed: tat tatra muktau
translated: That, there, in liberation.

analyzed: tatra anya darśana viṣaye
translated: There, in the object of seeing another.

original: icchā naivāstīti mṛṣaiva kalpya teyadīti yojanā /
analyzed: icchā nā evā asti iti mṛṣā eva kalpya teyadi iti yojanā
translated: If it is imagined that there is no desire at all, it is false. This is the construction of 'if'.

analyzed: bhidyate hṛdaya granthiḥ ityādi śruti uktā
translated: It is stated in the śruti beginning with 'the knot of the heart is cut' etc.

analyzed: svayam sākṣāt śati uktā iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: because it is said by the truthful one himself.

analyzed: tarhi iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: then.

analyzed: tad śabdaḥ vā tarhi arthaḥ
translated: Or the word tat has the meaning of then.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

original: muktānāṃ sāmyamaṅgīkṛtyānyadarśanābhāvena dveṣādiparihṛtyānyadarśanecchābhāvena cāratyādikaṃ pariharato 'prāmāṇikānekakalpanaṃ prāmāṇikaparityāgaśca 🔽syātām / /
analyzed: muktānām sāmyam aṅgīkṛtya anya darśana abhāvena dveṣa ādi parihṛtya anya darśana icchā bhāvena cāra ti ādikam pariharato prāmāṇika aneka kalpanam prāmāṇika parityāgaḥ ca  syātām
translated: Accepting the equality of the liberated ones, by the absence of seeing others, and by the absence of the desire to see others, avoiding attachment and so on, there would be the postulation of many unauthoritative things and the abandonment of the authoritative.

analyzed: sāmānya darśana abhāvena abhāvavat tad icchā bhāvānām aprāmāṇika tvāt
translated: Because the absence of seeing in general, the absence of having, and the absence of desire are unauthoritative.

analyzed: tāratamya ādeḥ prāmāṇika tvāt
translated: Because the gradation and so on are authoritative.

original: tato varaṃ tāratamyamaṅgīkṛtya dveṣādinirāsāya śrautanirdeṣatāsvīkāra iti /
analyzed: tatas varam tāratamyam aṅgīkṛtya dveṣa ādi nirāsāya śrauta nirdeṣa tā svīkāraḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is better to accept the gradation and accept the faultlessness taught in the scriptures in order to remove hatred and so on.

original: etena tāratamyaṃ sāmyaṃ vāṅgīkṛtya nirdeṣatvena dveṣādisamādhānaṃ vidhātavyamiti sandeho 'pi nirasto veditavyaḥ /🔽uktameva spaṣṭamāha tāratamyaṃ ceti //
analyzed: etena tāratamyam sāmyam vā aṅgīkṛtya nirdeṣa tvena dveṣa ādi samādhānam vidhātavyam iti sandehaḥ pi nirastaḥ veditavyaḥ  uktam eva spaṣṭam āha tāratamyam ca iti
translated: By this, the doubt that the solution of hatred and so on should be accomplished by accepting gradation or equality as faultless should be understood to be removed.

original: tāratamyaṃ ca kāmaṃ ca śrutamevātihāya tu /
analyzed: tāratamyam ca kāmam ca śrutam eva atihāya tu
translated: He states what has been said clearly: And gradation, and desire, having rejected only what is taught,

analyzed: aśrutā samatā kena kalpyate yukti māninā
translated: by whom is equality, which is not taught, imagined to be reasonable?

analyzed: anya darśanam ca iti api grāhyam
translated: And seeing others should also be taken.

analyzed: sa yaḥ manuṣyāṇām rāddhaḥ
translated: That which is accomplished for humans,

analyzed: kāmasya yatra āptāḥ kāmāḥ
translated: where desires are fulfilled,

analyzed: akṣaṇvantaḥ karṇavantaḥ sakhāyaḥ
translated: friends without envy or jealousy.

analyzed: ityādyau śrutam
translated: This and other such statements have been heard.

analyzed: na hi anya darśana abhāve sakhyam sambhavati
translated: For friendship is not possible in the absence of seeing others.

analyzed: samatā iti anya darśana abhāva icchā bhāvayoḥ api upalakṣaṇam
translated: Equality is a metaphor for the absence of desire to see others and the absence of desire.

analyzed: yuktim manyate iti yukta mānī
translated: He thinks it reasonable means he is conceited about what is reasonable.

original: yuktau bahumānavatā kenāpyevaṃ na kalpyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yuktau bahu mānavatā kena api evam na kalpyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that no one conceives it thus with great respect for what is reasonable.
For reasoning, which is another name for logic, is the consequence of abandoning what is authoritative and accepting what is not authoritative.

analyzed: nanu sama tāyāḥ aśruta tve pi nā aprāmāṇika tvam
translated: But even if equality is not heard, it is not unauthoritative.

original: nahi śrutireva pramāṇamityata āha kiṃ taditi //
analyzed: nahi śrutiḥ eva pramāṇam iti atas āha kim tat iti
translated: For it is not that the Veda alone is authoritative. To this he says: What is that?

analyzed: kim tat mānam samatve te muktānām upalabhyate
translated: What is that authority that is perceived in the equality of the liberated ones?

analyzed: na kiñcid tad śateḥ anyat
translated: There is nothing else but that.

analyzed: atas pramāṇa antara abhāve śruta tvena aprāmāṇika tvam eva siddhayati
translated: Therefore, in the absence of another means of knowledge, it is established that it is unauthoritative due to not being heard.

analyzed: yadi anya darśana abhāvāt ityādinā uktam upasaṃharati vṛthā iti
translated: If he summarizes what was said beginning with due to the absence of seeing others, he says: In vain.

analyzed: vṛthā ayam āgrahaḥ kena śruta hāni aśruta grahe
translated: This vain grasping is by whom, in abandoning what is heard and grasping what is not heard?

analyzed: kena na kena api kāraṇena
translated: By no means whatsoever.

analyzed: śruta hāni aśruta grahe iti dvandva eka vat bhāvaḥ
translated: The compound śruta-hāni-aśruta-graha is a dvandva with the singular ending.

analyzed: śruta hāni sahitaḥ śruta grahaḥ iti vā
translated: Or the grasping of what was not heard along with the loss of what was heard.

analyzed: viṣaya saptamīyam
translated: The locative case refers to the object.

analyzed: tatas na kāryaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it should not be done for that reason.

analyzed: muktānām tāratamye numāna antaram āha mokṣe
translated: He states another inference regarding the gradation of the liberated souls:

analyzed: mokṣe tāratamya itas cetana tvāt purā yathā
translated: Even in liberation, there is gradation, because of being conscious, as before.

analyzed: tāratamyena itas prāptaḥ tāratamyavān iti yāvat
translated: He has attained gradation, i.e., he possesses gradation.

analyzed: purā saṃsāre
translated: Before, in worldly existence.

original: nanvatra saṃsāre vartamānaṃ kamapi pakṣīkṛtyāyaṃ tāratamyeta iti sādhyate tatra ca mokṣe 'pīti siddhasādhanatāparihārāya viśeṣaṇamupādīyata
analyzed: nanu atra saṃsāre vartamānam kam api pakṣīkṛtya ayam tāratamyeta iti sādhyate tatra ca mokṣe pi iti siddha sādhana tā parihārāya viśeṣaṇam upādīyata
translated: But here, taking someone existing in this worldly existence as the subject, it is being proven that he has gradation. In that, in order to avoid the fallacy of proving what is already established by saying even in liberation, a qualification is used.

original: iti vā /🔽mokṣe 'pītyanena muktaṃ pakṣīkṛtya tāratamyeta iti vā /
analyzed: iti vā  mokṣe pi iti anena muktam pakṣīkṛtya tāratamyeta iti vā
translated: Or thus.🔽By saying even in liberation, taking the liberated one as the subject, it is said that he has gradation.

analyzed: muktam pakṣīkṛtya tāratamyetaḥ iti sādhyate
translated: It is being proven that taking the liberated one as the subject, he has gradation.

original: tatra prācīnena tāratamyena siddhasādhanatāparihārāya mokṣe 'pīti viśeṣaṇamupādīyata iti vā /
analyzed: tatra prācīnena tāratamyena siddha sādhana tā parihārāya mokṣe pi iti viśeṣaṇam upādīyate iti vā
translated: In that, in order to avoid the fallacy of proving what is already established by the earlier gradation, the qualification even in liberation is used.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: tasya nitya saṃsāri tvasya api sambhavena bādhā āpatteḥ
translated: Because there would be the fault of contradiction, even if it were possible for him to be eternally transmigrating.

analyzed: niścita mokṣa puruṣa viśeṣa pakṣīkāre pi dṛṣṭāntasya sādhya vikala tvāt
translated: Even if one accepts the position of a particular person who is certainly liberated, the example is deficient in the probandum.

analyzed: nahi saṃsārī mukti gata tāratamya upetaḥ
translated: For a transmigrator is not endowed with the gradation of liberation.

analyzed: dvitīye api pada vaiyarthyam
translated: In the second [alternative], the word also is meaningless.

analyzed: prāktana tāratamya upeta tvena siddha sādhana tā ca
translated: And there is the fault of proving what is already established, because [the person] is endowed with the gradation of the previous [state].

analyzed: tṛtīye pi dṛṣṭāntasya sādhya vikala tā eva
translated: In the third [alternative] also, the example is deficient in the probandum.

analyzed: tāratamya upeta tvam ca hīna adhika sadbhāvaḥ vā anyatara sadbhāvaḥ vā
translated: And being endowed with gradation means either the existence of inferiority and superiority, or the existence of one or the other.

analyzed: ādye parameśvare na aikāntyam  dvitīye siddha sādhana tā
translated: In the first [case], there is non-applicability to the Supreme Lord.🔽In the second [case], there is the fault of proving what is already established.

analyzed: muktānām api amuktebhyaḥ dhika tvasya pareṇa aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because the opponent accepts that the liberated ones are superior to the non-liberated ones.

analyzed: mukta adhika tva sādhane devadatte vyabhicāraḥ tat katham etat
translated: If [the opponent argues that] the liberated ones are superior to the non-liberated ones, then there is inconstancy in Devadatta. How is this?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: muktāḥ tadānīntanena parasparam tāratamyena upetāḥ cetana tvāt saṃsāriṇaḥ yathā iti ayam arthaḥ vivakṣitaḥ
translated: The meaning intended here is that the liberated ones are endowed with gradation in relation to each other at that time, because they are conscious, like transmigrators.

analyzed: tāratamyam ca kutaścid hīna tvam kutaścid adhika tvam iti etayoḥ anyatarat iti na ukta doṣaḥ
translated: And gradation means either being inferior to something or being superior to something. It is not stated that either of these two [is meant].

analyzed: sāmānyasya ca viśeṣa nirāsena apākaraṇe ca atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: And if the general is refuted by the exclusion of the particular, there is over-extension.

original: yadvā maktyuttarakṣaṇavartī muktaḥ prāg yato 'dhikatvahīnatvābhyāmupetasvarūpo 'bhūdidānīmapi tābhyāmupeta iti pratijñārtho vaṇarnīyaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā makti uttara kṣaṇa vartī muktaḥ prāk yatas dhikatva hīnatvābhyām upeta svarūpaḥ bhūt idānīm api tābhyām upetaḥ iti pratijñā arthaḥ vaṇarnīyaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning of the proposition should be stated thus: The liberated one who existed in the subsequent moment of liberation, who previously had a nature endowed with superiority and inferiority, is now also endowed with those.

analyzed: sāmānyatas eva vyāptiḥ abhidhātavyā iti
translated: The pervasion should be stated only in general terms.

analyzed: ābhāsān uddharati iti uktaḥ iti
translated: He quotes the refutation of the appearances.

analyzed: iti ukte uttaram kim te
translated: What is your reply to what has been said?

analyzed: ukte pratyukte
translated: When it has been stated and answered.

original: vyāptipakṣadharmatvayoḥ pramitatvānna kimapyuttaramastīti bhāvaḥ /🔽bādhitaviṣayamanumānamityata āha kalpaneti //🔽kalpanāmātravādinaḥ // / / //
analyzed: vyāpti pakṣa dharma tvayoḥ pramita tvāt na kim api uttaram asti iti bhāvaḥ  bādhita viṣayam anumānam iti atas āha kalpanā iti  kalpanā mātra vādinaḥ
translated: The meaning is that since the pervasion and the property of the subject are known, there is no reply at all.🔽Inference has an invalidated subject. Therefore he says supposition, etc.🔽Of the one who speaks only of supposition.

analyzed: kalpanā mātreṇa vadati iti tathā uktaḥ
translated: He is said to speak only of supposition.

analyzed: pūrveṇa eva sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with the previous [verse].

original: śrutīnāmanyārthatvātpramāṇāntarasya cābhāvātsvotprekṣayaiva muktānāṃ tāratamyābhāvaṃ vadatastavottaraṃ kimiti /
analyzed: śrutīnām anya artha tvāt pramāṇa antarasya ca abhāvāt sva utprekṣayā eva muktānām tāratamya abhāvam vadataḥ tava uttaram kim iti
translated: Since the Vedic statements have another meaning and there is no other means of knowledge, your reply is what, of one who speaks of the absence of gradation among the liberated ones only by his own imagination?

analyzed: yadi evam anumīyeta tadā muktāḥ duḥkha ādi upetāḥ cetana tvāt saṃsāri vat iti api anumīyeta iti atiprasaṅga parāhatam anumānam iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: If it were to be inferred in this way, then it would follow that the liberated souls are endowed with suffering etc., because they are conscious beings, like those in saṃsāra. Thus, the inference is refuted by the fallacy of over-extension. To this, he says: And suffering etc. are not to be inferred...

analyzed: na ca duḥkha ādikam kalpyam
translated: Suffering etc. are not to be inferred...

analyzed: kalpyam anumeyam muktasya  ādi padena aparipūrṇa ānanda tva ādeḥ saṅgrahaḥ
translated: ...by the liberated soul.🔽The word etc. includes incomplete bliss and so on.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha nirduḥkha tva iti
translated: Why? To this he says: Because of the authoritative declaration of the absence of suffering...

analyzed: nirduḥkha tva śruteḥ balāt
translated: ...by the authoritative declaration of the absence of suffering.

analyzed: atra api ādi padam grāhyam
translated: Here too, the word etc. should be supplied.

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intended meaning.

analyzed: samāna yogakṣema tva abhiprāyeṇa khalu ayam atiprasaṅgaḥ vācyaḥ na anyathā vyāpti abhāvāt
translated: The over-extension should be stated with the intention of equal association and safety, not otherwise, because there is no pervasion.

analyzed: na ca prakṛte tat asti
translated: And that is not so in the present case.

analyzed: duḥkha ādi sādhakasya nirduḥkha tva ādikam pratipādayantyā śrutyā bādhita tvāt
translated: Because the authoritative declaration, which teaches the absence of suffering etc. against the proof of suffering etc., is contradicted.

analyzed: śruteḥ apauruṣeya tvena dharmi grāhaka tvena ca anumānataḥ balavat tvāt
translated: Because the authoritative declaration, being non-human, is stronger than inference, which grasps the subject.

analyzed: tāratamya anumānasya ca abādhita tvāt iti
translated: And because the inference of gradation is unobstructed.

original: etadeva vivṛṇvanmuktasya nirduḥkhatvādi pratipādayantīḥ śrutīstāvatpaṭhitvā tāsāṃ tātparyamāha śokamiti / /
analyzed: etat eva vivṛṇvan muktasya nirduḥkha tva ādi pratipādayantīḥ śrutīḥ tāvat paṭhitvā tāsām tātparyam āha śokam iti
translated: Expounding this very thing, he first quotes the Vedic texts which teach that the liberated one is free from sorrow etc., and then states their purport in the words 'śokaṃ tarati' etc.

analyzed: śokam tarati ātma vettā tīrṇaḥ sarvān aduḥkha bhāj
translated: The knower of the Self crosses over sorrow, having crossed over all, he becomes free from sorrow...

analyzed: yena ānandyā iva bhavati na śocati kadācana
translated: By which one becomes full of bliss and never grieves at all.

analyzed: kilbiṣa spṛt pitu ṣaṇiḥ aram hitaḥ iha īśvaraḥ
translated: The remover of sin, the purifier of the father, the controller here, the Lord...

original: yaṃ yamantamabhiprepsuḥ sa saṅkalpād bhavediha /🔽ityādiśrutayo mānaṃ nirduḥkhatvādisampadi // / / //
analyzed: yam yam antam abhiprepsuḥ sa saṅkalpāt bhavet iha  ityādi śrutayaḥ mānam nirduḥkha tva ādi sampadi
translated: Whatever end one desires, he becomes by mere resolve here.🔽Such are the Vedic texts which are the means of valid knowledge regarding the possession of freedom from sorrow etc.

analyzed: anena tarati śokam ātma vid iti śrutim upādatte
translated: By this, he refers to the Vedic text 'tarati śokaṃ, ātmā vidyayā' (Tait. Up. 2.9.1).

analyzed: vettā veditā
translated: 'Vetta' means the knower.

analyzed: vicāraṇā arthasya vindateḥ vā rūpam etat
translated: This is the form of the root 'vindati' in the sense of 'to consider'.

original: tīrṇaḥ sarvānityanena tīrṇo hi tadā sarvāñchokāniti /
analyzed: tīrṇaḥ sarvān iti anena tīrṇaḥ hi tadā sarvān śokān iti
translated: By 'tīrṇaḥ sarvān' (Tait. Up. 2.9.1), he refers to 'tīrṇaḥ hi tadā sarvān śokān' (Tait. Up. 2.9.1).

analyzed: aduḥkha bhāj iti anena na an ānandam kañcid upaspṛśati iti
translated: By 'adukhabhāg' (Tait. Up. 2.9.1), he refers to 'nāna nandam kañcid upaspṛśati' (Tait. Up. 2.9.1).

original: yenetyanena tadvai jaivaṃ mano yenānandyeva bhavatītyatho na śocatīti /
analyzed: yena iti anena tat vai jaivam manaḥ yena ānandyā iva bhavati iti atha u na śocati iti
translated: By 'yena' (Tait. Up. 2.9.1), he refers to 'tad vai jaivam manaḥ yena anandyevābhūvaṃ na veda na jāne śokaṃ mama' (Tait. Up. 2.9.1).

analyzed: evaśabdena śoka abhāve labdhe yat punar na śocati
translated: By the word 'eva' (Tait. Up. 2.9.1), even though the absence of sorrow is understood, he again says 'na veda na jāne śokaṃ mama' (Tait. Up. 2.9.1).

analyzed: iti uktam tasya abhiprāyaḥ kadācana iti
translated: Thus, the meaning of this is stated.

original: kilpiṣaspṛdityanena sarve nandanti yaśasā'gatena sabhāsāhena sakhyā sakhāyaḥ /
analyzed: kilpiṣa spṛt iti anena sarve nandanti yaśasā āgatena sabhāsāhena sakhyā sakhāyaḥ
translated: By this, All friends rejoice in the one who has come with fame, who conquers the assembly, with the friend who conquers the assembly.

analyzed: kilbiṣa spṛt pituṣaṇiḥ hi eṣā amaram hitaḥ bhavati vājināya iti
translated: With this mantra,

original: parasparaṃ sakhāyaḥ sarve muktā āgatena svāgatena yaśasā yaśasvatā
analyzed: parasparam sakhāyaḥ sarve muktāḥ āgatena svāgatena yaśasā yaśasvatā
translated: mutually, all friends rejoice in the one who has come, in the one who has been welcomed, with fame, with the famous one,

analyzed: śasvinā
translated: with the prosperous one,

original: yaśovatā sabhāṃ sahata iti sabhāsahaḥ karmaṇyaṇ /
analyzed: yaśovatā sabhām sahate iti sabhāsahaḥ karmaṇi aṇ
translated: with the one who possesses fame, who conquers the assembly. The suffix 'aṇ' is used in the case of an action.

analyzed: tena sakhyā parameśvareṇa nimittena nandanti
translated: With that friend, the supreme Lord, as the cause, they rejoice.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: hi yasmāt īśvaraḥ eṣām muktānām kilbiṣa spṛt
translated: For, indeed, this Lord is the remover of the guilt of those who are liberated.

analyzed: duḥkham na sahate
translated: He does not tolerate suffering.

analyzed: spardhateḥ arthe spardhā iti dhātu antaram tatas kvip
translated: The root 'spardhate' has a different meaning, from which the suffix 'kvip' is used.

analyzed: pituṣaṇiḥ annasya dātā
translated: The giver of food is 'pitusani'.

analyzed: annam vai pituḥ iti śruteḥ
translated: Because of the Vedic text 'food is indeed the father',

analyzed: ṣaṇu dāne
translated: 'san' means giving.

analyzed: asmāt ikāra pratyayaḥ
translated: The suffix 'ikā' is added.

analyzed: aram alam mati artham  vājināya indriyāya hitaḥ bhavati
translated: 'Aram' means 'alam' (sufficient).🔽He becomes beneficial for the sake of the senses, for the sake of strength.

analyzed: indriyam vai vājinam iti śruteḥ
translated: Because of the Vedic text 'strength is indeed the sense',

analyzed: iha mukta viṣaye
translated: here, in the case of the liberated ones.

original: yaṃ yamityanena yaṃ yamantamabhikāmo bhavati so 'sya saṅkalpādeva bhavatīti /
analyzed: yam yam iti anena yam yam antam abhikāmaḥ bhavati saḥ sya saṅkalpāt eva bhavati iti
translated: By the words 'whatever' it is said that whatever object one desires, that comes to him by mere will.

analyzed: antam sthānam
translated: 'Antam' means a place.

analyzed: iha muktau
translated: 'Here' means in liberation.

analyzed: nirduḥkha tva ādi sampadi muktānām
translated: In the perfection of being free from suffering etc. of the liberated ones.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha atas iti
translated: What then? To this he says 'ataḥ' (therefore).

analyzed: atas duḥkha ādi anumayā labhyate
translated: Therefore, due to the inference of suffering etc., no scope is found here.

analyzed: śruti bādhita tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is because it is contradicted by the scriptures.

analyzed: atra mukteṣu
translated: Here, in the liberated ones.

original: muktā duḥkhādyupetā iti pratijñāyāḥ svavyāhatatvāccetyapi draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: muktāḥ duḥkha ādi upetāḥ iti pratijñāyāḥ sva vyāhata tvāt ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should also be seen that the proposition that the liberated ones are endowed with suffering etc. is self-contradictory.

original: tato 'pi kimityata āha tāratamyeti //🔽tāratamyānumā tena bhavennātiprasaṅginī // / / //
analyzed: tatas pi kim iti atas āha tāratamya iti  tāratamya anumā tena bhavet na ati prasaṅginī
translated: What then from that? To this he says 'tāratamyānumā' (the inference of gradation).🔽Therefore, the inference of gradation would not be subject to the fallacy of over-extension.

analyzed: tasmāt bādhā abhāvena samāna yogakṣema tva abhāvāt  mukta tāratamya sādhanam upasaṃharati śruti iti
translated: Therefore, because there is no contradiction, there is no equality of strength.🔽He concludes the proof of gradation in liberation with the word 'śruti' (scripture).

analyzed: śruti yukti balāt evam tāratamyam vibhāvyate
translated: Thus, gradation is perceived even in liberation by the power of scripture and reasoning.

analyzed: muktau api tatas ke tra virodham kartum īśate
translated: Then, who here is able to create contradiction?

analyzed: vibhāvyate samyak anubhūyate
translated: 'Vibhāvyate' means is rightly experienced.

analyzed: ke vādinaḥ na ke api  atra mukta tāratamya viṣaye
translated: 'Ke'pi' means no one.🔽'Atra' means in the matter of gradation in liberation.

analyzed: iti kāmacāra adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on optional conduct.
III. The section on the topic of both genders.

analyzed: atha ubhaya liṅga ādhikārika adhikaraṇe
translated: Now, in the section on the topic of both genders.

original: oṃ sarvathāpi tu ta evobhayaliṅgāt oṃ //
analyzed: om sarvathā api tu te eva ubhaya liṅgāt om
translated: Om. But they alone in every way, because of the indication of both.

analyzed: om na ca ādhikārikam api patana anumānāt tad ayogāt om
translated: Om. And not even by topic, because of the inference of falling, that is not proper.

analyzed: atra prathama adhikaraṇe na ādi jñāna yogyatāvatām eva jñāna prāptiḥ na anyeṣām iti uktam
translated: Here, in the first section, it is said that the attainment of knowledge is only for those who have the capacity for knowledge from beginningless time, not for others.

analyzed: dvitīye ca devatā ādi pada prāptiḥ anādi tad yogyatā upetānām eva na itareṣām iti abhihitam
translated: And in the second, it is stated that the attainment of the status of deities and so on is only for those who have beginningless capacity for that, not for others.

original: seyaṃ jīvānāṃ nānāvidhānādiyogyatā prasiddhaistaistaiḥ kāraṇairutkarṣāparkaprāptirbhavatīti vadadbhirvādibhirnābhyupagamyate 'tastāṃ sādhayitumāha
analyzed: sā iyam jīvānām nānāvidha anādi yogyatā prasiddhaiḥ taiḥ taiḥ kāraṇaiḥ utkarṣa āparka prāptiḥ bhavati iti vadadbhiḥ vādibhiḥ na abhyupagamyate tām sādhayitum āha
translated: This various capacity of the jivas for beginningless knowledge and so on is not accepted by the disputants who say that the attainment of superiority and inferiority occurs through well-known causes. Therefore, to establish that, he says

analyzed: anādi iti
translated: beginningless and so on.

analyzed: sarvathā api te eva ubhaya liṅgāt
translated: But they alone in every way, because of the indication of both.

analyzed: na ca ādhikārikam api patana anumānāt tad ayogāt
translated: And not even by topic, because of the inference of falling, that is not proper.

analyzed: anādi yogyatām ca eva kali vāṇī īśvara avadhim
translated: And who can prevent the beginningless capacity, up to Kali, Vani, and Isvara,

analyzed: kaḥ nivārayitum śaktaḥ yukta yāgama bala uddhatām
translated: which is exalted by reason and scripture?

analyzed: na kevalam muktānām tāratamyam iti ca arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is not only that there is gradation among the liberated, but also that there is gradation among the jivas.

analyzed: anena mukta tāratamyasya api idam sādhakam iti uktam bhavati
translated: This also proves the existence of the difference in the degree of freedom.

analyzed: anādeḥ nitya tvāt
translated: Because it is beginningless and eternal.

analyzed: eva śabdasya kaḥ eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The word eva (only) is connected with ka eva (who is the only one).

analyzed: kali vāṇī īśvara avadhī yasyāḥ sā tathā uktā
translated: That which has Kali and Vani as its limits is said to be so.

analyzed: yogyatā apakarṣa paramparāyāḥ kaliḥ avadhiḥ tad utkarṣa paramparāyāḥ vāṇīśvaraḥ
translated: The limit of the series of decrease in eligibility is Kali, or the limit of the series of increase is Vani.

analyzed: uddhatām a pratihatām
translated: Uddhata means unobstructed.

original: kathaṃ yuktyāgamasiddhetyata āgamānāṃ sāvakāśatvābhimānena yuktāveva bahumānavantaṃ pratyādau tāmāha brahmaṇa iti //
analyzed: katham yukti āgama siddhā iti atas āgamānām sāvakāśa tva abhimānena yuktau eva bahu mānavantam prati ādau tām āha brahmaṇaḥ iti
translated: How is it established by reasoning and scripture? For one who is very respectful to reasoning alone, thinking that the scriptures are ambiguous, he first mentions it as of Brahman.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ nyatra ādhikya yuktaḥ kālaḥ vivādavān
translated: The time that is superior to Brahman is the time of dispute.

analyzed: kālaḥ hi ayam yathā ityādi mānumā māninaḥ bhavet
translated: For this time, one who believes in inference would say as this...

analyzed: vartamāna kāle brahmā sarva adhikaḥ iti sampratipannam
translated: It is commonly accepted that Brahman is superior in the present time.

analyzed: atas vivādavān vivāda viṣayaḥ kālaḥ iti uktam
translated: Therefore, it is said that time is the subject of dispute, the object of dispute.

original: vartamānamahākalpavyatirikto 'tīto 'nāgataśca kāla etasya brahmaṇo yadanyata ādhikyaṃ tena yuktaḥ /
analyzed: vartamāna mahākalpa vyatiriktaḥ tītaḥ nāgataḥ ca kālaḥ etasya brahmaṇaḥ yat anyatas ādhikyam tena yuktaḥ
translated: The past and future time, other than the present great kalpa, is connected with that which is superior to this Brahman.

analyzed: kālaḥ hi iti kāla tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: For this time means because it is time.

analyzed: ayam vartamānaḥ kālaḥ yathā
translated: This is the present time, as it is.

analyzed: ādi padena ayam brahma atīta ādi kāle pi anyatas dhikaḥ brahma tvāt tad kāla varti brahma vat ityādeḥ saṅgrahaḥ
translated: By the word ādi (beginning), it includes the argument that even in the past time before Brahmā, he is superior to others because he is Brahman, like the Brahman who existed at that time.

analyzed: anumā māninaḥ bahu mānavataḥ bodhāya prayoktavyā bhavet
translated: It should be employed for the sake of understanding by those who have great respect for inference, who are proud of inference.

analyzed: anumā māninaḥ pratītim vā
translated: Or for the understanding of those who are proud of inference.

analyzed: brahma gatena ādhikyena kālasya sambandha abhāvāt katham anumānam iti ced na
translated: If it is asked how there can be inference in the absence of a relation between time and the superiority belonging to Brahman, it is not so.

analyzed: paramparā sambandhena anumāna prāmāṇya vādibhiḥ ayam kālaḥ veda vyatirikta idānīntana tva rahita pauruṣeyavān ityādi anumāna apravṛtteḥ aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because those who maintain the validity of inference through a mediate relation have accepted that this inference, This time possesses human authorship devoid of the presentness of non-Vedic origin, and so on, does not operate.

analyzed: tat idam uktam anumā māninaḥ iti
translated: This is what is meant by saying for those who are proud of inference.

original: brahmaṇa padādyabhāvakāle 'pi sarvotkarṣasiddhau yogyataiva sarvotkṛṣṭānādinityā siddhā bhavati / /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ pada ādi abhāva kāle sarva utkarṣa siddhau yogyatā eva sarva utkṛṣṭa anādi nityā siddhā bhavati
translated: Even when there is no word Brahman etc., the very fitness for the establishment of superiority over all becomes established as the eternally beginningless.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said.

analyzed: pramāṇa bādhitā iyam pratijñā
translated: This proposition is contradicted by valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntaḥ ca sādhya vikalaḥ
translated: And the example is devoid of the probandum.

analyzed: anya śabdaḥ hi ayam prakaraṇāt brahma vyatiriktam sarvam āha
translated: For this word anyat (other) mentions everything except Brahman due to the context.

original: tatra harermahālakṣmyā ṛjubhyaścādhikyaṃ brahmaṇaḥ kālatraye 'pi nāsti /
analyzed: tatra hareḥ mahālakṣmyāḥ ṛjubhyaḥ ca ādhikyam brahmaṇaḥ kāla traye na asti
translated: There, Hari and Mahālakṣmī are superior to the straightforward ones, but Brahmā is not superior to them at any time.

original: hareḥśriyaścādhikatvena ṛjūnāṃ samatvena pramitatvādityata āha anyaśabda iti //
analyzed: hareḥ śriyaḥ ca adhika tvena ṛjūnām sama tvena pramita tvāt iti atas āha anya śabdaḥ iti
translated: Because it is established that Hari and Śrī are superior and the straightforward ones are equal. Therefore it is said: The word 'any'...

analyzed: anya śabdaḥ hari śrī sva samebhyaḥ
translated: The word 'any' is used to denote something other than Hari, Śrī, and those equal to oneself.

analyzed: prayuktaḥ na eva doṣāya
translated: It does not cause any fault.

analyzed: sva śabdena brahma ucyate
translated: Brahmā is referred to by the word 'self'.

analyzed: sa ca āvartanīyaḥ
translated: And that should be repeated.

analyzed: svaḥ ca sva samāḥ ca iti
translated: 'Self' and 'those equal to self'.

original: yadā vaktā svavivakṣāṃ svayameva vyākhyāti kātra prakaraṇādyapekṣā /
analyzed: yadā vaktā sva vivakṣām svayam eva vyākhyāti kā atra prakaraṇa ādi apekṣā
translated: When the speaker himself explains his own intention, what need is there for context and other factors here?

analyzed: tad abhāve tasya upayogāt
translated: Because they are useful in its absence.

analyzed: kathāyām tu vyaktam eva vaktavyam
translated: But in a story, it must be clearly stated.

analyzed: anyathā pratijñā antara ādīnām api evam parihāra prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, even the other promises and so on would be subject to the same solution.

original: naiva doṣāya bādhādiheturnaiva bhavati / /🔽uktanyāyamanyatrāpyatidiśati rudrādiṣu ceti //🔽rudrādiṣu ca yuktitaḥ // / / //
analyzed: na eva doṣāya bādhā ādi hetuḥ na eva bhavati  ukta nyāyam anyatra api atidiśati rudra ādiṣu ca iti  rudra ādiṣu ca yuktitaḥ
translated: It does not cause any fault, as there is no reason for contradiction and so on.🔽He extends the stated reasoning to other cases as well, saying and in Rudra and others...🔽And in Rudra and others, it is proper...

original: anayaiva rītyā rudrādiṣvapi sānādiyogyatā yuktyā sādhanīyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: anayā eva rītyā rudra ādiṣu api sā anādi yogyatā yuktyā sādhanīyā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the same way, the primordial eligibility in Rudra and others should be established through reasoning.

original: vimataḥ kālo 'sya rudrasyeśvarādivyatiriktādyadādhikyaṃ tena yuktaḥ kālatvādetatkālavadityādi /
analyzed: vimataḥ rudrasya īśvara ādi vyatirikta ādya ādhikyam tena yuktaḥ kāla tvāt etat kālavat ityādi
translated: The time under dispute is connected with Rudra's superiority over Ishvara and others, because it is time, like this time.

original: nanu muktāstāvatsarve 'pi brahmaṇo 'dhikāsteṣāṃ muktatvādasya saṃsāritvāt /🔽ato 'nyaśabdavyākhyāne te 'pi kuto na gṛhyanta ityata āha uttamatvaṃ tviti //
analyzed: nanu muktāḥ tāvat sarve brahmaṇaḥ dhikāḥ teṣām mukta tvāt asya saṃsāri tvāt  atas nya śabda vyākhyāne te kutas na gṛhyante iti atas āha uttama tvam tu iti
translated: But all the liberated ones are superior to Brahman, because they are liberated and he is a transmigrator.

original: uttamatvaṃ tu muktānāmapi na brahmaṇo bhavet // / / //
analyzed: uttama tvam tu muktānām api na brahmaṇaḥ bhavet
translated: Therefore, why are they not included in the explanation of the word 'other'? To this he says: But the excellence of the liberated ones would not be of Brahman.

analyzed: atas tad agrahe na doṣaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is that therefore there is no fault in not grasping that.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha vyaktiḥ iti
translated: How is that? To this he says: The manifestation.

original: vyaktiḥ sukhasya tu bhavennatvādhikyaṃ sukhasya ca // / / //
analyzed: vyaktiḥ sukhasya tu bhavet na tvā ādhikyam sukhasya ca
translated: But there would be manifestation of happiness, not superiority of happiness.

analyzed: ādyaḥ tuśabdaḥ
translated: The first 'tu' word has the meaning of determination.

analyzed: vyaktiḥ eva iti sambaddhayate
translated: It is connected as 'manifestation only'.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ guṇa antara samuccaya athar ubhayatra anveti
translated: The word 'ca' is construed in both places as having the meaning of including another quality.

analyzed: prāk vidyamānasya eva svarūpa sukha ādeḥ muktau avidyā ādi āvaraṇa apāyena vyaktiḥ anubhava lakṣaṇā bhavet na tu kim api adhikam utpadyate
translated: The manifestation, which is characterized by experience, of one's own nature, happiness, etc., which existed before, by the removal of the obscurations such as ignorance in liberation, would occur, but nothing additional is produced.

analyzed: tathā sati anitya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if that were so, there would be the consequence of non-eternality.

analyzed: na ca brahmaṇaḥ svarūpāt itareṣām svarūpam adhikam
translated: And the nature of others is not superior to the nature of Brahman.

analyzed: na ca nirṇiktam kāṃsyam a nirṇiktāt suvarṇāt adhikam bhavati
translated: And a polished brass vessel is not superior to unpolished gold.

analyzed: etena mukta tva hetuḥ api pratyuktaḥ
translated: By this, the reason of being liberated is also refuted.

original: na kevalaṃ muktānāṃ brahmaṇo 'dhikatvaṃ nāsti kiṃ tarhītyata āha baleti //
analyzed: na kevalam muktānām brahmaṇaḥ dhika tvam nā asti kim tarhi iti atas āha bala iti
translated: Not only is there no superiority of the liberated ones over Brahman, but what then? Therefore it is said 'strength' etc.

original: balajñānādhikatvaṃ ca tebhyo hi brahmaṇaḥ sadā // / / //
analyzed: bala jñāna adhika tvam ca tebhyaḥ hi brahmaṇaḥ sadā
translated: And the superiority of strength and knowledge always belongs to Brahman from them.

analyzed: guṇa antara upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a metaphor for other qualities.

analyzed: sadā saṃsāre muktau ca
translated: Always in worldly existence and in liberation.

analyzed: etena sama śabdena api tad parigrahaḥ nirastaḥ
translated: By this, the inclusion of that by the word 'sama' is also refuted.

original: nanvevamanumāne vimataḥ kālo 'sya rājñaḥ sampratipannādhikyena yuktaḥ kālatvātsampratipannakālavadityapyanumānaprasaṅga ityata āha ādhikyasyeti
analyzed: nanu evam anumāne vimataḥ kālaḥ sya rājñaḥ sampratipanna ādhikyena yuktaḥ kāla tvāt sampratipanna kāla vat iti api anumāna prasaṅgaḥ iti atas āha ādhikyasya iti
translated: If it is so, then there is the contingence of another inference also, viz., 'the present time of the king under dispute is endowed with the acknowledged superiority, because it is time, like the acknowledged time'. In order to refute this, it is said 'of superiority' etc.

analyzed: ādhikyasya tu anitya tve na kiñcid mānam īyate
translated: But in the impermanence of superiority, nothing is measured.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: 'Of Brahman' is the remainder.

analyzed: anitya tve iti sādi tvasya api upalakṣaṇam
translated: 'In impermanence' is a metaphor for non-eternality also.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ rāja ādi ādhikyasya vyāvartakaḥ
translated: The word 'tu' (but) excludes the superiority of the king etc.

analyzed: bādhaka bhāva abhāvābhyām viśeṣāt na atiprasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no over-extension due to the difference between the presence and absence of contradiction.

original: evaṃ brahmādijīveṣvanādinityaṃ nānāvidhāṃ yogyatāṃ prasādhyedānīmāgamenāpi sādhayannādau tāvat śrutīḥ paṭhati śṛṇve vīra iti //
analyzed: evam brahma ādi jīveṣu anādinityam nānāvidhām yogyatām prasādhya idānīm āgamena api sādhayan ādau tāvat śrutīḥ paṭhati śṛṇve vīraḥ iti
translated: Having thus established the beginningless and eternal various kinds of fitness in the souls beginning with Brahman, now, in order to establish it by scripture also, he cites the scriptures at the beginning with I hear the hero...

analyzed: śṛṇve vīraḥ ugram ugram damāyan anyam anyam atinenīyamānaḥ
translated: I hear the hero, the fierce one, subduing the fierce one, leading one to another, not to be led.

original: edhamānadviḷubhayasya rājā coṣkūyate viśa indro manuṣyān // / / //
analyzed: rājā coṣkūyate viśaḥ indraḥ manuṣyān
translated: The king of both the prosperous and the poor, Indra, is praised by the people and men.

analyzed: vīraḥ dhī avasita anta gāmī
translated: The hero goes to the end of what he has undertaken.

analyzed: indraḥ parameśvaraḥ
translated: Indra is the Supreme Lord.

original: ugramugraṃ sarvānduṣyaprakṛtīndamayannityanarakaṃ prāpayannanyamanyaṃ sarvānsatsvabhāvānatinenīyamānaḥ saṃsāraṃ bhṛśamatikrāmayan svayogyatātirekeṇaidhamānaṃ
analyzed: ugram ugram sarvān duṣya prakṛtīn damayan iti anarakam prāpayan anyam anyam sarvān sat svabhāvān atinenīyamānaḥ saṃsāram bhṛśam atikrāmayan sva yogyatā atirekeṇa edhamānam
translated: Subduing all the fierce ones, those of wicked nature, he sends them to hell, leading one to another, all those of good nature, causing them to transcend worldly existence, increasing by his own superior fitness,

analyzed: dveṣyī iti edhamāna dviṣ
translated: the enemy of the prosperous, he is the enemy of the prosperous.

analyzed: śṛṇve śrūyate
translated: I hear, it is heard.

analyzed: kutas ubhayasya devatā asura vargasya rājā yatas
translated: From where is he the king of both the classes of gods and demons?

analyzed: kiñca manuṣyān viśaḥ prajāḥ coṣkūyate nityam parivartayati
translated: And he always turns, changes, the people and the subjects.

original: parā pūrveṣāṃ sakhyā vṛṇakti vitarturāṇo aparebhireti /
analyzed: parā pūrveṣām sakhyā vṛṇakti vitarturāṇaḥ aparebhiḥ eti
translated: He turns away from the friendship of the former, longing to go with the latter.

original: anānubhūtīravadhūnvānaḥ pūrvītindraḥ śaradastartarīti // / / //🔽parā pūrveṣām /🔽atītamantre pūrveṣāṃ pūrvanirdiṣyānāmugrāṇāṃ sakhyā sakhyāni parāvṛṇakti parityajati /
analyzed: anānubhūtīḥ avadhūnvānaḥ pūrvīḥ indraḥ śaradaḥ tartarīti  parā pūrveṣām  atīta mantre pūrveṣām pūrva nirdiṣyānām ugrāṇām sakhyā sakhyāni parāvṛṇakti parityajati
translated: Shaking off the non-experiences, Indra goes over the many autumns, having crossed over.🔽He turns away from the friendship of the former.

original: aparebhiraparaiḥ sādhubhiḥ saha sakhyāni vitarturāṇo 'tiśayena tvaramāṇa etyānānubhūtīḥ
analyzed: aparebhiḥ aparaiḥ sādhubhiḥ saha sakhyāni vitarturāṇaḥ tiśayena tvaramāṇaḥ etya ānā anubhūtīḥ
translated: He turns away, abandons, the friendships of the former, the fierce ones indicated before, with the latter, with the other good ones, longing to go with excessive speed.

original: samyaganubhavarahitānavadhūnvāno 'vame saṃsāre vartayannindraḥ pūrvīḥ śarado 'tītānsaṃvatsarāṃstīrṇo🔽vartamānāṃśca tartarīti /
analyzed: samyak anubhava rahitān avadhūnvānaḥ vame saṃsāre vartayan indraḥ pūrvīḥ śaradaḥ tītān saṃvatsarān tīrṇaḥ  vartamānān ca tartarīti
translated: Shaking off the non-experiences, turning away from the worldly existence, Indra has crossed over the many autumns, the past years,🔽and goes over the present ones,

analyzed: āgāminaḥ ca tariṣyati iti
translated: and will cross over the future ones.

analyzed: atra mantra dvaye surāṇām anāditas bhagavat bhajana abhāvaḥ nitya naraka avāptiḥ ca śrūyate
translated: In these two mantras, it is heard that the demons have been devoid of worshipping the Lord from beginningless time and have attained hell eternally,

analyzed: devānām sadā bhagavat bhajanam mokṣa avāptiḥ ca
translated: while the gods have always worshipped the Lord and attained liberation,

analyzed: manuṣyāṇām sarvadā saṃsāraḥ iti
translated: and humans are always in worldly existence.

original: divedive sadṛśīranyamardhaṃ kṛṣṇā asedhadapa sadmano jāḥ /
analyzed: dive dive sadṛśīḥ anyam ardham kṛṣṇāḥ asedhat apa sadmanaḥ jāḥ
translated: Day after day, he drove away the black half, similar to the other, the offspring of the abode.

original: ahan dāsā vṛṣabho vasnayantodavraje varcinaṃ śambaraṃ ca // / / //
analyzed: ahan dāsā vṛṣabhaḥ vasnayantā udavraje varcinam śambaram ca
translated: The bull, the lord, destroying the Dasyus, in the water-land, killed Vṛcin and Śambara.

original: dive dive varṣaṇādvṛṣabhaḥ parameśvaro dive dive sarvadā sadṛśīścetanatvamātreṇa kṛṣṇāstamomayīrjāḥ prajāḥ kāstā devebhyo 'nyamardhaṃ svīyātsadmanopāsedhat
analyzed: dive dive varṣaṇāt vṛṣabhaḥ parameśvaraḥ dive dive sarvadā sadṛśīḥ cetana tva mātreṇa kṛṣṇāḥ tamaḥ mayīḥ jāḥ prajāḥ kāḥ tāḥ devebhyaḥ nyamardham svīyāt sadmanā upāsedhat
translated: Day by day, the bull, the supreme lord, from the year, day by day, always, with beings similar only in having consciousness, the black, dark, fearful progeny, what are they? He, other than the gods, restrained half of his own abode.

analyzed: nivartayati
translated: He turns away.

original: kiñca dāsau dasyū vasnayantā jagacchāyadantau varcinaṃ śambaraṃ codavraje jalarāśau samudratīre 'hanhiṃsitavāniti /
analyzed: kiñca dāsau dasyū vasnayantā jagat chāya dantau varcinam śambaram ca udavraje jala rāśau samudra tīre han hiṃsitavān iti
translated: And the two Dasyu slaves, destroying the world's teeth, in the water-land, the ocean shore, killed Vṛcin and Śambara.

original: atra daityānāṃ kadāpi na mokṣa iti pratīyate /
analyzed: atra daityānām kadāpi na mokṣaḥ iti pratīyate
translated: Here it is understood that the demons will never be liberated.

original: taṃ bhūtiriti devā upāsāñcakrire te babhūvustasmāddhāpyetarhi supto bhūbhrūrityeva praśvasityabhūtirityasurāste ha parābabhūvuḥ // / /
analyzed: tam bhūtiḥ iti devāḥ upāsāñcakrire te babhūvuḥ tasmāt ha api etarhi suptaḥ bhūbhrūḥ iti eva praśvasiti abhūtiḥ iti asurāḥ te ha parābabhūvuḥ
translated: The gods meditated upon him as Bhūti (prosperity). They became prosperous. Therefore, even now, when one is asleep, one breathes with the sound Bhū-bhū-rā. The demons meditated upon him as Abhūti (non-prosperity). They were indeed defeated.

original: tad yathā peśaskarī peśaso mātrāmapādāyānyannavataraṃ kalyāṇataraṃ rūpaṃ tanuta evamevāyamātmedaṃ
analyzed: tat yathā peśaskarī peśasaḥ mātrām apādāya anyat navataram kalyāṇataram rūpam tanute evam eva ayam ātmā idam
translated: Just as a weaver, having taken a measure of thread, produces another, newer, better form, so does this Self, from this

original: śarīraṃ nihatyāvidyāṃ gamayitavānyannavataraṃ kalyāṇataraṃ rūpaṃ kurute pitṛyaṃ pitṛyaṃ
analyzed: śarīram nihatya avidyām gamayitavān yannavataram kalyāṇataram rūpam kurute pitṛyam pitṛyam
translated: Having destroyed the body, he has caused it to go to ignorance and has made a newer and better form, either paternal or

original: vā gāndharvaṃ vā daivaṃ vā prājāpatyaṃ vā brāhmaṃ vānyeṣāṃ vā bhūtānām // / / // /
analyzed: vā gāndharvam vā daivam vā prājāpatyam vā brāhmam vā anyeṣām vā bhūtānām
translated: Gandharva or divine or Prajapati or Brahmic or of other beings.

analyzed: tam bhūtiḥ iti
translated: Him they call Bhuti.

analyzed: tam parameśvaram
translated: Him, the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: bhūtiḥ aiśvarya rūpaḥ
translated: Bhuti is of the form of prosperity.

analyzed: babhūvuḥ muktāḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: They became liberated, the rest is.

analyzed: etarhi idānīm suptaḥ supta sthaḥ vāyuḥ
translated: Now, the wind that is asleep, that is in sleep,

analyzed: parābabhūvuḥ nitya nirayam prāptāḥ
translated: has become supreme, has attained eternal peace.

original: atra devāsurāṇāṃ samyagviparītopāsanābhyāṃ mokṣatamasoḥ prāptiḥ śrūyate /
analyzed: atra deva asurāṇām samyak viparīta upāsanābhyām mokṣa tamasoḥ prāptiḥ śrūyate
translated: Here, the attainment of liberation and darkness by gods and demons through right and wrong meditation is heard.

analyzed: tena deva tvam asura tvam ca sahajam iti jñāyate
translated: Therefore, it is known that godhead and demonhood are innate.

analyzed: tat yathā tat vakṣyamāṇam nidarśanam yathā
translated: That is the example that will be stated, as it is.

analyzed: peśaskārī suvarṇakāraḥ peśasaḥ suvarṇasya mātrām aṃśam
translated: The goldsmith, the gold worker, a portion of the gold.

analyzed: anyat iva navataram prāk ananubhavāt
translated: Other than before, newer, from non-experience.

analyzed: kalyāṇataram mala apakarṣāt
translated: Better, due to the removal of impurities.

analyzed: rūpam rucaka ādikam
translated: Form, such as gold ornaments.

analyzed: ātmā paramātmā
translated: The Self, the Supreme Self.

analyzed: anyeṣām bhūtānām manuṣya uttamānām
translated: Of other beings, of the best among humans.

original: atra suvarṇasyaiva yathā rucikādibhāvaḥ suvarṇakāreṇa kriyate na yasya kasyaciddravyasya tathā muktiyogyānāmeveśvareṇa muktatvaṃ kriyate nānyeṣāmiti 🔽pratīyate / /
analyzed: atra suvarṇasya eva yathā rucika ādi bhāvaḥ suvarṇakāreṇa kriyate na yasya kasyacid dravyasya tathā mukti yogyānām eva īśvareṇa mukta tvam kriyate na anyeṣām iti  pratīyate
translated: Here it is understood that just as the goldsmith makes the form of gold, such as a necklace, etc., out of gold itself, and not out of any other substance, in the same way, the Lord grants liberation to only those who are fit for liberation, and not to others.

analyzed: adhunā atra eva smṛtīḥ paṭhati prayānti iti
translated: Now, he quotes the Smritis here itself, beginning with They go...

analyzed: prayānti paramām siddhim aihika āmuṣmikīm drutam
translated: They quickly attain the highest perfection, both in this world and the next.

analyzed: yā na prāpya asuraiḥ sarvaiḥ akṣayā kleśa varjitā
translated: That imperishable state, devoid of afflictions, which is not attained by any of the demons,

original: na tāṃ gatiṃ prapadyante vinā bhāgavatān narān // / / //
analyzed: na tām gatim prapadyante vinā bhāgavatān narān
translated: human beings do not attain that state without being devotees of the Lord.

original: purā satye yuga iti prakṛtānāṃ devatāsvabhāvānāṃ prayāntītyanena mokṣādiphalaprāptimuktvā yā na prāpyetyasurāṇāṃ na tāṃ gatimiti manuṣyāṇāṃ
analyzed: purā satye yuge iti prakṛtānām devatā svabhāvānām prayānti iti anena mokṣa ādi phala prāptim uktvā yā na prāpya iti asurāṇām na tām gatim iti manuṣyāṇām
translated: Having said that the beings mentioned earlier, who are of the nature of deities, attain the fruits like liberation by the word go in They go, it is said that the demons do not attain that state, and the human beings

analyzed: ca kadācid tad prāptiḥ na asti iti ucyate
translated: sometimes do not attain it at all.

analyzed: avajānanti mām mūḍhāḥ mānuṣīm tanum āśritam
translated: The deluded ones disregard Me, who have resorted to a human body,

analyzed: param bhāvam a jānantaḥ mama bhūta maheśvaram
translated: not knowing My supreme nature as the great Lord of all beings.

analyzed: mogha āśāḥ mogha karmāṇaḥ mogha jñānāḥ vicetasaḥ
translated: Their desires are futile, their actions are futile, their knowledge is futile, and their minds are confused.

analyzed: rākṣasīm āsurīm ca eva prakṛtim mohanīm śritāḥ
translated: And have resorted to the nature of demons and demons, which is deluding.

analyzed: avajānanti iti anena bhagavat avajñā ādi lakṣaṇa rākṣasa ādi svabhāvavatām kadāpi puruṣa artha avāptiḥ na asti iva iti kathyate
translated: By despising, it is said that those who have the nature of demons, etc., characterized by contempt for the Lord, etc., never attain human goals.

analyzed: prakṛtiḥ svabhāvaḥ
translated: Nature means inherent nature.

analyzed: mahātmānaḥ tu mām pārtha daivīm prakṛtim āśritāḥ
translated: But the great souls, O Partha, who have resorted to the divine nature,

analyzed: bhajanti an anya manasaḥ jñātvā bhūtādim avyayam
translated: Worship Me with minds not attached to anything else, knowing Me as the beginningless and imperishable source of beings.

original: mahātmana ityatra bhagavadbhajanādilakṣaṇadevatvaṃ svabhāva iti pratīyate /
analyzed: mahātmanaḥ iti atra bhagavat bhajana ādi lakṣaṇa deva tvam svabhāvaḥ iti pratīyate
translated: In great souls, it is understood that divinity characterized by worship of the Lord, etc., is their inherent nature.

analyzed: abhayam sattva saṃśuddhiḥ jñāna yoga vyavasthitiḥ
translated: Fearlessness, purity of knowledge, steadfastness in yoga,

analyzed: dānam damaḥ ca yajñaḥ ca svādhyāyaḥ tapaḥ ārjavam
translated: Charity, self-control, sacrifice, study of the Vedas, austerity, and straightforwardness,

original: ahiṃsā satyamakrodhastyāgaḥ śāntirapaiśunam /🔽dayā bhūteṣvalolutvaṃ mārdavaṃ hrīracāpalam // / / //
analyzed: ahiṃsā satyam akrodhaḥ tyāgaḥ śāntiḥ apaiśunam  dayā mārdavam hrīḥ acāpalam
translated: Non-violence, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, tranquility, absence of slander,🔽Compassion towards beings, contentment, gentleness, modesty, and steadiness,

analyzed: tejaḥ kṣamā dhṛtiḥ śaucam adrohaḥ na atimāni tā
translated: Brilliance, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, absence of malice, and absence of pride,

analyzed: bhavanti sampadam daivīm abhijātasya bhārata
translated: These are the characteristics of the divine nature of one who is born noble, O descendant of Bharata.

analyzed: ḍambhaḥ krodhaḥ pāruṣyam eva ca
translated: Arrogance, pride, excessive self-importance, anger, and harshness,

analyzed: ajñānam ca abhijātasya pārtha sampadam āsurīm
translated: And ignorance, O son of Prtha, is the characteristic of the demoniac endowments.

original: abhayamityanenābhayādilakṣaṇaṃ devatvaṃ dambhādilakṣaṇaṃ cāsuratvaṃ svabhāva eveti jñāyate /
analyzed: abhayam iti anena abhaya ādi lakṣaṇam deva tvam dambha ādi lakṣaṇam ca asura tvam svabhāvaḥ eva iti jñāyate
translated: By the word 'fearlessness' it is understood that divinity characterized by fearlessness etc. and demoniac nature characterized by arrogance etc. are natural.

analyzed: mām ātma para deheṣu pradviṣantaḥ bhyasūyakāḥ
translated: Those who hate Me in their own bodies and in the bodies of others, are envious.

analyzed: tān aham dviṣataḥ krūrān saṃsāreṣu nara adhamān
translated: I cast those hateful, cruel, lowest of men into the worlds of birth and death.

analyzed: kṣipāmi ajasram aśubhān āsurīṣu eva yoniṣu
translated: Constantly, I cast the inauspicious ones into the demoniac wombs alone.

analyzed: āsurīm yonim āpannāḥ mūḍhāḥ janmani janmani
translated: Having attained the demoniac womb, the deluded ones, in birth after birth,

analyzed: mām a prāpya eva kaunteya tatas yānti adhamām gatim
translated: O son of Kunti, not attaining Me, then go to the lowest state.

analyzed: mām ātmā iti anena asura svabhāvānām andhatamasa avāpti paryavasānam abhidhīyate
translated: By the words 'My Self' it is said that those of demoniac nature attain the end of the attainment of blinding darkness.

original: dvividho bhūtasargo 'tra daiva āsura eva ca /
analyzed: dvividhaḥ daivaḥ āsuraḥ eva ca
translated: Here, the creation of beings is of two kinds: divine and demoniac.

analyzed: viṣṇu bhakti paraḥ daivaḥ viparītaḥ tathā āsuraḥ
translated: One who is devoted to Vishnu is divine, and the opposite is demoniac.

original: devānāṃ paramo dharmaḥ sadā yajñādikāḥ kriyāḥ /
analyzed: devānām paramaḥ dharmaḥ sadā yajña ādikāḥ kriyāḥ
translated: The highest duty of the gods is always the performance of sacrifices and other rites,

analyzed: svādhyāyaḥ tattva vedi tvam viṣṇu pūjā ratiḥ smṛtiḥ
translated: Study of one's own scriptures, knowledge of truth, and love for the worship of Vishnu are remembered.

analyzed: daityānām bāhuṣāḷi tvam mātsaryam yuddha satkriyā
translated: For the demons, it is boasting with their arms, envy, and the performance of battles.

analyzed: nīti śāstra pravedi tvam śiva pūjā ratiḥ smṛtiḥ
translated: The knowledge of the science of politics, the delight in worshipping Shiva, the memory,

analyzed: varṇa āśrama ācāravat tvam svādhyāyaḥ bhaktiḥ acyute
translated: The adherence to the duties of caste and stage of life, the study of one's own scriptures, devotion to Vishnu,

original: śive sūrye tathā devyāṃ svabhāvo mānuṣaḥ smṛtaḥ // / / //🔽anādivaiṣṇavā eva devatāstu svabhāvataḥ /
analyzed: śive sūrye tathā devyām svabhāvaḥ mānuṣaḥ smṛtaḥ  anādi vaiṣṇavāḥ eva devatāḥ tu svabhāvataḥ
translated: Devotion to Shiva, the Sun, and the Goddess - this is said to be the natural disposition of human beings.🔽The gods are naturally devoted to Vishnu from beginningless time.

analyzed: viparītāḥ tatas daityāḥ sadā eva anādi kālataḥ
translated: The demons are the opposite, always devoted to Vishnu from beginningless time.

analyzed: mānuṣāḥ miśra matayaḥ vimiśra gatayaḥ pi ca
translated: Human beings have mixed dispositions and mixed conduct.

analyzed: dvividhaḥ iti spaṣṭam deva asura tvayoḥ svabhāva tvam ākhyāyate
translated: It is clearly stated that the nature of gods and demons is twofold.

analyzed: sarga śabdasya svabhāva vāci tvāt
translated: Because the word creation denotes nature.

analyzed: dvividhaḥ eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is only of two kinds.

original: sargāṇāṃ subahutve 'piśubhāśubhaphalādhikau /🔽devāsurākhyau dvāveva gandhavadyāstadantarā iti vacanādavadhāraṇopapattiḥ /
analyzed: sargāṇām su bahutve piśubha aśubha phala adhikau  deva asura ākhyau dvau eva gandha vat yāḥ tad antarāḥ iti vacanāt avadhāraṇa upapattiḥ
translated: Even though there are many creations, only two - the gods and demons - have superior auspicious and inauspicious fruits,🔽while the Gandharvas and others have mixed fruits, according to the statement. Thus the restriction is appropriate.

original: svabhāva ityetaddevānāṃ daityānāmityatrāpi sambaddhayate /🔽paramo dharma iti yajñādikānāṃ kriyāṇāṃ viśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: svabhāvaḥ iti etat devānām daityānām iti atra api sambaddhayate  paramaḥ dharmaḥ iti yajña ādikānām kriyāṇām viśeṣaṇam
translated: The word nature is also connected here with of the gods and demons.🔽Supreme dharma is a qualification for the rites such as sacrifice.
The rites such as sacrifice are of the nature of supreme dharma by reflecting on the Lord and so on.

original: ratiḥ smṛtiśca viṣṇoḥ śivasya ceti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: ratiḥ smṛtiḥ ca viṣṇoḥ śivasya ca iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Rati and Smriti are of Vishnu and Shiva, the rest is clear.

analyzed: bahu śāli tvam iti asthāne bāhu bala prayogaḥ bhipreyate
translated: The use of the word bahushalita in place of ashalita is intended to convey the sense of having strong arms.

analyzed: yuddha satkriyā yuddha kauśalam  varṇa āśrama iti tad anuṣṭhāna mātra paryavasāyi tvam ācaṣṭe
translated: Yuddhasatkriya is skill in battle.🔽Varna and ashrama indicate that the purpose is limited to the mere performance of those duties.

analyzed: acyuta ādau sāmyena bhaktiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is devotion to Achyuta and others as equals.

analyzed: anādi iti spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning of anadi is clear.

analyzed: anādi tvāt eva svabhāvataḥ na ādi kālataḥ iti etat mānuṣāḥ iti anena sambaddhayate
translated: Because of being beginningless, it is naturally from beginningless time. This is connected with the word manusha.

analyzed: miśra matayaḥ samyak asamyak jñānāḥ
translated: Those with mixed minds have correct and incorrect knowledge.

analyzed: vimiśra gatayaḥ sukha duḥkha ātmaka saṃsāra phalāḥ
translated: Those with mixed destinies have the fruits of worldly existence consisting of happiness and sorrow.

analyzed: deva ādīnām api evam phalam jñātavyam
translated: The fruits of the gods and others should also be known in this way.

analyzed: śruti smṛti udāharaṇa phalam darśayati ityādi iti
translated: He shows the result of citing the scriptures and smrti: thus, etc.

analyzed: ityādi vākya sandarbhe jñāyate na ādi yogyatā
translated: Thus, in the collection of statements, the beginningless ability is known.

analyzed: sandarbhaiḥ iti ati bahūni vākyāni atra arthe nyatra udāhṛtāni draṣṭavyāni iti sūcayati
translated: By collections, he indicates that many statements cited elsewhere should be seen in this sense.

analyzed: uktānām anumānānām vyāpti avadhāraṇa ādi artham āgamānām ca anya artha vyākhyāna nirāsa artham anugrāhakam tarkam āha yadi iti
translated: In order to ascertain the pervasion, etc. of the stated inferences and to refute the explanation of the scriptures as having a different meaning, he states the supporting reasoning: If there were no beginningless distinction, how could it be now?

analyzed: yadi anādiḥ viśeṣaḥ na sāmpratam katham eva saḥ
translated: If there were no beginningless, most excellent distinction characterized by fitness, how could it be now?

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ svarūpa gataḥ yogyatā lakṣaṇaḥ tiśayaḥ
translated: Distinction is a special quality characterized by fitness inherent in the nature.

analyzed: sa viśeṣaḥ paridṛśyamānaḥ atiśayaḥ
translated: That distinction, when seen, is a special quality.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

original: yadi hiraṇyagarbhasyānādiḥ sarvotkṛṣṭo yogyatālakṣaṇo viśeṣo na syāttadā sāmprataṃ dṛśyamānaṃ sarvotkṛṣṭatvaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: yadi hiraṇyagarbhasya anādiḥ sarva utkṛṣṭaḥ yogyatā lakṣaṇaḥ viśeṣaḥ na syāt tadā sāmpratam dṛśyamānam sarva utkṛṣṭa tvam na syāt
translated: If there were no beginningless, most excellent distinction characterized by fitness belonging to Hiraṇyagarbha, then the most excellent nature seen now would not exist.

analyzed: tasya etat bīja tvāt
translated: Because that is the seed of this.

analyzed: kāraṇa abhāve ca kārya abhāvasya niyama tvāt
translated: And because the absence of the effect is a rule when there is the absence of the cause.

analyzed: anyathā sarveṣām api sarva utkṛṣṭa tva āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, because all would have the most excellent nature.

analyzed: evam anyatra api vaktavyam iti
translated: Similarly, it should be stated in other cases also.

original: nanu brahmādīnāṃ yogyatālakṣaṇānādiviśeṣābhāve 'pi sādino viśiṣyādṛṣṭādeva sarvotkṛṣṭatvādikaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: nanu brahma ādīnām yogyatā lakṣaṇa anādi viśeṣa abhāve pi sādinaḥ viśiṣya adṛṣṭāt eva sarva utkṛṣṭa tva ādikam bhaviṣyati
translated: But even in the absence of the beginningless distinction characterized by fitness belonging to Brahmā and others, the most excellent nature, etc. will arise from the unseen merit alone.

analyzed: tathā ca smṛtiḥ svadharma niṣṭhaḥ śata janmabhiḥ pumān viriñca tām eti
translated: And thus the Smṛti says: A man devoted to his own duty by a hundred births attains the state of Brahmā.

analyzed: ityādikā iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this is the case,

analyzed: atra vaktavyam
translated: then this should be stated.

original: kiṃ tadviriñcasya sarvotkarṣabījaṃ viśiṣyamadṛṣṭaṃ tataḥ prāktanatathāvidhamadṛṣṭamanapekṣyaiva jāyate /
analyzed: kim tat viriñcasya sarva utkarṣa bījam viśiṣyam adṛṣṭam tatas prāktana tathāvidham adṛṣṭam an apekṣya eva jāyate
translated: Is that special unseen potency, the seed of Viriñci's supremacy over all, produced independently, without regard to the previous unseen potency of that kind?

analyzed: uta apekṣya iti
translated: Or with regard to it?

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati adṛṣṭāt eva ca iti
translated: He refutes the first view, saying If it is only from the unseen...

analyzed: adṛṣṭāt eva ca adṛṣṭam svīkṛtam savarvādibhiḥ
translated: The unseen is accepted as only from the unseen by all the Vaiśeṣikas.

analyzed: tāni tāni dravya ādīni khalu adṛṣṭa utpattau nimittāni śruti smṛtibhyām upalabhyante
translated: Indeed, various substances etc. are observed in the scriptures and Smṛtis as the causes for the production of the unseen.

original: tatsampattiścādṛṣṭanimittaiva /🔽tasmānna kevalaṃ phalaṃ kinnāmottarottaramadṛṣṭaṃ ca pūrvapūrvādṛṣṭādbhavatīti cārvākavyatiriktasarvavādibhiḥ svīkṛtam /
analyzed: tad sampattiḥ ca adṛṣṭa nimittā eva  tasmāt na kevalam phalam kinnāma uttarottaram adṛṣṭam ca pūrva pūrva adṛṣṭāt bhavati iti cārvāka vyatirikta sarva vādibhiḥ svīkṛtam
translated: And the attainment of those is caused by the unseen itself.🔽Therefore, it is accepted by all the philosophers except the Cārvākas that the result is not only from the unseen, but also the subsequent unseen arises from the previous unseen.

analyzed: atas sarva utkarṣa hetoḥ viśiṣya adṛṣṭasya tathāvidha prāktana adṛṣṭa anapekṣa utpattika tva abhyupagame syāt
translated: Therefore, if it is accepted that the special unseen, the cause of supremacy over all, arises independently without regard to the previous unseen of that kind, there would be a contradiction with one's own doctrine.

original: bhavatvanyeṣāṃ vādināmitthaṃ siddhānto mama tu sarvotkarṣādiphalotpattāveva viśiṣyādṛṣṭāpekṣā natu tadutpattāvapīti /
analyzed: bhavatu anyeṣām vādinām ittham siddhāntaḥ mama tu sarva utkarṣa ādi phala utpattau eva viśiṣya adṛṣṭa apekṣā na tu tad utpattau api iti
translated: Let it be so for the other philosophers, but for me, there is a special regard for the unseen only in the production of the result of supremacy over all, not even in its production.

original: yadvā yadviriñcasya sarvotkarṣanimittaṃ viśiṣyamadṛṣṭaṃ tasya tathāvidhādṛṣṭakāryatve 'pi tasya nādṛṣṭakāryatvamiti / /
analyzed: yat vā yat viriñcasya sarva utkarṣa nimittam viśiṣyam adṛṣṭam tasya tathāvidha adṛṣṭa kārya tve pi tasya na adṛṣṭa kārya tvam iti
translated: Or, if the unseen potency of Brahmā, which is the cause of his preeminence over all, is admitted to be the cause of such and such effects, it does not follow that it is the cause of all effects.

original: sarvasyāpi pravāhasya tathātve hi bhavatāmiṣyasiddhiriti vadantaṃ pratyatiprasaṅgamāha ākasmika iti //
analyzed: sarvasya api pravāhasya tathātve hi bhavatām iṣi asiddhiḥ iti vadantam prati atiprasaṅgam āha ākasmikaḥ iti
translated: For if the entire series of effects were to be so, then your desired conclusion would be established. To one who says this, the author states the absurdity of the opponent's position in the following [verse]:

analyzed: ākasmikaḥ viśeṣaḥ ced adṛṣṭe kvacid iṣyate
translated: If a special [cause] is accepted as accidental in some unseen [entity],

analyzed: sarvatra ākasmika tvam syāt na adṛṣṭa apekṣa tā bhavet
translated: then everything would be accidental, and there would be no dependence on the unseen [entity].

original: kvacidviriñcotkarṣahetau taddhetau vādṛṣṭe viśeṣo 'tiśayo yadyākasmiko 'dṛṣṭanirapekṣa eveṣyate /
analyzed: kvacid viriñca utkarṣa hetau tad hetau vā adṛṣṭe viśeṣaḥ atiśayaḥ yadi ākasmikaḥ dṛṣṭa nirapekṣaḥ eva iṣyate
translated: If a special [cause], a particular [cause], is accepted as accidental, independent of the unseen [entity], in some unseen [entity] that is the cause of Brahmā's preeminence or in some other unseen [entity],

original: yadi kimapi viśiṣyamadṛṣṭaṃ tathāvidhādṛṣṭanirapekṣamevotpadyate ityaṅgīkriyata iti yāvat /
analyzed: yadi kim api viśiṣyam adṛṣṭam tathāvidha adṛṣṭa nirapekṣam eva utpadyate iti aṅgīkriyate iti yāvat
translated: if it is accepted that some particular unseen [entity] arises independently of any other such unseen [entity],

analyzed: tarhi sarvatra phala ādau api ākasmika tvam aṅgīkāryam syāt aviśeṣāt
translated: then in that case, everything, even the effect, would have to be accepted as accidental, because there is no distinction [between the two cases].🔽The author explains the consequence [of the opponent's position] in the following [verse]:

analyzed: āpādyam vivṛṇoti na iti
translated: Not so [is the answer].

analyzed: sarvatra iti anuvartate
translated: In all cases is to be supplied.

original: yadyevaṃ na vivrīyeta tarhi pareṇādṛṣṭasya niṣkāraṇatāyā anaṅgīkṛtatvādasaṅgato 'yaṃ prasaṅgaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi evam na tarhi pareṇa adṛṣṭasya niṣkāraṇa tāyāḥ an aṅgīkṛta tvāt asaṅgataḥ yam prasaṅgaḥ syāt
translated: If it were not so, then, since the opponent does not admit that what is not seen is without a cause, this reductio would be irrelevant.

analyzed: evam eva āpadākam api vyākhyeyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the reductio based on the undesirable consequence should also be explained in this same way.

analyzed: astu viriñca utkarṣasya api adṛṣṭa anapekṣa tā iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that let there be the superiority of Brahmā also without depending on unseen [forces], that is not so.

analyzed: prāc bhavīyasya dṛṣṭa kāraṇa kalāpasya naṣṭa tvena niṣkāraṇa tā āpātāt
translated: Because the collection of seen causes in a previous life would have perished, [Brahmā's superiority] would be without a cause.

original: kiñca viśiṣyo dṛṣṭakāraṇakalāpo 'pi tasya kuta iti vācyam /
analyzed: kiñca viśiṣyaḥ tasya kutas iti vācyam
translated: Moreover, it should be said how even a distinguished collection of seen causes [could be the cause of Brahmā's superiority].

analyzed: nirnimittaḥ ced atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: If [the cause] is without a reason, there would be an overextension [of the cause].

analyzed: svabhāva nimittaḥ ced siddham naḥ samīhitam
translated: If [the cause] has its own nature as a reason, then what we desire is established.

analyzed: etena dṛṣṭa vyāpāra parituṣyāt īśvarāt viriñcasya sarva utkarṣa sampattiḥ iti api nirastam
translated: By this [argument], it is also refuted that Brahmā's attainment of superiority over all is from God, who is pleased by seen activity.

original: anādiyogyatāparihārāditi / /🔽astu tarhi dvitīyaḥ pakṣa iti tatrāha adṛṣṭāccediti //
analyzed: anādi yogyatā parihārāt iti  astu tarhi dvitīyaḥ pakṣaḥ iti tatra āha adṛṣṭāt ced iti
translated: [This is because] the removal of beginningless fitness [is not possible].

analyzed: adṛṣṭāḥ ced viśeṣaḥ yama nādi tvam kutas na tat
translated: If it is argued that then let the second alternative be so, [the author] says If [the superiority] is from unseen [forces], then why is not beginninglessness [of that]?

analyzed: bhavati iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is it would be so.

analyzed: viśiṣyate iti viśeṣaḥ viśiṣyam adṛṣṭam iti arthaḥ
translated: Superiority means that which is distinguished, and unseen means that which is distinguished.

analyzed: ayam iti viriñcasya sarva utkaṣar hetuḥ
translated: This [means] the cause of Brahmā's superiority over all.

analyzed: anādi tvam tathāvidha adṛṣṭa paramparāyāḥ
translated: The beginninglessness of such a series of unseen [forces].

analyzed: anādi yogyatāvat tvam iti ca
translated: And the possession of beginningless capacity.

analyzed: tat tarhi
translated: That then.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: yathā viriñcasya sarvotkarṣe kāraṇaṃ viśiṣyamadṛṣṭaṃ tathāvidhādṛṣṭapūrvakaṃ
analyzed: yathā viriñcasya sarva utkarṣe kāraṇam viśiṣyam adṛṣṭam tathāvidha adṛṣṭa pūrvakam
translated: Just as the unseen [force] which is the cause of Brahmā's preeminence over all is preceded by such an unseen [force],

analyzed: vidha pūrva adṛṣṭa hetukam
translated: and is caused by such an unseen [force] that preceded it,

analyzed: tathā tat api tat api iti svīkāryam
translated: so that also must be accepted as having such a cause,

analyzed: samāna nyāya tvāt
translated: because the reasoning is the same.
