original: tathā cānādiviśiṣyādṛṣṭapravāhāśrayatvaṃ tasyaiva kuta ityanuyogasya nānyaduttaramanāderviśiṣyasvabhāvāt /
analyzed: tathā ca anādi viśiṣya adṛṣṭa pravāha āśraya tvam tasya eva kutas iti anuyogasya na anyat uttaram anādeḥ viśiṣya svabhāvāt
translated: And in response to the question How can that [Brahmā] alone be the basis of an endless series of special unseen [forces]? there is no other answer than that it has an endless special nature.

analyzed: tad tad phala prāpti upāyayoḥ prayatna adṛṣṭayoḥ āgantukayoḥ bīja bhūtaḥ na āgantuka svabhāva viśeṣaḥ eva anādi yogyatā ucyate
translated: The special nature that is the seed of the adventitious effort and unseen [forces], which are the means of attaining those [fruits], is called beginningless capacity.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: svabhāva ākhyā yogyatā yā haṭha ākhyā ityādi
translated: The capacity called nature and the capacity called constraint. and so on.

analyzed: atas siddhā brahma ādi kali paryanteṣu jīveṣu anādi yogya tā iti
translated: Therefore, it is established that there is beginningless capacity in the souls ranging from Brahmā to Kali.

original: bhagavānnirdeṣa iti yatprāguktaṃ tatsamarthanārthamuttaro granthaḥ /🔽nanuna sthānato 'pi' /
analyzed: bhagavān nirdeṣaḥ iti yat prāk uktam tad samarthana artham uttaraḥ granthaḥ  nanunaḥ sthānataḥ pi
translated: The subsequent text is for the purpose of supporting the statement made earlier that the Lord is faultless.

analyzed: ityādinā eva samarthitam etat
translated: But it has been argued that this is established by the statement beginning with Even from the point of view of place.🔽This is so.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: yukti ādinā prāptam sa doṣa tvam tatra apākṛtam
translated: The fault of being obtained by reasoning etc. has been refuted there.

analyzed: atra tu pratyakṣa prāptam iti bhedāt
translated: But here it is obtained by perception, so there is a difference.

original: etadapi tatraiva kuto na dūṣitamiti cet /
analyzed: etat api tatra eva kutas na dūṣitam iti ced
translated: If it is asked why this was not refuted there itself,

analyzed: viśva ādiṣu pratyakṣasya apravṛtteḥ
translated: it is because perception does not operate in the case of Viṣṇu etc.

original: prāsaṅgikaṃ tu nirākaraṇaṃ tatra vātra vā na kaścidviśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: prāsaṅgikam tu nirākaraṇam tatra vā atra vā na kaścid viśeṣaḥ
translated: But the refutation is incidental, whether there or here, there is no difference.

analyzed: prāc ukta artha prapañcaḥ ca atra anubhāṣyakṛtā kriyate
translated: And the elaboration of the meaning stated earlier is done here by the author of the commentary.

analyzed: mukta tāratamya ādeḥ prapañcana ādeḥ
translated: Due to the elaboration of the gradation etc. of liberation.

analyzed: atas tra eva yuktam
translated: Therefore, the elaboration of faultlessness is appropriate here itself.

original: kiñcātra jñānasvarūpanirūpaṇaṃ bhaviṣyati tatprasaṅgaśca jñānapāde samucitaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca atra jñāna svarūpa nirūpaṇam bhaviṣyati tad prasaṅgaḥ ca jñāna pāde samucitaḥ
translated: Moreover, the nature of knowledge will be determined here, and its relevance is appropriate in the section on knowledge.

analyzed: api ca na bhagavat sākṣātkāra mātreṇa aśeṣa puruṣa artha prāptiḥ kintu nirdeṣāt bhagavat darśanāt iti uktam
translated: Furthermore, it has been said that the attainment of all human goals is not by mere direct realization of the Lord, but by faultless vision of the Lord.

analyzed: tat ca anena nirdeṣa bhagavat darśanam upadarśitam bhavati
translated: And this faultless vision of the Lord is indicated by this.

original: tarhi tatraivāyaṃ granthasandarbhaḥ kuto na niveśita iti cet /
analyzed: tarhi tatra eva ayam grantha sandarbhaḥ kutas na niveśitaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked why this series of texts was not placed there itself,

analyzed: deva dānava mānava svabhāva prapañcanasya atra upayukta tvena tad ānantarya upapatteḥ
translated: Because the description of the nature of gods, demons, and humans is useful here and is appropriate immediately after that.

analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And we will explain it thus.

analyzed: idam atra śaṅkayate
translated: This is suspected here.

analyzed: rāmakṛṣṇa ādayaḥ bhagavat avatārāḥ bhagavatā atyanta abhinnāḥ iti tāvat samarthitam
translated: It has been established that Rāma, Kṛṣṇa, and other incarnations of the Lord are absolutely non-different from the Lord.

original: teṣāṃ ca parasparaṃ bhedastakālavartināṃ puruṣāṇāṃ pratyakṣeṇa dṛśyate /
analyzed: teṣām ca parasparam bhedaḥ ta kāla vartinām puruṣāṇām pratyakṣeṇa dṛśyate
translated: And their mutual difference is seen by the perception of men existing at different times.

original: naca te dehavanta iti coktam /🔽tato dehagata eva bheda ityanavakāśāt /
analyzed: na ca te dehavantaḥ iti ca uktam  tatas deha gataḥ eva bhedaḥ iti anavakāśāt
translated: And it has been said that they do not have bodies.🔽Therefore, the difference is only in the body, and there is no opportunity for it.

analyzed: tatas ca sarveṣām svātantrya anupapatteḥ
translated: And from that, the independence of all is not possible.

analyzed: keṣāñcid pāratantryam
translated: Some are dependent.

analyzed: evam anye pi bheda anuṣaṅgiṇaḥ doṣāḥ draṣṭavyāḥ
translated: In the same way, other faults that are associated with difference should be seen.

analyzed: samāna nyāya tvāt
translated: Because the same reasoning applies.

original: vedādhidoṣāśca pratyakṣeṇekṣyanta iti na bhagavato nirdeṣatvamiti /
analyzed: veda adhi doṣāḥ ca pratyakṣeṇa īkṣyante iti na bhagavataḥ nirdeṣa tvam iti
translated: And the faults of the Vedas are seen by perception, so the Lord is not faultless.

original: tatra tāvadbhedasya pratyakṣasiddhatāṃ nirākartumāgamavākyaṃ paṭhati naceti //🔽nacānyabhedavad viṣṇau bhedastaddarśināmapi /
analyzed: tatra tāvat bhedasya pratyakṣa siddha tām nirākartum āgama vākyam paṭhati na ca iti  na ca anya bheda vat viṣṇau bhedaḥ tad darśinām api
translated: To refute the establishment of difference by perception, he quotes an authoritative statement, not and so on.🔽And difference is not seen in Viṣṇu like in other things, even by those who perceive it.

analyzed: dṛśyate
translated: Difference is not seen in Viṣṇu like in other things, even by those who perceive it.

analyzed: caḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word ca (and) is for emphasis.

analyzed: anya bheda vat iti vyatireka dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: The example of difference from others is the example of difference from other things.

original: anyeṣāṃ ghaṭādīnāṃ yathānekatvātirikto 'nyonyābhāvalakṣaṇo bhedo dṛśyate na tatheti /
analyzed: anyeṣām ghaṭa ādīnām yathā anekatva atiriktaḥ nyonya abhāva lakṣaṇaḥ bhedaḥ dṛśyate na tathā iti
translated: Just as the difference characterized by mutual absence, which is different from multiplicity, is seen in other things like pots, it is not seen in that way.

original: viṣṇau bhedo na dṛśyata ityevokte 'nekatvasyāpyadarśanaṃ pratīyeta tadarthamidaṃ vacanam /
analyzed: viṣṇau bhedaḥ na dṛśyate iti eva ukte neka tvasya api adarśanam tad artham idam vacanam
translated: If it is said that difference is not seen in Viṣṇu, it would be understood that multiplicity is also not seen. For that purpose, this statement is made.

original: yadvā yathā viṣṇāvanyapratiyogiko bhedo dṛśyate na tathā svapratiyogika iti yojanā /
analyzed: yat vā yathā viṣṇau anya pratiyogikaḥ bhedaḥ dṛśyate na tathā sva pratiyogikaḥ iti yojanā
translated: Or, the construction is: Just as difference with another as its counter-correlate is seen in Viṣṇu, not so with itself as its counter-correlate.

original: anyathā ghaṭādipratiyogiko 'pi bhedo na dṛśyata ityapi pratīyeta /
analyzed: anyathā ghaṭa ādi pratiyogikaḥ pi bhedaḥ na dṛśyate iti api pratīyeta
translated: Otherwise, it would be understood that difference with pots etc. as its counter-correlate is also not seen.

analyzed: athavā anya pratiyāgika bhedavati viṣṇau iti aikapadyena vyākhyeyam
translated: Or, it should be explained as a single sentence: In Viṣṇu, which has difference with another as its counter-correlate.

analyzed: prayojanam tu uktam eva
translated: But the purpose is as stated.

analyzed: viṣṇau rāma kṛṣṇa ādi rūpe
translated: In Viṣṇu, in the form of Rāma, Kṛṣṇa, etc.

original: adhunātanairbhedo na dṛśyata iti parasyāpi sammatam /
analyzed: adhunātanaiḥ bhedaḥ na dṛśyate iti parasya api sammatam
translated: It is accepted by others also that difference is not seen by those of the present time.

analyzed: atas tad darśinām api iti uktam
translated: Therefore, it is said: even by those who see that.

analyzed: tṛtīyā arthe ṣaṣṭhī
translated: The genitive case is in the sense of the third case.

analyzed: avatāra darśibhiḥ api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even by those who see the incarnations.

analyzed: tad darśinām pratyakṣeṇa api iti vā
translated: Or, even by the perception of those who see that.

analyzed: svabhāvataḥ eva jīvāḥ trividhāḥ
translated: Living beings are naturally of three kinds.

analyzed: deva dānava mānava bhedāt
translated: Because of the distinction of gods, demons, and humans.

original: tatra daivaṃ pratyakṣaṃ tāvadavatārāṇāṃ parasparaṃ na bhedaṃ gocarayatīti bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: tatra daivam pratyakṣam tāvat avatārāṇām parasparam na bhedam gocarayati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: There, the direct perception of the divine, to begin with, does not present a difference among the incarnations, this is the idea.

analyzed: na kevalam etāvat kim tarhi iti atas āha pratyabhijñā eva iti
translated: Not only this much, but what else? To this he says 'recognition' etc.

analyzed: pratyabhijñā eva bahu rūpeṣu dṛśyate
translated: Recognition itself is seen in many forms.

original: uttamānāṃ puruṣāṇāṃ bhagavato bahurūpeṣu tadevedamityabhedaviṣayā pratyabhijñaiva purāṇādau dṛśyate /
analyzed: uttamānām puruṣāṇām bhagavataḥ bahu rūpeṣu tat eva idam iti abheda viṣayā pratyabhijñā eva purāṇa ādau dṛśyate
translated: In the case of the best men, in the many forms of the Lord, recognition of non-difference, 'that itself is this', is seen in the Puranas etc.

original: yathā jāmbavataḥ sa rāma evāyaṃ kṛṣṇa iti pratyabhijñā /
analyzed: yathā jāmbavataḥ sa rāmaḥ eva ayam kṛṣṇaḥ iti pratyabhijñā
translated: As the recognition of Jāmbavān, 'He is Rāma himself, this is Kṛṣṇa'.

analyzed: tathā ca kutas bheda jñānasya avakāśaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, how can there be scope for the knowledge of difference? This is the idea.

analyzed: nanu bahu tvam bhedena vinā anupapadyamānam tam ākṣipati
translated: But multiplicity, not being possible without difference, implies it.

original: tathā ca bahurūpeṣu pratyabhijñā na sambhavatyeva /
analyzed: tathā ca bahu rūpeṣu pratyabhijñā na sambhavati eva
translated: And thus recognition in many forms is not possible at all.

original: sambhavantī vā bhrāntiḥ syādityata āha bahutvaṃ ceti //
analyzed: sambhavantī vā bhrāntiḥ syāt iti atas āha bahu tvam ca iti
translated: Or if it is possible, it would be an illusion. To this he says 'multiplicity' etc.

analyzed: bahu tvam ca viśeṣeṇa
translated: And multiplicity with a particular...

analyzed: bhagavat rūpāṇām iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is 'of the forms of the Lord'.

analyzed: anyathā upapatti kuṇṭhita arthāpattiḥ na bhedam pramāpayati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that presumption, crippled by the possibility of another explanation, does not prove difference.

original: anyathāpyupapattipakṣe bhedasandehaḥ syātso 'pyaniṣya ityanyathaivopapattiṃ sūcayati na bhedeneti //
analyzed: anyathā api upapatti pakṣe bheda sandehaḥ syāt saḥ pi aniṣyaḥ iti anyathā eva upapattim sūcayati na bhedena iti
translated: If it were otherwise, there would be doubt about the difference, and that also is undesirable. Therefore, he indicates the possibility in another way, not by difference.

analyzed: na bhedena kathañcana
translated: Not by difference in any way...

analyzed: upapadyate iti ubhayatra śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is to be supplied in both places.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: bhagavat rūpāṇām bhede niravakāśa pramāṇa abhāvāt tad virodhāt ca
translated: Because there is no authoritative means of knowledge without scope for the difference of the forms of the Lord, and because it is contradicted by that.

analyzed: tat idam āha kathañcana iti
translated: This is what is meant by in any way...

original: evamuttamānāṃ puṃsāṃ bhagavadekarūpadarśanasamaye rūpāntarapratītāvasatyāṃ tato bhedajñānamasambhāvitam /
analyzed: evam uttamānām puṃsām bhagavat eka rūpa darśana samaye rūpa antara pratītau asatyām tatas bheda jñānam asambhāvitam
translated: Thus, when excellent men see the form of the Lord as one, and there is no cognition of another form, the knowledge of difference from that is not possible.

analyzed: pratiyogi jñāna abhāve bheda jñāna abhāvasya niyata tvāt
translated: Because the absence of the knowledge of difference is invariably absent when there is absence of the knowledge of the counter-correlate.

analyzed: satyām api tathā virodhinyāḥ pratyabhijñāyāḥ bhāvāt iti uktam
translated: And even when it is present, the recognition that contradicts it is present, as stated.

original: tathāpi madhyamādijanānāṃ pratyakṣaṃ bhagavadrūpabhede pramāṇaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: tathā api madhyama ādi janānām pratyakṣam bhagavat rūpa bhede pramāṇam bhaviṣyati
translated: Nevertheless, the perception of the people of the middle class and below will be a means of knowledge for the difference of the forms of the Lord.

analyzed: eka rūpa darśana samaye rūpa antara pratīti abhāve bheda darśana anupapattau api tad bhāve sambhavati eva
translated: Even when there is no cognition of another form at the time of seeing one form, the perception of difference is not possible, but when it is present, it is certainly possible.

analyzed: na ca teṣām api pratyabhijñā bhavadbhiḥ abhyupetum śakyate
translated: And they cannot accept recognition even in their case.

analyzed: uttama tva prasaṅgāt iti atas madhyamān apekṣya tāvat āha pratyabhijñā ca iti
translated: Because of the contingency of being the best, therefore, with reference to the middle [view], he says: And recognition...

original: pratyabhijñā ca yeṣāṃ na te 'pi tanmuṣyadṛṣṭayaḥ // / / //
analyzed: pratyabhijñā ca yeṣām na te tad muṣya dṛṣṭayaḥ
translated: And those who do not have recognition, they too do not see difference there.

analyzed: caḥ tu arthaḥ
translated: The word ca [means] and.

original: yeṣāṃ tu madhyamānāṃ janānāṃ pratyabhijñā bhagavadrūpeṣu nāsti te 'pi tatra bhedaṃ naiva paśyantīti yojanā /
analyzed: yeṣām tu madhyamānām janānām pratyabhijñā bhagavat rūpeṣu na asti te tatra bhedam na eva paśyanti iti yojanā
translated: But those people who are of the middle [view] and do not have recognition of the forms of the Lord, they too do not see difference there. This is the construction.

original: pratyabhijñābhāve kāraṇaṃ tena bhagavatā muṣyāpahatā dṛṣṭireṣāmiti /
analyzed: pratyabhijñā abhāve kāraṇam tena bhagavatā muṣya apahatā dṛṣṭiḥ eṣām iti
translated: The reason for the absence of recognition is that their vision is stolen away by that Lord.

original: tena bahutveneti vā /🔽bhagavadicchāyā teṣāṃ yogyatayā copodbalitaṃ bahutvamupalabhyamānaṃ pratīyamāne'pi
analyzed: tena bahu tvena iti vā  bhagavat icchāyā teṣām yogyatayā ca upodbalitam bahu tvam upalabhyamānam pratīyamāne pi
translated: Or by that multitude.

analyzed: vastuni vidyamānasya api abhedasya jñānam pratibadhnāti
translated: The multitude, which is perceived as being enhanced by the Lord's will and their capacity, even when the object is being cognized, obstructs the knowledge of non-difference, which exists.

analyzed: atra tad muṣya dṛṣṭayaḥ te pi iti anuvādāt tad muṣya dṛṣṭi tvāt pratyabhijñā eṣām na asti iti labhyate
translated: Here, because of the statement they too are those whose vision is stolen by that, it is understood that they do not have recognition because of having their vision stolen by that.

original: bhagavadrūpe bhedaṃ naiva paśyantītyukte ghaṭādibhyo 'pi bhedaṃ na paśyantīti mandasya pratītiḥ syāttāṃ nivārayitumāha bhedamiti //
analyzed: bhagavat rūpe bhedam na eva paśyanti iti ukte ghaṭa ādibhyaḥ pi bhedam na paśyanti iti mandasya pratītiḥ syāt tām nivārayitum āha bhedam iti
translated: When it is said that they do not see difference in the forms of the Lord, the dull-witted may think that they do not see difference even from pots and other things. To prevent that, he says difference...

original: bhedaṃ naiva prapaśyanti bhedamanyebhya eva ca /
analyzed: bhedam nā eva prapaśyanti bhedam anyebhyaḥ eva ca
translated: They do not see any difference at all, and others see only a difference from others.

analyzed: paśyanti evam hariḥ teṣām sandarśayati nā anyathā
translated: In this way, Hari shows them, not otherwise.

analyzed: anyebhyaḥ bhedam paśyanti eva ca iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: and others see only a difference from others.

original: nanu pratīyamānaṃ vastudvayaṃ bhedena vā pratīyate 'bhedena vā /
analyzed: nanu pratīyamānam vastu dvayam bhedena vā pratīyate bhedena vā
translated: But the two objects that are cognized are cognized either as different or as non-different.

original: bhedābhedodāsīnatayā tu pratītiḥ kathamityata āha evamiti //
analyzed: bheda abheda udāsīna tayā tu pratītiḥ katham iti atas āha evam iti
translated: But how is cognition possible as indifferent to difference and non-difference? To this he says thus.

analyzed: evam bṛhatsaṃhitāyām vacanam
translated: Thus, in the Brihat-samhita, there is a statement...

analyzed: teṣām yogyatā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is their fitness.

analyzed: anyathā gati buddhi ityādinā karma saṃjñāyām dvitīyā syāt
translated: Otherwise, in the case of the word karma, the accusative would be used in gati-buddhi.

analyzed: vibhakti vyatyayaḥ vā chāndasaḥ
translated: Or the inversion of case endings is Vedic.

analyzed: anyathā bhedena abhedena ca darśayati
translated: Otherwise, it shows both as different and non-different.

analyzed: yathā khalu akhyāta vādinām sahakāri sāmarthyāt bheda abheda audāsīnyena vastu pratītiḥ
translated: Just as for the non-dualists, the cognition of an object is indifferent to difference and non-difference due to the power of auxiliaries,

analyzed: yathā vā anyeṣām śuktikā śakala darśana anantaram vyāsaktau
translated: or just as for others, after seeing a piece of mother-of-pearl, there is attachment,

original: tathā parameśvaraśaktyātrāpi tathā pratītau ko virodhaḥ /
analyzed: tathā parameśvara śaktyā atrā api tathā pratītau kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: in the same way, here too, by the power of the Supreme Lord, if there is such cognition, what is the contradiction?

analyzed: adhama jīva pratyakṣasya tu anyā gatiḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: But for the perception of the lowest living being, there will be another way.

analyzed: evam īśvara rūpa bhede pratyakṣam nirākurvatā anumānam api nirākṛtam
translated: Thus, by denying the difference in the forms of God through perception, inference is also denied.

analyzed: bahu tvasya anyathā asiddheḥ ukta tvāt
translated: Because it has been shown that multiplicity is otherwise established.

analyzed: tad nyāyena ca ākāra viśeṣa ādīnām anyathā siddha tvāt iti
translated: And by that reasoning, the difference in aspects etc. is also otherwise established.

analyzed: vacanam asti iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is there is a statement.

analyzed: mā bhūt bhagavat rūpa bhedaḥ pratyakṣa anumāna siddhaḥ
translated: Let the difference in the forms of the Lord not be established by perception and inference.

analyzed: āgama siddhaḥ tu bhaviṣyati
translated: But it will be established by scripture.

analyzed: purāṇeṣu tatra tatra anya ādi śabda śravaṇāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is heard here and there in the Puranas with words like other, that is not so.

analyzed: na iha nānā asti kiñcana ityādi veda vākya virodhāt
translated: Because of the contradiction with Vedic statements like There is nothing different here at all.

original: purāṇameva vedasya kinna bādhakaṃ bhavatītyata āha neti //
analyzed: purāṇam eva vedasya kin na bādhakam bhavati iti atas āha na iti
translated: How can the Purana itself not be a contradiction to the Veda? To this he says no.

analyzed: na purāṇa gam
translated: Not the Purana.

analyzed: loka darśana vādī eva veda rodhāya śaknuyāt
translated: Only one who sees the world could be able to contradict the Veda.

analyzed: vacanam iti vartate
translated: Statement is understood.

original: purāṇavacanaṃ khalu lokānāṃ yadbhagavadrūpeṣu bhedadarśanaṃ tadanuvādaparameva /
analyzed: purāṇa vacanam khalu lokānām yat bhagavat rūpeṣu bheda darśanam tat anuvāda param eva
translated: The statement in the Purana is only a restatement of the people's view of the difference in the forms of the Lord.

analyzed: na vastu niṣṭham
translated: It is not about the real thing.

analyzed: upakrama ādinā tathā avagamāt
translated: Because it is understood as such by the introductory part etc.

analyzed: vedaḥ tu vastu tathātve tātparyavān
translated: But the Veda has the purport of the reality being so.

analyzed: liṅgaiḥ tathā adhyavasāyāt
translated: Because it is ascertained as such by the indications.

analyzed: atas na tat tat bādhanāya śaknoti
translated: Therefore it cannot contradict that.

analyzed: nanu etat vayāhatam
translated: But this is contradictory.

analyzed: yat prāk bhagavat rūpa bheda viṣayam pratyakṣam na asti iti uktam
translated: For it was said earlier that there is no perception regarding the difference in the forms of the Lord.

analyzed: idānīm tu tat asti iti
translated: But now it is said that it exists.

analyzed: tasya eva abhāve purāṇa vacanasya tad anuvādi tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because, in the absence of that, the statement in the Puranas cannot be explained as a restatement of it.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: bahu tva ādi anumāna ābhāsa janita bheda daśa rna anuvādi tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible to explain it as a restatement of the perception of difference produced by the fallacious inference of plurality etc.

analyzed: kiñca uttama madhyamānām bheda viṣayam pratyakṣam na asti iti abhihitam
translated: Moreover, it was stated that there is no perception regarding the difference between the best and the middling.

analyzed: adhamānām tu tat asti iti adhunā aṅgīkriyate
translated: But now it is accepted that the inferior have that.

original: tarhi tadeva bhagavadrūpabhede pramāṇaṃ bhaviṣyatītyapi na vācyam /
analyzed: tarhi tat eva bhagavat rūpa bhede pramāṇam bhaviṣyati iti api na vācyam
translated: Then it should not be said that that alone will be the means of knowing the difference in the forms of the Lord.

analyzed: uttamānām abheda viṣayeṇa pratyakṣeṇa bādhita tvāt
translated: Because it is contradicted by the perception of the best regarding non-difference.

analyzed: na ca tat eva na asti
translated: And that is not non-existent.

analyzed: pratyabhijñā eva bahu rūpeṣu dṛśyate iti āgama ukta tvāt
translated: Because it is said in the scriptures that recognition itself is seen in many forms.

original: tathāca bhīṣmavākyam /🔽tamimamahamajaṃ śarīrabhājāṃ hṛdi hṛdi viṣṭhitamātmakalpitānām /
analyzed: tathā ca bhīṣma vākyam  tam imam aham ajam śarīra bhājām hṛdi hṛdi viṣṭhitam ātma kalpitānām
translated: And so is the statement of Bhishma:

analyzed: pratidṛśam iva nā ekadhā arkam ekam samadhigataḥ smi vidhūta bheda mohaḥ
translated: I have realized that One, who is unborn, who is present in the heart of all embodied beings, who is divided into many forms like the sun, and who is free from the delusion of difference, by identifying Him with my own self.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus it is said.

original: atha bhedadarśanamevābhedadarśanasya bādhakaṃ kuto na bhavatītyata āha aparīkṣiteti //
analyzed: atha bheda darśanam eva abheda darśanasya bādhakam kutas na bhavati iti atas āha aparīkṣita iti
translated: Now, why is the view of difference not a sublater of the view of non-difference? To this he says 'not fully examined' etc.

analyzed: a parīkṣita dṛṣṭiḥ ca parīkṣā pūrva darśanam
translated: And the view not fully examined is the view preceded by examination.

analyzed: niṣeddhum śaknuvāt kvāpi
translated: It can somewhere refute...

analyzed: aparīkṣitā parīkṣayā pramāṇa tvena aniścitā
translated: Not fully examined means not ascertained as a means of valid knowledge by examination.

analyzed: na ityasya anukarṣaṇa arthaḥ caśabdaḥ  parīkṣā pūrvaḥ prāmāṇya niścayaḥ yasya darśanasya tat parīkṣā pūrva darśanam
translated: The word 'ca' is for the purpose of connecting 'na'.🔽That view which has examination preceding it, which has the ascertainment of validity preceding it, is the view preceded by examination.

original: parīkṣāpūrvaṃ darśanaṃ prāmāṇyaniścayo yasya pratyakṣasyeti vā /
analyzed: parīkṣā pūrvam darśanam prāmāṇya niścayaḥ yasya pratyakṣasya iti vā
translated: Or, that perception which has the ascertainment of validity preceded by examination.

analyzed: kvāpi iti anena niyamam āha
translated: By 'somewhere' he states the restriction.

original: tadanena yatparīkṣayā na niścitaprāmāṇyaṃ jñānaṃ na tannimittaprāmāṇyaṃ jñānāntaraṃ bādhata iti vyāptiruktā /
analyzed: tat anena yat parīkṣayā na niścita prāmāṇyam jñānam na tad nimitta prāmāṇyam jñāna antaram bādhate iti vyāptiḥ uktā
translated: By this he has stated the pervasion that knowledge whose validity is not ascertained by examination does not invalidate another knowledge whose validity is based on that.

analyzed: parīkṣā grahaṇam prāmāṇya niścaya upalakṣaṇam eva
translated: The mention of 'examination' is only for the purpose of illustrating the ascertainment of validity.

analyzed: na tu niyama artham iti uttaratra sphuṭībhaviṣyati  atra dṛṣṭāntam āha devadatta iti
translated: But not for the purpose of restriction, this will become clear later.🔽Here he gives an example with 'Devadatta' etc.

analyzed: vedadatta ādi dṛṣṭi vat
translated: Like the view of Devadatta and others...🔽...

original: yathā yajñadattādāvaniściprāmāṇyā devadattādidṛṣṭirna niścitaprāmāṇyāṃ yajñadattādidṛṣṭiṃ bādhate tathetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā yajñadatta ādau aniści prāmāṇyā devadatta ādi dṛṣṭiḥ na niścita prāmāṇyām yajñadatta ādi dṛṣṭim bādhate tathā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that just as the perception of Devadatta, whose validity is not ascertained, does not contradict the perception of Yajnadatta, whose validity is ascertained, in the same way.

analyzed: tatas kim yadi evam vyāptiḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked what follows if it is so, then the reply is:

analyzed: bheda darśanam aniścita prāmāṇyam abheda daśarnam tu niścita prāmāṇyam
translated: The perception of difference has uncertain validity, but the perception of non-difference has certain validity.

original: ato na tattasya bādhakaṃ kintu vaiparītyameveti vadāmaḥ /
analyzed: atas na tat tasya bādhakam kintu vaiparītyam eva iti vadāmaḥ
translated: Therefore, we say that it is not contradictory to that, but rather the opposite.

analyzed: kutas bheda darśanam aniścita prāmāṇyam iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: If it is asked how the perception of difference has uncertain validity, then the reply is:

original: na ca niścitabhedasya darśane 'sti purāṇagam /🔽vākyaṃ kvaciddhi / / / // / /c //
analyzed: na ca niścita bhedasya darśane sti purāṇa gam  vākyam kvacid hi
translated: And there is no ancient statement in the perception of a definitely different form.🔽A statement somewhere...

analyzed: caḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word ca (and) is for emphasis.

analyzed: kvacid pradeśe
translated: Somewhere means in some place.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The word hi (for) is for reason.

analyzed: parameśvara rūpa bheda viṣayam pratyakṣam tāvat asmākam purāṇa vākyāt eva siddham
translated: First of all, our perception of the difference in the form of the Supreme Lord is established only from the statements in the Puranas.

original: purāṇavākyaṃ ca kecidbhedaṃ paśyantīti vā pratipādayatu /
analyzed: purāṇa vākyam ca kecid bhedam paśyanti iti vā pratipādayatu
translated: And the statement in the Purana may either teach that some people see the difference,

analyzed: anuvādaka tayā liṅga tvena vā
translated: or it may be an indicator by way of restatement.

analyzed: atas tad prāmāṇya niścayaḥ tatas eva anveṣyavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the ascertainment of its validity must be sought from that itself.

analyzed: na ca bheda darśanasya prāmāṇyam niścāyayat purāṇa vākyam asti
translated: And there is no Purāṇa passage which ascertains the validity of the perception of difference.

original: ataḥ pramāṇābhāvānna bhedadaśarnasya prāmāṇyaniścaya iti bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: atas pramāṇa abhāvāt na prāmāṇya niścayaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, in the absence of any evidence, there is no certainty of the validity of the perception of difference - this is the idea.

analyzed: prāmāṇya niścayaḥ dvābhyām prakārābhyām bhavati
translated: The ascertainment of validity occurs in two ways.

analyzed: artha tathātva niścayena vā jñāna parīkṣayā vā
translated: Either by the ascertainment of the reality of the object, or by the examination of the knowledge.

analyzed: ādya abhiprāyeṇa uktam satya tayā niścita bhedasya iti
translated: With the first intention, it is said of that whose difference is ascertained as true.

original: dvitīyābhiprāyeṇa tu bhedasya darśana iti samāsaḥ /
analyzed: dvitīya abhiprāyeṇa tu bhedasya darśane iti samāsaḥ
translated: But with the second intention, the compound is perception of difference.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭhayā ākrośaḥ iti aluk
translated: The genitive is without the elision of the final a in ākraś.

original: niścitaṃ parīkṣitaṃ ca tadbhedasyadarśanaṃ ceti tathoktam /
analyzed: niścitam parīkṣitam ca tad bhedasya adarśanam ca iti tathā uktam
translated: That perception of difference is both ascertained and examined - thus it is said.

analyzed: tatra sva abhiprāyeṇa ākrośaḥ para abhiprāyeṇa niścita tvam iti avirodhaḥ  yadi purāṇa vākyāt eva
translated: There, the insult is with one's own intention, and the ascertainment is with the other's intention - thus there is no contradiction.

original: nniścitaprāmāṇyaṃ bhedadarśanaṃ na pratīyeta tarhi kīdṛśaṃ tatpratīyata ityata āha sammugdhamiti //
analyzed: niścita prāmāṇyam bheda darśanam na pratīyeta tarhi kīdṛśam tat pratīyate iti atas āha sammugdham iti
translated: If the perception of difference whose validity is ascertained is not understood even from the Purāṇa passage, then of what kind is it understood? To this he says mixed.

analyzed: sammugdha darśanam tatra gamyate
translated: The mixed perception is understood there.

analyzed: pramāṇa tva apramāṇa tvābhyām sandigdham
translated: It is doubtful due to being both valid and invalid.

analyzed: daśarnam bhedasya
translated: The perception of difference.

analyzed: tatra purāṇa vākye
translated: There, in the Puranic statement.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: purāṇa vākyam bheda darśana mātram gamayati
translated: The Puranic statement merely conveys the view of difference.

analyzed: na tu tasya prāmāṇyam aprāmāṇyam vā
translated: But it does not convey its validity or invalidity.

analyzed: tatas prāk abheda darśana avagamāt tatra prāmāṇya aprāmāṇya sandehaḥ eva yuktaḥ
translated: Therefore, before the understanding of the view of non-difference, doubt alone regarding its validity and invalidity is proper.

analyzed: avagate tu abheda darśane tasya aprāmāṇyam eva niścīyate
translated: But when the view of non-difference is understood, its invalidity alone is ascertained.

analyzed: purāṇa vākyāt eva tad prāmāṇyasya niścita tvāt
translated: Because its validity is ascertained only from the Puranic statement itself.

analyzed: samadhigataḥ asmi iti saṃśabda śravaṇāt
translated: Because the word samādhi is heard, meaning I am realized.

analyzed: hṛdi hṛdi nā ekadhā sthitam api iti anumānānām ābhāsa tvasya ukta tvāt
translated: And because it is said that the inferences are fallacious, even though they exist in many ways in the heart of each individual.

analyzed: vidhūta bheda mohaḥ iti bheda jñānasya moha tva abhidhānāt ca iti
translated: And because the knowledge of difference is said to be delusion, in the words vidhūta-bheda-moha.

analyzed: evam bhagavat rūpeṣu bheda abhāvaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: Thus the absence of difference in the forms of the Lord is established.

analyzed: tathā vedha ādi doṣa abhāvaḥ ca
translated: Similarly, the absence of defects like piercing is also established.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no means of valid knowledge (to prove their existence).

analyzed: nanu asti tad darśi tā pratyakṣam atra pramāṇam
translated: But is not perception, which perceives them, a means of valid knowledge here?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, it is not so.

analyzed: mahatām pratyakṣeṇa vedha ādi abhāva grāhiṇā bādhita tvāt
translated: Because it is contradicted by the perception of great souls, which grasps the absence of piercing etc.

original: idameva tasya bādhakaṃ kinna syādityata āha aparīkṣitameveti //
analyzed: idam eva tasya bādhakam kim na syāt iti atas āha aparīkṣitam eva iti
translated: How can this alone be its contradiction? To this he says it is only untested.

analyzed: aparīkṣitam eva atra vedha ādikam adhīśituḥ
translated: The piercing etc. of the Lord here is not examined.

analyzed: parīkṣā darśane nā eva dṛśyate kenacid kvacid
translated: In the doctrine of examination, it is not seen by anyone anywhere.

analyzed: atra vedha ādi doṣa
translated: Here, the fault of piercing etc.

analyzed: tad abhāvayoḥ madhye
translated: between the absence of that.

analyzed: adhīśituḥ atra avatāreṣu iti vā
translated: Or, in the incarnations of the Lord here.

analyzed: dṛśyate iti sambandhaḥ  yat vā vedha ādikam iti tat darśanam upalakṣyate
translated: The connection is is seen.🔽Or, the piercing etc. is indicative of the seeing of that.

analyzed: parīkṣayā yuktam darśanam parīkṣā darśanam
translated: The doctrine that is associated with examination is the doctrine of examination.

analyzed: yat vā parīkṣyate iti parīkṣā
translated: Or, it is examined, therefore it is an examination.

analyzed: guroḥ ca ha laḥ iti akāra pratyayaḥ
translated: And the suffix a is added to the guru and the हल.

analyzed: parīkṣā ca tat daśa ṛnam ca tasmin
translated: And that examination and that doctrine are in that.

analyzed: dṛśyate vedha ādikam kvacid
translated: The piercing etc. is seen somewhere.

analyzed: doṣa darśanam aparīkṣitam nirdeṣa tva darśanam tu parīkṣitam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the seeing of faults is unexamined, but the seeing of faultlessness is examined.

original: nanu doṣābhāvaviṣayaṃ mahatāṃ pratyakṣaṃ tāvatkutaḥ siddhamityata āha nirdeṣameveti //
analyzed: nanu doṣa abhāva viṣayam mahatām pratyakṣam tāvat kutas siddham iti atas āha nirdeṣam eva iti
translated: But how is the perception of the great ones, which has the absence of faults as its object, established? To this he says faultless etc.

analyzed: nirdoṣam eva tam brahmā dadarśa aśeṣa rūpiṇam
translated: Brahma saw him, who is faultless and has all forms.

analyzed: nirdoṣam eva rudraḥ drāk nirdoṣam tam purandaraḥ
translated: Rudra saw him, who is faultless. Indra saw him, who is faultless.

analyzed: nirdoṣāṇi asya rūpāṇi dṛṣṭāni evam sura uttamaiḥ
translated: The faultless forms of him are thus seen by the best of gods.

analyzed: anye sa doṣāḥ sarve nirdoṣaḥ hariḥ ekalaḥ
translated: Others are faulty, but Hari alone is faultless.

analyzed: iti barku śruteḥ ca eva sa doṣam na asya darśanam
translated: And also because of the statement of Bārka, his view is not faulty.

analyzed: adrāk adrākṣīt
translated: Adrāk, he saw.

analyzed: anityam āgama śāsanam iti vacanāt
translated: Because of the statement The scriptures are impermanent.

analyzed: purandaraḥ drākṣīt
translated: Purandara saw.

analyzed: anyaiḥ api sura uttamaiḥ
translated: And by other best gods.

analyzed: sa doṣāḥ dṛṣṭāḥ
translated: They saw as faulty.

analyzed: tasmāt hariḥ ekaḥ eva
translated: Therefore, Hari alone is faultless.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ śruti antara samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) is for the purpose of including another scripture.

original: asya parameśvarasya viṣaye mahatāṃ darśanaṃ sadoṣaṃ doṣagrāhi naiva /
analyzed: asya parameśvarasya viṣaye mahatām darśanam sa doṣam doṣa grāhi na eva
translated: In the matter of this Supreme Lord, the vision of the great ones is not faulty, not grasping faults.

analyzed: kintu nirdeṣam eva gṛhṇāti iti
translated: But it grasps only what is faultless.

original: doṣadaśarnamaparīkṣitaṃ tadabhāvadarśanaṃ tu parīkṣitametatkuta ityata āha aviddha iti //🔽aviddho viddhavad viṣṇurajāto jātavanmṛṣā /
analyzed: tad abhāva darśanam tu parīkṣitam etat kutas iti atas āha aviddhaḥ iti  a viddhaḥ viddha vat viṣṇuḥ a jātaḥ jāta vat mṛṣā
translated: The vision of faults is unscrutinized, but the vision of their absence is scrutinized. Where is this from? Therefore it is said aviddha (unpierced).

analyzed: abaddhaḥ baddha vat ca eva darśayati amita dyutiḥ
translated: The infinite-radiant Viṣṇu displays himself as if pierced, though unpierced, as if born, though unborn, as if bound, though unbound.

analyzed: iti paiṅgi śrutiḥ ca eva prāha nirdoṣa tām hareḥ
translated: Thus the Paiṅgi Śruti also declares the faultlessness of Hari.

analyzed: a viddham iva viddha vat
translated: As if unpierced, he is as if pierced.

analyzed: chāndasaḥ dvitīyā antāt vatiḥ
translated: The secondary suffix vati ending in the second case is Vedic.

analyzed: eva śabdasya āviddhaḥ ityādinā sambandhaḥ
translated: The word eva (only) is connected with aviddha (unpierced) and so on.

analyzed: darśayati ātmānam
translated: He displays Himself.

analyzed: pūrva śrutyā api ayam arthaḥ rthāt siddhayati iti paiṅgi śrutiḥ ca iti uktam
translated: It has been said that this meaning is established by implication from the previous hearing, and also by the Paiṅgi śruti.

analyzed: phala uktyā vivakṣitam artham upalakṣayati
translated: By stating the result, freedom from faults, he indicates the intended meaning.

original: atraiva spaṣṭāṃ śrutimudāharati aparīkṣiteti //🔽aparīkṣitadṛṣṭayaiva sadoṣo dṛśyate hariḥ /
analyzed: atra eva spaṣṭām śrutim udāharati aparīkṣitā iti  aparīkṣita dṛṣṭayā eva sa doṣaḥ dṛśyate hariḥ
translated: Here itself, he cites a clear śruti: Apa-ri-kṣita etc.🔽Hari is seen to have faults only by an uncritical view.

original: parīkṣādarśane naiva dṛśyo doṣo hareḥ kvacit /
analyzed: parīkṣā darśane nā eva dṛśyaḥ doṣaḥ hareḥ kvacid
translated: By a critical view, no fault of Hari is seen anywhere.

analyzed: iti paiṅgi śrutiḥ ca āha
translated: Thus says the Paiṅgi śruti.

analyzed: āha doṣa darśanasya aparīkṣita tvam nirdeṣa tā darśanasya parīkṣita tvam ca
translated: He says that the perception of faults is uncritical, and the perception of freedom from faults is critical.

original: tataḥ kimityata āha pramāṇaṃ hīti //🔽pramāṇaṃ hi parīkṣitam // / / //
analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha pramāṇam hi iti  pramāṇam hi parīkṣitam
translated: What then? To this he says For, only what is critical is valid etc.🔽For, only what is critical is valid.

original: yatparīkṣitaṃ parīkṣayā pramāṇatvenāvadhṛtaṃ tadeva pramāṇam /🔽aparīkṣitaṃ tvāpātataḥ sandigdham /
analyzed: yat parīkṣitam parīkṣayā pramāṇa tvena avadhṛtam tat eva pramāṇam  aparīkṣitam tu āpātataḥ sandigdham
translated: What is critical, determined to be valid by examination, that alone is valid.🔽What is uncritical is prima facie doubtful.

analyzed: niścita virodhi upanipāte tu apramāṇam eva
translated: When contradictory evidence is encountered, it is simply invalid.

analyzed: atas parīkṣitena nirdeṣa tā darśanena aparīkṣitam doṣa darśanam eva bādhyate
translated: Therefore, the uncritical perception of faults is indeed contradicted by the critical perception of freedom from faults.

analyzed: na tu viparyayaḥ
translated: But there is no reversal.

analyzed: prāmāṇya niścaye parīkṣā upayogaḥ pramāṇa siddhaḥ iti hi śabdaḥ
translated: The word 'hi' (for) indicates that the usefulness of examination in the ascertainment of validity is established by valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyate
translated: And this will be stated.

analyzed: atra kecid āhuḥ
translated: Here some say:

analyzed: svatas eva jñānānām prāmāṇyam gṛhyate
translated: The validity of cognitions is grasped by itself

analyzed: na tu parīkṣā adhīnam
translated: and not dependent on examination.

analyzed: sakalam api jñānam sva prakāśam yathārtham ca
translated: All cognitions are self-luminous and true.

original: ataḥ svenaiva svayaṃ svaprāmāṇyaṃ ca siddhayati kā tatra parīkṣāpekṣeti /
analyzed: atas svena eva svayam sva prāmāṇyam ca siddhayati kā tatra parīkṣā apekṣā iti
translated: Therefore, its own validity is established by itself alone. What need is there for examination there?

analyzed: anye tu bruvate
translated: But others say:

analyzed: jñānam tad prāmāṇyam ca anumānena eva gṛhyate iti
translated: The cognition and its validity are grasped only by inference.

analyzed: apare tu vadanti
translated: But others say:

original: jñānaṃ tatprāmāṇyaṃ ca sākṣiṇaiva jñāyata iti /
analyzed: jñānam tad prāmāṇyam ca sākṣiṇā eva jñāyate iti
translated: The cognition and its validity are known only by the witness.

original: yadi ca svataḥprāmāṇyagraho na syāttarhi na syādeva /
analyzed: yadi ca svatas prāmāṇya grahaḥ na syāt tarhi na syāt eva
translated: And if the grasping of validity were not from itself, then it would not exist at all.

analyzed: tasya parīkṣā adhīna tve navasthā prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if it were dependent on examination, there would be the fallacy of infinite regress.

original: anumānaviśeṣaḥ khalu parīkṣā nāma /🔽tatprāmāṇyāvadhāraṇaṃ ca parīkṣāntareṇeti kathaṃ nānavasthā syāditi /
analyzed: anumāna viśeṣaḥ khalu parīkṣā nāma  tad prāmāṇya avadhāraṇam ca parīkṣā antareṇa iti katham nā anavasthā syāt iti
translated: For examination is a particular kind of inference.🔽And the ascertainment of its validity by another examination - how could there not be an infinite regress?

analyzed: tatra pāmāṇya grahasya parīkṣā adhīna tve navasthā prasaṅgam tāvat pariharati na iti
translated: There, he first avoids the fallacy of infinite regress in the dependence of the grasping of validity on examination.

analyzed: na parīkṣā anavasthā syāt
translated: There would be no infinite regress of examination.

analyzed: prāmāṇya grahaṇasya parīkṣā adhīna tva aṅgīkāre pi iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: even if the acceptance of the apprehension of validity is admitted to be dependent on examination.

analyzed: tatra hetum āha sākṣī iti
translated: There, he states the reason with the witness etc.

analyzed: sākṣi siddhe tu asaṃśayāt
translated: But when established by the witness, because of the absence of doubt.

analyzed: dvividham khalu jñānam antaḥkaraṇa pariṇāma rūpam sākṣi rūpam ca iti
translated: Indeed, knowledge is of two kinds: that which is in the form of a transformation of the internal organ, and that which is in the form of the witness.

analyzed: tatra ādyāt viśeṣyum tuśabdaḥ
translated: There, the word but refers to the object of the first, which is of two kinds.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

analyzed: syāt iyam anavasthā yadi parīkṣā apekṣā syāt
translated: This infinite regress would be if there were a need for examination everywhere.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: sandigdhe khalu arthe parīkṣā apekṣyate na tu asandigdhe
translated: For, doubt is indeed required in regard to a doubtful object, but not in regard to a non-doubtful one.

original: saṃśayaśca manovṛttiviṣaye pānīyādau bhavati na punaḥ sākṣisiddhe sukhādau /
analyzed: saṃśayaḥ ca manaḥ vṛtti viṣaye pānīya ādau bhavati na punar sākṣi siddhe sukha ādau
translated: And doubt occurs in regard to water etc., which are the objects of mental modifications, but not in regard to pleasure etc., which are established by the witness.

original: atastāvadeva parīkṣā yāvatsākṣigṛhīteṣu sukhādiṣvavatāra iti kuto 'navastheti /
analyzed: atas tāvat eva parīkṣā yāvat sākṣi gṛhīteṣu sukha ādiṣu avatāraḥ iti kutas navasthā iti
translated: Therefore, there is examination only as long as there is entry into pleasure etc., which are grasped by the witness. How then is there an infinite regress?

analyzed: prapañcitaḥ ca ayam arthaḥ smābhiḥ prakṛti adhikaraṇe
translated: And this matter has been discussed by us in the Prakṛtyādhikaraṇa (Topic on Nature etc.).

original: manovṛttiviṣaya eva saṃśayo na sākṣisiddha ityatra kiṃ kāraṇamityata āha mānasa iti //
analyzed: manaḥ vṛtti viṣayaḥ eva saṃśayaḥ na sākṣi siddhaḥ iti atra kim kāraṇam iti atas āha mānasaḥ iti
translated: Here, what is the reason that doubt is only in the object of mental modification, not in what is established by the witness? To this he says mental etc.

analyzed: mānase darśane doṣāḥ syuḥ na vai sākṣi darśane
translated: In the mental perception, there may be faults, but not in the perception by the witness.

analyzed: manaḥ pariṇati rūpe doṣāḥ kāraṇatayā sambhāvitāḥ syuḥ
translated: The faults, in the form of modifications of the mind, may be suspected as the cause.

analyzed: vaiśabda stuśabda arthe
translated: The word 'va' (but) has the sense of 'tu' (however).

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ  dvividhaḥ hi saṃśayaḥ bhavati
translated: This is the meaning.🔽For doubt is of two kinds.

analyzed: ekaḥ tāvat āditas eva
translated: First, there is doubt from the very beginning.

analyzed: yathā sthāṇuḥ vā ayam puruṣaḥ vā iti
translated: For example, Is this a post or a man?

analyzed: aparaḥ tu niścaya pṛṣṭhabhāvī  yathā
translated: Second, there is doubt that arises after certainty.

analyzed: pratīyate sthāṇuḥ bhavati na vā iti
translated: For example, This is perceived as a post, but is it a post or not?

analyzed: tatra ādyaḥ viśeṣa adarśana ādi doṣa mūlaḥ
translated: Among these, the first arises from faults such as not seeing the distinction.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ pi prathama jñānasya doṣa janya tva śaṅkā mūlaḥ
translated: The second also arises from the suspicion that the first knowledge is produced by faults.

analyzed: doṣāḥ ca mānase eva darśane sambhavanti
translated: And faults are possible only in mental perception.

original: atastatsaṃśayātmakaṃ vā jāyate niścayatayā jātasya viṣaye vā āhāyarḥ saṃśayo bhavati /🔽natu sākṣisiddhe
analyzed: atas tat saṃśaya ātmakam vā jāyate niścaya tayā jātasya viṣaye vā saṃśayaḥ bhavati  na tu sākṣi siddhe
translated: Therefore, doubt arises either in the form of doubt about that, or doubt arises later regarding the object that was perceived with certainty.

original: darśane doṣasambhavaḥ /🔽ato na tatsaṃśayātmakaṃ nāpi sākṣisiddhe
analyzed: darśane doṣa sambhavaḥ  atas na tat saṃśaya ātmakam na api sākṣi siddhe
translated: But faults cannot arise in the perception established by the witness.

analyzed: tad siddhe rthe saṃśayaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, there is no doubt in the form of doubt about that, nor is there doubt regarding the object established by that, which is established by the witness.

analyzed: mānase darśane doṣāḥ sambhavanti iti sphuṭam
translated: It is clear that faults can arise in mental perception.

original: sākṣidarśane na sambhavantītyetatkuta ityata āha sudṛḍha iti //
analyzed: sākṣi darśane na sambhavanti iti etat kutas iti atas āha su dṛḍhe iti
translated: How is it known that they are not possible in the case of perception by the witness? To this he says: 'Very firm' etc.

original: sudṛḍho nirṇayo yatra jñeyaṃ tat sākṣidarśanam // / / //
analyzed: su dṛḍhaḥ nirṇayaḥ yatra jñeyam tat sākṣi darśanam
translated: That in which there is a very firm ascertainment, that should be known as perception by the witness.

analyzed: su dṛḍhaḥ kadāpi bādha rahitaḥ  nirṇayaḥ va dhāraṇa ātmakaḥ pratyayaḥ
translated: Very firm means never contradicted.🔽Ascertainment is a cognition having the nature of determination.

analyzed: yatra iti nipātaḥ yaḥ iti arthe
translated: The word 'yatra' (in which) means 'yaḥ' (who).

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: doṣāḥ tāvat jñānasya ḍolāyamāna tā darśanena balavat bādhaka upanipātena vā kalpyāḥ
translated: Defects can be postulated either by seeing the oscillation of knowledge or by the occurrence of a strong contradiction.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it has been said:

original: balavatpramāṇataśca'ścaiva jñeyā doṣā na cānyatā' iti /
analyzed: balavat pramāṇataḥ caḥ ca eva jñeyāḥ doṣāḥ na ca anya tā iti
translated: Defects should be known as arising from strong means of knowledge, not from anything else.

original: sākṣidarśanaṃ ca nirṇayātmakameva bhavati na ca bādhyata ityupapāditaṃ pṛthagadhikaraṇe /
analyzed: sākṣi darśanam ca nirṇaya ātmakam eva bhavati na ca bādhyate iti upapāditam pṛthak adhikaraṇe
translated: And it has been established in a separate section that perception by the witness is only of the nature of ascertainment and is not contradicted.

analyzed: atas pramāṇa abhāvāt na tatra doṣaḥ sambhavati
translated: Therefore, due to the absence of a means of knowledge, defects are not possible in that case.

original: sākṣisiddhe 'rthe saṃśayo nāstītyuktaṃ tadanubhavārūḍhaṃ kartuṃ sākṣisiddhamarthaṃ tāvadāha iccheti //
analyzed: sākṣi siddhe rthe saṃśayaḥ na asti iti uktam tad anubhava ārūḍham kartum sākṣi siddham artham tāvat āha icchā iti
translated: It has been said that there is no doubt regarding an object established by the witness. To make this understood through experience, he first states the object established by the witness, saying 'desire' etc.

analyzed: icchā jñānam sukham duḥkha bhaya abhaya kṛpā ādayaḥ
translated: Desire, knowledge, pleasure, pain, fear, fearlessness, compassion etc.

analyzed: sākṣi siddhā
translated: Are established by the witness.

analyzed: ādi padena prayatna dveṣau etad abhāvāḥ ca gṛhyante
translated: The word 'ādi' includes effort, aversion, and the absence of these.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha na iti
translated: What then? To this he says 'no'.

analyzed: na kaścid hi tatra saṃśayavān kvacid
translated: For no one is ever doubtful about anything anywhere.

analyzed: tatra kvacid iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is 'there, somewhere'.

original: na jātu mama sukhamasti na veti saṃśayo nāpi pratīyamānamidaṃ sukhaṃ sadasadveti saṃśaya iti hiśabdenāha /
analyzed: na jātu mama sukham asti na vā iti saṃśayaḥ nā api pratīyamānam idam sukham sat asat vā iti saṃśayaḥ iti hi śabdena āha
translated: The word 'hi' means that there is never doubt like 'I have no happiness' or 'I have', nor is there doubt like 'this happiness that is being experienced is real or unreal'.

analyzed: sākṣi darśanam abādhitam eva iti na yujyate śukti rajata ādau bādha darśanāt
translated: The perception by the witness is not contradicted. This is not proper, because there is contradiction in the case of silver in a shell.

original: nahi pratītisamayamātravartini tatrānyajñānaṃ sambhavatītyata āha yadīti // /
analyzed: nahi pratīti samaya mātra vartini tatra anya jñānam sambhavati iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: For at that time, when it is present only at the time of cognition, another cognition is not possible. Therefore he says 'if' etc.

original: yat kvacid vyabhicārī syād darśanaṃ mānasaṃ hi tat // / / //
analyzed: yat kvacid vyabhicārī syāt darśanam mānasam hi tat
translated: That mental perception which would be contradicted somewhere,

original: yaddarśanaṃ kvacicchuktirajatādau viṣaye vyabhicāri bādhitaṃ syāttaccakṣurādikaraṇakaṃ manaḥpariṇatirūpameva na sākṣirūpam /
analyzed: yat darśanam kvacid śukti rajata ādau viṣaye vyabhicāri bādhitam syāt tat cakṣuḥ ādi karaṇakam manaḥ pariṇati rūpam eva na sākṣi rūpam
translated: That perception which would be contradicted, contradicted, somewhere in an object like silver in a shell, that is only a transformation of the mind with the eye etc. as its instrument, not of the nature of the witness.

analyzed: kutas etat
translated: Why is this?
Because there is no undesirable consequence if the mental perception is accepted as contradicted.

analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ tu tathātve sarva vyavahāra vilopa prasaṅgasya ukta tvāt
translated: But if the witness were so, it would lead to the cessation of all transactions. This has been stated.

analyzed: tat idam uktam hi śabdena  sambhavati ca asya mānasa tvam anyathā khyāti samarthanāt iti
translated: This is what is meant by the word 'hi' (in the original text).🔽And it is possible for this (error) to be mental, because the theory of misapprehension is established.

analyzed: mānasasya darśanasya doṣa bādha sambhavaḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: The possibility of defect and sublation of mental perception has been stated.

original: kīdṛśasya tarhi prāmāṇyamityata āha mana iti //🔽manaścakṣurdarśanāderapi yatraiva sākṣiṇā /
analyzed: kīdṛśasya tarhi prāmāṇyam iti atas āha manaḥ iti  manaḥ cakṣuḥ darśana ādeḥ api yatra eva sākṣiṇā
translated: Of what kind then is the validity? To this he says 'The mind' etc.

analyzed: prāmāṇyam su gṛhītam syāt tat parīkṣita darśanam
translated: Even of the perception of the mind and the eye, where the validity is well ascertained by the witness, that perception is examined.

analyzed: manaḥ cakṣuḥ śabdau śrotra ādeḥ upalakṣakau
translated: The words 'mind' and 'eye' are suggestive of the ear etc.

analyzed: darśanam sākṣātkāraḥ  ādi padena laiṅgika śabda jñāna saṅgrahaḥ
translated: Perception is direct cognition.🔽By the word 'etc.' is included inferential and verbal cognition.

analyzed: indriya liṅga śabda karaṇakasya manaḥ vṛtteḥ jñānasya iti atharḥ
translated: The meaning is: of the cognition which is a modification of the mind, produced by the senses, inferential marks and words.

analyzed: nirdhāraṇe ṣaṣṭhī
translated: The genitive case is used in the sense of determination.

original: sambhāvitadoṣabādhasyāpītyaperarthaḥ /🔽yatra jñāne sugṛhītaṃ parīkṣayā niścitaṃ tatparīkṣitadarśanaṃ pramāṇamiti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: sambhāvita doṣa bādhasya api iti apeḥ arthaḥ  yatra jñāne su gṛhītam parīkṣayā niścitam tat parīkṣita darśanam pramāṇam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The word 'api' (even) means 'of that which is suspected of having defects and sublation'.🔽That cognition in which the validity is well ascertained, i.e., determined by examination, that examined perception is valid, is the remainder.

analyzed: pratyakṣa āgama jñāna prāmāṇya grahaṇe eva parīkṣā upayogaḥ
translated: The use of examination is only in the ascertainment of the validity of perception and scriptural cognition.

original: dharmijñānānumānopamānānuvyavasāyānāṃ tu prāmāṇyagrahaṇaṃ na parīkṣāpekṣamiti kecinmanyante /
analyzed: dharmi jñāna anumāna upamāna anuvyavasāyānām tu prāmāṇya grahaṇam na parīkṣā apekṣam iti kecid manyante
translated: But some think that the apprehension of the validity of the knowledge of the object, inference, comparison, and introspection, does not depend on examination.

analyzed: tad nirāsāya sarva mānasa saṅgraha artham manaḥ cakṣuḥ darśana ādeḥ madhye iti uktam
translated: To refute that and to include all mental cognitions, it is said in the middle of the vision of the mind and the eye.

analyzed: anyathā yatra jñāne ityādikam eva avakṣyat
translated: Otherwise, he would have said only where there is knowledge and so on.

analyzed: pramāṇam iti etāvatā pūrṇe parīkṣita darśanam iti anuvādena su gṛhītam iti etat vivṛṇoti
translated: That alone is the means of valid knowledge - this much being complete, by way of reiteration of examined vision, well-apprehended is explained.

original: evaṃ mānasapratyakṣādijñānaprāmāṇyagrahasya parīkṣādhīnatve 'pi sākṣiprāmāṇyagrahasya tadanapekṣatvānna parīkṣānavasthetyuktam /
analyzed: evam mānasa pratyakṣa ādi jñāna prāmāṇya grahasya parīkṣā adhīna tve pi sākṣi prāmāṇya grahasya tad anapekṣa tvāt na parīkṣā anavasthā iti uktam
translated: Thus, even though the apprehension of the validity of mental perception and other knowledge is dependent on examination, since the apprehension of the validity of the witness is independent of that, there is no infinite regress of examination, it is said.

analyzed: tatra kim anayā dvividha kalpanayā
translated: Then, what is the use of this twofold assumption?

original: sākṣivatpratyakṣādijñānasyāpi prāmāṇyagrahaḥ parīkṣānapekṣa evoktavidhayā svataḥ kinna syādityāśaṅkāṃ pariharati neti //
analyzed: sākṣi vat pratyakṣa ādi jñānasya api prāmāṇya grahaḥ parīkṣā anapekṣaḥ eva ukta vidhayā svatas kim na syāt iti āśaṅkām pariharati na iti
translated: Just as in the case of the witness, why cannot the apprehension of the validity of perception and other knowledge also be self-evident, independent of examination, in the manner stated? This doubt is being resolved by saying no.

analyzed: na jñāna dṛṣṭi mātreṇa prāmāṇyam tasya dṛśyate
translated: The validity of that is not seen merely by the vision of the knowledge.

analyzed: jñānasya dṛṣṭiḥ jñāna dṛṣṭiḥ
translated: The vision of knowledge.

analyzed: tasya jñānasya
translated: Of that knowledge.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: vṛtti jñānānām sva prakāśa tvam eva tāvat asat
translated: The self-luminosity of the means of knowledge is itself false.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no proof.

analyzed: jñāna vyavahārasya sākṣi vedya tvena eva upapatteḥ
translated: Because the usage of knowledge is logically possible only as known by the witness.

analyzed: idam aham jānāmi iti anubhavasya sākṣi rūpa tvāt
translated: Because the experience I know this has the nature of the witness.

analyzed: vimatam jñānam na sva prakāśam anātma tvāt kārya tvāt anitya tvāt manaḥ rūpa tvāt sukha ādi vat ityādi pramāṇa virodhāt ca
translated: And because there is contradiction with proofs such as The knowledge in question is not self-luminous, because it is not the self, because it is an effect, because it is non-eternal, because it is of the nature of the mind, like pleasure etc.

original: bhavatu vā jñānaṃ svaprakāśaṃ tathāpi svarūpamātra eva na tu svadharme prāmāṇye 'pi /
analyzed: bhavatu vā jñānam sva prakāśam tathā api svarūpa mātre eva na tu svadharme prāmāṇye
translated: Even if knowledge is accepted to be self-luminous, it is so only in its own form, not in its own property of validity.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

original: vedavākyaśravaṇe sati bāhyasya vākyārthajñānamutpadyate na vā /
analyzed: veda vākya śravaṇe sati bāhyasya vākya artha jñānam utpadyate na vā
translated: When the Vedic sentence is heard, does external knowledge of the sentence meaning arise or not?

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: satyām sāmagṣām kārya anudaya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is illogical for an effect not to arise when the assemblage of causes is present.

analyzed: anyathā mīmāṃsakasya api tad anudaya prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, even for the Mimamsaka, it would not arise.

analyzed: ādye tat prakāśate na vā
translated: Even in the first case, does that [knowledge] manifest or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣe
translated: If not, it contradicts one's own doctrine.

analyzed: prathame tad prāmāṇyam prakāśate na vā
translated: In the first case, does the validity of that [knowledge] manifest or not?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ  tad nirāsasya anu
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: sā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the refutation of that [invalidity] would follow.🔽Because it is illogical.

original: tato jñānadṛṣṭimātreṇa na jñānaprāmāṇyaṃ dṛśyata iti dvitīya evāṅgīkāryaḥ /
analyzed: tatas jñāna dṛṣṭi mātreṇa na jñāna prāmāṇyam dṛśyate iti dvitīyaḥ eva aṅgīkāryaḥ
translated: Therefore, since the validity of knowledge is not seen merely by the eye of knowledge, the second alternative alone must be accepted.

original: tathāca svaprakāśajñānenaiva prāmāṇyagraha iti kathaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā ca sva prakāśa jñānena eva prāmāṇya grahaḥ iti katham syāt
translated: And thus, how can it be that the apprehension of validity is only by the self-luminous knowledge?

original: apauruṣeyatvādiyuktibhiḥ prabodhito bāhyaḥ pratipadyate ca tatprāmāṇyamiti kathaṃ na parīkṣāpekṣatvam /
analyzed: apauruṣeya tva ādi yuktibhiḥ prabodhitaḥ bāhyaḥ pratipadyate ca tat prāmāṇyam iti katham na parīkṣā apekṣa tvam
translated: And since the external [person] is awakened by reasons such as being not of human origin, and understands that [scripture] is valid, how is it not dependent on examination?

original: anyathā vaidikajñānaprāmāṇye vipratipattireva na syāt jñānasvarūpavat /
analyzed: anyathā vaidika jñāna prāmāṇye vipratipattiḥ eva na syāt jñāna svarūpa vat
translated: Otherwise, there would be no disagreement even about the validity of Vedic knowledge, just as [there is none] about the nature of knowledge itself.

analyzed: kiñca evaṃvādinaḥ mate śukti rajata ādi vibhramaḥ na syāt
translated: Moreover, in the view of one who speaks thus, there would be no error such as silver in a shell.

original: idamanubhavasya rajatasmaraṇasya ca bhedāgraho hi vibhramaḥ /
analyzed: idam anubhavasya rajata smaraṇasya ca bheda agrahaḥ hi vibhramaḥ
translated: For error is the non-apprehension of the difference between this experience and the memory of silver.

analyzed: tatra prāmāṇya vat bhedasya anubhava tva smaraṇa tvayoḥ ca prakāśaḥ vaśyambhāvi iti katham vibhrama avakāśaḥ
translated: There, just as validity, so the manifestation of difference, of being an experience, and of being a memory, is necessarily present. How then is there room for error?

analyzed: nahi prāmāṇyasya bheda ādeḥ ca kaścid viśeṣaḥ sti iti
translated: For there is no difference at all between validity and the difference, etc.

analyzed: jñāna prāmāṇye saha eva anumeye iti api asat
translated: It is also not correct to say that the validity of knowledge is to be inferred along with [the knowledge itself].

analyzed: jñānasya apya  nu meya tve pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because knowledge itself🔽is not to be inferred, there being no evidence for it.

analyzed: tad vayavahārasya anyathā eva upapatteḥ
translated: Because the usage of that [knowledge] is otherwise possible.

analyzed: āśutara vināśinaḥ jñānasya jānāmi iti vartamāna tayā pratibhāsā  nupapatteḥ ca
translated: And because it is not possible for knowledge, which is destroyed very quickly, to appear as the present in the form I know.

analyzed: a parokṣa avabhāsa virodhāt ca
translated: And because it is contradictory to the appearance of non-obscuration.

original: anumeyatve 'pi jñānasya na jñānānumitimātreṇa prāmāṇyaṃ tasya dṛśyate /
analyzed: anumeya tve pi jñānasya na jñāna anumiti mātreṇa prāmāṇyam tasya dṛśyate
translated: Even if knowledge is to be inferred, its validity is not seen merely from the inference of knowledge.

analyzed: tat hi jñāta tayā vyavahāreṇa kāryeṇa vā anumātavyam
translated: For that must be inferred either by the usage of being known or by the effect.

analyzed: na ca tāvatā prāmāṇyam anumātum śakyate
translated: And by that alone, its validity cannot be inferred.

analyzed: vyabhicārāt
translated: Because of deviation.

original: tato jñātatādimātreṇa pratīte jñāne bādhābhāvādinā prāmāṇyamanumeyam /
analyzed: tatas jñāta tā ādi mātreṇa pratīte jñāne bādhā bhāva ādinā prāmāṇyam anumeyam
translated: Therefore, when knowledge is cognized merely by being known, etc., its validity is to be inferred by the absence of contradiction, etc.

analyzed: anyathā bāhyānām api vaidika jñāna prāmāṇya anumāna prasakteḥ  prasaktam api apodyate iti ced
translated: Otherwise, even outsiders would be forced to infer the validity of Vedic knowledge.🔽If it is argued that even what is forced is rejected,

analyzed: tarhi apavāda nirāsāya parīkṣā apekṣā vaśyambhāvinī iti āgatam
translated: then it becomes necessary to depend on examination in order to remove the exception.

analyzed: idam eva ca asmābhiḥ abhidhāsyate
translated: And this very thing will be stated by us.

analyzed: sarvathā parīkṣā anapekṣā iti tu na kṣamyate
translated: But it is not acceptable that it is completely independent of examination.

analyzed: etena sākṣi vedya tā pakṣaḥ pi pratikṣiptaḥ
translated: By this, the view that it is to be known by the witness is also refuted.

analyzed: aupaniṣada jñāna dṛṣṭi mātreṇa bāhyaiḥ tad prāmāṇyasya adarśanāt
translated: Because outsiders do not see its validity merely by the vision of the knowledge of the Upanishads.

analyzed: caturtha pakṣaḥ tu ati mandaḥ
translated: But the fourth view is very weak.

analyzed: anumāna ādi jñāna dṛṣṭi mātreṇa tad prāmāṇyasya cārvāka ādibhiḥ adṛṣṭa tvāt  vibhāge māna abhāvāt ca
translated: Because the Cārvākas and others do not see the validity of that [perception] merely by the knowledge seen through inference, etc.

analyzed: dharmi jñāna ādi prāmāṇye vigāna abhāvāt iti ced na
translated: And because there is no means of valid knowledge for distinguishing [the validity of perception].🔽If it is argued that it is because there is no distinction in the validity of the knowledge of the object, etc., that is not so.

analyzed: nirālambana ādi mata darśanāt
translated: Because they see [the validity of perception] as being without an object, etc.

original: upapattibādhitaṃ taditi cet /🔽tarhi svīkṛtā'pyuṣmataiva parīkṣāpekṣetyalaṃ pallaveneti / /
analyzed: upapatti bādhitam tat iti ced  tarhi svīkṛtā api uṣmatā eva parīkṣā apekṣā iti alam pallavena iti
translated: If it is argued that that [perception] is contradicted by reasoning,🔽then even though accepted, the heat [of the fire] depends on examination. So let there be enough of this trifling [argument].

analyzed: evam tarhi prāmāṇyam parīkṣā apekṣa grahaṇam eva aṅgīkriyatām
translated: If that is so, then like perception, etc., let the validity of the witness be accepted as depending on examination.

analyzed: dvidhā kalpanasya anyāyya tvāt iti atas āha niyamena iti
translated: Because it is unreasonable to assume it in two ways. Thus, he says necessarily [in the next verse].

analyzed: niyamena sukha ādyeṣu prāmāṇyam sākṣi gocaram
translated: The validity of the witness with regard to pleasure, etc. is necessarily seen.

original: dṛśyata iti vartate /🔽sākṣī gocaro yasya tattathoktam /
analyzed: dṛśyate iti vartate  sākṣī gocaraḥ yasya tat tathā uktam
translated: Is seen is understood.🔽That which has the witness as its object is said to be that way.

analyzed: gocara tvam ca āśrayatayā vivakṣitam
translated: And the state of being an object is intended as the basis.

analyzed: sukha ādi viṣaye yat sākṣi gatam prāmāṇyam tat niyamena dṛśyate
translated: The validity that is in the witness with regard to pleasure, etc. is necessarily seen.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

original: yadi vṛttijñānānāmiva sākṣijñānasyāpi prāmāṇyaṃ taddarśanamātreṇa na dṛśyate tadādhikamapi kāraṇaṃ kalpayāmaḥ /
analyzed: yadi vṛtti jñānānām iva sākṣi jñānasya api prāmāṇyam tad darśana mātreṇa na dṛśyate tadā adhikam api kāraṇam kalpayāmaḥ
translated: If the validity of the knowledge of the self were not seen merely by the seeing of it, as in the case of the knowledge of the means of valid knowledge, then we would assume some other cause.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: sukha jñāne dṛṣṭe tad prāmāṇya ajñāna saṃśaya viparyayāṇām kadāpi adarśanāt
translated: Because when the knowledge of pleasure is seen, the non-apprehension, doubt and error regarding its validity are never seen.

analyzed: kalpaka sadbhāve dvidhā kalpanasya adūṣaṇa tvāt iti
translated: And because in the case of the existence of the assumption, the twofold assumption is not a fault.

analyzed: kiñca sākṣi prāmāṇyasya api parīkṣā apekṣa grahaṇa tve navasthā ca syāt
translated: Moreover, if the validity of the self-knowledge also were to be apprehended in dependence on examination, there would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: nanu prāmāṇya grahaṇam abhilaṣatā na anavasthātaḥ bhettum yuktam
translated: But surely, one who desires to apprehend validity should not be compelled to avoid the infinite regress.

analyzed: parīkṣā anavasthā bhāve pi grāhaka anavasthāyāḥ duṣparihara tvāt iti atas āha sva prāmāṇyam iti
translated: Even in the absence of an infinite regress of examination, the infinite regress of the apprehender is difficult to avoid. Therefore he says:

analyzed: sva prāmāṇyam sadā sākṣī paśyati eva su niścayāt
translated: The self-knowledge is always seen by the self-witness with certainty.

analyzed: sākṣī eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The relation is: by the self-witness alone.

analyzed: sadā su niścayāt iti
translated: Always with certainty.

analyzed: parīkṣā an apekṣam eva iti yāvat  etat ca anubhava anyathā anupapattibhyām kalpyate
translated: That is, without dependence on examination.🔽And this is assumed by the non-concomitance with experience.

analyzed: nanu evam sati vṛtti jñānānām paratas prāmāṇyam uktam syāt
translated: If this is so, then the validity of the knowledge of the means of valid knowledge would be said to be extrinsic.

analyzed: jñāna sva rūpasya sākṣi vedya tvāt
translated: Because the nature of knowledge is to be known by the witness.

analyzed: prāmāṇyasya parīkṣā gamya tvāt
translated: Because the validity of knowledge is to be ascertained by examination.

original: tathāca na vilakṣaṇatvāditi yatsvataḥ prāmāṇyamiṣyaṃ tattyaktaṃ syādityata āha jñānasyeti //
analyzed: tathā ca na vilakṣaṇa tvāt iti yat svatas prāmāṇyam iṣyam tat tyaktam syāt iti atas āha jñānasya iti
translated: And thus, if it is accepted that knowledge is self-valid, that would be abandoned. To this he says of knowledge etc.

analyzed: jñānasya grāhakeṇa eva sākṣiṇā māna tā miteḥ
translated: Because the validity of knowledge is ascertained by the same witness that apprehends it,

original: jñānasya grāhakeṇa sākṣiṇaiva jñānasya mānatāyā miteḥ kāraṇātsvataḥprāmāṇyamiṣyata eveti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: jñānasya grāhakeṇa sākṣiṇā eva jñānasya māna tāyāḥ miteḥ kāraṇāt svatas prāmāṇyam iṣyate eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: the connection is that self-validity is accepted because of the reason that the validity of knowledge is ascertained by the same witness that apprehends it.

original: bhavetsvataḥprāmāṇyatyāgo yadi jñānameva sākṣivedyaṃ na prāmāṇyamiti brūmaḥ /
analyzed: bhavet svatas prāmāṇya tyāgaḥ yadi jñānam eva sākṣi vedyam na prāmāṇyam iti brūmaḥ
translated: The abandonment of self-validity would be possible if we said that only knowledge is known by the witness, not validity.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: jñāna vat tat prāmāṇyasya api sākṣi vedya tva abhyupagamāt iti
translated: Because the validity of knowledge is accepted to be known by the witness, just as knowledge is.

original: kimarthaṃ tarhi parīkṣāvaśyambhāvo 'bhyupagamyata ityata āha doṣeti //
analyzed: kimartham tarhi parīkṣā vaśyambhāvaḥ bhyupagamyate iti atas āha doṣa iti
translated: Then why is the necessity of examination accepted? To this he says fault etc.

analyzed: doṣa abhāve pramāṇa tvam
translated: The absence of faults is the validity of knowledge,

analyzed: sākṣiṇā niścita tvam iti vakṣyamāṇam iha api yojyam
translated: which is to be ascertained by the witness. This is to be connected here also.

analyzed: iti prāmāṇyasya iti pada dvayam adhyāhāryam
translated: Of validity - these two words are to be supplied.

original: jñānaṃ gṛhṇansākṣī karaṇadoṣābhāve 'sya prāmāṇyamityeva prāmāṇyaṃ niścinoti /
analyzed: jñānam gṛhṇan sākṣī karaṇa doṣa abhāve sya prāmāṇyam iti eva prāmāṇyam niścinoti
translated: The witness, while apprehending the cognition, ascertains its validity only when there is no defect in the instrument, as 'this is valid'.

analyzed: na tu pramāṇam eva idam iti
translated: But not that 'this is a valid cognition'.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha doṣa abhāvasya iti
translated: What then? Therefore it is said: 'of the absence of defects'.

analyzed: doṣa abhāvasya sākṣiṇā
translated: By the witness,

analyzed: niścita tvam kvacid ca eva svatas prāmāṇyam iṣyate
translated: the certainty of the absence of defects is sometimes accepted as self-validity.

analyzed: parīkṣayā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is 'by examination'.

analyzed: caḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for emphasis.

analyzed: kvacid eva prayojana vaśāt jijñāsāyām jātāyām parīkṣā lābhe ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: only when there is an examination in some cases, when there is a desire to know due to the purpose.

analyzed: doṣa abhāva niścaya arthā parīkṣā na tu prāmāṇya grahaṇa arthā
translated: The examination is for the purpose of ascertaining the absence of defects, not for the purpose of apprehending validity.

analyzed: tat punar jñānam iva sākṣi vedyam eva
translated: Moreover, that is to be known by the witness itself, like the cognition.

analyzed: atas na svatas prāmāṇya parityāgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no abandonment of self-validity, this is the idea.

original: syādetadyadīyaṃ prakriyā pramāṇavatī syānna ca tadastītyata āha ata iti //
analyzed: syāt etat yadi iyam prakriyā pramāṇavatī syāt na ca tat asti iti atas āha atas iti
translated: This may be said: if this procedure were valid, it would not be so. Therefore it is said: 'therefore'.

original: ato na sarvamānānāṃ prāmāṇyaṃ niścitaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: atas na sarva mānānām prāmāṇyam niścitam bhavet
translated: Therefore, the validity of all valid cognitions would not be ascertained.

analyzed: sākṣiṇā niścitam yatra tat prāmāṇya sva lakṣaṇam
translated: Where it is ascertained by the witness, that is the specific characteristic of validity.

original: ata eva hi sarveṣāṃ jñānānāṃ prāmāṇyaṃ prathamato na niścitaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: atas eva hi sarveṣām jñānānām prāmāṇyam prathamatas na niścitam bhavet
translated: For this very reason, the validity of all cognitions would not be ascertained at first.

original: kinnāma yatra yadā parīkṣāsahakṛtena sākṣiṇā prāmāṇyaṃ niścitaṃ bhavati tattadaiva prāmāṇyaṃ svalakṣaṇaṃ prāmāṇyasvarūpamaprāmāṇyaviviktaṃ
analyzed: kinnāma yatra yadā parīkṣā sahakṛtena sākṣiṇā prāmāṇyam niścitam bhavati tat tadā eva prāmāṇyam sva lakṣaṇam prāmāṇya svarūpam aprāmāṇya viviktam
translated: What is the name of that cognition in which, when the validity is ascertained by the witness assisted by the examination, at that very time, the validity, the specific property of the cognition, the nature of validity distinguished from invalidity,

analyzed: prāmāṇyam siddhayati
translated: is established.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

original: yadi sākṣī doṣābhāve pramāṇametaditi prathamaṃ sammugdhaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ gṛhītvā paścājjijñāsāyāṃ🔽satyāṃ parīkṣayā pramāṇamevetyavadhārayatītyeṣā prakriyā nāṅgīkriyeta tadānabhyastaviṣayāṇāṃ
analyzed: yadi sākṣī doṣa abhāve pramāṇam etat iti prathamam sammugdham prāmāṇyam gṛhītvā paścāt jijñāsāyām  satyām parīkṣayā pramāṇam eva iti avadhārayati iti eṣā prakriyā na aṅgīkriyeta tadā anabhyasta viṣayāṇām
translated: If this procedure were not accepted, that the witness first grasps the validity of this as a whole, thinking This is valid, and then, when there is an inquiry,🔽determines it to be valid by examination, then the validity of all cognitions arising from words etc. about objects not already known

original: śabdādinā jātānāṃ sarveṣāmapi jñānānāṃ prathamameva prāmāṇyamavadhāryeta /
analyzed: śabda ādinā jātānām sarveṣām api jñānānām prathamam eva prāmāṇyam avadhāryeta
translated: would have to be determined first of all.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: But this is not the case.

analyzed: tena jānīmaḥ u sti iyam prakriyā iti
translated: Therefore we know that this procedure exists.

original: uktamarthaṃ buddhayārohāya saṅkṣipyāha nahīti //🔽na hi kaścit sukhādyeṣu saṃśayaṃ kurute janaḥ /
analyzed: uktam artham buddhayā ārohāya saṅkṣipya āha nahi iti  na hi kaścid sukha ādyeṣu saṃśayam kurute janaḥ
translated: In order to bring the stated meaning to the mind, he summarizes with No.🔽For no one entertains a doubt regarding pleasure etc.

analyzed: na ca eva akhila mānāni niścinoti akhilaḥ janaḥ
translated: And not all people ascertain all cognitions.

analyzed: tasmāt anubhava ārūḍham kimartham upalapyate
translated: Therefore, why is it spoken of as if it were established by experience?

original: yasmātsukhādyeṣu kaścitsaṃśayaṃ na karoti yasmāccākhilāni vṛttijñānāni darśana eva pramāṇatayākhilo jano na niścinoti tasmātsākṣiprāmāṇyaṃ 🔽parīkṣānapekṣeṇa sākṣiṇaiva gṛhyate /🔽vṛttijñānānāṃ tu tatsāpekṣeṇetyanubhavārūḍhaṃ prameyaṃ kimarthamapalapyate /
analyzed: yasmāt sukha ādyeṣu kaścid saṃśayam na karoti yasmāt ca akhilāni vṛtti jñānāni darśane eva pramāṇa tayā akhilaḥ janaḥ na niścinoti tasmāt sākṣi prāmāṇyam  parīkṣā anapekṣeṇa sākṣiṇā eva gṛhyate  vṛtti jñānānām tu tad sāpekṣeṇa iti anubhava ārūḍham prameyam kimartham apalapyate
translated: Because no one doubts the existence of pleasure etc., and because all people do not ascertain all the knowledge of the modifications only through perception as valid, therefore the validity of the witness is grasped by the witness itself, which does not depend on examination.🔽But the validity of the knowledge of modifications is by one which depends on that. This well-known fact is to be known. Why is it denied?

analyzed: nirnimittam apalapitum na śakyate iti
translated: It cannot be denied without reason.

analyzed: na parīkṣā anavasthā syāt
translated: There would be no infinite regress of examination.

analyzed: iti uktam upasaṃharati doṣa abhāva ādikam ca iti
translated: Having said this, he concludes with and the absence of faults etc.

analyzed: doṣa abhāva ādikam ca eva sākṣī samyak prapaśyati
translated: And the witness truly sees the absence of faults etc.

analyzed: sākṣī eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is only the witness.

original: svasya parīkṣāyāśca doṣābhāvaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ ca parīkṣānirapekṣaḥ sākṣyeva samyak prapaśyati /
analyzed: svasya parīkṣāyāḥ ca doṣa abhāvam prāmāṇyam ca parīkṣā nirapekṣaḥ sākṣī eva samyak prapaśyati
translated: The absence of faults in itself and in the examination, and the validity, the witness itself truly sees without depending on examination.

analyzed: tasmāt na kā api anavasthā iti
translated: Therefore there is no infinite regress at all.

analyzed: aparīkṣitam eva
translated: Even without examination.

analyzed: ityādinā uktam upasaṃharati tat iti
translated: Having said this etc., he concludes with that etc.

original: tat parīkṣitamānena na doṣo viṣṇavi kvacit // / / //
analyzed: tat parīkṣita mānena na doṣaḥ viṣṇavi kvacid
translated: That, being examined by valid means of knowledge, there is no fault anywhere in Vishnu.

analyzed: tat tasmāt parīkṣitam eva mānam
translated: That, therefore, the valid means of knowledge is only what is examined.

original: tena ca bhagavati kvacidapi doṣo nāstīti siddham /
analyzed: tena ca bhagavati kvacid api doṣaḥ na asti iti siddham
translated: And by that it is established that there is no fault in the Blessed One at all.

analyzed: tad virodhāt aparīkṣitam doṣa darśanam apramāṇam eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the perception of faults, which is not examined, is not a valid means of knowledge because it contradicts that.

original: evamaparīkṣitaṃ doṣadarśanaṃ parīkṣitena nirdeṣatādarśanena bādhitaṃ na bhagavato doṣitvaṃ sādhayituṃ śaktamityuktam /
analyzed: evam aparīkṣitam doṣa darśanam parīkṣitena nirdeṣa tā darśanena bādhitam na bhagavataḥ doṣi tvam sādhayitum śaktam iti uktam
